headline: After Hurricane Sandy Wreaked Havoc, A Changed Perspective
text: It is fair to say Takashi Fujimoto has an independent streak. As an artistic young man growing up in postwar Hiroshima, Japan, during the grim years after the 1945 nuclear blast, he dreamed of leaving home to pursue his love of photography and escape the rigid expectations of what he termed a very conservative society.

headline: Politics and a Ruptured Tendon Don’t Faze Lead Iran Negotiator
text: WASHINGTON — On her way to brief highly skeptical members of Congress about the deal she was still negotiating in secretive talks with the Iranians, Wendy Sherman, the State Department’s No. 3 official and its lead negotiator with Tehran, fell and ruptured a tendon in her finger. She packed it in ice, went to a secure room, and continued her briefing on uranium enrichment levels and current intelligence about the intentions of America’s longtime adversary. Only then did she head to the emergency room.

headline: For Fordham, a Special Season Lives On
text: Reminders of the glory days of Fordham football are everywhere. The famed Seven Blocks of Granite are honored with a monument erected in 2008. Vince Lombardi, a guard on that unit and later a renowned coach, will forever be celebrated as a towering figure in the university’s history.

headline: A Rustic Paradise, Open for Development
text: GUADALUPE VALLEY, Mexico — The doors were locked. The lights were out. When Hugo D’Acosta and 60 of his neighbors reached Ensenada City Hall after being tipped off to a nighttime vote that would open their beloved wine region to Florida-style housing and golf courses, they had to shout just to get in.

headline: Traffic Agent Is Fatally Struck in Manhattan
text: A traffic enforcement agent was struck and killed by an industrial street-cleaning truck amid throngs of holiday shoppers in Midtown Manhattan on Saturday in what officials said was most likely an accident.

headline: Thanksgiving Openings Take Sales From Black Friday
text: Shoppers who braved the sales on Black Friday may have wondered at the size of the crowds. Did they seem a bit smaller than in years past?

headline: Knicks Find Solace in Quality of Losses
text: DENVER — The mood lifted in the Knicks’ locker room after Friday night’s game here. Raymond Felton said that they had “turned this thing around.” Carmelo Anthony said he could sense “the trust in one another out there.” J. R. Smith seemed relieved that the Knicks were “getting over the hump.”

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Nov. 29, 2013
text: A lot of iconic companies in the tech sector like H.P., Cisco and Blackberry have been struggling recently. This week on Money Talking, regular contributors Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine consider if the challenges are the result of problems at the company or external forces. Are these tech companies canaries in the coal mine for an impending stock market correction? Also, a look ahead to a Supreme Court case involving Halliburton, and how sanctions being lifted in Iran could affect that country’s economy.

headline: One Second Dooms No. 1 Alabama
text: AUBURN, Ala. — A football dynasty died Saturday, or at least went comatose.

headline: Lopez Helps Nets Defeat Depleted Grizzlies
text: MEMPHIS — While the Nets have tried to correct their early-season tailspin, they have hesitated to use injuries too often as an excuse. In professional sports, it can be considered unbecoming to do so.

headline: Paul F. Crouch, Who Built Evangelical TV Network, Dies at 79
text: Paul F. Crouch, a television evangelist who founded the Trinity Broadcasting Network with his wife and turned it into the world’s largest Christian television network, died on Saturday. He was 79.

headline: Thai Protests Turn Volatile as at Least 3 Are Shot Dead
text: BANGKOK — The week-old campaign of antigovernment protests in Thailand entered a dangerous new phase on Sunday after shootings involving rival political camps left at least three people dead and more than 110 wounded in Bangkok.

headline: In Areas Where Children Die Young, Family Planning Is a Hard Sell
text: Nairobi, Kenya There are a variety of reasons why women in traditional or less-developed societies give birth to many children: religious, cultural, economic, status and lack of adequate information. But one reason that seems so obvious once you think about it — but which seldom tops the list — is the fear that the children they do bear might not survive.

headline: Focus Turns to Investigation in Fatal Bronx Train Crash
text: The 5:54 from Poughkeepsie was rumbling through the Bronx on Sunday morning. Only 100 to 150 people were onboard — department store employees who were bracing for another busy after-Thanksgiving day, tourists from Texas who wanted to climb the Statue of Liberty, a police officer moonlighting as a security guard on his day off.

headline: Inflationistas at Bayes
text: I’m putting together a syllabus for one of the courses I’ll be teaching this spring – Econ 348, The Great Recession – and in the course of searching for various views about inflation, ended up looking at a dispute from a while back involving some of the usual suspects. Brad DeLong poked fun at John Cochrane for having declared, back in 2009, that “the danger now is inflation.” Cochrane angrily denied that this was of any significance – he only said that it was a danger, he didn’t necessarily predict that it would happen within any particular time frame. (He thereby provided a demonstration of another key fact about our economic debate: nobody ever admits that they were wrong about anything, and nobody changes views in the light of evidence.) Noah Smith, characteristically, tried to find some extenuating circumstances. Etc., etc.

headline: China Launches Moon Rover Mission
text: HONG KONG — China’s latest display of ambition in space involves sending a Jade Rabbit roaming across the Bay of Rainbows.

headline: God Didn’t Make Little Green Arrows
text: Actually, they’re little blue arrows here. In any case George Evans reminds me of paper (pdf) he and co-authors published in 2008 about stability and the liquidity trap, which he later used to explain what was wrong with the Kocherlakota notion (now discarded, but still apparently defended by Williamson) that low rates cause deflation.

headline: After Worst Year With Yanks, Hughes Is Said to Reach Deal With Twins
text: In early September, when Phil Hughes was at the end of a seven-game losing streak with his season’s earned run average above 5.00, his Yankees career all but over, it was easy to forget that he once had a bright future as a major league pitcher.

text: KIEV, Ukraine — Enraged by a violent crackdown by security forces, Ukrainians took to the streets with new, revolutionary urgency on Sunday, with hundreds of thousands of protesters demanding the resignation of President Viktor F. Yanukovich and a realignment of the country away from Russia toward Europe.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (BET, Centric) 2013 SOUL TRAIN AWARDS Dionne Warwick, above, is honored with the Legend Award, and Keith Sweat for lifetime achievement, at this 26th annual ceremony, taped Nov. 8 at the Orleans Arena in Las Vegas and hosted by Anthony Anderson. Jennifer Hudson is joined by Chaka Khan, Evelyn (Champagne) King and T. I. for a medley featuring Ms. Hudson’s new single, “I Can’t Describe.” Gladys Knight, Ronald Isley, Eric Benét, Ruben Studdard, Kenny Lattimore, Bobby V, Chrisette Michele, Eddie Levert, David Foster, Candice Glover and Debbie Allen will take the stage in honor of Ms. Warwick; Mr. Sweat will perform some of his hits with Faith Evans. Warren G., Doug E. Fresh, Slick Rick and Big Daddy Kane will salute the show’s ’90s theme.

headline: Blasts Kill at Least 12 Mourners at Funeral of Iraq Sunni Leader
text: BAGHDAD — Three blasts struck mourners at a funeral in northern Iraq on Sunday, killing at least 12 people and wounding 42, security officials and medical workers said.

headline: Spurs Tie United, and Perhaps Spare Their Manager
text: If professional pride and strong defiance can save the neck of a soccer team manager, then Tottenham Hotspur might just have made its point against Manchester United on Sunday.

text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo spoke to reporters after a Metro-North train derailed in the Bronx. Edward S. Kilduff, the Fire Department’s chief of department, described the rescue efforts.

text: LOS ANGELES — Billboards that buried the princesses in snow. TV ads that emphasized action and screwball comedy while playing down romance and sisterhood. Trailers that concealed the Broadway-style musical numbers.

headline: A Band With Some History Brings Heft to the New Place in Brooklyn
text: Rough Trade Records garnered some New York City cachet when it presented Television at the intimate club attached to the record store on Friday and Saturday nights. Rough Trade, a London institution since the punk era, opened its outpost in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Nov. 25. The club, with a capacity of 300, is very promising: a high-ceilinged box with utilitarian industrial décor, clear sightlines, a balcony and, for Television, the superbly clear sound that the music demands.

text: Before one of the wilder Saturdays in college football unfolded, the narrative for the Bowl Championship Series title game seemed relatively set.

headline: Flying Bodies, Broken Bones and Screams After Cars Leave the Track
text: Dull thuds pulsed through the eight cars of the Metro-North Hudson line train, jolting passengers from an early-morning doze or from the Christmas carols or pop tunes playing on their iPods.

headline: ‘Mob City’ Uses Twitter to Build Suspense for a Premiere
text: POPULAR shows like “The Walking Dead,” “The Voice” and “Scandal” have consistently figured in the weekly top 10 list for Nielsen Twitter TV Ratings, a new statistic that professes to measure not just the number of Twitter posts about shows but also the number of followers who read them. Now “Mob City,” a new TNT series about Los Angeles mobsters in the 1940s, has a stunt that hopes to build fans on Twitter before its premiere on Wednesday.

headline: Wage Strikes Planned at Fast-Food Outlets
text: Seeking to increase pressure on McDonald’s, Wendy’s and other fast-food restaurants, organizers of a movement demanding a $15-an-hour wage for fast-food workers say they will sponsor one-day strikes in 100 cities on Thursday and protest activities in 100 additional cities.

headline: Ebenezer Sharpens Sarcasm for Today
text: When Ebenezer Scrooge first appeared onstage, I thought: This guy is from Los Angeles. He probably works in the movie business.

headline: A Warm and Fuzzy Grandpa? Well, Not Exactly
text: We already know that grandpas can be bad, thanks to “Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa,” a Johnny Knoxville movie released in October in which an old man does all kinds of psychic damage to his 8-year-old grandson. But that bad grandpa was a model citizen compared with the bad grandpa in “Rick and Morty,” a blistering, demented animated series that begins Monday night on Adult Swim.

headline: The Fantasy That Teaches Children to Be Grown-Ups
text: As is traditional on the day after Thanksgiving, New York City Ballet turned on Friday to tree worship. The children in “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker,” as it’s billed, rise up, arms outstretched toward the onstage Christmas tree, and seem to be pulled in by the tinsel and lights. They leap up and down in front of it like teenagers idolizing a pop star. And that’s before the tree, already massive, grows three times as large.

headline: Jets Flop in Their Third Straight Loss
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Matt Simms did not jog onto the field after halftime Sunday. He sprinted. Sprinted into a game that bore only a faint resemblance to football, into a huddle that no longer belonged to Geno Smith, into a quarterback mess that has become a Jets specialty.

headline: ArcelorMittal Deal for Plant Signals Faith in a Recovery
text: LONDON — ArcelorMittal’s acquisition of an ailing rival’s steel plant in Alabama signals confidence in the economic recovery and may herald a resurgence of deal-making by ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, its chief executive suggested on Sunday.

headline: Covent Garden Alumnae Shine in a New Flower Patch
text: BRISTOL, England — What happens to star dancers who, after ascending to glory with one ballet company, take control of their own destinies and head off to pastures new? In the first half of 2013, the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden lost two of its most admired ballerinas, Tamara Rojo and Alina Cojocaru. Ms. Rojo — a Spanish dancer, now in her late 30s, whose best performances are characterized by intelligence and drama — left for a good reason: She is now artistic director of English National Ballet, where she continues to dance leading roles.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Dec. 2
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: The High Times, and the Hard Ones, of a Gritty Musical Outlaw
text: Johnny Cash’s life was a country song full of love and loss, passion and heartbreak — grief, loneliness, guilt, faith, melodrama and striving for redemption. His rough childhood and youth, and turbulent struggles with addiction and family tumult, gave him empathy for sinners in search of salvation and all those who had done hard time or known hard times. His plain-spoken writing and gritty, soul-deep singing transcended musical genres and gave voice to ordinary Americans’ experience of adversity. He was that rare outlaw beloved by soldiers and student protesters alike, by rock ’n’ rollers, convicts and devotees of Billy Graham’s crusades.

headline: Arts Dean Redefines Her Mission
text: Because Mary Schmidt Campbell has held so many high-profile positions in New York’s cultural world, she has long chosen to be somewhat politic about sharing her personal views.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Dec. 2
text: INSIDER TRADING TRIAL The trial of Michael S. Steinberg, one of Steven A. Cohen’s closest associates at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, will continue this week in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The trial, which recessed last Wednesday afternoon for Thanksgiving, will resume Monday with the former SAC analyst Jon Horvath on the stand. Mr. Horvath, who pleaded guilty to securities fraud charges in September 2012, is an important witness in the insider trading case against Mr. Steinberg. Mr. Horvath used to report to him at SAC.

headline: Lights, Mirrors, Instagram! #ArtSensation
text: Adam Friedman emerged from the twinkling lights and reflecting water of Yayoi Kusama’s “infinity room” and groped for the right words. “Ethereal,” he said. Pause. “Calming.” Another pause. “Calming, ethereal and meditative, all at the same time.”

headline: In Three Symphonies, the Demands of Mozart
text: Though Mozart wrote his final three symphonies, astonishingly, in a six-week burst in the summer of 1788, he would never have considered them a unit. It was not until long after his death that performing the three together became fashionable; it is now a commonplace.

headline: Macho Hero and His Sidekick Shoot ’Em Up in a Crooked India
text: Like many Hindi movies, “Bullett Raja” paints India as a swamp of corruption. But where some films treat the broken system as a spur for moral outrage, this bromantic shoot-’em-up, directed by Tigmanshu Dhulia, treats it as little more than a colorful backdrop for action with plenty of ready-made villains.

headline: On Beauty | For Women, a New Look Down Under
text: After years of razors, wax and lasers reducing pubic hair to the bare minimum — or nothing at all — there’s a return to a more natural state.

headline: Updated Presley Exhibit Features Graceland Items
text: An updated Elvis Presley exhibit at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland has opened featuring more than 40 artifacts on loan from his Graceland Mansion in Memphis, The Associated Press reported. Highlights include a 1975 custom-made “SuperTrike” motorcycle; a selection of Presley’s jewelry, like a walnut-size 41-carat ruby-and-diamond ring and a 25.5-carat opal ring; and a white suit he wore during the NBC special “Elvis” in 1968. Presley was among the first class of artists to be inducted into the hall of fame, in 1986.

headline: Rest in Peace, Elwood, ‘World’s Ugliest Dog’
text: A mixed breed dog named Elwood (below), who was named the “World’s Ugliest Dog” in 2007 and inspired his owner to write a children’s book about self-acceptance, has died, The Associated Press reported. He was 8 years old. Karen Quigley, 52, of Sewell, N.J., adopted Elwood, a dark-colored, nearly hairless Chinese crested and Chihuahua mix, after a breeder decided that he was too ugly to sell and would euthanize him. His odd appearance, which included heavy eyelids, a protruded tongue that hung out the side of his mouth and a white tuft of hair on his head, was a hit at the Sonoma-Marin County Fair in California, where the ugly dog contest is held. The experience motivated Ms. Quigley to write and self-publish a children’s book that promoted acceptance called “Everybody Loves Elwood.” The dog later developed an online following, being referred to as Yoda or E.T. by his fans. Elwood appeared at more than 200 events to help raise money for animal rescue groups and nonprofit animal organizations.

headline: A First for Sotheby’s: An Auction in Beijing
text: Sotheby’s held its first commercial auction in mainland China on Sunday, when an oil painting by Zao Wou-ki, “Abstraction,” sold for $14.7 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for one of his works, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Fall North American Championships Winners
text: PHOENIX — The first national titles at the 10-day Fall North American Championships were decided here on Saturday evening. The Nail Life Master Pairs was captured by Curtis Cheek of Las Vegas and Ishmael Del’Monte from Australia. They finished more than a board ahead of Kevin Bathurst of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., and Bobby Levin of Henderson, Nev. Third were Boye Brogeland and Espen Lindqvist from Norway.

headline: Transition Year for the General Manager Is a Fragile One for the Coach
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was late in the second quarter when Geno Smith dropped back to pass and it became all too apparent that he really needed to sit. With the Jets trailing by 3-0, he was in the end zone, trying to pitch out of a third-and-8 from their 3.

headline: Sex and the Single Priest
text: AMONG the teaching nuns at St. Matthew’s Catholic School, Sister Mary Robert was my favorite. She was young, not yet 30, with a gentle face framed by the starched white wimple. She tamed a classroom of hormone-dizzy eighth graders by making us want to please her. We offered up our compositions and our ventures in iambic pentameter, and were rewarded with encouragement that, at least in my case, never wore off.

headline: Insurers Claim Health Website Is Still Flawed
text: Weeks of frantic technical work appear to have made the government’s health care website easier for consumers to use. But that does not mean everyone who signs up for insurance can enroll in a health plan.

headline: A Swedish Retailer Promises a Living Wage
text: H&M, the Swedish retailer known for inexpensive yet hip clothes, said last week that it wants to ensure that workers who make its T-shirts and jeans are paid a living wage. If it achieves that admirable and ambitious goal, the company could go a long way toward improving the lives of thousands of poor workers in developing countries.

headline: Gloomy Numbers for Holiday Shopping’s Big Weekend

headline: Debt and Taxes
text: The debacle of the housing bust is not over. In addition to 10 million borrowers who have already lost their homes, nearly nine million still owe some $500 billion more on their mortgages than their homes are worth and, of them, 2.3 million are in or near foreclosure.

headline: Shiffrin Misses a Giant Slalom Win by a Sliver
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — The night before having the best giant slalom result of her career, a second-place finish here Sunday, Mikaela Shiffrin made a musical mix of two songs: “Battle Scars” by Lupe Fiasco and “The Scientist” by Coldplay.

headline: In the East China Sea, a Far Bigger Test of Power Looms
text: WASHINGTON — In an era when the Obama administration has been focused on new forms of conflict — as countries use cyberweapons and drones to extend their power — the dangerous contest suddenly erupting over a pile of rocks in the East China Sea seems almost a throwback to the Cold War.

headline: André Schiffrin, Publishing Force and a Founder of New Press, Is Dead at 78
text: André Schiffrin, a publishing force for 50 years, whose passion for editorial independence produced shelves of serious books, a titanic collision with a conglomerate that forced him out to stem losses, and a late-in-life comeback as a nonprofit publisher, died in Paris on Sunday. He was 78.

headline: The New Mayor and the Teachers
text: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio will take office facing the need to forge new labor agreements with the unions that represent nearly all of New York City’s 300,000 municipal workers. The largest of these, the United Federation of Teachers, is in a particularly sour mood. Representing 40 percent of the city’s work force, the union has been without a contract since 2009.

headline: 3 General Managers True to One School
text: If becoming a baseball general manager is to be accepted into an old boys’ club, then the annual general managers meetings are their grand convention. The executives spend a few days each off-season sitting through presentations and talking baseball, ending each night with big dinners and drinks at the hotel bar until it closes. Then they do it all again, only bigger, at the winter meetings a few weeks later.

headline: For 22 Years, Caught in a Murder Case’s Tangled Web

headline: Paul Walker, 40, Star of ‘Fast and Furious’ Movies, Dies in Crash
text: Paul Walker, an actor best known for his role in the “Fast and the Furious” movies about street racing, died on Saturday in Valencia, Calif., when the Porsche he was riding in crashed in a single-car accident and burst into flames. He was 40.

headline: Natalya Gorbanevskaya, Soviet Dissident and Poet, Dies at 77
text: Natalya Gorbanevskaya, a Russian dissident and poet who defied Soviet authorities by starting an influential underground publication and protesting the Soviet Union’s 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia, died on Friday at her home in Paris. She was 77.

headline: Willis Ware, 93, Engineer at Dawn of Computer Age, Dies
text: Willis H. Ware, an electrical engineer who in the late 1940s helped build a machine that would become a blueprint for computer design in the 20th century, and who later played an important role in defining the importance of personal privacy in the information age, died on Nov. 22 at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 93.

headline: Long on Cutting Edge of Print, New York Magazine Cuts Back

headline: Merchandise Uses Olympics Principles Against Russian Anti-Gay Laws

The supporters of an effort to help lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender citizens of Russia, where the Winter Games are to be held in February, are adapting that marketing tactic with a line of protest merchandise to be sold by American Apparel and promoted by athletes.

headline: In Olympic Sochi, a Photographic Pregame

Since its odyssey began in Moscow, the torch has been carried by foot, on trains, planes and troikas, taken to the North Pole via icebreaker and into lower Earth orbit on a Soyuz rocket.

headline: In New Tactic, Thai Police Lower Shields and Open Buildings to Protesters

Riot police officers cleared away barbed wire, put down their shields and opened the doors to a police compound that the protesters had vowed to besiege.

headline: The Making of the ‘Three Strikes’ Laws
text: After the 1993 murder of a child, many states passed laws to lock up repeat offenders for life, but today those laws are raising new questions about how crime is handled in America.

headline: Born of Grief, ‘Three Strikes’ Laws Are Being Rethought
text: This week’s Retro Report video is a story of how personal tragedy led to what has been called one of the harshest criminal laws in the country, California’s “three strikes” law. Intended to lock up the most violent repeat offenders for 25 years to life, the law was almost immediately embroiled in controversy. For an examination of the effects of California’s three strikes law, watch the video above. Below, a former Bay Area bureau chief for The Times recalls the case that galvanized the proposition drive for the law.

headline: How I Found a Surprisingly Good Health Plan
text: I’ve written four posts on health insurance recently, and there are more to come. I have been trying to get a sense of what I am buying, of how many options I have to consider, of how much it will cost and of how I can explain my choices to my workers. This has been extraordinarily complex.

headline: Amid Unrest, Ukrainian President Defends Choice on Accords
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Even as thousands of protesters occupied Independence Square, blockaded the Cabinet Ministry and continued to demand his resignation, President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine on Monday defended his refusal to sign accords with the European Union, said he was on the verge of securing lower gas prices from Russia, and urged opposition politicians to wait for presidential elections in 2015 to challenge him.

headline: A Dalit Village Waits Uneasily for Justice
text: The night a horde of men crossed over the nearby river and killed Mahendra Chaudhary and 57 of his villagers in the low-caste Dalit hamlet of Lakshmanpur Bathe in Bihar, he was probably having dinner with his family of six like any other day. If not dinner, he could have been cuddling his children, say his neighbors.

headline: Hilton Says It Plans to Raise Up to $2.4 Billion in I.P.O.
text: Hilton Worldwide disclosed on Monday that it planned to raise up to $2.4 billion in its upcoming initial public offering, in what would be one of the biggest stock sales of the year.

headline: Taking Questions on How to Negotiate Family Conflict
text: Our new Ask an Expert features Sheila Heen, an expert in the field of conflict negotiation, who will answer reader questions about how to resolve disputes in families and businesses: from who is hosting the holiday party to how to tell your employees there is no year-end bonus. It’s a month for difficult conversations.

headline: Metro-North Train Sped at 82 M.P.H. Ahead of Curve in Fatal Crash
text: The Metro-North Railroad train that hurtled off the rails on a sleepy holiday weekend morning was traveling 82 miles per hour as it approached one of the sharpest curves in the region’s rail system, federal investigators said on Monday — nearly three times the speed permitted through the turn.

headline: Citigroup’s Low-Key Chief
text: Michael L. Corbat has kept a relatively low profile since taking the helm of Citigroup in October 2012. And that appears to be just fine with the bank he runs, Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook.

headline: A Whiter Shade of Envy
text: MOSCOW — In Russian, envy comes in two colors: black and white. The former is mean and resentful: “It should be me, not you.” The latter is aspirational: “I want to be you.” “Black envy” affirms a despondent world view; “white envy” affords a hopeful one.

headline: UBS to Buy Back Bonds to Reduce Balance Sheet and Expenses
text: LONDON – The Swiss bank UBS said on Monday that it planned to buy back 1.75 billion euros, or about $2.37 billion, in bonds as part of an effort to reduce the size of its balance sheet and its future interest expense.

headline: Benghazification Begins
text: Healthcare.gov is much better. It’s not running like, say, Amazon — but remember, mainly the government is trying to give you money, namely subsidized insurance, rather than to sell you something, so it doesn’t have to match commercial performance right away. There are still serious problems with the back end — the delivery of information to insurers. But the site is no longer a laughingstock, it’s going to get better, and a lot of people are going to sign up by the time open enrollment ends on March 31.

text: After months of silence on the issue, acclaimed Chinese film director Zhang Yimou has admitted to having two sons and a daughter with his current wife, in contravention of China’s family planning rules.

headline: Doing Macro First
text: Mike Konczal makes a very good point about how we teach economics. He suggests that we should go back to the way Samuelson did it in 1948 — macroeconomics first, then micro. This, he suggests, would give students a better perspective on reality, even though all the same material would eventually be covered.

text: From tree houses to caves, nothing is off limits to hoteliers who think outside-the-box these days. Joining the increasing number of unusual accommodations popping up in the world is a stand-alone suite floating in the Indian Ocean, just off the coast of Tanzania in Africa, with a bedroom that offers views below the water, as well as above.

headline: Insurgents Strike in Major Nigerian City
text: LONDON — The authorities in northeastern Nigeria imposed a 24-hour curfew around the region’s main city on Monday after Islamic militants staged an audacious attack apparently aimed at a government air base, news reports said, describing the assault as among the most dramatic in the insurgents’ campaign to create an Islamic state.

headline: Vitamin D Fails to Ease Winter Coughs and Colds

headline: Fines, Without Explaining How They Were Calculated
text: A standard part of enforcement actions against companies these days is the multimillion-dollar – or even multibillion-dollar – penalty. What can be perplexing is figuring out how those penalties were determined, and whether they have much if any direct relationship to either the gains realized from the violations or the harm inflicted.

text: LONDON – A European financial watchdog on Monday left open the door for regulatory action after it said it discovered a series of “shortcomings” in how the major rating agencies assess risk to sovereign debt.

headline: A Foreign-Language Race Up for Grabs
text: Updated, 2:31 p.m. | After two consecutive years in which the Oscar winner for best foreign-language film seemed a foregone conclusion even before the awards season started, this year’s contest has the potential to be fiercely competitive. The field is diverse, and there are many strong entries, but no single film stands out the way that “Amour,” directed by the Austrian Michael Haneke, did last time, or as “A Separation,” directed by the Iranian Asghar Farhadi, did in 2012. That promises to make the next few months nerve-racking for filmmakers and distributors, but enjoyable for foreign film buffs.

headline: ‘Pippin’ Revival Recoups Investment
text: “You’re on the right track,” the Leading Player sings to the title character in the 1972 musical “Pippin,” and the same can be said of the Tony Award-winning Broadway revival. The producers announced on Monday that the show has recouped its $8.5 million capitalization after about eight months of performances. Only 25 percent of Broadway productions recoup their investors’ money and go on to earn profits.

headline: Cod Ceviche
text: Ceviche makes a light, satisfying meal. I like to serve it over a bed of spinach. You can begin the dish in the morning and the fish will be ready by dinnertime.

Ms. Kang assigned the photo shoot that resulted in that much-discussed image of an Israeli woman’s upper torso, including incision scars, a portion of her areola and her Star of David tattoo. Compassion!”), the producers announced on Monday. Directed by Sheryl Kaller (“Next Fall”), “Mothers and Sons” will begin previews Feb. 23 and open on March 24.

headline: Michael Tilson Thomas to Fill In for Philadelphia Orchestra Conductor
text: A severe sinus condition has sidelined the conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the Philadelphia Orchestra announced on Monday, but created an opportunity for New Yorkers to hear an unusual pairing of conductor and orchestra. Michael Tilson Thomas, the music director of the San Francisco Symphony, will fill in for Mr. Nézet-Séguin, in Philadelphia on Dec. 5, 7 and 8 and at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 6. Mr. Thomas made his subscription debut in Philadelphia only in 2008 (though he led the orchestra in summer concerts as far back as 1971), and returned in 2011. But he has never been heard with the Philadelphians in New York.

headline: Yanks Trade a Catcher to the Pirates
text: Chris Stewart had a unique feeling in April. It was the first time he had begun a second consecutive season with the same team, working with the same pitching staff and following the instructions from the same manager and coaches. It was a good feeling, he said, but it turned out to be fleeting.

headline: Canadian Opera Commissions New Work From Rufus Wainwright
text: Rufus Wainwright’s experience in the opera world may have seemed bruising to an observer. His first opera, “Prima Donna,” was commissioned by the Metropolitan Opera and Lincoln Center, but the Met withdrew when Mr. Wainwright insisted on writing in French instead of English; and though it was performed around the world, and by the New York City Opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was beat upon by critics for the thinness of its plot.

headline: Words That Wound
text: People may feel ashamed or afraid to talk about abuse, including the verbal kind, so the researchers from Northeastern University asked their older subjects to respond to questions by touching a computer screen. It gave them more privacy.

headline: The Read Around: Carla Kaplan
text: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Below, Carla Kaplan, the author of “Miss Anne in Harlem: The White Women of the Black Renaissance,” talks about her research habits, why this project took longer to write than she expected, and how being a white woman in the field of black studies helped her sympathize with the people in her book.

headline: Economists Are Different From You and Me
text: The newly minted Nobel laureate Robert Shiller reported in a 1997 paper, based on polling data, that economists worry much less about inflation than does the general public. The poll asked, for example, whether “preventing high inflation is an important national priority, as important as preventing drug abuse or preventing deterioration in the quality of our schools.” Eighty-four percent of Americans agreed but, among economists, only 46 percent agreed.

headline: Image Mysteries and Flatiron Glow Sticks
text: December events at the intersection of science and culture.

headline: Sugary Drinks Tied to Endometrial Cancer Risk
text: A new study has found that drinking sugar-sweetened beverages is associated with an increased risk for endometrial cancer in postmenopausal women.

headline: Where Last Season’s Winners Are Still Being Celebrated
text: Campaigns for the 2014 Oscars may have officially kicked off this week, but not everyone is finished discussing the merits of “Argo,” “Silver Linings Playbook” and other contenders from the last awards season.

headline: Biden Faces a Delicate Two-Step in Asia
text: TOKYO — With Japan locked in a tense standoff with China over disputed airspace, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived here late Monday for a weeklong visit to Asia intended to reassure a close ally and demand answers from a potential adversary.

headline: Sam Champion Leaves ‘Good Morning America’ for Weather Channel
text: The leading morning team in television is losing an important contributor with the announcement on Monday that Sam Champion would leave his post as the weather anchor for ABC’s “Good Morning America” to join the Weather Channel.

headline: Parliament in Somalia Votes to Remove Prime Minister
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Somalia’s Parliament voted the prime minister out of office on Monday in a no-confidence motion, with 184 of 249 lawmakers in favor, after what was termed a “constitutional dispute” between the president and the prime minister, Somali officials said.

headline: Amazon’s Blue-Sky Thinking
text: Amazon is promising yet more jam tomorrow – this time from drone deliveries.

headline: After Renting Out a Terrace, He Received an Eviction Notice
text: David Shea, a retired typographer, thought that he was renting out his large enclosed terrace to a visitor from Miami who was looking for a cheap place to stay for a few days in Manhattan. The man had contacted him through Roomorama.com, one of several websites that connect travelers with private hosts.

headline: Nets and Knicks Share Woes and, This Week, a Floor
text: Thursday is the one day of the week when the N.B.A.’s frantic nationwide schedule slows and all eyes turn to a doubleheader showcase on TNT. When the league scheduled this week’s matchup between the Nets and the Knicks, the first of their four meetings this season, it probably expected a game of far more consequence than a meeting of two of the three worst teams in the Eastern Conference.

headline: Healing Soldiers’ Most Exposed Wounds
text: Col. Robert G. Hale fixes faces.

headline: What to Expect at the Gothams
text: The traditional starter’s pistol for the glitzy season in New York is the Gotham Independent Film Awards, taking place tonight at Cipriani Wall Street, with the the comedian Nick Kroll (of “Kroll Show” on Comedy Central), an old Bagger pal, serving as host. Like its West Coast cousin, the Film Independent Spirit Awards, the Gothams are more of a D.I.Y. affair, full of jokes about tight budgets, short shooting schedules and other difficulties of indie filmmaking, an apparently thankless task that nonetheless inspires devotion in the room.

headline: The Great Los Angeles Auto Show Fire of 1929
text: Sunday brought about the end of another chapter in the history of the Los Angeles Auto Show, an event that, aside from 1940 to 1951, has showed off new cars since 1907. This year in the hallway between the two cavernous rooms glinting with new automobiles, there was a long display about the history of the show, bringing to light a bit of trivia.

headline: French Court Orders Criminal Trial for EADS Shareholders
text: PARIS — A French court on Monday ordered the German carmaker Daimler and the French media conglomerate Lagardère to face a criminal trial on allegations of insider trading in the 2006 sale of shares in the European aerospace and defense group EADS.

headline: T HOLIDAY
text: For the Italian fabric designer Idarica Gazzoni, every surface is a blank canvas until she embellishes it with her whimsical patterns.

headline: Rights Group Is Seeking Status of ‘Legal Person’ for Captive Chimpanzee
text: Chimpanzees are not people, no matter how they are dressed up for commercials, but perhaps they are close enough that they deserve some of the same rights humans have.

headline: Reality Checks on Tumorous Rats and Methane Bombs
text: This is a quick roundup of developments and resources illustrating how the most dramatic “front-page thought” or activist talking point is always worth examining from the root up. Or, as Carl Sagan liked to say, “Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.”

headline: In Thailand, a Drone’s Eye View of Protests
text: Thailand’s news media outlets have been increasingly using small, unmanned flying gadgets that give them a bird’s-eye view of the protests in the streets of their capital. As my colleague Thomas Fuller writes, the miniature drones have circulated videos of the battles, including one between riot police outside the prime minister’s office and protesters attacking the barricades.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Visual Editions’ ‘Where You Are’
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: The Gun Report: Thanksgiving Weekend Edition
text: Marissa Alexander, the Florida woman who unsuccessfully argued last year that the state’s Stand Your Ground law made her immune from prosecution after she fired a bullet into a wall in her home to scare off her abusive husband, has been released from prison as she awaits a new trial. Though no one was hurt, she received a 20-year prison sentence. Alexander had argued that she fired a warning shot from a legally licensed gun to defend herself from a beating at the hands of her estranged husband, a man who had testified to abusing her in the past.

headline: Immaculate Stability (Wonkish)
text: David Andolfatto, understandably, rises to Steve Williamson’s defense against the barbarians. But I’m sorry to say that he still doesn’t get the point.

headline: In Surprise Win, Laure Prouvost Takes Turner Prize
text: LONDON — The artist Laure Prouvost, whose works combine whimsical objects and drawings in evocative settings with an Instagram-like stream of film images, has won this year’s Turner Prize, the prestigious and often contentious annual award for a British artist under 50.

headline: Brussels to Investigate Deal for British Nuclear Plant
text: LONDON — European regulators said on Monday that they expected to conduct a full inquiry into a deal to build Britain’s first nuclear power station since 1995, threatening delays that could undermine investment plans for the 16 billion pound project.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 26-Dec. 2, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: New Strides in Spaying and Neutering
text: Todd Bruce, a herd manager on a farm in Oregon City, Ore., had long resisted neutering his 5-year-old Australian cattle dog, Cody, for fear of losing the extra set (or two) of legs in the field.

headline: A First Report Card Fails to ‘Exceed Expectations’
text: Don’t compare yourself to others. Let go of striving and accept the world as it is, not as you’d like it to be. Practice humility and gratitude. Forty-three years, and this is the Buddhist wisdom I’ve learned to embrace, the foundation on which my inner peace rests. Until I got my son’s first report card.

headline: Rare Biblical Texts From Bodleian and Vatican Libraries Digitized
text: A Gutenberg Bible, a dazzlingly illuminated 15th-century Hebrew Bible from Spain and a copy of Maimonides’s 12th-century commentary on the Mishnah written in the philosopher’s own hand are among the rare bibles and biblical commentaries from the Vatican Library and the Bodleian Libraries at Oxford that have been digitized and posted online, as part of a collaboration between the institutions that went live on Tuesday.

headline: As Lundqvist Sits Again, a Hot Hand Turns Cool
text: The Rangers’ goaltender controversy ended almost as quickly as it began. On Monday morning, Coach Alain Vigneault surprisingly named the first-year sensation Cam Talbot to start against the Winnipeg Jets on Monday night at Madison Square Garden. The decision meant a healthy Henrik Lundqvist would sit out a second straight game — which had not happened since February 2011.

headline: Liberal Catholics in the Age of Francis
text: My Sunday column discussed what Catholics on the political right should make of Pope Francis’s latest exhortation, and how they should respond to a papacy that has been emphasizing the church’s social teaching in language that Catholics with free-market views might not necessarily be eager to embrace. The other, equally-interesting question, of course is how Catholics of a more liberal persuasion (politically and theologically) should respond to Francis — or, perhaps more aptly, what they should be looking for, hoping for, and working toward in a pontificate whose tone they mostly find congenial, but whose substance has included reaffirmations of Catholic teaching on some of the culture-war issues dividing left and right.

headline: Justice Department Approves Microsoft Deal
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft got closer on Monday to completing the most significant deal in the company’s history, its $7.2 billion acquisition of Nokia’s mobile handset and services business.

headline: Robots and Property Values
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Searching for Answers After a Fatal Train Accident
text: The derailment was the deadliest in New York City in more than two decades, killing four and leaving dozens injured.

headline: Video of Police Brutality in Kiev Fuels Rage
text: Last Updated, Tuesday, 7:22 p.m. | As my colleague David Herszenhorn reports from Kiev, thousands of opposition protesters demanding the resignation of the Ukrainian government continued to occupy Independence Square in the capital on Monday, two days after images of the police battering demonstrators there backfired on the authorities, swelling the street protests.

headline: Justices Pass on Tax Case From Online Merchants
text: WASHINGTON — The United States Supreme Court on Monday let stand a ruling from New York’s highest court requiring Internet retailers to collect sales taxes even if they have no physical presence in the state.

headline: A Head for Hunting
text: They may be slow, but seahorses can snatch fast prey because of the unusual shape of their heads. Using a microscope outfitted with a laser and high-speed digital camera, researchers from the University of Texas at Austin observed that the area around a dwarf seahorse’s nostrils created a “no-wake zone” in front of its mouth, allowing the animal to sneak up on tiny crustaceans.

headline: Amazon Prime Air
text: Amazon released a video touting its Prime Air delivery service, which makes the use of drones.

headline: Emotion Has Its Place in Financial Planning
text: How many spreadsheets do you have on your computer? I bet a lot of you have at least one or two. There’s probably a budget spreadsheet showing how much you’ve spent, or one where you’ve worked out how much you’ll need in the future. Maybe you even use some budgeting software. Who knew it was so much fun lining up a bunch of numbers?

headline: Learning to Defuse the Aorta
text: When Dr. Hal Dietz arrived at Johns Hopkins University in the 1980s, he became obsessed with helping children with Marfan syndrome, a rare and often fatal disorder that can cause the aorta, the large blood vessel that carries blood from the heart, to grow and grow until it bursts.

headline: Accountant for Princeton Troupe Accused of Embezzling
text: The longtime accountant for Princeton University’s legendary touring musical-comedy troupe, the Triangle Club, has been charged with embezzling more than $100,000 from the club.

headline: Oxytocin Found to Stimulate Social Brain Regions in Children With Autism
text: The hormone oxytocin has been generating excitement — and caution — among people who care about autism.

headline: Bolshoi Music Director Resigns
text: MOSCOW — The music director and top conductor for the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow unexpectedly resigned on Monday, threatening a premiere of Verdi’s “Don Carlos” later this month and undermining efforts the Bolshoi’s leadership to return a stable image to the iconic theater after a year marred by scandal.

headline: In Communal Living, Intimacy’s Logistics
text: Q. How did primitive peoples, like Native Americans who lived in long houses with 20 families, get enough privacy for intimacy and intercourse?

headline: American Brass Quintet Makes Sure It Doesn’t Shrink to a Trio
text: Among North American brass ensembles none is more venerable than the American Brass Quintet, which was founded in 1960 and has been a resident ensemble at the Aspen Music Festival since 1970, and at the Juilliard School since 1987. But rosters change, and the retirement of the trumpeter Raymond Mase and the hornist David Wakefield has created two openings in the quintet in quick succession.

headline: Men at Work for Women in Labor
text: Doulas are trained to help new mothers cope with the rigors of childbirth. The very origins of the word — in Greek, “doula” means “a woman who serves” — seem to settle the question of gender. Doulas are women.

headline: In Performance: Peter Bradbury
text: Peter Bradbury in a scene from Patrick Barlow’s adaptation of Charles Dickens’s “Christmas Carol,” at the Theater at St. Clement’s.

headline: Walkabout: Mishaps in Pet Travel; Cyber Monday Travel Deals
text: Updated, 10:58 a.m. | Not every pet travel story ends happily. One woman reports that her dog was diagnosed with heat stroke, a urinary tract infection and liver problems, following a United flight from Houston to Boston. (NBC Washington)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Thailand, Ukraine, Syria and Gaza.

headline: Uncertainty Comes Fast for Redskins’ Sure Thing
text: LANDOVER, Md. — Antonio Smith Jr. works a merchandise stand at FedEx Field during Washington Redskins games, so he does not get to watch Robert Griffin III play every week. But he has a pretty good feel for how Griffin’s season is going.

headline: Chinese Leader’s Rise Came With New Attention to Dispute With Japan
text: BEIJING — The new air defense zone declared by China appears to have been approved by President Xi Jinping, the culmination of more than a year of pressure by Beijing to weaken Japan’s grip on disputed islands in the East China Sea, and by extension to expand China’s long-term access to the Western Pacific.

headline: Top U.N. Rights Official Links Assad to Crimes in Syria
text: GENEVA — The top United Nations human rights official linked President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to war crimes and crimes against humanity for the first time on Monday, citing evidence collected by her panel of investigators over the course of the 33-month-old conflict in that country.

headline: Building a Cheaper Catalyst
text: The chemical reactions that help produce margarine, medications, cleaner car exhaust and countless other useful things rely on valuable metals like platinum, rhodium and ruthenium as catalysts. But such metals are rare, expensive and occasionally toxic. For years, scientists have tried to develop methods of catalysis using cheap, common, nonpolluting metals like iron and cobalt.

headline: Gunmen Attack Offices of Pakistani Media Group in Karachi
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Unidentified gunmen opened fire on the office of a leading news media group in Karachi on Monday evening, wounding a security guard and underscoring the threats journalists face in the country.

headline: Five Wine Books Worth Noting
text: It’s been a boon literary year for wine lovers. The flow of noteworthy books has been so steady that some seminal works can get lost in the current, like a 25th anniversary edition of “Adventures on the Wine Route,” Kermit Lynch’s prophetic look back at the wisdom and traditions discarded by the mid-20th-century wine industry, presaging a welcome rediscovery and new embrace.

headline: Salesforce Picks Second Winner for Criticized Hackathon
text: After its public relations coup turned into a significant embarrassment, Salesforce.com has investigated itself, and changed the results of its recent contest for software developers.

headline: Finding Japan’s Aircraft-Carrier Sub
text: It could just as easily have been a rock.

headline: Circumcisions to Help Prevent AIDS Are on the Rise
text: Circumcision for AIDS prevention is increasing rapidly in eastern and southern Africa, according to newly released figures.

headline: An Older Buddha, and Disease Numbers Good and Bad
text: As Americans paused to count their blessings last week, scientists made some reassessments of their own. The World Health Organization sharply increased its estimate of 2009 swine flu deaths and architects in Nepal found evidence that Buddha lived centuries earlier than previously thought. Still need something to be thankful for? Researchers in Pittsburgh may have put a number on the cases of contagious disease prevented by vaccines.

headline: In New Orleans, the More Restaurants the Merrier
text: Food-obsessed New Orleans has fewer people now than before Hurricane Katrina, but it has, by one local expert’s count, 70 percent more restaurants.

headline: New Orleans Restaurant Scene Rises, Reflecting a Richer City
text: NEW ORLEANS — By one count there were already 65 restaurants on the three miles of Magazine Street, a major artery through this city’s upscale districts. But on a recent Monday, diners were eager for No. 66. The minute the lights went on at Ivy, an autumnal little lounge with an as-seen-on-TV chef, the curious were at the door.

headline: Families, in Many Shapes and Sizes (5 Comments)
Men Can Be Such Worms (and Vice Versa)
text: Studies have repeatedly shown that married people live longer. But not if you’re a roundworm: Having a man around can kill you.

headline: A Record Holiday Week for Broadway
text: Broadway had its best Thanksgiving week ever at the box office, setting a record of $31.5 million in ticket sales for the 32 musicals and plays running last week, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers. The previous Broadway record for the holiday week, set in 2011, was $28.1 million (about $29.2 million after adjusting for inflation).

headline: Breast Cancer Conundrum in Israel, A New Way to Neuter, Robot Security Guards
text: A new screening effort to identify cancer-causing gene mutations is leading Israeli women to question how much they want to know; a handful of nonsurgical sterilization treatments are emerging that may help unplug the bottleneck for humane animal control; could we soon be seeing night watchmen with wheels?

headline: New F.C.C. Chief Promises He Will Protect Competition
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said on Monday that he intended to aggressively promote and protect competition in the telecommunications industry, including making sure that smaller mobile phone companies have a reasonable chance of buying public airwaves in auctions next year.

headline: Big Bugs Too Lovely to Squish
text: The visionary poet William Blake tumbled into the universe through his infinite grain of sand. For the French painter Bernard Durin, the portal was a beetle.

headline: Reeling in the Years With Sour Reflection
text: If you like Steely Dan’s greatest hits too much, Donald Fagen of that band probably hates you already. You may be one of the “TV babies” who illegally download those songs, show up at his concerts expecting to hear familiar hits, have no patience for anything soulful or adventurous or obscure, yet rather humiliatingly are paying part of his rent these days. The phrase “TV babies” comes from the film “Drugstore Cowboy,” which used it to the same contemptuous effect.

headline: Rockwell Biography Angers His Family
text: The family of Norman Rockwell is waging a fierce campaign against a new biography of him, bristling at the book’s suggestions that Rockwell, artist of small-town Americana, could have been secretly gay or harbored pedophilic impulses.

headline: Your Life’s a Dud? Your Guy’s a Loser? Conjure Up an Ex-Child Star
text: Mary-Kate Olsen sits on the couch, her arm slung comfortingly over the shoulder of a dejected young woman. “I’ve been walking around in your head, Grace,” Mary-Kate says.

headline: Location, Location, Location
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Sale to NCR Is a Quick, Profitable Flip for a Private Equity Firm
text: It was only in August that Thoma Bravo, the private equity firm, completed its acquisition of Digital Insight, a company that processes payments for financial institutions. The seller was Intuit, the financial software company, and the price was $1.025 billion.

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: Jazz-Funk Persuasion Rules the Night
text: The album of the year in 1989, according to Down Beat magazine’s annual critics’ poll, was “Extensions,” an imposingly strong debut by the Dave Holland Quartet. Featuring Mr. Holland on bass, Steve Coleman on alto saxophone, Kevin Eubanks on guitar and Marvin Smitty Smith on drums, it was a lesson in post-bop transition, poised between polarities: tight and loose, inside and out, acoustic and electric, hot and cool.

headline: Times Minute: Dec. 02 at 6 p.m.
text: New details on the Metro-North train crash; Vice President Biden in Asia; and habeas corpus for chimps.

headline: On an Expansive Stage, a Company Spreads Its Wings
text: LONDON — The mind of the choreographer Mark Morris, as we read it in his dances, is bewilderingly diverse. I first saw his work 29 years ago, in its first London season, and he is as mysterious to me now as he was then — but more marvelously so. Last week, the week after the Mark Morris Dance Group’s 25th-anniversary performances of “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato” at Lincoln Center, Mr. Morris presented seven recent works in two programs at Sadler’s Wells Theater here. They ranged from the tender celebration of eccentricity in “A Wooden Tree” to the controlled philosophical imagery of “Socrates,” from the male-female intimate duet of “Jenn and Spencer” to the intermeshing group patterns of “Crosswalk.”

headline: No Comment Necessary: Spend Money on Politicians, Not Gifts
text: Via ThinkProgress

headline: Sheryl Crow: The Lost Album
text: Part 10: The singer and songwriter talks about why she scrapped her first album, and recalls how her live album “Sheryl Crow and Friends” came together.

headline: Sheryl Crow: Jingles and Michael Jackson
text: Part 4: The singer and songwriter recalls the beginning of her career, and recounts how she got the lead backup singer gig on Michael Jackson’s “Bad” tour.
