headline: Adding a New Note to a Musical Menagerie
text: “Peter & the Wolf” quickly became a holiday tradition at the Guggenheim Museum after it was first presented in 2007. Each year, a different artist creates installations to visually interpret the tale, punctuated by the narration of Isaac Mizrahi, the fashion and design impresario. This year, for the first time, Mr. Mizrahi is transforming a concert with art and storytelling into a full theatrical production under his command: He is directing the actors and designed the set and the costumes.

headline: In Taking Jobs, Women Take On a Saudi Taboo
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — The bearded religious police officers were not the ones who chastised the princess running the Harvey Nichols department store here when she decided to enhance the upscale shopping atmosphere with some instrumental lute music.

headline: Canadian Commissioner Wants Officials to Switch From BlackBerry Messenger
text: BlackBerry Messenger is one of the products on which BlackBerry, the ailing smartphone maker, is basing its revival. And the government of Canada, which has about 98,000 BlackBerrys in service, remains one of the company’s last strongholds.

headline: Avoiding a Different Kind of Turbulence
text: THERE are some good things about frequent business travel. I’ve been flying pretty much nonstop for about 20 years, and I’ve probably read about 2,000 books that I wouldn’t otherwise have found the time to read. I like the quiet time. I like the fact that people can’t find me and I can think about work, or read or watch a movie without interruptions.

headline: T HOLIDAY
text: You can’t go wrong getting her jewelry — except you can. Will she like it? Is it her style? Here, four stellar designers who each create work that embodies a different kind of woman.

headline: Sounds So Different, but With Some Common Ground
text: In the late ’70s, if you loved Black Flag, which was led by the guitarist and songwriter Greg Ginn, it generally meant that you had some thoughts about corruption and complacency in American culture, and that you hated expensive-sounding rock bands like Boston, which was led by the guitarist and songwriter Tom Scholz. If you loved Boston, it meant primarily that you lived somewhere near a radio.

headline: Goldman and JPMorgan Satisfy Fed With Capital Plans
text: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase have finally overcome a regulatory rebuke that had been hanging over both banks since the Federal Reserve performed stress tests this year on large financial firms.

headline: T HOLIDAY
text: You can’t go wrong getting her jewelry — except you can. Will she like it? Is it her style? Here, four stellar designers who each create work that embodies a different kind of woman.

headline: Pick Your Brazil XI for the World Cup
text: Every World Cup coach will have difficult decisions to make before the tournament opens next June — which players to take and leave home, which ones to start or sit — but few will face more second-guessing than Brazil’s Luiz Felipe Scolari.

headline: Bishops Sued Over Anti-Abortion Policies at Catholic Hospitals
text: The American Civil Liberties Union announced on Monday that it had filed a lawsuit against the nation’s Roman Catholic bishops, arguing that their anti-abortion directives to Catholic hospitals hamper proper care of pregnant women in medical distress, leading to medical negligence.

headline: A Second Act for a Top Wall Street Strategist
text: J. Tomilson Hill was a well-known Wall Street deal maker in the 1980s, a skilled merger tactician whose work on the bidding war for RJR Nabisco earned him a role in the book “Barbarians at the Gate,” which memorably said he came across to enemies as “an oiled-back Gordon Gekko haircut atop 5 feet, 10 inches of icy Protestant reserve.”

headline: For Fliers, PreCheck Adds as Much Confusion as Convenience
text: WE’VE come out of one of the busiest travel periods of the year, and if it showed anything, it was that confusion reigned for fliers.

headline: Cost of Health Care Law Is Seen as Decreasing
text: WASHINGTON — The rollout of President Obama’s health care law may have deeply disappointed its supporters, but on at least one front, the Affordable Care Act is beating expectations: its cost.

headline: Veteran Broadway Press Agent to Close Up Shop
text: The veteran Broadway press agent Michael Hartman announced on Monday that he was closing his company, the Hartman Group, on Jan. 5, leaving his account executives to quickly find new agencies for, among other shows, the blockbuster “Wicked,” the fan favorite “Rock of Ages,” and the coming musicals “Rocky,” “If/Then,” “The Last Ship” (Sting’s Broadway debut as a composer) and “Houdini” (starring Tony Award winner Hugh Jackman).

headline: Objects | Modern Jewelry for All Kinds of Women
text: You can’t go wrong getting her jewelry — except you can. Will she like it? Is it her style? Here, four stellar designers who each create work that embodies a different kind of woman.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: South Korea’s Romance App and Finland’s Other Cellphone Manufacturer
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: British Fashion Awards
text: See what Kate Moss, Gwyneth Paltrow and Alexa Chung wore.

headline: Intersection: Vintage Style in Bucharest
text: The old center of Bucharest, Romania, highlights vintage style and nonconformity in local fashion. Victor Placinta, an architect, said his wardrobe is inspired by British style.

headline: Solid-State Drives and the iTunes MiniPlayer
text: Choosing Speed Over Storage Capacity

headline: At Once-Promising Brooklyn Arts Center, Creative Hopes Are Dashed
text: Crowding into the tasting room of the Brooklyn Brewery, in Williamsburg, the nearly 200 painters, metalworkers, writers and self-styled entrepreneurs — all former members of 3rd Ward, the Bushwick arts center, D.I.Y. haven and creative network that collapsed in October — sounded a little like refugees.

headline: Riding With the 12 O’Clock Boys
text: A group of dirt bike riders in Baltimore have been called reckless. But to them, riding their bikes provides a sense of escape.

headline: Chernin Invests in Anime Streaming Company
text: Peter Chernin, the former News Corporation executive who now runs his own media investment firm, has proved to be an astute investor, putting money to work in high-flying start-ups like Pandora, Tumblr and Flipboard.

headline: Medical Technician Is Sentenced in Hepatitis C Outbreak
text: BOSTON — A medical technician was sentenced on Monday to 39 years in prison for infecting at least 45 hospital patients with hepatitis C by contaminating their syringes.

headline: Travel Sites for Hopscotching
text: To plan a vacation with his wife and two young sons last August, Peter Cohen had a lot to do. His itinerary was ambitious: fly into and out of Lisbon, and travel around Portugal, Spain, Morocco and Gibraltar by train, rental car and ferry.

headline: Underachieving Congress Appears in No Hurry to Change Things Now
text: WASHINGTON — The House straggled back to the Capitol on Monday night with just two weeks left before its likely entry into the Congressional record book for underachievement, still clinging to hopes that deals can be reached in the coming days on a budget and other once-routine bills that could ease some of the sting.

headline: Croatian Government to Pursue Law Allowing Civil Unions for Gay Couples
text: PARIS — The Croatian government pledged on Monday to press ahead with plans for a law allowing civil partnerships for gay people after a majority of Croats voted in a referendum to effectively ban same-sex marriage in the predominantly Catholic country.

headline: Mixed Reactions From Media Critics After One Cuomo Interviews Another
text: Andrew and Chris Cuomo are as close as brothers can be. They fish together, they vacation together and they tinker on cars together.

headline: The Families We Invent
text: When they were 11 years old, Kylee and Starr split a stolen Coors and made a wordless pact, pricking their fingers with a cactus needle to let their blood run together. The gesture symbolized the girls’ hope — their determination — that their lives would always be joined just as closely.

headline: Chinese Dissident Ai Weiwei to Take His Art to Alcatraz
text: The Chinese artist and political dissident Ai Weiwei was one of the most famous prisoners in recent history. Now he’s taking on one of the most infamous prisons of all time, using Alcatraz as the inspiration and site for a series of new artworks to debut next September.

headline: As Hospital Prices Soar, a Stitch Tops $500
text: SAN FRANCISCO — With blood oozing from deep lacerations, the two patients arrived at California Pacific Medical Center’s tidy emergency room. Deepika Singh, 26, had gashed her knee at a backyard barbecue. Orla Roche, a rambunctious toddler on vacation with her family, had tumbled from a couch, splitting open her forehead on a table.

headline: Japan in a Post-Growth Age
text: TOKYO — THESE days you can hardly open a newspaper or turn on a television in Japan without encountering another story relating to former Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi’s call, after visiting a nuclear waste facility in Finland, for ending Japan’s reliance on nuclear power. Since Mr. Koizumi made his comments in September, Japanese newspapers have been filled with positive editorials about the possibility of a nonnuclear future.

headline: Promotion of 3 Editors Is Announced at The Times
text: The New York Times announced three masthead promotions on Monday, moves that continue its emphasis on digital initiatives and enterprise reporting.

headline: Panel Appointed by Cuomo Says Corruption Is Commonplace in Albany
text: A panel appointed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo issued a stinging assessment of the state’s political culture on Monday, saying it had found evidence of probable wrongdoing and recommending sweeping changes to New York State’s elections, ethics and campaign finance laws.

headline: Paul Walker’s Death Complicates ‘Fast & Furious 7’ Filming
text: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — Universal Pictures executives, still reeling from the weekend death of one of the stars of their “Fast & Furious” films, got down to the difficult business on Monday of figuring out how to salvage their No. 1 movie franchise.

headline: Old Washington Building Rules Meet Push for Change
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Darrell Issa thinks the Height of Buildings Act has overstayed its welcome in the District of Columbia.

headline: Mexico: U.S. Indicts a Former Governor
text: The United States has indicted a former governor of a Mexican state that borders Texas in a case that has come to illustrate concerns over political corruption and has embarrassed the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. Federal prosecutors on Monday unsealed the indictment charging the former official, Tomás Yarrington Ruvalcaba, who served as governor of Tamaulipas State from 1999 to 2005, with racketeering and money laundering. Mr. Yarrington, who is being sought, funneled payments from drug traffickers into Texas banks, real estate and false businesses, prosecutors said. Mr. Yarrington, a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, ran for president in 2005. But he was ejected from the party in 2012 as the inquiry came to light during the presidential campaign of Enrique Peña Nieto, who promised a new PRI, free of corruption.

headline: Washington Mayor Will Seek Re-election
text: Mayor Vincent C. Gray of Washington said Monday that he would run for re-election. A spokesman for the mayor’s office, Robert Marus, said Mr. Gray had picked up petitions to begin gathering the 2,000 signatures required to participate in the Democratic primary on April 1. Mr. Gray was elected in 2010, and his tenure has been shadowed by investigations into that campaign, which was financed in part by $650,000 that was not reported to the election authorities. Mr. Gray has denied any knowledge of wrongdoing and has never been charged with a crime, but the investigation is still open and three of the mayor’s associates have been found guilty. Mr. Gray’s decision ended months of speculation and was likely to reshape the crowded Democratic field, which includes four members of the District of Columbia Council.

headline: New Job After Shots Are Fired: Helping Students Feel Safe
text: On a chill autumn morning, sun poured through the high windows as a young elementary school principal, Meghan Dunn, sat with her staff. On the fifth floor, a middle school principal in the same building, Kiersten Ward, chatted with her parent coordinator and an assistant.

headline: In Marketing, Art’s the Thing
text: FOR decades, the MGM lion has roared under the slogan “Ars gratia artis,” or “Art for art’s sake.” On Madison Avenue, executives are busily thumbing through their Latin dictionaries to figure out how to say “Art for marketing’s sake.”

headline: Britain: Envoy Aims to Mend Iran Ties
text: Britain’s new envoy to Tehran will travel to Iran on Tuesday, the first diplomatic visit by a British official since Britain’s embassy in Tehran was stormed more than two years ago. The visit of the envoy, Ajay Sharma, who has the rank of a nonresident chargé d’affaires, was announced by his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Habibollah-Zadeh, to the official news agency IRNA. Foreign Secretary William Hague confirmed the report in a Twitter message, adding, “We’ll improve U.K.-Iran ties on a step-by-step, reciprocal basis.” Mr. Habibollah-Zadeh said that Mr. Sharma’s visit would include a look at British diplomatic buildings and talks with Iranian Foreign Ministry officials, and that he would then make a similar visit to London.

headline: Insurers Are Offered Assistance for Losses
text: WASHINGTON — The White House is offering more money to insurance companies as an incentive for them to let people keep insurance policies that were to have been canceled next year.

headline: Apple Buys Topsy, a Social Media Analytics Firm
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is not known for being social — rather, it is known for being buttoned up about everything it does. But on Monday, the company confirmed that it had bought Topsy Labs, a research company that could help Apple better understand what people are talking about on social media networks like Twitter.

headline: Prosecutor Sees Danger in Budget Cuts
text: The United States attorney’s office in Manhattan has brought down terrorists, gang members, corrupt politicians and crooked executives, but budget cuts and hiring freezes may force the office’s top prosecutor to make difficult choices about which cases to pursue.

headline: Witness Tells of Pressure From SAC Trader to Get More Insider Data
text: Between 2007 and 2009, Jon Horvath developed a regular routine as a trader at SAC Capital Advisors: obtaining confidential information about Dell Inc.’s financial results well before the computer company’s quarterly disclosures.

headline: U.S. Pledges New Funds to Fight AIDS
text: The United States will commit up to $5 billion to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, President Obama said Monday at the White House. The pledge was made as the Geneva-based fund’s “replenishment conference” opened in Washington; the fund’s leaders hope to have $15 billion pledged by Tuesday. Under the terms of the pledge, the United States will pay the full amount only if other countries pledge $10 billion. “Don’t leave our money on the table,” Mr. Obama said. He also said that state waiting lists for AIDS drugs, which grew to more than 9,000 patients in 2010, were finally cleared last week with federal aid under the Ryan White Program. And he said another $100 million in the federal budget would be redirected to AIDS research.

headline: ‘Riding With the 12 O’Clock Boys’
text: Long before I actually saw any of the 12 O’Clock Boys, a notorious group of dirt bike riders in Baltimore, I heard them. The rev of their motors, even at a distance, was a regular addition to the constant soundscape of helicopters and sirens. (Their name is in reference to the vertical position the riders attempt while pulling off wheelies.)

headline: Factories Worldwide Are Showing Momentum
text: Bucking fears of a sharp brake on growth after the government shutdown in the United States and earlier signs of distress in Europe and Asia, global manufacturing activity sped up in November, raising hopes for a broader global economic turnaround in the coming year.

headline: Rule Change Could Ease ‘Justice Gap’ for the Poor
text: Lawyers who work for big corporations in New York but are not licensed to practice law in the state will be allowed to do pro bono work under a new rule meant to ease an acute shortage of legal representation for the poor, the state’s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, announced on Monday.

headline: The Interminable, Everlasting Lincolns (Part 1)
text: This is the second installment of a four-part series.

headline: Auburn Announcer Has the Call of a Lifetime, Twice in One Month
text: College football on radio is no place for subdued restraint. Announcers are oftentimes loud, excitable, and biased. Great, decisive, game-ending plays can be cues to go wild.

headline: Despite the Death of Paul Walker, Two  Movies Will Go On as Planned
text: LOS ANGELES – Universal Pictures isn’t yet sure how it will proceed on “Fast & Furious 7” following the death of Paul Walker, one of the unfinished film’s charismatic leads. But it was decided on Monday that two of Mr. Walker’s smaller movies, both completed, will go forward as planned.

headline: Amazon Delivers Some Pie in the Sky
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hard to believe, but there was once a time when the visionaries worked for the government. Rebuilding a ruined Europe, putting a man on the moon, ending poverty, connecting the American interior with highways — these were immense tasks undertaken, and often achieved, by bureaucrats.

headline: The Stem and the Flower
text: In an act of amazing public service, I have not written a column in three months. In the course of that time, I’ve stepped back from politics, a bit, and thought about other things. That naturally raises the question: How much emotional and psychic space should politics take up in a normal healthy brain?

headline: De Blasio Tweaks Bloomberg on Absence at Crash Site
text: Even couched in disclaimers, there was no mistaking the sign of change: If Sunday’s train derailment had occurred under his mayoralty, the mayor-elect, Bill de Blasio, said on Monday, he would have been on the scene — not missing in action.

headline: ‘The Process’ Can’t Always Beat the Breaks
text: Alabama has become the envy of college football because it has won three national championships in four seasons under Coach Nick Saban, utilizing a heavy-on-fundamentals formula that Saban refers to as a process. The Crimson Tide has also produced 24 N.F.L. draft picks, including 11 first-rounders in the last four drafts with its player-development process, which has led scouts to label the program the 33rd N.F.L. franchise. Florida State Coach Jimbo Fisher, a former assistant under Saban, has branded the Seminoles’ player-development strategy and their ascension to No. 1 this season a process.

headline: For Gay Community, Finding Acceptance Is Even More Difficult on the Streets
text: SAN FRANCISCO — There were times — after he told his parents he was gay, for example, and his mother wept and his father tried to hit him — when Fredy Bolvito curled up on a bench in Union Square here and cried because he had AIDS and no job and no place to stay and he felt, he said, that “my life was over.”

headline: The Asbestos Scam
text: In May, Carolyn McCarthy, a nine-term congresswoman from Long Island, was diagnosed with lung cancer. Her treatment began almost immediately, causing her to take a lengthy absence from her office while she fought the disease. At the same time, McCarthy, 69, ended a pack-a-day cigarette habit that she’d had for most of her life, presumably because she understood the link between cigarette-smoking and lung cancer. Scientists estimate that smoking plays a role in 90 percent of lung cancer deaths.

headline: Settled in New York, but Still Within Chernobyl’s Reach
text: Serafima Leyfman was extremely proud of her long, dark hair, which spilled all the way down to her legs. Her husband had also adored her lengthy tresses. She would not cut it, not even once, after they were married.

headline: Seeing the Toll, Schools Revise Zero Tolerance
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Faced with mounting evidence that get-tough policies in schools are leading to arrest records, low academic achievement and high dropout rates that especially affect minority students, cities and school districts around the country are rethinking their approach to minor offenses.

headline: Fast Recovery for Health Care Website
text: The Obama administration says it has made enormous improvements in its website for enrolling consumers in new health insurance plans. There are still major hurdles to surmount, but the strides made raise the prospects that the website will be able to help millions of Americans buy policies from private insurers on new insurance exchanges, either by Dec. 23, the deadline for policies that will take effect on Jan. 1, or by March 31, the deadline for taking out coverage without being fined. There will be federal subsidies to help those on modest incomes pay the premiums.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 2, 2013
A Moment of Peril in Kiev
text: Kiev’s Independence Square has been seized by protesters furious with Viktor Yanukovich, Ukraine’s president, because he has decided against signing a trade deal with the European Union — a deal that many ordinary citizens saw as critically important to their economic future. It is not immediately clear what Mr. Yanukovich can do, short of changing his mind and signing a deal. But the protests could well get bigger and more violent.

headline: Officials Erred in Mix-Up Near End of Giants Game
text: The N.F.L. on Monday said officials erred at the end of the Giants’ game with the Washington Redskins when they chose not to stop play after there was confusion about the down and the distance to go for a first down during the Redskins’ final drive.

headline: Banks as Payday Lenders
text: Last month, banking regulators put the finishing touches on rules designed to rein in short-term consumer loans from banks that are as dangerous to consumers as the predatory loans made by so-called payday lenders.

headline: Stealth S.U.V.’s
text: The pileup of grim fatality data about the risks of distracted driving has prompted New York State to assign highway troopers to a special fleet of 32 CITE vehicles, for Concealed Identity Traffic Enforcement, designed to catch cellphone texters as they tap away. These are nondescript gray S.U.V.’s that ride higher than normal so officers can peer down into vehicles moving suspiciously in the hands (or nonhands) of drivers eyeing and manipulating their electronic-message devices.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 3, 2013
text: “How much is that per minute?”

headline: Kurds’ Oil Deals With Turkey Raise Fears of Fissures in Iraq
text: ISTANBUL — The sharp, dry mountains that run between Turkey and Iraq have long marked a front line in the battle between the Turkish government and Kurdish separatists where cross-border attacks took many lives on both sides.

headline: A New Wave of Challenges to Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — More than a year after the Supreme Court upheld the central provision of President Obama’s health care overhaul, a fresh wave of legal challenges to the law is playing out in courtrooms as conservative critics — joined by their Republican allies on Capitol Hill — make the case that Mr. Obama has overstepped his authority in applying it.

headline: Names Have Changed, but the Quarterback Mess Remains
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The first quarterback to walk into the Jets’ locker room Monday was David Garrard. Geno Smith followed. And soon after, so did Matt Simms. By then, it had been revealed which of them would start Sunday against Oakland.

headline: HealthCare.gov: Flaws and Fixes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Goes Fast
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — SADDLE up, y’all; we’re going riding. Remember, always mount a puzzle from the left-hand side. You can spook a grid but good if you try to get on it from the right.

headline: Corrections: December 3, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: New York Subpoenas Websites in an Effort to Curb Payday Lenders
text: Government authorities are trying to choke off the supply of borrowers to online lenders that offer short-term loans with annual interest rates of more than 400 percent, the latest development in a broader crackdown on the payday lending industry.

headline: Eastern Conference Sets New Standards for Poor Play
text: So what is it with the Eastern Conference of the N.B.A.? After Monday’s games, only two of the 15 teams in the conference had records above .500. One other was at .500. How can you have so much bad basketball in one part of the country?

headline: Fates of Brooks and Coulson in Tabloid Hacking Case Are Diverging
text: LONDON — Once they were friends and colleagues who reveled in the heady world of British news, politics and intrigue. Together they rose from the scrappy newsrooms of London’s tabloids to the heights of establishment power, she as head of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper empire, he as Prime Minister David Cameron’s chief spokesman. For six years they were lovers, carrying on their affair even as each married someone else.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Success Goes West
text: There is no question that west is best this fall. Entering Monday’s games, N.B.A, N.F.L. and N.H.L. teams that play in the Eastern time zone have a far worse winning percentage than teams that don’t.

headline: Cool Prison, Better Outcome
text: To the Editor:

headline: Families, at Home and Work, Feel Losses
text: He was a father, a neighbor who could be trusted with a spare house key, a bear of a man whose wife called him “Gato,” which means cat — and handsome — in Portuguese.

headline: Is Wall Street Too Giddy?
text: Are we in a stock market bubble that could soon burst?

headline: ‘Llewyn Davis’ and ‘Fruitvale Station’ Win at the Gothams
text: “Inside Llewyn Davis,” the Coen brothers’ look at the 1960s New York folk scene, won best feature at the Gotham Independent Film Awards on Monday night, traditionally the kickoff event for awards season.

headline: With Pressure On, Brazil’s Coach Seeks Psychological Edge
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — While all 32 teams that have qualified for the World Cup anxiously await this week’s draw to determine the groups for next year’s tournament, nowhere is the pressure as great as in Brazil.

headline: Klinsmann Knows Well the Strains a Host Faces
text: Luiz Felipe Scolari, the manager of Brazil’s national soccer team, is obviously not the first coach to lead a team playing the World Cup on its home soil; the host receives an automatic berth. He is also not the first coach to lead one of the tournament favorites in a home World Cup; Jurgen Klinsmann did exactly that as the coach of Germany in 2006.

headline: Memorial Service for Train Crash Victims
text: Religious leaders gathered in the Bronx on Monday night for a memorial service overlooking the scene of Sunday's train derailment, in which four people died.

headline: Mets Take a Peek at Granderson
text: For the second time in two weeks, officials from the Mets’ front office have met with a prominent Yankees free agent. Signing such a player, however, is an entirely different matter.

headline: Closing Credits With Matthew Dickman and Takashi Murakami
text: Takashi Murakami conjures a furious vision in response to the poet Matthew Dickman’s rumination on love, death and the silver screen.

headline: Google Joins a Heavyweight Competition in Cloud Computing
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Google already runs much of the digital lives of consumers through email, Internet searches and YouTube videos. Now it wants the corporations, too.

headline: The Minimum-Wage Cure for Illegal Immigration
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | detonation
text: detonation •\ˌde-tən-ˈa-shən, ˌde-tə-ˈna-\• noun

headline: Consumer Watchdog to Monitor Student Loan Servicers
text: If you’re a borrower having trouble with the company that handles your student loans, you may be interested to learn that the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will soon begin scrutinizing practices of the largest loan servicers, the companies that manage loans on behalf of lenders.

headline: Thai Police Retreat, Restoring Some Calm to Capital
text: BANGKOK — Thai antigovernment demonstrators reached a truce on Tuesday in their battle to rid the country of its most influential political family, but thousands of protesters continued to follow the orders of their leader, who vowed not to give up his campaign.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) MOB CITY MOVIES In anticipation of the TNT mini-series “Mob City,” starting on Wednesday, Ed Burns, who portrays Bugsy Siegel in that show, and the TCM host Robert Osborne, introduce four classic thrillers: Raoul Walsh’s “White Heat” (1949), starring James Cagney as a gangster trying to stay a step ahead of an undercover agent, at 8; Walsh’s “The Roaring Twenties” (1939), with Cagney and Humphrey Bogart as war veterans involved in bootlegging, at 10; Fritz Lang’s “The Big Heat” (1953), with Glenn Ford as a determined cop who infiltrates the criminal underworld after his wife’s murder, at midnight; and John Huston’s “Key Largo” (1948), with Edward G. Robinson as a gang leader who holds a group of people hostage in a Florida hotel during a tropical storm, and Bogart (above left, with Robinson) as the World War II veteran who tries to take him down, at 2 a.m.

headline: Hong Kong Gets First Case of Avian Flu Virus
text: Hong Kong health officials raised avian influenza alert levels to serious late Monday after a domestic worker in the city became critically ill with the virus, the first reported case in the territory.

headline: American 15-Year-Olds Lag, Mainly in Math, on International Standardized Tests
text: Fifteen-year-olds in the United States score in the middle of the developed world in reading and science while lagging in math, according to international standardized test results being released on Tuesday.

headline: Biden Backs Ally Japan but Avoids Roiling China
text: TOKYO — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. delivered a carefully calibrated show of support for Japan on Tuesday, expressing deep concerns about China’s move to control airspace over islands in the East China Sea, but stopping short of a demand that Beijing reverse itself. Instead, he urged the feuding neighbors to talk to each other.

headline: Bloomberg Reporter Barred From Press Event With Chinese Premier
text: Updated, 6:54 p.m. | A Bloomberg News reporter traveling to China in connection with a visit by the British prime minister, David Cameron, was barred from a press event with Chinese prime minister, Li Keqiang, a sign of the continuing barriers the news organization faces in China.

headline: Nonresident Indians Play Major Role in Aam Aadmi Party’s Delhi Campaign
text: During the month of November, Mohan Thirumalai, an information systems manager at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, would pick up his phone at his home in Alabama around 10 p.m. and dial a random number in Delhi, the first of around 60 calls he would make each night.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Dec. 3, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Territorial Dispute in East China Sea Signals Larger Power Struggle
text: In “In the East China Sea, a Far Bigger Test of Power Looms,” David E. Sanger writes a news analysis about the rising tensions between China and the United States.

headline: Economic Realignment Fuels Regional Political Divisions in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — Anand Panyarachun, one of Thailand’s leading statesmen, recently noted that his country seemed to have everything going for it — plentiful natural resources, good weather and fortunate geography free from typhoons or volcanic eruptions.

headline: H.I.V. Infections Among Young Chinese Rising
text: Two decades after tens of thousands — some say hundreds of thousands — of Chinese contracted the H.I.V. virus from contaminated blood products in an epidemic that raged in the 1990s, the major transmission route today is sex, according to Chinese media reports, citing figures from the National Health and Family Planning Commission. Gay sex was a significant factor, doctors said.

headline: Detroit Ruling on Bankruptcy Lifts Pension Protections
text: DETROIT — In a ruling that could reverberate far beyond Detroit, a federal judge held on Tuesday that this battered city could formally enter bankruptcy and asserted that Detroit’s obligation to pay pensions in full was not untouchable.

headline: Using a Rough Surface to Stay Dry
text: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Boston University have found a new clue to staying dry, and it has to do with time and texture.

headline: ScienceTake: Splash!
text: New surfaces make water bounce, faster.

headline: Should Scientists Try to Help People Beat Old Age So We Can Live Longer Lives?
text: What would happen if anti-aging research actually succeeded — if our average life expectancy shot up from almost 80 to 100, 120 or even longer? Would that breakthrough be a good thing?

headline: Magnum: Social Concerns, Visual Pleasure
text: It has always been difficult to fit Magnum photographers into a single box. The founders of the first cooperative picture agency included socially concerned members like Robert Capa and David (Chim) Seymour, as well as Henri Cartier-Bresson, who was mostly interested in “visual pleasure.”

headline: Bolshoi Dancer Gets Six Years in Acid Attack on Director
text: MOSCOW — A Moscow court on Tuesday sentenced Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, the former Bolshoi Ballet Theater soloist, to six years in a penal colony for ordering an acid attack in January that nearly blinded the theater’s artistic director, Sergei Filin.

headline: R.B.S. to Compensate Card Holders After Online Error
text: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland, bailed out by the British government five years ago, had to apologize on Tuesday after a systems crash left millions of its customers unable to pay with their debit or credit cards for several hours on Monday evening.

headline: Kerry and Allies Step Up Pressure for Afghan Pact
text: BRUSSELS — Secretary of State John Kerry and allied diplomats stepped up the pressure Tuesday on the Afghan government to sign an accord soon that would allow American troops to stay in the country after 2014.

headline: Times Minute: Dec. 03 at 6 a.m.
text: Detroit braces for bankruptcy ruling; the Big Easy's restaurant boom; and the science of splashing.
