headline: Daily Report: Google Enters Fray of Corporate Cloud Services
text: Google already runs much of the digital lives of consumers through email, Internet searches and YouTube videos. Now it wants the corporations, too, Quentin Hardy reports.

headline: Ukraine Rejects E.U. Accord
text: Protesters reacted angrily when, under pressure from Russia, President Viktor F. Yanukovich did not sign a political and trade deal with the European Union as expected.

headline: Ukraine Protests Persist as Bid to Oust Government Fails
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Refusing to grant a central demand of protesters who have laid siege to public buildings and occupied a landmark plaza in this rattled capital, the Ukrainian Parliament on Tuesday defeated a measure calling for the resignation of Prime Minister Mykola Azarov and his government.

headline: Should a Student Conceal Her Lesbian Identity in College Application Essays?
text: Q. Dear Civil Behavior: Our daughter is a senior in high school and quite comfortable with her lesbian identity. We support her 100 percent, but we know the world is not always so tolerant. As she’s writing her college application essays this fall, she’s “coming out” in them — and we think that’s a bad idea. You just never know who’s reading these essays, so why risk revealing your orientation to someone who might be biased against you? We’ve strongly suggested she think over the ramifications of what she’s doing, but she doesn’t seem to have any doubt about it. Deadlines are approaching and we are at an impasse. How can we persuade her to keep some things private if they might hurt her chances of admission?” — Anonymous

headline: A Start-Up Tries Selling ‘Sprayable’ Caffeine
text: Start-Up: Sprayable Energy.

headline: Q. & A.: Rory Medcalf on the Meaning of China’s Air Defense Zone
text: China’s declaration of an air defense zone in the East China Sea has prompted concern among some neighbors who fear it will be used to bolster territorial claims.

headline: In the Land of Punk
text: CBGB was going down to Georgia. So was I.

headline: Phrases Gone Astray
text: Modifying phrases should usually be adjacent to what they are describing. When such a phrase pops up in an unlikely part of the sentence, the effect ranges from clunkiness to confusion to unintended comedy.

headline: In Performance: Peter Bradbury of ‘A Christmas Carol’
text: This week’s In Performance video features a scene with Peter Bradbury as Ebenezer Scrooge in Patrick Barlow’s new adaptation of Charles Dickens’s “Christmas Carol.” The show, directed by Joe Calarco, continues through Jan. 4 at the Theater at St. Clement’s.

headline: Homeless in Delhi Get Chance to Exercise Voting Rights
text: NEW DELHI — On a hazy Tuesday morning at a homeless shelter, Durga Dayal, 27, showed me his voter identity card with great elation. As I sat looking at his voter card, scores of people flitted in and out of the shelter, inquiring about whether their cards had arrived as well.

headline: A Strategist, Reinvented
text: J. Tomilson Hill, a well-known Wall Street deal maker in the 1980s who had a role in the book “Barbarians at the Gate,” has reinvented himself by applying his deal-making skills to a different business, Randall Smith reports in DealBook. Though he was ousted as co-chief executive of Lehman Brothers in 1993, he has recently gained prominence running the hedge-fund-of-funds business at the Blackstone Group, where he is the third highest-paid executive officer.

headline: On the No. 7 Train, ‘Hello’ in Many Tongues
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Allure of Stars and Spreadsheets
text: By now you might have seen the video gallery of some of the year’s most compelling actors, speaking lines crafted by some of the year’s best writers, and directed by the master cinematographer Janusz Kaminski. If not, feast on Cate Blanchett, Oprah Winfrey, Bradley Cooper and Michael B. Jordan here.

headline: Even With Website Fixes, Troubles Persist in Applying for Insurance
text: Melissa Godwin, 42, a former schoolteacher from Atlanta, said she had tried at least 15 times since early October to get through the application process on HealthCare.gov, the online insurance marketplace. On Monday, she was hoping things would be different.

headline: North Korea’s Leader Is Said to Oust Uncle in Power Play
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-un, the 30-year-old leader of North Korea, came to power two years ago so inexperienced and untested that the reclusive government named his uncle as the North Korean equivalent of a regent to watch over him.

headline: Qatar Judge Postpones Case Against U.S. Couple
text: DOHA, Qatar — An American couple charged with killing their 8-year-old daughter will have to wait several months for a verdict, after a court in the wealthy Persian Gulf emirate of Qatar on Tuesday postponed the proceedings until next year.

headline: Records in View as Offenses Keep Flying
text: This season is shaping up to be yet another record-setting one for N.F.L. offenses. Teams are averaging 23.3 points a game, the most since 1948, and more than 350 yards, which would eclipse the mark of 347 set last season. But it is not just the league averages that are soaring. Several players and teams are on a pace to have record-setting seasons.

headline: Investigating Corruption in Albany
text: In a report issued Monday, a panel appointed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo described a political system in which misconduct has become commonplace.

headline: Art in a New Park in Oslo
text: Already home to the sprawling Vigeland Sculpture Park, Oslo welcomed a new outdoor art venue in the Ekeberg Sculpture Park this fall.

headline: Fantasy Football: Player Picks for the Playoffs
text: It is the best time of the year to be a fantasy football analyst. The fantasy playoffs start this week for many owners and we have a full 13 weeks of statistics to sift through as we try to pinpoint the players who will perform the best in the next three crucial weeks.

headline: An Update on Risks of Abrupt Jolts from Global Warming
text: In 2002, the National Academy of Sciences published “Abrupt Climate Change: Inevitable Surprises,” a valuable report examining whether and how the building human influence on the climate system might lead to disruptive jolts. The most important finding, in a way, was that this was an area sorely in need of intensified research.

headline: Taking Home Prizes (and Possibly Silverware)
text: “Everybody shut up!” Bobby Cannavale shouted good-naturedly to the chattering audience at the Gotham Independent Film Awards on Monday night. Mr. Cannavale, a star of “Blue Jasmine” and a Bagger favorite, was acting on orders from the show’s host, Nick Kroll, as he tried to bring some order to the proceedings.

headline: Today in Small Business: Pop-Up Stores
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Wedding Fix Is In
text: I was never the type to create a wedding “dream board,” with collages of petal-strewn, princess-themed fantasy nuptials. So I thought the process of planning my own wedding would be fairly painless and practical. That was before I entered the economically baffling world of the wedding-industrial complex.

headline: Keeping Avalanches Out of the Games
text: Some of the mitigation techniques used by a team of experts devoted to avalanche prevention at Rosa Khutor, the newly built resort that will host the Alpine skiing and snowboarding events at the 2014 Winter Olympics in February.

headline: Activist Fund Seeks Change at the Top of Abercrombie
text: Updated, 1:17 p.m. | Abercrombie & Fitch may have lost its crown as the king of teen fashion, but a hedge fund is hoping that a change in leadership could revive the retailer’s fortunes.

headline: By Design | In Salzburg, an Astonishing Contemporary Art Collection in a 17th-Century Austrian Manor
text: For the art dealer Thaddaeus Ropac, a Baroque 17th-century Austrian manor makes a perfect foil for modern art and furniture.

headline: Unacceptable Realities
text: The other day I found myself hanging out with several other semi-public liberal figures (yes, we were drinking white wine), and the conversation turned to hate mail — specifically, what generated the most hysterical outpourings. For the others, it was often issues that are not my department, like reproductive rights. But for me, it’s two things: health care and monetary policy.

headline: Hoping to Tame the Snow in Sochi
text: SOCHI, Russia — Scattered high on the craggy, snow-swept cliffs of the Caucasus Mountains, dozens of wide-mouthed metal pipes jut horizontally from the rocks. An elbow joint turns the pipes downward, like spouts of giant faucets.

headline: Chickpea Stew, Complex and Colorful, From Meager Beginnings
text: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: T HOLIDAY
text: For the art dealer Thaddaeus Ropac, a Baroque 17th-century Austrian manor makes a perfect foil for modern art and furniture.

headline: The Battle of Fort Sanders
text: By Nov. 29, 1863, Union-held Knoxville, Tenn., had been under Confederate siege for 12 days. The city itself was a war zone. Sharpshooters from increasingly closer vantage points picked off officers and men alike, so accurately that only one civilian was killed among dozens of dead soldiers. Artillery positions exchanged fire around the line.

headline: No (Spousal) Benefits for You
text: Following valid orders from higher-ups is central to how the military functions.  At least, it’s supposed to be.  But getting every state National Guard unit to comply with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s order that same-sex spouses of military personnel be given full spousal and family benefits is proving difficult.

headline: Bob Dylan Charged With ‘Inciting Hate’ Under French Law
text: To people who follow the pronouncements of Bob Dylan, his comment in a Rolling Stone interview in September 2012 suggesting that American blacks could sense whether whites had slave-master blood “just like Jews can sense Nazi blood and the Serbs can sense Croatian blood” may have seemed just the sort of vaporously impressionistic, emotionally pointed kind of thing that Mr. Dylan has been known to say for decades.

headline: The Snowden Files, Press Freedom and Britain
text: Updated 12:58 p.m. As Alan Rusbridger, editor of The Guardian, faced questions on Tuesday from members of a Parliamentary committee about publishing classified National Security Agency documents, media organizations from around the world called on officials to uphold Britain’s commitment to freedom of the press.

headline: Image of the Day: December 3
text: The day is aimed at promoting support for the rights and well-being of persons with disabilities.

headline: In Our Pages: December 4
text: 1938: ‘Scarlett O’Hara’ Chosen

headline: Slide Show: Gotham Awards
text: See what Lupita Nyong’o and Jared Leto wore to the Gotham Independent Film Awards, the traditional starter’s pistol for the glitzy season in New York.

headline: Times Minute: Dec. 03 at Noon
text: Detroit's bankruptcy ruling; a ballet star is sentenced and movie awards season kicks off.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Overcoming Media Bias
The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: Train Engineer Was Dazed Before Crash, Lawyer Says
text: The engineer who operated the Metro-North Railroad train that derailed over the weekend, killing four people and injuring more than 70, told the authorities on Tuesday that he had become dazed before the accident, suffering what his lawyer referred to as “highway hypnosis.”

headline: An Authentic Lambrusco With Posole
text: Posole presents a deeply satisfying array of earthy, spicy, savory and bright flavors, which offer more than a few possible areas of harmony, as long as the wine is low in alcohol and tannins. My first thought: an authentic Lambrusco with dry, meaty flavors and refreshing bubbles that ought to pair beautifully.

headline: ‘Spring Breakers,’ the One Film Cineastes and John Waters Can Agree On
text: Two best-of announcements this week, from the New York Film Critics Circle and the National Board of Review, may help bring some clarity to an overstuffed Oscars contest. At the moment, though, the Bagger is more interested in some lists that probably have little affect on the race but say a lot about how to encapsulate movies. The cineaste journals Cahiers du Cinéma (from France) and Sight & Sound (Britain) announced their best films of the year recently, as did John Waters, in ArtForum. There was some overlap.

headline: Dance Music Redux
text: Every few years, dance music has a moment in this country — at least, that’s how it can seem from afar. But the truth is that ever since disco, dance music has been a constant in American pop, even if it wasn’t dominant. And around the world, it is often at pop’s center, with Americans looking on in curiosity.

headline: October Medicaid Applications Far Outpace Enrollment Through Exchanges
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Tuesday that 1.46 million people had applied and been found eligible for Medicaid or the Children’s Health Insurance Program in October, far more than had selected a private health plan in the new insurance marketplaces.

headline: When Is It Safe to Drive After Breaking a Bone?
text: Hands on the steering wheel, one foot toggling between brake and pedal, head twisting to check mirrors. Consider the many bones and joints you must engage before you even turn on a car’s ignition, among them the fingers, wrist, forearm, elbow, shoulder, neck, heel, ankle and leg.

headline: For Art Basel, Miami’s Swankiest Garage Becomes a Gallery Yet Again
text: Right now, the art world and its glamorous interlopers are revving their engines for this year’s Art Basel Miami Beach, which opens to the public on Thursday. Meanwhile, at the city’s premier automotive temple, grease monkeys are putting the final touches on an exhibition of cars as art. The Swiss-minimal garage at 1111 Lincoln Road, designed by Herzog & de Meuron, has become the apogee of Art Basel lavishness and excess since opening in 2010, with pop-ups galore (like this year’s Colette-sponsored Art Drive Thru, which opened yesterday), and events like 2011’s Ferrari fete, during which hot rods paraded up and down the structure’s seven levels of open-air ramps all night long.

headline: How Much Would You Pay to Have a Baby?
text: I love casinos. The sounds, the lights, the corny decadence. … I love it all, except for one thing: I hate losing money. So in the handful of times I’ve visited one, I’d give myself a high-low limit. If I lost $100 or won $200, I’d have to leave. I guess I’m not much of a gambler.

headline: Billy Joel to Be a Madison Square Garden ‘Franchise’
text: Add Billy Joel to the list of franchises — sports teams, until now — that call Madison Square Garden home. At a news conference on Tuesday morning at which Mr. Joel, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and several Garden executives spoke, Mr. Joel was named as the Garden’s first entertainment franchise, joining the Knicks, the Rangers and the Liberty.

headline: Soccer and Logic Don’t Often Mix
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — In 500 words, I’m about to logically explain why I do not subscribe to logic.

headline: TimesTalks: Diego Luna
text: The actor and director talks about his upcoming movie "Elysium," and the differences between acting for theater and film.

headline: Wall Street Toasts Blankfein and Judaism at UJA-Federation Dinner
text: Goldman Sachs emerged from the financial crisis as the whipping boy of Wall Street. But on Monday evening, the firm’s chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, was feted like a king.

headline: Biden Asked to Raise Case of Jailed Nobel Laureate and Wife
text: A group of human rights organizations has issued an open letter calling on Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to press Chinese officials on the plight of two of the country’s most prominent dissidents, Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned Nobel Laureate, and his wife, Liu Xia, who is under house arrest and said to be suffering from severe depression.

headline: TimesTalks: Ricky Gervais
text: The comedian reflects on his approach to comedy, the success of "The Office" and his new series on Netflix, "Derick."

headline: Do You Get In Any Reading Over the Holidays?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Anna Holmes and Pankaj Mishra reminisce about travel, solitude and guilty pleasures.

headline: A Chance to Step Into Disney’s Childhood
text: LOS ANGELES — The on-again-off-again campaign to turn Walt Disney’s Chicago birthplace into an attraction has taken an unexpected new turn. And two theme park ride designers who mostly work for Disney rivals are at the wheel.

headline: Louis C.K. Signs Production Deal With FX
text: Louis C. K. is extending his association with the FX network, signing a production deal that will create new shows for the networks under the FX umbrella.

headline: The King of Fruits
text: Durian stinks so badly that it’s banned from hotels and mass transit in parts of Southeast Asia, yet it’s regarded by some as a delicacy.

headline: A Love Letter to a Smelly Fruit
text: When my friend Bob Halliday thinks about durians, the tropical fruit that some say smells like garbage, he not only salivates with delighted anticipation, but he also “foams like a geyser.” Those were the words he used on the eve of our visit to an orchard north of Bangkok that was filled with these green spiky fruits dangling dangerously from towering trees.

headline: Cultivating a Wine Region in India
text: In India, where whiskey is the alcoholic drink of choice and teetotalers exist by the legions, a wine culture has been almost nonexistent. Nashik (also Nasik), a picturesque area with deep green rolling hills about a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Mumbai, is finally changing that perception. More than a half-dozen wineries with attractive tasting rooms and, in some cases, restaurants and accommodations, have opened here in the last several years and are turning this fertile valley into a popular oenophile destination for trendsetting Indians.

headline: Volcker Rule on Bank Risk Approaches Its Final Edits
text: Updated, 8:56 p.m. | Federal regulators have reached a tentative agreement to complete a rule aimed at Wall Street risk-taking, federal officials said on Tuesday, overcoming internal squabbling and an onslaught of Wall Street lobbying that stymied them for years.

headline: Versace Valuation May Be as Over the Top as Its Clothes
text: Versace’s valuation looks as aggressive as its outfits. The Italian fashion house, which is sizing up buyout firms and sovereign wealth funds to finance a capital increase, believes it is worth more than 1 billion euros, or $1.36 billion, and could triple in value in three years. There is real potential, because Versace has fallen behind industry trends. But a big price tag for a skimpy minority stake next to a powerful family? That’s hard to pull off.

headline: Fed Policy and Inequality
text: Catherine Mann, an economist at Brandeis University, discusses the ways in which quantitative easing has increased wealth among both high-income and lower-income groups.

headline: The Gun Report: December 3, 2013
text: In September, Gary Roberts, 57, was shot to death by his wife after he threatened to kill the police officers who were on their way to the couple’s Greenfield, Ind., home to question him about the arsenal of explosives and some 1,400 weapons he had stored in the basement. Elizabeth Roberts, 56, his wife of 31 years, told police that her husband began loading ammunition into a gun magazine and pledged to kill any officers who came to the home. When she said she would shoot him to prevent the impending bloodshed, he handed her a gun loaded with hollow-point bullets and told her to do what she had to do. She fired one shot into his chest, killing him.

headline: For World Cup Draw: 32 Divided by 4
text: FIFA announced which teams would be in each of the four pots for Friday’s World Cup draw in Brazil during a news conference on Tuesday in Bahia, Brazil.

headline: Whom the Fed Is Enriching
text: At a November confirmation hearing, Janet Yellen was asked whether Federal Reserve policies had mostly benefited wealthy people, while doing little to improve life for the common man. After all, ultra-low interest rates and quantitative easing likely contributed to the run-up in stock prices over the last few years.

headline: A Documentary Shortlist Filled With Politics and Music
text: Updated, 3:47 p.m. | Working from a record 151 qualifying films, the motion picture Academy on Tuesday announced the 15 films on the shortlist for the best documentary feature Oscar:

headline: Out of the Doldrums, Automakers Post Strong U.S. Sales
text: Sales over the Thanksgiving weekend may have been a disappointment for the nation’s retailers, but they were a boon for automakers, lifting their sales in the United States for November to the best rate since before the recession.

headline: Thomas Keneally to Write Book and Lyrics for New Musical
text: Thomas Keneally, best known for writing “Schindler’s List” but also the author of historical works about the founding of his native Australia, will turn to that subject in “Transport,” a new musical for which he’s written the book and lyrics.

headline: 1930 Model A Ford Makes Cross-Country Voyage on Second Try
text: Sometimes, it’s best to cut one’s losses and move on. For Rod Wade, the Australian automotive adventurer whose cross-country run last month in a 1930 Model A Ford was abbreviated by a broken crankshaft, cutting his losses wasn’t in the cards. It was time to move on; all the way across the United States.

headline: Little Things Stand Out About Baseball’s Best
text: The Hall of Fame is baseball’s finish line, the ultimate validation for careers that awed and inspired us when we were much younger. We view it with nostalgia because we want to remember the good.

headline: Extra FaceTime IDs, and Reordering Email
text: Multiple IDs

headline: Pope Francis and the Ghost of Sargent Shriver
text: After my post yesterday contrasting the challenges the Francis era may offer to American Catholics who feel at home on the political right of center with the opportunities it may open up to their more liberal co-religionists, it’s only fair to also point out the implicit challenge that the new pope is offering to liberal Catholics as well — or at least to liberal Catholics who see their relationship to the church in terms of fidelity as well as criticism and dissent.

headline: Sleep and the City
text: Travelers looking for a good night’s rest in a city that never sleeps can customize their experience at WestHouse, a luxury boutique hotel scheduled to open in late December.

headline: Windsor Terrace: Less Way Station, More Destination
text: For decades the curved, somewhat comma-like shape of Windsor Terrace, in central Brooklyn, seemed almost to symbolize its role: a kind of geographic pause between larger flanking neighborhoods. Squeezed between Park Slope and the various parts of the Flatbush area, and linking them in the process, Windsor Terrace never really achieved the stature of its bigger-name peers.

headline: Fried Chicken’s Northern Exposure
text: Here’s a culinary etiquette question: Does a bottle of bourbon qualify as a “dish,” as in “bring your favorite Southern dish”?

headline: Why Tracey Emin Is in a Miami State of Mind
text: Tracey Emin has always been associated with London. It’s where she studied painting before achieving early notoriety as one of the “Young British Artists.” It’s the place she unveiled her infamous camping tent, embroidered with the names of all the people she’d ever slept with. It’s the city in which she continues to live, work and teach.

headline: Taconic Capital Co-Founder to Retire
text: Kenneth D. Brody, a co-founder of the hedge fund Taconic Capital Advisors, plans to retire from his full-time role by the end of the year, he told his investors on Tuesday.

headline: Editor Describes Pressure After Leaks by Snowden
text: The top editor of the British newspaper The Guardian told Parliament on Tuesday that since it obtained documents on government surveillance from a former National Security Agency contractor, Edward J. Snowden, it has met with government agencies in Britain and the United States more than 100 times and has been subjected to measures “designed to intimidate.”

headline: Preview: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
text: Oscar Isaac and Adam Driver in a clip from the Coen brothers’ new movie.

headline: New York, Circa the ’60s, Reborn in New York, Circa Today
text: How the Coen brothers’ new film starring Oscar Isaac and Carey Mulligan recreates a lost bohemian downtown.

headline: Positively Fourth Street, All Over Again
text: One primary pleasure of the Coen brothers’ new movie, “Inside Llewyn Davis” — a film that is abundant in its pleasures — is revisiting a New York that most New Yorkers thought was gone for good: Greenwich Village of the early 1960s, when downtown was teeming with bohemians and dreamers and not with lost tourists holding upside-down maps. “Davis” follows a Bob Dylanesque folk singer named Llewyn Davis and unfolds mostly (with a few detours to far-flung uptown and Chicago) in that fabled realm of a lost New York, complete with cold-water flats and smoke-filled subterranean clubs.

headline: Syria Crisis Is Worsening, U.N. Relief Official Says
text: UNITED NATIONS — The top emergency relief official at the United Nations expressed new alarm on Tuesday at the humanitarian crisis caused by Syria’s civil war, telling the Security Council that despite some modest progress, both the government and insurgent sides were still impeding urgent deliveries of food and medicine to millions of desperate civilians.

headline: Text to Text | ‘I Have a Dream’ and ‘The Lasting Power of Dr. King’s Dream Speech’
text: Last summer was the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. painted his dream of racial equality and justice for the nation that still resonates with us. “I have a dream,” he proclaimed, “my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.” In this Text to Text, we pair Dr. King’s pivotal “I Have a Dream” speech with a reflection by the Times literary critic Michiko Kakutani, who explores why this singular speech has such lasting power.

headline: Beyond Brisket and Burritos in Austin, Tex.
text: People who say that Austin isn’t at all like the rest of Texas should look a little harder. The capital city may swaddle its Lone Star bravado in slacker irony, swap out big hair for cycling musculature and express its rugged individualism with six-strings rather than six-shooters ... but really, we’re talking about the same prideful, gabby, strangely infectious psychodynamic. Even for Austin’s most rabid Gov. Rick Perry haters, defecting from the state is not an option: they adore being Texans, one and all, and appreciate that the term sets them apart somehow.

headline: How a Growing Business Set Itself Apart
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners were joined by a guest, Rebecca Cenni, founder of Atrium Staffing. This post continues the conversation with Ms. Cenni, who explained how her $140 million staffing and payroll firm differentiates itself.

headline: Court Is Accused of Unfairly Targeting a Continent’s Leaders
text: Little noticed outside Africa, a movement against the International Criminal Court has been brewing on the continent this fall, challenging a unique but often polarizing international mechanism to prosecute grave human rights abuses.

headline: International Criminal Court Wrestles With Applying Law, or Bending
text: THE HAGUE — As the International Criminal Court takes up its highest-profile trials to date — the case of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya and his deputy, William Ruto — it is wrestling with a question that so often looms over international justice: Should the law prevail, or bend to the demands of diplomacy and political stability?

headline: Surprising New Face in Arabic Music
text: The Arab world has an unlikely new star: an American who sings — but barely speaks — Arabic. Not only that, her genre is traditional Arab music.

headline: TimesTalks: Kim Cattrall
text: The actress talks about acting for theater as opposed to television, and moving out from under the shadow of Samantha, her character on “Sex and the City.”

headline: TimesTalks: Metallica
text: The band talks about their new film, “Metallica: Through The Never.”

headline: Charlie Bird
text: Inside the SoHo restaurant that gets packed early on and stays that way for hours.

headline: A Relaxed Air, but Attention Must Be Paid
text: THE HARDEST-WORKING WOMAN in the food business one recent night was the host of Charlie Bird, in SoHo. Armed with nothing but good cheer and a smile that could stop a war, she had the unenviable job of preventing an uprising in a waiting area by the door that might comfortably hold three people if they were very skinny and could survive for minutes at a time without breathing. There were around 10 of us.

headline: ‘American Hustle’ Makes a Showing With Critics Circle
text: The late-arriving “American Hustle,” which reunites David O. Russell with much of his casts from “The Fighter” and “Silver Linings Playbook,” was the surprise winner with the New York Film Critics Circle, which announced its year-end picks on Tuesday. The film, set loosely around the 1970s Abscam scandal, took best feature, best screenplay (for Mr. Russell and Eric Singer) and best supporting actress, for Jennifer Lawrence. It is among the final entries in the very tight Oscar race this season and beat out expected competitors like “12 Years a Slave,” “Nebraska” and “Inside Llewyn Davis.”

headline: The Art of Plating
text: Amanda Cohen, the chef and owner of Dirt Candy, showcases the different qualities of spinach in this beautiful construction.

headline: Beautiful Plates
text: Food meets plate in a process far more elaborate and elemental than many may realize.

headline: The Ceramic Canvas
text: Wait. We know you’re hungry. We know you’re ready to use that shiny fork as a battering ram. But before you dismantle and devour that dish of beautiful food placed in front of you, take a moment to look at it. Really look.

headline: Americanized Labor Policy Is Spreading in Europe
text: In 2008, 1.9 million Portuguese workers in the private sector were covered by collective bargaining agreements. Last year, the number was down to 300,000.

headline: Supreme Court Considers Frequent Flier Contracts
text: WASHINGTON — Rabbi S. Binyomin Ginsberg used to fly often enough on Northwest Airlines that he achieved Platinum Elite status, the highest level. But the airline revoked his membership in its frequent flier program in June 2008, saying that he had abused it by making too many complaints and by booking himself on full flights in the hope of being bumped.

headline: House Votes to Extend Gun Law Without New Provisions for 3-D Printed Firearms
text: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Tuesday to extend a law banning firearms that can pass undetected through airport X-ray machines, but left out provisions that law enforcement officials say are necessary to combat the growing threat of guns made with 3-D printers.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Black Action Tees
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: The Real Health Care Distraction?
text: In the last few weeks it’s been trendy, in Republican circles, to claim that anything Democrats do or say unrelated to the Affordable Care Act is a ploy to “distract” attention away from the problematic HealthCare.gov rollout. (Really, anything: filibuster reform or a diplomatic breakthrough with Iran.)

headline: She Makes That Much on Broadway?
text: On TV Land, you don’t sweat the details. Three Hollywood harpies accidentally land in Ohio, move in with Betty White and date young cornfed hunks (“Hot in Cleveland”)? Of course. Three men share an apartment owned by their wacky divorce lawyer (“The Exes”)? Why not.

headline: When Life Resembles Art … or at Least Monty Python
text: As a dude of a certain age whose so-called formative years were lived in the mid-’80s, I have spent a good portion of my life trying to perfect my Cockney accent in falsetto and forcing Monty Python expressions into everyday conversation. Sometimes it’s not easy. Then there are times like last week.

headline: Oyster Bar Franchise Opens in Brooklyn
text: Headliner

headline: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Central African Republic, Thailand, Bahrain and Ukraine.

headline: Obama Urges Focus on Health Care Law’s Benefits
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday urged Americans to “refocus on” the benefits of the Affordable Care Act, pointing to people who had already avoided costly health care expenses because of the law’s provisions.

headline: The City of Angels and Crime and Seriously Stylish Hats
text: Warning: In the Land of Noir, things move more slowly than they do in our usual television cop show universe. Men — and, yes, it’s mostly men in the Land of Noir — walk with an odd combination of shuffle and swagger that is not designed for speed. Conversation is sparse. Deliberate. Nobody’s in a hurry to get his words out.

headline: T.R. Fehrenbach, Historian, Dies at 88; Chronicler of Larger-Than-Life Texas
text: T. R. Fehrenbach, a historian and journalist whose sweeping treatment of Texas history portrayed the state as an almost mythic land, powerfully pleasing many Texans while mightily rankling others, died Sunday in San Antonio. He was 88.

headline: Expansive and Teasing, and Still a Superstar
text: For the last few years, Garth Brooks, ubiquitous high-energy country megastar of the 1990s, has been more or less in hiding, spending time with his family and only peeking his head out from under his shell for occasional one-man shows — focusing on the music that influenced him — at the Wynn Las Vegas casino, where he had a residency beginning in 2009.

headline: Kozlowski Is Granted Parole
text: Come January, L. Dennis Kozlowski’s long tenure in New York State’s penitentiary system will near its end.

headline: Bach as a Mensch and an Imperfect Human Being
text: Not to proclaim that an author’s first book will necessarily stand as his magnum opus, but it is hard to imagine what the English maestro John Eliot Gardiner, 70, might do to surpass “Bach: Music in the Castle of Heaven” in its commitment, scope and comprehensiveness. True, as Mr. Gardiner writes and has amply shown over the decades, he is “equally (though differently) drawn to the three B’s — Beethoven, Berlioz and Brahms — and could have mustered equivalent fervor for writing about Monteverdi, Schütz or Rameau.”

headline: On Piano, and Staying Attuned to the Audience
text: Eric Yves Garcia, a Manhattan piano bar entertainer who toiled in semi-oblivion at Chez Josephine until his recent appearances at the New York Cabaret Convention, belongs to the school of jazz-leaning connoisseurs of the American Songbook epitomized by the irreplaceable Bobby Short. If Mr. Garcia’s sprightly appearance at the Laurie Beechman Theater on Monday evening says anything about the frustrations of turning out semi-anonymous background music in a restaurant, it might be that inside many a piano bar musician beats the heart of an aspiring concert entertainer, waiting for his moment.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The World’s Most Expensive Phone, and Why We Like Listicles
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Instruments May Look Standard, but the Sounds They Create Are Not
text: At the start of the Mannes Percussion Ensemble’s concert on Monday evening James Baker, the ensemble’s director, announced a change in the program. Two planned works had been dropped, he said, because the group had decided it would rather prepare fewer pieces at a higher level of polish than bite off more than it could comfortably chew.

headline: Fraternal Ties, of Gut and Sinew
text: In movies, the working class often serves as a sacrificial emblem of the failure of the American dream, one that these days is often embellished with lovingly photographed decay and an elegiac air. Set in a corroded stretch of the Rust Belt, “Out of the Furnace” ups the ante with a story of two blue-collar brothers — a steel mill welder and a former soldier — who are as totemic as the figures immortalized in a Works Progress Administration mural. It’s a heavy, solemn tale of blood ties that turns into a melodramatic gusher filled with abstractions about masculinity, America and violence, but brought to specific, exciting life by Christian Bale, Casey Affleck and Woody Harrelson.

headline: Proving That Ailey Never Stands Still
text: On a recent afternoon, 10 dancers from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater caught their breath after a run-through of “Chroma,” an exceptionally fast-paced, convoluted work by the British choreographer Wayne McGregor. The windows of the fifth-floor studio offered sweeping views of Midtown Manhattan, but the city looked almost sleepy next to the dancing that had just happened.

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute: Dec. 03 at 6 p.m.
text: President Obama makes a health care announcement; a government shake-up in North Korea; and the future of the pencil.

headline: A Home School Where the Lessons Are Subtle
text: Desultory, dauntingly DIY but secretly efficient, “Breakfast With Curtis” is something like a leafy summer afternoon in movie form. This is the third feature from the writer and director Laura Colella, who has shot it in and around her own well-loved, multifamily Victorian and the house next door. Her neighbors play the film’s overlapping, underdressed group of friends and family. This micro-indie movie is partly about a taciturn, home-schooled teenager, Curtis (subtly played by Jonah Parker), coming out of his shell, but it’s mostly about hanging out.

headline: Police Officer Charged in Queens Extortion Racket
text: Shortly after opening a new restaurant in Astoria, Queens, this year, the owner received an unwelcome visitor, he said, who explained that it would cost him money to operate “in our neighborhood.”

headline: Illinois Legislature Approves Retiree Benefit Cuts in Troubled Pension System
text: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — The Illinois legislature on Tuesday ended a day of emotional debate and fierce back-room arm-twisting by passing a deal to shore up the state’s debt-engulfed pension system by trimming retiree benefits and increasing state contributions.

headline: Bryant and Messi Try to Repeat a Hit Airline Ad
text: A commercial for Turkish Airlines that unexpectedly became a worldwide hit in social media, drawing more than 105 million views on YouTube in the last 12 months, is getting a sequel.

headline: A Rare Glimpse at Some of the Finest Jewelry and Objects Ever Made
text: When Kate Middleton married Prince William in Westminster Abbey in April 2011, she wore a delicate Cartier diamond tiara known as the “Halo Scroll.” In 1936, the Duke of York purchased it from the French jeweler for his wife, three weeks before they ascended to the throne and became King George VI and Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother. She later gave it to her daughter, Princess Elizabeth — now Queen Elizabeth II — as an 18th birthday present.

headline: Busy in Gray Areas of the Law in a Bid to Control a Rival
text: In Charles W. Ergen’s war for LightSquared, the fiercest fight involves a legal loophole.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ to Raise Money for Liz Cheney’s Senate Bid
text: WASHINGTON — Supporters of Liz Cheney, whose campaign for a Senate seat in Wyoming got off to a rocky start, have created a “super PAC” to bolster her “name awareness and approval rating.” The group is hosting a high-dollar fund-raiser this week in Washington featuring her father, former Vice President Dick Cheney, at a Georgetown restaurant, according to an emailed invitation.

headline: A Traditional Audio Company Enters the Wireless Realm
text: The growth of the market for wireless speakers has slowly been enticing more traditional audio companies to cut their wires, too. And a recent offering from Klipsch shows that high-end audio companies know how to fit a lot of sound into tiny wireless speakers.

headline: Real Estate Rumblings in Ho Chi Minh City
text: After years in the doldrums, the Vietnamese real estate market is showing signs of life. But many analysts say banking and political reforms are needed before a healthy rebound will be possible.

headline: Optimism Over Vietnam Property, With Caveats
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — Dinh Thien Thien’s barbecue business bloomed just as Vietnam’s property market wilted. It was not a coincidence.

headline: Lampert’s Firm Cuts Its Stake in Sears
text: Edward S. Lampert, the hedge fund manager who serves as Sears Holdings‘ chief executive, remains the struggling retailer’s biggest shareholder.

headline: A Gaming Headset for Players on the Go
text: As consumers shift more of their attention from console games to mobile apps, gaming accessory makers are following suit. The latest offering comes from Turtle Beach, which has released a headset designed specifically for mobile media.

headline: Frank, Once Kidd’s Right-Hand Man, Is Demoted
text: Less than two hours before the Nets tipped off against the Denver Nuggets on Tuesday, Coach Jason Kidd announced a change to his staff. Lawrence Frank, Kidd’s top lieutenant and the Nets’ only assistant with head-coaching experience, was being reassigned away from game and practice duties.

headline: Quest for Meaning, Millennial Edition
text: To the Editor:

headline: Holiday Dressing Answers May Be in Your Closet Now
text: The most wonderful time of the year can be more stressful than festive if you’re fretting about what to wear (and perhaps a looming credit-card bill). But you may not need to look beyond your closet. There must be a black dress, white dress, pantsuit or sequined sheath in there somewhere. Then give it the fun it deserves with unexpected, eye-catching accessories. Any one of these will do the statement-making trick.

headline: President Karzai and the Afghan Security Agreement
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Self-Gifting’? Please
text: To the Editor:

headline: The App Age Comes to a Longstanding Tradition
text: These days, even many of the most ingrained holiday traditions are subject to technological advances.

headline: Keep the Old-Style Phones!
text: To the Editor:

headline: Activists Fear Egypt’s Police Force, First Target of Protests, Is Out for Revenge
text: As they have for nearly three years, activist filmmakers in Egypt continue to document the death of protesters at the hands of the security forces.

headline: Director of Barnes Foundation Steps Down
text: The Barnes Foundation announced on Tuesday that Derek Gillman will step down as executive director and president as of Jan. 1 to become a visiting professor at the Westphal College of Media Arts & Design at  Drexel University.

headline: We Hear You. You Don’t Want to Hear Us.
text: My column this week, “Disruptions: Want Calls on Planes? You’ll Need to Speak Up,” generated quite a vociferous response from readers. I noted in the column that the Federal Communications Commission was considering allowing the use of cellphones on planes, and readers noted in the comments that they were vehemently against such an idea.

headline: For the First Time, a Former Player Will Lead the Baseball Players’ Union
text: Less than two weeks after the death of the union leader Michael Weiner, the executive board of the baseball players’ association named Tony Clark as his replacement on Tuesday. Clark, a former first baseman for several teams, including the Yankees and the Mets, will formally assume the role after a vote by the general membership.

headline: What Bankruptcy Means for Detroit
text: City officials hope a judge’s ruling allowing bankruptcy will release Detroit from the grip of creditors and move it toward recovery.

headline: Panel Says Global Warming Carries Risk of Deep Changes
text: Continued global warming poses a risk of rapid, drastic changes in some human and natural systems, a scientific panel warned Tuesday, citing the possible collapse of polar sea ice, the potential for a mass extinction of plant and animal life and the threat of immense dead zones in the ocean.

headline: A Handwritten Apology
text: According to documents released at his arraignment in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Tuesday, Cory Dunton, the suspect in a shooting last month at the Bryant Park skating rink, asked for a pen and paper after hearing that a victim in the shooting might have been left paralyzed.

headline: Greenpeace Activists Detail Russia’s Capricious Justice System
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — An odd thing about the investigation into what exactly happened in the Arctic on Sept. 18 between activists on a Greenpeace International ship and the Russian authorities was how little the investigators asked about the episode when they called the 30 crew members in for questioning, one by one, from their isolated holding cells.

headline: An Unexpected Apology Stokes the Embers of a Feud
text: When it comes to Wall Street grudge matches, this one is sure to rank right up there.

headline: Maine: Shrimp Season Is Called Off
text: Regulators on Tuesday voted to cancel the 2014 shrimp season in the Gulf of Maine, the first such shutdown since 1978. Before the vote, the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission’s Northern Shrimp Section cited research that shows stocks of shrimp are at historic lows, because of factors such as overfishing and warming waters. The fishery for northern shrimp, also called pink shrimp, was worth an estimated $1.2 million in its limited 2013 season; in 2011, according to regulators, it was worth more than $10 million.

headline: Andro Linklater, Who Re-Examined American Frontierism, Dies at 68
text: While on a book tour of the United States in the 1990s, Andro Linklater, a Scottish journalist and popular historian, peered from his plane at the vast checkerboard orderliness of America’s former wilderness frontier and asked himself a historian’s sort of question: Which came first, the pioneers or the surveyors?

headline: Tests on Arafat Find No Proof of Radiation Poisoning
text: PARIS — French investigators studying the remains of Yasir Arafat have concluded that the Palestinian leader most likely did not die of radiation poisoning, Mr. Arafat’s widow, Suha, said here Tuesday. She noted, however, that the investigators did find unusually elevated levels of radioactivity in and around his body.

headline: In Kiev City Hall, Energized Protesters Settle In for a Long Winter’s Uprising
text: KIEV, Ukraine — On the granite facade of the hulking City Hall building near Independence Square, the center of the protests here, graffiti in black spray paint declares “Headquarters of the Revolution!!” Inside, protesters are preparing for a long stay.

headline: Immigration Activists End a Fast on the National Mall
text: WASHINGTON — A longtime labor leader and two other advocates of an immigration overhaul ended their water-only fasts on Tuesday in a tent on the National Mall, the 22nd day of an effort to press the House to take up legislation on the issue.

headline: Knicks’ Three-Win Circus Draws Spotlight
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Carmelo Anthony acknowledged that the Knicks were concerned about Coach Mike Woodson’s job security. A television reporter asked Kenyon Martin if he hated the Nets. Iman Shumpert bolted for the security of the locker room. Metta World Peace said he got into a fight over pasta.

headline: More Late-Night Time for Boston Transit Users
text: BOSTON — Ian Gillespie, 23, recently moved to Boston from the New York area and is among the legion of transplants who have been surprised and disappointed that the subway here, known as the T, shuts down at 1 a.m. on weekends.

headline: Cribbs Is Put on Injured Reserve
text: The Jets signed the returner Darius Reynaud on Tuesday and placed Josh Cribbs on injured reserve with a shoulder injury.

headline: Germany: Ban Sought on Political Party
text: Germany’s 16 states submitted a petition to the Constitutional Court on Tuesday to ban the far-right National Democratic Party on the grounds that its ideology resembles that of the Nazis. Germany has strict laws on banning political parties and a similar attempt failed a decade ago. The states insist they have enough evidence to prove the National Democratic Party poses a danger to democracy and the rule of law.

headline: Parents Push to Quiet Roar From Trains Near Queens School
text: Two fingers on the lips, two fingers from the other hand held aloft: That is the sign youngsters at Public School 85 Judge Charles Vallone Elementary in Astoria, Queens, have learned to flash when nothing can be heard above the subway’s roar.

headline: Let Slip the Drones of Peace
text: The United Nations proudly announced on Tuesday the deployment of its first peacekeeping drone, an unmanned aerial vehicle that will be used to monitor the forested border between the Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda, looking for fighters from the defeated M23 rebel group and other militias.

headline: The Secrets Inside Us
text: WHEN the news broke recently that a team of Belgian scientists had “discovered” a new body part — a ligament located just outside the knee — the first place my mind went was to Padua.

headline: The Poor Need Cheap Fossil Fuels
text: PRAGUE — THERE’S a lot of hand-wringing about our warming planet, but billions of people face a more immediate problem: They are desperately poor, and many cook and heat their homes using open fires or leaky stoves that burn dirty fuels like wood, dung, crop waste and coal.

headline: Newsweek Plans Return to Print
text: Newsweek, the struggling weekly magazine that ceased print publication last year, plans to turn the presses back on.

headline: Corruption Panel’s Report Offers Look at the Payback Culture in Albany
text: A politically connected organization had just received a large grant from New York State, but its executives were not satisfied.

headline: Trader’s Defense Lawyer Challenges Memory of a Crucial Witness
text: Jon Horvath has been positioned as a star witness for federal prosecutors in the insider trading trial of Michael S. Steinberg, his former boss at SAC Capital Advisors. But under questioning by the defense on Tuesday, Mr. Horvath, a former analyst at SAC, acknowledged having some memory lapses, potentially undercutting some of his credibility.

headline: $12 Billion Is Pledged to Fight AIDS, TB and Malaria
text: The world’s donor countries on Tuesday pledged $12 billion over three years to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.

headline: Rare Cancer Treatments, Cleared by F.D.A. but Not Subject to Scrutiny
text: When federal regulators permitted the sale of an unproved device that uses intense heat to combat cancer, they did so for a compelling reason, to give hope to some women desperately ill with cervical cancer.

headline: One Man Lost and Impaired, the Other Fearful and Armed
text: CHICKAMAUGA, Ga. — Deanne Westbrook had tried everything to keep her husband, Ronald, in the house.

headline: Five Former N.F.L. Players Sue the Chiefs Over Head Injuries
text: Five former Kansas City Chiefs sued the team Tuesday for not warning them of the long-term dangers of concussions they say they received during their playing days.

headline: New Leads Explored in Teenager’s Killing
text: The grapevine in the new, small high school carried the news: The mother of a dead classmate, Jennifer Negron, was visiting. Even now, almost 22 years later, Cindy Morales remembers seeing her.

headline: Case Over Gun-Safety Ads Fosters Unlikely Alliance
text: PHOENIX — A state appeals court here heard arguments on Tuesday about whether Phoenix was within its rights to remove bus shelter ads that proclaimed “Guns Save Lives,” which the city said constituted political speech. The ads, paid for by the owner of a business offering gun-safety lessons, contained text in smaller type praising the State Legislature for allowing people to carry concealed weapons without a permit.

headline: Vonn Set to Test Knee
text: Lindsey Vonn will test her injured right knee on Wednesday with a training run in advance of this weekend’s World Cup event in Lake Louise, Canada.

headline: The Interminable, Everlasting Lincolns (Part 2)
text: This is the third installment of a four-part series.

headline: Suspect in Ice Rink Shooting Writes Apology to a Victim
text: It was around the time that he was being fingerprinted last month that Cory Dunton cast aside his initial denials and asked for a pen and paper.

headline: At de Blasio’s City Hall, Expect an Outsize Role for His Wife
text: Bill de Blasio’s wife, Chirlane McCray, was fed up. An ad for her husband’s political opponent was running on her favorite radio station, and she wanted the de Blasio campaign to respond.

headline: Jihadist Groups Gain in Turmoil Across Middle East
text: WASHINGTON — Intensifying sectarian and clan violence has presented new opportunities for jihadist groups across the Middle East and raised concerns among American intelligence and counterterrorism officials that militants aligned with Al Qaeda could establish a base in Syria capable of threatening Israel and Europe.

headline: Pension Ruling in Detroit Echoes West to California
text: A judge’s decision in Michigan is resonating all the way to California.

headline: Speculating on de Blasio’s Choice for Schools Chief
text: It might normally be of little interest that Joshua P. Starr, a Maryland schools superintendent, spent the Thanksgiving holiday in Brooklyn, dining on crispy beef tongue fries and visiting a Jean Paul Gaultier exhibit.

headline: Dietary Advice for the Gluttony Season
text: Now that the gluttony season is upon us, you may be re-re-re-evaluating your diet; or perhaps you’ll be stewing on it four weeks from today, making commitments to do better before summer.

headline: Picking Sarkisian, U.S.C. Makes Gut Decision, if Not Sentimental One
text: LOS ANGELES — Pat Haden, the Southern California athletic director who still remembers what it feels like to be booed by angry fans from his days quarterbacking the Los Angeles Rams, stood in a hallway of the McKay Center and shrugged at the less-than-enthusiastic response to his hiring of Steve Sarkisian as the Trojans’ new football coach.

headline: A Eunuch in India Campaigns as a Political ‘None of the Above’
text: NEW DELHI — A rinky-dink political parade was winding through the back streets of northwest Delhi on Sunday afternoon, past narrow alleyways and a clutch of pigs, ferrying along a candidate in heavy makeup and a blue sari.

headline: At Peter Kaplan’s Funeral, Mourning the Master of the Masters
text: LARCHMONT, N.Y. — Manhattan publishing took a very sad holiday on Tuesday. Many of its better-known practitioners traveled by train, car and, in some cases, chartered bus, to Larchmont Temple in Westchester County to say farewell to one of their heroes, Peter W. Kaplan. Mr. Kaplan died last Friday of lymphoma.

headline: Fate of Detroit’s Art Hangs in the Balance
text: With a ruling by a federal judge on Tuesday that Detroit is eligible to enter bankruptcy, the fate of the city’s art collection — one of the finest in the country — now moves front and center in the legal battle over the city’s future.

headline: A Wall Street Grudge
text: Two years ago, Egan-Jones cut the rating on Jefferies. A few weeks ago, Sean Egan apologized to the investment bank’s chief executive.

headline: Bibi and Barack, the Sequel
text: Could Bibi Netanyahu and Barack Obama share the 2014 Nobel Peace Prize?

headline: Bar Exam Passed, Immigrant Still Can’t Practice Law
text: Cesar Vargas seemed to have checked all the right boxes in his quest to become a lawyer in New York State. He made honors at both college and law school in New York City, his home since coming to the United States from Mexico at age 5. He interned with a State Supreme Court judge, a Brooklyn district attorney and a United States congressman. And he passed the state bar exam.

headline: Hands-On Bavarian Count Presides Over a Pencil-Making Empire
text: STEIN, Germany — Count Anton-Wolfgang von Faber-Castell has been known to hurl wooden pencils from the tower of his castle to the stone courtyard below.

headline: More College Adjuncts See Strength in Union Numbers
text: BOSTON — Gillian Mason was passionate about literature in college, so she made a career of it, earning a Ph.D. in American studies from Boston University. She had part-time teaching jobs on different campuses, but after 10 years as an adjunct she realized that she would never find a tenure-track job, or even one that paid a living wage.

headline: Penciling In the Future
text: A visit to the pencil-making factory of Faber-Castell in Stein, Germany, one of the world's largest makers of writing instruments.

headline: Mommy, the Drone’s Here!
text: WASHINGTON — The novelty of flying cars never materialized. But flying novels are right around the corner.

headline: A Mother Leads a Family Tested by Schizophrenia
text: What Teresita Galarza didn’t know would not hurt only her. It would also take a heavy toll on some of her children.

headline: U.S. Senators Say South Korea Should Not Hire China Firm
text: WASHINGTON — Two leading senators have asked the Obama administration to warn South Korea against allowing Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications firm, to build large parts of a next-generation network for the capital city of Seoul, arguing that it could give the Chinese government a way to enter the networks of a major American ally.

headline: Considering Which Head or Heads May Roll for a Troubled Website Rollout
text: WASHINGTON — White House officials, asserting that the HealthCare.gov website is largely fixed, are under mounting pressure from Democrats and close allies to hold senior-level people accountable for the botched rollout of President Obama’s signature domestic achievement and to determine who should be fired.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 3, 2013
For Vikings, New Stadium Meets Lingering Doubts
text: MINNEAPOLIS — On a raw, wintry morning, the brothers Zygi and Mark Wilf, the owners of the Minnesota Vikings, repeatedly stuck gold-painted shovels into a mound of dirt at the groundbreaking ceremony for the team’s new stadium, next to the soon-to-be-demolished Metrodome.

headline: Keeping Shareholders in the Dark
text: Protecting investors and ensuring proper corporate governance are the essence of the mission of the Securities and Exchange Commission. But you wouldn’t know that from the recent actions of the agency and its chairwoman, Mary Jo White.

headline: Lessons Unlearned on Rail Safety
text: When a Metro-North train jumped the tracks in the Bronx on Sunday morning, killing four people and injuring more than 70, it was going 82 miles per hour, on a 30 m.p.h. curve. Why it hit that horrific speed — whether because the engineer was sleeping, distracted or incapacitated, or because of some catastrophic mechanical failure — is a question for the National Transportation Safety Board, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs Metro-North, and criminal investigators and prosecutors.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 4, 2013
text: “This once proud and prosperous city can’t pay its debts. It’s insolvent. It’s eligible for bankruptcy. But it also has an opportunity for a fresh start.”

headline: Sustaining Resilience at Sea
text: On the face of it, the value of a marine reserve — the equivalent of a national park or wildlife preserve on land — seems obvious. The oceans are in trouble, and setting aside regions of biodiversity, where fishing is strictly limited, if not prohibited, is one of the few effective means of protecting many species at once. But politically, there is nothing simple about creating marine reserves in international waters. Recently, China and Russia succeeded in blocking, yet again, the creation of a large marine reserve in Antarctica.

headline: Corrections: December 4, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: One Seeing Pink Elephants
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m going to say this up front: I like the puzzles I’ve seen by Daniel Raymon. I think he has a lot of potential as a constructor. He seems like a very nice guy. But this theme set has a glaring problem.

headline: Sock-of-the-Month Clubs Rise Online, Bringing Subscriptions to Feet
text: CONSUMERS have been enthusiastic about subscribing to an array of products, from monthly shipments of razor cartridges to regular deliveries of trial-size personal care products. But the subscription model has gained a foothold with, fittingly, socks.

headline: Richard L. Podos
text: Mr. Podos, 50, is the president and chief executive of Lance Capital, a company based in New York that provides funding for commercial real estate tenant improvement projects. Before founding the company in 2004, Mr. Podos worked at the Equis Corporation.

headline: Video: Attacks From a Credit Ratings Agency
text: Two years ago, Sean Egan, the managing director of the credit ratings agency Egan-Jones, criticized the investment bank Jefferies on CNBC, Fox Business Network and Bloomberg Television. Below are excerpts and video from some of those appearances.
