headline: Ellsbury and Yankees Near a 7-Year Deal
text: When the Yankees signed Johnny Damon away from the Boston Red Sox in 2006 — two years after he helped them beat the Yankees and win the World Series — it was a coup. Damon provided the Yankees with speed on the bases and home run power from the left side of the plate, and he helped them win a championship in 2009.

headline: Life in a Mobile Nation
text: If people relocate over and over, because they can afford to or because they can't afford not to, how does that change civic life?

headline: Judy Rodgers, Chef of Refined Simplicity, Dies at 57
text: Judy Rodgers, a chef whose San Francisco restaurant, Zuni Café, helped transform the way Americans think of food through its devotion to local, seasonal ingredients meticulously prepared, died on Monday in Berkeley, Calif. She was 57.

headline: U.N. Measure Would Send Forces to Aid Central African Republic
text: UNITED NATIONS — France formally circulated a Security Council resolution on Tuesday night that would authorize thousands of African troops, aided by hundreds of French soldiers, to restore order in the Central African Republic, a mineral-rich country that has plunged into deadly anarchy and threatens to destabilize the region.

headline: Nonprofits With Sought-After Buildings Take Advantage of a Hot Market
text: After 40 years, United Cerebral Palsy of New York City plans to move from its headquarters in the Gramercy Park neighborhood of Manhattan.

headline: The Center Cannot Hold
text: If you ask them, Americans will tell you that they want constructive compromise and a more conciliatory political regime, even though they are reluctant to reach agreement when it comes to the specific issues that they actually care about.

headline: Peter Graf, Volatile Father of Tennis Great, Dies at 75
text: Peter Graf, who as the coach and manager of the tennis great Steffi Graf acquired the nickname Papa Merciless for his stern control of almost every aspect of her life, died on Saturday in Mannheim, Germany. He was 75.

headline: How the Auto Industry Fared in November
text: The sales increase, after a slowing in September and October, was being closely watched as an indication of the recovery’s staying power.

headline: Dick Dodd, Lead Singer of the Standells, Dies at 68
text: Dick Dodd, the lead singer of the Standells, the California rock group best remembered for “Dirty Water,” which became a hit in the mid-1960s and a Boston sports anthem decades later, died on Friday in Fountain Valley, Calif. He was 68.

headline: A Stellar Backcourt Keeps the Orange Out in Front
text: SYRACUSE — Jim Boeheim sounded happy. Almost. He praised his defense. He praised his team’s conditioning. Mostly, he praised his guards.

headline: What Bankruptcy Means for Detroit
text: City officials hope a judge’s ruling allowing bankruptcy will release Detroit from the grip of creditors and move it toward recovery.

headline: A Rich Fix in the Spirit of Steinbrenner
text: It was just a line in a news release, and it was not even about Jacoby Ellsbury. But it made you stop for a moment and imagine that Hal Steinbrenner’s words had been said by his father.

headline: A Tiananmen Celebrity, With Snout, Confounds Beijing
text: It took a small, pink pig with black patches on her rump and head to accomplish what many Beijing residents consider impossible: confounding the police who constantly guard Tiananmen Square in the sensitive heart of the city.

headline: Why a Brisk Walk Is Better
text: Walking, fast or slow, is wonderful exercise. But now a first-of-its-kind study shows that to get the most health benefits from walking, many of us need to pick up the pace.

headline: Revolution Fund Invests in Sweetgreen Salad Chain
text: Venture capitalists are increasingly taking an interest in the food business, with several start-ups trying to bring fresh thinking to what consumers put on their plates.

headline: The Minimum Wage and the Laws of Economics
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: A Rise in Diversity
text: Though black and Hispanic firefighters make up a small percentage of the New York City Fire Department, the most recent class of trainees is the most diverse in the department’s history.

headline: For New York City Fire Department, More Diversity Amid Tension
text: By now, the 242 recruits at the New York City Fire Department’s training academy have climbed hundreds of flights of stairs carrying at least 100 pounds of gear. They have rushed into burning buildings, smoke-filled subway cars and a bombed-out Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus.

headline: Word of the Day | piecemeal
text: piecemeal •\ˈpes-ˌmel, -ˈmel\• adjective and adverb

headline: Shooting for a Moon Filled With Robots
text: Over the last half-year, Google has quietly acquired eight technology companies in an effort to create a new generation of robots.

headline: Google Puts Money on Robots, Using the Man Behind Android
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — In an out-of-the-way Google office, two life-size humanoid robots hang suspended in a corner.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 7 P.M. (NBC) CHRISTMAS IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER In this 81st tree-lighting ceremony, Mary J. Blige; Toni Braxton; Mariah Carey; Kelly Clarkson; Kenny Edmonds, known as Babyface; the Goo Goo Dolls; Ariana Grande; Jewel; and others will gather around a 76-foot Norway spruce. Donated by the Vargoshe family of Shelton, Conn., the tree, being hoisted into place, above, will be covered with 45,000 LED lights and topped with a Swarovski crystal star through Jan. 7. Then it will be milled for lumber for Habitat for Humanity. The Rockettes will add their kicks to the festivities, presided over by Matt Lauer, Savannah Guthrie, Al Roker and Natalie Morales of the “Today” show on NBC. The entertainment before the lighting will feature performances by Ashanti and Lauren Alaina. “SNL Christmas,” at 9, offers holiday sketches from “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Biden Urges Restraint by China in Airspace Dispute
text: BEIJING — Chinese leaders pushed back at visiting Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday over what they assert is their right to control a wide swath of airspace in the bitterly contested East China Sea. But the Chinese also indicated that they had not decided how aggressively to enforce their so-called air defense identification zone, which has ignited tensions with Japan.

headline: As Delhi Heads to Polls, a Poor Neighborhood Recalls Empty Promises
text: NEW DELHI — On Tuesday, the crowded lanes of Sangam Vihar were without those rickshaws outfitted with loudspeakers, which had been blaring political slogans in the lead-up to the state legislative assembly vote the next day. The last pamphlets had been doled out before being trampled under foot or used as napkins. No more mega rallies were planned, with most of the biggest political names having come and gone in the past few weeks as they campaigned for a contest seen as a preview for the national elections next year.

headline: Bruce Lee’s Famed Jumpsuit Goes to Auction
text: The iconic yellow jumpsuit worn by the martial artist Bruce Lee in the film ‘‘Game of Death’’ is being auctioned in Hong Kong on Thursday.

headline: Major Hezbollah Figure, Tied to Syrian War, Is Assassinated Near Beirut
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hassane Laqees was a major player in the Lebanese Shiite militant group Hezbollah from its inception three decades ago to its current intervention in Syria’s civil war. Over the years, he survived several assassination attempts.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Times Minute
text: Times Minute is a recently introduced video series featuring quick looks at top headlines, and published three times every weekday. Use the video above to answer these questions:

headline: Suining County, Where What Goes Up Often Comes Down
text: China’s space program is a subject of pride and excitement around the country. In Suining County, it’s cause for an added thrill, if an anxious one. Debris from rockets launched from the Xichang Satellite Launch Center often crashes down in that rural area of southern Hunan Province.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 4, 2013
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Obama Presses Case for Health Law and Wage Increase
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama left the White House on Wednesday for one of the capital’s working-class neighborhoods to talk about the economy, not simply to divert attention from the troubles of his Affordable Care Act but also to explain how that law, for all of its flaws, fits into his vision for Americans’ economic security and upward mobility.

headline: The Trials of Jacob Mach
text: A documentary follows a Lost Boy who, 12 years after leaving Sudan, has found that the dream of a better life is both all around and just outside his grasp.

headline: A Lost Boy Grows Up
text: Jacob Deng Mach stood 25 yards from a row of torso-shaped targets, his hands numb and twitchy in the March morning chill. It had been seven months since he entered Atlanta’s police academy, and things were not going so well. Despite three days of practice, he had failed on each of his first four tries to pass the firearms qualifying test, and his scores were largely trending in the wrong direction.

headline: Life After Death in Chicago
text: The killing of a high school honors student and majorette who had participated in President Obama’s inaugural parade earlier this year elicited national outrage. Granted, some people who had been following gun violence against young people in Chicago wondered where the outrage was when other teenage boys were murdered.

headline: What Are the Best Things You’ve Read, Watched, Heard or Played This Year?
text: In December each year, The Times publishes its critics’ “best of” lists, which compile their favorite books, movies, music, television shows, video games and more. For instance, over the weekend, the Book Review published its 100 Notable Books list, as well as its Notable Children’s Books list.

headline: New York Today: Gridlock Alert
text: Updated 12:00 p.m.

headline: Times Minute: Dec. 04 at 6 a.m.
text: Google gets robots; an unlikely Arab singer; and the world's smelliest fruit.

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: Why the Dutch Love Black Pete
text: WHEN I was growing up in Amsterdam in the 1970s, the phenomenon of Santa Claus was relatively unknown. Christmas was celebrated without Santa and mostly without gifts. St. Nicholas — Sinterklaas in Dutch — was the man with the presents.

headline: What Price Love?
text: I had an old boyfriend who now and then, late weekend mornings, would pose that steamy, love in the age of Viagra question: “Should I take a pill?”

headline: After a Car Accident, an Entrepreneur Decides to Think Big
text: It was 1996, and 22-year-old Felena Hanson was driving through an intersection in San Diego to meet friends when a fire truck smashed into her car. She broke 27 bones in her arms, legs and face. “I was in a wheelchair for about three months,” she said. “I was told I would never run again. What a great wake-up call to really give you some perspective on life.”

headline: Ukrainian President, in China, Monitors Unrest Back Home
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The bulletins started arriving from President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s news service at 6 a.m. Ukraine time on Wednesday — not with updates about the besieged public buildings or the occupation of Independence Square here by thousands of protesters — but with news of his visit to the Museum of Qin Terra Cotta Warriors and Horses in Xi’an, China.

headline: Daily Report: Google Cash Yields Leadership on New Robots
text: In an out-of-the-way Google office in Palo Alto, John Markoff reports, two life-size humanoid robots hang suspended in a corner.

headline: A By-The-Numbers Rebel
text: More than a decade after Avril Lavigne emerged from Napanee, Ontario, with dyed hair, tank tops, skinny ties and a big mouth, the matter of her inner punkishness is settled business. There is none. But Ms. Lavigne always gave great facade, and she still does.

headline: Europe Sets Big Fines in Settling Libor Case
text: LONDON — Demonstrating a new resolve to punish bank misconduct, the European Union fined a group of global financial institutions a combined 1.7 billion euros ($2.3 billion) on Wednesday to settle charges that they colluded to fix benchmark interest rates.

headline: Shanghai Students Again Top Global Test
text: Students from Shanghai have once again outscored their peers around the rest of the world in reading, math and science, according to the newly released results of an international standardized exam.

headline: Morning Agenda: European Union Imposes Fines for Rate-Fixing
text: E.U. IMPOSES FINES FOR RATE-FIXING  |  The European Union has fined a group of global financial institutions a combined 1.7 billion euros ($2.3 billion) in a landmark accord over alleged collusion to fix two benchmark interest rates, The New York Times reports. The agreement, announced by European Union antitrust officials on Wednesday, relates to actions by traders at some of the world’s largest banks, including Citigroup, Royal Bank of Scotland and Deutsche Bank, who were accused of fixing rates for the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, as it relates to the Japanese yen and the euro interbank offered rate, or Euribor.

headline: Land for Peace (of Mind)
text: JERUSALEM — Last Saturday, thousands of Israeli Bedouins and Arabs staged demonstrations, some of them violent, against a government plan to resettle the Bedouins of the Negev desert.

headline: ‘Give a Little Bit,’ by Hitmakers Supertramp and Goo Goo Dolls
text: Fans grow up. Rock bands do too.

headline: Paolo Sorrentino on ‘The Great Beauty’ and Italian Alienation
text: Updated, 4:23 p.m. | It’s been 15 years since an Italian movie, Roberto Benigni’s “Life Is Beautiful,” won the Academy Award for best foreign-language film, and in the interim only one film from that country has even received a nomination. So this year the Italians have decided to go bold and brassy and have submitted “The Great Beauty,” Paolo Sorrentino’s deliberately lurid portrayal of alienation and excess in today’s Rome.

headline: Back to the Real Lower East Side
text: Dear Diary:

headline: PREs, VSPs, and the ECB
text: Personal update: I’m traveling — family stuff, not work — so posting will be limited.

headline: 1938: Midinettes Throng Boulevards in Traditional ‘Husband Hunt’
text: St. Catherine’s Day celebrations in 1967, from the archives of France’s National Audiovisual Institute.

headline: OPEC, Foreseeing No Glut, Keeps Oil Production Level Steady
text: LONDON — Members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed on Wednesday to leave their combined daily quota for petroleum production at 30 million barrels, a decision that was expected to keep prices at their current steady and relatively high levels.

headline: Standard Chartered Warns on Consumer Banking Profit
text: LONDON – Standard Chartered, the British bank that generates most of its earnings in Asia, warned on Wednesday that operating profit at its consumer banking unit would fall this year for the first time in a decade.

headline: If You Liked ‘Stand Your Ground,’ You’ll Love the Jeffersonian Project
text: The Guardian, a British newspaper, has made American headlines recently for publishing revealing documents about the National Security Agency. On Tuesday it ventured straight into domestic political territory with an eye-opening set of leaked documents about a conservative advocacy organization with a well-financed presence in this country’s state capitals.

headline: Travelers’ Tails
text: Based on the evidence presented in two new picture books, animals have a big advantage over humans when it comes to international travel. With no need for passports, reservations, foreign currency or fanny packs, they simply flit from place to place, enjoying the best views without ever having to wait in line.

headline: Books That Tell the Story of Work
text: “My Antonia.” “The Devil Wears Prada.” “The Wealth of Nations.”

headline: A Princess Finds Her Dark Side
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — In “American Hustle,” the latest film by the director David O. Russell, Rosalyn Rosenfeld (Jennifer Lawrence) plants a lipstick-smearing kiss on Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), a grifter who is having an affair with a fellow con artist (Christian Bale), who just happens to be Rosalyn’s husband. The kiss caps off a scene of rage-filled accusations and not-so-veiled threats. The possibility that members of the Mafia might kill all three of them only ratchets up the heat.

headline: Train Had a Warning System, Just Not in the Operator’s Cab
text: The Metro-North Railroad train that derailed on Sunday included a system designed to warn an operator of a potential accident. But such an “alerter,” which can automatically apply the brakes if an operator is unresponsive, was not in the cab where William Rockefeller apparently fell into an early-morning daze at the controls. It was at the other end of the train.

headline: Today in Small Business: Remember Groupon?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: To Make Hospitals Less Deadly, a Dose of Data
text: Going to the hospital is supposed to be good for you. But in an alarming number of cases, it isn’t. And often it’s fatal. In fact it is the most dangerous thing most people will do.

headline: Truck With Radioactive Load Is Recovered in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — The theft of a truck carrying radioactive material, the kind used in hospitals but also potentially as a dirty bomb, unnerved Mexico and set off a two-day hunt before both the vehicle and its potentially lethal contents were found Wednesday at nightfall.

headline: The 10 Best Books of 2013
text: The year’s best books, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.

headline: Brazuca: The World Cup Ball
text: Thirty-two teams. Eleven cities. Hundreds of players. Millions of fans. Just one ball.

headline: Wanderlust | The Crowds Swell on Mexico’s Pacific Coast
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Three-Way Race Draws Delhi’s Young, and Everyone Else, Out to Vote
text: NEW DELHI — The polling stations were supposed to close at 5:30 p.m. on Wednesday, just after sunset. But with thousands still waiting in the dark to cast their vote in the state assembly elections, the Delhi Election Commission decided to extend the voting until 6:30 p.m. Then to 7:30 p.m.

headline: In Our Pages: December 5
text: 1888: Preventing Egypt ‘Bloodshed’

headline: Wheelies: The Fewer Fixes Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: U.S., Stepping Up Role, Will Present West Bank Security Proposal to Israel
text: CHISINAU, Moldova — American officials plan to present the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, with detailed ideas about security arrangements on the West Bank under a possible peace agreement with the Palestinians, senior State Department officials said on Wednesday.

headline: The South’s Forgotten Painter
text: The Southern painter Conrad Wise Chapman is not nearly so well known as his Northern colleagues Winslow Homer and Sanford Gifford, but he deserves historical attention – if only because he appears to have been the only Southern artist to sustain a career while wearing the uniform of the Confederate Army.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Out of the Furnace’
text: Scott Cooper narrates a sequence from his film featuring Casey Affleck, Woody Harrelson and Willem Dafoe.

headline: Neon Works Light Up the Art Scene in Miami
text: “Neon makes people happy,” the British artist Tracey Emin said Tuesday night, “That’s why you see it in Las Vegas, bars, brothels and theaters.” She was standing in a darkened gallery at the Museum of Contemporary Art North Miami, surrounded by dozens of her signature neon works and looking very happy herself.

headline: For Top Deputy, de Blasio Picks Government Veteran
text: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio made the first big appointment of his administration on Wednesday, naming Anthony E. Shorris, a former executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and a commissioner in the Koch administration, his top deputy.

headline: Mandy Greenfield to Become Artistic Director of Williamstown Theater Festival
text: The Williamstown Theater Festival, a leading summertime destination for New York actors, directors, and writers to collaborate on ambitious productions, has chosen an Off Broadway leader as its new artistic director. Mandy Greenfield, the artistic producer of Manhattan Theater Club, will succeed Jenny Gersten beginning in September, the festival announced on Wednesday.

headline: Times Minute: Dec. 04 at Noon
text: Vice President Biden arrives in China; a school in Queens battles the subway; and a refugee seeks a better life.

headline: Surviving the Dark Side of Affiliate Marketing
text: The Santa Claus Christmas Store, in Santa Claus, Ind., was typical of a lot of brick-and-mortar businesses when it sought to expand its online footprint earlier this year. In addition to sprucing up its website and increasing its pay-per-click advertising budget, it joined an affiliate marketing network. This connected the 7,000-square-foot holiday emporium with the vast community of bloggers, coupon sites and other “affiliates” around the web that promote products in return for a percentage of each sale they encourage.

headline: Think the E.R. Is Expensive? Look at How Much It Costs to Get There
text: Kira Milas has no idea who called 911, summoning an ambulance filled with emergency medical technicians. Ms. Milas, 23, was working as a swim instructor for the summer and had swum into the side of the pool, breaking three teeth.

headline: Interference Costs Coach of Steelers $100,000
text: Pittsburgh Steelers Coach Mike Tomlin will presumably think twice about where he stands on the sideline this weekend when his team faces the Miami Dolphins.

headline: Is Affiliate Marketing Worth the Risk?
text: When e-commerce retailers try to drive sales by introducing affiliate marketing programs, they frequently contract outside program managers to help them recruit the best affiliates and to ferret out the coupon abusers, the “cookie-stuffers,” and the other unsavory characters who drive up their commission costs and erode their bottom lines (the subject of a small-business guide just published by The Times).

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: Parliament Versus the Press
text: Ever since Edward Snowden leaked documents on the National Security Agency’s data-mining programs, governments of countries such as the United States and Great Britain have tried to dismiss the concern that mass, secret surveillance is incompatible with an open, democratic society. So it was chilling and more than a little ironic to see members of the British Parliament grill a newspaper editor on Tuesday for daring to publish information on government spying.

headline: We’re Heading to London! (But How to Take the Dog?)
text: When this newspaper decided to transfer me from upstate New York to London, the first question from my house was what would happen to our 2-year-old golden retriever.

headline: ‘Story First, Maps Second’
text: Every tech start-up has its creation myth.

headline: Beats Music Streaming Service Says It Will Begin in January
text: The music world has spent more than a year guessing when Beats Music, the new service from the makers of Beats by Dr. Dre headphones, would arrive. Now there’s an official date, or at least a month: January.

headline: Ebb in Uranium Enrichment in U.S. Raises Questions About Nuclear Policy
text: WASHINGTON — Energy Department officials will shake hands and exchange congratulations with Russian representatives at a Port of Baltimore dockside ceremony on Tuesday as a freighter from St. Petersburg is to arrive with the final shipment of enriched uranium that was once intended for Soviet warheads. The uranium will be turned into fuel for American power reactors, completing a 20-year program, called Megatons to Megawatts, that has eliminated enough highly enriched uranium to fuel about 19,000 warheads.

headline: Classical Playlist: Anna Caterina Antonacci, Mivos Quartet, Matthew Brown and More
text: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.

headline: Poetry, and Motion
text: Since we are now entering the time of year when theater producers turn to Rockettes and blessings from Tiny Tim, consider “The Rime of the Ancient Mariner,” a new staged reading of the harrowing 1798 poem by Samuel Taylor Coleridge, counterprogramming. The epic poem, performed by the illustrious Irish actress Fiona Shaw, features a sailor stopping a man on a way to a wedding to tell of a trip at sea that becomes cursed after he shot an albatross. His crew mates force him to wear the dead bird, which gives us the expression “albatross around your neck.”

headline: Libor Bank Fines Reflect Rewards of Cooperating
text: The rewards of early settlement in the scandal involving manipulation of the London Interbank Offered Rate, or Libor, are becoming more obvious.

headline: Three Rockwell Classics Bring Nearly $57.8 Million
text: Three paintings by Norman Rockwell celebrating homey, small-town America, among the most popular of his 322 covers for The Saturday Evening Post, sold at Sotheby’s on Wednesday morning for a total of nearly $57.8 million, about twice their high estimate.

headline: Below the Line: Making ‘Gravity’
text: With its immersive feel, large-scale visuals and adventurous pacing, Alfonso Cuarón’s sci-fi drama “Gravity” has won over critics and audiences alike — a good sign its Oscar possibilities. And with its long-take action sequences set in zero gravity, it has become one of the most “how did they do that?” movies of the year. Here’s a little on how they did it.

headline: Serbian-Born Composer Wins $100,000 Prize
text: Djuro Zivkovic, a 38-year-old composer who was born in Serbia and lives in Stockholm, has won the 2014 Grawemeyer Award for Music Composition for his work “On the Guarding of the Heart.” The prize, awarded annually by the University of Louisville, is among the most prestigious international prizes for classical composition and carries a cash award of $100,000.

headline: Lundqvist’s Deal With Rangers Is ‘From the Heart’
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Henrik Lundqvist said he wanted to be a Ranger for life, and now he will have that chance. The Rangers announced Wednesday that Lundqvist had signed a seven-year contract extension, ending speculation that he might depart when his contract expired at the end of the N.H.L. season.

headline: The Magic of West Point
text: My students jest that I earned my degree from Hogwarts. I dare not correct the record.

headline: A New Plan for Norton Museum of Art From Norman Foster
text: The Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach, Fla., on Wednesday unveiled a new master plan designed by the British architect Norman Foster that will nearly double its gallery space and add an education center, auditorium and restaurant.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Redfeather Snowshoes
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Student Debt Load Found to Vary by College and State
text: Rising student debt has become a national concern, but the picture is far from uniform, with students at some colleges borrowing 10 times as much as their counterparts at other colleges, a report released Wednesday says.

headline: Super Bowl Advertising Is Already Sold Out, Fox Executives Say
text: The phrase “going, going, gone” is associated with baseball rather than football, but Fox Broadcasting is telling advertisers that commercial time during Super Bowl XLVIII on Feb. 2, 2014 is, finally, gone.

headline: Student Debt and the Class of 2012
text: The Institute for College Access and Success reports not only enormous variation in student debt from school to school, but also wide differences by region.

headline: Video: Classically Structured in Bucharest
text: Recently, Victor Placinta was strolling in the old center of Bucharest, Romania, an area known for its historic architecture, and, in more modern times, as a cultural hub where coffee-guzzling intellectuals gather. Wearing a tailored green blazer, a pinstriped shirt, a yellow tie and cuffed jeans, he described his style to an interviewer as classic.

headline: Russia’s First Smartphone Goes on Sale
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s first smartphone – a quirky, dual-screen device with a traditional LCD-color display on one side and an electronic-paper display similar to the Amazon Kindle on the other – began selling in Russia and several other European countries on Wednesday.

headline: Poll Finds Young People Souring on Health Law and Obama
text: WASHINGTON — A majority of 18- to 29-year-olds – a constituency crucial to the success of President Obama’s health overhaul — disapprove of the law, and fewer than a third of those who are uninsured are likely to sign up for coverage, according to a new poll by Harvard University’s Institute of Politics.

headline: Image of the Day: December 4
text: The day is observed to commemorate the role of Indian Navy during the India-Pakistan war of 1971.

headline: Majority of Silent Films Are Lost, Study Finds
text: The Library of Congress announced on Wednesday the results of a survey that found that 70 percent of the feature-length films made in the United States during the silent era have been lost. The reasons range from the natural deterioration over time of highly flammable nitrate film stock to outright neglect.

headline: The Gun Report: December 4, 2013
text: The N.F.L. has banned an ad by a gun components distributor from airing during the Super Bowl, despite the fact that it was specifically designed to fit the rules that would allow it to be broadcast.

headline: Phone and Tablet Covers With a Country Flair
text: Is it this nostalgic time of year that inspires people to cloak technology in a rustic covering?

headline: Enrollment Numbers Rise After Website Improves
text: WASHINGTON — About 29,000 people successfully navigated HealthCare.gov and selected an insurance plan on Sunday and Monday, more than the entire number of people who were able to enroll through the federal exchange during the month of October, according to a person familiar with the project.

headline: Baffling 400,000-Year-Old Clue to Human Origins
text: Scientists have found the oldest DNA evidence yet of humans’ biological history. But instead of neatly clarifying human evolution, the finding is adding new mysteries.

headline: Two Brothers to Lead Bowdoin Music Festival
text: The cellist David Ying and his brother, the violist Phillip Ying, have been named artistic directors of the Bowdoin International Music Festival, a summer festival and music school with a strong current of contemporary music running through its chamber and orchestral programs. The festival, held at Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Maine, was founded in 1964 by the violinist Lewis Kaplan, who will hand over the reins to the Yings at the end of the 2014 season.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Out of the Furnace’
text: In this video, the writer and director Scott Cooper narrates a sequence from his drama featuring Casey Affleck, Woody Harrelson and Willem Dafoe. He discusses where he shot the scene and how he gave direction to the actors to create a particularly tense moment between them.

headline: Microsoft Produces a Winner in Tablets
text: I can’t be the only person who needs fewer gadgets in his life.

headline: The Wedding Markup
text: My “It’s the Economy” column for this coming Sunday looks at some of the reasons that people who interact with the wedding industry so often feel ripped off.

headline: Calls to Newtown 911: ‘They’re Still Shooting!’
text: DANBURY, Conn. — The first of the calls came at 9:35 a.m.

headline: National Poetry Series, a Promoter of Poetry in Print, Faces a Shortfall
text: The National Poetry Series, a 35-year-old organization that facilitates the publication of five books of poetry each year, is in danger of closing.

headline: I Can’t Hear You, I Have an Artist in My Ear
text: Frances McDormand leads us on a brisk docent tour of the life, career and varied obsessions of the artist Suzanne Bocanegra in “Bodycast,” an odd but highly enjoyable dramatized lecture being presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Fishman Space through Saturday.

headline: In Crown Heights, a Victory Over Sharp Elbows
text: Adam Fleming and Julia Sommer were surprised by how much they loved Brooklyn.

headline: Formula One Race in New Jersey Is Delayed Again
text: PARIS — Formula One delayed its expansion into the United States market again Wednesday when its governing body dropped a proposed race in New Jersey from the 2014 schedule.

headline: Christie’s Reveals Detroit Art Appraisal
text: The heart of the world-class collection of the Detroit Institute of Arts would raise somewhere between $452 million and $866 million if sold to help the City of Detroit dig its way out of bankruptcy, Christie’s said Wednesday, announcing the results of a highly anticipated appraisal.

headline: IBM’s Big Plans for Cloud Computing
text: Ambition is an impressive thing, particularly when a desire for world domination is combined with existential survival.

headline: Homes in Rio de Janeiro
text: A market that has been “extremely profitable for the last five years” has recently stabilized, and there is less speculation.

headline: House Hunting in ... Rio de Janeiro
text: A THREE-BEDROOM DUPLEX IN THE IPANEMA DISTRICT OF RIO

headline: He’s Comfortable Working the Room
text: AGE 26

headline: Honda Unveils World Touring Car Championship Civic
text: Honda released a version of the 2014 Civic for the Fédération Internationale de l’Automobile World Touring Car Championship this week, which the automaker said would reflect recent changes to series regulations.

headline: Daughter Says Mandela on ‘Deathbed’
text: Nelson Mandela waged a long struggle against apartheid. And he is still fighting, this time for his life from what his oldest daughter is describing as his “deathbed.”

headline: ‘Her’ Wins Big at  National Board of Review Awards
text: The National Board of Review did little to provide clarity to a jumbled race with its best-of picks, announced Wednesday. The organization chose Spike Jonze’s near-future romance, “Her,” as best film, with Mr. Jonze as best director.

headline: N.F.L. Having a Hair Moment
text: Players throughout the league are exploring tonsorial frontiers that make a mockery of the sport’s rigid, militaristic heritage.

headline: A Supernova of Bad Sex? Manil Suri Wins Uncoveted Award
text: The novelist and mathematician Manil Suri has been long-listed for the Booker Prize and short-listed for the PEN/Faulkner Award. But on Tuesday he finally came in first, when his novel “The City of Devi” took home the Literary Review’s annual Bad Sex in Fiction Prize.

headline: Memorial Image of Hezbollah Official Links Him to Sectarian Battle for Syria
text: As our colleagues Anne Barnard and Ben Hubbard report from Beirut, after the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah announced the death of a senior military official on Wednesday, a photo montage of the dead man began circulating online that connected him to the sectarian battle for control of neighboring Syria.

headline: Muscle Aches From Statins? Drug Interactions May Play a Role
text: People who use statin drugs to lower their cholesterol sometimes complain of muscle pain and soreness. But a new study suggests that in some cases these side effects may be a result of combining statins with other medications.

headline: As Online Ads Look More Like News Articles, F.T.C. Warns Against Deception
text: WASHINGTON — What happens when advertising stops being obvious?

headline: A U.S. Reply, in English, to Terrorists’ Online Lure
text: WASHINGTON — Concerned by the attempts of Al Qaeda and its global affiliates to attract more Americans and other Westerners, the State Department is stepping up its online efforts to combat violent extremists’ recruiting of English speakers.

headline: Former Clinton Aide Joins News Corp. as Communications Chief
text: News Corporation announced on Wednesday that Jim Kennedy, a veteran political operative who has worked closely with Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton in a range of roles in the White House and elsewhere, will join the company as its chief communications officer.

headline: Kiev Protesters See Potent Ally Under a Spire
text: KIEV, Ukraine — After riot police officers stormed Independence Square here early Saturday, spraying tear gas, throwing stun grenades and swinging truncheons, dozens of young protesters ran, terrified, scattering up the streets. It was after 4:30 a.m., the air cold, the sky black. As they got their bearings, the half-lit bell tower of St. Michael’s Golden-Domed Monastery beckoned.

headline: Lawmakers in France Move to Discourage Sex Trade
text: PARIS — After months of heated debate, the French Parliament’s lower house on Wednesday took the first step in criminalizing the purchase of sex, approving a package of legislation to discourage prostitution.

headline: Text to Text | ‘How Photography Helps Astronomy’ and ‘Comet Nears Sun’
text: What are comets, and why should we care about them? How have scientists studied them in the past, and how do they study them now? In this Text to Text, we pair an article from the Times archives about the then-cutting edge technology that allowed astronomers to photograph Halley’s comet in 1910 with a recent Times article highlighting what astronomers hope to learn about the origins of the solar system from space-based observations of Comet ISON.

headline: A Shiplike Building Gets Another New Life
text: A 200-foot-long shiplike structure floated into its berth on Seventh Avenue half a century ago. Unable to ignore it, Greenwich Villagers have loved or hated it ever since.

headline: Homes for $725,000
text: Photos of a house on the water in Maryland, a Colonial mansion in Maine and a log house in Colorado.

headline: What You Get for... $725,000
text: PASADENA, MD.

headline: This Week’s Can’t-Miss Events Around Miami
text: The 2013 edition of Design Miami throws open its doors today, and Art Basel Miami Beach  follows suit tomorrow, but the city has been packed with fairgoers since Monday who have been flocking to the countless ancillary happenings. Below, a few destinations not to be missed. T will bring continuing coverage of what’s happening around Miami throughout the week, with some additional wrap reports early next week, so stay tuned, and be sure to follow us on Twitter and Instagram at @tmagazine for more.

headline: More Than Words Can Say
text: Last Friday, Peter Kaplan, one of the greatest editors of his generation, and a name to rank among those like Gingrich, Felker and Shawn, died of cancer at the age of 59. Within hours, fellow journalists had taken to Twitter to mourn his loss and celebrate his life.

headline: Heady Days for Hair in the N.F.L.
text: It was a scene worthy of the Roman Colosseum. After stuffing a run by Arizona’s Andre Ellington in a game Nov. 17, Jacksonville defensive end Jason Babin emerged from the pile of bodies clutching a mysterious black tangle of what looked like snakes; he thrust it into the air like a victorious gladiator.

headline: Would a South Korean Lars Peter Hansen Have Won the Nobel Prize?
text: Nobody (in the United States) likes the results of the PISA tests (the Program for International Student Assessment). As Motoko Rich writes elsewhere in The Times, 15-year-olds in the United States scored in the middle of the developed world in reading and science, while lagging in math, setting off “a familiar round” of hand-wringing (in the United States), blaming (ditto) and credit-taking (that would be in other, more successful countries, like South Korea, Japan and Singapore).

headline: Connecticut High School Cancels Student Production of ‘Rent’
text: The principal of Trumbull High School in Trumbull, Conn., has become the latest administrator to cancel a drama club production of the musical “Rent,” which deals frankly with sexuality, drug use, HIV and love in the lives of straight and gay characters.

headline: The Image Chaser
text: In the late 1990s, when Pascal Dangin was one of the few people who knew how to retouch digital images — fixing the folds of a dress, adding more sunshine — he was something of a genie in a bottle. A former hairdresser, he had taught himself to perform a new kind of magic in a world of artifice. It brought him wealth and the top fashion photographers and art directors.

headline: Martin Bashir Resigns From MSNBC Over Palin Comments
text: Following a firestorm over his recent comments about Sarah Palin, the MSNBC host Martin Bashir resigned on Wednesday, citing what he called his “ill-judged comments.”

headline: Snowboarders Hike All Night for Descent
text: In this companion piece to Teton Gravity Research’s “Higher Unplugged” series, the snowboarder Jeremy Jones traveled to the French Alps to join big mountain rider Xavier de Le Rue.

headline: NATO Cites Urgency in Reaching Pact Between U.S. and Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — International officials signaled new urgency on Wednesday for the United States and Afghanistan to reach an agreement on a long-term security deal, but officials suggested that there had been little movement on either side of the deadlock.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Michael Kors and Amy Sedaris
text: A dual review of what’s new, starring Michael Kors and Amy Sedaris.

headline: Scene City: Another Stop on Hillary Clinton’s Gala Circuit
text: Mrs. Clinton was honored at the Women for Women International’s benefit.

headline: Keeping Up the Pace With Raphael Saadiq
text: The Grammy Award-winning singer and songwriter Raphael Saadiq, 47, is the executive music producer for the musical film “Black Nativity,” which opened in theaters last week. A native of Oakland, Calif., he lives in Los Angeles and the Bay Area.

headline: What the Jetsons Will Really Be Wearing
text: WHAT WILL 2023 LOOK LIKE? Or 2061? If you take your cue from “Her,” Spike Jonze’s cinematic fantasy set in an indeterminate time and place, the future won’t look so very different from the here and now.

headline: Video: Snowboarders Hike All Night for Descent
text: In the past six years, Jeremy Jones has collaborated with Teton Gravity Research to create a trilogy of films: “Deeper,” “Further” and now “Higher.” These films document his efforts to explore and snowboard remote mountains under his own power.

headline: Icahn Discloses Latest Push for an Apple Buyback
text: Carl C. Icahn hasn’t exactly been quiet about his efforts to persuade Apple of the wisdom of a giant share buyback. Now, he’s on the cover of Time magazine pressing his case.

headline: One Direction Tops Album Chart
text: One Direction shot to the top of the Billboard album chart this week, as record sales rose over all, thanks in no small part to abundant Black Friday discounts.

headline: “12 Years a Slave” and Our Hopeless Conversation About Race
text: In the past month, two prominent liberal writers — my former colleague Frank Rich and my frequent sparring partner Jonathan Chait — have written pieces for New York Magazine linking the film “12 Years a Slave” to contemporary debates about race and conservatism. Both pieces, unfortunately, are textbook examples of why those debates tend to go nowhere in a hurry.

headline: Dialysis Raises Hard Questions for Older Patients
text: The population of people on dialysis is graying; adults aged 75 and older are the fastest growing group beginning this treatment. But often doctors don’t answer their key question: “How long can I expect to live?”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Ukraine, Gabon, Syria and Thailand.

headline: Indian Voters Poised to Weaken Governing Congress Party
text: NEW DELHI — Voters in the Indian capital turned out in record numbers on Wednesday to vote in a closely watched state election, forcing officials to keep polling places open for two or three extra hours to accommodate tens of thousands of people still waiting to vote.

headline: A New Artisan Trail in Virginia
text: Arts, food and farm lovers can explore 75 stops in Shenandoah County, Va., along the new O Shenandoah County Artisan Trail. The easily accessible region, part of the mountainous Shenandoah Valley, flanks Interstate 81 on both sides.

text: Mark Pryor of Arkansas holds one of the more vulnerable seats in the Senate. A Democrat in a state that voted for Mitt Romney in 2012, he’s facing an opponent, Rep. Tom Cotton, who’s supported by both the Tea Party and the Republican establishment.

text: WASHINGTON — John D. Apel says his First Amendment rights were violated when he was convicted of breaking federal law by entering an area set aside for protests near the main entrance to Vandenberg Air Force Base, from which he had been banned.

headline: Chinese Firm Increases Stake in Brazilian Tech Company
text: The Chinese Internet firm Qihoo 360 Technology Company has significantly increased its bet on a Brazilian cloud-based online security company, PSafe Tecnologia, by leading a $30 million round, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Elixir, a New Gay Bar in Queens
text: The diverse borough of Queens is now home to an equally diverse gay bar. Opened earlier this year in the bustling neighborhood of Astoria, Elixir is owned and operated by two transgender women, Lidia Jimenez and Marilyn Sulay, who have created a place popular with that branch of the LGBT community, too.

headline: Work Inspired by Trayvon Martin Case to Have Premiere on Thursday
text: A free showcase of short plays and a folk opera about race in the United States, inspired by debates over the Trayvon Martin case, will have its premiere on Thursday at the City University of New York Graduate Center. Called “Facing Our Truth: 10-Minute Plays on Trayvon, Race and Privilege,” the project comes from the New Black Fest, which supports innovative plays by and about black people.

headline: Giving Fans the Hits, of Course, but Including Some Reflection
text: The album Elton John released this year, “The Diving Board” (Capitol), was radically stripped down and introverted. Most of the music is acoustic: just piano, bass and drums behind exposed vocals. Would that approach carry over to his latest arena tour?

headline: For News Media, a Mostly Cautious Approach to Newtown Tapes
text: Media outlets reacted mostly with caution on Wednesday to the release of 911 calls from inside Sandy Hook Elementary School during last year’s shooting rampage in Newtown, Conn.

headline: G.M. Said to Plan Sale of Stake in Ally
text: General Motors plans to sell the last of its holdings in Ally Financial, its onetime financing arm, through a private placement of shares, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Obama Speaks About Economic Challenges
text: President Obama spoke at the Center for American Progress about the hurdles faced by some Americans, like income inequality and a growing lack of upward mobility.

headline: A Sundance Lineup Laced With Race, Horror and Family Turmoil
text: LOS ANGELES — What will art house theaters be playing in 2014? Sundance programmers on Wednesday threw their weight behind a cluster of new films that largely explore race and messy families, two tried-and-true indie themes.

headline: Sundance, Film by Film
text: The Sundance Film Festival has released its competition lineups for its 30th edition in January, and as the Bagger’s colleague Brooks Barnes reports here, though the programmers largely opted for films along themes they know well — race and family — they also took an unusual turn into horror. “Over all, we’re seeing films that are of much higher quality,” John Cooper, Sundance’s director, said. “We think a lot of that is coming from technology, which has freed filmmakers from limitations, including financial ones. You can do special effects now.”

headline: Winners Crowned at Fall North American Championships
text: PHOENIX — Several national titles have been gained here over the last few days at the Fall North American Championships.

headline: Big Composer on Campus: A Vocal Tribute to That Curriculum Mainstay, Britten
text: One hundred years after his birth, Benjamin Britten has been firmly propelled into the canon through his acceptance by major opera companies and orchestras. But what has fed and continues to feed the fire of interest is the attractiveness of his works to young musicians, and particularly young singers. It is because he has been embraced by conservatories that he has truly entered the musical bloodstream.

headline: Fifth Third Bank and Executive Settle Charges With the S.E.C.
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday that it had settled with Fifth Third Bancorp and its former chief financial officer, Daniel Poston, in a case involving improper accounting for soured mortgages around the time of the financial crisis.

headline: Miami Museum’s Challenge: The Beach
text: MIAMI — Visitors who turn off Biscayne Boulevard at the entranceway to the new Pérez Art Museum Miami may wonder for a moment if they are in the right place. The dust-covered road runs past a huge construction site, where a science museum two years from completion is still just a structural skeleton.

headline: Not Just for Breakfast Anymore
text: It started simply enough: Some months ago, I needed to make myself something to eat, and I had a few ounces of leftover scallops from dinner the night before. I remembered something I learned in Madrid called a tortillita, which inspired me to produce a kind of eggy pancake — or, if you like, a floury omelet — laced with shrimp, parsley and onion. I beat together an egg and a little flour until smooth, wanting to thicken the mixture just enough so that it wouldn’t run in the pan. I chopped the scallops and added them to the batter, along with a bit of onion, some parsley, salt and chopped fresh chile, shallow-frying all this by the spoonful in abundant oil. Predictably, the little guys — eight in total — took a couple of minutes per side to become gorgeously golden. I sprinkled them with salt, squeezed a few drops of lemon over each and ate the entire batch by myself, in about the same amount of time they took to cook.

headline: Apps to Smooth Your Journey
text: Many travel apps, while great in principle, are too complicated, wonky or simply not helpful enough to earn a spot on your smartphone home screen. Some, however, can make travel easier. And who doesn’t want that during the frantic holiday season? Besides, now that smartphones can be used during takeoff and landing, there’s no time like the present to turn yours into a personal travel assistant. So whether this season’s travels take you up in the air or on the road, here are a few of my favorite apps to make the journey smoother.

headline: Lawson, Celebrity Chef, Admits Cocaine Use, but Denies Ex-Husband’s Claims
text: LONDON — Nigella Lawson, the celebrity chef, acknowledged in court on Wednesday that she had taken cocaine and other drugs from time to time. But Ms. Lawson said she was not the kind of habitual user that her former husband, the advertising executive Charles Saatchi, had described in a private email.

headline: Suspect in Killing at Los Angeles Airport Is Held Without Bail
text: RANCHO CUCAMONGA, Calif. — The man charged with opening fire with an assault rifle, killing an airport safety officer and shooting three others at Los Angeles International Airport last month made a brief initial appearance before a federal judge here on Wednesday, his face scratched and his neck bandaged.

headline: A Plus-Size Falstaff Grows Into His Outsize Part
text: His mounting unpaid bar tab at the Garter Inn will run to its 6,000th bottle of sherry. He will send off his 400th love letter to Windsor’s merry wives. And, before his final comeuppance and joyful last laugh, he will hear his 2,400th chime at midnight in Windsor Park.

headline: Hagel Details 20% Cut in Personnel Who Report to Him
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Wednesday unveiled details of a plan to save at least $1 billion in personnel costs over five years through a 20 percent reduction in the number of Pentagon staff members who report to him.

headline: Swiss Open Inquiry Into Collection That Was Transferred to Unicef
text: ZURICH — The authorities here are investigating the transfer to Unicef in Germany of one of Europe’s largest and finest private art collections, a vast trove amassed by Dr. Gustav Rau, an eccentric collector and philanthropist who died in 2002.

headline: Listen Up | A New Voice for the Girl-Pop Revolution
text: It’s safe to say, in the wake of the success of artists like Lorde and Icona Pop, that we’re currently in the midst of a girl-pop revolution, and hot on the heels of this trend is Femme, a 25-year-old from London who cites her inspirations as a “proper mishmash” of Motown and Destiny’s Child. “I only started messing around with music when I was 16,” she said yesterday while waiting for a flight to New York, where she performs tonight at the Mercury Lounge, the second stop on her debut United States tour. “For me, making music was always just for fun.”

headline: Michael Urie: Lessons From a Master Shopper
text: On a recent Saturday morning, the actor Michael Urie was part of the throng filtering past the ticket takers in the opening hours of the Pier Antique Show on the West Side of Manhattan. The reed-thin Mr. Urie, who is around six feet tall (“I say 5-11, so not to get typecast as tall”) seemed to feel at home among the sharp-eyed shoppers, being a frequent visitor to flea markets and vintage clothing stores.

headline: A Futuristic Exercise
text: “The Hunger Games” is set in a dystopian future, but the characters are dressed to the hilt for it. In the second installment of the series, they wear clothes by Alexander McQueen, the Indonesian designer Tex Saverio (who’s outfitted Lady Gaga) and — to practice survival skills in the training center — Lucas Hugh, a luxe London-based workout brand.

text: In this age of customized everything — lattes, sneakers, Monopoly boards — it’s perhaps surprising that most women still leave their cosmetics colors to the experts.

headline: Dressing for a Festive Holiday Party
text: Michael Bastian’s advice: “Don’t abandon every shred of your regular style just because it’s a holiday. It’s not Halloween.” Here are some options.

headline: Appropriately Inappropriate for ‘Festive Dress’
text: Even in a world where nothing should be taken for granted — banks, climate, Miley Cyrus — one may persuasively argue that most people are pleased to receive a party invitation. The old joke still holds: What are the two saddest words in the English language? “What party?”

headline: Dear Internet, Thank You for Introducing Us
text: Every couple has a “how we met” story, usually a sweet account of the moment their eyes met across a crowded room or how a chance encounter led to love. How many of those tales now include a mention of dating apps like Tinder, messages exchanged on a dating site, or a particularly thoughtful remark on an Instagram photo that led to coffee and beyond?

headline: In Miami, a House Comes to Visit
text: Patrick Seguin is known for his Paris gallery, his friendship with Jean Nouvel, who designed it, and his treasure trove of 17 restored houses by Jean Prouvé. He has exhibited a house here and there, in Paris and Turin, but he has never before had his workers pack a whole Prouvé house into 10 crates and ship it to America. The 8X8 house (8 meters by 8 meters, or about 26 feet by 26 feet) is one of two 1945 Prouvé houses Mr. Seguin found in Bezaumont, France. (The other is a historical monument.) Made in a factory and easily assembled and taken apart, they were an elegant, thrifty solution to the postwar housing crisis in France. The 8X8 house is on display at Design Miami in Miami Beach through Sunday, furnished with pieces by Prouvé and Pierre Jeanneret. In Miami, it would make a high-status pool house. “No need to be a billionaire to go for one of these houses,” he said, but the price is $2.5 million. Information: patrickseguin.com.

headline: Patterns With Stories to Tell
text: Bisazza, a leading Italian producer of tile, is introducing two glass mosaic patterns by the Milanese designer Paola Navone, whose globally inflected style is becoming familiar to American audiences, thanks to her collaborations with Anthropologie and Crate & Barrel. For one pattern, Affresco, she translated a traditional floral design into something colorful, grainy and surrealistic, aiming to make the images look as if plaster had been peeled away to unveil frescoes beneath the surface. Halo-Halo, her black-and-white take on Pop Art and graffiti, which she describes as “perhaps pictograms by some distant civilization or a board game from an imaginary place,” is available in nine motifs that can be used in a multitude of configurations. Bisazza also introduced its first ceramic tiles, designed by Antonio Citterio, collaborating with Patricia Viel, and Marcel Wanders. Affresco is $44 to $68 a square foot; Halo-Halo is $324 a square foot. Information: 212-334-7130 or bisazza.com.

headline: Pretty, but Where’s the Kandinsky?
text: Readers will be forgiven for not immediately seeing the connection between Vasily Kandinsky’s paintings and Madeline Weinrib’s new napkins for the Neue Galerie, where an exhibit of the Russian artist’s work is on view. “The idea was to collaborate, not copy Kandinsky,” Ms. Weinrib said via email from India. “I decided to reimagine one of my favorite patterns, using colors from Kandinsky’s ‘Fugue’ painting. I thought the combination of colors would complement a variety of dishes, with a modern unexpected punch.” That pattern, called Daphne, is usually hand-woven in silk Ikat. Ms. Weinrib used hand-printed cotton instead, which made possible the intricate design, as well as machine washing. A set of four napkins, one each in blue, celery, iris and navy, is $100 at the Neue Galerie Design Shop. Information: 212-628-6200, extension 496, or shop.neuegalerie.org.

headline: A Millennial D.I.Y.-er With the Digitized Touch
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On the morning of Oct. 4, a line of women snaked out the doors of the Festival Pavilion at Fort Mason Center, a space the size of an airplane hangar at the edge of the bay here. They were waiting to get into a conference for “makers” — artists, designers, chefs and other do-it-yourselfers, headlined by Brittany Morin.

headline: Classics From Midcentury Given a Second Chance
text: While developing a line of midcentury-inspired products, employees of Stanley Furniture in North Carolina collected 40 of the company’s original pieces from the 1950s and ’60s by scouring sources like eBay and Craigslist. Each item was stripped down and restored to its original condition with updated paints, finishes and upholstery. Twenty-nine of the pieces — part of a group now known as the Heritage Collection — will be sold online starting Thursday at One Kings Lane. The pieces are “true to what midcentury furniture was all about: a great attention to detail, a precise design, honest materials and construction that can withstand the test of time,” said Adam Tilley, Stanley Furniture’s vice president for product. “It’s nice to see that all those things we held dear are still alive today.” The Mix’N Match Armchair is $1,199. Information: onekingslane.com.

headline: Sales at Judy Ross Textiles, Two’s Company and Others
text: Judy Ross Textiles will discount many pillows, rugs and holiday stockings up to 70 percent, through Saturday (an 18-inch-square Arbor pillow, originally $195, is $80); 22 East 17th Street (Broadway), Suite 714, 212-842-1705, judyrosstextiles.com.

headline: Reassessing an Uproar in Architecture
text: Adolf Loos, the enigmatic Moravian-born architect, is better known for his writings than his buildings. A century after the publication of his polemical essay “Ornament and Crime,” a Columbia University exhibition called “Adolf Loos: Our Contemporary” examines his enduring relevance. Loos provoked a furor in 1910 with the severe facade of a men’s tailoring shop and apartment block facing the imperial palace in Vienna. It became known as “the house without eyebrows” for its lack of decoration, and Emperor Franz Josef was said to have drawn his carriage curtains when he rode past. By contrast, Le Corbusier acknowledged the Modern movement’s debt to Loos, saying he “scrubbed under our feet; it was a Homeric cleansing — precise, philosophical and logical.” Yehuda E. Safran, who organized the show, had more to say about him. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

headline: Two Leaders’ Enmity Stokes Concern Over Vote in Fragile Democracy

The caller was Sheikh Hasina, the prime minister. The recipient was Begum Khaleda Zia, the leader of the political opposition.

headline: Yarnell Hill Fire Report

headline: Arizona Agency Is Faulted in Deaths of Firefighters

headline: Bob Newhart Might Have Lived Here
text: Seventeen years after losing his partner, Jed Johnson, in a plane crash, the architect Alan Wanzenberg starts over.

headline: Alan Wanzenberg: A New View on Life
text: One was self-taught, his hungry, intuitive eye shaped by his years at Andy Warhol’s Factory, and by curating the artist’s multifarious acquisitions, creating order and beauty at Warhol’s townhouse. The other was more formally (if not quite traditionally) educated, at Berkeley, Harvard and by a fresh-out-of-grad-school job as a young architect at I. M. Pei. Together, Jed Johnson and Alan Wanzenberg formed one of the most influential design partnerships of the 1980s and early 1990s, making sensuous, modern environments for celebrity and art world heavies like Richard Gere, Mick Jagger and Jerry Hall, Peter and Sandy Brant, and Beth Rudin De Woody.

headline: Mobile Payments Gain Traction Among India’s Poor
text: MUMBAI, India — In a narrow room filled with acrid fumes in one of the world’s largest slums, Chinak Ramtheol earns about $4 a day tending machines that melt and slice plastic trash into pellets for recycling.

headline: In Obama’s Book List, Glimpses of His Journey
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has never visited the rugged mountains of Chechnya, but if he digs into one of the novels he bought last weekend, “A Constellation of Vital Phenomena,” he will be transported to a land of unremitting violence and tragedy, where the innocent are caught up in war as often as the guilty.

headline: Vincent A. Marchiselli, Ex-New York Legislator From Bronx, Dies at 85
text: Vincent A. Marchiselli, who served 10 years as a New York State assemblyman from the Bronx and was a lonely, defiant voice against the scandal-scarred Bronx Democratic organization in the 1980s, died on Friday in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 85.

headline: Vapors and Emotions Rise at Hearing on E-Cigarettes
text: A woman in a skintight dress lounged in the front row of the City Council chamber on Wednesday, sucking on an electronic cigarette and blowing out sweetly scented clouds, as if she were at a nightclub. Other people in the crowd of about 200 did the same, puffing on devices like a red-tipped cigarette clone, a green glass hookah and something that looked like a black pencil with a glowing blue tip.

headline: Cultural War Games
text: In its ongoing effort to protect the American public from the War on Christmas, Fox News has a special online map highlighting current reported atrocities. I am looking at it now, and the message is clear: as problems go, this one is imaginary.

text: Surfers around the world descend every winter on the North Shore of Oahu, where a five-mile stretch of breaks churns out picturesque waves with inconceivable power.

headline: No, There Won’t Be a Doctor Shortage
text: IN just over a decade the United States will need 130,000 more doctors than medical schools are producing. So says the Association of American Medical Colleges, which warns of a doctor shortage that will drive up wait times, shorten office visits and make it harder for Americans to access the care they need.

headline: Food Carts in Los Angeles Come Out of the Shadows
text: LOS ANGELES — The dance plays out daily in MacArthur Park, Boyle Heights, South Los Angeles and elsewhere across this sprawling metropolis: A lone police car rolls slowly past a popular corner, sending dozens of street vendors scrambling for cover, pushing tamale carts around corners and into the doorways of nearby shops.

headline: Recalling TV’s Golden Age, Stars Pitch Products Tied to Their Shows
text: DURING the golden age of radio and the early years of television, when advertisers and agencies owned the programs they sponsored, a popular way to pitch products was with what were known as cast commercials: Cast members of the programs would deliver a spiel or two during their shows, often in character and usually with a gentler touch that soft-pedaled the hard-selling tactics of typical commercials.

headline: Top Witness in SAC Case Can’t Recall Some Points
text: Jon Horvath’s memory failed him again during the insider trading trial of his former boss, Michael S. Steinberg, once a top trader at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors.

headline: A Grandchild’s Love Quells the Demons of Addiction
text: For 17 unholy years, Mary Woods, 56, called the streets of Manhattan her home. Crack cocaine was her sustenance, prostitution her trade. That all changed in 2009, when an arrest for the criminal sale of a controlled substance put a more permanent roof above her head: that of a jail cell on Rikers Island.

headline: Amsterdam Has a Deal for Alcoholics: Work Paid in Beer
text: AMSTERDAM — After more than a decade out of work because of a back injury and chronic alcoholism, Fred Schiphorst finally landed a job last year and is determined to keep it. He gets up at 5:30 a.m., walks his dog and then puts on a red tie, ready to clean litter from the streets of eastern Amsterdam.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 4, 2013
The President on Inequality
text: The issues that have obsessed Washington for the last few months — the government shutdown, the broken health care website, the unrelentingly bitter tone of a stalemated Congress — mean very little to most Americans. For a broad swath of the country, what matters hasn’t changed since the recession, and it is economic anxiety. Six in 10 workers in a Washington Post poll last week said they were worried about losing their jobs, the highest number in decades. Many of the millions who are unemployed have reached new depths of despair.

headline: As Yankees Take Big Bites, Mets Nibble
text: The Mets are confident in their starting rotation. They have a left-hander and four right-handers, power arms for the front end and proven, solid options for the back. All of the starters are younger than 30.

headline: Egypt’s Latest Constitution
text: Egyptians are squandering another chance to build a broadly inclusive democratic system with the latest constitutional revisions. The new charter defies the revolutionary promise of the Arab Spring by reinforcing the power of institutions that have long held Egypt in an iron grip.

headline: New York’s ‘Legalized Bribery’
text: The panel deputized this summer to investigate corruption in Albany released its first report this week. It is, quite properly, scathing — a damning list of the ways that New York State politicians twist, abuse and sometimes break the law to enjoy the fruits of a pay-to-play government where “large donors set the legislative agenda.” The 25-member panel — The Commission to Investigate Public Corruption — has done New Yorkers a great service. It has provided one of the best guidebooks for reforming Albany’s corrosive culture in many decades.

headline: SolarCity to Use Batteries From Tesla for Energy Storage
text: Commercial building owners, even those who reduce their overall energy use, have long struggled to cut special power fees that are based on periods of highest demand.

headline: Kerry Vows to Help Moldova Hew to the West
text: CHISINAU, Moldova — In a lightning visit to Moldova, Secretary of State John Kerry pledged American support on Wednesday to help this former Soviet republic develop closer political and economic ties with the European Union.

headline: Unarmed Man Is Charged With Wounding Bystanders Shot by Police Near Times Square
text: An unarmed, emotionally disturbed man shot at by the police as he was lurching around traffic near Times Square in September has been charged with assault, on the theory that he was responsible for bullet wounds suffered by two bystanders, according to an indictment unsealed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Wednesday.

headline: U.N. Official Details Plans for Removing Syria’s Chemical Arms
text: The United Nations official in charge of coordinating the disposal of Syria’s chemical weapons arsenal provided new details on Wednesday about the plan to eliminate them, saying the most dangerous materials would be sealed by trained Syrians and sent overland to the country’s Mediterranean port of Latakia, where ships would take them to a second, unspecified foreign port.

headline: Chicago Pursues Deal to Change Pension Funding
text: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — First came the State of Illinois, now comes the City of Chicago.

headline: Quickly and Easily, Scanning and Storing Documents on the Go

headline: App Smart: Document Scanning

headline: Tuck’s Dominance Evokes His Past, but His Future May Be Elsewhere
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — As much as Justin Tuck would prefer to toil in relative anonymity, to be just another forceful element in a resurgent defense, he is finding that impossible as he nears what may be the end of a memorable Giants career.

headline: Gang Members Said to Consider Blackmailing Toronto’s Mayor
text: OTTAWA — Gang members were heard on wiretaps discussing drug use by Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto and suggesting that he could be blackmailed, according to a police document that was released by a court on Wednesday.

headline: Democrats’ Latest Campaign for Health Care Law Begins

headline: Banks Fail to Comply With Parts of Mortgage Settlement, Report Says
text: Three of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders are still failing to comply with key requirements of a national settlement over mortgage abuses, according to a new report that suggests that some borrowers are still trapped in a tangle of red tape and errors as they try to save their homes from foreclosure.

headline: Paul Aussaresses, 95, Who Tortured Algerians, Dies
text: Gen. Paul Aussaresses, who stunned France in 2000 when he asserted that he coldbloodedly tortured and summarily executed dozens of prisoners during his country’s brutal colonial war in Algeria decades earlier, died Tuesday in La Vancelle, France. He was 95.

headline: Puzzlement
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Now this is how you make a Thursday theme. Something a little unusual, a bit more so than earlier in the week. Tricky, but carefully tread that tightrope between challenging the solver and making it overcomplicated. Keep it simple. You can tell I liked this one by Dan Schoenholz. It’s just so simple in its theme design, I didn’t even care that there were four cheaters in the grid (I am a bit biased toward themed puzzles. Sue me.)

headline: Documents Say Phones Outside U.S. Are Tracked
text: The National Security Agency is tracking the location and movements of hundreds of millions of cellphones outside the United States in an effort to find suspicious travel patterns or coordinated activities by intelligence targets, according to secret documents leaked by the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden.

headline: Assistant to Accused Antiquities Smuggler Pleads Guilty to Possessing Looted Items

headline: Massachusetts: Warren Rules Out a Run for President
text: Senator Elizabeth Warren, the freshman Massachusetts Democrat who has been mentioned as a possible presidential candidate in 2016, said Wednesday that she would not run. “I pledge to serve out my term,” which expires in January 2019, she told reporters. “I am not running for president,” she said. “I am working as hard as I can to be the best possible senator that I can be.” She had been promoted by some liberals, without her encouragement, as a populist alternative to Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Rediscovering Form, McIlroy Also Finds Some Perspective
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — For Rory McIlroy, fans shouting his name have become background noise, as natural as the pounding surf in nearby Malibu. It is rare that a single cry of “Rory” can turn his head, as happened Wednesday after McIlroy walked off the first tee box at Sherwood Country Club during the pro-am for the World Challenge, hosted by Tiger Woods.

headline: Sudanese Detainee to Be Sent Home From Guantánamo

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 1 P.M. (Starz) TWELVE MONKEYS (1995) A prisoner from the future (Bruce Willis) is forced by his captors to travel back in time to the 1990s to stop a virus from being released in this science fiction tale directed by Terry Gilliam. Madeleine Stowe is the psychiatrist who believes his seemingly crazy story, and a mental patient (Brad Pitt) is top among his list of suspects. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin said the movie is “fierce and disturbing, with a plot that skillfully resists following any familiar course. The film’s hero fears that he’s half-crazy, and for two hours Mr. Gilliam artfully keeps his audience feeling the same way.”

headline: Covering Biden in Beijing, and Becoming the Story

That meant he got special access to the vice president, but also had to feed the rest of the press corps details and color on the visit. And he more than rose to the occasion, particularly when he became part of the story. The following are excerpts of his report from the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse.

headline: Lawyers Describe Abuse Outside Chinese Activists’ Trial

headline: Assault on Yemeni Defense Ministry Compound Kills 52

headline: Raising Coca and Hopes in Bolivia
text: The landscape Marcelo Pérez del Carpio remembered from childhood days at his grandparents’ farm about four hours northeast of La Paz has changed over the last 20 years. Back then, the town of Challa was home to a few people who devoted themselves to agriculture. But when he returned this year, he found a boomtown that had turned its back on traditional fruit and vegetable crops, luring to its lush acres migrants intent on cultivating coca.

headline: There’s a Reason They Call Them ‘Crazy Ants’
text: The first time Mike the Hog-a-Nator noticed the ants, they were piled outside his cardiologist’s office. This was two summers ago, in Pearland, a suburb of Houston. There was a forbidding, fibrous heap of dead ants on either side of the building’s double doors, each a couple of feet long. And there were also legions of living ants shuffling over the dead ones — though Mike the Hog-a-Nator had to bend down to see these. Otherwise, so many individual ants were moving so chaotically, and so fast, that the entire reddish-brown tangle at his feet looked as if it were shimmering. Mike the Hog-a-Nator remembers thinking: What the world? Then he went inside for his weekly appointment.

headline: How Seriously Should We Take Standardized Tests?
text: A Times article this week about the international PISA test announced “American 15-Year-Olds Lag, Mainly in Math, on International Standardized Tests.” In November, an article about a national test, the National Assessment of Educational Progress, showed that though there have been gains, “achievement gaps between whites and blacks, whites and Hispanics, and low-income and more affluent students stubbornly persist.”

headline: BNP Paribas to Take Control of Polish Unit of Rabobank

headline: U.S. Evangelicals, Indian Expats Teamed Up to Push Through Modi Visa Ban
text: In March 2005, the United States denied a visa to Gujarat’s chief minister, Narendra Modi, now the Bharatiya Janata Party’s prime ministerial candidate in next year’s Indian elections. The visa was denied because of Mr. Modi’s alleged role in the 2002 riots in Gujarat that left more than 1,000 dead, most of them Muslims. But it came about from a highly unusual coalition made up of Indian-born activists, evangelical Christians, Jewish leaders and Republican members of Congress concerned about religious freedom around the globe.

headline: Winter Games, Caucasian Misery
text: MOSCOW — The Black Sea resort of Sochi, with its breathtaking views of the nearby Caucasus Mountains, was once a favorite holiday destination of Communist Party bosses in the Soviet era. Now reincarnated in gleaming glass, steel and concrete, Sochi is getting ready to welcome the 2014 Winter Olympics, opening on Feb. 7.

headline: Melancholy Odyssey Through the Folk Scene

That’s a pretty good definition, one that certainly applies to “Hang Me, Oh Hang Me,” the chestnut that opens “Inside Llewyn Davis,” Joel and Ethan Coen’s intoxicating ramble through Greenwich Village in 1961, before the neighborhood was annexed by New York University and Starbucks.

headline: Shaking the Bitcoin Believers
