Though China has stopped short of an outright ban, the move dashes hopes the country might allow start-up currencies to exist alongside the official renminbi.

headline: The Nashville Experiment
text: Emaline Cameron was among the thousands of refugees who poured into occupied Nashville, Tenn., in 1863. While the strains of war may have contributed to her flight from her native Smithville, about 50 miles to the east, Emaline crossed Union lines to distance herself from an imploded marriage. James Hayes, known as Toy, had divorced her on the grounds that he was not the father of their eldest child. She admitted as much in court: while growing up Emaline had worked as a chambermaid at the Smithville Hotel, which was run by her parents. After a boarder left the 15-year-old pregnant, they quickly married her off to the naïve Toy.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Moncler Gaston Jacket
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Times Minute: Dec. 05 at Noon
text: Bratton named New York City's Police Commissioner; Yemen's Defense Ministry attacked; and fast-food workers go on strike.

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: U.S. Says Diplomats Defrauded Medicaid
text: The contours of the alleged insurance fraud seemed unusual enough: The participants, men and women, were accused of improperly seeking Medicaid benefits for pregnancies, births and postnatal care.

headline: More Revivals This Way Come
text: Do we really need another “Macbeth” right now?

headline: The Paradoxical Art Tricksters
text: The Bruce High Quality Foundation skewers (and seduces) the art world.

headline: Crossing Over to an Area We’ll Call. ...
text: When a strange little show called “The Twilight Zone” was first broadcast in 1959, the executives at CBS probably had no idea they had a game changer on their hands. The anthology of dark morality tales — with an occasional detour into brainy comedy — did well in the ratings but was canceled after five seasons. It wasn’t until the series started running in syndication at night and on weekends that its popularity soared. Shows like “The Walking Dead” and “American Horror Story” owe their popularity to its sharply written blend of horror, science fiction and thriller.

headline: Fake Artifact by an Unknown? Sold!
text: It’s a tick or two into an early November morning, and at a basement club in NoHo, members of the city’s most famous — and yet technically anonymous — art collective, the Bruce High Quality Foundation, are celebrating their latest lark.

headline: How Crime Declined in New York City and the U.S.
text: The city’s next police commissioner, William J. Bratton, managed during his first term to garner considerable acclaim for the drop in crime, even as crime was falling in many other big cities as well.

headline: 36 Hours in Kauai, Hawaii
text: These days, Kauai sits firmly on the tourist radar, an indisputable rival of its famous neighbors, Oahu and Maui. But upon first glance at its unspoiled natural splendor, you’d never know it. A closer look at one of the oldest (geologically speaking) and arguably most beautiful of the major Hawaiian Islands reveals a blossoming culinary scene, a rooted arts community and a smattering of resorts. But thanks to careful regulation (by law, building heights max out at 55 feet) and a certain amount of pushback from residents (in 2007 protesters quickly quashed high-speed ferry service between Oahu and Kauai), most of the island still feels like the world’s most stunning backwater.

headline: Ask Well: Endurance Exercise and Life Span
text: Question:

headline: Explaining Drama Behind World Cup Draw
text: About the only thing that is certain about Friday’s World Cup draw (11:30 a.m. Eastern) is that the 32 teams will be divided into eight groups of four for the first round, and that none of those groups will be easy to navigate.

headline: Gupta Suit Against Partner Is Dismissed
text: A federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed a lawsuit brought by Rajat Gupta, the former managing director of the consulting giant McKinsey & Company, who had accused a former longtime friend of trying to stop him from having a say over a private equity fund they started together.

headline: A Vintage Vision for ‘Her’ (No Jeans Please)
text: In the future, will we all be wearing high-waisted pants and shirts over shirts? Yes, if we live by Spike Jonze’s rules. That’s the look in his movie “Her,” a romance set in the near future that is gaining steam on the awards circuit.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: A Substitute Thanker?

headline: Reports From the Central African Republic’s ‘Darkest Days’
text: The civilian toll of the violence raging in the Central African Republic was highlighted on Thursday with multiple reports of hospitals overwhelmed by the wounded and people trying to flee to safety. The latest bout of fighting flared just before the United Nations Security Council voted to authorize African Union and French military forces to deploy to protect civilians.

headline: On the Right, It Will Always Be October
text: For almost two months, the debacle of healthcare.gov allowed conservatives to live the life they always wanted. Health reform was a dismal failure; Obama would go down in history as a laughingstock; government can’t do anything; viva Ayn Rand!

headline: Prosecutors Draw Fire for Sentences Called Harsh
text: Federal prosecutors in Baltimore offered Roy Lee Clay a stark choice.

headline: Pope Setting Up Commission on the Sexual Abuse of Children by Priests
text: VATICAN CITY — In his first concrete step to address the clerical sexual-abuse problem in the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Francis will establish a commission to advise him on protecting children from pedophile priests and on how to counsel victims, the Vatican said Thursday.

headline: Private Equity and Monetary Thinking
text: There has been a kind of fun exchange between the think tank Third Way — which says it offers “fresh thinking”, although it looks pretty stale to me — and Elizabeth Warren. Third Way published a remarkably clumsy attack on economic populism, singling out the senator and Bill DeBlasio for special ire; Warren then raised the question of who, exactly, supports Third Way. The answer, big surprise, is Wall Street.

headline: Gauging Android Variants Among Cellphones, and Changing Windows 8 Defaults
text: Choosing an Android Experience

headline: An Owner Figures Out How to Save on His Health Insurance
text: When I started this series on health insurance, I thought I might devote three or four posts to the subject. Instead, as I turned up surprising information, I realized that there was much more to say. This is an important and expensive purchase for a business owner, and there are great benefits to making the effort to understand how it works.

headline: Okwui Enwezor to Be Visual Arts Director of Venice Biennale
text: Okwui Enwezor, director of the Haus der Kunst in Munich, has been appointed the visual arts director of the next Venice Biennale, which will run from May 9 through Nov. 22, 2015.

headline: Arrests Over Satirical Video Lay Bare Emirati Sensitivities
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The video was undeniably silly: a 20-minute mockumentary about a fictional martial arts school in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, where grandmaster Saloom Snake trains combatants to throw sandals, strike with the thin ropes of an Arab headdress and summon help on Twitter for fights that never actually occur.

headline: De Blasio Announces Police Commissioner
text: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio announced William J. Bratton as his choice for commissioner of the New York City Police Department.

headline: Long Laughs and Poignant Moments
text: Good comedies can benefit from bad vibes. That’s certainly true for “Clever Little Lies,” a show at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick that delivers a large share of laughs but comes most alive when its amiable characters turn unhappy.

headline: The Gun Report: December 5, 2013
text: On the eve of the one-year anniversary of the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary, USA Today has published an interactive about mass killing in America called “Behind the Bloodshed.” Examining F.B.I. data, which defines a mass killing as four or more victims, a team of reporters found that since 2006, there have been more than 200 mass killings in the U.S. They also found that such massacres occur far more often than the government reports.

headline: A Dinner in Miami Beach to Honor Some of the World’s Most Renowned Architects
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: T HOLIDAY
text: As a backdrop for superb art and a lively young family, a neutral palette deployed with a discerning eye and subtle hand is anything but bland: it is intelligent, sophisticated and rather cozy.

headline: Ford Wants to Take Next Mustang to New Places
text: Online media leaks aside, the 2015 Ford Mustang is, officially, no longer a secret after its unveiling Thursday morning in New York City and five other sites around the world. Alan R. Mulally, Ford’s chief executive, spoke at the New York opening, noting that it was here, at the 1964 World’s Fair, that the Mustang was first introduced to an enthusiastic public.

headline: Coalition of Evangelical Churches Seeks Prayers for Boehner on Immigration
text: A coalition of evangelical Christian churches pushing for an overhaul of the immigration laws will run radio commercials over the next two weeks calling for prayers for the speaker of the House, John A. Boehner of Ohio, to take up legislation on the issue.

headline: Marin Mazzie to Star in ‘Bullets Over Broadway’
text: “Go, gentle Scorpio, go — your Pisces wishes you every happy return,” cooed Helen Sinclair, the self-dramatizing diva who had all the best lines in Woody Allen’s 1994 period comedy “Bullets Over Broadway.” Dianne Wiest won a supporting actress Academy Award as the aging Helen, and the character is once again generating buzz as a musical adaptation of “Bullets” prepares to start performances on Broadway this spring. The front-runner for the role has been an open secret for months — “don’t speak!” as Helen would say — but the producers finally confirmed on Thursday that, indeed, three-time Tony Award nominee Marin Mazzie would star as Helen.

headline: Investors, Dismayed by Losses at Sears, Pull Money From Hedge Fund
text: The storied investing empire of Edward S. Lampert is shrinking.

headline: An Actress in a Different Take-Charge Role
text: If you ask most actors or directors why they love a particular writer’s work, they will give you blandly polite answers, cryptic answers or, if you’re really lucky, somewhat thoughtful answers. Ask Phylicia Rashad about August Wilson, whose Pulitzer Prize winner “Fences” she is directing at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven this month, and she pours forth like the daughter of a poet (Vivian Ayers) that she is.

headline: Holiday Books
text: The New York Times Book Review looks at art books, travel books, cookbooks and more.

headline: G.M. to Pull Back on Chevrolet Sales in Europe
text: General Motors said on Thursday that it planned to scale back its Chevrolet brand in Europe over the next three years as the automaker strives to stanch losses and become profitable there.

headline: Letters: ‘Discovery of Middle Earth’
text: ‘Discovery of Middle Earth’

headline: President of Rhode Island School of Design to Depart
text: John Maeda, the president of the Rhode Island School of Design announced Wednesday that he will leave the school at the end of this semester to join Kleiner Perkins Caufield Byers, a venture capital firm in Menlo Park, Calif. Mr. Maeda will also consult for eBay.

headline: Your Questions Answered (and Your Actress Nods Wanted)
text: Loyal readers and commenters here in Baggerland have been wondering about the late-breaking additions to the awards melee, like “American Hustle” and “Wolf of Wall Street,” films that have yet to be released. Do the critics groups, voters and other all-important prognosticators get a chance to see them on the big screen before they make their pronouncements about what they liked best this year?

headline: At the Broadmoor, Free Lessons in Tango and Tennis
text: The Broadmoor, the 744-room, 3,000-acre resort in Colorado Springs,  recently introduced more than a dozen weekend activities and classes that its guests can participate in for no cost through the end of April.

headline: German Official Assails Unrepentant Bank Executive
text: BERLIN — Wolfgang Schäuble, the German finance minister, made a sharp and unusually personal attack on Thursday on the co-chairman of Deutsche Bank, Jürgen Fitschen.

headline: Nominee for E.U. Bank Regulator Moves Closer to Post
text: FRANKFURT — Danièle Nouy, the French official proposed to lead Europe’s new banking regulator, on Thursday received the overwhelming backing of a key committee of the European Parliament, virtually assuring she will get the job.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: male doulas, sleep hormones and feeding baby. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Living With Cancer: Nude Mice
text: A tense moment at a meeting of my support group convinced me that cancer patients have wildly divergent needs for information about their condition. This is especially true when the disease is considered chronic, rather than curable.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey,’ the Long Island Version
text: Among the most noticeable residents of Southampton in the early 1900s was Samuel Longstreth Parrish, a local benefactor who donated the land for Southampton’s hospital, helped establish its library and founded its art museum. His former home, headquarters of the Southampton Historical Museum, is now the setting for “Downton Abbey Style in Southampton: 1900 to 1920,” an exhibition about mansions and millionaires and their many servants.

headline: Aficionados on Walkabout at Art Basel Miami Beach
text: And then on the second day, they had brunch. After the frenzied opening hours of the Art Basel art fair in Miami, ambitious shoppers and browsers ambled into Thursday a bit more leisurely, taking in coffee and bagels with their art at the homes of some of Miami’s top collectors. Dennis Scholl, a vice-president at the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, and his wife, Debra, have donated 300 works to the newly christened Pérez Art Museum Miami. But they still had plenty left to show off at their terraced apartment, which sits a stone’s throw from the convention center, home base for the fair.

headline: Two Remaining Rebel States
text: What a difference a day (sometimes) makes.  On Tuesday, I reported here that three states — Mississippi, Georgia and Louisiana — were still refusing to comply with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s order issued in August that same-sex spouses of military personnel be given spousal and family benefits. That was down from eight states as of mid-November that were refusing to process applications for benefits at Guard facilities, or issue identification cards required to claim benefits, including medical services on the Guard member’s home base.

headline: Old Enough at Heart
text: I am a seventh grader in New York City, and I love going to the theater, especially with my friends. Now that I can no longer buy under-12 tickets, mine cost just as much as everyone else’s in the theater, but I am still treated like a child who can’t behave. How should I respond when anxious ushers tell me not to kick the seats in front of me before I’m even seated? Or when adults warn me that taking pictures is not allowed, which everyone knows? I don’t want to whine (like a child), but I don’t want to be patronized, either. Any suggestions?

headline: Rough Trade NYC Puts Live Music On Hold
text: Rough Trade NYC, the record store and live music club that opened last week in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has canceled shows in its performance space, apparently to improve its soundproofing after noise complaints, the store announced Thursday.

headline: Kozlowski’s New Job: Software Company Clerk
text: L. Dennis Kozlowski was once a high-flying chief executive, perched atop Tyco International.

headline: On Other Side of Country, a Lesson in Chemistry
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — While everyone in the East is trying to figure out what is going so sideways with the Knicks and the Nets, the West is puzzling over how the Portland Trail Blazers, who won 33 games last season, are off to a 16-3 start, the best in the conference. If there was any question that their start was a fluke, the Blazers answered by dealing the Indiana Pacers their second loss of the season on Monday and outgunning the Oklahoma City Thunder, 111-104, on Wednesday.

headline: Tapas, and More, by Brothers From Spain
text: When Sangria 71 opened in early September, it took Williston Park by storm, and the deluge of patrons continues. On a recent Tuesday night (an off night at most restaurants), Sangria 71 was packed. A man at a table near the center of the room complained, “I feel like I’m in the middle of the New York City Marathon.” He was talking about the swarm of waiters whizzing by, trying to keep up with the crowd of customers.

headline: Take Your Best Voice to the Singalong at BAMcafé
text: Millions know the actor and comedian Harry Shearer as the voice of multiple characters on “The Simpsons”; still others recognize his work on “Saturday Night Live” or “Le Show” on NPR. For the Miser, however, none of those achievements compares with his tour de force performance as Derek Smalls, the hapless bass player for the heavy-metal outfit in “This Is Spinal Tap,” Rob Reiner’s wildly influential 1984 mockumentary.

headline: New Zealand Vampires and Nazi Zombies at Sundance
text: “A feral swarm of mass savages.”

headline: Seeing New Jersey as a State of Inspiration
text: The New York art world’s attitude toward New Jersey has not changed much since the art critic Ted Castle wrote in 1978, “New Jersey is practically not a place.”

headline: Larb Ubol
text: Inside the Hell’s Kitchen Thai restaurant where the focus is on the food.

headline: Awaiting Worst Storm Surge in 60 Years, Britain Closes Thames Barrier
text: As Britain braced for the worst tidal surge in more than half a century, the massive steel barriers that protect London were being shut to save the capital from the possibility of deadly and damaging floods.

headline: 3 Concert Halls Complement and Compete
text: Still riding a wave of popularity after 50 years of touring, the Beach Boys are very likely to sell out both shows they have booked at the Tarrytown Music Hall on Dec. 14, according to Bjorn Olsson, the hall’s executive director.

headline: Afghan Policewoman Is Killed, Fourth in Last Six Months
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two gunmen on a motorcycle shot and killed a policewoman in western Afghanistan on Thursday, wounding her daughter and two other family members who were with her. It was the fourth killing of an Afghan policewoman in the last six months.

headline: And You Thought You Knew Thai
text: To a passer-by, there is little to distinguish Larb Ubol from the 30 or so pad Thai joints that are its neighbors in Hell’s Kitchen.

headline: Gym or Dance Floor? Either Works
text: EVER since I got a C+ in a modern-dance class in college — despite my sincerest effort — I have been keenly aware that I am no dancer. Attempts over the years to learn other forms, including hip-hop and salsa, confirmed this. Yet I stubbornly persist. So when I learned about a K-pop dance class, I decided to give it a whirl.

headline: Casing the Greenwich Village Exteriors of ‘Inside Llewyn Davis’
text: In order to recreate the look of Greenwich Village in the early 1960s for their new movie, “Inside Llewyn Davis,” the Coen brothers filmed on real streets in present-day New York, installing props and adjusting the camera’s lens in ways that made the environment seem true to the time period. As the magazine’s culture editor Adam Sternbergh writes in this weekend’s magazine, finding the right location for each shot was crucial (the filmmakers avoided using special effects).

headline: A Warhol Is Said to Be Bought by a Walton
text: As the dust settles after last month’s enormous fall auction season, it remains a mystery who bought Francis Bacon’s “Three Studies of Lucian Freud,” for $142.4 million, and Andy Warhol’s “Silver Car Crash (Double Disaster)” for $104.5 million.

headline: Too Late to Book a Holiday Getaway? Not Necessarily
text: We’re into December, when last-minute planners from New York and other scarf-wearing regions start dreaming of spending Christmas break on a Caribbean beach somewhere, anywhere. Or, to put it more accurately, dream of having had the foresight to plan such a trip in August, when prices — both flights and hotel rooms — were still reasonable. Conventional wisdom has it that booking now for a late December getaway is a fool’s errand, and a rich fool at that.

headline: Old World Butchers, Preserving Traditions at the Holidays
text: Like a lot of Italian-Americans, David Perrotti enjoys the Feast of the Seven Fishes on Christmas Eve. But for Mr. Perrotti, 66, of Martinsville, the annual seafood extravaganza is not just a way to preserve tradition. It is also a night off from worrying about the centerpiece of a holiday dinner. Scores of dinners, actually.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Cassina x Louis Vuitton Chaise Longue
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: High Body Mass Linked to Hearing Loss in Women
text: A high body mass and a large waist are both associated with self-reported hearing loss, a new study has found.

headline: Antiques Stores Fall to Online Offerings
text: Manhattan antiques shops founded decades ago are vanishing at an alarming rate, unable to compete with online offerings. No trace remains of Elliott Galleries’ presence on East 79th Street; its white marble storefront has been razed. Yale R. Burge Antiques, on East 62nd Street, is closing and will auction inventory at Doyle New York in January. The former home of Cove Landing, on Lexington Avenue, has sat empty while the proprietor, Angus Wilkie, tucks inventory into his apartment storage spaces and organizes short-term displays at the W. M. Brady gallery on East 80th Street.

headline: Where Babysitting Is Truly an Art
text: LET grown-ups have their personal chefs, personal shoppers and personal pilots. For waist-high tykes like Andrew Wang, 5 and fizzy, New York now offers something better: the personal artist, rentable by the hour as babysitter.

headline: Deal Lawyer Joins Willkie
text: For decades, attorney Kirk A. Radke has worked behind the scenes helping to arrange private equity deals. Now the noted corporate lawyer is pulling off a deal for himself with a move to law firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher after a long tenure at Kirkland & Ellis, another large law firm.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Central African Republic, Israel, Thailand and New York.

headline: Mandela’s Death Leaves South Africa Without Its Moral Center
text: JOHANNESBURG — Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s first black president and an enduring icon of the struggle against racial oppression, died on Thursday, the government announced, leaving the nation without its moral center at a time of growing dissatisfaction with the country’s leaders.

headline: Bulls’ Derrick Rose Vows Injury Won’t Change Him
text: CHICAGO — Derrick Rose, the Chicago Bulls’ point guard, hobbled on crutches into a room in the basement of the United Center on Thursday morning to meet the news media for the first time since he had surgery last week to repair a meniscus tear in his right knee. He wore a red hooded sweatshirt with his trademark logo, a design with the letter “D” inside a rose.

headline: Mandela’s Struggle in Posters
text: Nelson Mandela spent 27 years in prison before his release in February 1990. During that time, a global anti-apartheid campaign took off, and his international influence grew exponentially.

headline: The Life of Nelson Mandela, 1918-2013
text: Mr. Mandela, who led the emancipation of South Africa from white minority rule and served as his country’s first black president, died at 95.

headline: Mandela as Dissident, Liberator and Statesman
text: Nelson Mandela, the leading emancipator of South Africa and its first black president, died on Thursday.

headline: A Poet Who Pushed (and Recycled) the Envelope
text: Like many a Connecticut Valley puritan, Emily Dickinson was practical, inventive and private. Dismissing the commercial marketing of poetry as an “auction of the mind,” she pioneered a very personal version of desktop publishing, creating 40 handwritten, stitch-bound volumes of her own poetry, each in an edition of one.

headline: Funny Lady
text: There was a time when Nora Ephron was frequently compared to Dorothy Parker, even by Nora Ephron. (“All I wanted in this world was to come to New York and be Dorothy Parker. The funny lady. The only lady at the table. The woman who made her living by her wit.”) I believe we have all gotten over that. As Ephron herself figured out long ago, the idea of Dorothy Parker was far superior to the living version, who was good with a one-liner but not much fun to be around. The real Nora Ephron was the person every­body wanted to hang out with, in part because she was funny and charming but more critically because she made the people she was with feel funny and charming. (I certainly wanted to hang around her, and we were friends for years.) She was never the life of the party in the classic center-of-the-crowd sense. She was the one who listened and then finally tossed in the one fabulous line that brought every­thing together. Her best writing was exactly the same.

headline: Vanities
text: I feel deeply underqualified to review the two coffee-table behemoths that landed on my desk: “Vanity Fair 100 Years” and “85 Years of the Oscar.”

headline: A Season of Scrooges (and a SQuja’)
text: A look at 61 actors from holiday productions of “A Christmas Carol” across the country, including a Klingon and one in drag.

headline: Shell Opts Not to Build Plant on Gulf Coast, Citing Costs
text: Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday that it would not build an immense gas-to-liquids plant on the Gulf Coast because of concerns over its cost. Shell had been studying the possibility of building a plant to take advantage of cheap shale gas in the United States for at least two years.

headline: The Life and Legacy of Nelson Mandela: 1918-2013
text: Nelson Mandela, whose activism made him a central figure in ending apartheid in South Africa, went from a prisoner to president in his lifetime.

headline: Just a Sweet Pair of Sociopaths
text: Among the inventions of the new “Bonnie & Clyde” — a four-hour extravaganza on Sunday and Monday nights, shown simultaneously by A&E, History and Lifetime — one of the less fortunate is a voice-over narration for the young killer Clyde Barrow. At turning points in the story, Barrow muses about fate, love and the reasons for the deadly two-year crime spree he carried out with Bonnie Parker and other associates in the early 1930s.

headline: Mandela Taught a Continent to Forgive
text: ACCRA, Ghana — FOR years, it seemed as though only one photograph of Nelson Mandela existed. It showed him with bushy hair, plump cheeks, and a look of serious determination. But it was a black-and-white shot, so grainy it looked ancient — a visual documentation of an era and an individual whose time had long passed.

headline: Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s Liberator as Prisoner and President, Dies at 95
text: Nelson Mandela, who led the emancipation of South Africa from white minority rule and served as his country’s first black president, becoming an international emblem of dignity and forbearance, died Thursday night. He was 95.

headline: Conservatives and Structural Racism
text: Responding to some of the discussion (my own contribution perhaps included) around Jonathan Chait’s controversials thoughts on conservatives and “12 Years a Slave,” The Daily Beast’s Jamelle Bouie tweeted: “Empathy about racial issues is nice, but actual policy to ameliorate effects of structural racism would be better, and I’m not sure conservatism is equipped to do that. I would be happy to be wrong though.”

headline: The Making Of
text: The designer opened up his New York studio on the eve of his prefall presentation to share his personal inspirations and how it all came together.

headline: The Contradictions of Mandela
text: I REMEMBER Nelson Mandela. No, not the universally adored elder statesman who successfully resisted the megalomania that comes with deification, and who died Thursday at age 95, but the young lawyer who used to sit in my parents’ living room until the early hours of the morning, debating African nationalism with my father, Ashby Peter Mda.

headline: The Voice of Mandela
text: Major speeches and letters from the life and career of South Africa’s first black president, organized by date, topic and readers’ favorites.

headline: In Reversal, White House Says Obama Did Meet Uncle
text: WASHINGTON — White House officials on Thursday abruptly changed their story about whether President Obama had ever met his father’s half brother, a Boston man who faced deportation to Kenya after a drunken-driving arrest in 2011.

headline: Champagnes That Leave the Sweetness Behind
text: As with clothing and hair, wine knuckles under to fashion. Different styles, regions and grapes all have their moments in the marketing spotlight, although the rationales for these sudden blasts of commercial heat can vary wildly.

headline: Fragonard Portrait Draws $28 Million at London Auction for Unicef
text: Unicef of Germany on Thursday auctioned off part of what had been one of Europe’s largest private art collections, reaping $31 million for the charity, much of it from the sale of a Fragonard portrait of a French general that drew nearly $28 million in bidding at Bonhams in London.

headline: Updates: First Reactions to the Death of Nelson Mandela
text: The Lede is following global reaction to the death of Nelson Mandela on Thursday. The New York Times obituary, “From Rebel to Prisoner to President,” was written by Bill Keller, the former executive editor who covered the end of apartheid as Johannesburg bureau chief from April 1992 until May 1995.

headline: ‘Venetian Glass by Carlo Scarpa’
text: A look at a new show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Clear, Opaque and Oh, So Delizioso
text: Craft. Decorative. Functional. Well made. Words like these are often used to keep objects in their place, carefully segregated from the realm of art.

headline: ‘Danish Paintings From the Golden Age to the Modern Breakthrough’
text: A look at works from an exhibition at Scandinavia House.

headline: Desire and Prudery, Wrestling to a Draw
text: In the movie “Babette’s Feast,” a Frenchwoman comes to a remote Danish fishing village seeking political asylum after losing her husband and son in the Paris Commune of 1871.   The local residents are puritanical Protestants; Babette is a Roman Catholic sensualist. She wins over her gloomy hosts by staging a lavish multicourse dinner that awakens them to their own bodily appetites.

headline: Memories of Mandela: John F. Burns
text: John F. Burns was Johannesburg bureau chief from 1976 to 1980.

headline: A Day of Adulation and Hope
text: It was late afternoon on one of the sky-blue summer days common in the verdant landscape of South Africa’s Western Cape, during a return visit nearly a quarter of a century ago, that I first glimpsed Nelson Mandela as a free man, walking to his destiny through the gates of Victor Verster Prison after 27 years as the world’s most celebrated political prisoner.

headline: Warring Emotions Play Out in a Universe Torn by Conflict
text: As an actor, Sergio Castellitto, a brooding and playful screen presence, especially in films directed by Jacques Rivette, is capable of impressive subtlety. As a director, though — notably of “Don’t Move” (2005) and now “Twice Born,” both starring Penélope Cruz — he seems to go out of his way to discourage precisely that quality. A throbbing melodrama set partly during the Balkan wars of the early 1990s (and based on a novel by Margaret Mazzantini, Mr. Castellitto’s wife), “Twice Born” generously allows each member of its talented, cosmopolitan cast an opportunity to howl and scream and tremble and generally overdo it.

headline: Memories of Mandela: Alan Cowell
text: Alan Cowell was Johannesburg bureau chief from 1983 to 1987.

headline: A Hero, Everywhere and Nowhere
text: From the moment of my arrival in South Africa in late 1983 to my enforced departure at the insistence of the apartheid government in early 1987, Nelson Mandela was everywhere and nowhere: a name on protesters’ lips, but unseen and unheard, a potent refrain in the clamor for liberation, a hidden presence in a remote prison cell, the anchor on a dream of freedom.

headline: Memories of Mandela: Suzanne Daley
text: Suzanne Daley was the Johannesburg bureau chief from 1995 to 1999.

headline: Statesman, Dandy, Flirt
text: As president, Nelson Mandela had so many requests for interviews that he frequently met with journalists in groups of three or four — often at 7 a.m. too, because he got up early. He never allotted much time for questions, sometimes just half an hour, and his temper flared easily, so watch out. In many ways, he was more a chief statesman than the head of a government. He didn’t like defending — or talking about — policy. And he had no patience for critics.

headline: Lodgings That Will Light Your Stay
text: Hotels around the world are getting into the festive spirit of the season by paying extra attention to their Christmas trees.

headline: Three Neighbor Problems
text: Evict Thy Neighbor?

headline: Memories of Mandela: Donald G. McNeil
text: Donald G. McNeil Jr. was a Johannesburg correspondent from 1995 to 1999.

headline: (Almost) Meeting Mandela
text: I never interviewed Nelson Mandela, but toward the end of my time in Johannesburg, he spoke at the annual dinner of the Foreign Correspondents Association. At the end, everyone got in line to shake his hand as he exited. Normally, I don’t buddy up to important people — I think it’s compromising. But this time I was telling myself off: “Oh, for Christ’s sake, Donald, stop being such a prig. It’s Madiba, he’s a living saint, and he’s 80 years old. He’s not going to be around much longer. Get in line and shake his hand.”

headline: Memories of Mandela: Ian Fisher
text: Ian Fisher was Nairobi bureau chief from 1998 to 2001.

headline: The Making Of | A Wardrobe Fitting for Joseph Altuzarra’s Fictional Leading Lady
text: On Monday, Joseph Altuzarra was hard at work in his New York studio, putting the finishing touches on the prefall 2014 looks he began designing in September, right after his spring/summer 2014 runway. For this fifth anniversary collection, which hits stores in May 2014, the newly engaged designer is looking back to move forward. “In the past couple of years we were really developing the brand around this kind of woman,” says Altuzarra about his imaginary muse, who balances French sensuality with effortless American style. “I think it is a powerful thing to look at a show and have it superdesirable and have it superwearable.” To achieve that balance this time around, his nearly 80 designs are fraught with layers of contrast. Body-hugging sheath dresses are understatedly sexy thanks to preppy madras fabric. Innocent, collegiate-striped skirts have dangerously high slits, an Altuzarra signature. The resurfacing of his other popular standbys — cropped peacoats, oxford shirt dresses, simple knits and soft, draped cocktail dresses — round out the collection so that it essentially becomes a complete wardrobe for the Altuzarra woman. Here, a look at just who that is, along with a behind-the-scenes look at how it all come together.

headline: The Downside to F.H.A. Loans
text: Mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration are the go-to product for borrowers who don’t have much cash for a down payment. But the required mortgage insurance premiums have become so costly that some critics argue that the agency is taking advantage of borrowers who have few other options.

headline: The Power of a Man Speaking Truth
text: I will give away the story of my only encounter with Nelson Mandela by saying my wife was just pregnant at the time with our second child. We saddled this small creature with the very big name of Nelson, and here is why:

headline: Ambition Begins With the Amuse Bouche
text: The Willows, in the DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel in Bristol, has the antiseptic look of an airport lounge, with cookie-cutter industrial art and vinyl-surfaced furniture, but there is nothing institutional about its food.

headline: Bubbles Make Rillettes Even Better
text: I have always believed that slices of prosciutto rimmed with creamy fat are best eaten with a bone-dry sparkling wine. And if the sparkler is Champagne, so much the better.

headline: Memories of Mandela: Lydia Polgreen
text: Lydia Polgreen has been the Johannesburg bureau chief since 2012.

headline: A Racial Acceptance That Resonates
text: In 1980, when I was 4 years old, my family moved to Kenya for my father’s job as a development consultant. My mother is from Ethiopia, and my father is a white American, but in the swirl of expat life in Nairobi, there was nothing unusual about that. My elementary school classes were full of kids who were half Kenyan, half British; half Chinese, half Rwandan; half Indian, half Filipino.

headline: Not Breaking Ties: Retaining Rockwell Family Heirlooms
text: Although all eyes were on three of Norman Rockwell’s best-loved paintings, which brought a total of $57.8 million at Sotheby’s on Wednesday morning, two smaller works by the artist were snapped back up by William Stuart, one of the brothers who had inherited them from their father, Kenneth J. Stuart, Sr., the Saturday Evening Post’s longtime art director. The elder Mr. Stuart died in 1993.

headline: Nelson Mandela
text: Nelson Mandela, who died on Thursday at age 95, fully deserved the legendary stature he enjoyed around the world for the last quarter-century of his life.

headline: Clinging to a Frail Presence, a Living Symbol
text: By the time I arrived in South Africa in 2008, a frail and declining Nelson Mandela was rarely seen in public anymore, and yet his presence was everywhere, his name on every set of lips and his face never far from any mind’s eye.

headline: On the 42nd Floor, a Menu Worthy of the Views
text: When 42 opened six years ago, jackets were required and guests were treated to complex molecular gastronomy designed to dazzle and even shock, like a vinegar turned into powder and served on a mirror with octopus. Tweaks came after the financial crisis (jackets were no longer necessary, and a $79 prix fixe menu was offered), but the restaurant remained, in the words of its celebrated chef-owner, Anthony Goncalves, “a special-occasion place.”

headline: Memories of Mandela
text: Past and present Africa correspondents of The New York Times reflect on their experience covering Mr. Mandela.

headline: Minority-Dominated Class Graduates From New York Fire Academy
text: Amid wailing bagpipes and roaring applause, the newest batch of New York City firefighters graduated from the fire academy on Thursday, joining a 148-year-old institution that is steeped in tradition, but also on the cusp of significant change.

headline: A Maniac Fights to Prove Murder by the Police
text: Pick a corruption scandal, any corruption scandal, if you want a contemporary analogy for the outrages in Dario Fo’s political farce “Accidental Death of an Anarchist.”

headline: For a Village Troubadour, a Late Encore
text: He was the big fish in the small pond that was the Greenwich Village folk music scene circa 1960, sought out and emulated by newcomers like Bob Dylan and Tom Paxton. But by the time his memoir, “The Mayor of Macdougal Street,” was published posthumously in 2005, Dave Van Ronk had been relegated almost to a footnote in the history of American popular music, better known for the many singer-songwriters whose careers he had fostered than for his own work.

headline: Mandela Lives
text: My favorite fact about Nelson Mandela is that he invited one of his white jailers, who had helped imprison him for 27 years, to his inauguration as South Africa’s president. It was a sign of the magnanimity, warmth and absolute lack of vindictiveness that marked Mandela.

headline: Mandela as Dissident, Liberator and Statesman
text: Nelson Mandela, the leading emancipator of South Africa and its first black president, died on Thursday.

headline: Mars Mission Is Uneventful Till the Undead Feel Unwell
text: Good on atmospherics but unimaginatively plotted, “The Last Days on Mars” is a low-budget zombie movie whose observations of group psychology in high-stress situations fitfully signal higher aspirations. The feature film debut of the Irish director Ruairi Robinson, it was adapted by Clive Dawson from Sydney J. Bounds’s short story “The Animators.”

headline: A Warrior Learns a Different Pose
text: It’s important to understand that my husband, Peter, refuses to take baths. He does shower, yes, but he finds baths unmanly, just like soccer — or any other sport that does not require players to crash into one another like angry apes and beat their chests.

headline: Look at How Exciting My Life Is!
text: Early in “Night Train to Lisbon,” Raimund Gregorius (Jeremy Irons), a stuffy academic, remarks that his wife left him because she found him boring. Oh how right she was!

headline: M.L.S. Cup Final: In Simulation, Sporting K.C. Wins
text: It would be easy to overlook (as many have) the Major League Soccer championship match, which is scheduled for Saturday afternoon between host Sporting Kansas City and Real Salt Lake.

headline: President Obama Remembers Mandela
text: Mr. Obama spoke of an “influential, courageous and profoundly good” man, who was an inspiration and a model for many, including himself.

headline: The New Girl, in Proverbial Pursuit of Popularity
text: The teenage mating game, as portrayed in the smart, chilly “S#x Acts,” is a perilous sport, and woe to the girl who doesn’t abide by its tricky rules. The film’s protagonist, Gili (Sivan Levy), is a wide-eyed, flirtatious high school student whose family recently moved to an upscale neighborhood in Tel Aviv, which could stand for any affluent city where bored, sexed-up youths communicate via smartphone. Acutely aware of her outsider status, Gili, whose family is not wealthy, has her dates drop her off at a luxury apartment building across the street from her actual address. She seems to have unlimited freedom to come and go as she pleases.

headline: Wastewater Case Raises the Concept of Underground Trespassing
text: A case involving the disposal of industrial wastewater pits two interests that are dear to many Texans against each other: oil and gas resources versus private property rights.

headline: Good Samaritan Ensnared in a Web With No Exit
text: “Swerve,” a would-be thriller set in the Australian outback, throws a handful of familiar genre bits at the screen, including a very bad man, a menacing husband, a wily wife, a rootless stranger and a chunk of change. Certainly there’s promise in the setting, which with its swaths of desert and roads to nowhere evokes the violent sun-scorched world of “Red Rock West,” John Dahl’s 1993 cowboy noir about a chunk of change, a rootless stranger, a wily wife, a menacing husband and a very bad man. Yet to say that the films have similar parts is about as meaningful as pointing out that a 1970 Pontiac G.T.O. and a 1971 Ford Pinto both have internal combustion engines, when only one is worth the ride.

headline: President Jacob Zuma on Mandela
text: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa gave the news Thursday night that former President Nelson Mandela had died, calling him their nation’s “greatest son.”

headline: Nelson Mandela’s Legacy: Full Coverage
text: Photos, videos and articles on Nelson Mandela’s life and legacy.

headline: In Pursuit of New Flights, and Reaching Beyond Soft Landings
text: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, which has sometimes been criticized for having a showbiz sensibility and living in the past, continued its slow, steady rebirth under the artistic direction of Robert Battle on Wednesday. While the Ailey company knows how to cater to audiences, a more gratifying truth has emerged: The dancers are also generous with choreographers. Life outside of “Revelations” is within their grasp.

headline: East River Views, Boat Parking, Bar on Premises
text: River House, the majestic 1931 co-op tower at the north corner of the East River and 52nd Street, is taking the unusual step of offering the River Club complex on its lower floors as a $130 million apartment, which would close one of the most luxurious clubs in New York.

headline: Continental Flair, With an Aggressive Edge
text: The shtick is simple, as obvious as they come: handsome guy in a well-cut suit with pompadour held aloft by ample hair product, standing on an elevated platform behind D.J. gear and shaking vigorously to the music he’s playing. A little visual dissonance goes a long way.

headline: An Architecture Grounded in Opposing Forces
text: When people say that the frame of jazz is flexible enough to admit pretty much anything, they might be thinking of bandleaders like the bassist Ben Allison. But if they’re thinking specifically about him, they’re not defining flexibility only as real-time freedom and permissiveness; they’re thinking of structure and design.

headline: Ecological Shifts Spell Challenges for the Pecos River
text: In the final 100 miles of the Pecos River, as it journeys south through far West Texas to empty into the Rio Grande, there is one public access point.

headline: Parting the Waters of the Exodus Story
text: The choreographer Reggie Wilson often finds the ideas for his dances while on a journey. Like an anthropologist, he conducts field research, traveling to places that interest him. Ideas lead to other ideas and accumulate in clusters before he translates them into sensual, structurally complex performances. So it’s a nice joke that near the start of “Moses(es),” a thrilling work that had its New York premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater on Wednesday, Mr. Wilson comes upon a huge pile of tinsel that he methodically stuffs into a red wheelie suitcase. He gets it all in.

headline: The Singer’s Bohemia, and His New Legal Practice
text: Jackson Rathbone, Jasper from the “Twilight” movies, has a pretty good singing voice, and he shows it off in “Live at the Foxes Den,” a slight movie that could have been significantly better with a little story doctoring.

headline: Coal in Your Stocking? How About a Murderer in Your B&B?
text: One of those who’s-the-murderer parlor games is a plot pillar of “Merry Christmas,” an experiment in filmmaking by Anna Condo that itself feels like a parlor game, and not a particularly entertaining one.

headline: The Insider | Thea Westreich on What Not to Miss at Art Basel in Miami Beach
text: If anyone should have a polished game plan for how to tackle the opening of an art fair, it’s an art adviser, whose entire professional livelihood is constructed around building collections for private clients. The wife-and-husband duo of Thea Westreich and Ethan Wagner have spent more than 30 years working, as Thea Westreich Art Advisory Services, on behalf of some of the world’s most intrepid collectors, often establishing markets of new and challenging genres, like living-room-unfriendly video art. They are also big collectors themselves, not only of art but also of books: the library in their SoHo loft has more than 13,000 volumes by and about artists.

headline: Remembering Composers Lost to AIDS
text: Seeking a bittersweet rhyme between vocal performances and talking-head recollections, “All the Way Through Evening” is a very modest memorial to New York City musicians cut down by AIDS in the 1980s and early 1990s.

headline: The N.B.A. Prospect, After the Chance Is Gone
text: If history is often written by the victors, “Lenny Cooke” suggests that there might be a certain mercy to fading from view. With the benefit of hindsight, and with a bonanza of documentary footage shot by someone else, the brothers Josh and Benny Safdie relate the cautionary tale of Lenny Cooke, basketball phenomenon turned ordinary person. Like ghostly chroniclers hovering near, they show Mr. Cooke during his rise as a high school prodigy in the early 2000s up through his spectacular snub at the 2002 N.B.A. draft and beyond.

headline: The Puzzle of a Past
text: “Implanted” is an ambitious first feature from Thomas Verrette about Ethan, a young man trying to recover lost memories while being treated by his father, a doctor. It’s part medical science fiction and part puzzle film. Ethan’s fragmented self-narrative is linked to its traumatic cause, so solving the mystery at the center of the film is satisfying. This is not the case in some puzzle films (“Memento,” “Upstream Color”), in which an elaborate construction distracts from a standard crime or romance plot at the core.

headline: Treating Allergies With Pills or Drops Instead of Shots
text: For much of her adult life, Shirley Hickey received two injections a week in an effort to tame severe allergies that caused frequent sore throats and sinus infections. Now she uses a less painful method.

text: The remorseless march of extinction — including our own — is captured with chilling clarity in “Revolution,” Rob Stewart’s unapologetically partisan argument against fossil fuels and fossilized thinking.

headline: A Zebra of a Different Color, or Another Pattern
text: “Khumba,” the second feature from the South African animation studio Triggerfish, is a wondrous and slightly deranged story about oddballs embracing their differences. The titular young hero is a South African zebra who is born half-white in a gated community of chicly striped peers. The superstitious zebras conclude that Khumba is the cause of the drought that follows his birth. For them, no stripes mean no rain.

headline: Meningitis Outbreak Strikes Two Universities
text: Outbreaks of bacterial meningitis have struck two college campuses, though health officials say the episodes — one on the East Coast, the other on the West Coast — are apparently unrelated.

text: The growth of Western classical music in China has been remarkable, with a number of notable instrumentalists emerging in recent years. Some of the whales beached themselves and died, while others appeared destined for the same fate despite rescuers’ efforts.

Two long-running holiday train exhibits offer much more elaborate versions of the miniature tracks that circle many a family’s Christmas tree.

headline: Vowing to Slay the (Already Subdued) Stop-and-Frisk Dragon
text: Standing next to the next police commissioner on Thursday morning, Bill de Blasio promised that he would bring an end to “stop-and-frisk as we knew it.”

headline: SAC Witness Concedes Omission on Illicit Data
text: For days, Jon Horvath has testified at the insider trading trial of his former boss, a onetime top hedge fund executive, that he was pressured to obtain confidential corporate information to do his job.

headline: Coalition of Liberals Strikes Back at Criticism From Centrist Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — In a sign of the left’s new aggressiveness, a coalition of liberals is trying to marginalize a centrist Democratic policy group that was responsible for a Wall Street Journal op-ed article this week that said economic populism was “disastrous” for the party.

headline: Sister Mary Nerney, Advocate for Women in Prison, Dies at 75
text: Sister Mary Nerney, a Roman Catholic nun who was a nationally known advocate for female convicts, in particular those who were survivors of domestic violence, died on Nov. 27 in Manhattan. She was 75.

headline: Somalia: Suicide Bomber Attacks Convoy in the North
text: A suicide car bomber struck a security force’s convoy on Thursday in northern Somalia, killing at least seven people and wounding 37, local officials and witnesses said. The convoy, which was attacked in the town of Boosaaso in the semiautonomous region of Puntland, included members of the Puntland Marine Forces and two foreigners who were training the local security forces. Details about the casualties were not immediately available, and no group claimed responsibility after the explosion. President Hassan Sheik Mohamud of Somalia condemned the attack, saying that “terrorists have lost the war on the battlefield and are now devoting all their efforts in harming innocent civilians.” The Shabab rebel movement has been waging an insurgency for years to impose a strict interpretation of Islamic law in Somalia, but Puntland has been relatively peaceful compared with other parts of the country.

headline: Picture Book Will Preside With Bratton
text: If there was an unexpected star at the news conference on Thursday announcing that William J. Bratton would be New York City’s next police commissioner, it was a faded yellow copy of “Your Police,” a children’s picture book published in 1956, that Mr. Bratton tenderly held in his hands.

headline: Obama Gets Real
text: Much of the media commentary on President Obama’s big inequality speech was cynical. You know the drill: it’s yet another “reboot” that will go nowhere; none of it will have any effect on policy, and so on. But before we talk about the speech’s possible political impact or lack thereof, shouldn’t we look at the substance? Was what the president said true? Was it new? If the answer to these questions is yes — and it is — then what he said deserves a serious hearing.

headline: Christopher Evan Welch, 48, a Versatile, Busy Actor, Dies
text: Christopher Evan Welch, an in-demand character actor who appeared in everything from Shakespeare to “The Sopranos,” including films by Woody Allen, Steven Spielberg and Charlie Kaufman, died on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 48.

headline: The Irony of Despair
text: We’ve made some progress in understanding mental illnesses over the past few decades, and even come up with drugs to help ameliorate their effects. But we have not made any headway against suicide.

headline: Heroines at the Box Office
text: The two most popular movies in America have something in common: they feature female protagonists. Jennifer Lawrence plays Katniss Everdeen in “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire,” which took in $110.1 million over the long Thanksgiving weekend. Kristen Bell is the voice of Princess Anna in “Frozen,” which grossed $93 million over the same period.

headline: Saying Farewell, Mayor Delivers a Rare Display of Public Emotion
text: The voice of the man behind the microphone quivered, at first imperceptibly.

headline: Families See Colorado as New Frontier on Medical Marijuana
text: FOUNTAIN, Colo. — As their children cooed from wheelchairs and rocked softly in their arms, the marijuana migrants of Colorado clasped hands, bowed their heads and said a prayer of cautious thanks.

headline: The Devils’ Succession Plan Appears Back on Track
text: NEWARK — Cory Schneider’s first three months in New Jersey have been quite a roller-coaster ride.

headline: Bratton Is Expected to Reshape Police to Rebuild Relationship With Public
text: The incoming New York police commissioner, William J. Bratton, provided few details on Thursday about his plans for his second stint running the nation’s largest police force, but people familiar with his thinking said there would be significant changes in personnel, priorities and how the department is organized and run.

headline: Money to Fight Global Diseases
text: Donor nations have pledged $12 billion over the next three years to a global fund that finances programs to curb three devastating infectious diseases in mostly poor or low-income countries. The amount falls short of the $15 billion goal set by the fund’s leaders, but it is, nevertheless, a vote of confidence in the programs at a time when many nations face fiscal constraints.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 5, 2013
The de Blasio Team Takes Shape
text: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio, who has promised a new vision for New York, has appointed two familiar, seasoned veterans to help him manage the nation’s largest city government.

headline: Obama’s Path Was Shaped by Mandela’s Story
text: WASHINGTON — Without Nelson Mandela, there might never have been a President Obama.

headline: One or More Spins Before Feasting
text: As president and chief executive of New York Public Radio, Laura R. Walker, 56, oversees metropolitan area stations including WNYC, WQXR and New Jersey Public Radio. The organization produces more than 375 hours of programming each week, including “Radiolab,”  “Freakonomics Radio” and “Studio 360.” She lives in Brooklyn Heights with her husband, Bert Wells, 56, a lawyer, their 14-year-old daughter, Claire, and their cockapoo, Aki. Their son, Evan, 22, is a senior at Yale and often comes home for the weekend because he is writing his senior thesis on the 9/11 museum.

headline: In South Bronx, a Church Pantry Scrambles to Feed Growing Lines of the Hungry
text: The food line started before light outside the stone church with red doors in the South Bronx on a recent Friday. There were grim-faced old men next to weary mothers with children and Spanish-speaking immigrants with handcarts and milk crates.

headline: House Bill Raises Bar for Suits Over Patents
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday overwhelmingly passed a bill protecting technology companies and their customers from nuisance patent-infringement lawsuits by shell companies that exist merely to gather dormant patents and threaten lawsuits against suspected violators.

headline: $225 Million? Seattle’s Pursuit of Cano Could Be Too Rich for Yanks
text: Even as the Yankees’ highest-ranking executives gathered at Yankee Stadium on Thursday to introduce Brian McCann, their newly signed catcher, the bulk of the questions posed to them were about Robinson Cano.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 6, 2013
text: “He was our father, our mother, our everything.”

headline: A Pioneer of Rap Music Craves 9-to-5 Stability
text: Lamar Hill began his first career on a central Harlem street corner, in the pre-MTV days of boomboxes and mix tapes. He and two pals, calling themselves Kool Moe Dee and Special K, recorded some of the earliest hip-hop records as the Treacherous Three. Wearing a T-shirt with an iron-on decal bearing his preferred name, L. A. Sunshine, he plugged his speakers into streetlight outlets to blast what was then a bold and unfamiliar new music, called rap.

headline: New York City Increases Its Resistance to Federal Entreaties on Foreign-Born Detainees
text: For years, New York City correction officials routinely provided federal immigration authorities with information about foreign-born detainees in their custody. The city, in response to federal requests, would transfer many of those detainees into federal custody, often leading to their deportation.

headline: House and Senate Are Near Deal to Speed Trade Pact
text: Negotiators from the House and Senate are nearing an agreement that would “fast-track” the sweeping trade deal the Obama administration is negotiating with a dozen Pacific nations, officials said Thursday.

headline: Students Use Twitter to Remember American Teacher Killed in Libya
text: After an American chemistry teacher at a school in Benghazi, Libya, was gunned down while jogging Thursday, his students turned to Twitter to share memories of a man they said inspired and motivated them, often with online banter and humor.

headline: At a Temple Proud of Its Traditions, a New Rabbi With ‘Alternative’ Ideas
text: Rabbi Joshua M. Davidson, the new senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan, literally works under the watchful eyes of his predecessors. Just outside his office are two rows of oil portraits of past senior rabbis, dating back to the 19th century — to the early days of the temple and the Reform Jewish movement.

headline: California City’s Return to Solvency, With Pension Problem Unsolved

headline: At a Whitewashed Queens Warehouse, an Unlikely Apostle 0f Graffiti Art
text: Rufino Garcia hated graffiti. He hated it so much that, for years, he carried a bucket of white paint and a rolling brush in the cab of his delivery truck, to instantly cover the spray-painted signatures that seemed to sprout like weeds on the vehicle’s flanks overnight.

headline: The Public Pension Problem
text: Are government retirees being forced to pay for a pension fund crisis caused by bad investments and Wall Street fees? If so, what's the solution?

headline: Stockton’s Struggle
text: Before Detroit, Stockton, Calif., was the largest city to file for bankruptcy. Now, Stockton is working its way back, and city leaders see lessons in its ordeal for other struggling municipalities.

headline: After Decision on Winston, Voters Must Make a Call
text: Until three week ago, Jameis Winston appeared to be the perfect Heisman Trophy candidate. He was a quarterback with gaudy statistics, and his Florida State Seminoles were undefeated and contending for the national title. Better, he was only a redshirt freshman and, as a bonus, Winston boasted a catchy nickname, Famous Jameis.

headline: Rueful Romance, Stripped of All but Vulnerability
text: What the world does not need now, many theatergoers would agree, is another jukebox musical manufactured to supply baby boomers with a sweet rush of synthetic nostalgia. “What’s It All About?” might almost be the plaintive cry of a visitor transported from the middle of the last century, wondering when recycled pop hits became the standard scores for Broadway shows. In fact, it’s the title of a new revue devoted to the music of Burt Bacharach that opened on Thursday night at New York Theater Workshop.

text: Ending years of acrimony, New York City has agreed to settle a major class-action lawsuit and adopt regulations requiring that half of the city’s more than 13,000 yellow cabs be accessible to people with disabilities within six years, a person involved in the negotiations said on Thursday night.

headline: M.L.S. Final Is Only the Latest Collision Between Kansas City and Salt Lake
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Kei Kamara, a Sporting Kansas City striker, trotted upfield, his eyes locked on the high-flying ball headed in his direction. As it seemed to be sailing way over his head, Kamara peeked to his left. In an instant, he was lying twisted on the field, gasping for air.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 7 P.M. (Sundance) VANILLA SKY (2001) David Aames (Tom Cruise), a 33-year-old master of the universe, finds his life upended after a car crash in Cameron Crowe’s erotic science-fiction adaptation of “Abre los Ojos,” Alejandro Amenábar’s Spanish romantic thriller. Cameron Diaz plays Julie Gianni, the latest plaything in David’s endless succession of beautiful women. Penélope Cruz (above, with Mr. Cruise), who starred in Mr. Amenábar’s original, is Sofia Serrano, whom Julie discovers David flirting with at the birthday party he neglected to invite her to. And suddenly the simple offer of a ride the next morning becomes a suicide leap as Julie drives her car off a bridge, leaving her dead and David condemned to wearing a latex mask. “With its roller-coaster plot and surreal special effects, ‘Vanilla Sky’ is not the kind of film one associates with Mr. Crowe,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The most warmhearted of mainstream Hollywood directors, Mr. Crowe has in the past extended to his characters the affection of an unusually careful and sympathetic listener.” In this film, “that ear is not as sharp,” he continued. “Still, the movie carries a lingering tug of sweetness, most apparent in the film’s heady soundtrack,” which “evokes the dream of eternal youth that infuses ‘Vanilla Sky.’ ”

headline: In China, Mandela Is Claimed by Authorities and Dissidents Alike
text: The death of Nelson Mandela prompted widespread expressions of sympathy in China, an indication of how his many roles — campaigner in the fight against racial inequality, political prisoner, national leader and senior African statesman — appealed to numerous segments of Chinese society.

text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Two years ago, Bode Miller kicked out of the starting gate atop the treacherous Birds of Prey downhill course and laid down a bold and technically flawless run that earned him a victory.

headline: Mandela’s Death Stirs Sense of Loss Around the World
text: SOWETO, South Africa — The mood was more festive than funereal. Outside Nelson Mandela’s former home in Soweto on Friday, crowds sang, chanted and danced. People carried posters emblazoned with his famous quotations. Children ran through the streets holding up pictures of the former president’s face torn from the morning’s newspapers.

headline: Recalling and Covering Nelson Mandela
text: Nelson Mandela, who died on Thursday, inspired hundreds of millions of people around the world with his uncompromising vision for the end of apartheid in South Africa and his efforts to bring a peaceful transition to a democratic society. Among those he influenced was Ozier Muhammad, a New York Times staff photographer, who reminisced about covering Mr. Mandela in a conversation with James Estrin earlier this year. Their conversation has been edited.

headline: Taiwan May Miss Out on Jia Zhangke’s ‘A Touch of Sin’
text: There is still no sign that “A Touch of Sin,” a controversial new film by China’s most famous art house director, Jia Zhangke, will be shown in Chinese theaters anytime soon. But fans thinking of seeing the film in Taiwan might end up disappointed, too. It has yet to be approved for release there under a quota system that allows 10 mainland movies to be shown each year in the island’s theaters.

headline: In Classic Car Auctions, Value Is Subjective
text: It can be difficult to tell when a classic car is going to make a lot of money at auction and when it will fail to meet the seller’s expectations. So much of it is subjective — a mixture formed of buyer whim, fickle market conditions and black magic.

headline: Attack on Yemen’s Defense Headquarters Is Linked to Al Qaeda
text: SANA, Yemen — A two-pronged attack on Yemen’s heavily guarded Defense Ministry headquarters that killed 52 people was carried out by Al Qaeda militants, social media accounts and websites that often carry Qaeda statements said on Friday.

headline: Syria's Spreading Bloodshed
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon — I was in Tripoli to draw, documenting the Syrian refugee crisis; that was what I was doing when I met Samar. She was queuing for food vouchers, along with fellow Syrian refugees, at the office of a local Sunni leader. Her young son, Hamad Noor, played at her feet. Like most refugee children, he wasn’t going to school.

headline: A Flight Diversion
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — I was woken by the pilot’s voice. In the drowsy hum of the airplane, his words crackled, and I thought I heard something about preparing to land. Could I have slept so long? I looked at the time. It was only three hours into the Lagos-to-Atlanta flight. The flight attendants were hurrying back and forth. The pilot was still speaking. “We have an emergency onboard, and we have had to divert the flight to Dakar.” I could feel the plane descending. It seemed too fast. A sweeping hollowness. My fog of sleep cleared instantly. Something was wrong, the pilot was too cryptic, the flight attendants too blank-faced, snatching up cups, urging seats straight. I thought: If I die, I hope it’s quick and I don’t know.

headline: Fraud in Bitcoin, Unchecked
text: IN BITCOIN, FRAUD IS QUICKER THAN THE LAW  |  Pump-and-dump schemes are shut down in the financial markets all the time. But such frauds involving digital money like Bitcoin have gone unchecked, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. Government authorities do not agree on which laws apply to Bitcoin, the popular virtual currency — or even on what Bitcoin is.

headline: A Mexican Director, a Maori Tale
text: The director Dana Rotberg came to make “White Lies,” New Zealand’s entry in the competition for the best foreign-language film Oscar, by a circuitous and unlikely route. A Jewish-Mexican, she spent part of the 1990s in Sarajevo, then returned home to Mexico City as the mother of a young child, only to find her own country in a spiral of violence.

headline: Lowest Jobless Rate in 5 Years Raises Odds of a Fed Move
text: After years of frustrating fits and starts in the wake of the financial crisis and the Great Recession, the United States economy finally appears to be generating jobs at a healthier, more sustainable pace that many analysts now think will continue into 2014. The official unemployment rate fell in November to its lowest level since 2008.

headline: Pro-Government Ukrainians Take to Streets to Denounce European Social Values
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Pro-government demonstrators deployed a new tactic on Friday to counter protests in favor of European integration, marching through the capital, Kiev, to oppose homosexuality, which they said would accompany a greater European Union role in Ukrainian affairs.

headline: My Health Insurance Was Canceled
text: I’m one of the many people in the United States who have had their individual health insurance policy canceled since the full implementation of the Affordable Care Act began Oct. 1. I own the Quintessence Group, a marketing consulting company based in Philadelphia. I have seven employees, but I’ve dodged the staff health insurance bullet for years because all of my employees have either had insurance through their spouses or have worked as independent contractors.

headline: More Hours, More Earnings
text: Here’s some good news in this good-news jobs report: Earnings climbed last month. That means that while many more Americans are finding jobs, the ones that are already working got a boost, too.

headline: 30 Takes of One Song? No Sweat for ‘Llewyn’s’ Star
text: Updated, 12:37 p.m. | Michael B. Jordan is not the only actor this season whose life changed thanks to one film. “On a practical level, as soon as Joel and Ethan cast me, the doors opened up for more parts,” said Oscar Isaac, the star of the Coen brothers’ “Inside Llewyn Davis,” which opens on Friday.

headline: Hagel Seeks to Assure Gulf Allies of U.S. Commitment
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, opening a week of travels meant to reassure Persian Gulf allies nervous about an interim nuclear deal with Iran, vowed Friday that the Pentagon would not reduce its military deployments to the region or its focus on countering shared security threats.

headline: The Dutch-Elm Disease of Creative Minds
text: Not long ago, I attended something called the Web Summit, a massive tech-industry conference held in Dublin over the course of a couple of days. The event had a two-tier structure: on one level, it was a vast, teeming trade show at which early-stage start-ups were given the opportunity to set out their stalls and sell themselves — to venture capitalists, angel investors, media people — and to network with one another; but on a more elevated plane, it was a grand conclave of the tech industry’s high priests, who came from all over the world (though mostly Northern California) to deliver talks and public interviews to audiences of several thousand.

headline: Life Along the 100th Meridian
text: In the western panhandle of Nebraska, where it is not uncommon for newcomers to be asked, “So how long are you staying in our country?” the question of continuity repeats itself each day anew.

headline: Costly Mistakes and Voter Suppression
text: I own a small manufacturing company, and recently I made a special order for a friend. He and I agreed on a certain price. My bookkeeper misunderstood my billing instructions and sent an invoice for less than the agreed-upon price. I discovered the mistake two weeks later. I contacted my friend to notify him of the mistake and to tell him we were sending out a corrected invoice. He said, “Your mistake is not my problem,” and that he would only pay the incorrect amount on the original invoice. Who is right? STEVE COHEN, BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y.

headline: I Guess I’ll Manage
text: “You’re in management,” my mother said. “You have to wear a bra.” She looked as if I’d shown up for breakfast wearing a codpiece and snorkel. I glanced down and realized that, indeed, I’d forgotten to wear a bra beneath my sweater. It hardly made a difference in the geography of the region, but I was ashamed of my absent-mindedness. A mother’s reproach is never sharper than at 7:30 on a Monday morning.
