headline: Lenny Kravitz’s Halfway Mark
text: You grew up between the Upper East Side and Bed-Stuy. Which neighborhood did you feel more comfortable in?  Well, after I was in first grade, Monday through Friday was Upper East Side going to P.S. 6, and Friday night through Sunday night was Bed-Stuy. But I didn’t like one more than the other. I had two different lives, and in fact two different names. My name in Bed-Stuy was Eddie.

headline: Who Made That Energy Drink?
text: The energy drink, as we know it, started in Japan. In the postwar period, amphetamines were very popular until laws were passed to curb their use in the 1950s. Then in 1962, a company called Taisho introduced Lipovitan D — a legal, energizing tonic sold in minibar-size bottles. By the 1980s, such vitamin-fortified, extra-caffeinated beverages were being regularly consumed by Japanese executives struggling to get ahead. One television ad showed Arnold Schwarzenegger bursting from a flagon like a juiced-up genie. Another had a hero in suit and tie, signing deals and making presentations as he raced around the world. “Can you fight for 24 hours a day?” he chanted with his chin upturned. “Businessman, businessman, Japanese businessman!”

headline: Pour the Port, Hold the Stodginess
text: It’s not a fancy bar, the place where I work, but we do carry port. Just one brand is enough for our purposes. In my nearly four years of working there, I’ve only seen one person order it: a middle-aged man who shows up maybe once every six weeks (on my shift, anyway; I suspect he comes at other times too), drinks three glasses and leaves.

headline: This Is What It Looks Like at the Center of America
text: A photo portolio by Andrew Moore of some of the most sparsely populated regions west of the 100th meridian.

headline: Capturing America at Its Plainest
text: To create his large-format photographs of the Great Plains region, Andrew Moore chartered a two-person plane and attached his camera to the wing.

headline: Food Allergies Less Deadly Than Accidents
text: A fatal allergic reaction is a dramatic event, often involving a young person, so it naturally attracts attention. But that attention itself may lead people to overestimate the risk.

headline: Big Band
text: Eighty years before “branding” had become the familiar hard-nosed term for the packaging and selling of entertainers, Duke Ellington was a dreamlike synthesis of image, talent and social relevance. As a black jazz titan in a racist age — he rose to stardom in the 1920s — the aristocratic maestro took on a weighty double role: to lift jazz to the level of concert music and to win respect for his race.

headline: Bebop
text: When you’re writing about the movies, the film critic and painter Manny Farber said, the language ought to emulate the art. “I don’t think you can be mimetic enough,” Farber told an interviewer. That is to say, screen violence calls for barbarous prose; romance requires a warmness of tone. This principle could be applied to writing about all the arts, or most of them — including jazz, as the cultural critic and novelist Stanley Crouch has demonstrated with his judicious, strategically crafted new book about Charlie Parker, the revered and immeasurably influential alto saxophonist and composer. “Kansas City Lightning: The Rise and Times of Charlie Parker” is, like the music made by its subject in his abbreviated life, free-flowing and severe, volatile, expansive, allusive and indulgent. From bravura sentence to serpentine paragraph, the book is a virtuoso performance of musical-literary mimesis.

headline: Children’s Books
text: Six beautiful large-format books take readers on imaginative journeys.

headline: Picturing World War I
text: When I saw the title of this volume, I expected one of those encyclopedias in which texts by historians are interspersed with grainy images that bring the arguments to life. “The Great War” could not be more different. The images presented here are not illustrations for a narrative; they are the narrative. Hilary Roberts, the head curator of photography at the Imperial War Museums in Britain (home of the world’s most extensive collection of World War I photographs), provided the historical and contextual expertise. Mark Holborn is a celebrated editor of illustrated books and a master of photographic mise-en-scène. The result of their collaboration is a book of extraordinary power and clarity.

headline: The Somme
text: The Battle of the Somme was immortalized even before the fighting had ceased. The intensive British and French assault along the chalk ridges of the Somme River Valley began on July 1, 1916; scarcely two months later, a silent film — shot within and behind the British trenches — screened in London cinemas. The Somme, like so many other battles of the Great War, was also commemorated in real time by such trench-line poets as Alan Seeger, who composed what became, in short order, their own epitaphs (“I have a rendezvous with Death”) as German shells shook the wet earth beneath them.

headline: Short-Term Gains, Long-Term Trouble
text: Most of the job numbers, even when they look good, are still not even close to what they were before the Great Recession, which officially began in December 2007.

headline: Fine Arts
text: Six illustrated art books reflect periods of intense conflict and social change.

headline: Comics
text: Collectors divide the history of comic books into discrete eras evocative of Olympic medals: golden age, silver, bronze. But the culture that comics have inspired, comprising as it does more than seven decades of fractious characters, creators and commentary across a variety of media, doesn’t surrender itself to so tidy a ­taxonomy.

headline: Guilty Pleasures
text: Roger Corman, the producer of hundreds of low-budget films with titles like “The Slumber Party Massacre,” has been mythologized not to death so much as to bland respectability, which some fans might argue is worse.

headline: New York Views
text: THE STORIES THEY TELL  Artifacts From the National ­September 11 Memorial Museum: A Journey of ­Remembrance  Skira Rizzoli, $19.95.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE INVENTOR AND THE TYCOON: The Murderer Eadweard Muybridge, the Entrepreneur Leland Stanford, and the Birth of Moving Pictures,  by Edward Ball. (Anchor, $16.95.) At the height of his genius, Eadweard Muybridge, a British immigrant whose advancements in photography in the late 1800s gave rise to the motion picture industry, killed his wife’s lover in cold blood. Ball weaves an account of that crime, and the sensational trial that followed it, into the larger story of Muybridge’s complicated relationship with his patron, the railroad magnate Leland Stanford.

headline: Tracking a Thief, Once You Know There Is One
text: The first time my father was ever robbed, decades ago, he was vacationing in England with my mom. A certified public accountant, he had certain fiscal habits, one of which was to count and order his money, highest denomination bill to lowest, all facing the same way in his wallet. He did this constantly, usually at home after work. In England, though, he performed the rite in the hotel pub. My mother was furious. For good reason.

headline: Inside the List
text: No. 1 Dad: James Patterson’s latest thriller, “Cross My Heart,” is new at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list. It’s Patterson’s second Alex Cross book to top the list this year and, impressively, his seventh novel to reach the hardcover list in 2013. (That’s not counting appearances on the middle-grade list, the young adult list, the mass-market paperback list, the e-book list or the manga list — and the year isn’t over yet.)

headline: Cooking
text: When the seasonal cookbook offerings include titles like “Fifty Shades of Kale” and an updated edition of “The Eat-a-Bug Cookbook,” choice is not a problem. The yearly avalanche includes something for everyone. There are books from star chefs and famous restaurants, the latest go-rounds from tried-and-true food writers, the now customary exercises in vegetable-worship, armchair-tourist cookbooks and one book that defies description.

headline: A Speakeasy Experience
text: Somewhere between the formality of a dinner theater and the cheesiness of a theme restaurant, the Heath at the McKittrick Hotel is — to use the phrase favored by marketing professionals — “a culinary experience.” Opened two weeks ago by Punchdrunk, the British theater company that also runs that immersive — sorry — theatrical experience, “Sleep No More,” in the same hotel in Chelsea, the Heath is a recreated speakeasy/supper club, complete with a jazz band, suspendered barmen, and haze of fake (i.e., health department-compliant) cigarette smoke. “When the band started playing,” said Ian Smith, one of five finance types who ate at the Heath last week, “I felt like I was in an episode of ‘Boardwalk Empire.’ ”

headline: Travel
text: Food is the springboard for much of this season’s best travel writing. From the novice who opens a Western-style restaurant in Kigali to the critic who gags over a series of bad meals in Cairo, the search for corporeal sustenance proves a reliable source of inspiration. But, as Lawrence Osborne reminds us, this quest isn’t always about food. Frequently — to borrow from Woody Allen — there must be a beverage.

headline: Gardening Yesterday
text: December is, of course, the holiday season, but for gardeners it’s also the reading season. In the garden, we play out fantasies, desires and longings, and the ensuing tussle with nature — sometimes gentle, sometimes violent — is for a beauty we can make. Like sex, quite a lot of gardening happens in the mind. This season, a few books that look back to the past may well stir your imagination.

headline: Interiors
text: It must be the whisper of time as it bends over the horizon, a susurration of mortality none can escape. What else could have prompted so many decorators to publish their portfolios, visual memoirs that attest to lives rich with clients? Decorating is one of the most evanescent of the visual arts. It’s painful to walk into a room in which every inch has been lavished with attention, imagination and money, only to learn that the wrecking ball is about to arrive, commissioned by the next decorator. Devastating — when it isn’t good riddance to bad rubbish. Sometimes it takes a while to tell the difference.

headline: Photography
text: Sometimes the world of photography books can seem not unlike that of popular music on disc, with endless repackaging of the classics — each new volume containing pictures that haven’t been previously reprinted, so that if you are a devotee or a completist you will have to shell out for another tome. And yet major surprises continue to arrive, dispatches from the past. Consider, for example, the work of the Chilean photographer Sergio Larrain (1931-2012), whose career was both extraordinary and unusually abbreviated. It was only after studying forestry at Berkeley that he began seriously taking pictures in the mid-1950s, and then an encounter with the Bolivian mystic Oscar Ichazo in 1968 caused him to retreat for the remainder of his life into meditation and yoga, taking small, quiet photos only occasionally, as complements to his inner quest. But for the decade or so that he was in the world and regularly taking pictures, his work, as amply illustrated in SERGIO LARRAIN (Aperture, $85), edited by Agnès Sire, was a constant source of wonder.

headline: Gardening Today
text: For gardeners, winter is a period of rest, if not entirely of relaxation. The trees are bare, the flower beds dormant, the pruners and trowels packed away in the toolshed. All those hours once spent weeding and mowing can now be devoted to recalling our triumphs and brooding over our failures. There’s also, finally, enough leisure time to study other people’s gardens and pick up a few pointers. And yet, infuriatingly, many of those gardens are also in sleep mode. What to do? The answer to that question — as to so many others — can be found in a book. Five of them, to be precise.

headline: Antarctica
text: Antarctica is a life-changing place. From its first explorers to today’s hardy souls who live and work there, it has always drawn certain people to its austere and compelling majesty. If you go to Antarctica, it may or may not change your life. But what matters is that Antarctica itself is changing and, at the same time, changing us. These two books will first open your eyes to the staggering beauty of the place. Then they will chill you. At the bottom of the world, strange and terrifying things are happening miles above and beneath the icy surface, some of them understood, some not; many man-made, some irreversible and all determining the future of this last clean place on earth, and of earth itself.

headline: Covering the Waterfront, in Photographs
text: Many of the freighters and tankers arriving

headline: Screen Gems
text: The moment held forever on the cover of “Moments That Made the Movies” is a lulu: Joe Gillis floating facedown in Norma Desmond’s swimming pool in “Sunset Blvd.” The water is lit from below; the palette is 5 a.m. City of Angels black-and-white. Gazing at the image even in silence, anyone who loves movies can conjure the voice-over narration of the dead man, talking to the audience directly, describing to us how he, “just a movie writer with a couple of B pictures to his name,” has wound up at the decaying mansion of a faded movie star with two shots in his back and one in his stomach. The poor dope. Maybe an advanced movie lover can even hear the unique voice of the speaker — William Holden as Gillis — telling the tale that won the picture 11 Oscar nominations in 1951.

headline: Image of the Day: December 6
text: Mr. Mandela, 95, died in Johannesburg, South Africa, after a long illness.

headline: Star Style
text: It may approach a Tom Swifty, but costume designers have an image problem. As fashion designers have inflated to dirigible proportions — stamping their initials on baby bootees, plotting I.P.O.’s and presiding like some kind of self-appointed Warren court over the quivery aspirants of “Project Runway” — their kinfolk in the movie business have receded ever more into the shadows. They emerge only around Oscar time, even then making little impression on the culture at large. Almost two decades have passed since Lizzy Gardiner, one-half of the Australian team that outfitted “The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert,” accepted her statuette, jangling gently in a dress she’d made from 254 American Express gold cards. “I’m broke,” she explained, “and I didn’t have anything to wear.”

headline: L’Amour
text: Long before Cole Porter observed that birds, bees and educated fleas do it, the French poet Alexis Piron made the same point in his X-rated “Ode to Priapus.” Anthologized in “The Libertine,” the literary historian Michel Delon’s delectable new volume of 18th-century French erotica, it catalogs an array of fauna (“Dromedary, whale, and duck, / Insect, critter, man”) united in their lusty predilection for verbs and nouns too obscene to print in this newspaper, though collectively identifiable by Porter’s own euphemistic pronoun of choice: “Everything does it, reasonable or not.” Reminiscent, too, of the catalog aria from Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” — an enumeration of the skirt-chasing hero’s thousands of conquests by age, rank, nationality and hair color — Piron’s dirty laundry list underscores both the dogged ubiquity of the sex instinct and the inexhaustible variety of its ­expressions.

headline: Tradition!
text: In my family, we have a ritual. (Tradition!) After a particularly wonderful Shabbat or holiday dinner, we channel my great-grandmother Pearl Gottler and chant in unison, “Ach, I’m stoffed. I’m bloated. I couldn’t eat another bite.”

headline: Stuffed Animals
text: The 337 images in “Taxidermy” are artful and immaculate — everything that a taxidermy workshop, with its dust, fumes, stench, viscera and decay, is not. This book is eye candy (the frontispiece is, in fact, a surprisingly delectable array of glass eyes), which makes sense because Alexis Turner is the founder of London Taxidermy, a business that supplies natural history artifacts to the fashion and film industries, among other clients. You can see his stuffed and pickled props in the “Harry Potter” films, “Sherlock ­Holmes,” “Pirates of the Caribbean,” “Les ­Misérables,” “Anna Karenina,” “Skyfall” — and now in this book.

headline: Release the Hounds
text: Gregory Berns wasn’t sure if his pug Newton really loved him. Newton wagged his tail and gave kisses, but that wasn’t enough. Berns, a neuroscientist, wanted hard data. He also hoped to uncover “what makes for a strong dog-human bond” and how that might improve canine welfare. So he built a special M.R.I. machine, and trained dogs to lie still inside it, allowing him to study their brains. Though the results may seem obvious to dog lovers (that humans and dogs experience emotions similarly), they’re not a given for science. Berns’s book is a beautiful story about dogs, love and neurology that shows how nonhuman relationships are inspiring researchers to look at animals in new ways, for their benefit and ours.

headline: Public Painting
text: Walls in New York sometimes do more than divide space. A few of them are also pages of the city’s history writ large — testament to the shifting civic vision of generations of New Yorkers. In “Murals of New York City: The Best of New York’s Public Paintings From Bemelmans to Parrish,” which features more than 30 large-scale works around the city, the muralist Glenn Palmer-Smith and the photographer Joshua McHugh tutor natives and tourists alike in how these walls — and a few ceilings — can best be appreciated.

headline: Razzle Dazzle
text: An instructive way of getting a sense of the power of Bob Fosse’s choreography is by listening to the original cast album of a 1959 musical called “Redhead.” The show ran for 452 performances, a head-­scratcher since the songs are merely serviceable. But the photos reveal all. The songs were irrelevant: What made “Redhead” a hit was the genius of Fosse’s dances.

headline: The Splendid Splinter
text: The people at the Alcor cryonics facility, in Scottsdale, Ariz., would have us believe that Ted Williams really is immortal. They have his body there, the head severed from the rest, flash-frozen in a giant thermos-like tank and awaiting only the scientific advancement that will allow him to be thawed, resuscitated and rejuvenated. Meanwhile, with every passing season, his longevity in the statistical department seems more and more certain. While other baseball records fall with actuarial regularity, Williams’s 1941 batting average of .406, the highest in nearly 90 years, shimmers ever more brightly, a landmark that even a hitter like Barry Bonds was unable to approach.

headline: Cat Fancy
text: Look — how can you not? — at the supple creature stretched across the divan. Legs bent and parted, arms folded overhead, eyes trained on some distant vision. She could lounge that way for hours, it seems, staring at the wall, or through the human who gazes on her, he confounded by her aloofness, tormented by what he cannot know: What does she feel? What does she desire? What does she think of me?

headline: Aerosol Art
text: In 1994, the filmmaker Charlie Ahearn went to see his friend Martin Wong the day before that artist and collector gave away his life’s work. Wong had recently received a diagnosis of H.I.V. and had decided to bestow his collection on the Museum of the City of New York, then head home to San Francisco to be with family. Ahearn describes the moment as a visit to “Ali Baba’s cave of secret art treasures,” where “Chinese ceramics, Christmas ornaments, gold frames and antiques, fireman jackets and hats, stacks of canvases and art hung to the ceiling.”

headline: Springsteen’s Handwritten Lyrics to ‘Born to Run’ Sell for $197,000
text: The handwritten lyrics to an embryonic version of Bruce Springsteen’s “Born to Run” were sold for $197,000 at an auction at Sotheby’s on Thursday, a spokesman for the auction house said.

headline: Sweet Soul Music
text: “Knock on Wood,” “Soul Man,” “Hold On, I’m Coming,” “In the Midnight Hour,” “These Arms of Mine,” “I’ve Been Loving You Too Long,” “Green Onions,” “I’ll Take You There,” “Who’s Making Love” and, of course, the theme from “Shaft”: The list of hits produced by Stax could fill this page by itself. But Robert Gordon’s “Respect Yourself: Stax Records and the Soul Explosion” — “Respect Yourself” as performed by the Staple Singers, that is — is much more than a nostalgia trip or a soundtrack on paper. Gordon, a Memphis resident who has written books about his city’s music and a well-received biography of Muddy Waters, profiles singers, songwriters and producers. But he has also written a social history, viewing the company that for more than 15 years produced some of the most popular and important music in America as part of the history of Memphis and of the civil rights movement.

headline: Prequel
text: Before most American celebrity-watchers became aware of her as Jack Nicholson’s notably elegant girlfriend, in the mid-1970s — and before her acting career took off in 1985, when she was 34 (an Oscar award for “Prizzi’s Honor” and nominations for “Enemies: A Love Story” and “The Grifters”) — Anjelica Huston had a magical, if sometimes star-crossed, life in Ireland, England and New York. She was the daughter of the larger-than-life director John Huston (“The Treasure of Sierra Madre,” “The Maltese Falcon,” “The African Queen”), a man of great appetites and macho endeavor with whom “not only women but men of all ages fell in love . . . with that strange loyalty and forbearance men reserve for each other,” his daughter writes. Huston’s mother, Ricki Soma, a ballerina and the daughter of an Italian-restaurant owner in New York, was John Huston’s fourth wife. They eloped when she was 18 and he was in his mid-40s. Huston was their second child and — with her mother now transformed into the beautiful couture-clad “translucent and remote” mistress of a vast West Ireland estate — she was raised amid multiple servants, visiting film-world eminences and colorful locals in the kind of world that has disappeared, other than, say, in movies starring Keira Knightley.

headline: Hard Knocks
text: Football, George Will once argued, “combines the two worst things about America: violence punctuated by committee meetings.” But in fact those “committee meetings,” with their militaristic strategies and tribal rituals, help explain the National Football League’s popularity in America. Sure, the violence might be problematic, especially in light of recent head trauma studies. But did you see that hit in the 49ers game?! Pass the bean dip.

headline: American Songbook
text: In late 1938, with the world on the brink of war, Kate Smith asked Irving Berlin, the world’s most famous songwriter, for a patriotic song she could sing on her annual Armistice Day radio broadcast. He dusted off and reworked a number he had begun writing in 1918 but abandoned. Before introducing the song to her vast national audience, Smith predicted that it “will be timeless — it will never die — others will thrill to its beauty long after we are gone.”

headline: Heeeere’s Johnny!
text: The day after he was hired by Johnny Carson, an obscure young lawyer named Henry Bushkin tagged along with him and some thugs in the night as they broke into an apartment searching for proof of Carson’s wife’s infidelity. They found plenty, as Bushkin tells it, and Carson leaned against a wall and wept, revealing the .38 he was carrying in case things went wrong. That was in 1970, when Carson had already settled into his role as superstar host of “The Tonight Show.” Over the next 18 years, Bushkin was his lawyer, fixer, friend and liege, “like all those guys on ‘Entourage,’ except there was only me.”

headline: Cooking Light With Seafood
text: Many of you, still full from Thanksgiving, may be anticipating holiday parties to come and wondering how to balance things out with some of the meals in between. With this in mind, I decided to work on light fish and seafood dinners for this week’s Recipes for Health. They should provide you with a respite from rich food during this shortened window between Thanksgiving and Christmas.

headline: Allure
text: The jury is still out on glamour. Some critics see it as the scourge of modern society, an illusory opiate doled out by a ruling elite to dazzle the masses into submission. For others glamour is a fragile and endangered species, the inspirational product of simpler times — before, say, a photograph of Scarlett Johansson tripping and falling could become, in the space of an hour, an Internet meme — as our tell-all society collapses the distance between us and our idols irrevocably.

headline: Classical Pottery
text: Not so long ago, developing an informed appreciation for Greek vases, in particular fineware with painted scenes, was no easy matter for anyone aside from serious students and dedicated connoisseurs with access to the world’s museums. As for illustrated books, there wasn’t much between the affordable volumes of John Boardman’s Thames & Hudson paperback series, with their masterly text and plentiful but small and hard-to-see photographs in black and white, and expensive volumes with magnificent photos, mostly relegated to academic libraries. That’s all changed, largely because of the Internet, where high-resolution photographs of individual vases — on academic and curatorial websites with expert analysis, certainly, but also on the Flickr accounts of museumgoing tourists — let you zoom in on the tiny details in which much of the delight of Greek vase painting lies. But the lower cost of printing has also put beautifully printed large-format books within reach, and for readers getting interested in Greek vases for the first time, a coherent illustrated overview of the subject is invaluable and much more manageable on the page than on-screen.

headline: Paris-London
text: When it comes to frills and fashions, London defers to Paris. It was ever so. Jonathan Conlin, the American-born author of an admired history of London’s National Gallery, starts his series of sprightly strolls through these two great cities by imagining the journey of a “fashion doll,” a child-size mannequin that could be kitted out in the latest Paris style and brought back via Calais or Ostend for an astute dressmaker to use as her model when arraying London’s titled fashion lovers. The first such doll crossed the Channel — ready for the latest take on wimples, ladies? — in the 14th century. Prudently, the author confines his study in cultural crossings to the two centuries leading up to the Great War.

headline: Muppet Man
text: It’s not easy being a puppeteer. Consider the opening sequence of 1979’s “The Muppet Movie,” in which Kermit the Frog performed “The Rainbow Connection,” the ­follow-up to his breakout number, “Bein’ Green.” Kermit strummed his banjo while perched on a log in the middle of a swamp. The set had been carefully constructed on a studio back lot, but even fake swamps have real water. This required Jim Henson, Kermit’s creator and performer, to execute the complicated sequence submerged. As Kermit crooned, Henson lurked beneath the surface of the ersatz bayou, his lanky frame folded into a ­custom-made diving bell, his oxygen pumped in through a tube. To make his frog sing, the puppeteer had to become amphibious.

headline: Music Lessons
text: Seventeen pages into “Play It Again: An Amateur Against the Impossible,” Alan Rusbridger offers readers an implicit dare. Here the typeface changes from words to musical notes — not just any notes, but excerpts from Frédéric Chopin’s Ballade No. 1 in G minor, Op. 23, one of the most complex and challenging pieces in piano repertoire.

headline: Composers
text: On Jan. 1, 1869, the mother of two of Richard Wagner’s children, though not quite yet his wife, began keeping a diary. Though, calling the 14-year account that Cosima Wagner eventually produced a diary is like calling a battleship a boat. At the start of his idiosyncratic new book, “Richard Wagner: A Life in Music,” Martin Geck notes that Cosima’s journals ended up running nearly one million words. Full of mythologizing and after-the-fact edits, they give us, in conjunction with Wagner’s own copious writing and correspondence, an unprecedented opportunity: For no other cultural figure of his significance do we have a record of daily life so relentlessly extensive.

headline: The Chelsea
text: “It’s a sad irony of New York life that over time, the fabled buildings and institutions that first attract us to the city fade into invisibility.” So begins Sherill Tippins’s thorough, if not groundbreaking, Hotel Chelsea history. For the past dozen or so years, the Chelsea has been raging against invisibility. Former guests and residents as different as Dee Dee Ramone, Abel Ferrara and Ethan Hawke have featured it in their work. Current residents have waged a very public battle with its recent owners. In anticipation of a potentially soul-killing renovation, two new books capture its lovably scuzzy spirit. One is an evocative coffee-table book by the photographer Victoria Cohen, HOTEL CHELSEA (Pointed Leaf Press, $95), which treats the oddly painted rooms’ quirky mix of old and new furniture, worn carpeting and garish bedspreads as something like sacred relics. The other is Tippins’s doorstop-hefty ­“Inside the Dream Palace,” which aspires to tell the “definitive story.”

headline: Pre-Fab Four
text: Approaches to retelling the Beatles’ story slice in two distinct directions: narrow or wide. Some authors choose a single figure and bore down deep, which has brought the count of Paul McCartney life stories to at least 10, with more in the pipeline. Others frame the narrative from more expansive angles, weaving in the era’s social texture, politics and cultural context (see Devin McKinney’s shrewd “Magic Circles” from 2003 or Jonathan Gould’s peerless “Can’t Buy Me Love” of 2007).

headline: An App to Find Holiday Light Displays
text: If there were a Charlie Brown Christmas tree of apps, it would be Christmas and Holiday Light Displays.

headline: Challenged by Tea Party, Veteran Mississippi Senator Seeks 7th Term
text: WASHINGTON — Thad Cochran, a Mississippi Republican who was first elected to the Senate in 1978, set up a generational and ideological clash in the state’s Republican primary when he announced Friday that he would seek a seventh term in 2014.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Inside Llewyn Davis,’ ‘Out of the Furnace’ and ‘Lenny Cooke’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on Scott Cooper’s drama “Out of the Furnace,” the period Coen brothers film “Inside Llewyn Davis” and the documentary “Lenny Cooke.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Kaikado Canister
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Eli Broad, at Art Basel in Miami, Focuses on Los Angeles
text: The billionaire collector and philanthropist Eli Broad picked up an early John Baldessari work at the Dominique Lévy gallery on the first day of the giant Art Basel art fair in Miami. But over lunch at the Setai Hotel on Thursday afternoon, he was much more interested in talking about what may be his Baldessari’s newest home: the $140 million contemporary art museum that Mr. Broad and his wife, Edythe, are building on Grand Avenue in downtown Los Angeles. The architectural team of Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio were on hand to show off the work in progress, which is scheduled for completion in the fall of 2014.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Notable Books of 2013
text: This week, the Book Review editors Sarah Smith, Alida Becker, Barry Gewen, Gregory Cowles and Parul Sehgal discuss the year’s notable books; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Notable Books of 2013
text: This week, editors at the Book Review editors discuss the year’s notable books.

headline: Time for an Equestrian Transformation
text: For the Ford Mustang and its loyal fans, there’s only one question: Where has the time gone? A 22-year-old college graduate wowed by the first, illustrious Mustang would be roughly 72 today — and, as Ford surely hopes, may still be excited by the latest model, whether to drive it or to recommend it to a grandchild.

headline: Reactions to Mandela’s Death
text: Notable figures and readers of The New York Times share their perspectives.

headline: Where Mandela Once Boxed, a New Set of Struggles
text: SOWETO, South Africa — Tumelo Mabitle shifted his weight from foot to foot and took a few sturdy jabs at the heavy bag.

headline: Hyundai, BMW, McLaren, Dodge and Mercedes-Benz Issue Recalls
text: Hyundai will recall about 15,500 Entourage minivans from the 2007-8 model years for a corrosion-related steering problem, according to a report the automaker posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Judge Rejects Bid to Stop Deals on Leasing Public Housing Land
text: The New York City Council and a group of public housing tenants have lost a bid to stop the Bloomberg administration from making any deals to lease public housing land to private developers.

headline: Credit Suisse Highlights Its Break Dancer Who Strips
text: Big banks occasionally like to highlight their employees’ achievements, including career milestones, charity work or even running a marathon.

headline: Think Back: Let's Make a Deal
text: As President Obama seeks common ground with Republicans, The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus looks at major deals Democratic presidents and conservative legislators have reached.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Germany; California; Amsterdam
text: Christmas Markets, Germany

headline: An Encore for the ‘Smash’ That Wasn’t
text: As the characters from “Smash” would tell you — if they still had a television series on which to say it — not every show-business dream comes true.

headline: Paramount Signs a Deal to Rehire Bruckheimer
text: LOS ANGELES — Jerry Bruckheimer is once again a Paramount top gun.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A penthouse in Murray Hill, a one-bedroom on the Upper East Side and a two-bedroom in a prewar Brooklyn building.

headline: Times Minute | Mandela’s Funeral Plans
text: Also in the Minute, mixed reactions in the Soweto township and blanket coverage around the world.

headline: Peppy Speaks! (And Gives an Interview)
text: PARIS — When Bérénice Bejo talks about her 2012 Oscar loss for her performance in “The Artist,” she admits she was disappointed.

headline: Times Minute | Plans for Mandela’s Funeral
text: In the Video

headline: 25 More Cookbooks
text: THE A.O.C. COOKBOOK. By Suzanne Goin. (Knopf, $35.) The author of “Sunday Suppers at Lucques” follows up with recipes from her small-plates, wine and cheese restaurant in Los Angeles. Caroline Styne, her business partner and wine director, provides wine notes for pairings.

headline: In Six Neglected Films, a Universe of Yearning
text: Appropriation can be a funny thing, as Djibril Diop Mambéty’s galvanizing “Touki Bouki” demonstrates.

headline: Awful Children
text: “We blot out bad things from our minds and especially when they have been bad things we ourselves have done, in childhood perhaps most of all.” So says the narrator of “Dolly,” the second of two short novels by Susan Hill in which bad things done in childhood refuse, despite grown-up minds’ best efforts, to stay blotted. Nasty stuff of this sort may resurface after years of psychoanalysis or — less therapeutically if more efficiently — in the course of a compact, elegantly constructed ghost story, which happens to be one of Hill’s specialties. Her nerve-­shaking 1983 novel “The Woman in Black” is a modern classic of the genre, in the whispery manner of M. R. James and Robert Aickman. (It was made into a movie, unmemorably, last year; a stage adaptation has been running in London since 1988.)

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE HEIR APPARENT: A Life of Edward VII, the Playboy Prince,  by Jane Ridley. (Random House, $35.) He was vain, gluttonous, promiscuous and none too bright, but “Bertie” emerges as an appealing character in Ridley’s superb book.

headline: Scholars Explore Christian Perspectives on Animal Rights
text: BALTIMORE — “There was a time when Rebecca, our eldest, was desperate to have a pet,” David Clough told me when we met at the American Academy of Religion conference, held in Baltimore before Thanksgiving. “And she was in the unhappy position of having a father who had reflected ethically on the question at some length” — a father with misgivings about the human use of animals, even for companionship.

headline: Getting Back to Even
text: For the 38th consecutive month, the country added jobs: 203,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in November, to be more precise.

headline: What I Said
text: I’m in a meeting of the Bavarian Illuminati Group of 30; very interesting discussion, all off the record. But I can’t resist mentioning that one participant, arguing that we should end easy-money policies despite the continuing depressed state of the economy, warned of potential costs and declared that these costs have been stressed by “very serious people.” The participant clearly did not have capital letters on the words, even implicitly. But I did have a hard time not laughing.

headline: Hell on Shoe Leather
text: During the golden weeks of autumn, it seemed as if everyone in the world wanted to go for a walk with William B. Helmreich. The journalist from Norway. Students who have lapped up his courses at City College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. The publicist at Princeton University Press, which just published “The New York Nobody Knows: Walking 6,000 Miles in the City,” his doorstop-size account of four years of trekking into every corner of the five boroughs, dead-end streets and desolate industrial areas included.

headline: Spending Again, Mets Lure Granderson
text: When Curtis Granderson said earlier this week that he had the salmon while having lunch with Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson, the comment, almost predictably, turned into comic material. The Mets could not afford to offer Granderson a steak, the Twitter jokes went. The Mets had to split the bill. And of course Granderson ended up eating salmon; the Mets, after all, are always swimming upstream.

headline: A Spoonful of Sugar for a Sourpuss
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — What happens when Richard M. Sherman hunches over a baby grand piano and leads a singalong? Judging from a recent evening on the patio at the Polo Lounge here, people not only warble the ditties but are magically transported back to childhood.

headline: Cano Said to Leave for Mariners; Beltran Reportedly Heads to Yanks
text: On Thursday afternoon, shortly before they were scheduled to meet with the Seattle Mariners, representatives for Robinson Cano placed a call to the Yankees, saying they believed their client could get a 10-year deal for more than $230 million. They wanted to know how the Yankees would respond.

headline: ‘Idol,’ Meet the Trapps: The Perils of Tinkering With Favorite Things
text: Nobody could solve the problem of this Maria.

headline: A Fanboy Shows Superheroes the Way
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Greg Berlanti, watching from a distance, couldn’t stop smiling as he sidled up to members of his creative team on the set here of “Arrow” — his second-season CW network adaptation of the “Green Arrow” comic book character — gushing like the adolescent fanboy he used to be.

headline: T HOLIDAY
text: Rei Kawakubo, the singular designer of Commes des Garcons, is bringing her multibrand store Dover Street Market to New York City.

headline: No Rehearsals for a Prestige Cast
text: In terms of Oscar nominees and winners per frame, the ensemble films “August: Osage County” and “American Hustle” may be tough to beat this season. (Honorable mention: “Prisoners,” starring Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Melissa Leo and Paul Dano.) But “Out of the Furnace,” from the writer-director Scott Cooper (whose “Crazy Heart” earned two Oscars, including a long-overdue statue for Jeff Bridges) and starring Christian Bale (Oscar winner), Casey Affleck (nominee), Woody Harrelson (nominee) and Forest Whitaker (winner) makes a strong showing.

headline: Undaunted by Giants
text: There is no shortage of residential real estate expertise in real estate-obsessed New York City. Upward of 20,000 licensed professionals are eager to step in and, for a seemingly small commission, assist sellers and buyers in negotiations with high-impact consequences. The brokerages employing the vast majority of agents are real estate’s equivalent of corporations, with multilayered staffs equipped to unflinchingly process multitudes of transactions. Their success is measured in quantifiable dollars; their reputations precede them.

headline: Review: 2014 Lexus LX 570
text: Need to crawl over boulders and tow a 7,000-pound boat before heading to the opera? The 2014 Lexus LX 570 might be your tool. Understand the inefficiencies before writing the big check though.

headline: Enhanced Medical Care for an Annual Fee
text: On a recent morning, Edward S. Goldberg, an unusually affable internist who bears the look of a scholarly Robert De Niro, sat in his office on the Upper East Side and described the realities of practicing general medicine in the Manhattan of the 21st century. Dr. Goldberg, who also retains a specialty in gastroenterology, opened his practice in 1993 and accepted insurance for the first 16 years. By 2008 his reimbursements for office visits had been, in some cases, reduced to a tenth of what they were in the previous decade, he said. Colonoscopies, which had once rendered him $1,800 per procedure, were now bringing in $350.

headline: Reflections From Soweto
text: Near Nelson Mandela’s former home, South Africans mourn the late leader and remember his legacy as a freedom fighter.

headline: Nelson Mandela, Freedom’s Champion
text: To the Editor:

headline: You Can’t Fight Guns With Silence
text: The shock of the gun massacre of 20 schoolchildren and six adults last Dec. 14 in Newtown, Conn., has largely dissipated in Congress, which proved unresponsive to proposals for stronger gun safety. But the shock remains for a nationwide group of alarmed mothers organized after the carnage, who are taking to the air waves with the message that a ritual moment of silence to honor the victims on the anniversary is hardly enough. “With 26 more school shootings since that day, ask yourself: Is silence what America needs right now?” the new ad entreats as an intruder masked in black approaches a schoolhouse door.

headline: Holiday Gift Guide
text: Book the ultimate experience, like following in your ancestors’ footsteps (literally) or dining at every top restaurant in the world.

headline: Holiday Gift Guide
text: The most delicious foods, from organic cured bacon to artisanal jams, sent monthly to your home.

headline: Holiday Gift Guide
text: A piece from one of the world’s great jewelry houses is an instant classic, a sound investment and a family heirloom.

headline: Chinese Police Recommend Trial for Rights Advocate
text: HONG KONG — The police in Beijing have recommended that one of China’s most prominent human rights advocates, Xu Zhiyong, be tried for his role in organizing demonstrations demanding that the Communist Party disclose officials’ wealth and provide equal educational opportunities, his lawyer and a friend said Friday.

headline: Live Performance of ‘Sound of Music’ Is Ratings Gem for NBC
text: NBC’s gamble of filling an entire night with live musical theater paid off handsomely on Thursday as “The Sound of Music,” with Carrie Underwood in the Julie Andrews role of Maria, posted the network’s best entertainment ratings for a Thursday night since 2009.

headline: U.S. Faces Difficult Path in World Cup
text: No goals were scored on Friday. No substitutions were used, no games were won, and no points were tallied. Yet somehow, it felt as if the United States national team lost.

headline: Holiday Guide
text: Commission a painting of your loved one (or yourself).

headline: Holiday
text: For the man who has everything, offer a pair of these personally crafted shoes, like traditional English brogues or chic French boots.

headline: Holiday
text: Sharpen your driving skills with a range of options, from racing through Finland’s icy terrain to off-roading in Africa.

headline: Beneath Malta’s Beauty, a Tangled History
text: Nicholas de Piro doesn’t look like a warrior monk. As the bespectacled grandfather padded around his 16th-century palazzo, pointing out curiosities like a gilded sedan chair and silver medical tools, he appeared more likely to offer me a cup of tea than slay anyone in the name of Christ. And yet that is the sort of thing Mr. de Piro’s order, the Knights of Malta (officially the Sovereign Hospitaller Order of the Knights of St. John of Jerusalem, of Rhodes and of Malta), were known for in their heyday. Drawn from the most noble families of Europe, they left their homelands, took vows of chastity and obedience and dedicated themselves to fighting infidels. The order no longer wages war, focusing instead on caring for the sick and poor. Until I arrived at Mr. de Piro’s doorstep on the Mediterranean island-nation of Malta, though, I’d had no idea that the Knights of Malta still existed.

headline: Views From Malta
text: Take a tour of the Mediterranean island-nation’s capital, Valletta.

headline: A Commodity Business in Name and Prospects
text: Deutsche Bank’s decision to ditch commodities portends just how commoditized the business may be. The German lender is quitting energy, agriculture, base metals and dry bulk trading. That should free up capital without hurting results. And while it ought to ease the pain from a deep swoon in commodities, profits remain elusive for almost all banks involved.

headline: T HOLIDAY
text: Fashion’s purest visionary, Rei Kawakubo, is about to redefine shopping in New York City. Her latest collection for Comme des Garçons is strange, beautiful, singular and, for most of us, unwearable. Yet fashion’s most powerful provocateur is also one of its savviest commercial minds.

headline: Furnishing Small Castles at the Tiny Doll House
text: Leather drum tables, chinoiserie mirrors, beanbag chairs — the Tiny Doll House carries all kinds of miniature furnishings from all eras, all of them intricately detailed, and all of them very, very small.

headline: Interior Design for a Dollhouse
text: The Tiny Doll House on the Upper East Side carries detailed miniature furnishings from all eras, and all of them very, very small.

headline: The 2014 Lexus LX 570: A Behemoth for a Modern Age
text: Car buyers who are impressed by efficiency will wince when looking at the 2014 Lexus LX 570. It weighs three tons. Power is produced by a 5.7-liter V8 that makes 383 horsepower and drinks premium-grade gasoline. During my test drive, I saw about 11 miles per gallon in easy city driving. And given the size of this hulking S.U.V., the interior is not particularly spacious.

headline: Kristen Wiig Is a Serious Actress
text: “Kristen Wiig is currently staring at a meatball sitting at a table at Dumpy’s. Her hair is wet and she’s wearing a towel.”

headline: Health Care Law Providing Relief and Frustration
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Mike Horrigan is a lifelong Democrat with heart problems who supports President Obama’s health care law because he expects it will help many people obtain better insurance, including himself.

headline: Big Ticket | Vintage-Modern Fusion for $43 Million
text: A vintage TriBeCa loft building designed as a department store in 1862, reinvented as a warehouse for a children’s shoe company and then, in 2001, gut-renovated and transformed into boutique apartments, has sold for $43 million. It was the most expensive sale of the week, and garnered one of the highest prices for a downtown residence, according to city records.

headline: Bloomberg Says Critics of His Spanish Need to ‘Get a Life’
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has been unusually reflective lately as he prepares to leave office after 12 years, offered a parting thought Friday to some of his critics — specifically, those who have mocked his sometimes tin-eared attempts over the years at speaking Spanish.

headline: T HOLIDAY
text: The “Bridesmaids” actress helps pen her own celebrity profile.

headline: Holiday
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The 100 Notable Books of 2013
text: This week, The New York Times Book Review publishes its annual Holiday Books issue. In addition to roundups of the season’s cookbooks, travel books, gardening books and more, the issue includes the 100 Notable Books of 2013 — fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of the Book Review.

headline: David Blaine and Madonna to Judge Art for Charity
text: Madonna announced on Friday that the illusionist David Blaine would join her as a guest curator for the December installment of Art for Freedom, the online competition that she started in September with Vice, the multimedia company. The goal of the program is to encourage artists, photographers, videographers and poets to create works that put a spotlight on social justice.

headline: Whisper Campaigns and Out-Loud Tweets
text: Over at Vulture, the Bagger’s pal Kyle Buchanan checks in on a deliciously evil part of awards lobbying, the whisper campaigns against front-runners. You know you’re a front-runner when someone is out to destroy you.

headline: Art Market in the Doldrums
text: Recent auction reports may give the impression that the art market is skyrocketing. But, to judge by the Mei Moses index, which compares repeat sales of the same artworks, the market has has remained relatively flat over the last two years.

headline: Garth Brooks is Back, Heroes in Tow
text: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the singer’s career and his new box set, “Blame It All On My Roots: Five Decades of Influences.”

headline: Materially Speaking ... Oh, Christmas Tree?
text: Looking back on it, I blame the Christmas tree for any material excesses we might be guilty of. We are not that sort of people, I promise. We drive secondhand cars. Most of the front half of the house hasn’t been renovated in the 30 years we’ve lived here. We pay cash.

headline: Movie Review: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Inside Llewyn Davis."

headline: A Tap-Dancing Act by the Minsky Sisters
text: The Minsky Sisters went on after the appetizer, which was not a bad time. The music began: “Sugar Foot Stomp.” Then them: tap, tap, tappity-tap-tap. They did time steps, wings, paradiddles — spanking the floor.

headline: Financial-Crisis Recoveries, Compared
text: As mentioned in a previous post, the United States job market recovery has been anemic, but recoveries after financial crises have historically been even worse.

headline: Mobile Banks Gaining Popularity With Young Consumers
text: TURIYA GOETZE, a 23-year-old teaching assistant in Kansas City, Kan., found herself looking for a new bank this summer. Her student checking account at a large national bank had expired, and she was worried about paying lots of fees on a traditional account.

headline: Movie Review: 'Out of the Furnace'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Out of the Furnace."

headline: Mandela’s Socialist Failure
text: In the last two decades of his life, Nelson Mandela was celebrated as a model of how to liberate a country from the colonial yoke without succumbing to the temptation of dictatorial power and anti-capitalist posturing. In short, Mandela was not Mugabe, South Africa remained a multi-party democracy with free press and a vibrant economy well-integrated into the global market and immune to hasty Socialist experiments. Now, with his death, his stature as a saintly wise man seems confirmed for eternity: there are Hollywood movies about him — he was impersonated by Morgan Freeman, who also, by the way, played the role of God in another film; rock stars and religious leaders, sportsmen and politicians from Bill Clinton to Fidel Castro are all united in his beatification.

headline: Movie Review: 'Lenny Cooke'
text: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews "Lenny Cooke."

headline: Icy Weather Grounds Flights Across the U.S.
text: A layer of ice and snow accompanied by plunging temperatures swept across the country on Friday, leading to the cancellation of hundreds of flights and delays at some airports.

headline: A Watering Hole for Writers
text: Elaine’s attracted a slew of literary notables, who even had their own table at the restaurant.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Eyes Solved
text: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out why a 9-year-old boy had nearly a week of a waxing and waning fever and swollen glands. Turns out, it was not much of a challenge for many of our readers. A whopping 50 percent of those who responded recognized this disease as …

headline: The Gun Report: December 6, 2013
text: * The House of Representatives overwhelmingly voted to extend the Undetectable Firearms Act, which makes it illegal to manufacture, possess or sell guns that lack material that can set off a metal detector—but didn’t amend the law to require permanent metal inserts in plastic guns. As the law stands, gun manufactures abide by an honor system whereby they promise to keep enough metal in a weapon to set off alarms. The N.R.A. has so far stayed silent on the measure’s bipartisan renewal. The bill, sponsored by North Carolina Republican Howard Coble, now heads to the Senate, where Democratic lawmakers are considering revisions to deal with emerging technology, like 3D printed guns.

headline: After Trying Times, at Last Something to Celebrate
text: Marni Galison was single and looking — but not for herself.

headline: Colin Eglin, 88, Key White Opponent of Apartheid, Dies
text: Colin Eglin, a South African politician who was at the forefront of his country’s white, liberal opposition to apartheid and who then helped draft the Constitution that ended it in 1993, died on Nov. 29 in Cape Town. He was 88.

headline: Record Prices Mask a Tepid Market for Fine Art
text: A few weeks ago, a triptych portrait by the British modernist painter Francis Bacon sold for $142.4 million, a record for a work of art at auction. The next night, a silk-screen print, “Silver Car Crash (Double Disaster),” by the American pop artist Andy Warhol brought $105.4 million. And this week, “Saying Grace,” by the American illustrator Norman Rockwell, sold for $46.1 million.

headline: Generation Born After Apartheid Sees Mandela’s Fight as History
text: JOHANNESBURG — Sitting in her comfortable suburban living room 45 minutes east of Johannesburg, Nokuthula Magubane, 18, was doing something close to unthinkable to older generations of black South Africans: She was affectionately praising Afrikaans.

headline: Born Free in South Africa
text: The future of South African politics may depend on the generation born after Mandela.

headline: Pathetic Centrists
text: So progressive Democrats have seized on an op-ed by the group Third Way — an op-ed attacking Elizabeth Warren and Bill de Blasio for their terrible, horrible economic populism — as a way to start reclaiming the party from the “centrists”. And it’s working: the centrists are very much on the run.

headline: Popcast: Garth Brooks Is Back, Heroes in Tow
text: This week: The semi-return and musical autobiography of Garth Brooks.

headline: Wagner’s World, Strings Attached
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — A hush descended on the auditorium of the University of Florida’s Phillips Center here on a recent afternoon, as wide-eyed children leaned forward in their seats, watching the Queen of Hearts lead Alice to the Gryphon. Suspended from fine threads inside a jewel box of a traveling stage, the characters moved with fluid grace, their gestures synchronized to the actors’ voices and the soft strains of folk music that came off the speakers in the Salzburg Marionette Theater’s production of “Alice in Wonderland.”

headline: Does This Dress Make Me Look Incredible?
text: Who knew that Dr. Brian Mark Bolante was a tulle kind of guy? Certainly not he or his fiancée, Kate Roffler.

headline: U.S. Orders Changes at Metro-North After Derailment
text: Five days after a fatal Metro-North Railroad derailment in the Bronx, the Federal Railroad Administration issued an emergency order on Friday requiring the railroad to have two people in place to operate trains at potentially precarious sites.

headline: Weekend Reading: Giving Credit for the Volcker Rule
text: Financial regulators are expected to approve a version of the Volcker Rule next Tuesday that is more powerful than Republicans and Wall Street lobbyists would have liked. Jamie Dimon, the chief of JPMorgan Chase and one of the most outspoken critics of the rule, deserves some of the credit for its passage.

headline: Talking Race With a Toddler Who Wasn’t Talking About Race at All
text: Recently, my 27-month-old daughter, Morgan, asked this: “Mommy, can you hand me the black one?”

headline: Reviving Elaine’s Without Elaine
text: The swanky canopy will be out front again at 1703 Second Avenue at 88th Street, braving East River winds with new fabric popping on the original frame. It will be charcoal, not yellow, though. Inside, the walls will be decorated with framed revenants of the room’s high-oxygen heyday. But really. Can there be a new Elaine’s without Elaine?

headline: The Making of Dover Street Market New York
text: Rei Kawakubo, the singular designer of Commes des Garçons, is bringing her multibrand store to New York City.

headline: Nuns, Missing in Syria, Resurface in Video
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A group of nuns who vanished recently from the ancient Aramaic-speaking Syrian town of Maaloula resurfaced on Friday in a video, saying that they had left with rebels to escape shelling in the area and were safe inside a villa in a nearby rebel-held town.

headline: Turning a Retirement Into a Hiatus
text: Alessandra Ferri, like so many ballerinas before her, knew when it was time to quit. At 44, she retired from American Ballet Theater, performing her final Juliet there in 2007.

headline: Hints of Elaine’s in the Writing Room
text: The idea behind the above image was to conjure the spirit of Elaine’s, the famed Upper East Side bar and restaurant, in a setting where it was now invisible.

headline: Wheelies: The Shanghai Fog Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: Properties include a six-bedroom home in Purchase, N.Y., with a guest cottage on 2.7 acres, and a 1940 brick house with three bedrooms in River Edge, N.J.

headline: See Red Flags, Hear Red Flags
text: WHAT do Enron and the corporate-accounting scandals of the early 2000s have in common with the subprime-mortgage crisis and the Great Recession? In both cases, the delivery of accurate information to the broader economy was compromised because auditors were hired and paid by the firms they audited.

headline: What if the Flood Maps Are Just Plain Wrong?
text: As Hurricane Sandy approached the Northeast coastline last year, hundreds of families felt secure that they would remain safely above the worst of it. Their confidence came from longstanding assurances that federal flood maps were correct, that their homes and businesses were officially outside the flood plains predicted for even the worst of storms.

headline: Yanks Try a New Tactic: Restraint
text: This was their test. The Yankees, having already absorbed the costly and crippling embarrassment of a 10-year contract to a player over 30, were asked to do it again. They said no. They lost their best hitter Friday, yet it was a victory for the organization.

headline: Following a Recruit, and Sizing Up the Atlanta Police Force
text: In mid-August 2012, I was reporting the article that appears in this Sunday’s magazine about Jacob Deng Mach, a Sudanese refugee — one of the so-called Lost Boys — who was hoping to become an Atlanta police officer. The 22-week training was notoriously grueling, and on his sixth day at the academy, Mach pulled up lame during a one-and-half-mile run. Academy officials sent him to an orthopedic clinic that saw a steady stream of injured recruits, and I followed in my car along with the video reporter, Brent McDonald, and the photographer, Béatrice de Géa.

headline: ‘Win’ Returns to Towson’s Vocabulary
text: TOWSON, Md. — When Coach Rob Ambrose arrived at Towson University in 2009, he had one goal for the Tigers’ moribund football program that he would not mention.

headline: Quirky Kikkerland Opens Its First Retail Store
text: Kikkerland, a New York company that has been selling quirky, colorful accessories for more than 20 years, has opened its first retail store. The shop — a 1,000-square-foot space in the West Village — offers the company’s entire collection, including lightning-bolt-shaped power strips and bottle openers resembling Mexican wrestlers, along with products from other manufacturers. Kevin Brynan, an owner of the home store Mxyplyzyk, which closed its Greenwich Avenue location last year after more than two decades, was hired to assist in the creation. “I was actually one of their first customers,” in the early ’90s, Mr. Brynan said, adding that he and Kikkerland’s owner, Jan van der Lande, have long shared an appreciation for amusing design. The store’s interior, designed by FormNation, is as playful as the products, with display structures shaped like buildings, tables reminiscent of haphazardly stacked boxes and a central shelving unit that doubles as a floor-to-ceiling ladder to nowhere. Kikkerland is at 493 Avenue of the Americas (West 13th Street). Information: 212-678-2250 or kikkerland.com.

headline: For Grandchildren, the Gift of Financial Awareness
text: THIS is the time of year when many grandparents struggle to figure out what to get their grandchildren for the holidays — and many parents, stuck in the middle, worry that those presents will be too indulgent. Instead, a group of financial educators is advocating that grandparents, with their children’s support, give their grandchildren the gift of financial awareness.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Wild, Woolly Chairs at Design Miami
text: The chairs at Design Miami have grown fur. A number of vintage pieces, which bring to mind Hans Wegner’s Halyard chair and the artist François-Xavier Lalanne’s sheep series, have had their hard edges softened by upholstery in shearling or Mongolian lamb. Juliet Burrows, of the Scandinavia-focused New York design gallery Hostler Burrows, says of the pieces: “They sell out as soon as we put them on the floor.”

headline: Emergency Order for Metro-North
text: After a fatal train derailment on Sunday, the Federal Railroad Administration ordered Metro-North to make changes in the interest of passenger safety.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Greece, Ukraine, India and the Philippines.

headline: Enrollment Errors Put Medical Coverage at Risk
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday that the enrollment records for roughly a quarter of all the people who signed up for health insurance on its website in October and November could contain errors, raising questions about whether those consumers would get coverage in time to pay for their medical care next month.

headline: Send in the Cameras: Sondheim on TV
text: Even Stephen Sondheim’s die-hard fans may not know that he considers “Opening Doors,” from “Merrily We Roll Along,” his most autobiographical song.

headline: Something New, Something Old
text: TESTED 2014 Toyota Tundra “1794” CrewMax 4x4

headline: 'Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom'
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom.”

headline: Hyundai Reverses Policy on Settling Warranty Disputes
text: Until Friday evening, owners of Hyundais who had not studied a supplement to their owner’s handbooks might have been surprised if their cars developed problems that resulted in disputes over warranty coverage. The jolt would come in the form of a policy that required some warranty disputes to be settled through binding arbitration — unless owners notified Hyundai, within 90 days of purchasing the vehicle, of their decision to opt out of the arrangement.

headline: On Alert for Red-Light Cameras
text: Banished by voters in Houston, facing legal challenges in Missouri and working undercover in New York City, traffic-monitoring cameras, promoted as accident-reducing tools by safety advocates and decried as intrusive revenue-generators by opponents, are nothing if not controversial.

headline: Reading for Enthusiasts of Every Level
text: For car and motorcycle enthusiasts a book can be a lasting and appreciated gift, but what book? These six reviews can help in sorting through publishers’ recent offerings. Among them is a clever racing history meant for young children and adults; a compendium of stories, some very bizarre indeed, about cars and the people who collect them; an account of Mustang’s first five decades; and a travelogue of a biker’s around-the-world journey.

headline: Week in Pictures for Dec. 6
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from New York City and the region. Subjects include Black Friday shoppers, the Metro-North train derailment and a graduating class of firefighters.

headline: Picking Up a Gun and an Accent
text: Why would an English rose portray a Texas thistle?

headline: A Singer Is Part of the Big Picture
text: Recently, a 25-foot-tall photograph of the jazz singer Cécile McLorin Salvant has been on view outside the main entrance to Jazz at Lincoln Center, at 60th Street and Broadway. Such a distinction happened quickly by jazz-world standards. She’s 24, and her first album with any distribution, “WomanChild” (Mack Avenue), came out only six months ago. But it’s not surprising that Jazz at Lincoln Center should want to go out on a limb to promote her. Though she writes her own songs, she puts original, idiosyncratic and virtuosic force on old repertory, some of it from the high era of American songbook standards, some of it older than jazz itself.

headline: Commemoration and Celebration
text: The superb violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter is back in town this week, and celebration is on her agenda. On Tuesday night, she will join the New York Philharmonic to herald her new Deutsche Grammophon CD, a red-blooded account of Dvorak’s rich, robust Violin Concerto. Manfred Honeck, who conducts the Berlin Philharmonic on the disc, will also direct her Philharmonic rendition of the work, presented alongside Dvorak’s “Carnival” Overture and “New World” Symphony. (7:30 p.m. Tuesday, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5656, nyphil.org.)

headline: Even Cowgirls Get a Show
text: Is it possible to have a catfight on horseback? We may find out thanks to “Rodeo Girls,” a reality series that begins on Wednesday at 11 p.m. on A&E.

headline: New Home for a Festival
text: The eclectic, genre-busting festival Migrating Forms, now in its fifth year, has itself migrated — to BAMcinématek. As for forms, expect all types, from experimental shorts to features by the Hong Kong auteur Johnnie To. The festival opens on Wednesday with an art-gallery-meets art-house punch: four shorts by Ryan Trecartin first presented as an installation at the Venice Biennale. Mr. Trecartin — he “seems bound for greatness,” the art critic Roberta Smith wrote in The New York Times — will introduce the films.

headline: Footwork With Fury
text: It’s easy to associate flamenco with wild stamping, and Soledad Barrio can stamp with fury. But she can also do more than that — much more. Her dynamic and emotional range helps make her one of today’s leading exponents of this traditional Spanish form. In her company, Noche Flamenca, she is surrounded by excellent dancing partners, guitarists and singers, and the little troupe can seem like a family onstage. In her solos, Ms. Barrio invests old flamenco forms with new life, showing herself capable of both light dartings and outbursts of raw passion, her footwork recalling laughter at one moment and gunfire the next.

headline: A (Big) Bit of Egypt in Central Park
text: The oldest man-made, outdoor object in New York is the towering, granite obelisk in Central Park known as Cleopatra’s Needle: It’s nearly 3,500 years old. The story of the 69-foot-tall, 220-ton, hieroglyphic-covered, Egyptian monolith is examined in “Cleopatra’s Needle,” an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that includes drawings, prints, photographs and textiles. One of a pair — the other, with the same name, is in London — the ancient obelisk and its companion were commissioned by Thutmose III in about 1450 B.C. for a sun temple in Heliopolis.

headline: Vintage Shows, Devotionals and a Tribute
text: Thelonious Monk

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius on KEXP
text: I’d recommend their shows this weekend at the Bowery Ballroom, but both shows are sold out. I will, however, report.

headline: Week in Pictures for Dec. 6
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Black Friday shoppers, the Metro-North train derailment and a graduating class of firefighters.

headline: On Getting Stuck (and Unstuck)
text: There is nothing more exhilarating to a songwriter than a new song being born.

headline: Behind Scenes, Ukraine’s Rich and Powerful Battle Over the Future
text: KIEV, Ukraine — They are not sleeping in tents in Independence Square, but Ukraine’s ultra-wealthy businessmen, known as the oligarchs, perhaps pose as grave a threat to President Viktor F. Yanukovich as the demonstrators on the streets of this capital city.

headline: Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs Match
text: PHOENIX — The premier pair event of the Fall North American Championships here, the Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs, was won on Thursday evening by Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y., and Agustin Madala, who lives in Argentina but represents Italy.

text: Chapter 1: Mustang Enters the Market

headline: Musical Tributes to Nelson Mandela
text: The pop music world was slow to concern itself with Nelson Mandela’s long imprisonment but his name, and his movement, would eventually become the focal point of numerous songs.

headline: AT&T Responds to Shareholders’ Concerns on User Data
text: In November, shareholders of AT&T and Verizon Communications sent resolutions to the two companies demanding that they publish regular reports on how they share customer information with the government for surveillance efforts.

headline: A Serene Baton for a Scottish Reverie
text: Many guest conductors come to the New York Philharmonic angling to make an impression. Not so the respected American conductor David Zinman, who led the orchestra on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall like a musician who had nothing to prove.

headline: Spectral Lure of the Magic That Faded
text: The narrator of the exquisite title song of Stacey Kent’s new album, “The Changing Lights,” remembers a carefree conversation years earlier in the back seat of a cab, in which she and her companion “vowed to guard our dreams from all the storms that lay ahead” and “laughed about the hopelessness of so many people’s lives as we slowly moved toward the changing lights.”

headline: ‘Sound of Music’ Director on What Went Right — and Wrong
text: Twitter had its fun and the critics were largely unimpressed, but mathematically speaking, NBC’s live “Sound of Music” ended up being a success for the network. Roughly 18.5 million viewers tuned in to watch Carrie Underwood and the rest of the cast rework the Von Trapp saga.

headline: In Chronicling Mandela, Finding Themselves
text: The photographers João Silva, David C. Turnley and Louise Gubb remember what it was like to photograph Nelson Mandela’s life.

headline: Long Journey for Mother and Child
text: Dances that keep going around in circles or in which the performers endlessly spin are usually joyful or ecstatic or in pursuit of a mystical transcendence. In “Fire Underground,” the piece by Donna Uchizono that debuted at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, she and Rebecca Serrell Cyr spin and spin and circle each other, but the effect is shattering. This dance is a heartbreaker.

headline: Modo, a New Version of Bikram Hot Yoga, Is Growing Popular
text: Two studio owners in Canada didn’t realize it at the time, but in the inflexible, almost militaristic world of Bikram yoga, where 90-minute classes are taught in 105-degree heat from a single memorized dialogue, their building studios without carpet turned out to be an act tantamount to secession.

headline: 6 Arrested in Theft of Truck With Radioactive Waste
text: MEXICO CITY — Six people have been arrested in connection with the theft this week of a truck carrying highly radioactive waste in an episode that caused an international scare and raised concerns about the transporting of nuclear material.

headline: Making a Difference in This Season of Giving
text: With the holiday giving season in full swing, you may be re-evaluating just how much to give to charitable causes and where to donate.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Strange but True Tales of Car Collecting’
text: Section 3: Stranger Than Fiction

headline: The Sound Is the Same, but the Music Has Awakened to the World
text: The perceived narrowness of North American hardcore punk 30 years ago — clomping two-beat rhythm, two-minute songs, interchangeable anti-authority verses yelled by young men — was really only heard from its orthodox wings. (Every movement needs them.) But if you could have seen it all from above, you’d have seen it going all over the place: funk, minimalism, surf, prog, noise, theater, comedy.

headline: French Court Allows Auction of Hopi Artifacts to Proceed
text: A French court on Friday allowed an auction house to go forward with the sale of 25 sacred Hopi Indian artifacts despite a legal battle initiated by the Native American tribe, which says that the masklike objects were stolen and that selling them is a sacrilege.

headline: Injections to Treat an Embarrassing Ailment Win U.S. Approval
text: The first drug to treat Peyronie’s disease — an embarrassing and sometimes painful curvature of the penis — won approval on Friday from the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Photographing Outside Apartheid’s White Bubble
text: João Silva was among a handful of photographers who made their reputation chronicling the fall of apartheid in South Africa. While he has gone on to cover conflicts in Iraq, Afghanistan and elsewhere, he still lives and works in South Africa, even photographing mourners gathering in front of Nelson Mandela’s home on Friday (below). Mr. Silva recalls covering those momentous years leading up to and after Mr. Mandela’s election as South Africa’s first black president in a conversation with Shreeya Sinha, an editor at the international desk, which has been edited. More photos by Mr. Silva of Mr. Mandela, and recollections by other photographers, were published Friday in a multimedia feature.

headline: Musical Chairs at the Met
text: In opera productions, the overall staging and individual performances tend to settle in and develop during the course of a run. This is something my colleague Zachary Woolfe explained in an exhaustive project in The New York Times that involved attending all nine performances of the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Bellini’s “Norma” this fall.

headline: Words of Courtship, Classic and Ad-Libbed
text: Seeing a new Shakespeare production can be dispiriting. Suffering through a director’s bombastic conceit or uninspired performances of lines that should set your imagination on fire, you might feel you’d be better off reading the play at home, by yourself.

headline: An Assist for Weinstein’s ‘Mandela’
text: LOS ANGELES — Harvey Weinstein is a master at using publicity to build buzz around his movies, whether that means ginning up a controversy or concocting a cultural tie-in.

headline: A Collector Bets His Eye and His Gut
text: MIAMI BEACH — Eleven minutes into the 11 a.m. preview of Art Basel Miami Beach on Wednesday, Steve Wilson, a Kentucky collector, made his first purchase: an installation made from dozens of bricks by the Italian artist Elisabetta Benassi.

headline: The Insider | Katerina Llanes of the Pérez Art Museum Miami on How to Navigate Basel
text: A not-for-tourists guide to Art Basel in Miami Beach might sound like an oxymoron. But it’s never a bad idea to ask a local for her advice on where to sniff out the best in art and fun. Katerina Llanes is a native Miamian who just moved back to the Magic City after a stint in Los Angeles, where she was a curator for MOCAtv. Her new post is Time-Based Arts Coordinator at the just-opened Perez Art Museum Miami (PAMM), which has been playing host to the hordes all week.
