headline: Art, a Balm After the Storm
text: There are many reasons for living in a great city like New York. One is all the time you can spend in the company of strangers — made possible by the city’s streets, public spaces and its magnificent (if flawed) public transportation system — which is both humbling and creatively stimulating.

headline: Enterprising Business Students Turn to Fashion
text: This week I’m on the road, traveling between Palo Alto, Calif., where I did a talk with Ron Johnson, the former J.C. Penney chief executive, at Stanford University, and Dallas, where Karl Lagerfeld will put on a Texas-size extravaganza for Chanel. That’s more contrast than you normally get in a week. And maybe that’s a good argument for getting out of the office.

headline: In the Book ‘The Killer Detail,’ Considering the Essence of Chic
text: PARIS — Ask an elegant Frenchwoman the secret of her style, and she will give you two words: balance and detail.

headline: Ex-Goldman Trader Sentenced to 9 Months in Prison
text: A federal judge in Manhattan on Friday sentenced Matthew Taylor, a former Goldman Sachs trader, to nine months in prison for covering up an $8.3 billion unauthorized trade at the firm.

headline: At BigLittle Get Together Catering Company, an Eye for Food and Fashion
text: “It does look like sperm,” Lauren Gerrie said as she squeezed thick lines of rosemary aioli onto the plates she and her co-chef, Flannery Klette-Kolton, were preparing for a dinner party in New York earlier this fall. “For whatever reason, sperm has been the underlying theme of this meal.”

headline: Poor Old Shine’s Debut Album a Highlight for 2013
text: It may be the stuff of liner-notes legend, but the story goes that the original incarnation of Poor Old Shine was formed only to fulfill a gig that was booked without a band and that the name was chosen only hours before the show. But they knew a good thing when they heard it, and Poor Old Shine, after some lineup revisions, became something very real.

headline: A Leader in Mao’s Cultural Revolution Faces His Past
text: BEIJING — ON the surface, at least, there is not much about Chen Xiaolu to suggest a lifetime of regret.

headline: Food Matters | 10 of the World’s Greatest Old Dining Institutions
text: In “Under the Spell of Old Restaurants,” Sadie Stein muses on the special magic of classic culinary establishments with white tablecloths and old-fashioned menus. Here, she shares 10 personal favorites. What are your most treasured old restaurants around the world? We invite you to share your thoughts by posting in the comments section or tweeting us at @tmagazine, and we’ll share the best responses in a future post.

headline: Obama Recalls an Aide to Guide Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration continues the aggressive public defense of the Affordable Care Act it began this week, the president will get some help from his former chief congressional lobbyist, Phil Schiliro, who is returning temporarily to the White House almost exactly two years after he left.

headline: John Waters Offers Season’s Greeting With a Wink
text: As with other seasonal workers (think Rockettes, Rudolph, sidewalk Santas), John Waters is a hot ticket come Christmas, when the film director, screenwriter, artist, collector and stand-up comedian goes on the road with “A John Waters Christmas,” his staged monologue about all things merry and dark.

headline: Cancer Survivors Celebrate Their Cancerversary
text: The attendant walked into the hospital waiting room and called my name. I took a deep breath and hurried through the door. “I’m always surprised when my name is pronounced properly at a doctor’s office,” I said.

headline: Jean-Claude Beton, Who Sent Orangina Around the World, Dies at 88
text: Jean-Claude Beton, who transformed  Orangina, an obscure citrus soda made in the Mediterranean, into a distinctive international brand, died on Dec. 2 in Marseille, France. He was 88.

headline: An Englishman in New York
text: The speakers at the fund-raising gala in New York last month had come to praise the guest of honor: the new president and chief executive of the International Rescue Committee, David Miliband. Amid all the charity-circuit one-liners delivered by big-ticket names like Bill Clinton, George Soros and Samantha Power, a remark by Madeleine Albright, the former secretary of state, hit closest to home.

headline: An Ethicist’s Guidelines for Charitable Giving
text: Peter Singer, the ethicist and philosopher, has suggested guidelines for charitable giving by the top 10 percent of American taxpayers that he believes make ethical sense.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Futurism in Men’s Wear
text: The cutting edge of fashion is definitely reflected in the young men experimenting with new technologies in fabrics and daring cuts and colors. Last Saturday, a multiday pop-up art installation caught the spirit of this fashion wave. From the upper left, diagonally to the lower right, two artists from Atlanta, Trey Wadsworth and Trever Nichols, landed in New York at 2 a.m. with an alien in a spaceship “crashing” near the Flatiron Building. They built their creation, including statues of revelers on park benches. Mr. Wadsworth is shown seated next to his “wino,” Mr. Nichols is to Mr. Wadsworth’s left. The alien met his match with New Yorkers in high-tech style. In October in Paris, one man wore a suit with contrasting fabric inserted in the jacket (bottom row, first four photos from left). One Parisian had enough piercings to scare any alien.

headline: Transparency on Charities
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pushed Out of a Job Early
text: If there is one thing older workers fear in this economy, it’s losing their jobs as they approach retirement. But that is exactly what happened in March to Richard L. White, who was the director of career services at Rutgers University for 22 years.

headline: What’s in a Name: Family and More
text: To lose your maiden name completely. To change it personally and keep it professionally. To hyphenate or not to hyphenate.

headline: Q. & A. With Anthony P. Carnevale
text: Anthony Carnevale, an economist who is director of the Georgetown University Center on Education and the Workforce, has been one of the most outspoken advocates for changing the education system to produce more graduates with skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (known as the STEM fields). He and his colleagues at the center produced an influential 2011 report showing that the United States needs to do more than produce an elite corps of STEM workers — it needs to raise those skills in the vast majority of students. More than a third of all STEM jobs by 2018 will be for those with less than a bachelor’s degree, the report found, raising the importance of high school engagement, community colleges and two-year associate degrees.

headline: Slowly They Modernize: A Federal Agency That Still Uses Floppy Disks
text: WASHINGTON — The technology troubles that plagued the HealthCare.gov website rollout may not have come as a shock to people who work for certain agencies of the government — especially those who still use floppy disks, the cutting-edge technology of the 1980s.

headline: A Tricky Airline Merger, but With Labor’s Blessing
text: Airline mergers are notoriously difficult to pull off, but when the deal between American Airlines and US Airways closes on Monday, the giant carrier can at least count on having employees on its side.

headline: After a Notorious Hoax, Te’o Focuses on His Career With the Low-Key Chargers
text: SAN DIEGO — When Manti Te’o arrived here last spring during one of his visits with N.F.L. teams before the draft, Chargers linebacker Donald Butler could not help chuckling with a few teammates.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Pill to Treat Hepatitis C
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a pill that is expected to make the treatment of hepatitis C less onerous, shorter in duration and more effective.

headline: Marrow Transplants Fail to Cure Two H.I.V. Patients
text: Two patients in Boston whom doctors hoped they had cured of both H.I.V. and cancer through bone-marrow transplants have seen their H.I.V. return, researchers said Friday.

headline: Wall Street Finds Good News
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Ochoa’s Legacy Casts a Shadow Over Mexican Aspirants to Her Throne
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — South Korea’s Se Ri Pak opened the door for her compatriots with four L.P.G.A. wins and two major championships in 1998, and many wondered if Lorena Ochoa would usher in the talents of other Mexican women the same way.

headline: Displaced by Hurricane Sandy, and Living in Limbo
text: LONG BEACH, N.Y. — For Kathryn Fitzgerald and her young daughter, Megan, home was a modest three-bedroom house here, on a tightly packed segment of Delaware Avenue two blocks from the Atlantic Ocean. That was the only home that Megan had ever known, until Hurricane Sandy hit and a rank mixture of floodwater and untreated sewage rose to chest-high in the lower level of the house.

headline: North Korea Says It Has Released Veteran It Held After Visit
text: Merrill Newman, 85, active retiree and intrepid traveler, preferred exotic places to popular ones. He had sailed around the world. He had been to Cuba and the Galápagos Islands. So it was not so odd when he decided that his next journey would be a return to North Korea, where 60 years ago he did top-secret work as a United States Army intelligence officer.

headline: Work and Rewards
text: The employment report for November shows why fast-food workers across the nation are striking for higher pay and why workers are pushing for a higher minimum wage at the federal, state and local levels.

headline: Truckloads for Hurricane Sandy Victims
text: The Federal Emergency Management Agency provided an accounting of the kinds of losses for which $1.4 billion in grants was earmarked.

headline: Quarterbacking at Missouri Requires Team-First Mentality
text: ATLANTA — Missouri quarterbacks have been burdened with the dreaded “system guy” tag for years. They are hoarders of statistics, passing for 3,000 yards a season while completing 60 percent of their throws in Coach Gary Pinkel’s offense. Brad Smith, Chase Daniel, Blaine Gabbert and the current starter, James Franklin, have not escaped ridicule by critics.

headline: Front Pages Mark Mandela’s Death
text: Newspapers around the world mourned the death of Nelson Mandela.

headline: Heart and Soul
text: What does it mean, this odd little illustration that you find embellished on Comme des Garçons T-shirts? Is it a loving eye? A knowing heart? A thinking passion? A benign vision?

headline: Rising Tension Seen in North Korea and at Sea Border
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has deployed more attack helicopters and rockets near a disputed western sea border with South Korea, the South’s intelligence chief told Parliament on Friday, raising fears that the North might be planning a provocation to deflect attention from reports of a brutal internal power struggle.

headline: Fleeing to Next Town, Bosses May Find Minimum Wage Is Rising There, Too
text: ROCKVILLE, Md. — When Marc Elrich, a county councilman in the northern Washington suburbs, sought to raise the minimum wage, businesses threatened to move across the Montgomery County line to pay workers less.

headline: De Blasio Style Evident in Effort to Sway Critics of Bratton
text: The Rev. Al Sharpton was blunt with Bill de Blasio on the telephone a few nights ago: He had reservations about the mayor-elect’s impending choice for police commissioner.

headline: A Pope’s New Path on Child Abuse
text: After decades of Vatican indifference and evasion, Pope Francis has ordered the creation of a commission to study the rape and intimidation of schoolchildren by priests and to recommend measures for effective reform. The new commission, long overdue, will be composed of international experts, both lay and religious, reflecting the global scope of the scandal. Its task is to propose concrete recommendations for firmer safeguarding of schoolchildren and better training of Roman Catholic priests.

headline: A Bad Decision at Guantánamo
text: In a perverse move, the Defense Department announced on Thursday that it had sent two of the longest-held detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, both Algerian citizens, back to Algeria against their will.

headline: Finding a Quiet Space
text: Dionne Parsons grew up in her aunt’s home among seven siblings and three cousins, sharing a bedroom with four girls. There was plenty of noise and an occasional good time, but no privacy. “I want my own space,” said Ms. Parsons, who is 23. “That’s my whole thing.”

headline: Bratton’s Time in California May Offer Clues to His Plans for New York Police
text: LOS ANGELES — It was a moment of crisis for the Los Angeles Police Department, and it threatened to derail William J. Bratton’s tenure as its chief. Tens of thousands had gathered for a long-planned immigration rally on May 1, 2007, at a city park. As protesters began to block the street, a police helicopter blasted orders for the crowd to disperse. Moments later, dozens of officers wielded batons and shot 240 rounds of rubber bullets into the crowd.

headline: Japan’s Parliament Approves a Secrecy Law Amid Protests
text: TOKYO — In an unusual late-night session with protesters chanting outside, Parliament passed a secrecy law on Friday that the prime minister said would strengthen national security but opponents warned would stifle democracy.

headline: Take It as a Sign
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — All these years I’ve been getting these strange patterns on my feet after being out in the sun during the summer, and I didn’t even know there was a name for them. SANDAL TAN.

headline: Decades After the Cultural Revolution, a Rare Letter of Remorse
text: In an apology for his actions as a student during the Cultural Revolution, Chen Xiaolu, the son of China’s famed Foreign Minister, Chen Yi, published a notice in his school alumni blog in August. A profile based on interviews with Mr. Chen in the Saturday editions of the New York Times and the International New York Times refers to the apology, a rare expression of remorse from someone involved in carrying out Mao’s orders. Mr. Chen explains the apology was too long in coming, and says reflections on the past are necessary in order for China to move forward.

headline: The Holiday Issue
text: T’s final issue of 2013 is a festive affair. In our cover story, Suzy Menkes celebrates the enigmatic designer Rei Kawakubo of Comme des Garçons, who is bringing the “beautiful chaos” of Dover Street Market, her multibrand fashion bazaar, to New York’s Kips Bay neighborhood. Elsewhere, we visit four prominent artists — Jeff Koons, KAWS, Ugo Rondidone and Chuck Close — to find out what sorts of work they themselves collect, and what their collections say about them. At the Park Avenue apartment of Renee and Mark Rockefeller, we find that the color beige doesn’t have to be tepid and uninspired; deployed with a discerning eye, it can be smart and seductive. We capture the zany wit of Kristen Wiig, who appears in the forthcoming film “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty,” by asking her to fill in the blanks in a Mad Lib that (sort of) describes her career trajectory to date. We visit the Moroccan city of Tangier, which, as home to expats like Pierre Bergé, Bernard-Henry Lévy and Roger Vivier, remains one of the world’s great melting pots for creative types. We meditate on the magic touch of the hotelier André Balazs. We pay tribute to the enduring glamour of well-preserved old restaurants, from Paris’s La Grenouille to New York City’s “21” Club, that feel trapped in amber. And finally, in the spirit of the season, we offer the very best gifts you can give, from food to fragrances to jewelry to adventures of a lifetime. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: How the Government Gives
text: NEWTON, Mass. — THIS is the season of giving, the time when Americans from all income levels make donations to support food pantries, health centers, art and educational institutions, and other organizations that are so important for our civic society. Many donors work hard to stretch their charitable dollars to provide the maximum benefit for those in need.

headline: Nets Hit Bottom, but Have Plenty of Company in East
text: The Nets have played just 53 games at Barclays Center, and the debacle that took place Thursday ranks among the worst of those performances.

headline: With Protests at Home, Ukraine’s Leader Leaves China Without Aid Deal
text: With huge anti-government protests waiting for him back home, President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine concluded his trip to China on Friday expressing a desire for greater trade and cooperation, but Beijing offered no announcements of the sort of aid that would help him shore up a weak economy and his own embattled political position.

headline: Two Cheers for E-Cigarettes
text: Imagine a product — a legal but lethal one — that kills 400,000 Americans a year. Public health advocates have been trying for decades to persuade Americans not to use it. The industry has been sued and sued again, but it is still operating profitably. One out of every five Americans is addicted to the product.

headline: For a Full Year, Taxi Drivers Trade Anonymity for a Full Display
text: No one lusts after the New York taxi driver.

headline: 12 Months of Cabdrivers
text: Seven New York City taxi drivers are joining firefighters in the city’s calendar canon.

headline: A Lesson Before Dying
text: One of the great lights of the world went dark on Thursday. Nelson Mandela left this world, having enormously altered it.

headline: Ahmed Fouad Negm, Dissident Poet of Egypt’s Underclass, Dies at 84
text: CAIRO — Ahmed Fouad Negm, an Egyptian poet whose irreverent writing, forged by poverty and prison, lacerated Egypt’s strongmen, gave voice to its underclass and inspired its dissidents, died on Tuesday at his home here. He was 84.

headline: Engineer in Metro-North Crash Is Called Dedicated and Kind
text: RHINEBECK, N.Y. — His name may be Rockefeller, but he is from a humble branch of the family whose first arrival in America was an 18th-century immigrant from Rockenfeld, Germany, not from the branch that made the name a synonym for vast wealth.

headline: Norway’s Svindal Wins Birds of Prey Downhill
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway never dreamed he would be a star.

headline: Art Kaminsky, Whose Clients Won the ‘Miracle on Ice,’ Dies at 66
text: On Feb. 22, 1980, the United States hockey team triumphed over the powerful Soviet squad in the Winter Olympics in what came to be called the Miracle on Ice. The Americans went on to win the gold medal.

headline: Day That Starts Well Ends Even Better for the Knicks
text: Life was different for the Knicks on Friday. For the bulk of the season — fine, all of it — their morning film sessions were the basketball equivalent of warm beer.

headline: Disappointment in Successors to Nelson Mandela, a Revered Father of a Nation
text: MVEZO, South Africa — Adam Bhasikile’s day begins at dawn, always in the same way. Flanked by donkeys, she walks to the valley floor, collecting water for the family to cook, clean and bathe from the Mbashe River, which snakes around this hilltop village like a winding moat. It is an unending ritual that Nelson Mandela’s mother, who gave birth to the future president here in 1918, almost certainly performed as well.

headline: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand: In Her Words
text: The senator from New York talks about how her grandmother inspired her to enter politics, and the way women work together in the Senate.

headline: New York’s Junior Senator, Doggedly Refusing to Play the Part
text: WASHINGTON — If there were a chutzpah caucus in the United States Senate, Kirsten Gillibrand of New York would be its natural leader.

headline: Macklemore & Ryan Lewis Dominate Grammy Nominations
text: Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, an independent rap duo from Seattle that became one of the biggest hit makers of the year, opened the Grammy Awards’ nominations special on CBS on Friday night with a performance of their hit “Thrift Shop,” and then went on to dominate the nominations themselves.

headline: In the Air | Winter Wonderlands
text: With the advent of the snowy season, the mystical serenity of an ice-cloaked world is inspiring the creation of enchanted interiors and ethereal designs.

headline: Pennsylvania Wants to Use Federal Funds to Cover Poor
text: WASHINGTON — The governor of Pennsylvania, Tom Corbett, released details on Friday of his proposal to use federal Medicaid funds to buy private health insurance for low-income people — a plan similar to one being carried out by Arkansas and considered by other Republican governors who oppose expanding Medicaid under President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Michael Kammen, Historian of U.S. Psyche, Dies at 77
text: Michael Kammen, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian whose scholarly aim was no less than the illumination of the collective American psyche, died on Nov. 29 in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 77.

headline: Former Ohio State President Returns to West Virginia
text: E. Gordon Gee, 69, who resigned from his second stint as president of Ohio State University in July after a series of embarrassing gaffes, will start another second-time-around job next month, as interim president of West Virginia University. Dr. Gee, who has also been president of Brown, Vanderbilt and the University of Colorado, previously served as president of West Virginia University from 1981 to 1985, when he was one of the nation’s youngest university presidents. Dr. Gee will serve until a new president is named, and be paid, on an annual basis, $450,000.

headline: Deadly Factory Fire Bares Racial Tensions in Italy
text: PRATO, Italy — Dozens of bouquets block the entrance to the Teresa Moda outlet and factory where seven Chinese workers died last Sunday in a fire that swept through the establishment where they worked and lived.

headline: Long Island Village Intentionally Discriminated Against Minorities, Judge Says
text: A federal judge ruled on Friday that the predominantly white Long Island village of Garden City had intentionally discriminated against blacks and Hispanics when it enacted a zoning change in 2004 that favored the building of townhouses or single-family homes over modestly priced apartments.

headline: Wheelchair Settlement Poses Test for Cab Industry
text: The announcement on Friday that New York City had settled a major class-action lawsuit that, if approved, would result in at least half of its taxicabs becoming wheelchair accessible by 2020 drew praise from politicians, industry figures and advocates for the disabled.

headline: Keeping Faith, Even When Home Is an Uncertain Place
text: When asked to tell the story of his life and of the circumstances that left him homeless, Eugene Manu, 21, tripped over his words, his testimony stalled by moments of nervousness and trepidation, filled with false starts and constant backpedaling.

headline: Robert Wachs Dies at 73; Promoted Comedy, Including Eddie Murphy’s
text: Robert D. Wachs, a founder of the Comic Strip, a New York nightclub that was a proving ground for star comedians like Eddie Murphy, whom Mr. Wachs managed for more than a decade, died on Dec. 2 in Manhattan. He was 73.

headline: Yankees Reportedly Sign Beltran to Three-Year, $45 Million Deal
text: On two previous occasions when Carlos Beltran was a free agent, he told friends in baseball that he idolized Bernie Williams and that his lifelong dream was to play for the Yankees, even if it meant less money. Both times there was no fit and Beltran signed instead with the Mets and then the St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) STOKER (2013) In his English-language debut, the South Korean director Park Chan-wook (“Oldboy,” “Lady Vengeance”) tells the story of India Stoker (Mia Wasikowska), a solitary Connecticut teenager embroiled in a landscape of family secrets, sexual subtext and aristocratic entitlement after her father (Dermot Mulroney) dies in a car accident on her 18th birthday. Then her handsome Uncle Charlie (Matthew Goode), whom she never knew, comes to visit her mother (Nicole Kidman, above left, with Ms. Wasikowska), who seems insufficiently grief-stricken to her daughter. That’s when the family’s housekeeper (Phyllis Somerville) disappears, and a worried relative (Jacki Weaver) alludes to further danger ahead. “A great deal of information has been withheld, perhaps from India and certainly from us, and Mr. Park, with sadistic relish, takes his time with revelations that are both ghastly and a bit disappointing,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The exquisite sense of mystery that has built up around India begins to dissipate as the focus shifts to Charlie, and tantalizing ambiguities are resolved into a tale of madness and murder.” Which, he added, “is not so bad, though the final act of ‘Stoker’ walks a fine line between the sensational and the silly.” Learning the truth about Charlie, Mr. Scott said, “does not so much explain what had come before as turn everything upside down, scattering the puzzle pieces in a colorful, brutal cascade.” The actor Wentworth Miller (“Prison Break”) wrote the screenplay.

headline: Goodbye, Bronx. Hello, Queens.
text: In the 51 years that the Mets and the Yankees have shared New York, although hardly equally, more than 100 players have worn the uniforms of both teams. And that figure doesn’t include Casey Stengel, who managed both clubs.

headline: American Veteran Seized by North Korea During a Tour Returns Home
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Ending more than a month of captivity in North Korea, an 85-year-old American veteran returned to the United States on Saturday, soon after the North let him go, citing his “sincere repentance” for his actions during the Korean War.

headline: Hong Kong Reports Second Case of Deadly Bird Flu
text: HONG KONG — Health officials in Hong Kong late Friday reported the city’s second confirmed case of avian influenza in a week, in an 80-year-old man who resides in the neighboring mainland Chinese city of Shenzhen.

headline: Biden Looks Into North Korea at Border
text: PANMUNJOM, South Korea — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. peered into the leafless wilderness of North Korea on Saturday, making a time-honored visit to the demilitarized zone just hours after the North released an American citizen detained by the authorities since October.

headline: South Africans Prepare for Days of Mourning and Commemoration
text: JOHANNESBURG — The rainbow nation that Nelson Mandela fought so hard for decades to make a reality turned out in droves at his home here on Saturday to pay tribute to South Africa’s departed leader.

headline: An Outsize Rapscallion Let Loose on Postwar England
text: After the director Robert Carsen’s production of Verdi’s “Falstaff” had its premiere at the Royal Opera House in London last year, word spread that it was wonderful — a thoughtful, affecting and hilarious staging that updates the action from the time of Henry IV to England in the 1950s.

headline: In Afghanistan, Hagel Presses for Pact on Security, but Is Not Meeting Karzai
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel arrived in the Afghan capital on Saturday, where he conferred with top security officials but consciously chose not to see President Hamid Karzai, whose decision to delay signing a security agreement with the United States has left the future of the American military mission here in doubt.

headline: Tale of a Tailspin
text: The Jets are 5-7 after three straight losses, but their record understates just how far they have fallen.

headline: Fantasy Football: Rookie Report, Part 1
text: College football season only lasts 12 games, but N.F.L. rookies are hitting the home stretch of their new, 16-game season this year. Across every position, there have been big successes and failures in this rookie class, as draft stock no longer matters, and it’s all about what they’ve left on the field. We will start with this year’s rookie quarterbacks and running backs, analyzing their fantasy performance so far and looking ahead.

headline: Cano Renews a Rivalry Across a Great Divide
text: Seattle is the only city in the major leagues that has never hosted the World Series. You might have missed the games in Houston, Denver and St. Petersburg, Fla. — two apiece during the last decade. Washington has gone 80 years without hosting. But at least those cities have taken a turn.

headline: Fiery Beason Is ‘Godsend’ for Giants’ Defense
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants Coach Tom Coughlin interrupted a reporter the instant he recognized the question pertained to the possibility that linebacker Jon Beason would become a free agent after the season.

headline: Pook Turtles, Armorclads and the Civil War on the Rivers
text: The Battle of Hampton Roads, in March 1862, was the world’s first engagement between armored warships. Yet the Union’s Monitor and the Confederacy’s Virginia were far from the world’s first ironclads. The British, French and Russians had used armored floating batteries in the previous decade’s Crimean War.

headline: Working to Keep the Lights On at This Season’s Super Bowl
text: Al Kelly, the head of the host committee for this season’s Super Bowl, was with Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, when the lights went out at the Super Bowl in New Orleans in February. As they struggled in Johnson’s dimly lit suite to comprehend what had happened, Kelly had an additional thought.

headline: Nelson Mandela, Communist
text: IN 2011, the British historian Stephen Ellis published a paper concluding that Nelson Mandela had been a member of the South African Communist Party — indeed, a member of its governing Central Committee. Although Mandela’s African National Congress and the Communist Party were openly allied against apartheid, Mandela and the A.N.C. have always denied that the hero of South Africa’s liberation was himself a party member. But Ellis, drawing on testimony of former party members and newly available archives, made a convincing case that Mandela joined the party around 1960, several years before he was sentenced to life in prison for conspiring to overthrow the government.

headline: Who Owns the Arctic
text: Territorial claims of countries in the Arctic are being spurred by the presence of large caches of oil and natural gas, melting ice and dwindling energy reserves in other regions.

text: This interview with  Dara Richardson-Heron, chief executive of the Y.W.C.A., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Purged North Korean Is Cut From Film
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s state-run television on Saturday broadcast a rerun of a propaganda documentary about its leader, Kim Jong-un, after deleting all footage showing his uncle, Jang Song-thaek, who South Korean intelligence officials believe was recently dismissed from all his posts.

headline: Ukraine Demonstrators Say They Won’t Relent on Demands for Change
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Furious about President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s decision to scrap political and trade accords with Europe, Mykola Nomonko shut his auto parts store in the western city of Staryi Sambir, piled his five employees into a minibus and drove to Kiev, the capital, to protest. It was Sunday, Nov. 24. Nearly two weeks later, he is still here.

headline: JPMorgan Tracked Business Linked to China Hiring
text: Federal authorities have obtained confidential documents that shed new light on JPMorgan Chase’s decision to hire the children of China’s ruling elite, securing emails that show how the bank linked one prominent hire to “existing and potential business opportunities” from a Chinese government-run company.

headline: Caution: Reading Can Be Hazardous
text: NOT long ago I had to be treated for a retinal tear. My eye doctor says this could have happened at just about any time and was most likely the result of nothing more than middle age, but I think he’s wrong. I’m pretty sure I tore my retina from reading too much.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 8
text: Nelson Mandela, the first black president of South Africa, died Thursday, leaving many to eulogize and honor the world leader. Mr. Mandela led his country’s emancipation from white minority control, after spending 27 years in prison for opposing apartheid rule. Many Sunday shows will celebrate the life and legacy of Mr. Mandela, gathering guests who knew him both personally and professionally.

headline: Woodrow Wilson, Stud Muffin
text: WASHINGTON — ON Thursday night, we sat around, talking about the lawyer and constitutional expert in the White House, a leader both didactic and charming, peacenik and hawk; the Ivy League academic who improbably ascended to the Oval Office on brains, not beholden to anyone; the Democrat, eager to fight economic inequality and help the 99 percent, who would give a government bailout if he had to; the dapper man with large ears, elegant speeches he wrote himself, a love of golf.

headline: Borderline Insanity at the Fence in Nogales
text: The fence that separates Nogales, Ariz., from Nogales, Mexico, is a see-through wall of vertical steel rods 15 to 18 feet high, set four inches apart in a deep bed of concrete. It is a rusty ribbon that runs up and down dusty hills and streets, cutting one city into two and jutting into the desert for a few miles east and west.

headline: The Thorny Challenge of Covering China
text: HOW do major American news organizations write about a Communist country with the world’s second-largest economy — a country that doesn’t believe in press rights and that punishes tough-minded coverage?

headline: Can’t We Do Better?
text: THE latest results in the Program for International Student Assessment, or PISA, which compare how well 15-year-olds in 65 cities and countries can apply math, science and reading skills to solve real-world problems were released last week, and it wasn’t pretty for the home team. Andreas Schleicher, who manages PISA, told the Department of Education: “Three years ago, I came here with a special report benchmarking the U.S. against some of the best performing and rapidly improving education systems. Most of them have pulled further ahead, whether it is Brazil that advanced from the bottom, Germany and Poland that moved from adequate to good, or Shanghai and Singapore that moved from good to great. The math results of top-performer Shanghai are now two-and-a-half school years ahead even of those in Massachusetts — itself a leader within the U.S.”

headline: Can Foreign Aid Help This Girl?
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — ALMOST four years after the earthquake that devastated Haiti, Darline St. Luc, 13, is one of the hundreds of thousands of people who are still homeless. She and her family get by in a leaky, rat-infested shack made out of old USAID grain sacks, and she says that she sometimes goes days without eating.

headline: The Bible as Bludgeon
text: YOU can make a successful run for political office in this country without an especially thick résumé, any exceptional talent for expressing yourself, a noteworthy education or, for that matter, a basic grasp of science.

headline: From the Steel Mill to the ‘Super Bowl Shuffle’

headline: The Case for Filth
text: IN Claire Messud’s novel “The Emperor’s Children,” the ultraliberal Murray Thwaite comes home late, steps in cat vomit and keeps walking: “It still was not, nor could it ever be, his role to clean up cat sick,” Ms. Messud writes. The boomer hypocrite is practically a comic type by this point, but in his domestic disregard, Murray Thwaite is like most other men, liberal or conservative, old or young.

headline: Secular Stagnation Arithmetic
text: Still playing around with the question of secular stagnation. Based on some recent conversations, it seems to me that it’s useful to put some numbers to the issue – to quantify, at least roughly, the hole that seems to have developed in sustainable demand.

headline: Shameful Profiling of the Mentally Ill
text: A CANADIAN woman was denied entry to the United States last month because she had been hospitalized for depression in 2012. Ellen Richardson could not visit, she was told, unless she obtained “medical clearance” from one of three Toronto doctors approved by the Department of Homeland Security. Endorsement by her own psychiatrist, which she could presumably have obtained more efficiently, “would not suffice.” She had been en route to New York, where she had intended to board a cruise to the Caribbean.

headline: Rushing for the Arctic’s Riches
text: AMHERST, Mass. — WHILE many existing oil and gas reserves in other parts of the world are facing steep decline, the Arctic is thought to possess vast untapped reservoirs. Approximately 13 percent of the world’s undiscovered oil deposits and 30 percent of its natural gas reserves are above the Arctic Circle, according to the United States Geological Survey. Eager to tap into this largess, Russia and its Arctic neighbors — Canada, Norway, the United States, Iceland and Denmark (by virtue of its authority over Greenland) — have encouraged energy companies to drill in the region.

headline: Gordon Versus The Androids
text: We just had a session with Bob Gordon and Joel Mokyr on the outlook for future growth, and I think I have a new way to explain why my gut feeling is that Bob, while making a persuasive case (pdf), is probably wrong.

headline: Playing Pension Games
text: Pity the municipal bondholder. Between Detroit’s bankruptcy and the rising concerns over unfunded pensions in Illinois and elsewhere, it has been a rough year for many muni bond investors. While the Standard & Poor’s municipal bond index has recovered from its September lows, it is still off 2.7 percent for the year.

headline: Christie Ally Resigning From Port Authority
text: A Port Authority official with close ties to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is resigning after state lawmakers questioned whether lane closings on the George Washington Bridge that led to extensive traffic backups in September were politically motivated.

headline: Winter Storms Grip U.S., Knocking Out Power and Grounding Flights

headline: World Traveler With Humble Roots
text: If ever there were a frequent flier club for racehorses, Red Cadeaux would be the charter member. In the Hong Kong Vase at Sha Tin on Saturday, Red Cadeaux, a 7-year-old chestnut gelding, was to make another stop on a multiyear world tour unlikely to be matched any time soon, except maybe by the Rolling Stones.

headline: Cricket, a Once-Genteel Sport, Reveals a Darker Side
text: LONDON — Among the traditionalists in candy-striped blazers at the venerable Lord’s Cricket Ground in London, the sport is often viewed through the prism of ideals espoused by the upper-crust Victorians who set the game’s rules 150 years ago. Players were expected to behave at all times, win or lose, as gentlemen, and never allow their stiff-upper-lip resolve to falter.

headline: In Mass Attacks, New Advice Lets Medics Rush In
text: WASHINGTON — Seven minutes after the authorities in Sparks, Nev., received a call one day in October that a gunman was on the loose at a local middle school, a paramedic wearing a bulletproof vest and a helmet arrived at the scene.

headline: As a School Shooting’s First Anniversary Nears, Newtown Asks for Privacy
text: NEWTOWN, Conn. — The people here are adamant: They do not want a return to their streets of the antenna-topped vans from an international array of news media, and reporters holding microphones to their faces.

headline: Second and Later Chances Await an Alternate Door to Baseball Hall of Fame
text: For as long as the Baseball Hall of Fame has stood on Main Street in Cooperstown, N.Y., old-timers and veterans committees have elected those whom baseball writers have not — from Connie Mack and Iron Joe McGinnity to Phil Rizzuto and Walter O’Malley. With their broad portfolio of available candidates, whose achievements span the history of baseball, the committees have elected more members, 162, than the Baseball Writers’ Association of America, which has anointed 112.

headline: In a Scoreboard of Words, a Cultural Guide
text: Data is the new oil. The next revolution will be social-mobile-local. Technology is evolving faster than ever.

headline: Long Data

headline: Obama Says He Can Envision Nuclear Deal With Iran

headline: No Cano, but Spree of Signings for Yankees
text: Not since 2008, when the Yankees previously failed to make the playoffs, has the team acted so aggressively on the free-agent market. Back then, after the shock and disappointment of an idle October, the Yankees spent lavishly to retool their roster, committing $423.5 million.

headline: In Cuba’s Press, Streets and Living Rooms, Glimmers of Openness to Criticism
text: MEXICO CITY — It is a rare day in Cuba when the Communist Party’s triumphalist newspaper suggests that the government — just maybe — messed up. Or when the party’s chief ideologist renounces government secrecy. Or a salsa star, performing at an official concert, calls for the freedom to vote and to smoke marijuana.

headline: Whiskers Unlimited? Not on Wall St.
text: Beards are very much in fashion now. Here in Manhattan, you can spot them just about everywhere, from well-trimmed, barely-there goatees to lush, furry profusions of hirsuteness. In certain parts of Brooklyn, it’s almost hard to find a man who doesn’t have a beard, especially now that the weather is colder.

headline: Towson Stifles Fordham’s Run but Not Its Spirit

My argument is that the right kind of aid does work, and I bet I’m going to be deluged with inquiries about how readers can help. So for those seeking more information, here goes.

headline: Two Outs

headline: So Easy to Sign Up, and So Hard to Cancel

I filled out a short form online and that was it. My apartment had a cable Internet connection before I unpacked the dishes.

headline: Tabu Ley Rochereau Dies; Spread the Sound of Soukous

headline: After Setbacks, a Ban on Double Dipping Could Gain Traction

headline: A Holiday Gift Guide to a Library of Books With Local Connections
text: As any book-loving Texan can tell you, the volumes most often given during the holiday season fall largely into three familiar categories: kitsch like “Stupid Texas: Idiots in the Lone Star State” (2010), coffee-table books featuring wildflowers or West Texas vistas, and the latest takes on the Kennedy assassination. But if you’re aiming for something a little more original, here is a selection of recently published Texas-flavored books to satisfy even the most idiosyncratic personality on your shopping list.

headline: In an Israeli Plan, Bedouins See a Threat to Their Way of Life
text: JERUSALEM — As Israel prepares to force thousands of Bedouins to give up land that their families have lived on for generations, officials have struggled to convince residents of the ramshackle communities scattered across the vast Negev desert that moving to new, legal homes will pave a path to a better future.
