text: It is not easy:

headline: On Stage in Seoul
text: Building on the phenomenal popularity of Korean pop music and soap operas among women in their 20s and 30s, Broadway and Korean producers are turning Seoul into a boomtown for American musicals.

headline: Who Says Math Has to Be Boring?
text: American students are bored by math, science and engineering. They buy smartphones and tablets by the millions but don’t pursue the skills necessary to build them. Engineers and physicists are often portrayed as clueless geeks on television, and despite the high pay and the importance of such jobs to the country’s future, the vast majority of high school graduates don’t want to go after them.

headline: Musicals Couldn’t Be Hotter Off Broadway (by 7,000 Miles)
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The packs of young women arrived 90 minutes early for the evening’s show: “Murder Ballad,” a rock musical that flopped off Broadway in July and then opened here four months later in an all-Korean production. They wanted time to shoot smartphone video of Seoul’s newest theater, built inside a shopping mall, and start scoring autographs: of actors, sure, but lighting operators and makeup artists too.

headline: A Problem Hidden in Alaska’s Vastness
text: The bounties of nature mask a hard reality: that this is a place without much of a safety net for people without homes.

headline: Alaska’s Thin Line Between Camping and Homelessness
text: SOLDOTNA, Alaska — People come to Kenai Peninsula for the natural beauty or for an Alaskan escape from the routines that shape life in fussier places.

headline: Madoff Victims, Five Years the Wiser
text: It was the first global Ponzi scheme — a slow-motion crime wave that began in the Manhattan offices of a stockbroker named Bernard L. Madoff, spread to wealthy enclaves in Palm Beach, Fla., and Southern California, and reached as far as the Persian Gulf. It carried a breathtaking price: $64.8 billion in paper wealth and at least $17.5 billion in cash losses. Those affected ranged from carpenter-union pensioners to French aristocrats.

headline: Parliament Approves 2014 Budget in Greece
text: ATHENS — Greece’s Parliament early on Sunday approved a budget for 2014 which predicts a timid return to growth after six years of recession despite the reluctance of many government lawmakers to impose further cutbacks on a country reeling from economic hardship.

headline: Husband’s Death Brings Another Trauma
text: As a teenager in Ukraine in the 1940s, Lyudmila Kopolovich endured the Holocaust.

headline: Switzerland’s Küng Wins Super-G, but Miller Is the Main Attraction
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Bode Miller of the United States skied an electrifying run that showcased the kind of risky, brilliant and inspired skiing that is his trademark. The only thing missing for Miller in the World Cup super-G race Saturday was a podium finish.

headline: In Nation Remade by Mandela, Social Equality Remains Elusive
text: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa — When Freddy Kenny started his business selling vegetables out of a battered pickup truck in the 1970s, a siren used to sound over this city, his hometown, every night at 9, signaling to him and every other black person that they must leave the city limits immediately or face arrest.

headline: Auburn Runs Over Missouri, Finishing U-Turn to SEC Title
text: ATLANTA — The Auburn Tigers had a hard time explaining it themselves. It made them pause, and then shake their heads from side to side, as they stopped to ponder the spectacle of what they did this season.

headline: Vows: Making It Important
text: When New Jersey began allowing same-sex marriages, Christine Newman and Eileen Bruns gave themselves six weeks to plan a wedding. The couple met at Catholic school and have been together 23 years.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 7, 2013
Devils Spoil Opening of Rangers’ Homestand
text: The Rangers and the Devils often play edge-of-the-seat games, and Saturday’s meeting at Madison Square Garden — the 39th regular-season showdown between Martin Brodeur and Henrik Lundqvist — lived up to the standard.

headline: Deborah Leiderman, Theodore Geiger
text: Deborah Amy Leiderman and Theodore Sigmund Geiger are to be married Sunday at B’nai Jeshurun, a synagogue in New York. Rabbi Michelle Dardashti will perform the ceremony.

headline: Erin Hespe and Troy Cudworth
Laura Silver and Michael Bisberg
text: Laura Jessamyn Silver and Michael David Bisberg are to be married Sunday at ReBar, a restaurant in Brooklyn. Matthew Gline, a Universal Life minister, is officiating.

headline: Frances Black, Matthew Strauss
text: Frances Anne Black and Matthew Adam Strauss were married Saturday in the Sovereign Ballroom at the Omni King Edward Hotel in Toronto. Catherine E. H. Kentridge, an officiant affiliated with the Center for Spiritual Living Toronto, led a ceremony incorporating Jewish and Catholic traditions.

headline: Alyssa Hart, Matthew Ross
text: Alyssa Donna Hart and Matthew Scott Ross were married Saturday at the Greenpoint Loft, an event space in Brooklyn. Leslie Papa, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated.

headline: Sally Elbaum and Mark Friedman
text: Sala Myriam Elbaum, the daughter of Judy Urman Elbaum and Steven S. Elbaum of Essex Fells, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Mark David Friedman, a son of Cheri Savits Friedman and Steven M. Friedman of New York. Rabbi Elliot J. Cosgrove officiated at the Pierre in New York.

headline: Natalia Berry, Eric Twerdahl Jr.
text: Dr. Natalia Chong Berry and Dr. Eric Haynes Twerdahl Jr. were married Saturday at the Cathedral Church of St. James in Toronto. The Very Reverend Douglas A. Stoute, an Anglican priest and the rector of the cathedral, performed the ceremony.

headline: Gabrielle DeMatteis, John Keller
text: Gabrielle Lauren DeMatteis and John Frederick Keller were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan. The Rev. James C. Williams, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Emily Felderman, Jason Raxenberg
text: Emily Faye Felderman, a daughter of Lisa Morris Felderman and Dr. Theodore P. Felderman of Syosset, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Jason Garrett Raxenberg, a son of Lawrence M. Raxenberg and Dr. Francine P. Raxenberg of Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi Neil Kurshan performed the ceremony at Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

headline: Steven Harris and Lucien Rees-Roberts
text: Glenn Steven Harris and Lucien Peter Rees-Roberts were married Saturday at Galloway Hill, their country house in Kinderhook, N.Y. Peter J. Spears, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Katherine Gabel, Eunice Shatz
text: Katherine Gabel and Eunice Shatz were married Friday at the home of Lillian Faderman and Phyllis Irwin, friends of the couple, in Fresno, Calif. Rabbi Laura Novak Winer officiated.

headline: Kat McCullough and Michael Braun
text: Kat Anne McCullough and Michael Ryan Braun were married Saturday evening at the W Union Square hotel in New York. Rabbi Lisa Rubin officiated.

headline: David Adams, Robert Schwartz
text: David Merle Adams and Robert Schwartz were married Saturday at the Bicycle Club, a restaurant in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. The Rev. David Pomeroy, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: Zing Bai and Issac Chao
text: Haijing Zing Bai and Isaac Eugene Chao were married Saturday in Brooklyn. Judge Harold Baer Jr. of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York in Manhattan, for whom the groom was an intern, officiated at the Montauk Club.

headline: Ideal Candidates for Romance
text: Diana Lynn Doukas and Matthew Wagner House were married Saturday at St. Sophia Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. Steven Zorzos, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: A Union of Mutual Admiration
text: Dr. Christine Anne Newman and Eileen Bruns were married Saturday by John Graf Jr., a Universal Life minister, at Eno Terra, a restaurant in Kingston, N.J.

headline: In a Battle of the Lowly, the Nets Come Out on Top
text: MILWAUKEE — Mercifully, the N.B.A. schedule makers banished the Nets from New York two nights after the embarrassment of Thursday’s shellacking at the hands of the Knicks on national television. The Nets traveled to the relative obscurity of Milwaukee on Saturday — away from the pressing local news media, heckling fans and the intensifying criticism of Coach Jason Kidd less than a third of the way into his first season on the job.

headline: Florida State Overwhelms Duke and Sets Sights on a Bigger Test
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The ugliness and uncertainty that surrounded Florida State quarterback Jameis Winston and threatened to mar the stunning perfection of his 2013 season was dismissed with Thursday’s announcement in Tallahassee, Fla., that he would not face charges of sexual assault.

headline: Spartans Squash Buckeyes and Debate Over B.C.S. Title Game
text: INDIANAPOLIS — By late Saturday, the debate had ended. There would be no arguments about quality of opposition, or the strength of one conference relative to another. There would be no clamor for Ohio State to appear in the Bowl Championship Series title game.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (A&E, History, Lifetime) BONNIE & CLYDE Bruce Beresford puts his spin on the doomed love affair of the 1930s gangsters Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow in this two-night mini-series starring Holliday Grainger and Emile Hirsch. William Hurt portrays Frank Hamer, the retired Texas Ranger who led the team that killed Parker and Barrow in 1934. Holly Hunter (above left, with Ms. Grainger) plays Parker’s mother. “Mr. Beresford (‘Tender Mercies,’ ‘Driving Miss Daisy’) gives the sentimental material a corresponding autumnal glow, and there are sweeping, lovely images of Texas fields under big skies, a shimmering crescent moon and an oil refinery sparkling in the night,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. Comparing Mr. Beresford’s work to Arthur Penn’s 1967 film with Faye Dunaway and Warren Beatty, Mr. Hale adds: “In the end, ‘Bonnie & Clyde’ has the one thing in common with ‘Bonnie and Clyde’ that you’d expect: the fusillade of machine-gun fire, and Barrow and Parker’s bodies twitching and bursting as they’re torn apart. While it doesn’t have the force of Penn’s brutal choreography, it’s a surprisingly graphic scene for basic cable. Less surprising is a gratuitous, last-minute plot twist that serves to cement the film’s portrayal of Barrow as a tragic, star-crossed hero. Apparently, only the misunderstood die young.”

headline: Corrections: December 8, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Malignaggi Dominates Judah to Claim Battle of Brooklyn
text: When Paulie Malignaggi believes he has been wronged, he does not quietly stand by. When he has been on the losing side of a controversial decision, he has ranted about everything from incompetent judges and crooked scorecards to the influence of promoters. His tantrums have become well-known. It was the same story Saturday night in Brooklyn.

headline: Export Surge Sets Up Big Surplus for China
text: HONG KONG — China’s exports rose more than expected last month, government figures released Sunday showed, as resurgent demand from consumers in the United States and the European Union helped put the Asian manufacturing juggernaut on track for its biggest annual trade surplus since 2008.

headline: Congress Party Defeated in Indian State Elections
text: NEW DELHI — The results of state elections in four states dealt a blow to the Indian National Congress on Sunday, signaling the waning power of the dynasty that had dominated Indian politics for nearly all of the post-independence era and giving momentum to the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party ahead of general elections in May.

headline: In Soweto and Beyond, Mandela Still Serves as a Beacon of Hope
text: SOWETO, South Africa — The walls of the Regina Mundi Catholic Church here are riddled with bullet holes from the days when it was a center of the struggle against apartheid. But on Sunday, parishioners instead focused on the traces of Nelson Mandela.

headline: Capturing of the Country From the Strut of a Plane
text: For the last seven years, Andrew Moore has been traveling to the northern Great Plains to photograph the land and the people who live there. In this week’s edition of the magazine, we feature several of Moore’s pictures from this project, which he has titled “Dirt Meridian.” You can see how he made the pictures in this video. What follows is a condensed version of a conversation we had recently about the project.

headline: Tracking the Volcker Rule
text: Following the 2008 financial crisis, lawmakers restricted the ability of banks to invest and trade for their own accounts. But first, regulators had to agree on the rules.

headline: Prenatal Depression: What I Didn’t Expect When I Was Expecting
text: I arrived late, hands covering a flat stomach where a bump should have been. I watched as the other women waddled to their seats. Each mother-to-be held a pen in one hand, scratching around a protruding belly button with the other. They scrawled in their open journals, “can’t wait to meet you,” “felt you kick today!” With no burgeoning stomach blocking the view of my blank page, I wrote, “This is terrible.”

headline: South Korea Announces Expansion of Its Air Defense Zone
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Defying both China and Japan, South Korea announced on Sunday that it was expanding its air patrol zone for the first time in 62 years to include airspace over the East China Sea that is also claimed by Beijing and Tokyo.

headline: In Our Pages: December 9
text: 1963: Thai anti-Communist prime minister dies

headline: Protesters in Kiev Topple Lenin Statue as Rallies Grow
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Public protests thundered into a full-throttle civil uprising in Ukraine on Sunday, as hundreds of thousands of protesters answered President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s dismissiveness with their biggest rally so far, demanding that he and his government resign.

headline: Disruptions: At Your Door in Minutes, Delivered by Robot
text: Raise your hand if you get this whole Amazon drone thing.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Bobbi Brown Palette
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Afghan Effort to Get Justice for Women Seems to Stall
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite years of intensive effort by Afghan and international rights advocates, progress in obtaining justice for abused women in Afghanistan appeared to have stalled, according to a report released Sunday by the United Nations.

headline: For Del Bosque and Spain, Another Championship Phase Begins
text: LONDON — Of all the men in the room when the World Cup draw was conducted, Spain’s Vicente del Bosque was the one with something to lose.

headline: Bombings in Mostly Shiite Districts of Baghdad Kill Dozens
text: BAGHDAD — A series of attacks on Sunday against markets, shopping areas and auto repair shops in largely Shiite neighborhoods of Baghdad killed at least 45 people and wounded dozens more, the police and medical officials said.

headline: Thai Premier Calls for Elections as Opposition Quits
text: BANGKOK — Facing volatile street protests and the mass resignation from Parliament of the main opposition party, Thailand’s prime minister on Monday called for fresh elections, the latest in a series of attempts to defuse anger against her political party and her powerful family.

headline: Tony Shalhoub Joins ‘Act One’ Cast
text: The Lincoln Center Theater announced on Sunday that Tony Shalhoub and Santino Fontana would both portray the playwright and theater director Moss Hart in James Lapine’s stage adaptation of “Act One,” based on Mr. Hart’s 1959 autobiography of the same name. The two actors, along with a third who has yet to be cast, will play Mr. Hart at various stages of his life, from his impoverished childhood in the Bronx to his many successes on Broadway.

headline: Disney’s ‘Frozen’ Leads Wintry Weekend Box Office
text: It was the box-office calm before the Christmas storm: “Out of the Furnace,” the only new movie in wide release in North American theaters over the weekend, had terrible ticket sales, while holdovers skated along and Oscar hopefuls like “Inside Llewyn Davis” started their slow rollout.

headline: ‘Falstaff’
text: Scenes from Robert Carsen’s production of Verdi’s work at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Tearing Down Lenin’s Statue in Kiev
text: Protests in Ukraine’s capital, which have grown steadily for weeks, reached new heights on Sunday when demonstrators toppled a statue of Vladimir Lenin.

headline: No Set or Props, but Songs to Propel the Imagination
text: “Around the World” at the Mint Theater chronicles a journey of 80 days and thousands of miles, but it’s really a journey of rediscovery, one for which the only thing you’ll need to pack is a vivid imagination.

headline: A New Play Brings the Deepwater Horizon Disaster to the Stage
text: “Spill,” a new play based on interviews with dozens of people affected by the Gulf of Mexico oil rig explosion in 2010, will have its premiere production this spring in the state that was at the center of the environmental disaster. The drama, which features some 30 real-life characters speaking in the verbatim style of the documentary-like “Laramie Project” plays, will run March 12 through 30, at the Swine Palace theater on the Louisiana State University campus in Baton Rouge, the theater and the play’s creators announced on Sunday.

headline: In Season Filled With Lows, Knicks Outdo Themselves
text: Amid a season already brimming with poor performances, the Knicks seemed strangely determined to set new benchmarks for futility when they arrived at Madison Square Garden on Sunday morning. How many shots could they miss? How many points could they allow? How many more paying customers could they disappoint?

headline: A Sea of Subtlety, Till Thunder Strikes
text: Near the end of Jon Kinzel’s “Someone Once Called Me a Sound Man,” the choreographer, joined by the dancers Simon Courchel and Stuart Shugg, arranges and rearranges maybe a dozen knee-high panels propped on the ground. Some are a single hue: red, white, black. Some have patterns. The reshuffling of their order is like a demonstration of color theory, each panel affecting perception of the others. It’s all very subtle. And then Mr. Kinzel picks up one panel and suddenly punches a hole in it with a hammer.

headline: Comcast Hires JPMorgan as Adviser for Possible Time Warner Cable Bid
text: Comcast has hired JPMorgan Chase to advise it on a possible bid for Time Warner Cable, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Eastern Showdown
text: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: ‘LIFT’
text: Scenes from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s performance of Aszure Barton’s new work.

headline: A Haze of Bare Chests, Thigh Slaps and Squalls of Vertical Flight
text: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater continued its run at City Center on Thursday and Friday nights with two more showings of “Revelations,” a gorgeous rendition of Ronald K. Brown’s “Grace” and a ponderous addition to the repertory that takes advantage of the Ailey dancers but gives them little in return. In Aszure Barton’s “LIFT,” bare chests, thigh slaps and a pseudo-tribal sensibility elicit one cringe after another.

headline: Hybrid Forms Blossom Where Middle Eastern Instruments Meet Jazz
text: On Saturday night at the Asia Society, in the debut concert by a quartet called Sound: The Encounter, ears were more trustworthy than eyes.

headline: Jets Try Out a New Look: Competence
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets have trudged into their training facility the past three Mondays, showing up out of embarrassment and pride as much as obligation. On days after losses, attendance is mandatory. Meetings are had. Game film is reviewed. Encouragement is dispensed after fury has been unleashed.

headline: A Public Works Boom in Japan Has Echoes From the Lost Decade
text: SAGA, Japan — The bulldozers started up with a rumble this year in this bucolic corner of southern Japan, unleashing a construction frenzy — and a sinking feeling of déjà vu.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Chéri
text: Alessandra Ferri and Herman Cornejo in a scene from a new piece directed and choreographed by Martha Clarke.

headline: Summoning the Fantastical, Long After an Opium Trip Has Lost Its Novelty
text: There are many ways to read the “Symphonie Fantastique.” Berlioz wrote the work in 1830 as an early example of what Liszt would come to call program music (as opposed to the instrumental works without story that anti-Lisztians would champion as “absolute music”).

headline: Lucius Live (Personal)
text: So I’m continuing my project of going to live performances of the bands I feature on Friday Night Music posts, and last night got to see Lucius.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Dec. 6, 2013
text: Cities and states are trying to figure out how to address the growing public pension crisis. Collectively, they’re underfunded by an estimated $1 trillion. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine discuss what Detroit, Illinois and Rhode Island all have in common. Plus, banking regulators will meet next week to approve the Volcker Rule, which would make it illegal for banks to make trades with their own money. Will it make the financial system safer? And a look at Time magazine’s exclusive interview with Carl Icahn, the shareholder activist who’s doing all he can to force a bigger stock buyback at Apple.

headline: Celebrity Lawyer Still Has the Skills
text: When we first met Michael Connelly’s Mickey Haller in “The Lincoln Lawyer” (2005), his shyster qualities were irresistible. He used his car as an office, advertised his services on bus benches in high-crime areas and bribed bail bondsmen with cans of Planters holiday nut mix filled with money. This last ploy gave Mickey untold business opportunities and let him eat a squirrel’s diet out of Tupperware until springtime. He was a refreshing change from his brooding, much older half-brother: Mr. Connelly’s best-known character, Hieronymus Bosch, a.k.a. Harry.

headline: A Seesaw Finish at North American Championships
text: PHOENIX — The Fall North American Championships ended here on Sunday, with the final sessions of the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams and the Keohane North American Swiss Teams. The results are at acbl.org.

headline: Badge of Seriousness Watch
text: Jim Kessler, who co-wrote that remarkably self-destructive op-ed from Third Way attacking Elizabeth Warren and Bill de Blasio, explains what set them off: Warren’s talk of expanding Social Security.

headline: Holiday Tradition, Performed With Mandela in Mind
text: The Choir of Trinity Wall Street gave the first of its three “Messiah” performances on Saturday evening together with the Trinity Baroque Orchestra under its conductor, Julian Wachner. But before the first note of Handel was heard, the noble interior of Trinity Church filled with the soaring harmonies of “Nkosi Sikelel’ iAfrika” (“God Bless Africa”), the hymn embedded in today’s South African national anthem, which the singers performed in honor of Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, who died on Thursday at 95.

headline: Italian Film Wins Honors in Europe
text: Paolo Sorrentino’s “The Great Beauty” from Italy claimed three top prizes at the 26th annual European Film Awards on Saturday in Berlin, where it won for best picture and best director for Mr. Sorrentino, and best actor for Toni Servillo. The film follows Mr. Servillo’s character after his 65th birthday as he takes in the sights and sounds of Rome. Voted on by 2,900 members of the European Film Academy, Joshua Oppenheimer’s “The Act of Killing” won the prize for best documentary, and Veerle Baetens took the best actress award for her role in the Belgian film “The Broken Circle Breakdown.” “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” which won the Palme d’Or at the Cannes International Film Festival in May, was shut out.

headline: Flea Theater Gets a Place to Call Home
text: In the post-Sept. 11 devastation, when Lower Manhattan was effectively shut down and New Yorkers stayed home, the Flea thought its days as an Off Off Broadway theater were over.

headline: We Interrupt This TV Show for a Musical
text: Whatever you thought of NBC’s live “Sound of Music” last week, it was not television’s musical event of the season. The forthcoming finals of “The Voice”? Also not. Last month’s Country Music Awards, Tuesday’s American Country Awards or the recent “Barbra Streisand: Back to Brooklyn”? Not, not, not.

headline: Crisis for Insane Clown Posse: Getting Saner
text: FARMINGTON HILLS, Mich. — For more than 20 years, the rap duo Insane Clown Posse has courted controversy by rhyming about depravity, brutality and insanity. Now it causes trouble by making fun of Miley Cyrus.

headline: Heading Up a Committee
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — The puzzles for Monday through Thursday of this week were featured in the first Arlington Heights (Ill.) Memorial Library Crossword Tournament.

headline: Mandela, Self-Declared Yankee, Gets Plaque in Monument Park
text: During a triumphant visit by Nelson Mandela to New York in June 1990, shortly after he had been released from a South African prison, one of his most memorable stops was a rally and concert at Yankee Stadium, where he put on a team cap and jacket and proclaimed, “I am a Yankee.”

headline: Fed’s Plan to Taper Stimulus Effort Is Not Expected Until Next Year
text: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials are in no hurry to retreat from their bond-buying campaign to stimulate the economy and are likely to postpone any cuts to the program until next year, according to public statements by Fed officials and interviews with some of them.

headline: Rangers’ Staal Out With Neck Problem
text: Rangers defenseman Marc Staal was scratched from Sunday’s game against Washington as a result of “neck issues” caused by a hit to the chin in a loss to the Devils a day earlier.

headline: TD Ameritrade Commercials Link Olympics and Investing
text: WHEN athletic brands sponsor Olympic athletes, the connection is straightforward, since competitors are reaching great heights — and speeds — using the sponsors’ equipment or clothing.

headline: In Shepherding Detroit Bankruptcy, Lawyer Tackles a Job He Didn’t Ask For
text: DETROIT — Kevyn D. Orr, the man who must now revive Detroit, commutes each week from Maryland to a cavernous old office building here that seems to dare him to succeed: the former headquarters of a company, itself recently in bankruptcy, that once sold more than half of America’s cars — General Motors.

headline: Anatomy of Detroit’s Decline
text: A look at how the collapse of Detroit – battered by financial missteps, racial tensions and leadership lapses – culminated in insurmountable debt that led the city to file for bankruptcy.

headline: A Feminist Kant
text: In one of his more memorable essays, “Getting Away from Already Being Pretty Much Away from It All,” David Foster Wallace describes a visit to the Illinois State Fair. The friend who accompanies him, whom he calls Native Companion because she’s a local, gets on one of the fair’s rides. While she’s hanging upside down, the men operating the ride stop it so that her dress falls over her head and they can ogle her.  After she gets off the ride, Wallace and Native Companion have a heated discussion about the incident.  He thinks she’s been sexually harassed and thinks something should be done about it.

headline: The Takeout Item Left on Bloomberg’s Plate
text: He has battled the tobacco, taxicab and soda industries. Now, in his last days in office, one of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s final showdowns is with makers of plastic-foam food containers.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Dec. 9
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Dec. 9
text: AIRLINE MERGER After two years of fits and starts, the merger of US Airways and American Airlines is set to become final on Monday, clearing the way for what will be the world’s largest carrier valued at nearly $18 billion. The newly formed airline, which survived a federal lawsuit over the summer, will continue to operate as two carriers under a single management until the task of combining them can be completed. The process is expected to take years, though frequent fliers could start to see changes early next year.

headline: Afghan Leader Agrees to Talks on Closer Iran Ties
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Amid highly public tensions with the United States over a long-term security deal, Afghanistan’s president looked to forge closer ties with neighboring Iran, agreeing in principle to start negotiating an economic and security “pact of friendship,” Afghan officials said.

headline: With New Formula, an Official Helped Unmask the Face of Poverty in New York
text: Over and over again, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio has hammered it home: Forty-six percent of New Yorkers are poor or nearly poor. It is his mantra, the figure he holds up as proof that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has failed nearly half of his citizens.

headline: What Obama Left Out of His Inequality Speech: Regulation
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — President Obama’s speech on inequality last Wednesday was important in several respects. He identified the threat to economic stability, social cohesion and democratic legitimacy posed by soaring inequality of income and wealth. He put to rest the myths that inequality is mostly a problem afflicting poor minorities, that expanding the economy and reducing inequality are conflicting goals, and that the government cannot do much about the matter.

headline: New, Bigger and Bolder ‘T’ Logo Adorns a ‘Model Cab’ That Has an Uncertain Future
text: Reading lights. Sliding doors. Climate controls. Passenger air bags. Electrical outlets. Antibacterial seats. These features were to be standard in the city’s Taxi of Tomorrow.

headline: Near a Vote, Volcker Rule Is Weathering New Attacks
text: Even as five regulatory agencies prepared to vote Tuesday on a regulation that seeks to rein in risk-taking on Wall Street — an effort known as the Volcker Rule — lawyers and lobbyists were gearing up for another round of attacks against it.

headline: Tensions Rise as Indiana Schools Chief and Governor Clash Over New Agency
text: INDIANAPOLIS — For Glenda Ritz, who took office as Indiana’s top education official this year, the awkward reality of being the lone statewide elected Democrat here did not take long to blossom into all-out combat.

headline: Venezuelan Mayoral Votes Show No Big Power Shift
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuelans went to the polls on Sunday to elect hundreds of mayors around the country in a vote seen as an early test of the fledgling president, Nicolás Maduro, and his ability to carry the country further along the socialist path laid out by his predecessor and mentor, Hugo Chávez.

headline: More Medicaid Patients, but Not Enough Doctors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Edouard Molinaro, Oscar Nominee for Directing ‘La Cage,’ Dies at 85
text: Edouard Molinaro, who received an Oscar nomination for directing the 1978 French film “La Cage aux Folles,” which was remade in the United States as “The Birdcage” and as a Broadway musical, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 85.

headline: Travel Snarled on East Coast in a Blast of Snow and Sleet
text: Snow and freezing rain hit the East Coast on Sunday, causing flight cancellations and dangerous road conditions, and making for a few slippery N.F.L. football games.

headline: Good Old Books, on Paper
text: To the Editor:

headline: Candor About the Dead
text: To the Editor:

headline: Minimum Wage Studies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fred Scherer, 98, Dies; Diorama Painter Mastered Even Illusion of Air
text: In the memory of every schoolchild who has been marched through the American Museum of Natural History in New York in the last 75 years — among a few hundred million, by rough count — surely lies some trace of the pleasant shock felt at the first sight of a wildlife diorama, its taxidermy creatures and painted habitat landscape melding seamlessly to make a world.

headline: Ligety Dominates and Miller Surprises in 1-2 U.S. Finish
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Ted Ligety and Bode Miller of the United States added a page to ski racing’s record books Sunday, taking gold and silver in the giant slalom race here. It was the first one-two finish for American men in a giant slalom since 2005.

headline: Bringing Back the Artistic Beauty of a 19th-Century Church
text: The stunningly decorated sanctuary of St. Anselm’s Church in the South Bronx is a marvel of art and architecture, capturing Byzantine, Greek, Italian and German styles. No glistening detail is random, from the gold band circling the balconies — a reminder of God’s crowning glory — to the 12 side pillars, one for each apostle.

headline: A Soweto Church Says Goodbye to Mandela
text: At Regina Mundi Catholic Church in Soweto, not far from his former home, parishioners gathered on Sunday to celebrate the memories and legacy of Nelson Mandela.

headline: Advocates Struggle to Reach Immigrants Eligible for Deferred Action
text: The two women had spent a couple of afternoons wandering a heavily Chinese neighborhood in Brooklyn on a seemingly straightforward quest: to find young, undocumented immigrants and enroll them in a federal program that lets them stay in the country for at least two years and work legally.

headline: Capital Salutes 5 Stars With Kennedy Center Honors
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Sonia Sotomayor was 15 when Carlos Santana gave his renowned performance at Woodstock — one that would help catapult his music career, eventually taking him to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1998, and now to the White House and the State Department as a Kennedy Center honoree.

headline: The Punishment Cure
text: Six years have passed since the United States economy entered the Great Recession, four and a half since it officially began to recover, but long-term unemployment remains disastrously high. And Republicans have a theory about why this is happening. Their theory is, as it happens, completely wrong. But they’re sticking to it — and as a result, 1.3 million American workers, many of them in desperate financial straits, are set to lose unemployment benefits at the end of December.

headline: Signals Upgraded for Curve in Track Where Metro-North Crash Occurred
text: One week after a Metro-North train derailed in the Bronx, killing four people and injuring scores of others, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Sunday night that it had upgraded its signal network to warn operators as they approach the sharply curving section of track where the crash occurred.

headline: Saving the Fed From Itself
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE Federal Reserve is pursuing a very risky monetary policy. Its leaders — the departing chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, and the vice chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, whom President Obama has nominated to succeed him — are correct that the American economy needs more stimulus, and they believe that the central bank, because of political paralysis, is the only game in town. But if Congress and the Obama administration could agree on a fiscal stimulus that goes beyond a short-term budget deal, the Fed would not have to take such risks.

headline: Where Freedom of the Press Is Muffled
text: In China on Thursday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke plainly about the role of a free press in a democratic society.

headline: Brooklyn District Attorney-Elect Chooses Top Assistant
text: A former prosecutor best known for convicting top members of New York’s crime families is being appointed to the No. 2 position at the Brooklyn district attorney’s office, the incoming district attorney, Kenneth P. Thompson, said Sunday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 8, 2013
News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Sake of Argument Vanishes in a Sensible B.C.S. Finale
text: In its final season, college football’s beleaguered postseason system, known as the Bowl Championship Series, seemed destined for one last controversy. This felt not only likely but somehow appropriate.

headline: Eyes on Iran, Navy in Gulf Stays at Ready
text: ABOARD THE U.S.S. WHIRLWIND, in the Persian Gulf — In the past six months, this small United States Navy coastal patrol ship has engaged Iranian gunboats three times in international waters here.

headline: In Mistake-Filled Year, Giants Are Eliminated From Playoff Race in Fitting Fashion
text: SAN DIEGO — The Giants, after losing their first six games, have long been in need of a miracle to rescue their season, and the way their day began Sunday, they needed all the divine intervention they could get when Eli Manning, on the last play before halftime, launched a long, arcing pass from midfield. Receiver Hakeem Nicks leapt high, soaring above several players, and landed with the ball.

headline: Iran, From Enemy to Ally
text: LONDON — THE recent nuclear deal with Iran has caused a predictable furor among Middle East hawks. But it offers an opportunity for a much bigger breakthrough: rapprochement and, eventually, even strategic cooperation with Iran.

headline: Dropping ‘Zero Tolerance’ in Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Case for Tolerating E-Cigarettes
text: DEBATE over e-cigarettes — battery-powered cigarette look-alikes that heat liquid nicotine but emit a harmless vapor — is raging. New York City and Chicago are considering adding e-cigarettes to their bans on smoking in bars, restaurants and parks, and Los Angeles is moving to restrict e-cigarette sales, even though e-cigarettes don’t generate smoke and, while not proved to be entirely safe for users, are undoubtedly less hazardous than tobacco cigarettes.

headline: Three Senators Try to Hold Off G.O.P. in South
text: NEW ORLEANS — Things traditionally get started a little late down here, an inclination that runs from mealtimes to political races. But with nearly a year to go before the 2014 election, it is already open season on Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana.

headline: Quips Follow Denver Post’s Naming of Marijuana Editor, but Its Intent Is Serious
text: Newspaper editors typically operate behind the scenes, overseeing reporters inside the newsroom and outside the spotlight.

headline: Oscar Campaign Trail Leads to the Rose Bowl
text: LOS ANGELES — The backup-singer documentary “20 Feet From Stardom,” a strong Oscar contender if not squarely a shoo-in, is looking to get a little help on the campaign front from … football fans?

headline: Eagles Rally by Keeping It Simple in the Snow
text: PHILADELPHIA — When a driving snow arrived a couple of hours earlier than predicted and continued throughout the opening half, the Philadelphia Eagles knew their best-laid plans had to be changed.

headline: Mr. de Blasio’s Fiscal Challenge
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg last month presented his successor, Bill de Blasio, with a housewarming gift: a balanced budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. What loomed as an imminent crisis for the new administration — an expected $2 billion deficit — had vanished, Mr. Bloomberg declared, thanks to new savings and higher-than-expected revenues. The sudden infusion of black ink doesn’t necessarily make the next mayor’s job easy, he said, “but it reduces the pain.”

headline: When Bishops Direct Medical Care
text: Beyond new state efforts to restrict women’s access to proper reproductive health care, another, if quieter, threat is posed by mergers between secular hospitals and Catholic hospitals operating under religious directives from the nation’s Roman Catholic bishops. These directives, which oppose abortions, inevitably collide with a hospital’s duty to provide care to pregnant women in medical distress. This tension lies at the heart of a federal lawsuit filed last week by the American Civil Liberties Union.

headline: France’s New Approach to Curbing Prostitution
text: The lower house of the French Parliament overwhelmingly passed a bill last Wednesday that would impose stiff fines on anyone paying for sex, while offering assistance to prostitutes to leave the sex industry. The law, which is expected to be passed by the Senate by summer, has been bitterly debated. But it would bring France more in line with a growing consensus among European and American governments that it makes better sense to treat prostitutes as exploited and abused victims rather than as criminals. That has become increasingly true in Europe with the increase in the trafficking of foreign women, including underage girls, to work in richer countries.

headline: Amid Rows of Tin Shacks, a Luxury Hotel Rises
text: SOWETO, South Africa — A cool pitcher of ginger-infused water greets guests at the Soweto Hotel and Conference Center in the Kliptown section of this township, which grew over decades of racial oppression to segregate black workers from the rest of Johannesburg.

headline: Tragic Course of a Delirious Blaze
text: The rapture of sexual love and the disorienting pain of parting are viewed as through frosted glass in “Chéri,” a dramatically muted but gorgeously danced new work from the choreographer Martha Clarke, based on the titular novella by Colette.

headline: San Francisco Demonstrates That It Has a Home-Field Advantage, Too
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For most of four quarters, it looked as if San Francisco quarterback Colin Kaepernick and running back Frank Gore would be outplayed, again, by their counterparts on the rival Seattle Seahawks. The 49ers may be the defending N.F.C. champions, but they have spent the season feeling left behind in their own division.

headline: Amid the Uproar Over the Health Law, Voices of Quiet Optimism and Relief
text: Since his chronic leukemia was diagnosed in 2010, Ray Acosta has paid dearly for health insurance: more than $800 a month in premiums, plus steep co-payments for the drug that helps keep him alive.

headline: Corrections: December 9, 2013
text: EDITORIAL

headline: The Executive Assistant
text: When Sergio Kletnoy, the executive assistant to the Cosmopolitan editor Joanna Coles, saw “The Devil Wears Prada” years ago, he knew this was the industry he wanted to work in.

headline: The Gofer’s Expanding Portfolio
text: Sergio Kletnoy was trapped in traffic and running behind schedule. As the executive assistant to Joanna Coles, the editor of Cosmopolitan magazine, Mr. Kletnoy had spent the day scheduling a December lunch for Ms. Coles, booking her business trip to Boston and accompanying her to Chelsea, where she made a speech before an online financial group while he held her purse. In a free moment, he had interviewed the singer Betty Who for Cosmopolitan’s blog and arranged for Ms. Coles to meet her as well.

headline: The Politics of Runaway Trains and Other Avoidable Calamities
text: Updated, 3:21 p.m. | Trains are, over all, an incredibly reliable means of moving people efficiently and economically through crowded corridors, as Bryan Walsh recently pointed out in Time.

headline: Starting From Scratch, a Second Time
text: Three years ago, Silvia Alvarado woke to black smoke, an awful, thick cloak of it, creeping into her bedroom. She corralled her four children and her husband, and they padded rapidly down the stairs, coughing, shoeless and still in pajamas. From the street, they watched their apartment burn, and with it their belongings.

headline: A Rebuilding Meets a Falling Apart
text: Growing up in an Indianapolis suburb, little Brad Stevens must have paid close attention when he attended his first basketball camp, run by three former Indiana University players, including Mike Woodson, in the early 1980s.

headline: From Memos to Mistletoe
text: How can we make the most out of the American workplace tradition that is the office holiday party?

headline: A Global Dining Empire Loses an Outpost
text: BEIJING — The last meal at Maison Boulud in China, at least for now, was served on Sunday.

headline: Hollywood Buildup Prepared the Way for Bryant’s Return to the Floor
text: LOS ANGELES — The messianic trailer previewing one of the most anticipated events of the year in Hollywoodland ended with the words “The Legend Continues December 8.” Before Ron Burgundy’s return to the big screen in “Anchorman 2,” the larger-than-celluloid star of the Lakers, Kobe Bryant, reappeared on the N.B.A. stage for his first game since sustaining a torn Achilles’ tendon.

headline: North Korea Releases List of Accusations Against Purged Official
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea confirmed on Monday that Jang Song-thaek, the uncle of Kim Jong-un, the country’s top leader, had been stripped of all titles of power and expelled from the ruling Workers’ Party of Korea. Mr. Jang is the most prominent figure to be purged since Mr. Kim took power two years ago.

headline: Fire Officials Told to Watch for Bias as Rookies Report
text: As the newly graduated class of New York City firefighters reports for duty this week, the court-appointed monitor overseeing efforts to diversify the Fire Department has issued a report urging officials to guard against possible discrimination against black and Hispanic rookies.

headline: With Second Loss, Rangers’ 9-Game Homestand Is Off to a Shaky Start
text: The Rangers need wins in bunches during this month’s franchise-record nine-game homestand if they want to achieve any type of distinction in a congested Metropolitan Division.

headline: Young Jets Safety Emulates Veteran Teammate With Pivotal Play
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The genesis of Antonio Allen’s blocked punt and touchdown in the second quarter Sunday can be traced back to last Monday, when the Jets’ special-teams coordinator, Ben Kotwica, told Allen to line up just off the center, rather than off the edge.

headline: Cerberus, Gun Maker’s Owner, to Offer a Way Out to Its Investors
text: The owner of the Freedom Group, the gun manufacturer whose Bushmaster rifle was used in a deadly Connecticut school shooting nearly a year ago, is planning to give other investors in the company a way to cash out as an attempt to sell it has stalled.

headline: Amid Rows of Tin Shacks, a Luxury Hotel Rises
text: In the Kliptown section of Soweto, $180-a-night hotel rooms sit 30 yards from tin shacks.

headline: Union in Position to Defend Indefensible
text: The role of the N.H.L. Players’ Association in on-ice disciplinary matters has fallen under the spotlight again after two ugly episodes in Saturday night’s game in Boston, one involving the Pittsburgh Penguins’ James Neal and the other the Bruins’ Shawn Thornton.

headline: Tech Giants Issue Call for Limits on Government Surveillance of Users
text: Eight prominent technology companies, bruised by revelations of government spying on their customers’ data and scrambling to repair the damage to their reputations, are mounting a public campaign to urge President Obama and Congress to set new limits on government surveillance.

headline: Snacking Your Way to Better Health
text: Nuts to you! No, that’s not an insult. It’s a recommendation to add nuts to your diet for the sake of your health and longevity.

headline: Obama and Big Tech Companies to Push Coding Event for Students
text: Computer code is something most people enjoy the benefits of without ever laying their eyes on it. But this week, it will be hard for students to avoid calls for them to learn how to program.

headline: H.P. Tying More Big-Business Systems Together
text: Hewlett-Packard’s new computer hardware for big business may have impressive technology specifications, but it gets really interesting when you step back and look at why H.P. made these kind of machines.

headline: On Health Exchanges, Premiums May Be Low, but Other Costs Can Be High
text: WASHINGTON — For months, the Obama administration has heralded the low premiums of medical insurance policies on sale in the insurance exchanges created by the new health law. But as consumers dig into the details, they are finding that the deductibles and other out-of-pocket costs are often much higher than what is typical in employer-sponsored health plans.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 14

headline: A Senator Plans Legislation to Narrow Authorities’ Cellphone Data Requests
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Cellphone carriers last year answered at least 1.1 million requests from law enforcement agencies seeking information on caller locations, text messages and other data for use in investigations, according to reports from the carriers.

headline: Eastern States Press Midwest to Improve Air
text: WASHINGTON — In a battle that pits the East Coast against the Midwest over the winds that carry dirty air from coal plants, the governors of eight Northeastern states plan to petition the Environmental Protection Agency on Monday to force tighter air pollution regulations on nine Rust Belt and Appalachian states.

headline: Activist Investor Plans to Increase Pressure on Bob Evans
text: Last week, Bob Evans Farms announced that it had declined to make strategic changes recommended by one of its biggest investors. Now that investor, the hedge fund Sandell Asset Management, plans to turn up the heat on the restaurant operator.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Cars sales totaled 1.25 million in November, an increase of 8.9 percent compared with November 2012. Analysts variously attributed sales to Black Friday discounts, an improved economy and favorable financing. This year may be the best year for car sales since 2007.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10:30 P.M. (Ovation) THE YOUNG VICTORIA (2009) Emily Blunt, above, portrays a decidedly unfrumpy Queen Victoria as a teenage monarch; Miranda Richardson is her mother, the Duchess of Kent, who would gladly pull the puppet strings; and Rupert Friend is Albert, Victoria’s first cousin and the eventual love of her life. “Despite the filmmakers’ efforts to persuade us that ‘The Young Victoria’ is a serious work, and despite some tense moments and gunfire, the movie’s pleasures are as light as its story,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this “frivolously entertaining film,” directed by Jean-Marc Vallée and written by Julian Fellowes. “No matter. Albert may never rip Victoria’s bodice, but he does eventually loosen it, to her delight and ours.”

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 1-7
text: Sports can be structured upon strategy, grace and athleticism. At other times, the plan seems to be “leap, clutch, grab, and just hang on tight.”

headline: Alderson Tempers Expectations About Mets’ Winter Meeting Plans
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Fresh from handing out the largest free-agent contract in his tenure as the Mets’ general manager, Sandy Alderson arrived here for baseball’s annual winter meetings, his suite turned into a makeshift conference room.

headline: Visiting Pakistan, Hagel Seeks to Shore Up Alliance
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel cautioned Pakistan’s prime minister on Monday that if Pakistani regional officials followed through on their threats to block NATO supply lines for the war in Afghanistan, it could jeopardize hundreds of millions of dollars in assistance to the military here, Pentagon officials said.

headline: A Conversation With: Author James Astill
text: When it comes to cricket, “nothing unites Indians, in all their legions and diversity, more than their love for it,” writes James Astill in his book “The Great Tamasha: Cricket, Corruption and the Turbulent Rise of Modern India” which was released earlier this year.

headline: Indian Stock Markets Hit Record High on B.J.P. Victories
text: The Indian stock markets hit record highs on Monday after the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party, perceived as a more business-friendly party by investors, performed well in four state elections.

headline: Survey Finds Many Female Workers Experience Sexual Harassment
text: A survey of female factory workers in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou found that most had experienced sexual harassment from co-workers and that about one in six had quit their jobs to escape it, losing a substantial amount of money in wages.

headline: Protests Continue in Thailand After Election Is Set
text: BANGKOK — A call for new elections by Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra of Thailand on Monday failed to quell antigovernment demonstrations, as tens of thousands of protesters massed outside her office and vowed to expel her powerful family from the country.

text: In any home, some cleaning-related tasks spark dread in some members of the household, while others don’t mind them at all. For example, one person might detest emptying the dishwasher, and therefore, complete other chores that he or she likes more, or at least is willing to do.

headline: Why Machiavelli Still Matters
text: FIVE hundred years ago, on Dec. 10, 1513, Niccolò Machiavelli sent a letter to his friend Francesco Vettori, describing his day spent haggling with local farmers and setting bird traps for his evening meal. A typical day for the atypical letter writer, who had changed from his mud-splattered clothes to the robes he once wore as a high official in the Florentine republic.

headline: Infiltrating a Virtual Gaming World
text: These documents show that government agencies have grown worried that terrorist groups are taking to the virtual worlds of online gaming to establish safe communications channels.

headline: Covidien to Acquire Medical Technology Company in $860 Million Deal
text: LONDON – Covidien has agreed to acquire the Israel medical technology company Given Imaging in a deal valued at about $860 million, expanding the scope of its gastrointestinal diagnostic testing business.

headline: Exxon Valdez: In the Wake of Disaster
text: In 1989, a tanker ran aground off the coast of Alaska, causing one of the worst oil spills in United States history. Nearly 25 years later, the lessons of the Exxon Valdez continue to resonate.

headline: Lessons From the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill
text: On a cold March night in 1989, the tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground off the coast of Alaska, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil into the waters of Prince William Sound and creating one of the worst oil spills in American history. This week’s Retro Report examines how that spill happened and follows its impact over the past twenty-five years. Watch the video above for the complete story. Below, a Times reporter who covered the BP oil disaster of 2010 writes about how containment and cleanup evolved.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Kevin Sack on His Friendship with a Lost Boy
text: Kevin Sack, who wrote this week’s cover story about the American life of Jacob Mach, one of the Lost Boys of Sudan, is a senior reporter at The Times.

headline: Dealing With Employee Disputes in China
text: I don’t know any foreign business owner in China who hasn’t been to labor court at least once. Labor courts address and adjudicate cases very quickly, and you will need a Chinese lawyer to represent you. The courts are organized into a three-tiered system in which the first arbitrator makes a decision, and then each party has the right to appeal it to the next-highest tier.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 9, 2013

headline: World of Spycraft
text: One of the most extraordinary things revealed in the documents disclosed by Edward J. Snowden is the surveillance of video games like World of Warcraft by Western spy agencies.

headline: Spies Infiltrate a Fantasy Realm of Online Games
text: Not limiting their activities to the earthly realm, American and British spies have infiltrated the fantasy worlds of World of Warcraft and Second Life, conducting surveillance and scooping up data in the online games played by millions of people across the globe, according to newly disclosed classified documents.

headline: In Our Pages: December 10
text: 1913: Women Could Be Solicitors

headline: Ukraine’s Forces Move Against Protesters, Dimming Hopes for Talks
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Ominous new action by Ukraine’s security forces on Monday, including a raid on an opposition party’s headquarters, appeared to diminish prospects for talks between the government and protest leaders, as Western officials grasped for a way to defuse the country’s intensifying political crisis.

headline: Fresh Attacks on the Volcker Rule
text: Five regulatory agencies are preparing to vote on Tuesday on a final draft of the Volcker Rule, the regulation that seeks to rein in risk-taking on Wall Street. But lawyers and lobbyists are gearing up for another round of attacks against it, Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess report in DealBook.

headline: Verizon to Buy Content Delivery Network Start-Up
text: Verizon announced on Monday that it had agreed to acquire EdgeCast, a fast-growing content delivery network start-up.

headline: Looking on the Bright Side of Bad Air
text: The heavy air pollution that shrouded much of eastern China over the past week has generated intense coverage in Chinese media, including a few efforts to find silver linings in the haze. Aided by the expansion of real-time air quality monitoring to many cities, along with official websites that report pollution data, Chinese residents have a far better idea now of what they are breathing than they did just a few years ago, when such information was considered sensitive and Chinese officials reacted angrily to the United States posting from a monitoring device at its embassy in Beijing.

headline: The Dead Hand Versus the Invisible Hand, Urban Edition
text: Sometimes you read an economics paper that just makes you start grinning in pleasure. Michaels and Rauch on path dependence of urban locations is one of those papers.

headline: Scores of Leaders Heading to South Africa for Service
text: JOHANNESBURG — From Afghanistan to Zimbabwe, from Scandinavia to the Caribbean, heads of state from around the world are descending on South Africa to take part in an enormous farewell to Nelson Mandela on Tuesday, presenting the government with a security test, logistical challenge and protocol quiz all rolled into one.

headline: Helicopters Don’t Help (Wonkish)
text: David Beckworth has a good piece on a point I’ve also tried to make: the irrelevance of “helicopter money”, and in particular the irrelevance of the decision to finance budget deficits by printing money as opposed to selling bonds.

headline: Critics in L.A. and Boston Split Over Year’s Best
text: The pool of Oscar hopefuls continues to grow, as evidenced by the number of ties in the Los Angeles Film Critics Association’s year-end choices, announced Sunday. “Gravity” and “Her” both took home the best film award; Cate Blanchett (“Blue Jasmine”) and Adèle Exarchopoulos (“Blue Is the Warmest Color”) tied for best actress; and James Franco (“Spring Breakers”) and Jared Leto (“Dallas Buyers Club”) will have to share the prize for best supporting actor.

headline: User Data Requests Received by Cellphone Carriers
text: Cellphone carriers last year answered at least 1.1 million requests from law enforcement agencies seeking information on caller locations, text messages and other data for use in investigations, according to reports from the carriers.

headline: My Favorite Martian
text: As we all know, there are three kinds of economists. There are liberal professional economists; there are conservative professional economists; and there are professional conservative economists (aka right-wing hacks). Surely, you say, there must be four kinds? Not really — there just isn’t enough money on the left, an asymmetry that gives rise to the well-known hack gap.

headline: Sysco to Buy Rival US Foods in Deal Valued at $3.5 Billion
text: Updated, 8:48 p.m. | The tasting menu at Per Se, Thomas Keller’s gastronomic mecca, features such delicacies as dry-aged American Wagyu beef and pressed duck.

headline: Robert Diamond Aims to Make Banking Comeback – in Africa
text: LONDON – Robert E. Diamond Jr., who was ousted as chief executive of Barclays nearly 18 months ago amid a rate-fixing scandal, is planning a banking comeback.

headline: Statue Symbols
text: MOSCOW — The envious Ukraine-watch of many Russians culminated Sunday when a statue of Lenin was toppled in Kiev. It evoked the memory of one of the most richly symbolic, joyous and ultimately disappointing moments in Russia’s own history, when, after a hard-line coup failed in August 1991, a monument to Felix Dzerzhinsky, the founder of the secret police, in front of the K.G.B. headquarters in Moscow was toppled. A new era was beginning.

headline: Public Ouster in North Korea Unsettles China
text: BEIJING — North Koreans had long known Jang Song-thaek as the No. 2 figure in their country, the revered uncle and mentor of Kim Jong-un, the paramount leader. Then on Monday state-run television showed two green-uniformed guards clutching a glum-looking Mr. Jang by the armpits and pulling him from a meeting of the ruling party after he was denounced for faction-building, womanizing, gambling and other acts as dozens of former comrades watched.

headline: Image of the Day: December 9
text: Tibetan activists protesting against China in New Delhi.

headline: Why Federal Reserve Support Is Really a Bailout
text: It has become something of an article of faith in the financial world that government support like discount-window liquidity does not count as a bailout. Namely, the argument is that if a financial institution needs to borrow some money on a short-term basis from the government, but the institution is otherwise solvent, that the lending is not a bailout.

headline: Making ‘Llewyn Davis’ and Crowning Sorrentino
text: The Coen brothers’ “Inside Llewyn Davis,” loosely based on the memoir “The Mayor of Macdougal Street” by Dave Van Ronk, found favor with moviegoers this weekend, topping the Coens’ box office record for per-screen ticket sales. (It earned about $402,000 on four screens and will expand to more theaters later this month.)

headline: Parent of Airbus to Cut 5,800 Jobs as Europe’s Military Budgets Shrink
text: PARIS — European Aeronautic Defense and Space, the parent company of Airbus, announced plans on Monday to cut 5,800 jobs from its military and space divisions over the next three years as it responds to reductions in European military budgets driven by austerity measures.

headline: Industrial Production Slows in Germany
text: PARIS — Output at German factories, mines and power plants declined in October for a second straight month, official data showed on Monday, the latest sign that the economy at the heart of the euro zone recovery might not be growing as quickly as had been hoped.

text: Mike Ryan of the Sable Kitchen and Bar in Chicago created a warming cocktail from red wine and whiskey.

headline: Torre, La Russa and Cox Elected to Hall of Fame
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Together they won more than 7,500 games in the major leagues, with 17 pennants and 8 championships across 91 seasons writing out lineup cards. Next summer, Joe Torre, Tony La Russa and Bobby Cox will share a stage in Cooperstown, N.Y.
