text: Leo Robitschek from the NoMad in New York City created a whiskey cocktail with a hint of crisp apple.

headline: Snowbirds and Townies
text: Tonia Guffey of Dram in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, created a cocktail packed with holiday flavors: orange, cocoa and cinnamon.

headline: Act of Faith
text: New York City bartender Dan Greenbaum created a simple cocktail of mixed rums with a hint of bitters.

headline: The Minimum Wage Ain’t What It Used to Be
text: David Neumark is professor of economics and director of the Center for Economics and Public Policy at the University of California, Irvine.

headline: Without Notice, Putin Dissolves a News Agency
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin exerted new control over Russia’s state news media on Monday, dissolving by decree one of Russia’s official news agencies, RIA Novosti, along with its international radio broadcaster as he continues a drive to strengthen the Kremlin’s influence at home and abroad.

headline: Iraq Forces Clash With Gunmen in Syria Border Area
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi forces battled gunmen trying to infiltrate the country from neighboring Syria on Monday, while attacks in Baghdad and north of the capital killed more than 20 people, officials said.

headline: The Right to an Attorney Who Actually Does His Job
text: On Dec. 4, a federal judge in Washington State issued a stinging rebuke of the public-defense systems of two towns near Seattle, finding them so inadequate that they violate the Sixth Amendment right to the assistance of counsel in criminal prosecutions.

headline: Will There Be ‘Too Much Stuff’ Under Your Tree?
text: Last year, I sent myself an iCal reminder on Dec. 1 that read “too much stuff last year.” The year before’s Christmas morning had lasted well into the afternoon, and a few days later, new toys that would have been greeted with delight on any other day sat untouched by the recipients. It was a festival of materialism that no one over the age of 10 in my family had any desire to repeat.

headline: Gas-Station Banksy Brings $209,000 at Auction
text: As auctions of Banksy works go, the sale of “Flower Girl” at Julien’s Auctions on Thursday had none of the cloak-and-dagger elements of earlier sales. And perhaps that lack of intrigue accounts for the work’s relatively low sale price of $209,000, nearly a third less than the auction house’s highest estimate, and a fraction of the  $1.1 million fetched by another Banksy work, “Slave Labor,” at a London auction in June. Or maybe Banksymania is on the wane.

headline: Pixies Name a Bassist for Coming Tour
text: This time she’s not named Kim.

headline: Lincoln’s 10 Percent Plan
text: By early November 1863, Abraham Lincoln found himself frustrated with the glacial pace of wartime reconstruction efforts, particularly in Louisiana. In an August letter to Maj. Gen. Nathaniel Banks, the president had outlined “what I would like Louisiana to do.” His wish list included a new constitution, statewide adoption of emancipation, a system to help ease the transition from slavery to freedom for blacks and whites and education for young freedmen and women. He went on to assure his abolitionist general that “I shall not … retract the emancipation proclamation; nor … ever return to slavery any person who is free by the terms of that proclamation, or by any of the acts of Congress.”

headline: For Bitcoin, Square Peg Meets Round Hole Under the Law
text: The advent of a new medium to conduct business inevitably means avenues for criminals to swoop in to take advantage. The development of Bitcoin, the virtual currency that is not issued by any government, presents challenges for the authorities to use laws that were not designed for the digital world to combat illegal conduct.

headline: Times Minute | Tighter Pollution Rules
text: Also on the Minute, spies snoop on video games and Mayor Bloomberg fights to ban foam.

headline: Listen Up | A Baroque-Folk Troubadour Takes Flight
text: The weighty confessionals captured on “Love’s Crushing Diamond” — the recent breakout album from the singer-songwriter Jordan Lee’s ironically corporate-sounding nom de musique, Mutual Benefit — weren’t originally meant for mass appeal. The 25-year-old had initially intended to distribute the deeply personal album as a limited release on his D.I.Y., cassette-only label, Kassette Klub. The tracks document the strain that a rootless lifestyle took on his relationships when, for the better part of 2012, he rambled across the country from Austin, Tex., to Brooklyn. “I don’t want to sound corny, but it was a kind of soul-searching journey,” Lee says. “The big lesson I learned is you’re not supposed to feel good all the time — that it’s easier to just be O.K. with things you can’t control.” As a result, the album carries a haunting power that couldn’t help but find a larger audience.

headline: Mâche and Radicchio Salad With Beets and Walnut Vinaigrette
text: Of all the greens I worked with this week, mâche has the sweetest, mildest flavor. It goes nicely with the bitter radicchio, sweet beets and the nutty vinaigrette. Mâche is so delicate that it takes very little dressing.

headline: Times Minute | Tighter Pollution Rules
text: In the Video

headline: The Decision Tree
text: This week’s puzzle came out of a recent conversation with Leonard Dick, an executive producer for the brilliant CBS series “The Good Wife.” The series’ 100th episode, “The Decision Tree,” ran on Dec. 1. (Check it out here if you missed it.) Toward the end of the episode, the lawyer Will Gardner (played by Josh Charles) mapped out a complicated decision on a yellow pad of paper.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Johnson Honored for Sixth Nascar Title
text: Nascar’s annual season-ending Champions Week concluded in Las Vegas Friday night with a celebration of Jimmie Johnson’s sixth Sprint Cup title. Speculation has already begun as to whether he can make it seven championships next year, which would put him among the sport’s immortals.

headline: Ancient Martian Lake May Have Supported Life
text: About 3.5 billion years ago — around the time life is thought to have first arisen on Earth — Mars had a large freshwater lake that might well have been hospitable to life, scientists reported Monday.

headline: Chrysler to Recall 5,600 Vehicles; N.H.T.S.A. Investigates Hyundai
text: Chrysler will recall about 4,200 cars and pickups in the United States and 1,400 in Canada because the 8-speed automatic transmission could fail, while in a separate action the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether a Hyundai recall earlier this year should have covered more vehicles.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Rise of Uber
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Brooklyn Historical Society to Present Exhibition on Abolitionists
text: A major five-year exhibition opening Jan. 15 at the Brooklyn Historical Society will bring to life the stories of largely unknown Brooklyn abolitionists who led the anti-slavery movement. The exhibition, “In Pursuit of Freedom,” will display maps, pamphlets, advertisements, letters, landscape painting, and even a rare copy of the Emancipation Proclamation signed by Abraham Lincoln to document the battle for black rights.

headline: Scenes Not Safe for Work, Even for the Film Editor
text: By now most of the Oscar bloggerati have seen “The Wolf of Wall Street,” which means one thing: it is poised to “devour” the Oscar race completely. Or its chances are, at best, “a mixed bag.”

headline: Xiaomi Plans to Expand Into Southeast Asia
text: TOKYO — Since August, when the Chinese mobile phone maker Xiaomi lured away a top Google executive, Hugo Barra, to oversee its international expansion plans, two big questions remained: When and where would Xiaomi turn its attention?

headline: For Doormen, the Holidays Bring Tips and Colleagues’ Curiosity
text: When Christmastime comes to Wall Street, bankers are summoned to bosses’ offices to learn the number that junior analysts and executives alike regard as a reflection of self-worth: their year-end bonuses, linked to performance, earnings and perhaps how much their boss likes them.

headline: Hearings on San Francisco Crash Set to Explore Broader Problems
text: WASHINGTON — When the National Transportation Safety Board opens two days of hearings here Tuesday on the deadly crash of an Asiana jumbo jet  in San Francisco in July, investigators will have little difficulty establishing the immediate causes, including the three pilots’ failure to monitor their airspeed.

headline: Overcoming an Aversion to Loss
text: We’ve all heard (probably too much) about the downfall of Lance Armstrong. If you’ve followed his career at all, you know how committed this guy was to winning. Last week, I happened to see the trailer for the documentary “The Armstrong Lie.” It opens with a close-up shot of Armstrong’s chiseled face staring intently into the camera and explaining what drives him:

headline: Nokia Said to Propose Remedy for India Tax Standoff
text: LONDON – The Finnish cellphone giant Nokia is expected on Tuesday to offer almost $400 million to resolve a tax dispute with Indian authorities ahead of the company’s planned sale of its handset business to Microsoft for $7.2 billion.

headline: Fran Drescher to Join ‘Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella’
text: But how will she pronounce “Ella”? The cruel stepmother in the Broadway musical “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” will get a Queens makeover this winter when Fran Drescher — best known for her nasal, glass-breaking twang on the CBS comedy “The Nanny” — takes over the role, the show’s producers announced on Monday.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Fredericks & Mae Travel Checkers
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Excerpt: 'Watson Intelligence'
text: John Ellison Conlee and David Costabile in a scene from "The (curious case of the) Watson Intelligence," a new play by Madeleine George at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: Citing Back Problems, Halladay Retires After 16 Years and 203 Wins
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The Toronto Blue Jays signed a two-time Cy Young Award winner on the first day of the winter meetings, but he will not throw another pitch in the majors. Roy Halladay, who played 12 of his 16 seasons for Toronto, signed a one-day contract and announced his retirement.

headline: Hotel Week Deals in New York
text: High hotel prices are a fact of life in New York, but the third annual Hotel Week NYC can make the city a little more wallet friendly. From Jan. 3 to 12, 2014, 30 hotels in New York, many that charge more than $500 a night for room, will be offering fixed prices of a $100, $200 or $300 excluding taxes.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: David Adelman, executive director of Mindshare New York, part of the Mindshare division of GroupM, was named Chicago office lead. He succeeds Mary Carpenter, who takes a new role, overseeing a new performance marketing practice for Mindshare in North America. GroupM is owned by WPP.

headline: Art and Technology, Together Again, at Los Angeles County Museum of Art
text: In 1966, Maurice Tuchman, a curator at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, looked around at the technological fields blossoming in his city and at the growing number of artists interested in technology and decided to help put the two worlds together. The program he created, Art and Technology, was a brief but highly influential experiment in cross-pollination, placing artists like Robert Irwin and James Turrell, for example, at the Garrett Corporation, an aerospace company, to conduct research into perception.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: Ads Use Famous Figures to Put a Face on a Problem
text: As a campaign for a school for students in grades 5 through 12 seeks to encourage parents to enroll their children, it also has a larger purpose: helping to change perceptions about students who are described with terms like learning disabilities, learning differences, special needs and special education.

headline: Neil Young to Play Benefit Shows for Native American Group
text: Neil Young will play four benefit concerts in Canadian cities to raise money for the legal defense fund of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation, a Native American group based in Alberta that is suing Shell Canada to prevent it from undertaking oil sands extraction projects that the group says will encroach on lands and resources protected by an 1899 treaty.

headline: After Hours | An NC-17 Retelling of ‘The Nutcracker’
text: The jewel-box-small, down-at-the-heels Minetta Lane Theater is the perfect setting for this opulently burlesque and deliciously Freudian retelling of “The Nutcracker,” which has shades of Cirque du Soleil, “Sleep No More” and “Fanny and Alexander” (with a dash of “Satyricon”). It’s the work of the Brooklyn-based, largely Juilliard-trained dance-and-acrobatics ensemble Company XIV. On a proscenium framed by heavy red curtains, with candelabra where the footlights would usually be, Tchaikovsky’s darling little Clara (a radiant Laura Careless) is a mini-Marie Antoinette with a comeuppance in store, to be delivered by Drosselmeyer, her godfather, played like a smarmy satyr pimp by Jeff Takacs. The genius of this production, which includes eye-dazzling physical feats performed on giant hula hoops and from silken swings, is its transformation of traditional ballet into louche vaudeville: the famous Spanish dance becomes a foot-stomping, castanet-clicking striptease; in the storied Kingdom of the Sweets, Clara wields a fat black whip to play gleeful dominatrix over a troupe of bare-bottomed, harnessed Licorice Boys.

headline: Ask Nick Kristof
text: UPDATE: Read Part 1 of Nick’s answers to your questions.

headline: Ex-Mayor Sentenced in Harassment Case
text: LOS ANGELES — Bob Filner, the former mayor of San Diego, was sentenced on Monday to three months of house arrest and three years of probation for harassing women during his abbreviated term.

headline: Smoky Beef and Vegetables in a Petite Package
text: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Progress on Banking Stalemate in Europe
text: BERLIN — Germany’s finance minister signaled on Monday that his country might be ready to compromise on two main sticking points for Berlin on a mechanism for shutting failing banks in the euro zone.

headline: Ukraine on Edge as Protesters and the Authorities Face Off
text: In the continuing antigovernment demonstrations in Ukraine, Sunday is being called a historic day, when public protests thundered into a full-throttle civil uprising with a huge rally, and when demonstrators toppled a statue of Lenin.

headline: Abercrombie Renews Chief’s Contract and Revamps His Pay
text: Abercrombie & Fitch, the teenage fashion brand known for its provocative advertisements of nearly naked men and scantily clad women, has signed a new contract with its chairman and chief executive, Michael S. Jeffries, and has linked his pay more with the company’s performance.

headline: Big Savings Promised in Food Merger
text: Sysco’s acquisition of US Foods shows how investors are eating up synergies. The $3.5 billion purchase, revealed on Monday, received a rapturous reception, with the buyer’s market valuation surging by as much as a quarter – or $5 billion – before giving up some gains. Hefty cost cuts help the merger math.

headline: World of Spycraft
text: The government’s m.o. in electronic snooping can be summarized as follows: any data that can be collected must be collected so it can be stored and analyzed whenever it may be needed.

headline: With Rental Demand Soaring, Poor Are Feeling Squeezed
text: WASHINGTON — Violeta Torres cannot afford her apartment.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Dec. 3-9, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: WPP Chief Tempers Buoyant 2014 Ad Forecasts
text: The chief executive of WPP, the world’s largest advertising holding group by revenue, said on Monday that caution remained the watchword for marketer clients of agencies owned by WPP and others.

headline: Holiday Drinks From the Experts
text: Professional bartenders put their personal spins on cold-weather cocktails.

headline: Deciphering the Volcker Rule
text: The Volcker Rule is the keystone of the most sweeping overhaul of financial regulation since the Depression. The rule imposes some requirements that are tougher than the banks had hoped.

headline: The Read Around: Scott Anderson
text: By looking at the history of how the Middle East was divided nearly 100 years ago, says Scott Anderson, author of "Lawrence in Arabia," you can see the coming political fault lines.

headline: When Lightning Strikes Your Car
text: Q. When caught in a lightning storm, should you stay in a car or get out?

headline: It’s Post Time: At the Big A, Big Art
text: Aqueduct Racetrack is no one’s idea of an art gallery. But Paul Kelleher, a corporate development executive at the New York Racing Association, which operates the track, was keen to broaden his customer base and he saw potential. The place is big. It has lots of walls. Why not unleash a few street artists and let them do what they do best: spray-paint?

headline: Michael French, Who Battled a Rare Dementia, Dies at 73
text: Michael French, whose long struggle with the brain disease frontotemporal dementia was the subject of a 2012 New York Times article and video, died Nov. 30 at a nursing home in Manhattan. He was 73.

headline: The Read Around: Video of Scott Anderson
text: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Below, Scott Anderson, author of “Lawrence in Arabia,” talks about how you can see present-day political fault lines by studying the history of how the Middle East was divided nearly 100 years ago.

headline: Backing Up a Book With Gmail, and Another Screen for a Mac Laptop
text: Backing Up

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: One-day labor walkouts were staged at fast-food restaurants in 100 cities Thursday, with workers demanding a living wage of $15 an hour. But it’s not just McDonald’s and Burger King employees who are underpaid: Higher-tier fast-food places also stiff their workers. Maxwell Strachan at the Huffington Post thinks we should be tipping them.

headline: Parties in California Squabble Over Another Website
text: LOS ANGELES — California has enjoyed one of the smoothest rollouts of a health care exchange in the country. But the state’s Democrats are accusing Republicans of trying to sabotage the state-run exchange by putting up their own health care website.

headline: U.S. Charges 18 Sheriff’s Officers in Inquiry Into Misconduct at Los Angeles Jails
text: LOS ANGELES — Federal prosecutors on Monday charged 18 current and former members of the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department with excessive use of force and obstruction of justice as part of a sprawling investigation into allegations of misconduct and abuse of inmates in county jails, federal law enforcement officials said.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Precious Nature at Design Miami
text: The futuristic curves of Zaha Hadid were few and far between at this year’s just-completed edition of Design Miami. Instead, the fair offered numerous treatments of flora and fauna, many of which imbued these natural phenomena with a loving sense of preciousness. A few examples: a bird encased in a glass purse by the Dutch jewelry designer Ted Noten at Ornamentum; a tree by the Parisian furniture designer Maria Pergay at Demisch Danant; and a sculpture of a carnivorous plant dotted with dragonflies by Taher Chemirick at Galerie BSL.

headline: The American Film Institute’s Top 10 Could Be a Clue to Oscar Nominees
text: The American Film Institute, dedicated to preservation and a fairly reliable predictor of the Academy’s tastes, announced its 10 best films and TV series of the year on Monday. On the big screen, its picks were:

headline: Inside the Book: Rube Goldberg
text: His reservoir of elaborate contraptions that mutated simple tasks into madcap feats of ingenuity made Rube Goldberg rich and famous. But he was also an all-around cartoon man and artist.

headline: I’ll Have a Glass of Originality
text: The first time you hear Bing Crosby croon his way through “White Christmas,” it can coax a smile. By the 17th time, your ears may have gone numb out of self-preservation.

headline: Beyond a Man’s Machines
text: In the first half of the 20th century, Rube Goldberg was the Thomas Edison of the newspaper comics pages.

headline: A Rare Middle East Agreement, on Water
text: JERUSALEM — In a rare display of regional cooperation, representatives of Israel, Jordan and the Palestinian Authority signed an agreement on Monday to build a Red Sea-Dead Sea water project that is meant to benefit all three parties.

headline: Navy Secretary Expands Review of Supply Contracts
text: Secretary of the Navy Ray Mabus has expanded an internal review of the Navy’s ship-supply contracts, in a new sign that overbilling practices discovered in the Pacific could be occurring worldwide.

headline: Counterattack of the Deficit Scold Deadenders
text: The deficit scolds have not had a good year. They’ve seen their forecasts of fiscal disaster fizzle; they’ve seen their favorite economic analyses crash and burn; they’ve seen the rise of a faction with actual power in the Democratic party that refuses to acknowledge their wisdom. This last bit is crucial: deficit scoldery has always depended on the illusion of consensus, in which all the, well, serious people agreed that debt is the most important enemy.

headline: For Natural Adversary of the Bargaining Table, Labor Holds a Banquet
text: PHILADELPHIA — The grizzled labor leaders in the audience had scarcely seen anything like it.

headline: Hoops for Hotel Upgrades
text: On Andrew Hazelton’s last trip to Phoenix, he checked into a hotel and walked out, then checked into another room a few miles away. Mr. Hazelton, who travels frequently for his job in film distribution consulting, isn’t a finicky traveler. He is one of a growing cadre of business travelers who go to extraordinary lengths to secure elite-level status at their preferred hotel brand.

headline: Intellectuals on a Mission
text: Two years ago, a pair of scientists set off on a barnstorming tour to save the world from religion, promote science and reason, and sell a few books.

headline: Airlines’ Credit Card Perks Take It on the Chin
text: KEEPING track of travel credit card perks is a chore similar to managing the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament office pool, except you can’t depend on that guy in the office who understands all those complex brackets. You have to do it yourself.

headline: American Singer Is a Finalist, but Not a Winner on ‘Arabs Got Talent’
text: An American singer, Jennifer Grout, made it to the top three in the finals of the hit television show “Arabs Got Talent” in Beirut, Lebanon, on Saturday but ultimately fell short of the top honor. Ms. Grout, 23, had become a sensation across the Arab world after her surprisingly adept performances of classical Arab music, a genre that is largely fading among younger generations in the Middle East. She speaks little Arabic.

headline: Israel to Allow Building Materials Into Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — Under pressure from the United Nations amid a mounting economic and humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip, Israel has agreed to restart the transfer of construction materials to Gaza on Tuesday after an eight-week hiatus.

headline: Berlin Philharmonic Plans Major Concerts in New York
text: The Berlin Philharmonic and its chief conductor, Simon Rattle, will give not one but two major opening-night concerts in New York next fall.

headline: Fassbender and Poehler Make the Sundance Premieres Cut
text: Sundance programmers on Monday unveiled their 2014 Premieres lineup, and, while it is too early to say what art-house hits might lurk among the titles, there are some obvious attention grabbers.

headline: In Marrakesh, Lodging With a Starry History
text: The new seven-room boutique hotel in Marrakesh, Riad Star, offers a stylish and well-located base next to the Marrakesh Museum, as well as a little bit of stardust: it was the former home of entertainer Josephine Baker.

headline: A Doctor’s Formula for Care
text: It was almost 15 years ago that I set my personal record, since equaled but never exceeded, of 18 patients seen in the course of a single afternoon. What I remember are not the details of that particular day — all days are hectic for one reason or another — but a conversation I had at a party a short time later.

headline: Enjoys Fellow Travelers, Even if They Have Flippers
text: I’VE been fortunate when it comes to travel. I’ve seen so much of the world and have met many interesting people. But like all frequent travelers, I have had my share of strange encounters. I once had a seatmate who would remove a small wad of tissue paper from his mouth, fastidiously wipe his fingernails, and then pop the tissue back into his mouth. He did it for the flight’s duration, and it was really quite unnerving.

headline: Tales of Longing and Loss, in All Their Rhythmic Intensity
text: The program that Noche Flamenca is presenting at the Joyce Theater through Sunday is nearly the same as the one this exemplary flamenco troupe presented at the Cherry Lane Theater in 2010. The Joyce, where the company has performed since 2011, is less intimate than the Cherry Lane but holds more than twice as many seats. That size allows more people to experience a solo by the company’s star, Soledad Barrio. And encountering Ms. Barrio is an experience everyone should have.

headline: Square Roots | The Making of a Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show Look
text: Greg Kessler/Kessler Studio

headline: Idea of Healthy Obesity Is Tested
text: The idea that there are obese people who are nonetheless healthy may be a myth.

headline: An Inexpensive Way to Print Out Metal Parts
text: Low-cost 3-D plastic printers can produce almost anything, from clothes and toys to household items and furniture.

headline: New Hurdles for Premature Babies
text: Middle-income countries in Asia and Latin America have been doing better at saving premature infants, experts report, but blindness and cerebral palsy are on the rise among the babies saved.

headline: The Montreal Protocol, a Little Treaty That Could
text: Here is a remarkable fact about global warming: It might be twice as bad right now were it not for a treaty negotiated by a conservative American president, for an entirely different purpose, based on motives no one has ever quite understood.

headline: An Evolutionary Twist and a New Role for Drones
text: Congratulations to “science,” named by Merriam-Webster as its 2013 Word of the Year after searches for the term on its website jumped 176 percent. The word “does lurk behind a lot of big stories that we as a society are grappling with,” John Morse, president of Merriam-Webster, told The Christian Science Monitor.

headline: U.S. Ends Bailout of G.M., Selling Last Shares of Stock
text: Updated, 8:52 p.m. | The government bailout of General Motors ended on Monday with the Treasury Department’s announcement that it had sold its final shares of G.M. stock.

headline: The Male Koala’s Hefty Come-Hither Call
text: Based on their size, male koalas should have a mating call that sounds like a human baby’s cry. But the call is actually closer in pitch to an elephant’s rumble.

headline: Strong Week for Broadway’s Carole King Show, Still in Previews
text: The Carole King songlist in “Beautiful,” the new Broadway musical about Ms. King’s early years as a singer, has been drawing strong numbers of fans and others in the show’s first weeks of preview performances. The production had its best ticket sales yet last week, grossing $814,141 for eight performances, or 80 percent of the maximum possible amount, according to box-office data released on Monday by the Broadway League.

headline: Composers Redeemed From Oblivion
text: Consumers will buy generic or obscure brands if the cost is lower or the quality rivals that of an established product. But the 18th-century Scottish music publisher Robert Bremner wasn’t willing to take a chance with the little-known composer Domenico Gallo, publishing his 12 Trio Sonatas as those of Giovanni Pergolesi, a name-brand composer.

headline: A Magic Wand, Fluidly Sliding Through Genres
text: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra’s concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening was mainly mellow and mellifluous, with lovely works by Handel and Mozart, and even subdued for a time, with Irving Fine’s “Serious Song.” But halfway through, it ran delightfully amok, when Martin Frost — the soloist for the evening, in a superb performance of Mozart’s sublime Clarinet Concerto — broke loose in an encore.

headline: A Closer Look at Tornadoes in a Human-Heated Climate
text: I’m slow blogging these days, given the constraints that come with balancing teaching, journalism, family life and (these days) my music. I apologize for the delay here:

headline: Teachers Tell Us How to Fix Science and Math
text: There was some good news today for New York City high school students interested in computers — the city’s Department of Education announced it would spend $1 million in public and private money to train 120 teachers in computer science and coding. Dozens of new computer science classes taught by newly trained teachers will open in high schools across the city next fall, and Chancellor Dennis Walcott said they would eventually expand to elementary and middle schools.

headline: Unlikely Pairings Can Lead to Surprises
text: The Frick Collection’s Music Room, which seats just 175, is an ideally intimate space for chamber music. This is especially so when the performers are as excellent as the brilliant young German violinist Augustin Hadelich and the fine British pianist Charles Owen, who played a memorable recital there on Sunday afternoon, a highlight of the Frick’s valued concert series, now in its 75th-anniversary season.

headline: A Showy Beetle That Befriends Ants
text: A newly discovered beetle species from the lowland rain forests of French Guiana coexists with ants. The colorful insect belongs to the Pseudomorphini tribe, a family of beetles known to live among ant species. Called Guyanemorpha spectabilis, the beetle’s large size and rich colors make it stand out in comparison with its dully colored relatives in the Western Hemisphere.

headline: Obama and the Doomsayers
text: The sudden resurgence of liberal optimism about Obamacare — the subject of my Sunday column — has included some “I told you so’s” directed at those members of the D.C. media inner ring who declared Obama’s presidency potentially finished, ruined, kaput, during the recent cascade of bad news and polls. Over at The New Republic, Alec MacGillis weaves two other potentially Obama-friendly developments (the decent jobs numbers, and the quasi-deal with Iran) into an argument that doomsaying is simply ridiculous on its face:

headline: Science Bookshelf
text: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH  by Malcolm Gladwell. Little Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of “The Tipping Point” and “Outliers.” (1)

headline: Science of Vitamins, Rights for Chimps, Driving While Mending
text: You probably take them every day, but do you know what vitamins really do? Can an ape be declared a person — legally speaking? When should you get back behind the wheel after breaking a bone?

headline: More Helpful Fatty Acids Found in Organic Milk
text: Whole milk from organic dairies contains far more of some of the fatty acids that contribute to a healthy heart than conventional milk, scientists are reporting.

headline: Palliative Care Shortage (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: German Coalition Hangs on a Vote by One Party
text: KAMEN, Germany — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative Christian Democrats and their center-left Social Democratic rivals may have announced an agreement last month for a new coalition government for Germany, but there is still one obstacle left to clear: an up-or-down vote this week on the deal by all 474,820 members of the Social Democrats.

headline: High Court Weighs Air Safety vs. Pilot’s Reputation
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday  tried to find the right balance between air safety and a pilot’s reputation, with several justices taking an unusually active role in framing the issues to be decided by the court.

headline: SAC Reaches Deal to Sell Reinsurance Firm
text: The billionaire trader Steven A. Cohen is one step closer to converting his onetime $15 billion hedge fund into a family office after a tentative deal to sell a reinsurance firm he formed in 2012.

headline: Torre Tips Cap on Way to Hall
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The cuffs on the sleeves of Joe Torre’s dress shirt Monday were monogrammed with his signature — just Joe, no last name needed, a symbol of his status. But the championship ring he chose for his career valedictory suggested something deeper.

headline: New Albums by R. Kelly and Parmalee
text: R. KELLY

headline: Negotiators Reach Compromise on Defense Bill
text: WASHINGTON — House and Senate negotiators reached final agreement Monday on a Pentagon policy bill that would strengthen protections for military victims of sexual assault and keep the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, open over President Obama’s strenuous objections, as Congress rushed to wrap up work for the year.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Africa, Ukraine, Central African Republic and Syria.

headline: From Plato, Philosophy Manipulated
text: If you are looking for mindless entertainment, you may want to skip “The Republic, or My Dinner With Socrates.”

headline: NBC Says It Will Put On a Show, Again
text: The enormous ratings for last week’s live version of “The Sound of Music,” which reached 18.6 million viewers, have NBC’s top entertainment executive pushing the button on a follow-up.

headline: A Fed Dissident on Policy and Transparency
text: Charles I. Plosser, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, who will become a voting member of the Fed’s policy-making committee in 2014, spoke with a small group of reporters in Philadelphia last week about his view of the economy, why he doesn’t think the Fed should taper its bond-buying campaign, and why he intends to continue airing his disagreements with the Fed’s leaders.

headline: In Performance: Fiona Shaw
text: Fiona Shaw performs an excerpt from Samuel Taylor Coleridge’s 18-century poem, “The Rime of the Ancient Mariner.” The show is at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: Dec. 6-8, 2013
text: On Sunday, CNN presented Global Lessons on Guns, which explored gun control in other countries. Compared to other wealthy nations, in 2009, America had six times as many gun homicides per 100,000 people as Canada, 16 times as many as Germany, and 33 times as many as England and Wales. Why?

headline: A Savory Apple Tart Revives the Party
text: The cocktail party season is upon us, and with it a barrage of cheese and crackers in place of dinner. Not that there’s anything wrong with cheese and crackers. It’s just that after the third party or so, my enthusiasm for even the ripest artisanal cave-aged wedge starts to wane.

headline: Decoding a Tsunami’s Source
text: In the powerful earthquake off Japan in 2011, the size of the destructive tsunami it spawned caught scientists by surprise. But they soon learned why the waves were so large: measurements showed that part of the seafloor along the fault moved as much as 50 meters, or 55 yards, to the east, displacing an enormous amount of water.

headline: Considering the Humanity of Nonhumans
text: What is a person?

headline: A Life Interrupted by Viewers
text: LONDON — For a while, you forget that you are deep inside the galleries of the Victoria & Albert Museum. There’s the unmade bed with fancy sheets and the sound of running water from behind a closed door. A cigar sits in a custom-made ashtray. Books by Ruskin and Foucault line an aesthete’s shelves. The scene, you soon learn, is part of the latest installation by the cross-disciplinary artists Michael Elmgreen and Ingar Dragset.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Protesting Google’s Shuttle, and Going Inside Samsung’s Testing Labs
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Vitamins’ Old, Old Edge
text: In 1602, a Spanish fleet was sailing up the Pacific coast of Mexico when the crew became deathly ill. “The first symptom is pain in the whole body that makes it sensitive to touch,” wrote Antonio de la Ascensión, a priest on the expedition. “Purple spots begin to cover the body, especially from the waist down; then the gums become so swollen that the teeth cannot be brought together, and they can only drink, and finally they die all of a sudden, while talking.”

headline: Memoir of a Stroke: Petals Fall, and Words Fail
text: Read that an actress has made a play out of her own experiences as a stroke survivor, and you might presume it’s a pity-me monologue or self-congratulatory piece about overcoming adversity. But “Struck,” a work with that pedigree at Here Arts Center, defies those expectations. Instead, it is a bracing sort of stage poetry, an almost hallucinatory assemblage of dreams, fears and memories. It’s an effort to capture the experience of a stroke and a recovery, not as they would have been observed by a second party, but from the inside.

headline: Planting Mysteries and Clues
text: Images from the work of the artists Michael Elmgreen and Ingar Dragset.

headline: Clots Tied to Heart Pump Open Debate on Risks Patients Face in Trials
text: A new report showing an increase in blood clots associated with a popular heart device is dividing experts over whether a clinical trial of the implant is potentially too risky for patients.

headline: China to End Loophole in Child Rape Law, Experts Say
text: For 16 years, children’s rights advocates have called on the Chinese government to do away with a law that allows men who have sex with girls under 14 years of age, the legal age of consent, to receive a more lenient punishment than those convicted of raping older girls or women if they can “prove” that the child was paid or otherwise compensated for sex.

headline: Accidents on Roads Not Taken
text: In “Lost and Found,” the most haunting story in Russell Banks’s erratic new collection, a married and middle-aged plumbing and heating supplier named Stanley meets — or, rather, remeets — a pretty brunette at a convention at the Marriott Hotel in Miami. He “knows her from some other crowded room” but can’t immediately place her. Then he realizes that she’s the same woman, Ellen, he had ended up with in a hotel room years before.

headline: New York’s Full-Court Bust
text: The Knicks and Nets have shown that they cannot produce a championship caliber professional basketball team, and William C. Rhoden says it's time the fans stay home.

headline: Rule That Curbs Bank Risk-Taking Nears Approval
text: Updated, 12:44 p.m. | Wall Street is entering an uncertain new era as the rule that has come to symbolize Washington’s efforts to rein in financial risk-taking finally takes hold.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: New York’s Full-Court Bust
text: The Knicks and the Nets have shown that they cannot produce a championship-caliber professional basketball team, and now it’s time the fans stay home.

headline: Credit Suisse Moves Star Analyst to Investment Banking Side
text: For 12 years, Howard Chen analyzed the world of investment banking at Credit Suisse. Now the well-respected analyst is moving across the bank to become an investment banker.

headline: Paul Walker Memorial Draws Thousands
text: Over the weekend, Paul Walker fans and mourners gathered at the Santa Clarita, Calif., crash site where the “Fast & Furious” star lost his life.

headline: States Found to Shift Funds From Antismoking Efforts
text: Despite billions of dollars nationwide from tobacco taxes and settlements with manufacturers more than a decade ago, only two states are poised to meet federal recommendations for tobacco prevention spending during the 2014 fiscal year, an alliance of advocacy groups said in a report issued on Monday.

headline: The Sweet Caress of Cyberspace
text: For a while I worried that my father was having a thing with his GPS.

headline: Support, and a Smile, for Same-Sex Marriage
text: EVER since the movie “My Big Fat Greek Wedding” became a hit, the idea of stringing colorful words between “My” and “Wedding” as a humorous device has become a meme, as attested by examples like “My Big Fat Gypsy Wedding,” “My Big Gay Italian Wedding” and “My Small Italian Shotgun Wedding.”

text: For over a century, there has been no more sheepish, if reliable, self-defense than this for the tardy New York City traveler: The train was late. There was nothing I could do.

headline: After Mandela, a Test at the Polls for His Party
text: DIEPSLOOT, South Africa — Isaac Makhura gestured toward the squalid sprawl of shacks outside his house in this informal settlement, where some of the country’s most desperate people live. Was it any wonder, he said, that he no longer had any qualms about voting against the African National Congress, the party of his entire family for three generations?

headline: If a Story Is Viral, Truth May Be Taking a Beating
text: Truth has never been an essential ingredient of viral content on the Internet. But in the stepped-up competition for readers, digital news sites are increasingly blurring the line between fact and fiction, and saying that it is all part of doing business in the rough-and-tumble world of online journalism.

headline: Nebraska: Candidate Quits Congressional Race
text: Pete Festersen, a Democratic candidate for Congress in Nebraska, ended his campaign on Monday, two months after saying he would run because of voter anger over the Republican-led shutdown of the federal government. He told The Omaha World-Herald that he was leaving the race because it was not the right timing for him and his family. Mr. Festersen was running against Lee Terry, a Republican who has held his seat since 1999. Republicans said that Mr. Festersen’s decision signaled that Democrats were worried about losing support in the 2014 election because of problems with the rollout of the health care law.

headline: Print and Digital Books

headline: Williams Is Set to Return, and Chandler Is Preparing To
text: They have been glaring in their absence, two standout players who have sat and watched, and grimaced, as their respective teams, the Nets and the Knicks, have combined to outdo each other in displays of bad basketball.

headline: Argentina: Looting Spreads as Police Officers Stage Strikes
text: Strikes by police officers demanding higher salaries opened the way for looting in cities across Argentina over the weekend. Police officers in 14 of the country’s 23 provinces have staged work stoppages in recent days, local news media said. Some of the strikes have been settled with agreements for pay increases, but officers of at least nine police departments were still protesting on Monday afternoon. One person died during looting in the city of Concordia, on the border with Uruguay, on Sunday night, raising the death toll linked to the chaos to three. Thousands of federal troops have been deployed to the provinces, according to the Security Ministry and Argentina’s national news agency. Government officials accused opposition politicians of fomenting the new wave of looting, but some analysts criticized the focus of the government’s efforts to reduce poverty. “There is still a nucleus that remains impoverished, that sees nothing positive on the horizon,” said Carlos F. De Angelis, a sociologist at the University of Buenos Aires.

headline: Nebraska Democrat Drops Challenge for House Seat
text: A Democratic candidate for Congress in Nebraska ended his campaign on Monday, just two months after announcing that he would enter the race because of voter anger over the Republican-led shutdown of the federal government.

headline: Bill Porter, an Exceptional Salesman Who Inspired a Film, Dies at 81
text: Bill Porter, an Oregon door-to-door salesman who plied his trade for decades despite having severe cerebral palsy, and whose story inspired an Emmy-winning television film starring William H. Macy, died last Tuesday in Gresham, Ore. He was 81.

headline: Art Basel | Matthew Stone
text: Scenes from "Love Focused Like a Laser," Matthew Stone's opera performed by the pool of the Shore Club in Miami.

headline: Scholarship and Politics: The Case of Noam Chomsky
text: It’s not often that you get a public confirmation of views you’ve been pushing for years. But that’s what happened to me last week when I attended the 2013 John Dewey lectures given by Noam Chomsky under the auspices of the Columbia University philosophy department.

headline: Protests Continue in Downtown Kiev
text: Tens of thousands were gathered at Independence Square in Kiev for antigovernment protests on Sunday night.

headline: How Mandela Shifted Views on Freedom of Markets
text: When you think about Nelson Mandela, you probably think about freedom — free people, free country, free speech. What may be overshadowed by Mr. Mandela’s extraordinary legacy was his complicated journey to support free markets and a free economy.

headline: The Science and Art of Science Writing
text: I blame a rattlesnake for my career.

headline: 35 and Single
text: An Argentine shares her intimate search for love and the answer to this question: To be happy, should she settle down or remain a free spirit?

headline: Cerberus, Hamstrung in Efforts to Sell Firearm Maker, Tries New Tack
text: Shortly after 1 a.m. on a day nearly a year ago, Cerberus Capital Management announced that it planned to sell its gun manufacturing company, the Freedom Group, after the deadly school shooting in Connecticut four days earlier.

headline: Eleanor Parker, 91, Dies; Oscar Nominee Was in ‘Sound of Music’
text: Eleanor Parker, who was nominated three times for a best-actress Oscar but whose best-known role was a supporting one, as the marriage-minded baroness in “The Sound of Music,” died on Monday in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 91.

headline: ‘35 and Single’
text: Over the past 10 years, I’ve been compulsively filming everyone and everything for no particular reason. All my love stories and breakups have been recorded and systematically kept.

headline: Macy’s and Barneys Among Stores to Post Shoppers’ ‘Bill of Rights’
text: Shoppers will find an unusual addition to the traditional decorations at Macy’s, Barneys New York and other major stores this holiday season: a “Customers’ Bill of Rights” that addresses racial profiling.

headline: Thinking for the Future
text: We’re living in an era of mechanized intelligence, an age in which you’re probably going to find yourself in a workplace with diagnostic systems, different algorithms and computer-driven data analysis. If you want to thrive in this era, you probably want to be good at working with intelligent machines. As Tyler Cowen puts it in his relentlessly provocative recent book, “Average Is Over,” “If you and your skills are a complement to the computer, your wage and labor market prospects are likely to be cheery. If your skills do not complement the computer, you may want to address that mismatch.”

headline: The Customers’ Bill of Rights
text: The document, to be displayed by Macy’s, Barneys New York and other major stores in the city, outlines rights drawn from existing store policies prohibiting racial profiling.

headline: A Player With a Cause, but Without a Team
text: CHADDS FORD, Pa. — Royce White opened his front door and loomed there for a moment, all 6 feet 8 inches of him.

headline: Before the Battles and the Protests, the Chains
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — From a certain spot here on Dexter Avenue, a person can see the place where Jefferson Davis was inaugurated as president of the Confederacy, the church where a young Martin Luther King Jr. rose to prominence and the corner where Rosa Parks got on the bus.

headline: New York State Hospital Data Exposes Big Markups, and Odd Bargains
text: Just how expensive is your hospital? In New York, the answer may lie in a trove of hospital cost data newly posted online by the State Health Department.

headline: As Miller Is Kept Out, His Fame Only Grows
text: For the sixth time in 10 years, Marvin Miller was not elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame on Monday. Depending on your rooting interest, that is bad news or good news.

headline: A Breakthrough Agreement at Risk
text: President Obama and President Hassan Rouhani of Iran both spent time last weekend trying to sell the Iran nuclear deal to skeptics among their constituents. In Mr. Obama’s case, that meant addressing pro-Israel supporters at the Saban Center for Middle East Policy, a Washington think tank. Mr. Rouhani’s speech to a university audience in Tehran was televised nationally. While either side could undermine the November interim agreement, and with it the best chance in 30 years for a genuine thaw in Iranian-American relations, the more serious threat seems to be on the American side.

headline: What Washington Gives New York: Added Strain on the Social Safety Net
text: To visit Luz Delgado in her apartment high at the top of a prewar building on Walton Avenue in the Bronx is, after a peculiar fashion, to travel to a knife’s edge of worry.

headline: A Season for Sales Taxes
text: On Cyber Monday this month, a big day for online shopping, the Supreme Court quietly cleared the way for states to begin collecting some $13 billion in sales taxes that go uncollected each year on Internet purchases. That development creates an important opening for hard-pressed states to update their sales-tax codes broadly.

headline: Health Care Exchange Is Vastly Improved, Users Say
text: MIAMI — After two months of false starts, error messages and pleas for patience from the once-hobbled federal online health care exchange, Karen Egozi, the chief executive of the Epilepsy Foundation of Florida, watched on Monday as counselors navigated the website’s pages with relative ease.

headline: Fairer Policing in Suffolk County
text: Five years after the killing of Marcelo Lucero, an Ecuadorean immigrant, fueled an outcry in Suffolk County, N.Y., the Justice Department and the county police department have reached a tentative agreement to settle an investigation of discriminatory policing in immigrant communities there.

headline: Bob Dylan’s Discordant Notes
text: Last month, France presented Bob Dylan with its highest civilian prize, the Legion of Honor. At the ceremony, the French culture minister gushed about how Mr. Dylan had  inspired a whole generation to push for peace and civil rights, about how he was inspired by Verlaine and Rimbaud in his fight for justice and freedom.

headline: Stopping Bloodshed in the Central African Republic Amid Ghosts of Genocide
text: UNITED NATIONS — The word genocide sends shivers down the spines of United Nations diplomats, resurrecting the memory of the world body’s failure to stem massacres in Rwanda nearly 20 years ago and, before that, in Bosnia.

headline: A Child of Foster Care Struggles to Defeat the Odds
text: It happened in the bed right next to hers.

headline: Ex-Clinton Aide Expected to Join Obama
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, after a rocky year that leaves him at the lowest ebb of his presidency, is bringing into his White House circle the longtime Democratic strategist John D. Podesta, a former chief of staff for President Bill Clinton.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Smarts and Feelings, Vying for Attention
text: “The (Curious Case of the) Watson Intelligence” probably seemed like a real dazzler when it was in the mind of its author, the playwright Madeleine George. But like many newfangled inventions that seem spectacular in blueprint form — good luck with those creepy-looking drones, Amazon! — the play now chugging across the stage at Playwrights Horizons too often sputters and stalls, falling victim to its own grand ambitions.

headline: Higher Calling
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — There was a brief time in my household where I had to lock up the MAGIC MARKERs. The Girl was 3 years old, and she was so enamored of the colors and what she could do with them that it became clear to me that she needed close supervision.

headline: The Berkeley Model
text: Fred Wiseman is the grand old man of documentary filmmaking. Over the course of his long career, he has made 41 movies, the vast majority of them documentaries. They tend to share certain traits. They are often quite long. They rely entirely on dialogue: Wiseman never uses narration in his documentaries. And they often focus on institutions. Wiseman has done films about a mental hospital (“Titicut Follies”), a police precinct (“Law and Order”), and a high school (“High School”). Some of his films have the force of an exposé; others impart the documentary equivalent of a big wet kiss.

headline: Real Basketball Moms of Kentucky
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Michelle Green brings a billboard-size poster of her son’s head to his basketball games and has been known to cheer so aggressively that she has been thrown out of the gym. Susie Walker-Byrd has switched her son’s high school three times to accommodate his basketball dreams. Carmelita Clay is convinced that her son should be on national television because of his basketball skills.

headline: The End of Cash
text: Despite digital alternatives, most holiday shoppers this year are wielding credit cards, debit cards and cash. Is there a better way?

headline: New York City Subpoenas Secret Tapes by Police Officer
text: New York City lawyers have subpoenaed documents and tape recordings used by a journalist who wrote a book about a New York City police officer who disclosed the manipulation of crime reports at his Brooklyn precinct.

headline: Playing for Now or Future, Giants Face Complications
text: Since their loss to Dallas on Nov. 24, the Giants have been destined for an ignominious exit from the N.F.L. playoff chase. Sunday’s defeat in San Diego only made it official, a sloppy and fitting pratfall in a mess of a season that dawned with six successive losses.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 10, 2013
text: “The military was demonstrating its loyalty to Kim Jong-un, and Kim Jong-un was demonstrating his loyalty to the military.”

headline: Intersection: Fordham Road in the Bronx
text: Terrance Burke, 24, says his simple style is “always more than what it seems.”

headline: Jets Need Consistency and Help to Move On
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It is Week 15 for the Jets, which means that they are 6-7, coming off a victory and preparing to head south for a game that will boost — or destroy — their faint playoff hopes.

headline: Buses and Trains Are Foundation of Plan to Get Ticket Holders to the Super Bowl
text: SECAUCUS, N.J. — Next year’s Super Bowl will be the first to be played in an uncovered stadium in a cold-weather region. Organizers, who hope it will be the Super Bowl of mass transit, announced plans on Monday that they said would use buses and rails to move more people to and from the game than for any Super Bowl before.

headline: Housing Squeeze
text: Demand for affordable housing has grown while the supply has remained stagnant.

headline: Newtown Massacre Prompts More Vigilance in Schools and Elsewhere
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — Every morning Sgt. Edward Weihe walks into his office here and sifts through the police blotter to see what calls came in overnight. An interesting shift for a town’s police department can look blasé when reduced to paper forms: suspicious people outside buildings, vandalism, juvenile arrests.

headline: Joseph Napolitan, Pioneering Campaign Consultant, Dies at 84
text: Joseph Napolitan, a campaign consultant whose use of polling and media advertising heralded the rise of independent strategists like himself and the waning power of party organizations in the management of American political campaigns, died on Dec. 2 in Agawam, Mass. He was 84.

headline: Ukrainian Protesters Struggle to Keep Police and Cold at Bay
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Aleksandr Kvashenko looked up from making sandwiches in his tent encampment to realize that he had suddenly been encircled by hundreds of riot police officers. The camp’s usual contingent of burly men had sallied out to a nearby street as security forces began confronting protesters.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 9, 2013
Clues but No Full Account of Order That Turned a New Jersey Town Into a Parking Lot
text: It would seem a minor whodunit for a small suburb: On the first day of school in September, three access lanes leading from Fort Lee, N.J., streets to the George Washington Bridge were unexpectedly and mysteriously shut down. Cars backed up, the town turned into a parking lot, half-hour bridge commutes stretched into four hours, buses and children were late for school, and emergency workers could not respond quickly to the day’s events, which included a missing toddler, a cardiac arrest and a car driving into a building.

headline: Alderson Considers Best Way to Flesh Out Mets’ Rotation
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — As baseball’s annual winter meetings kicked into gear Monday, the Mets were busy working on complementary deals that would fill out their roster. Sandy Alderson, the no-longer-impoverished general manager, had three or four more needs to address, some trade chips available and roughly $10 million to $12 million to spend. He said that he had been so busy that he missed Sunday night’s episode of “Homeland.”

headline: Mayor Ousted in Colombia After Claims of Bungling
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The inspector general of Colombia on Monday ordered the mayor of Bogotá to be removed from office, saying that he had made serious mistakes in his handling of the botched transfer of garbage collection from private contractors to a government-run service.

headline: Snowy Owls to Be Trapped Instead of Shot at New York Area Airports
text: Airport officials in New York are starting a program to trap and relocate snowy owls after reports that the birds were being killed with a shotgun at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: Delay Foreseen in Removing Syrian Chemicals
text: The leader of the global monitoring group that is helping oversee the eradication of Syria’s chemical weapons arsenal raised the strong possibility on Monday of a delay in the timetable, saying it would be “quite difficult” to meet a deadline three weeks from now for transporting the most dangerous materials out of the country by sea.

headline: Outfield Full, Yanks Seek Pitching and Infield Help
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — With an off-season spending binge behind him, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman arrived at baseball’s winter meetings Monday afternoon having many lesser roster issues still unresolved.

headline: Stan Tracey Dies at 86; Helped British Jazz Emerge From American Shadow
text: Stan Tracey, a pianist and composer who was one of the most highly regarded jazz musicians in Britain and a mentor to numerous younger players, died on Dec. 6. He was 86.

headline: Cost vs. Charges in Neonatal Care
text: Costs and charges for admissions vary widely among New York hospitals, but their markups are often huge.

headline: Texas Conservative Steve Stockman to Challenge Senator John Cornyn
text: WASHINGTON — In a surprise move, Representative Steve Stockman of Texas, a conservative,  filed just before the Monday evening deadline to challenge Senator John Cornyn, two-term incumbent, in next year’s Texas Republican primary.

headline: China Everbright to Try Again for Public Offering
text: HONG KONG — China Everbright Bank is hoping the third time will be the charm.

headline: Rethinking the Idea of a Basic Income for All
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”
