text: severity •\sə-ˈver-ə-te\• noun

headline: Video of Violent Hazing in Paramilitary Unit Stirs Dismay in China
text: A video of paramilitary troops being badly beaten in a hazing ritual has gone viral on Chinese websites this week, exposing a rarely seen side of the country’s security forces.

headline: China Is Tied to Spying on European Diplomats
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Computer breaches at the foreign ministries of the Czech Republic, Portugal, Bulgaria, Latvia and Hungary have been traced to Chinese hackers.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (CBS) THE VICTORIA’S SECRET FASHION SHOW Earthly beauties like Adriana Lima, Alessandra Ambrosio, Lily Aldridge, Lindsay Ellingson, Karlie Kloss, Doutzen Kroes and Behati Prinsloo don angel wings and skimpies — including a gem-encrusted piece said to be worth $10 million, designed by Mouawad and worn by Candice Swanepoel — to strut the runway at the 69th Regiment Armory in Manhattan in this extravaganza, taped (twice, to get every angle just right) on Nov. 13. Taylor Swift, above in foreground; Fall Out Boy; a Great Big World; and Neon Jungle serenade the models in segments titled “British Invasion,” “Birds of Paradise,” “Parisian Nights,” “Shipwrecked,” “Snow Angels” and “Pink Network.”

headline: World Bids Farewell in the Land Mandela Freed
text: SOWETO, South Africa — For a day, the world came to Nelson Mandela’s adopted hometown. There were celebrities: Bono, Naomi Campbell, Charlize Theron. There were kings-in-waiting: Crown Prince Haakon of Norway and Crown Prince Felipe of Spain. There were more presidents and prime ministers than at just about any other setting outside a United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Obama, George W. Bush and Hillary Clinton Share Flight to South Africa
text: JOHANNESBURG — President Obama, his predecessor, and the woman who might be his successor crossed the Atlantic together Monday in an example of extended bipartisan togetherness to pay tribute to Nelson Mandela at a memorial service on Tuesday.

headline: Women’s Voices Go Unheard Within Walls of Ahmedabad Ghetto
text: AHMEDABAD, Gujarat — On a hot October morning, an intense discussion was waging between three women in a nondescript beauty salon in the Juhapura locality of Ahmedabad, the city’s largest Muslim ghetto.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Dec. 10
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | $15 Wage in Fast Food Stirs Debate on Effects
text: In “$15 Wage in Fast Food Stirs Debate on Effects,” Steven Greenhouse reports on the competing opinions of how a large wage increase would affect the fast-food industry.

headline: Chinese Activist’s Computer Did Not Have Spyware, N.Y.U. Says
text: Chen Guangcheng, the blind legal advocate who made headlines last year after escaping house arrest in China, can apparently rest assured: The Apple smartphone and tablet he was given upon his arrival in New York by Christian activists do not contain spyware.

headline: Stumbling Block for Turkey’s Missile Deal With China
text: China’s agreement with Turkey to sell it more than $3 billion worth of air-defense missile systems may soon run into a deal-breaker: the United States Congress.

headline: Thai Premier Rejects Demands That She Quit
text: BANGKOK — Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra on Tuesday rejected demands by antigovernment protesters that she step aside before elections she called in response to weeks of demonstrations.

headline: What Anesthesia Can Teach Us About Consciousness
text: More than a decade ago, a 43-year-old woman went to a surgeon for a hysterectomy. She was put under, and everything seemed to be going according to plan, until, for a horrible interval, her anesthesia stopped working. She couldn’t open her eyes or move her fingers. She tried to breathe, but even that most basic reflex didn’t seem to work; a tube was lodged in her throat. She was awake and aware on the operating table, but frozen and unable to tell anyone what was happening.

headline: Why Are Americans Staying Put?
text: Economists admire Americans for many traits: our profound respect for property rights, our tendency to forgo vacation days, our ingenious methods of mass-producing “food.” Another important attribute is our willingness to move, between houses, between states and across the country. Some economists believe our inborn rootlessness makes the country’s work force more dynamic and strengthens our economy’s growth. Imagine how much worse off the country might be if the 49ers had decided against making the trek to California or the sharecroppers chose to stay in the South.

headline: Photographing the White House From the Inside
text: Yoichi Okamoto was the first official White House photographer, serving under President Lyndon B. Johnson from late 1963 to January 1969. Known as Oke, he was born in Yonkers in 1915 and was a still and motion-picture photographer in the Army during World War II. He then worked for the United States Information Agency and met L.B.J. while he was vice president, photographing his trip to Berlin in 1961. Johnson liked him, and Mr. Okamoto accompanied him on other overseas trips.

headline: ScienceTake: Angry Birds
text: Mockingbirds furiously protect their nests against intruding cowbirds, with mixed results.

headline: Who Are Your Heroes?
text: When Nelson Mandela died last week, millions of people around the world mourned the loss of a global hero. In the video above, South Africans speak about how much Mr. Mandela meant to them.

headline: In Search of What He’s Owed
text: Speaking of senior scams, as we recently were, a phony magazine sweepstakes serves as the spark plug in the new movie “Nebraska.”

headline: In a Bird’s Nest, an Animal Behavior Puzzle
text: Sometimes the scientists who study animal behavior solve puzzles and other times they uncover new ones. The war between mockingbirds and cowbirds is a case in point.

headline: Volvo to Sell Machine Rental Business for $1.1 Billion
text: LONDON – The Volvo Group has agreed to sell its construction machinery rental business to the California-based private equity firm Platinum Equity for 7.2 billion Swedish kronor.

headline: New York Today: Snowstorm
text: Updated 12:01 p.m.

headline: Times Minute | Movement in Congress
text: Also in the Minute, tardy notes for commuters and a wide-open Oscar race.

headline: Times Minute |  Movement in Congress Ahead of Recess
text: In the Video

headline: Daily Report: Online Attacks on European Diplomats Are Tied to China
text: Computer breaches at the foreign ministries of the Czech Republic, Portugal, Bulgaria, Latvia and Hungary have been traced to Chinese hackers, Nicole Perlroth reports.

headline: Congress Avoids Reality, Again
text: AFTER almost six weeks of budget negotiations uncharacteristically devoid of histrionics and dire threats, a House-Senate conference committee gave birth Tuesday night — but only to a mouse.

headline: Delhi’s Popular Chief Minister Couldn’t Escape Anti-Congress Wave
text: NEW DELHI — On Sunday morning, a posse of journalists parked themselves outside Sheila Dikshit’s home in central Delhi. A gripping political narrative was taking shape elsewhere: Ms. Dikshit, the chief minister who had governed Delhi for 15 years, was trailing in her district to Arvind Kejriwal, a political debutant and the feisty leader of the 1-year-old Aam Aadmi Party.

headline: After Mandela
text: The world comes to a moral crossroads.

headline: Even Superwoman Can Have Back Problems
text: There are two kinds of people, my sister says. People with back problems, and people who don’t have back problems yet.

headline: Assessing Whether Entrepreneurs Should Get M.B.A.’s
text: Have you noticed how many universities are rushing to create entrepreneurship programs as part of their M.B.A. offerings? As The Wall Street Journal recently noted, the answer is quite a few. One might say better late than never — or even think that the traditional M.B.A. program is finally gaining some relevance and teaching people how to build a business. Think again.

headline: Despite Improving Indicators, Poll Finds Harsh View of Obama on Economy
text: Last week’s reports of hopeful economic indicators did nothing to improve the American public’s negative opinion of President Obama’s stewardship of the nation’s economy. However, while most Americans describe the economy as in bad condition, there has been a slight uptick in the number who view the nation’s fiscal circumstances positively, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: What’s in the Volcker Rule
text: Wall Street is entering an uncertain new era as the Volcker Rule — the regulation at the heart of Washington’s efforts to rein in financial risk-taking — takes hold, Ben Protess and Peter Eavis report in DealBook. The rule, a copy of which was reviewed by The New York Times, imposes some requirements that are tougher than the banks had wanted. Five federal agencies are expected to vote to approve it on Tuesday — though some might do so in private because of inclement weather in the Washington area. (One of them, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, has canceled its public meeting.)

headline: In Performance: Fiona Shaw of ‘Rime of the Ancient Mariner’
text: This week’s In Performance video is with Fiona Shaw, in an excerpt from a new staged reading of Samuel Taylor Coleridge’s 1798 poem “The Rime of the Ancient Mariner.” This scene features the passage that birthed the expression “albatross around your neck.” The show, directed by Phyllida Lloyd, continues through Dec. 22 at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: The Slang Patrol
text: Slang and colloquialisms have their place, for special effect or to deliberately convey an informal, conversational tone. But otherwise, they can seem trite or hackneyed, and can undercut the serious and literate tone we seek.

headline: Swiss Bank Becomes First to Participate in U.S. Tax Deal
text: LONDON – Valiant Bank, a small Swiss bank, became the first in Switzerland to say that it would sign up to a deal with the United States aimed at ending a three-year tax evasion dispute with Switzerland.

headline: Hedge Fund Seeks Higher Bid in Pharmaceutical Merger
text: Updated, 12:06 p.m. | LONDON – Elliott Management, the New York-based hedge fund founded by Paul Singer, urged the McKesson Corporation on Tuesday to sweeten its deal to acquire the German pharmaceutical wholesaler Celesio, saying its tender offer to acquire the outstanding shares of Celesio “substantially undervalues” the company.

headline: Jesus at the United Nations
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Solid Pace of Expansion Seen in China
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese economy is no longer as red-hot as it once was, but it remains solidly growing, judging by data released over the past few days.

headline: Rights Lawyer Among 4 Abducted in Syria; 2 Journalists Are Also Being Held
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Syrian human rights lawyer who was one of the most vocal early leaders of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad was abducted along with three colleagues in a suburb of Damascus, the Syrian capital, on Tuesday by masked men, according to antigovernment activists, who pointed fingers at an Islamist rebel faction that she had criticized.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Creatures of Comfort Sweater
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: On a Psychedelic Trip Known as ‘American Hustle’
text: The producers are going all-out for “American Hustle,” which had multiple exclusive screenings, Q&As and a splashy premiere at the Ziegfeld Theater in the last several days, all with attendant meet-and-greets and afterparties. The story, loosely based on the 1970s Abscam scandal, inspired period event design and details, like cocktails named the Combover (for Christian Bale’s egregious hairdo) and Lady Edith (for Amy Adams’s character) at the reception at Cipriani 42nd Street on Sunday evening.

headline: New G.M. Chief Is Company Woman, Born to It
text: DETROIT — Her father was a die maker for 39 years, one of the legions of employees who performed the gritty tasks that made General Motors the nation’s largest and most powerful auto company.

headline: In Our Pages: December 11
text: 1938: Paris Enjoys American Football

headline: Police Push Into Kiev Square as Crisis Grows
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Battalions of Ukrainian security forces early Wednesday stormed Independence Square, the central plaza in Kiev where protesters had been rallying against the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovich for more than two weeks.

headline: Updated Microsoft Photosynth Makes HDTV Look Low-Resolution
text: I recently visited the top of Mount Everest. Well, at least it felt like I did.

headline: Walkabout: The Rise of Dubai’s Sedate Sister; A Ground War Between Airlines
text: Abu Dhabi is gradually stepping out of Dubai’s shadow, as a destination in its own right. With a budding skyline and growing number of international museums and luxury apartments, expats and Emiratis are starting to flock in. (BBC)

headline: Europe Moves to Prohibit Some Deep-Sea Trawling
text: PARIS — The European Parliament on Tuesday sided with the fishing industry by voting against an overall ban on deep-sea trawling, but it agreed to restrict some of the worst excesses of the practice.

headline: Image of the Day: December 10
text: A demonstration on Human Rights Day in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: After Taking Big Step, Colts Stumble a Bit
text: After a 2-14 season in 2011, the Indianapolis Colts hired Ryan Grigson as their general manager, and his success was immediate. In 2012, the Colts made the playoffs and he was named executive of the year by two groups: Pro Football Weekly in conjunction with football writers, and The Sporting News.

headline: Obama Highlights at Mandela’s Memorial
text: In his speech, President Obama talked about how Nelson Mandela had inspired him.

headline: For This Audition, Acting Not Required
text: Christian Bale gained 50 pounds to play a 1970s grifter in “American Hustle.” Robert Redford did tricky water stunts in “All Is Lost.” The cast of “12 Years a Slave” was subjected to countless period tortures. For actors, awards-caliber movies often mean feats of physical endurance. As his audition for the coming film “Lone Survivor,” Peter Berg’s adaptation of the true story of a Navy SEAL unit under attack in Afghanistan, Emile Hirsch had to hit the gym, six days a week at 6 a.m., for three months.

headline: South Africa Faces Its Future
text: In the shadow of Nelson Mandela’s death, four South Africans ponder a future without the man who inspired and set so many free.

headline: Paul Walker Crash Site Memorial Draws Thousands
text: Valencia, Calif. — Enrique Padron considered himself lucky. Among the thousands who attended Sunday’s informal tribute at the site where Paul Walker, a star of the multibillion-dollar “Fast and Furious” movie franchise, died in a crash on Nov. 30, Mr. Padron picked up an overlooked red fragment. Holding it in his left palm, he said he believed it to be a carbon fiber remnant from the 2005 Porsche Carrera GT in which Mr. Walker and his friend, Roger Rodas, had been driving.

headline: War of Words Over the Volcker Rule: A History
text: Everyone has an opinion about the Volcker Rule.

headline: Lucky Brand Apparel Sold to Leonard Green for $225 Million
text: Mid- to high-end fashion brands are finding themselves as acquisition targets. In the latest deal, the private equity firm Leonard Green & Partners agreed on Tuesday to buy Lucky Brand Jeans from the Fifth & Pacific Companies, the clothier formerly known as Liz Claiborne, for about $225 million.

headline: European Lawmakers Support Carbon Trading System
text: The European Parliament on Tuesday approved a rescue plan for the European Union’s system for trading carbon-emission credits. The lawmakers hope to revive prices for carbon credits, which have been so low that the system is creating few incentives for smokestack industries to cut back on their emissions of greenhouse gases.

headline: Joni Mitchell’s ‘Woodstock,’ by Heather Maloney and Darlingside
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the  website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: At the Finish Line on the Volcker Rule
text: Updated, 9:02 p.m. | Five years after the financial crisis, President Obama summoned regulators to the White House for an update on how they were changing the ways of Wall Street.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Webrooming’ Beats ‘Showrooming’
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Roots of Reconstruction
text: On Dec. 8, 1863, just two weeks after delivering the Gettysburg Address, President Lincoln gave his third State of the Union to Congress. In the 19th century, the State of the Union was called the Annual Message, and it was a written document rather than a speech. While much of this annual message was the usual laundry list of the administration’s foreign and domestic acts, at the end Lincoln turned to the progress of the war – and began to sketch the outlines of peace.

headline: Defective Breast Implant Sales Draw Prison Term for French Executive
text: PARIS — A court in Marseille, France, sentenced the founder of a French company on Tuesday to four years in prison for selling hundreds of thousands of defective breast implants in more than 65 countries.

headline: Oprah Winfrey Picks ‘Invention of Wings’ for Her Book Club
text: Oprah Winfrey has added a third selection to her revived book club, choosing “The Invention of Wings” by Sue Monk Kidd, Ms. Winfrey said on Tuesday.

headline: My I.V.F. Education
text: “Hello, Amy?” a young, excited voice said, lilting at the end.

headline: Wheelies: The Vision Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: More Dysfunction in Washington? Blame Geography.
text: House and Senate negotiators are nearing a modest budget deal to break the cycle of periodic fiscal crises that both parties say have hampered the economy. But for President Obama, the “grand bargain” remains elusive. That wasn’t always the case for Democratic presidents. In fact, some found it much easier to cut deals with Republican legislators.

headline: Linda Lavin to Star in New Nicky Silver Play
text: The team responsible for “The Lyons” — the playwright Nicky Silver, the actress Linda Lavin and the director Mark Brokaw — will reconvene this spring at the Vineyard Theater, where “The Lyons” ran before moving to Broadway in 2012, for Mr. Silver’s latest work, “Too Much Sun.” Previews begin on May 1; the play opens on May 20.

headline: With Filibuster Threat Gone, Senate Confirms Two Presidential Nominees
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate slowly began working its way through a backlog of presidential nominees on Tuesday now that Republicans are virtually powerless to block confirmations, approving a once-stalled judge to a powerful appeals court and a new director for the agency that oversees federal home lending.

headline: A Physical Toy With a Digital Counterpart
text: With the phenomenal success of Skylanders Swap Force and Disney Infinity, which melded physical toys with digital games, imitators were bound to follow.

headline: A Stripped-Down Look to Highlight Your iPhone
text: For some companies, less is more.

headline: Experiencing Butterflies
text: Dominic Harris, a British digital artist and designer, discusses his work at DesignMiami.

headline: Boeing Looks Around, and a State Worries
text: EVERETT, Wash. — Riveters once ruled here, as Boeing airplanes rolled off the line and into the sky from giant factories where rivers of aluminum were pounded into form and function. And Boeing, founded in nearby Seattle in 1916 in the era of the Sopwith Camel, returned the favor, building up the Puget Sound region as a blue-collar powerhouse from the 1940s through the commercial jet age. Almost half of the company’s 171,000 employees still call Washington State home.

headline: Times Minute | G.M.’s New Leader
text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | G.M.'s New Leader
text: Also on the Minute, world leaders honor Nelson Mandela and mockingbirds protect their nests against intruding cowbirds.

headline: Obama Reaches Out to Cuba’s Leader, but the Meaning May Elude Grasp
text: SOWETO, South Africa — President Obama shook hands with President Raúl Castro of Cuba on Tuesday, offering a friendly gesture freighted with symbolism to one of America’s most enduring Cold War foes.

headline: Chinese Professor Who Advocated Free Speech Is Fired
text: BEIJING — Officials at one of China’s most respected universities have reportedly fired an outspoken legal scholar for advocating free speech and for repeatedly calling on the government to abide by its own Constitution.

headline: La Scala Confirms Chailly Will Be Principal Conductor and Music Director
text: After months of speculation the Teatro alla Scala in Milan confirmed on Tuesday that Riccardo Chailly, the Milanese conductor, would become the opera house’s principal conductor in 2015 before becoming its music director in 2017. As music director Mr. Chailly will replace Daniel Barenboim, who is leaving at the end of 2014, two years before his contract was set to expire. A La Scala spokesman said no one would have the title of music director in the interim between Mr. Barenboim’s departure and Mr. Chailly’s assumption of the post.

headline: Crazy Ants
text: Watch them go.

headline: Justices Hear Case on Cross-State Pollution Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday in a knotty environmental case over how to hold states responsible for air pollution that drifts across their borders and causes harm in downwind states.

headline: In Store | For the New York Design Shop Kiosk, It’s Good to Be Greek
text: Hidden in a gritty upstairs loft amid SoHo’s multitude of megastores, Kiosk — the Spring Street object boutique founded in 2005 by the husband-and-wife team Marco ter Haar Romeny and Alisa Grifo — defiantly embraces the small-scale and the local. The couple travels through a different country each season to source what they call, with deadpan accuracy, “things from places.” And while their focus is on inexpensive everyday trinkets rather than contemporary design, the duo’s eye for clever packaging and typography (Grifo, a set designer, has worked at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum and Metropolis magazine) helps them gather the sort of whimsical, accidentally chic souvenirs you wish you’d brought back from Provence or Portugal yourself.

headline: ‘Fruitvale Station,’ Re-Edited
text: It’s already been a sweet awards ride for “Fruitvale Station,” a hit at Sundance that has gone on to collect trophies from the Gothams, the New York Film Critics Circle, the National Board of Review and a best-of-the-year mention from the American Film Institute. It’s the story of Oscar Grant III, who was killed by a transit officer in Oakland, Calif., in 2009. The film’s star, Michael B. Jordan,  spoke with Oprah Winfrey recently, and he and the film’s 27-year-old director, Ryan Coogler, were named to Time magazine’s list of young people changing the world.

headline: The Volcker Rule: Faults and Virtues
text: Regulators hope the rule, named for Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, can cut risks taken by banks, but tiny holes in the 71-page rule may leave those banks some wiggle room.

headline: Another Shuffle in Russian Ballet World as Scandal Fallout Continues
text: MOSCOW — A former star ballerina has resigned as artistic director of the Vaganova Ballet Academy in St. Petersburg and been hired by the city’s Mikhailovsky Theater in the latest fallout from the scandal that has rocked Russian classical dance since the acid attack on the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, last January.

headline: Three Ways to Improve Small-Business Lending
text: Last week, the House Small Business Committee met to examine the post-recession, small-business lending environment. Witnesses before the committee included representatives of credit unions, bankers, the Federal Reserve and private businesses involved in small-business lending and credit reporting. A summary of their testimony can be found in an interesting article by Kent Hoover.

headline: Changing of the Guard in a Traditionally Male Industry
text: The announcement that Mary T. Barra will become the first female chief executive of General Motors is more than a human resources changeup. It’s a nod to the changing times.

headline: Kennedy Center Names New Chief
text: Deborah F. Rutter, who as president of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra helped it navigate the financial shoals that have sunk other orchestras, will become the president of the Kennedy Center next fall, the center announced on Tuesday.

headline: The New, in Context, for Ear, Heart and Brain
text: From ancient Greece to the moon by way of Monteverdi, Mahler and Puccini: Wednesday evening’s concert by the Dolce Suono Ensemble at Roulette in Brooklyn drew a wide arc. Dolce Suono, which appeared there as part of the inventive Ear Heart Music series, is a Philadelphia-based chamber ensemble founded by the flutist Mimi Stillman that eloquently advocates for new music while placing it in a historical context.

headline: Political Fight on Farm Aid and Food Stamps Hits Home in the Delta
text: BELZONI, Miss. — Thomas Bond, a cotton grower whose onetime 8,500-acre partnership of farms received $4 million in federal subsidies in the last seven years, thinks that many residents in the surrounding Mississippi Delta need food stamps. But he says the program is too big and rife with fraud.

headline: A’s Have Been Harvard’s Most Common Grade for 20 Years
text: In the last few days, reports that Harvard’s most common grade is an “A” have  now gone viral. But despite the shocked-shocked! tone of some of the coverage, this is actually very old news.

headline: The Distraction of a Handshake in South Africa
text: Sometimes what happens on the sidelines of a main event attended by world leaders can steal a bit of the spotlight.

headline: The World After Filibuster Reform
text: By a vote of 56-38, the Senate on Tuesday confirmed Patricia Millett to the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals — thereby filling the 8-year vacancy created when John G. Roberts Jr. left the powerful court for a higher calling.

headline: Kenny Irwin’s Creations on View in Baltimore
text: For years, Southern Californians have flocked at Christmastime to the Palm Springs yard of Kenny Irwin Jr., to see his extensive “Robo Lights” holiday display. This year, East Coast residents have an opportunity to view the artist’s work with “Have Yourself a Happy Little Robotmas,” part of “Human, Soul and Machine: The Coming Singularity!” on view through August at the American Visionary Art Museum, or AVAM, in Baltimore.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Designers Turn to Jewelry
text: Perhaps it was the economics of shipping furniture as opposed to smaller, wearable items, but Design Miami seemed to have far more than its fair share of jewelry this year. In addition to the pieces by blue-chip artists like Alexander Calder and Moriko Mori at Louisa Guinness, there were amazing works by Gerd Rothman, like a necklace with fingerprints, at Ornamentum; cool vintage pieces by Gijs Bakker, a founder of Droog, including a brooch of a high jumper at Caroline Van Hoek; and colorful Op Art-inspired pieces by Carlos Cruz-Diez at Elizabetta Cipriani.

headline: Good Governance at G.M.
text: General Motors has navigated a smart route to succession. Daniel F. Akerson, who has run the company since mid-2010, is stepping down in January. Replacing him as chief executive is Mary Barra, who despite 33 years of service at the automaker, has mostly sidestepped the taint of prebankruptcy failures. G.M., freshly liberated from the government bailout, also on Tuesday appointed an independent chairman for good governance measure.

headline: Obama Shakes Hands With Castro
text: President Obama and President Raúl Castro of Cuba exchanged a handshake at Nelson Mandela’s memorial, raising questions over what the gesture could mean for ties between the United States and Cuba.

headline: Tough Competition for Original Scripts (and Cover Songs)
text: The conventional wisdom in Hollywood is that the only films to find surefire success at the box office are remakes and sequels, and this year has seen precious few exceptions. Buzzfeed helpfully ranks the top 15 original films, starting with the Oscar contender “Gravity” — the only original story in the Top 10 grosses of the year — and ending with another Oscar hopeful, “Prisoners” (the 50th-highest grosser).

headline: From Rebel to Statesman: Teaching About the Life of Nelson Mandela
text: What makes a leader great, and when exactly does the transformation take place? In this lesson students and teachers can follow the evolution of Nelson Mandela in archival articles from The New York Times, from his early years as a jailed dissident in apartheid South Africa to his death last week at the age of 95.

headline: Wilpon Says Mets Have ‘a Long Way to Go’
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — It was supposed to be a triumphant moment for the Mets, Curtis Granderson onstage smiling for photographs, holding his new, pinstriped No. 3 jersey, flanked by Jeff Wilpon and Sandy Alderson. Granderson was the biggest free-agent signing of Alderson’s tenure as the general manager. He was the newest face of the franchise, the cleanup hitter to team with David Wright.

headline: Snowden for Person of the Year, and Coverage of a Story That Just Won’t Quit
text: Some stories have legs: They just keep coming; they don’t fade away.

headline: The Medicare Part D Analogy
text: Responding to my weekend column, which gently pushed back against the sudden burst of liberal optimism about HealthCare.Gov, Ezra Klein gently pushes back against my point that Obamacare’s quest to enroll the young and healthy faces bigger hurdles than did its model, Romneycare, in Massachusetts:

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Multiparty System
Though Revenue Growth Is Slowing, States See More Budget Stability, Report Finds
text: While states are continuing to see modest progress in their struggle to dig out from the 2008 recession, the era of chronic budget instability and wholesale service cuts appears to have ended, according to a report released Tuesday by the National Association of State Budget Officers. The rate of revenue growth in 2014, however, is expected to be significantly lower than in 2013,  the report said.

headline: World Leaders Mourn Mandela
text: In a rare gathering, scores of leaders from around the world came together to pay tribute to Nelson Mandela at a national memorial service.

headline: Paris Auction of Native American Artifacts Goes Forward Despite U.S. Request
text: PARIS — A contested auction of artifacts from the Hopi and San Carlos Apache tribes went forward Monday, generating more than $757,000 in sales despite a request by United States officials to suspend the sale of the Native American items.

headline: After Chicken Is Spotted in Central Park, an Odyssey Begins
text: Marc Klein was walking his dog, Cocoa, last Wednesday morning in Central Park when he spotted something rustling in the fallen leaves near the park’s entrance at West 97th Street.

headline: Inside the Evolving Hotel Bathroom
text: I check into a lot of hotels — and one of the first things I check out is the guest-room bathroom. From no-frills to cushy, cramped to roomy, a hotel bathroom can be an oasis or an eyesore. There are those that are cheap and cheerful, and those that appear to be lit for police interrogations. Others are as slick and dark as nightclubs, more conducive to Do Not Disturb-sign passion than makeup application.

headline: Restaurant Report: Spork in Bend, Ore.
text: Spork, a Bend, Ore., restaurant that began as a food truck, is a precocious lovechild of sesame and pork. Jeff Hunt, an owner and the executive chef, developed the menu based on expeditions to places like Bangkok and the Yucatán; the result is dishes like spicy fried chicken with kimchi and fried catfish tacos with chile mayo.

headline: Hotel Review: Aloft Cleveland Downtown
text: Rates

headline: Square Roots | The Making of a Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show Look
text: Greg Kessler/Kessler Studio

headline: Losing Your Membership in the Frequent Flier Club
text: A case that was recently heard by the Supreme Court may have travelers wondering what exactly could get them removed from their frequent flier programs.

headline: Fantasy Football: Rookie Report, Part 2
text: We are continuing our fantasy football analysis of this year’s rookie class by looking at the top wide receivers and tight ends. There has only been one star emerging at either position, but there is plenty of potential for other players to get noticed as the season winds down.

headline: Cuomo Backs Plan to Ease Array of Tax Burdens and Faces a Fight
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday embraced a package of proposals to reduce the effects of property, estate and business taxes, setting the stage for a battle over revenue collection that is expected to dominate the New York State legislative session that begins next month.

headline: Canada Goose Sells Majority Stake to Bain Capital
text: Canada Goose, the maker of expensive winter jackets with distinctive red, white and blue arm patches, has sold a majority of the company to Bain Capital, the private equity firm.

headline: Show Us Your Scenes From Mandela’s Farewell
text: Tens of thousands of South African citizens and scores of foreign dignitaries are celebrating Nelson Mandela in his native country this week.

headline: The Latest Hotel Feature: A Smartphone
text: The new Viceroy New York has a novel amenity: a cellphone in every room.

headline: A Plan for a More Powerful Military That Costs Less
text: WASHINGTON – In October, the Army chief of staff, Gen. Ray Odierno, said that because of budget cuts, only two of the Army’s 42 combat brigades were ready for battle. In November, he warned members of the Senate Armed Services Committee that if the nation had to fight in the near term, “it is unlikely that the Army would be able to defeat an adversary quickly and decisively.”

headline: The Gun Report: December 10, 2013
text: Friday marked the 20th anniversary of a gun massacre on the Long Island Rail Road in New York that claimed six lives and left 19 wounded. On Dec. 7, 1993—six years before Columbine—Colin Ferguson, a 35-year-old Jamaican immigrant, boarded a commuter train during the evening rush hour armed with a nine-millimeter semiautomatic Ruger pistol and a small duffel bag jammed with ammunition. He opened fire as the train approached the Merillon Avenue Station.

headline: Scene City: ‘American Hustle’ Premiere
text: Stars like Christian Bale attended the premiere in New York, and the film’s disco themes carried through to the after party.

headline: Jane Austen Portrait Sold for $270,000
text: A watercolor portrait of Jane Austen commissioned in 1869 and retained by the Austen family fetched $270,600 at auction at Sotheby’s in London on Tuesday.

headline: Can Bhutan Achieve Hydropowered Happiness?
text: James Fahn, the executive director of the Internews Earth Journalism Network (featured here before), recently returned from a visit with other environmental journalists to Bhutan, where efforts to attain “gross national happiness” are running into obstacles as the country strives for democracy, prosperity and environmental protection. Here’s a “Your Dot” contribution from Fahn, who is also a lecturer at the University of California, Berkeley, Graduate School of Journalism and the author of “A Land on Fire“:

headline: Weighing Cord Blood Donation Against Private Banks
text: When I was pregnant with my first child, I noticed private (family) cord blood banking ads at every doctor’s office and web page I visited. My first inclination was to open my wallet and plead with them to save my child’s life from horrible diseases I would almost have preferred never to learn about. But the upfront expenses to bank my child’s cord blood would have exceeded the combined cost of the stroller, crib, changing table and nursing chair on my shopping list. Could cord blood banking possibly be that valuable?

headline: How Time Warner Could Benefit by Turning the Tables
text: Time Warner Cable could play Pac-Man. One plan being discussed, being acquired by smaller rival like Charter Communications, would create a highly indebted cable giant with a value including debt of more than $100 billion.

headline: Chocolate Trees for Christmas, a King’s Tipple and More
text: To Shop: Rustic Tableware With Italian Charm

headline: The New Jersey Traffic Conspiracy
text: Here are a few dots that are beginning to look suspiciously connected:

headline: Holiday Drinks From the Amateurs
text: Jennifer Steinhauer and Helene Cooper mix up their own versions of cold-weather cocktails.

headline: Seven Sentenced to Prison Over Deadly Bridge Collapse
text: Seven government officials and construction project managers have been sentenced to prison terms of up to 14 years in connection with the collapse of a bridge in Sichuan Province in July, the state news media reported.

headline: Pianist to Receive New Award From Chamber Society
text: What to give a beloved 90-year-old pianist? How about a fairly demanding international tour of birthday concerts and a new award from the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center? Menahem Pressler, who helped found the Beaux Arts Trio in 1955, will turn 90 on Dec. 16 — and he has been marking the milestone with a series of concerts in France and Germany.

headline: No Eggnog Allowed
text: TO: HELENE

headline: Acid-Suppressing Drugs Linked to Vitamin B12 Deficiency
text: People who use certain acid-suppressing drugs for two years or longer are at increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia, neurological problems or dementia, researchers reported on Tuesday.

headline: Not Much Snow, but Enough for a New York Record
text: There are some days when you wake up, hear the wind howling, see the snow falling and just know that New York City is in for a monstrous a storm.

headline: Republican Says Iran Deal Should Halt Uranium Enrichment
text: WASHINGTON — Laying down a marker, the Republican chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee said Tuesday that a follow-on nuclear accord with Iran should require that Tehran stop enriching uranium.

headline: A ‘Gravity’ Short for a Winter’s Day
text: Set in icy Greenland, “Aningaaq” is a short film made by Jonás Cuarón, the screenwriter (with his father, Alfonso) of “Gravity.” It’s a companion piece to the film, which never cuts away from the action in space centered on Dr. Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock).

headline: Walmart Names New Head of Foreign Operations
text: Two weeks after naming a new chief executive, Walmart announced on Tuesday that David Cheesewright, president of several overseas divisions,would soon take on all of the company’s international operations.

headline: Capitol Leaders Agree to a Deal on the Budget
text: WASHINGTON — House and Senate budget negotiators reached agreement Tuesday on a budget deal that would raise military and domestic spending over the next two years, shifting the pain of across-the-board cuts to other programs over the coming decade and raising fees on airline tickets to pay for airport security.

headline: Finance Chief of R.B.S. Resigns After 3 Months in Post
text: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland said Tuesday that Nathan Bostock resigned as chief financial officer after less than three months in the job.

headline: Scuffles Tuesday in Ukraine
text: Ukraine’s political crisis intensified as scuffles erupted between the riot police and protesters.

headline: Mary Barra, G.M.’s New Chief, Speaking Her Mind
text: Mary T. Barra, who was named the next chief executive of General Motors on Tuesday, visited The New York Times in November and talked with reporters and editors. What follows is an edited, condensed version of the interview.

headline: Ants to Keep Out of Your Pants
text: In last weekend’s magazine article about invasive ants in Texas, Jon Mooallem refers to the psychological torment that comes from feeling like something is crawling all over your body. Well, try watching the video above without getting squirmy and . . . yes, antsy. You might think these are regular old ants that happened to get worked up over something, but no, this is what they’re like all the time. They never go marching one by one.

headline: Q. & A. With Freeman Hrabowski
text: Freeman Hrabowski has probably done more to encourage interest in science and math among minority and low-income students than any other educator. As president of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, Dr. Hrabowski has turned his campus into one of the top sources of African-American postgraduate degrees in science and engineering, and he has helped develop several pioneering scholarship programs to get disadvantaged students interested in the subject and to become teachers in those fields. In 2011, he led a National Academy of Sciences study on increasing minority participation in science and technology, which recommended a series of ways to improve early childhood preparation, stimulate interest among high school students, and make college more affordable. He recently discussed some of those ideas with David Firestone of The New York Times editorial board.

headline: Interview With Kevin Kelly, Author of ‘Cool Tools’
text: Kevin Kelly is the former editor of Wired magazine and author of several books, including “What Technology Wants,” which explores the similarities of technology and organisms.

headline: Having One for the Sky
text: A man at a bar orders a julep. The bartender nods and turns to grab a canvas satchel known as a Lewis bag. He fills it with ice, reaches for a wooden mallet and begins to pulverize the bag’s contents, creating the crushed ice needed to build the cocktail.

headline: A Special ‘Nutcracker’ Bond
text: Gelsey Kirkland’s relationship with “The Nutcracker” runs deep. She played Clara opposite Mikhail Baryshnikov in his 1977 production for American Ballet Theater, but one of her strongest memories is of when she was a student at the School of American Ballet. Ms. Kirkland, a lovely wisp of a girl, was cast as the lead in George Balanchine’s classic version. What could go wrong?

headline: Here, the Sound of Triumph Takes on a Different Tone
text: There’s a good chance that a vast majority of musicians who have come up through this country’s student orchestras and concert bands have stormed through the inexorable finale of Shostakovich’s Symphony No. 5. Far fewer musicians of any age will have played the famous conclusion in the manner that the conductor Benjamin Zander molded it during a concert by the Boston Philharmonic Youth Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening.

headline: Home and Hearth? Try Bar and Grill
text: Poor George Bailey. As if he weren’t already teetering on the edge, a Christmas Eve visit to a bar is no help to Jimmy Stewart’s desperate protagonist in “It’s a Wonderful Life.” Just before resolving to end it all, he gets hammered at the hands of one of the least agreeable barmen on film in a bar where even an angel gets no respect.

headline: A Nostalgic Chord, Shared in Solitary Style
text: The oddest and most revealing album released this year by the pianist Keith Jarrett — there have been five so far, for anyone keeping score — is “No End,” a generous helping of noodly, faintly tribal rock jams recorded to cassette in a home studio in 1986. Mr. Jarrett plays every instrument himself, leaning on electric guitar and drums, and hardly touching the piano. The multitracked result often feels like a sincere but hermetic response to the Grateful Dead, which apparently isn’t too far off the mark.

headline: The Disaster Is Over, but the Effects on a Nation Are Not
text: “Fukushima.” The name of the nuclear power plant that was severely damaged in the March 2011 earthquake and tsunami that devastated coastal areas of northeastern Japan has become an ominous buzzword. Along with “Chernobyl,” it lurks in the backs of our minds as a symbol of the unthinkable. Maybe if we just forget, we tell ourselves, everything will somehow turn out all right. Yet, from most evidence, the crisis appears to be far from over.

headline: Making the Volcker Rule Work
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Art Collectors Show Their Chinese Prizes
text: When the prodigious Miami collectors Don and Mera Rubell first visited China, in 2001, they found the artists they met fascinating, but they were frankly unimpressed by the art itself. “It was our most intense trip with the least amount of art,” Mr. Rubell said. “Many of the artists seemed to be making work for export.”

headline: This American Abroad Is Far From Innocent
text: At first, the setup may seem familiar. An American military veteran — alienated and adrift after a war — wanders through a chilly European city in December. He pals around with an intelligent and alluring young woman, about half his age; at bars and cafes, he encounters fellow expatriates, as well as natives who view his wealth and nationality with envy and suspicion.

headline: Murderfist
text: Photos of the sketch comedy troupe.

headline: One’s Crude, the Other’s Cerebral
text: The sketch comedy group Murderfist begins every show like an English soccer riot, the unkempt members of the cast stomping around the stage, bouncing off one another, a blur of beer bottles, beards and bellies.

headline: Artists on Artists | Art Spiegelman on the Varied Craft of Ad Reinhardt
text: It’s been a banner year for the cartoonist Art Spiegelman, regarded by many as the father of the contemporary graphic novel. Long revered for “Maus,” his Pulitzer Prize-winning concentration camp epic (published in two parts in 1986 and 1991), the artist’s work is broader than many realize, as his retrospective at the Jewish Museum in New York (through March 23, 2014) reveals. The show, which has already appeared in Europe and Canada, includes Spiegelman’s early Wacky Pack and Garbage Pail Kids sketches, and closes with more recent projects, like a performance he choreographed and designed with the dance troupe Pilobolus and a colored-glass window representing an art student’s life that he made for his alma mater, the High School of Art & Design in New York. In October, Spiegelman published his monograph, “Co-Mix” (Drawn & Quarterly), and premiered his hybrid slide-show-talk-concert “Wordless!,” which focuses on the woodcut novels of early-20th-century artists like Lynd Ward, at the Sydney Opera House. It runs for one night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Jan. 18.

headline: Composed of Bumps, Murmurs and Sighs
text: A quiet revolution underway for some time now at Columbia University’s Miller Theater continued apace on Thursday night, when the enterprising new-music ensemble Either/Or devoted a Composer Portraits program to works by Anna Thorvaldsdottir. Under the watch of Melissa Smey, the theater’s executive director since 2009, Miller has devoted considerable resources to presenting music by female composers, both established and emerging — and has done so with a lack of fanfare that characterizes the initiative as no anomaly, but simply business as usual.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Art That’s All About the Money … Literally
text: On paper, art is a lot like money. The value of an art object has almost nothing to do with the time required to make it, and even less to do with its materials; if counterfeit, its worth is nil. So it’s no wonder that some physical artists in a disembodied world are — like Warhol in the plastic age or Rihanna in “Pour It Up” — all about the benjamins. At this year’s Art Basel in Miami Beach, Scott Campbell (OHWOW Gallery) showed sculptures built with greenbacks and Hugh Scott-Douglas (Blum & Poe) manipulated foreign currency in a set of his signature magnified scans. Meanwhile, over at NADA, Robert Wechsler (China Art Objects Galleries) exhibited perfectly symmetrical cubes constructed from spare change. In a time of relentless secondary-market speculation that turns young artists into stocks just waiting to be cashed in, it’s almost as if the artists themselves are turning around and saying: “Happy now?”

headline: Leaders of Israel and Iran Praise Mandela, From a Safe Distance

headline: Thousands of Ignored Child Abuse Allegations Plague Arizona Welfare Agency
text: PHOENIX — A longtime homicide detective on assignment with Arizona’s child welfare agency noticed an unfamiliar notation — N.I., for not investigated — as he examined a file containing allegations of sibling-on-sibling sexual abuse. When he encountered the notation again, on a file listing accusations that a father burned his son with an iron, the detective began asking questions.

text: Federal regulators voted today to approve the the Volcker Rule, a centerpiece of the Dodd-Frank Act.

headline: 2 New York City Colleges Draft Rules That Restrict Protests
text: At Cooper Union, it was outrage over a new tuition policy. At City College, it was anger over the closing of a community center. At both Manhattan colleges, student protest shut down buildings, garnered headlines and largely defined campus life over the past year. Now those two very different institutions are considering policies that could restrict how, when and where students can express dissent, while raising the penalties for those who disobey.

headline: On Horseback, Mallet in Hand, Breaking Barriers for Women
text: HOUSTON — Under a soft blue sky at Houston Polo Club last month, Sunny Hale set the strategy as the team captain and was the leading scorer with five goals in Goose Creek’s 7-6 victory in the United States Open women’s polo championship. She was also one of the reasons the tournament has existed for the more than 20 teams and nearly 100 women who were there. Although she is hardly as well known as Nacho Figueras, the polo star and face of Ralph Lauren, Hale may be the most famous female polo player in the world. In 2000, she became the first woman on a winning team in the United States Open, and she has been named the most valuable female player seven times.

headline: Louis Waldon, Actor in Warhol Films Seized for Obscenity, Dies at 78
text: Louis Waldon, an actor who appeared in several Andy Warhol films including “Lonesome Cowboys” and “Blue Movie,” which the authorities seized for obscenity shortly after it was released, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 78.

headline: Hail to the Police Chief
text: LOS ANGELES — WHEN I first met Bill Bratton, at a Christmas party in Los Angeles in 2002, I told him that it was nothing personal but I would soon be suing him, just as I had sued several Los Angeles police chiefs before him. That was my job as a civil rights lawyer, and at that time, we had a rogue police force that refused civilian control, rejected court orders, abused people of color and acted with terrifying impunity.

headline: Missing From Science Class
text: A big reason America is falling behind other countries in science and math is that we have effectively written off a huge chunk of our population as uninterested in those fields or incapable of succeeding in them.

headline: Who Needs a Gun?
text: In September, Navy Yard; in November, a racially fraught shooting in Michigan and a proposed “stand-your-ground law” in Ohio; now the first anniversary of the Newtown massacre — there’s no avoiding the brutal reality of guns in America. Once again, we feel the need to say something, but we know the old arguments will get us nowhere. What’s the point of another impassioned plea or a new subtlety of constitutional law or further complex analyses of statistical data?

headline: Dwindling Tools to Raise Wages
text: Senator Ted Kennedy once called the minimum wage “one of the best” tools for fighting poverty.

headline: Angell to Be Honored at Hall of Fame
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Roger Angell, whose graceful prose has made him baseball’s foremost essayist for more than half a century, will be honored at the Hall of Fame next summer as the winner of the J. G. Taylor Spink Award.

headline: Uruguay Acts to Legalize Marijuana
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Uruguay’s Senate approved legislation on Tuesday that will allow the country to legalize the cultivation and sale of marijuana on a nationwide scale. Uruguay’s leftist president, José Mujica, a supporter of the measure, has signaled that he will enact the legislation in coming days.

headline: Ain’t Nothin’ Like a Dame
text: WASHINGTON — The halo of smoke clears momentarily to reveal America’s newest sensitive man: John Boehner.

headline: Men With Pelvic Pain Find a Path to Treatment Blocked by a Gynecology Board
text: After visiting dozens of doctors and suffering for nearly five years from pelvic pain so severe that he could not work, Daniel Davidson, 57, a dentist in Dalton Gardens, Idaho, finally found a specialist in Phoenix who had an outstanding reputation for treating men like him.

headline: Impasse Over Security Deal Adds to Afghan Economy’s Troubles
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The stubborn impasse over a long-term security deal with the United States has not only raised concerns about the future of the Afghan security forces, but put an instant and alarming drag on the Afghan business climate, already suffering as Western forces have pulled out.

headline: Empty Boxes of Political Economy
text: Sorry about blog silence; real life intruded.

headline: In Granderson, Mets Take Strikeouts With the Power
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Curtis Granderson, who was brought to the Mets to hit home runs, now wears the number of a man who swatted 714, mostly for the Yankees. That would be No. 3, as in Babe Ruth. Granderson chose it because he wanted a single-digit number for his trim frame — “I’m a little guy,” he said — and because he was born in March, the third month.

headline: Why Mandela Was Unique
text: The global outpouring of respect for Nelson Mandela suggests that we’re not just saying goodbye to the man at his death but that we’re losing a certain kind of leader, unique on the world stage today, and we are mourning that just as much. Mandela had an extraordinary amount of “moral authority.” Why? And how did he get it?

headline: After 65 Years of Setting Time, a Watchmaker Shuts His Tiny Store
text: Needing an expensive watch fixed, Tim Bell made a call on Tuesday morning to a master watchmaker, Sal Bracco, who has been repairing them for 65 years.

headline: Study Finds Federal Contracts Given to Flagrant Violators of Labor Laws
text: A new congressional report criticizes the federal government for awarding tens of billions of dollars in contracts to companies even though they were found to have violated safety and wage laws and paid millions in penalties. Issued on behalf of the Democratic senators on the Health, Education, Labor and Pension Committee, the report cited examples over the past six years.

headline: New York Asks Cellphone Carriers to Explain Why They Rejected Antitheft Switch
text: SAN FRANCISCO — New York State’s top prosecutor is investigating why American cellphone carriers have yet to embrace antitheft software on Samsung smartphones, raising questions about possible coordination among the biggest carriers.

headline: Iraq: 13 Sunnis Killed, Then 12 Shiites
text: Seven Sunni construction workers were killed by unidentified gunmen who fired on them from a speeding S.U.V. on Tuesday morning in Abara, a majority-Sunni village in Diyala Province, police and medical officials said. When their families took the bodies to a ritual washing hall, a bomb exploded, killing six family members, two women and four men. That evening, a suicide bomber targeted a Shiite shrine in Diyala, killing 12 Shiites. “Al Qaeda has succeeded in its strategy,” said Haider al-Musawi, a security expert and former army officer. “Now Sunnis think that the Shiites are killing them, and the Shiites think that the Sunnis killed them.” He said the situation could become worse than Syria barring an immediate solution, which would be “a miracle.” The 25 were among 31 people killed in Iraq on Tuesday.

headline: N.B.A. Players Are Paying by the Rules
text: Not all basketball players can dunk. Not every coach can take his team to the playoffs. But anyone in the N.B.A. can be fined — and lately, it seems, almost everyone has.

headline: Expiration of Hotel Room-Tax Rate in New York City Causes Confusion
text: New York City can be an expensive place for out-of-towners seeking a bed for the night. But those visitors have unknowingly paid thousands of dollars more in hotel taxes than they should have because of confusion caused by City Hall.

headline: Obama Sees a Rebound in His Approval Ratings
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s approval ratings, which hit his all-time low last month, have returned to where they were before the rollout of the health care law’s enrollment process, but Americans still lack confidence in the White House’s management of the Affordable Care Act, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The public’s opinion of the law itself has improved after repairs to the enrollment website.

headline: Brooklyn Beach Community Changes, and Angrily Divides
text: Living on the same mansion-lined streets, they have denounced each other by email and by insinuation. Meeting in the same elementary school auditorium, they have clashed over barbecue grills and traffic lights. Sharing a private safety patrol, they have come to blows.

headline: State Gun Laws Enacted in the Year After Newtown
text: In the year after the school killings in Newtown, Conn., states passed 109 gun-related bills. Of those, 70 loosened gun restrictions and 39 tightened them. A chart tracks their paths.

headline: New Projects on the Horizon at Manhattan’s Piers
text: Lining the southern section of the island of Manhattan like bristles on a brush, some decaying piers with their dilapidated buildings remain symbols of failed promises and discarded proposals.

headline: Eran Polack
text: Mr. Polack, 40, is the chief executive of HAP Investment Developers, a company with offices in New York and Tel Aviv that focuses mainly on midsize residential and commercial properties, mainly in northern Manhattan. His partners in the company are Amir Hasid and Nir Amsel.

headline: $40,000 Crocodile Jacket Is Stolen From Men’s Store in Manhattan
text: At a men’s clothing store called Zilli on East 57th Street, the holiday shopper with exotic tastes and a spare $50,000 will find Astrakhan fur coats and jackets made of python — with interchangeable collars of beaver, ermine or mink. But, while you will find deerskin vests and a black chinchilla bedspread at Zilli this week, missing from the racks is a certain jacket of brown Australian crocodile.

headline: Israel: Law Reduces Migrant Detention
text: The Israeli Parliament passed legislation on Tuesday allowing for the detention of African migrants and asylum seekers who enter the country illegally for up to a year without trial. The bill amended previous legislation allowing detention without trial for up to three years. Israel’s Supreme Court overturned that law in September, ruling that it violated principles of human dignity and freedom. The amendment also allows the state to hold migrants already in Israel indefinitely in what it called “open” detention facilities. About 60,000 Africans have entered Israel since 2005.

headline: ‘Long and Arduous Process’ to Ban a Single Wall Street Activity
text: At 6 feet 7 inches, Paul A. Volcker struck an imposing figure as chairman of the Federal Reserve during the economically turbulent 1980s.

headline: Modern Makeover for Wrigley Building, Long a Hallmark of Chicago’s Skyline
text: CHICAGO — The renovation of the landmark Wrigley Building, one of the beacons along this city’s Magnificent Mile, is an effort by an investor-turned-developer to reposition one of Chicago’s most famous structures amid the city’s expanding retail district.

Chris Christie who ordered the shutdown.

headline: Effort to Help Filipino Women Falters, U.N. Says
text: WASHINGTON — A new effort to protect women from rape and help them deliver babies in the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines remains troubled and inadequate, the United Nations and international aid groups said this week.

headline: What’s Taken Home

headline: Vice Media Buys a Tech Company to Experiment With Content Distribution
text: ADVERTISING, journalism and technology continue to converge. The latest example: Vice Media’s acquisition of Carrot Creative, a digital agency that creates apps, websites and games for media companies and brands.

headline: Telling a Dark Story to Offer Some Light
text: It’s not always easy for Sylvia Anderson to tell her tale. But she believes strongly in sharing it with the world, nonetheless.

headline: After Setbacks, Online Courses Are Rethought
text: Two years after a Stanford professor drew 160,000 students from around the globe to a free online course on artificial intelligence, starting what was widely viewed as a revolution in higher education, early results for such large-scale courses are disappointing, forcing a rethinking of how college instruction can best use the Internet.

headline: New Posting System Likely to Delay, Not Sink, Sale of a Japanese Ace
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — It is hard to quantify what Masahiro Tanaka did for the Rakuten Eagles and the city of Sendai last season when he led the team to a Japan Series title. But there is little doubt the Eagles think it is more than $20 million.

headline: Gannett to Add USA Today to Local Papers
text: Gannett Company, one of the nation’s largest newspaper chains, will try to expand its advertising and circulation revenue by inserting parts of its flagship newspaper, USA Today, into its local newspapers.

headline: Brazilian Panel Says Ex-Leader Was Murdered
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — The Truth Commission in São Paulo, Brazil’s largest city, said Tuesday that Juscelino Kubitschek, the country’s president from 1956 to 1961, was murdered in 1976 in a conspiracy by the military dictatorship ruling Brazil at the time.

headline: Arizona: Auctioned Artifacts to Be Returned to Tribes
text: A day after more than 27 of their sacred artifacts were sold at a contested auction in Paris for $757,000, the Hopi and San Carlos Apache Indians of Arizona learned Tuesday that 24 of the items had been bought by a foundation that plans to return them to the tribes. The Hopi artifacts are colorful and intricate masklike items held to be imbued with divine spirits. Gregory Annenberg Weingarten, a vice president of the Los Angeles-based Annenberg Foundation, said it had decided to buy the items, at a cost of $530,000, once it became clear that the Paris auction house EVE would not delay the sale to allow the tribes time to gather proof that the items had been stolen from their lands long ago. “These are not trophies to have on one’s mantel,” he said.

headline: Poll: The President and Health Care
text: New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Knicks Talk Good Game but Don’t Play It
text: CLEVELAND — The Knicks lost any sense of stability long ago. Cracks formed when Tyson Chandler broke his right leg during the team’s fourth game of the season, and the season has been a patchwork quilt ever since — a ragged, ripping-at-the-seams patchwork quilt.

headline: Rise of Young Leaders Signals a Mandate for Political Change in Italy
text: ROME — For all its melodrama and theatrics, Italian politics is often defined by what does not happen. The Italian Parliament has been deadlocked on major changes for years, unable or unwilling to enact bills to overhaul the political system or unshackle the economy, which has barely grown in two decades.

headline: Jim Hall, Master Jazz Guitarist Who Played With the Greats, Dies at 83
text: Jim Hall, a jazz guitarist who for more than 50 years was admired by critics, aficionados and especially his fellow musicians for his impeccable technique and the warmth and subtlety of his playing, died on Tuesday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 83.

headline: Williams and Pierce Return, and So Does Nets’ Ability to Stay in a Game
text: When the Nets brought together all the luxurious parts that now constitute their wildly expensive roster, point guard Deron Williams was presented as the engine that would propel the machine.

headline: New Leadership for Lululemon in Management Shake-Up
text: Perhaps going on television and suggesting that women with large thighs were not the ideal customer — at least when it comes to yoga pants — would never be considered advisable for the top executive of an athletic wear company.

headline: A Modest Compromise on Spending
text: How the two-year budget agreement compares with previous plans for the current fiscal year.

headline: Callahan Is Lost to Knee Injury, Adding to the Rangers’ Frustration
text: Trapped in his goaltender’s equipment, Henrik Lundqvist can display only so much anger. But he is clearly reaching a higher level of distress as the Rangers keep losing at home.

headline: Does Rising Inequality Make Us Hardhearted?
text: Over the course of American history, support for economic redistribution has been the exception, not the rule. In the 20th century, support for redistributive policies emerged as a dominant force in national politics only in the Depression decade of the 1930s; it was intermittently influential from 1945 to 1965.

headline: New York Court Won’t Order Fox Reporter to Testify, Shoring Up State Shield Law
text: A New York State shield law protecting journalists was bolstered Tuesday when the state’s highest court refused to require a Fox News reporter to return to Colorado to testify in the case of James E. Holmes, the man accused of shooting 12 people in July 2012 in a movie theater in Aurora, Colo.

headline: Novel Tactics for Dealing with Pollution
text: Some sensible medical advice: Jamming cigarette butts up your nostrils will not ward off the acrid smog enveloping China, and is positively risky for your health. Thus some Chinese newspapers have told readers, in the most giddying example yet of how chronic air pollution is forcing citizens to desperate inventiveness.

headline: Coach Named for New York M.L.S. Team
text: New York City F.C., which will begin Major League Soccer play in 2015, announced that it had hired Jason Kreis as the club’s first coach. Last Saturday, Kreis was the losing coach when Real Salt Lake fell to Sporting Kansas City in a penalty kick shootout in the M.L.S. Cup. His contract with Real Salt Lake, where he has been the coach since 2007, is to expire at the end of the year.

headline: Kerry’s Statement on Ukraine
text: Following is a statement by Secretary of State John Kerry on events in Ukraine:

headline: 2 French Paratroopers Killed in Central African Republic
text: PARIS — President François Hollande of France arrived Tuesday in the Central African Republic just hours after the French government announced the death of two French paratroopers. The paratroopers were part of the newly augmented French military force that arrived over the weekend to help stem the increasing violence in the country.

headline: Close to the Olympics, Far From the Bounty
text: GULRIPSHI, Georgia — A little less than three miles from Sochi’s main Olympic Stadium, the site of the opening and closing ceremonies of the Winter Games in February, the Psou River stands as Russia’s border with Georgia. But no one directly on either side of the derelict border post considers any part of the region Georgia.

headline: The 10 Best Pieces at This Year’s Design Miami
text: Design Miami, the nine-year-old satellite fair to Art Basel in Miami Beach, is known for showcasing works by modern masters like Jean Prouvé and Charlotte Perriand. This year proved no different, with prefab houses by both on display (Prouvé’s built within the Design Miami tent, Perriand’s on the beach behind the Raleigh Hotel). But in addition to the large-scale showstoppers, there were numerous more intimate works of interest. Many dealers showed jewelry or decorative objects alongside furniture. Several galleries created complete residential settings in which they installed their pieces. Demish Danant, for example, felt like a Parisian apartment from the 1970s with its boiserie and wall-to-wall carpeting. And while a few galleries did show new work, objects from the ’40s to the ’70s were predominant, adding to the fair’s throwback feel. Here is some of the best this year’s Design Miami had to offer.

headline: Conflicting Pressures on Demand for Doctors
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Exercise as Potent Medicine
text: Exercise can be as effective as many frequently prescribed drugs in treating some of the leading causes of death, according to a new report. The study raises important questions about whether our health care system focuses too much on medications and too little on activity to combat physical ailments.

headline: Word of the Day | contagion
text: contagion •\kən-ˈta-jən\• noun

headline: In Lebanon, a Fear of Permanent Refugees
text: Given the history of refugee housing – flimsy tents that were replaced by multi-story dwellings – the Lebanese view even the most modest of new shelters for Syrians with suspicion.

headline: Lebanon Worries That Housing Will Make Syrian Refugees Stay
text: WADI KHALED, Lebanon — The modest shelter housing some Syrian refugees here, a few hundred yards south of the border with Syria, hardly looks objectionable. Made of plywood walls on a concrete foundation of some 250 square feet, with one door, two windows and a corrugated zinc roof, the squat structure is called a “box shelter.”

headline: Ukraine’s Path to Unrest
text: Just a few months ago, President Viktor F. Yanukovich seemed to be on track to signing a trade and political agreement with the European Union. A look back through crucial moments over the past year.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 5 through Dec. 8 with 1,000 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were in English or Spanish.

headline: Bomb Explodes Outside Kabul Airport
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide car bomb exploded outside the military entrance to Kabul International Airport on Wednesday morning, the police said.

headline: Spotify Adds Led Zeppelin, and Turns Focus to Mobile
text: With competition growing in the streaming music market, Spotify announced a series of changes meant to entice new customers and extend its digital footprint farther around the world.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 11 P.M. (A&E) RODEO GIRLS Five female barrel racers of varying expertise — Darcy LaPier (above), Marvel Murphy, Barb West, Megan Etcheberry and Jessica Holmberg — don boots, chaps and spurs as they travel the rodeo circuit with their horses in pursuit of the spoils, and a little rough-and-tumble playtime with cowboys like Ty Murphy and Anthony Lucia. Forget the hooves: That’s when the claws come out. Part 2 of this series premiere will be shown Thursday at 10 p.m.

headline: A Long Wait for a Last Moment With Mandela
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — Patience Mashele put on her black, gold and green shirt, hat and skirt and left her house before dawn. She did not want to be late. It was time to say goodbye.

headline: Death of Prince Marks End of Mysore Royal Family Line
text: BANGALORE, Karnataka — The 600-year-old Kingdom of Mysore has come to an end after Srikantadatta Narasimharaja Wodeyar, the last remaining member of the Mysore Royal family, died of a heart attack in Bangalore at the age of 60 on Tuesday.

headline: Worker Deaths Raise Questions at an Apple Contractor in China
text: SHANGHAI — Last September, a young Chinese laborer named Shi Zhaokun began working long hours at a huge manufacturing plant that produces Apple’s new iPhone 5C.

headline: India’s Supreme Court Restores an 1861 Law Banning Gay Sex
text: NEW DELHI — The Indian Supreme Court reinstated on Wednesday a colonial-era law banning gay sex, ruling that it had been struck down improperly by a lower court.

headline: Ukraine Forces Retreat, Ceding Square to Protests
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian authorities’ surprise decision to storm the central square occupied by antigovernment protesters here early Wednesday sharply escalated tensions with Western leaders, while an equally abrupt pullout by the police after a nine-hour siege created a growing sense of unpredictability about President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s handling of the crisis.

headline: Draft of Security Plan Calls for a Muscular Japan
text: TOKYO — Japan must strengthen its defense and seek a larger regional role as the balance of power shifts with the rise of China and the decline of American influence, according to a draft of a new national security strategy released Wednesday.

headline: C.I.A. Honors Former Officers Held Captive for Decades in China
text: The Central Intelligence Agency has awarded its highest honor for valor, the Distinguished Intelligence Cross, to two former officers who spent two decades imprisoned in China.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 11, 2013
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Spies Among the Elves, Gnomes and Supermodels
text: The questions below are based on the video embedded above, but students might also read the related article, “Spies Infiltrate a Fantasy Realm of Online Games.”

headline: Santander to Buy Stake in Bank of Shanghai for $647 Million
text: LONDON – The Spanish lender Banco Santander has agreed to buy an 8 percent stake in Bank of Shanghai for 470 million euros as part of its strategy to increase its presence in Asia.

headline: In Ford’s White House, Not Holding Back
text: Someone once asked David Hume Kennerly if he ever held back when he was President Gerald R. Ford’s White House photographer. Though it was sometimes difficult — as when the Fords cried after his 1976 election loss — Mr. Kennerly said he did not. “I think it comes from my background,” he said. “It comes from journalism.”

headline: David O. Russell: In Conversation
text: You could argue that, with his new film, “American Hustle,” coming on the heels of “The Fighter” and “Silver Linings Playbook,” David O. Russell has put together the best trifecta of any active American filmmaker. “The Fighter” earned seven Oscar nominations; “Silver Linings” received eight; and “American Hustle” was just named the year’s best film by the New York Film Critics Circle. Early in his career, Russell developed a reputation as a brilliant but difficult director; George Clooney said the two actually came to blows on the set of Russell’s third film, “Three Kings,” and later a YouTube video circulated of Lily Tomlin and Russell in a full-throated, expletive-laced shouting match on the set of his fourth film, “I Heart Huckabees.” Whether­ the characterization was fair, Russell has since undergone a personal, artistic and, ultimately, professional transformation. He regards “Hustle,” a highly fictionalized version of the Abscam scandal of the late ’70s and early ’80s, as the third in a loose trilogy of films about ordinary people trying to live passionate lives. It’s a journey he has had some experience with firsthand.

headline: How Do You Know if What You Read Online Is True?
text: One of several viral Twitter posts that told the tale of a Thanksgiving feud on a plane. It later turned out the feud never happened, and the posts were described by the writer as a short story.

headline: Shanghai Man Seeks Record Sum After Home Museum Demolished
text: Updated, 8:35 a.m. ET | A homeowner in Shanghai is suing over the destruction of his personal museum and garden in what some Chinese news outlets are reporting would be the country’s most expensive case of forced demolition.

headline: A Quiet Start to South-North Water Transfer
text: The Chinese government has often brandished its feats of building vast dams and channeling rivers as triumphs of engineering. Not this time. This week a first leg of what the government calls the world’s biggest water transfer project officially started in a mood of subdued resignation.

text: Updated 12:13 p.m.
