headline: Who Goes to Work to Have Fun?
text: “ONE of our core values is to inject fun and quirkiness into everything we do,” Neil Blumenthal, a founder of the online eyeglass retailer Warby Parker, recently told The New York Times. This is a philosophy currently enjoying a resurgence in the tech and retail industries, among others. As we enter the season of office holiday parties, it’s a safe assumption that the workplace quirkiness quotient will skyrocket. Which means it’s also the season for the curmudgeons among us to renew our passionate entreaty: Please — no, really, please — can we stop trying to “make work fun”?

headline: Daily Report: New York Asks Why Cellphone Carriers Rejected Antitheft Switch
text: New York State’s top prosecutor is investigating why American cellphone carriers have yet to embrace antitheft software on Samsung smartphones, raising questions about possible coordination among the biggest carriers, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: Boies Schiller Again Pays Associates Generous Bonuses
text: Updated, 8:44 p.m. |  The law firm co-founded by the well-known litigator David Boies is again breaking away from the pack when it comes to showering big year-end bonuses on young lawyers.

headline: A Conversation with: Lawyer and Activist Gautam Bhan
text: The Supreme Court ruling on Wednesday that made gay sex illegal again in India is seen as a setback by the country’s gay community, whose members were expecting a judgment in their favor after the Indian government refused to appeal the 2009 ruling of the lower court to decriminalize homosexuality.

headline: The Booming Business of Bilingual
text: To get her bilingual school off the ground in Austin, Tex., Adriana Rodriguez had to sell her house.

headline: British Regulator Fines Lloyds Bank $46 Million Over Sales Program
text: LONDON – Britain’s Financial Conduct Authority fined the Lloyds Banking Group about $46 million on Wednesday for failing to properly manage its compensation program so that its financial advisers were not encouraged to sell consumers unnecessary products to meet sales targets.

headline: A Bootstrapping Entrepreneur Decides to Bet the Family Home
text: It’s not at all uncommon for entrepreneurs to tap into their home equity to finance a business idea. A few years ago, Adriana Rodriguez of Austin, Tex., took an even more striking step: She sold her house to support her education start-up and moved her family into a small rental.

headline: Helping Brazil’s Poor Heal at Home
text: We often hear about the harmful effects of poverty on health, particularly the health of children. But we hear less about the decisive role health plays in triggering, or exacerbating, poverty.

headline: Barclays to End Sponsorship of London Bike Program
text: Updated, 2:55 p.m. |

headline: Potential Misunderstandings
text: Izabella Kaminska reports on a “strongly worded” riposte to the secular stagnation hypothesis, in which analysts at Independent Strategy declare that we don’t have inadequate demand, we have debt causing the economy to grow above potential. Unfortunately, the paper itself isn’t available, only Kaminska’s description, so I can’t see how strong the wording is. If her description is accurate, however, some other stuff is … not so strong. For it seems that like so many writers in this area, the authors don’t understand the meaning of potential output.

headline: Upstairs, Downstairs, Outside
text: Via Mark Thoma, David Cay Johnston has a great piece noting that today’s service economy is in many ways like the Edwardian-era economy in which a small number of wealthy people employed a large number of servants — except that we tend to outsource the service, relying on restaurants and cleaning services instead of cooks and maids. And our outsourced servants are, he notes, arguably paid and treated worse than the in-house servants of the past, even in absolute terms — let alone relative to per capita GDP.

headline: A Dangerously Divided Ukraine
text: Ukraine’s president, Viktor Yanukovich, took a tentative step toward defusing his country’s political turmoil earlier this week by convening a “round table” with former Ukrainian presidents to discuss possible responses to the protests engulfing the capital, Kiev. But he promptly negated any value in that gesture by ordering security police to clear the demonstrators’ encampment in Independence Square early Wednesday morning. Though the police appeared to pull back by midday, the confrontation plunges Ukraine deeper into crisis.

headline: Enforcing the Volcker Rule
text: Five federal regulators agreed on Tuesday on a final version of the Volcker Rule, which aims to prohibit regulated banks from using customer money to trade for their own gain. Now, the rule’s biggest test may be just around the corner, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes.

headline: It’s a Wonderful Last Few Years of Life
text: INT: A Greenwich Village high-rise apartment.

headline: Ryan and Murray Describe Budget Deal
text: The agreement would raise military and domestic spending over the next two years but prevent another government shutdown.

headline: E.U. Ministers Stagger Toward Banking Deal
text: BRUSSELS — As European finance ministers plod toward an agreement on how to wind down ailing banks , details that emerged on Wednesday indicated that the resolution could be as cumbersome and time-consuming as the process to achieve it.

headline: A View of the Empire State Building Seen Anew
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Negotiating Conflicts, Part 1: Family Grudges
text: Sheila Heen, an expert in negotiation and difficult conversations, is answering reader questions about how to resolve disputes within families and in other parts of life.

headline: Amazon’s Prophet and Losses
text: Three months ago, you could buy a share of Amazon for $300. Today, it would cost you nearly $400. Surely such a run-up was driven by expectations that the company’s all-important fourth quarter would be even better than forecast.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Amanda Moffat Pitcher
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Apple Family Plays to Be Filmed for PBS
text: Richard Nelson’s critically acclaimed Apple Family plays, which are running in repertory at the Public Theater through Sunday, will be recorded for television by WNET, the PBS station on Channel 13 in New York, for broadcast at a future date, the Public announced on Wednesday.

headline: U.S. Cites Rise in Health Plan Signups as Sebelius Testifies
text: WASHINGTON — The number of people selecting health insurance plans in the federal and state marketplaces increased last month at a brisk pace, bringing the overall figure to nearly 365,000, the Obama administration said on Wednesday. The November number was more than double the one for October, but still well below the administration’s goal.

headline: Mexico’s Incumbency Trap
text: MEXICO CITY — For almost one hundred years, all official stationery from the Mexican government bore this motto: “Sufragio efectivo, no reelección” (Effective suffrage, no re-election). That was the rallying cry of the Mexican Revolution of 1910, which began in protest, among other things, of the seventh re-election of President Porfirio Díaz.

headline: ‘12 Years a Slave’ Leads SAG Nominations
text: Actors make up the largest branch of the Academy, so the Screen Actors Guild Awards are something of a barometer for the Oscars. On Wednesday morning, the guild announced its nominations. Up for outstanding performance by a movie cast, the equivalent of the best-picture Oscar, are:

headline: Hardships Linger for a Mending Ireland
text: DUBLIN — On the rare days when John Donovan visits downtown Dublin, there is a buzz in the air: Streets bustle with pedestrians. “Sold” signs festoon Georgian brick buildings that had languished on the market for years. At Silicon Docks, a hub where Google, Facebook and other tech companies are clustered, crowds of taxis line up for easy fares.

headline: Feasts for the Eyes, 1,001 Nights’ Worth
text: By the time midnight strikes on Dec. 31, The New York Times will have reviewed almost 900 movies in the course of 2013. This number, which grows every year, nonetheless represents a tiny fraction of the moving-picture entertainment made available to the public over the previous 12 months on television, video on demand and streaming services and at the festivals that span the globe and the calendar. In such circumstances, the traditional 10-best list, always arbitrary, seems downright cruel — to filmmakers, to readers and to the overwhelmed critic who must kill, or at least neglect, some of his darlings and subject himself to the self-flagellation of second-guessing. (Oh dear: “Kill Your Darlings” — shouldn’t I have made room for that one?)

headline: The Festival World, and What’s Beyond
text: We are living in an era of cinematic abundance, so why does this feast sometimes feel like a famine? That’s the question every American critic needs to ask as she weighs the year’s bounty. From one angle, 2013 looks terrific. Critics began sending the cheering news about thinking-adult entertainment from the Cannes Film Festival in May (where “The Great Beauty,” “Inside Llewyn Davis” and “A Touch of Sin” sent filmgoers into raptures), good news that continued once the fall — a.k.a. festival, a.k.a. Oscar — season kicked off in August at Venice and Telluride, which offered up the likes of “All Is Lost,” “Gravity” and “12 Years a Slave.”

headline: Citigroup Names New Board Member
text: Citigroup announced on Wednesday that Duncan P. Hennes, a longtime financial executive, would join its board.

headline: Interpreter at Memorial Service Said to Have Been an Impostor
text: QUNU, South Africa — He stood with a deadpan expression just inches from President Obama and other world leaders speaking at Nelson Mandela’s memorial, dressed in a dark suit, with a blue security lanyard bearing the words “state funeral” draped around his neck, flapping his arms and gesticulating in what was supposed to be sign language for the deaf.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘12 Years a Slave’
text: At 82, with several decades of work as a costume designer and art director, five Oscar nominations (beginning with the 1978 film “Days of Heaven”), an Emmy (for “Twin Peaks”) and a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Art Directors Guild, Patricia Norris knows Hollywood and its vanities.

headline: Trips With a BBC Earth Touch
text: Tauck, the travel company based in Norwalk, Conn., is teaming with BBC Earth, the British channel known for its natural history documentaries, for a series of nature-focused trips beginning in 2014 called Earth Journeys.

headline: An Oyster, Filled With Books, Is Set to Open on Staten Island
text: No one has to tell Mohammed Iddrisu that a public library branch is long overdue in his neighborhood, Mariners Harbor, on the north shore of Staten Island.

headline: News Organizations Call On Syrian Rebels to End Kidnappings
text: Thirteen international news organizations, including the BBC, The Associated Press and The New York Times, have written a letter to the armed opposition in Syria asking for assurances that their reporters will not be abducted.

headline: Microsoft and Sony Game Consoles Neck-and-Neck in Sales
text: Game companies often issue dueling sales announcements for their products in an attempt to show who has the upper hand in the business. This holiday season, Sony appears to have a slight edge on its rival Microsoft.

text: Greg Kessler/Kessler Studio

headline: De Blasio Says He’ll Move to Gracie Mansion
text: The father got a big new job, only to face a seemingly agonizing choice: Should he stay in the house he owned in the neighborhood he said he loved, or move to the much fancier house that came with the job?

headline: Health Care Marketplace: December Enrollment Report
text: The Department of Health and Human Services released the number of Americans who signed up on health care exchanges in December.

headline: In Our Pages: December 12
text: 1888: Wild Beast Tamer Torn to Bits

headline: Limits of Vitamin D Supplements
text: A large review of studies has found that vitamin D supplements have little or no benefit beyond the low levels required for bone health.

headline: When a Second-Term President Nears the Midterm Shoals
text: WASHINGTON — History says President Obama should brace for another round of midterm election losses next year — and be grateful for the opportunity.

headline: A Geopolitical Twist in the Foreign Film Race
text: Every now and then, the Oscar competition for best foreign-language film is enlivened when it turns out that filmmakers from different places have tackled the same subject, unaware that someone else had the same idea. That’s the case this year, but with an additional geopolitical twist: the director of one of the films involved is an Israeli, and the director of the other is Palestinian.

headline: Hany Abu-Assad on ‘Omar’ and Strange Coincidences
text: In 2006, the Palestinian director Hany Abu-Assad’s drama “Paradise Now,” about two young Palestinian men planning a suicide attack in Israel, won the Golden Globe for best foreign-language film and was also nominated for an Oscar in that category. Now, after an unhappy interlude in which he made a Hollywood action film called “The Courier,” Mr. Abu-Assad is back in the thick of awards season with “Omar,” which looks again at the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but from a different angle.

headline: Yuval Adler on ‘Bethlehem’ and Heidegger
text: Updated, 4:54 p.m. | Before beginning a career in film, Yuval Adler, the director of “Bethlehem,” Israel’s submission for the foreign-language Oscar, worked in a lot of different fields. After earning a degree in mathematics in Tel Aviv, he was a numbers cruncher in New York “for some guy who was doing hedge fund stuff,” while simultaneously trying to develop himself as an artist, living in a studio in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He also earned a Ph.D in philosophy from Columbia University, writing his dissertation on finger-pointing as an example of a linguistic phenomenon called indexicality.

headline: Lighting Up the Night
text: In the interval between Hanukkah and Christmas, as we head toward the winter solstice, light — from the sun, streetlamps, or candles — seems more precious than ever. In his new picture book, “Dusk,” the Warsaw-born author and illustrator Uri Shulevitz follows a little boy and his grandfather on their afternoon walk through the streets of New York, following the shifting lights of the short day as they go.

headline: 7 Reasons Not to Buy Your Child an iPad for Christmas
text: When it comes to Christmas, I’m a sucker for the “wow” gift (and if anyone has any ideas for my 8-year-old daughter, let me know). I want to surprise and delight as much as anyone (and as an interfaith family, we alternate doing the big gifts for Hanukkah or for Christmas — the timing means it’s Christmas this year). But there’s one big gift I won’t go for: the tablet computer in any form, and that includes the game-and-video playing Kindle Fire.

headline: F.D.A. Restricts Antibiotics Use for Livestock
text: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday put in place a major new policy to phase out the indiscriminate use of antibiotics in cows, pigs and chickens raised for meat, a practice that experts say has endangered human health by fueling the growing epidemic of antibiotic resistance.

headline: Louisiana Locksmith Supports Auto Library, Wins a Ferrari
text: If you’re going to keep a racing library and archives going, the best way to raise money is probably going to have something to do with cars. That is why it isn’t surprising that the International Motor Racing Research Center in Watkins Glen, N.Y., raffles off a classic car every year to raise money.

headline: Pilots in Crash Were Confused About Control Systems, Experts Say
text: WASHINGTON — The pilots of the Asiana jumbo jet that crashed in San Francisco on July 6 were deeply confused about the plane’s automated control systems, and that is a common problem among airline pilots, according to experts who testified Wednesday in a National Transportation Safety Board hearing on the crash.

headline: Google’s Road Map to Global Domination
text: Fifty-five miles and three days down the Colorado River from the put-in at Lee’s Ferry, near the Utah-Arizona border, the two rafts in our little flotilla suddenly encountered a storm. It sneaked up from behind, preceded by only a cool breeze. With the canyon walls squeezing the sky to a ribbon of blue, we didn’t see the thunderhead until it was nearly on top of us.

headline: Times Minute | Fragile Calm in Kiev
text: Also on the Minute, the Syrian refugee crisis causes housing problems in Lebanon and exercising may be more potent than medicine.

headline: What’s That Noise? Well, Think Again
text: A scrappy troupe of polymorphic performers are coming to town this week to ask New Yorkers to see with their ears. Or is it to hear with their eyes? Either way, Squonk Opera, a multimedia troupe of infinite jest with an imagination to match, is determined to blur the lines of our sensory responses to music with its “Mayhem and Majesty,” which opens on Dec. 18 at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Cracks in Air Travel May Widen
text: Two new studies have found that rough days may be ahead for air travel congestion.

headline: Classical Playlist: Anne-Sophie Mutter, Christian Tetzlaff, Richard Egarr and More
text: ‘DVORAK’Anne-Sophie Mutter, violin, with Berlin Philharmonic, Manfred Honeck, conductor(Deutsche Grammophon)With a sound like molten chocolate and a romantic temperament to match, the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter is in her element here in a glowing recording of works by Dvorak including the darkly heroic Violin Concerto and the gorgeous Romance in F minor. The Berlin Philharmonic under Manfred Honeck tempers the sweetness with playing that is rich, intense, but also edgy where needed. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: Congress Needs to Extend Unemployment Insurance
text: There is a lot to say about the Congressional budget deal, and we do that later on the editorial page. For now I wanted to dwell on the outrageous failure of Congress to extend federal long-term unemployment benefits.

headline: Dropping Health Plans, to Pick Better Coverage
text: For nearly 20 years, Keith Perkins offered health insurance to employees of his small electrical contracting company in Greencastle, Pa., and footed most of the bill. This year, with the arrival of the Affordable Care Act’s insurance marketplace, he decided to stop.

headline: ‘Selfie’ of Obama Was Misinterpreted, Photographer Says
text: This is an era when one honest image can ignite viral misinterpretation. So an Agence France-Presse photographer, Roberto Schmidt, has provided invaluable context for his photograph of a grinning President Obama joining two prime ministers in taking a snapshot of themselves at Nelson Mandela’s memorial ceremony.

headline: Have You Considered Dropping Your Company’s Health Coverage?
text: In an article we’ve just published, Stacy Cowley writes about small-business owners who are choosing to stop offering health coverage not just because it removes an administrative burden but because many of their employees come out ahead.

headline: Kidd, Woodson and the Game of Survival
text: It is no great revelation to say that many coaches in professional sports come upon their jobs primarily because their predecessors were blamed for someone else’s failures or foibles.

headline: No Farm Bill in Sight as Recess Looms for Congress
text: WASHINGTON — Prospects for passage of a new farm bill before the end of the year appear dim, with just a week left before Congress adjourns for the holidays, although lawmakers insisted they were close to a deal.

headline: A Social Diary of This Year’s Miami Art Fairs
text: Let’s be honest about the art fairs that concluded on Sunday in Miami. They were about one thing: money — the making of it, by selling art, and the spending of it, on having a decadently good time. And the art sold well. Very well. Dealers at the two biggest fairs, Art Basel in Miami Beach, at the Miami Beach Convention Center, and NADA (the New Art Dealers Alliance), at the Deauville Beach Resort in North Beach, boasted that despite predictions of Basel burnout, plenty of collectors attended and sales were stronger than in recent years. So rest assured that these tropical rituals of end-of-year excess will continue for the foreseeable future.

headline: Today in Small Business: Who Wants to Be a Teen Millionaire?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Moncler Prices I.P.O. at Top of Range
text: LONDON — Moncler, the Italian designer of luxury winter jackets, is set to raise $938.8 million in its initial public offering, which was priced at the top end of the range late on Wednesday.

headline: 20 Recipes for Cookies and Bars
text: Everyone loves a good cookie (or a chewy brownie, or a stick of biscotti). Here are recipes to keep your sweet tooth satisfied through the holidays.

headline: Capitals’ Ovechkin Scores Four Goals and Celebrates in Style
text: Alex Ovechkin of the Washington Capitals has been such a productive goal scorer in his eight N.H.L. seasons that it takes something truly special to make his goals noteworthy these days. The fact that he is leading the league in goals with 26 after 29 games? Yawn. That he became the Capitals’ career leader for power play goals? Insert crickets chirping.

headline: This Guy’s in Love With Your Songs
text: Burt Bacharach’s canon of effervescent pop classics belongs to the world, no question; a guy who could turn out hits for artists encompassing Perry Como and El DeBarge clearly has no trouble writing for a wide audience. But for generations of pop-music obsessives and fellow musicians, Mr. Bacharach’s distinctive compositional sophistication — those uneven time signatures, the rich jazz chords — has made him a folk hero.

headline: Denmark, Where Joy Is Always in Season
text: There appears to be nothing rotten in the state of Denmark these days. For the second straight year, Denmark has been named the happiest country, according to a survey of 156 nations called the World Happiness Report.

headline: Cuisine and Crowds Along a Stretch of Singapore
text: Named for its storied past as the home of exclusive clubs for Chinese businessmen in the 1800s and early 1900s, the stretch of Club Street that extends to Ann Siang Road, on the fringe of Singapore’s Chinatown, is making a comeback. With trendy new restaurants and bars and attractive boutiques sprouting up in the historically preserved shop houses lining a winding slope, crowds are thronging to the area. On weekend nights, the enclave is conveniently off limits to cars.

headline: A Popular Noncandidate Keeps His Options Open and the Voters Guessing
text: LONDONDERRY, N.H. — The trademark pickup truck rolled up to the Harold Square restaurant here one rainy night last week and out popped Scott P. Brown, the former senator from Massachusetts. He had been a senator for only three years, but that was long enough to whet his appetite for more.

headline: Obamacare’s Many Possible Futures
text: The latest data on Obamacare signups is yet another rorschach test for the law’s supporters and skeptics: The accelerating rate of signups is either evidence that enrollment might yet achieve escape velocity or an indicator (given how low, in absolute numbers, private enrollment remains) that even with a smoother website experience the program is never going to reach its “multiple millions of private enrollees” goal. I’ve been writing lately about the latter possibility, and sketching scenarios where low enrollment leads to adverse selection and makes the entire mandate-regulate-subsidize setup unsustainable. But the new numbers provide a good opportunity to note that “unsustainability” is a shorthand phrase that obscures as much as it reveals, and there are many, many likely outcomes for Obamacare that fall somewhere between “meets its supporters expectations” and “collapses under its own weight.”

headline: Soothing Words on ‘Too Big to Fail,’ but With Little Meaning
text: This summer, President Obama’s new Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, offered a financial reform litmus test: By the end of 2013, could we say with a straight face that we have solved the “too big to fail” problem?

headline: A Literary Look Back at 2013
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, all 10 columnists look back at 2013 and answer: What was the most interesting literary development — welcome or lamentable — of the year?

headline: Acrostic
text: Acrostic puzzle for December 15, 2013

headline: A Happy Hour for Private Equity
text: Oriental Brewery may produce a happy hour for its private equity investors.

headline: Acrostic Answer
text: Acrostic answer for December 15, 2013

headline: Escape From the Pink Shag Rug
text: Back in 2008, Beth Antonelli — then Beth Freedman — bought a one-bedroom in Carroll Gardens. “I thought it was the practical thing to do,” she said. Her co-op cost $337,000, with monthly maintenance in the $500s.

headline: U.S. Suspends Nonlethal Aid to Syria Rebels
text: WASHINGTON — Just a month before a peace conference that will seek an end to the grinding civil war in Syria, the Obama administration’s decision to suspend the delivery of nonlethal aid to the moderate opposition demonstrated again the frustrations of trying to cultivate a viable alternative to President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Just the Facts, but Which Ones Are Included in Times Articles?
text: Now that we know the person of the year (at least according to Time magazine), I have a nomination for the understatement of the year. It’s this: New York Times readers examine the paper closely.

headline: Two Hirst Dot Works Are Stolen in London
text: LONDON — Two signed prints by Damien Hirst were stolen early Monday from a west London art gallery, the police said Wednesday. The two prints, part of Mr. Hirst’s series of multicolored dot artworks, were estimated by the manager of the Exhibitionist Gallery to be worth about $54,000. The larger of the two, Pyronin Y, measures 40 inches by 46 inches and was produced in 2005; the smaller one, Oleoylsarcosine, is 26 inches by 35 inches and dates from 2008.

headline: Carven: SoHo, by Way of the Gare du Nord
text: In the short four and a half years since Guillaume Henry set out to revive the venerable house of Carven, he has given the label a youthful new look, with the kind of flirty and flattering designs a cool young French girl would want to wear. There are 16 stores worldwide, including, now, its first in the United States, just opened in SoHo. For the new store, which was designed in collaboration with the architect Eric Chevalier, Mr. Henry (above right) was after something familiar and approachable, like a train station, perhaps, or an old theater. Along the wall as you enter the shop, there’s a long black leather bench made for Carven by the design house Domeau & Pérès. The plywood flooring is dyed red, and overhead, a captivating light installation gives the space a cheerful ambience.

headline: Police Question Parents in Baby’s Death
text: New York City police detectives on Wednesday questioned the parents of a 4-month-old boy who died on Tuesday night after he was taken to a Manhattan hospital unconscious and with signs of bruising on his hands, feet and back.

headline: Garth Brooks Hits No. 1 With a Walmart-Only Collection
text: Garth Brooks has scored his ninth No. 1 album on the Billboard chart with an eight-disc boxed set available only at Walmart.

headline: Are Women Just ‘Choosing’ Not to Pursue Science Careers?
text: The second editorial in our series about science and math education, which focuses on women and minorities, has sparked an impassioned debate among online commenters about the career choices women, and to a lesser extent minorities, make.

headline: Beastie Boys Continue Copyright Battle With Toy Company
text: Despite an earlier effort to broker peace between the Beastie Boys and a San Francisco-area toy company, the legal battle over a viral video that parodied one of the rap group’s songs goes on.

headline: Judith Regan Returns to Publishing by Joining Phaidon
text: Judith Regan, the publisher who was fired by HarperCollins in 2006, has landed a new job in the book business.

headline: An App That Will Never Forget a File
text: Some photos are on your smartphone. Others sit on your home computer. Your digital work documents, favorite web clippings and notes from meetings? Scattered like confetti after New Year’s Eve.

headline: App Smart: Winter Games
text: Apps for iOS and Android let you enjoy winter-themed games, including skiing and snowboarding, from the comfort of the indoors.

headline: Skier's Fresh Eyes Enable First Descent
text: In the third episode of Teton Gravity Research's Behind the Line, Angel Collinson impresses veteran athletes by skiing a technical line deep in the Neacola Mountains.

headline: Playing in Ice and Snow, Without Ever Venturing Outdoors
text: Yes, it’s cold outside. And yes, it’s getting slushy and dark and snowy and wet.

headline: Below the Line: Underwater With ‘All Is Lost’
text: J. C. Chandor’s drama “All Is Lost” is receiving accolades for the stoic, nearly wordless performance of Robert Redford. But the Indian Ocean, where Mr. Redford’s character is stranded, gives a pretty strong performance itself. Working with water, particularly  underwater, can be a challenge for filmmakers. So while Mr. Chandor used Frank G. DeMarco (“Margin Call”) as his cinematographer for the scenes outside the water, he hired a specialist in underwater photography for the wetter moments. That man, Peter Zuccarini, is one of the industry’s go-to cinematographers for underwater photography.

headline: Iran’s Hardliners, and Ours
text: There are several reasons to applaud – warily, provisionally – the first steps Iran, the United States and other world powers have taken toward a deal to prevent a Persian bomb. One reason for cheer is that the interim agreement has brought together the hard-liners, theirs and ours, in reciprocal dismay. When John Bolton, the most enthusiastic armchair warrior of the George W. Bush brigade, and Mohammad Reza Naqdi, the head of Iran’s brutal Basij paramilitary, are both unhappy, you’ve probably done something right.

headline: Bitcoin Believers See a Role for Wall Street
text: A venture capitalist, a former regulator, a lawyer and a pair of entrepreneurs — Bitcoin evangelists all — gathered on Tuesday in the private dining room of an upscale Manhattan restaurant to discuss their vision of a world in which the currency plays a role in mainstream finance.

headline: A Dancer’s Workout
text: Robert Fairchild, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, talks about his workout and his role in "The Nutcracker."

headline: That Unskewed Feeling
text: It goes without saying that Obamacare had a disastrous rollout. But it’s not October any more. Enrollment is rising fast, and administration officials — who have every reason not to overpromise after what happened last time — are sounding increasingly confident.

headline: The Gun Report: December 11, 2013
text: A year ago today, a gunman opened fire inside the Clackamas Town Center mall in Oregon, killing Cynthia Yuille, 54, and Steve Forsyth, 45, and seriously injuring 15-year-old Kristina Shevchenko. Clad in tactical clothing and a hockey mask, Jacob Tyler Roberts, 22, opened fire with a stolen AR-15 semiautomatic rifle near the food court and killed himself 22 minutes later. His motive is not known. There were between 8,000 and 10,000 shoppers in the mall that day.

headline: Sellers in 'Insomnia Is Good for You'
text: A clip from a short film by Peter Sellers that was recently discovered. Video provided by Dimwittie Films.

headline: The Workout: Dancing in ‘The Nutcracker’
text: Ballet looks elegant and effortless, but it is by far one of the most physically demanding professions. While all ballet dancers require flexibility, strength and stamina, male dancers also need tremendous core strength and stability to safely lift, carry and hold ballerinas in awkward positions.

headline: Struggle for Kiev Square Unfolds Live Online
text: Updated, 3:02 p.m. | As my colleagues David Herszenhorn and Andrew Kramer report from Kiev, the security forces failed to clear protesters from the city’s main square overnight, despite dismantling barricades and shoving against lines of demonstrators for hours in the freezing cold.

headline: Man Admits Role in Theft of $7 Million From Charity
text: The owner of a Long Island insurance company who was charged last month with helping a Jewish community leader loot more than $7 million from one of New York City’s most influential social service organizations pleaded guilty on Wednesday to charges in the scheme.

headline: House Hunting on Antigua
text: Moondance, a three-bedroom home with three guest cottages, is on the market for $3.25 million.

headline: House Hunting on ... Antigua
text: A PLANTATION-STYLE HOME WITH GUEST COTTAGES AND SEA VIEWS

headline: Sellers in 'Dearth of a Salesman'
text: A clip from a short film by Peter Sellers that was recently discovered. Video provided by Dimwittie Films.

headline: In Cuba, Ice Cream and Tolerance in a Rainbow of Varieties
text: Two revolutions clash in “Strawberry & Chocolate,” Senel Paz’s play set in Havana in the early 1980s: the Cuban one and a sexual one. “This country belongs to the revolutionaries,” says the bullying party-liner Miguel (Andhy Mendez), “not to the softies.”

headline: R.B.S. to Pay $100 Million to Settle Inquiries Into Violations of Sanctions
text: The Royal Bank of Scotland is paying $100 million in fines to New York and federal banking regulators to settle civil investigations into accusations that some of its former employees helped conceal transactions involving customers from Iran, Sudan and other nations subject to international sanctions for about a decade.

headline: Acrobatic Verbal Maneuvering
text: The Times’ Richard Sandomir asked Ray Hudson to describe his famously colorful style of calling soccer games, which he does from thousands of miles away, in a tiny booth in South Florida.

headline: Video: Skier’s Fresh Eyes Enable First Descent
text: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: After Clashes, Police Pull Out of Kiev Square
text: Ukraine’s authorities halted their crackdown in Independence Square after a night of clashes with protesters who have been rallying against the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovich.

headline: Trash Can Yields Two Long-Lost Peter Sellers Films
text: Two 1957 films by Peter Sellers, long thought to be lost, have been found by the building manager of the now-defunct Park Lane Films in London. The master prints of “Dearth of a Salesman” and “Insomnia is Good,” were in 21 film cans that the manager, Robert Farrow, salvaged from a trash can outside the building when the studios were cleared before to refurbishment in 1996.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Artisanal Cheese (and Crackers to Go With It)
text: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: What’s Going on in San Francisco?
text: It’s a city of very rich people and very poor people.

headline: A Tasty (and Cheap) Escape to Dutchess County, N.Y.
text: Pure Mountain Olive Oils and Vinegars in Rhinebeck, N.Y., is a lovely place to buy a $17.99 bottle of basil olive oil, should that fit your budget. But it’s also a lovely place to try some free, as I did on a recent visit, dousing a cube of cheese and grape tomato — a modified caprese salad on a toothpick. Also: a piece of crispy baguette toast or three slathered with asparagus pesto. And dozens more olive oils to sample solo (tasting instructions provided) or with chunks of bread. Was I overindulging? Apparently not.

headline: For Fashion Week, Striking Their Lincoln Center Tent
text: On Tuesday afternoon, a relaxed and witty Oscar de la Renta sat among a small group of fashion editors as models in matching black bobs showed 40 pieces from the designer’s pre-fall collection, a snow-dusted Bryant Park visible from the 25th-floor windows of his showroom.

headline: Manchester United Faces Doubter in the Market
text: The English soccer team Manchester United has made a poor showing on the field this season. Now the British hedge fund manager Crispin Odey is making a multimillion-dollar bet that the club’s New York-listed shares are destined for a similar trajectory.

headline: Wife Appeals for Release of Journalist Kidnapped in Syria
text: International news organizations, including the BBC, The Associated Press and The New York Times, have written a letter to the armed opposition in Syria asking for assurances that their journalists will not be abducted, as my colleague Ravi Somaiya reported.

headline: An Apology to Ronaldinho
text: Ray Hudson recounts one particular outburst that may have gone too far.

headline: What You Get For $1,250,000
text: This week’s homes include a farmhouse in Massachusetts, a brick house in Houston and a bungalow near the beach in California.

headline: What You Get For... $1,250,000
text: SHEFFIELD, MASS.

headline: In the Spirit of the Valley, It’s Silicon This and Silicon That
text: The sliver of land in Northern California between salt ponds and the Pacific Ocean has for many come to symbolize all that is prosperous and innovative in the world. Silicon Valley. The land of Google and Intel and Jobs.

headline: Vocal Acrobat Mixes Soccer Calls With Awe
text: MEDLEY, Fla. — About 4,400 miles from Spain, Ray Hudson is calling a Real Madrid game the way he always does: off a television screen in a tiny soundproof room in South Florida. Free from distractions, he delivers his analysis in the thick Geordie accent of his native Newcastle, and it is as ludicrous as it is informed, as grandiloquent as it is sharp-eyed.

headline: Bitcoin Fever: Using Digital Currency to Understand the Nature of Money
text: Overview | What are bitcoins, and why are people buying them? What makes currency valuable?

headline: Video: At a Bronx Fashion Bazaar
text: Lining Fordham Road in the Bronx are shops selling everything from bejeweled cellphone cases to the latest sneakers. “Fordham is one of the Bronx’s biggest fashion areas, so you see a lot of fashionable people around here,” Ann McField said as she was making a run to a fabric store on Fordham Road and Walton Avenue. “A lot of Jordans.”

headline: For Women, Hairstyles at the Barbershop
text: Like many women in New York, Katie Armour, editorial director of the digital magazine Matchbook, is absolutely devoted to her hairdresser. “He’s so wonderful, I know all about his family,” said Ms. Armour, 27, who travels from her apartment on the Upper East Side to the West Village once a month to get her hair done.

headline: Keep an Eye on Children, or Other Valuables
text: I still remember the baby monitor my parents had — my friends and I used it as a primitive walkie-talkie.

headline: A 'Fake' Sign Language Interpreter
text: The interpreter used at the memorial for Nelson Mandela was said to be an impostor.

headline: Obama’s Orwellian Image Control
text: THE Internet has been abuzz over the spectacle of President Obama and the prime ministers of Britain and Denmark snapping a photo of themselves — a “selfie,” to use the mot du jour — with a smartphone at the memorial service for Nelson Mandela in South Africa on Tuesday.

headline: Fantasy Football: Daily League Advice for Week 15 and Beyond
text: Working in the fantasy sports world, one of my long-term goals is to introduce daily fantasy sports (salary-cap-based leagues that redraft every week) to traditional season-long fantasy owners. That is why I just published a book about it.

headline: Detroit Symphony Hails Its Healthier Finances
text: The city of Detroit may be in bankruptcy, but the Detroit Symphony Orchestra is back in the black. The symphony planned to disclose on Thursday that it had balanced its budget for the first time since 2007. The orchestra ended the 2013 fiscal year with a small surplus after raising $18.9 million in contributions, a 43 percent increase over the year before. Ticket revenue rose to $6.26 million as the orchestra sold more subscriptions, it said.

headline: Hoping to Save the Remains of a Ming Dynasty Temple
text: First a printing press, then real estate developers, now a welding-machine factory. Everyone has taken a piece of Nianhua Si, or Picking Flowers Temple, a Ming dynasty place of worship in the storied Drum Tower district of Beijing.

headline: Fewer Psychiatrists Seen Taking Health Insurance
text: WASHINGTON — Psychiatrists are significantly less likely than doctors in other specialties to accept insurance, researchers say in a new study, complicating the push to increase access to mental health care.

headline: Big Change for China and the World
text: During his trip to China last week — a visit important for its timing and the difficult issues it tackled, principally in five hours of talks with President Xi Jinping — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had breakfast with American business leaders.

headline: Hilton Prices Its I.P.O. at $20 a Share
text: When Hilton Worldwide went private in a $26 billion deal with the Blackstone Group, it became one of the biggest companies ever to sell itself in a leveraged buyout.

headline: ‘American Hustle’: These Looks? They Deceive
text: In the new film “American Hustle,” a fictionalized account of the Abscam scandal at the height of the disco era, the looks are over the top. Dresses are tight, tight, tight. Jewelry is oversize. The men have comb-overs or pompadours or perms.

headline: Aide to Senator Is Arrested in Child Pornography Case
text: WASHINGTON — Federal law enforcement officers on Wednesday searched the Washington home of a chief of staff for Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, for child pornography.

headline: Sebelius’s Testimony in Two Minutes
text: As Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, testified before Congress, a Republican representative said that speaking to her was “like talking to the Republic of Korea.”

headline: In Store | Prada’s Vintage-Inspired Separates for a New Dover Street Market
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Baruch College Student Dies in Fraternity Pledge Ritual in Poconos
text: The game is called the Glass Ceiling, and it is played outside. It involves blindfolding a person and placing a heavy item on his back. He has to navigate to someone who is calling for him, and as he makes his way, others try to tackle him.

headline: Beatles by the Volume, Not Shy on the Footnotes
text: On Oct. 12 or Oct. 13, 1961, Paul McCartney and John Lennon visited the Hôtel de Beaune in Paris, near the Seine, to have their hair cut by a friend. Mark Lewisohn, billed on his book jacket as “the world’s only professional Beatles historian,” may know more about this seminal pop-cultural event than anyone else on the planet, including Mr. McCartney. The budding Beatle might have been too caught up in the moment to remember its exact details. Mr. Lewisohn has had some 50 years to parse them.

headline: Novelties at a Miami Art Basel Exhibition
text: MIAMI BEACH — Pharrell Williams’s bulletproof vest might not stop a snowflake. But that’s fine with Mr. Williams, who stopped at Art Basel Miami Beach last week to take in the art fairs and hawk a few wares of his own. His channel-quilted vests ($1,495) and mirrored shades ($595), created in collaboration with Moncler, were selling at a good clip at the Colette Art Drive-Thru, a pop-up installation by the influential Parisian retailer and the Alchemist shops on Lincoln Road here.

headline: Nick Kristof Answers Your Questions
text: On Monday readers were invited to ask Op-Ed columnist Nick Kristof questions on any topic. Dozens of readers asked Nick about subjects like the freedom of the press in China, President Obama’s second term agenda, whether the Middle East will ever have a Mandela-like figure, what he leaves out of his columns and more.

headline: Weinsteins Sue Warner Over Proceeds on ‘Hobbit’ Films
text: LOS ANGELES — Bob and Harvey Weinstein escalated a legal dispute over their claim to a share in the proceeds from the new “Hobbit” films by Warner Bros. with a lawsuit filed in a New York state court on Tuesday.

headline: Soap, Perfume and Cosmetics With Spice Notes
text: When it’s cold outside, a touch of spice in beauty products can be appealing, without the guilt of visiting the airport Cinnabon.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Africa, Ukraine, Central African Republic and Syria.

headline: Shopping for Investments in a Health Savings Account
text: HEALTH savings accounts have been around for a decade and more people are using them, but comparing the features of various accounts can still be challenging. Alternatives range from basic savings accounts offered by credit unions to those allowing investments in mutual funds or even individual stocks.

headline: European Copyright Laws Lead to Rare Music Releases
text: Thanks to a provision in the European Union’s new copyright law, fans of some musicians who made recordings in the 1960s are likely to be treated, for the foreseeable future, to annual batches of previously unissued material. But because artists and record labels are apparently unhappy about being forced to release material they would rather keep in the vaults, collectors need to be quick and alert: So far, the most tantalizing recordings have turned up in limited, hard-to-find editions. And where labels are normally eager to publicize their releases, they are doing their best to keep these ones secret.

headline: Fall North American Championships
text: PHOENIX — On the final day of the Fall North American Championships here on Sunday, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams was won by the defending champions, Team Monaco: Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness. They finished just over two boards ahead of Norberto Bocchi and Agustin Madala from Italy, Krzysztof Buras and Grzegorz Narkiewicz from Poland, and Aleksander Dubinin and Andrei Gromov from Russia. Third were Martin Fleisher, Chris Willenken and Zia Mahmood of New York City, Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J., Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif., and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.

headline: Alvin Ailey Dancers at City Center
text: The company reprised works by Paul Taylor, Rennie Harris and Ohad Naharin.

headline: Staying Aloft in Different Styles (With or Without Dress Suits)
text: For its second week in residence at City Center, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater reprised the three works that Robert Battle added to the company’s repertory when he became artistic director in 2011. Paul Taylor’s “Arden Court,” Rennie Harris’s “Home” and Ohad Naharin’s “Minus 16” afford a thorough, generous look at three styles: American modern dance, hip-hop and Gaga, the movement form invented by Mr. Naharin, an Israeli choreographer. How can a performer’s presence alter the stage’s canvas? How does subject matter, however veiled, become universal?

headline: Military Chief in Iran Scolds a Top Official
text: TEHRAN — The highest commander of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps of Iran lashed out at the country’s foreign minister on Wednesday, telling him to stick to diplomacy and stay out of military business.

headline: Aramark Prices Its I.P.O. at $20, Low End of Range
text: Aramark, the big food services company, priced its initial public offering on Wednesday at $20 a share, the low end of its expected range.

headline: For No. 2 at Fed, White House Favors Central Banker in the Bernanke Mold
text: WASHINGTON — Stanley Fischer, the former governor of the Bank of Israel and a mentor to the Federal Reserve’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, is the leading candidate to become vice chairman of the Fed, according to former and current administration officials.

headline: Prison Memoir of a Black Man in the 1850s
text: Years ago, a rare-books dealer browsing at an estate sale in Rochester came across an unusual manuscript, dated 1858. The family selling it said little about where it had been for the last 150 years. It appeared never to have left upstate New York.

headline: Roberto Cavalli’s Tuscan Restaurant, in Miami Beach
text: MIAMI BEACH — “Art Basel, I don’t go,” Roberto Cavalli said the other day. “I don’t like.” The perma-tanned Florentine lifestyle impresario was in town to oversee construction on Cavalli Miami, his soon-to-open restaurant and lounge on Ocean Drive.

headline: Serving Up Folky Americana With Holiday Toppings
text: In 2005, the songwriter Sam Beam, who records as Iron and Wine, and the Tucson band Calexico released an EP they recorded together, “In the Reins,” giving Mr. Beam’s songs some of Calexico’s Southwestern, country-mariachi flavor. Christmastime brings family reunions, and for its annual Holiday Cheer benefit concert, on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, the Americana-loving public radio station WFUV (90.7 FM) brought Iron and Wine and Calexico back together, adding other sometime collaborators and kindred spirits: Kathleen Edwards, Beth Orton, Nick Lowe, Glen Hansard and Amos Lee. Calexico backed them all, jovial and versatile.

headline: Holiday Cheer
text: Beth Orton, Nick Lowe and Glen Hansard were among the artists joining Calexico and Iron and Wine at the Beacon Theater.

headline: Strictly Tongue in Chic
text: Fashion logo parody T-shirts include “Giraunchy” and “Ballinciaga.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Snapchat Raises $50 Million, and Encountering an All-Too Convincing Robot
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Killing Game Takes in New Players
text: When you’re No. 4, you can try harder or you can give up and peddle cat videos. It’s a pleasant surprise that Crackle — the video site owned by Sony that in public awareness comes somewhere south of Netflix, Amazon and Hulu — keeps making an honest effort.

headline: Canadian Utility Buys UNS Energy of Arizona for $2.5 Billion
text: Fortis, the biggest gas and electricity distribution utility in Canada, is making a move into the desert.

headline: Tokya: a Japanese-Themed Dance Club
text: In the quiet canyons of Midtown Manhattan after dark, a short stretch of East 58th Street has become a night-life micro district jammed with town cars, velvet ropes and paparazzi. Now a Japanese-inspired nightclub called Tokya has joined the fray. Across the street from Lavo and next door to the reality-star hub Tao, this subterranean space may be smaller and more intimate, but it parties just as hard.

headline: Times Minute | Sebelius Grilled
text: Also on the Minute, Spotify adds Led Zeppelin and a sign language interpreter at Mandela’s memorial is an impostor.

headline: Times Minute | Sebelius Grilled
text: In the Video

headline: Wheelies: The Down Under and Away Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Police Clash With Kiev Protesters
text: The New York Times’ David M. Herszenhorn reports from Kiev on the Ukrainian security raids early Wednesday on the protesters’ camp in Independence Square.

headline: Sales at David Weeks, Claireware and Others
text: David Weeks is discounting lamps, sconces and chandeliers up to 95 percent Friday and Saturday (standing Monopod lamps, regularly $3,500, will be $1,300); cash or check only; 68 Jay Street (Water Street), Suite 612A, Brooklyn; 718-596-7945, davidweeksstudio.com.

headline: At a French Museum, Peeks at Nureyev’s World
text: MOULINS, France — Like his fabled appetites for dance and sex, Rudolf Nureyev’s hunger for collecting was insatiable. By 1983, when he was 45 and became director of the Paris Opera Ballet, he was the rock star of dance and a very rich man, with homes all over the world filled with treasures.

headline: Is There a Looming Doctor Shortage?
Foreign Aid Saves Lives. It’s Good Policy, Too.
