headline: Obama Greets Raúl Castro
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Lesson From Newtown
text: To the Editor:

headline: A ‘Paltry’ Year-End Tip?
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Amsterdam, Paid in Beer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mets Are Said to Spend Again, Agreeing to 2-Year Deal With Colon
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — When Matt Harvey, the Mets’ ace, was lost for the 2014 season to Tommy John surgery, it was generally assumed the Mets’ season would be lost as well. Sandy Alderson, the team’s general manager, spoke about living with certain weaknesses on the roster and about spending wisely, which was interpreted to mean that the Mets would do more to sign free agents this off-season but maybe not a whole lot more.

headline: A Continental Feast for the Eyes and the Ears
text: Imagine attending a circus, a dance performance and a world music concert, all in one day. It would be exhausting, not to mention mind-boggling to schedule. But now this feat can be accomplished in a single location in about 100 minutes: It’s called “Mother Africa.”

headline: One Best Actor, So Many Possibilities
text: Christian Bale more or less looks like himself in “Out of the Furnace,” which is something of a feat. As an ex-con mill worker in Scott Cooper’s working-class drama, Mr. Bale, a performer capable of extreme physical transformation, sports longish hair and a goatee, as he often does off screen. And, on his neck, a tattoo of the ZIP code of Braddock, Pa., where the movie is set.

headline: Facebook to Join S.&P. 500
text: Facebook stock jumped close to 4 percent in after-hours trading on Wednesday on news that the social media giant would join the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index at the end of next week.

headline: Major League Baseball Plans to Ban Collisions at Home Plate
text: It is an iconic part of baseball: A player rounds third base, sprints toward home plate and barrels into the catcher at full speed.

headline: Hey, Mediocrity, Two Wizards Want You Gone
text: White-faced creatures in silver headpieces hand out beaded necklaces at the door, onyx-hued for those who choose to back the Black Wizard, navy for those cheering on the Blue. Just inside, color-coded cocktails are served in tiny cups: for Blue’s partisans, a concoction of rum, Blue Curaçao and lime juice; for Black’s, bourbon and coffee liqueur. Later, for some, there will be doughnut holes.

headline: Video Shows Moment of Impact of Asiana Flight 214
text: In  video of the July 6 crash of Asiana Airlines flight 214 that was newly released Wednesday by the National Transportation Safety Board, the plane can be seen tumbling down the runway and making a dramatic cartwheel after hitting the sea wall at San Francisco International Airport, breaking off the back of the fuselage.

headline: Thai Prime Minister Facing Leadership Questions Old and New
text: BANGKOK — When Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra’s former high school teachers learned she had become Thailand’s first female prime minister, they were concerned.

headline: Met Opera ‘Audition’ Winners, 6 Years After
text: Catching up with the winners of the 2007 Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions.

headline: Brooklyn Is Roasting by an Open Fire
text: Bucolic Brooklyn, the borough of beehives, chicken coops, farm-to-table restaurants and rooftop vegetable gardens, is annexing another back-to-nature accouterment: the fire pit.

headline: Seasonal Shopping Events Starting Dec. 12
text: Openings

headline: No Tie-Dye Required
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A few weeks ago, Mike North ambled up the steps of his home in the Lower Haight neighborhood here, feeling blissed out. Fresh from a 90-minute yoga class with live music and an instructor who had worn fishnet stockings and high heels, he was looking forward to a quiet, relaxing evening.

headline: Europeans Pay Less for Mobile Use, but at a Cost
text: LONDON — Europeans are paying almost two-thirds less for their cellphone contracts than their counterparts in the United States, according to a report to be published Thursday by the British telecommunications regulator.

headline: The Appalling Stance of Rand Paul
text: I don’t put much past politicians. I stay prepared for the worst. But occasionally someone says something so insensitive that it catches me flat-footed.

headline: English Hand Press Used by Designer William Morris Is Sold for $233,000
text: The 122-year-old English hand press that was used by the designer William Morris to produce “The Works of Geoffrey Chaucer,” his ornate masterpiece of decorative printing, has been acquired by the Rochester Institute of Technology for its Cary Graphic Arts Collection.

headline: The Mirror of Guantánamo
text: A decision last week by the federal appeals court in Washington, rejecting yet another Guantánamo detainee’s challenge to his continued confinement, left barely a ripple in the vast, still pond of Guantánamo litigation. Yet its very ordinariness makes the case of Ali v. Obama worth a few minutes’ consideration as another detention year, the 12th, draws to a close.

headline: Development Blitz Provokes a Murmur of Dissent in Monaco
text: MONACO — As protests go, it was tiny: just a handful of people gathering quietly at a condemned building they thought should not be torn down. But in a place where dissent is rare, the demonstration counted as daring, even radical.

headline: Paul Ryan Discusses Budget Deal
text: Representative Ryan and Senator Patty Murray agreed on a budget plan that could possibly prevent another government shutdown.

headline: ‘Intentional Communities’
text: Communes, former politically idealistic (and cheap) ways for hippies to live, are springing up in large San Francisco Bay Area houses colonized by Silicon Valley 20-somethings.

headline: Bipartisan Budget Deal Puts Ryan Under Fire From Fellow Conservatives
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s eight terms in Congress have produced much political celebrity and Republican respect but just two laws bearing the Ryan name — a renamed post office and a modified excise tax on arrows like the ones he uses for bow hunting.

headline: Canada to Stop Delivering Mail to City Homes Over 5 Years
text: WATERLOO, Ontario — Canada’s postal service said Wednesday that it would cease home delivery over the next five years, and substantially increase postal rates.

headline: Fashion Logo Parodies, Strictly Tongue in Chic
text: Some people spend hundreds, even thousands of dollars to ensure that designers’ logos are prominently featured on their handbags, sneakers and jackets. But for $28, a different kind of fashion-insider cachet, knowing and impudent, can be bought. That’s the price of a T-shirt from Reason Clothing, whose apparel uses nearly identical fonts of high-fashion labels to turn Dior into “Poor,” Fendi into “Trendi,” or Balmain into “Nawman.”

headline: Charlamagne Tha God: Keeping a Hot Seat Warm
text: Charlamagne Tha God, the shock-jock host of 105.1’s morning show, “The Breakfast Club,” has a penchant for making his guests squirm.

headline: The Turf Is Their Runway
text: Cam Newton, 24, the star quarterback of the Carolina Panthers, apparently isn’t content with typical statistics like passing yards or completion percentage. Despite his team’s recent eight-game win streak (which ended Sunday with a loss to the New Orleans Saints) and a definite shot at the playoffs, Mr. Newton has another form of gridiron expression in mind.

headline: Waris Ahluwalia: A Ubiquitous Presence, However Unlikely
text: What better place to debut a jewelry collection by Waris Ahluwalia than the regal Explorers Club on the Upper East Side? With its wood paneling, stained-glass windows and imposing stuffed animals shot by ruling-class rifles, it seemed to be art-directed for someone who might be mistaken for European aristocracy or Indian royalty.

headline: JPMorgan Plans to Unveil a Program for Job Skills
text: When Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago received a call earlier this year asking if he would support a new jobs initiative from JPMorgan Chase, he replied with his typical bluntness.

headline: Nigella Lawson: Another Chef Lands in the Soup
text: Last week, the celebrity cook Nigella Lawson admitted in a London court that she had used cocaine and marijuana.

headline: Autographs of the Formerly Famous
text: “Keir Dullea, gone tomorrow,” Noël Coward once quipped about the handsome actor, who is probably best known for playing the astronaut in “2001: A Space Odyssey.”

headline: Mourning Son Killed at 15, and Celebrating His Life
text: The living room of Sharon Cherry’s third-floor apartment in Harlem looks out over a playground, yet feels like a shrine. Two walls are adorned with poster-size photographs of a fresh-faced teenage boy, staring straight at the camera; Ms. Cherry wears a T-shirt printed with an image of the same face. “My son,” she said, tears already starting to stream down her face, “George White.”

headline: As Winter Nears, Chinese Capital Is Blanketed in Green
text: BEIJING — Sooty skies are not the only reliable indicator that winter has finally descended on the Chinese capital. Vendors selling roasted sweet potatoes occupy street corners with their repurposed oil-drum ovens. To ward off the sniffles, Beijing cabdrivers nibble on cloves of raw garlic, making taxi rides especially trying.

headline: How to Truly Honor Mandela
text: World leaders, including President Obama, are jostling for the chance to celebrate Nelson Mandela this week, which would surely make Mandela smile. He had a mischievous sense of humor, and he knew better than anybody that the United States and other countries now embracing him had spurned him when he could have actually used the help.

headline: Republicans Running in Reverse
text: Let’s hear it for women in high places.

headline: Former Quarterback Sues League Over Hits to the Head
text: The former star quarterback Craig Morton sued the N.F.L. in Federal District Court in Northern California on Tuesday, accusing the league of deliberately hiding information about the dangerous effects of head hits and concussions.

headline: Should Democracies Have Monarchs?
text: Thailand's king was once seen as a steadying hand in the nation's rocky politics. But does that kind of intervention help or hinder?

headline: Goodell Says Miami Case May Lead to New Workplace Rules
text: IRVING, Tex. — N.F.L. players should expect rule changes next year regarding behavior in locker rooms and with teammates in the wake of reports of bullying on the Miami Dolphins.

headline: The Ultimate Meltdown
text: What makes a $100 candle worth having?

headline: Luxury Candles’ Trial by Fire
text: For the last three weeks, my apartment has looked like a New Age temple and smelled, at various times, like fresh-cut grass, a Roman church, tomatoes and a Cuban tobacco barn. But was it really transformed?

headline: Waxing Extravagant
text: Recently I went shopping for candles and ended up spending nearly $900. I know what you’re thinking: Outrageous, right? I thought the same thing.

headline: Accused of Harming Bees, Bayer Researches a Different Culprit
text: MONHEIM, Germany — Bayer cares about the bees.

headline: Pepsi Deal Underscores an Emphasis on Snacks
text: In an unusual deal that goes far beyond the soda wars, PepsiCo is to announce on Thursday that it is unseating Coca-Cola as the beverage supplier to one of the nation’s hottest restaurant chains, Buffalo Wild Wings.

headline: The Play at the Plate: Safer
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Bruce Bochy spent his first career in baseball as a catcher, his second as a manager. He has absorbed the crush of oncoming base runners and felt the sickening despair of witnessing his own catchers’ injuries in collisions at the plate.

headline: Ex-Officer Is Cleared in Hurricane Katrina Shooting
text: NEW ORLEANS — A former New Orleans police officer who was convicted three years ago in the shooting death of a civilian in the days after Hurricane Katrina, but was granted a retrial on appeal, was acquitted Wednesday on all counts.

headline: Rivers Returns as Foe, but Not a Hated One
text: BOSTON — Doc Rivers spent nine years in Boston, a stretch that lasted longer than his playing career in Atlanta and any other stint in his life since his childhood on the South Side of Chicago. He presided over a team that lost a franchise-record 18 consecutive games in 2007 and a team that won an N.B.A. championship a year later.

headline: Zeus Jones to Open San Francisco Office
text: ZEUS JONES, a consultancy that specializes in tasks for brands like digital, design, social media and content creation, is joining a parade of advertising agencies opening in San Francisco by hiring a well-known senior executive based in the Bay Area.

headline: U.S. Colleges Finding Ideals Tested Abroad
text: WELLESLEY, Mass. — Members of the Wellesley College faculty reacted strongly when word spread that Peking University might fire Prof. Xia Yeliang, a critic of the Chinese government. Professor Xia, an economist, had visited Wellesley over the summer after the college signed a partnership agreement with Peking University.

headline: Have We Met?
text: LONDON — Imagine entering the boardroom and meeting for the first time each of the company’s 15 directors. These are important people in your life; you’ll be expected to recognize them when you next meet.

headline: N.C.A.A. Change Is Coming, Maybe
text: Throughout Wednesday morning, some of the most important people in college sports settled into ballrooms on the seventh floor of the Marriott Marquis in Manhattan. There was talk and talk and more talk, forums and discussions and presentations. There were athletic directors and administrators and N.C.A.A. officials.

headline: Montefiore Faces Neighborhood Opposition to Medical Complex in Bronx
text: A new medical center in the Bronx might seem like a welcome addition to a borough of 1.4 million residents facing a growing health crisis from obesity, diabetes, asthma and chronic diseases.

headline: Hometown Remembers Madiba the Villager, Well Before Mandela the Icon
text: QUNU, South Africa — Nelson Mandela was on one of his early morning walks here in his rural home village when he spotted an old friend loosening up the soil on his land with a donkey-drawn plow. Mr. Mandela contemplated the sight, and though he was president at the time, he promptly and inexplicably took over.

headline: The Toll From Three Deadly Diseases
text: International health agencies at the United Nations have documented enormous gains made over the past decade to curb three devastating diseases: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. Despite this great progress, there is still a big gap between what’s been accomplished and what more could be done with sufficient financing.

headline: Bargain-Basement Prices at a New York Hospital Prove Too Good to Be True
text: Knee joint replacements at one-tenth the next cheapest price statewide! Baby deliveries below what they cost the hospital! At such discounts, one could imagine New Yorkers trekking three hours from Times Square to a small upstate hospital to fix an aching joint or to give birth, considering that some Americans fly overseas for surgery to escape high costs.

headline: India’s Reversal on Gay Rights
text: India’s Supreme Court issued a disgraceful ruling against human rights in reinstating a law that bans gay sex. On Wednesday, the court reversed a landmark 2009 decision by the Delhi High Court that decriminalized sex between consenting adults regardless of their gender.

headline: The Minimalist Budget Deal
text: For most of this year, the brutal cuts to federal spending known as the sequester have wreaked havoc on important programs, cutting off hundreds of thousands from Head Start and low-income housing assistance, setting back scientific research and environmental protection, and costing more than a million jobs. Getting rid of the sequester for domestic programs was a high priority for Congressional Democrats, and they achieved much of what they wanted in a budget deal reached on Tuesday that in other important respects was disappointing.

headline: Joe Bihari, Who Put Early R&B on Record, Dies at 88
text: Soon after the Bihari brothers started leasing jukeboxes in black neighborhoods of Los Angeles in the early 1940s, they realized they had a problem. While their business had a solid distribution network of stores, bars and restaurants, they could not find enough records to play in their machines.

headline: Deal for Bronx Soccer Stadium in Works as Clock Ticks
text: The owners of New York’s new professional soccer team and the Bloomberg administration are nearing a tentative agreement to build the city’s first soccer-only venue: a $350 million, 28,000-seat stadium near Yankee Stadium in the Bronx.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 12, 2013
text: “He gave me my freedom. I can wait a little longer.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 11, 2013
A Final Farewell to Mandela
text: Onthatile Mokoena, 20, was born in South Africa with opportunities and freedoms that her parents were not afforded. She joined thousands at the Mandela memorial to give thanks and pay respects.

headline: Police Break Up Luxury Car Theft Ring and Arrest 16
text: The car thieves plied their trade with a certain finesse. No windows were broken or doors pried. Rather, they focused on stealing the high-tech keys of prestigious brands like Bentley, BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Porsche.

headline: Bronx Courts Make Gains in Reducing Case Backlog
text: Judges and prosecutors in the Bronx have reduced a crippling backlog of felony cases by more than half in the last 11 months, but the borough’s courts still lag behind the rest of New York City in dispensing justice, court officials announced on Wednesday.

headline: No Longer ‘Robot,’ Smith Reprograms Outlook
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — David Lee, the Jets’ quarterbacks coach, spoke during minicamp about efforts by the rookie Geno Smith to learn a new playbook in a new system. This was before Smith was named the starter, when the staff was still evaluating him.

headline: Corrections: December 12, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Dare to be Stupid
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I usually begin the blog posts for puzzles like this one by David Steinberg by saying something like “No, you’re not crazy.” And you’re not. In fact, if you’re not sure what you should be doing with this theme, pull up a seat and join the club. I eventually figured it out, but it was rough going there for a while.

headline: Criminal Action Is Expected for JPMorgan in Madoff Case
text: JPMorgan Chase and federal authorities are nearing settlements over the bank’s ties to Bernard L. Madoff, striking tentative deals that would involve roughly $2 billion in penalties and a rare criminal action. The government will use a sizable portion of the money to compensate Mr. Madoff’s victims.

headline: An Indispensable Player on Obama’s Team Takes His Leave, at Last
text: WASHINGTON — Pete Rouse, President Obama’s “indispensable man” with a low profile and big footprint, is the quirky insider who built the Obama organization, hired nearly everyone from the White House chief of staff on down, plotted strategy and regularly said he was about to leave.

headline: New Film, ‘Out of the Furnace,’ Accused of Stereotyping Ramapough Indians
text: MAHWAH, N.J. — The past week has been unsettling for the Ramapough Mountain Indians, who live on this northern stretch of the Appalachian Mountains that overlooks the Manhattan skyline and wealthy parts of Bergen County. The new movie “Out of the Furnace,” featuring a star-studded cast that includes Christian Bale and Woody Harrelson, also features numerous negative references to the Ramapoughs. They include a fight-ring subplot.

headline: Madoff Trustee’s 2010 JPMorgan Suit
text: A series of internal JPMorgan emails suggesting that employees had concerns about the bank’s ties to Bernard L. Madoff. Some of the emails surfaced in a lawsuit filed by the trustee for Mr. Madoff’s victims.

headline: Slow Progress on Support for Women’s Museum
text: WASHINGTON — A House committee hearing on Wednesday to consider a bill that could ultimately lead to the construction of a women’s history museum here showed little sign that the initiative was gathering the momentum it needs to end a 10-year struggle for congressional approval.

headline: Hagel Lifts Veil on Major Military Center in Qatar
text: AL UDEID AIR BASE, Qatar — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s visit to the advanced air operations center here this week was not just a stop at an important outpost of the United States military. It was also a major step forward for Pentagon transparency.

headline: On Sturdier Ankles, Williams Bolsters Nets’ Offense
text: The sight of Deron Williams zooming around the court Tuesday night sent a jolt through the Nets.

headline: Shares in Chinese ‘Bad Bank’ Surge in Hong Kong Debut
text: HONG KONG — Shares in the state-run ‘‘bad bank’’ China Cinda Asset Management rose as much as 33 percent on their trading debut in Hong Kong on Thursday after the bank raised around $2.5 billion last week on huge demand for its initial public offering.

headline: Giants Focus on Winning What They Can
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — General Manager Jerry Reese used the heady days of training camp in the summer to post a calendar on the Giants’ bulletin board that counted down the days to Super Bowl XLVIII at MetLife Stadium on Feb. 2.

headline: New Act Proposes National Paid Family Leave Policy
text: For years, the United States has been criticized for its status as an extreme world outlier in its support for families. After Australia passed its parental leave law in 2010, the United States became the only industrialized nation not to offer paid maternity leave. That failing has contributed to the United States’ being condemned for human rights violations by Human Rights Watch.  The United States also ranked last in breast-feeding support by Save the Children. The case for national paid family leave has been brought up by everyone from feminist academics to Fox News anchors — and me.

headline: Rangers, Reeling at Home, Are Now Short-Handed, Too
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Winless three games into a record nine-game homestand, the Rangers can perhaps gain inspiration from familiar faces.

headline: Texas Plan to Execute Mexican May Harm U.S. Ties Abroad, Kerry Says
text: HOUSTON — The scheduled execution next month of a Mexican national by the State of Texas threatens to damage relations between the United States and Mexico and complicate the ability of the United States to help Americans detained overseas, Secretary of State John F. Kerry has warned Texas officials.

headline: House of Hard Knocks
text: Rescuing an old stone farmhouse in France required a dig through layers of junk and concrete.

headline: An Archaeological Rehab
text: For 20 years, the old stone house on the hill stood empty, the forest surrounding it creeping ever closer. The house’s elderly owner had died, leaving it to relatives who were in no hurry to sell and had priced it accordingly.

headline: A Live-In Love Triangle Ends in a Beating Death
text: There were family outings at the beach, homemade pizza nights, a wintry day spent making a dreadlocked snowman — evidence of a secret life in Queens that seemed happy, if unconventional.

headline: Queens Site May Be Added to Superfund List
text: The site of a defunct chemical company in Ridgewood, Queens, that was involved in atom-bomb research will “very likely” be added to the federal Superfund list, an Environmental Protection Agency official said on Wednesday.

headline: Here’s Looking Through You, Kid
text: An overnight stay in Philip Johnson’s Glass House, where many have peeked but few have slept.

headline: Bedtime Under Glass
text: New Canaan, Conn. — The weekend crowds blocking Ponus Ridge Road in December of 1948 were in a holiday mood, The New York Times reported. Hundreds from “this conservative old community of early colonial homes” turned out to watch workers put the finishing touches on a house few could have predicted would become a modernist classic.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 15 Matchup Breakdown
text: From a fantasy football perspective, fewer N.F.L. teams have been more unpredictable than the Indianapolis Colts.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Chargers (6-7) at Broncos (11-2)
text: 8:25 p.m., NFL Network

headline: Pass the Cassoulet ... And the Memories
text: Stamped with symbols representing life experiences (a mountain, a torn heart and a pizza slice, to name just a few), Grail, a cassoulet dish from the design firm Grain, is intended to inspire mealtime conversation. “We used contemporary icons of things you would encounter in the city, traveling or online, but applied them to a more timeless piece, almost like Egyptian hieroglyphs,” said James Minola, who founded the Bainbridge Island, Wash., company with his wife, Chelsea. “We imagine people sitting around it at a table; maybe one of these icons speaks to you and reminds you of a story to share.”

headline: Rare Gems from Ettore Sottsass
text: Ettore Sottsass designed furniture, ceramics, dishware, jewelry, fashion boutiques, an apartment for Gianni Agnelli and, perhaps most famously, the red Valentine typewriter for Olivetti. This Austrian-born, Milan-based architect and designer also led a Zelig-like social life, founding the influential Memphis group and becoming friends with a diverse coterie that included Allen Ginsberg, Helmut Newton and Karl Lagerfeld.

headline: Stopping by the Woods at Dusk (or Dawn)
text: The wallpaper company Trove’s latest pattern, called Trace, was inspired by a summer road trip through Yellowstone. “There had been a fire, and as we drove through we saw many stages of the forest, in growth but also in death,” said Jee Levin, a founder of Trove with Randall Buck. The couple, who were introducing their 7-year-old son, Sebastian, to the park, photographed trees that were rugged and imperfect. Back in New York, they designed what Ms. Levin called “our own forest.” The result is a romantic image of a silhouetted woods at dusk sitting above its hand-drawn mirror image. Flip the piece and it looks like a forest at dawn. Trace is one of three patterns in Trove’s winter collection, which will be formally released next month. It is 12 feet high with a 67-inch-wide repeat, and is $16 a square foot. Information: 212-268-2046 or troveline.com.

headline: New York City Backs Off Moving Court to TriBeCa
text: After an uproar and a lawsuit by TriBeCa residents, New York City agreed in a settlement to withdraw plans to move a criminal summons court there, the plaintiffs announced Wednesday.

headline: Fabrics Put Through the Wringer
text: Since 2000, Mary Bergtold Mulcahy has been designing block-printed organic cottons with Srinivas Pitchuka, a textile artisan in India. Working in a tradition called kalamkari, Mr. Pitchuka bleaches the textiles in the sun, washes them in the river, beats them against stones to make them soft and boils them. Then he prints them with vegetable dyes. Last month, Ms. Mulcahy opened Les Indiennes, a shop in Hudson, N.Y., that sells the fabric as quilts, pillow covers, tablecloths and yardage, along with miscellaneous home accessories. Most of the items cost up to 70 percent less than the same goods sold online or through other retailers. Eighteen-inch-square pillow covers are $25. Painted eggshell ornaments from the Czech Republic are $5 each. Les Indiennes is at 444 Warren Street, Hudson, N.Y. Information: 518-828-2811 or lesindiennes.com.

headline: With a Whoosh and a Zoom: Cleaning Tools
text: To some, cleaning house means making a casual tour with the vacuum and taking a few jabs at the toilet with a soapy brush. Not Sabrina Fierman. As vice president of New York’s Little Elves, a cleaning firm used by many designers and contractors, she takes the job to a level that would satisfy the most obsessive germaphobe.

headline: Embracing Miami’s Past and Future
text: Allan Shulman, the 51-year-old principal of the architectural firm Shulman & Associates in Miami, first became known for historic preservation. He rescued the 1915 Browns Hotel on lower Ocean Drive, which was built of pine. And he found a way to save much of the Art Deco Lincoln Theater on Lincoln Road, turning it into a stylish glass-walled H & M store. His new, 5,000-square-foot Miami Center for Architecture and Design (known as MCAD) opened last Friday in part of the 1912 main Miami Post Office, on Northeast First Avenue, in Downtown Miami. Over the years, the building had suffered much indignity, including a spell as an Office Depot. Now, as the new headquarters of the American Institute of Architects Miami chapter, it will be a place for free community events as well as professional gatherings. Speaking by phone from his office in the Miami Design District, Mr. Shulman, president of the Miami chapter, offered details about MCAD and opinions on the city’s building scene. (The interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Federer and His Agent Start Their Own Firm Representing Athletes
text: In the latest shift in a sports management business that appears to be trending toward the boutique, Roger Federer has joined with his longtime agent Tony Godsick and two American investors to form an agency called Team8.

headline: Christian Bale’s Character Secrets
text: An interview with the star of “American Hustle” and “Out of the Furnace.”

headline: A New Wave of Bold, Flat Sandals
text: Retailers are stocked to the gills with warm-weather wear from resort collections, including this new breed of chic yet comfortable sandals. Perfect for a tropical escape, they are the bold, stylish descendants of Japanese geta clogs and crunchy Birkenstocks. Simple, shiny versions from Céline and Chloé go well with any look, while printed options from Giambattista Valli and Givenchy are enough to make an outift. Crisscrossed straps get the leather-and-lace treatment thanks to Marc Jacobs, Robert Clergerie and No. 21. But the crystal-embellished slides from Marni and plush, allover-velvet shoes from Sonia Rykiel are true standouts in this utilitarian category of style.

headline: Broader Approach Urged to Reduce Gun Violence
text: The most effective way to reduce gun violence without significantly curtailing Second Amendment rights is to treat the problem as a public health issue, like smoking or drunken driving, rather trying to profile potential shooters, according to a report released Thursday by a panel of experts who were commissioned by the American Psychological Association to study the issue in the wake of the Newtown, Conn., massacre.

headline: De Blasio on the Move: Comparing 2 Houses
text: They are separated by all of eight miles. But the rowhouse in Park Slope, Brooklyn, that Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio is leaving and Gracie Mansion, the Upper East Side residence he is about to inhabit, are quite different.

headline: Shopify Raises $100 Million in Third Round of Financing
text: Shopify may have begun seven years ago as an online store for three friends to sell snowboards. But as the company’s growth has exploded, so has its goal: becoming a giant of commerce, both on and off the web.

headline: Health Care Prices Move to Center Stage
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Word of the Day | disapprobation
text: disapprobation •\(ˌ)dis-ˌa-prə-ˈba-shən\• noun

headline: Week 15 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Fight for a Wild Card
text: One of the more interesting matchups this weekend is the New England-Miami game.

headline: Showing Desperation, the Knicks Stave Off a Defeat
text: The Knicks had a heap of problems to address before Wednesday night’s game against the Chicago Bulls, and if that was not readily apparent to the players, the coaching staff made sure to drill the message home.

headline: Two Ex-Mets Getting Look From Yankees
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — With uncertainty surrounding the Japanese pitcher Masahiro Tanaka, the Yankees have had preliminary discussions with the agents for two former Mets, Johan Santana and Mike Pelfrey, in the pursuit of starting pitching.

headline: The L Train Has Been Rerouted to the Garden
text: Almost without exception, this has been a bad year for the New York area’s major sports teams. Even the Yankees tumbled. But nothing can quite compare with the almost daily misery being inflicted on fans who show up at Madison Square Garden. In the last month, the Rangers and the Knicks have combined for 12 losses in 15 home games.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 9:30 A.M. (Starz) TO ROME WITH LOVE (2012) In Woody Allen’s tribute to the Italian cinema of the 1950s and ’60s, a retired and overly psychoanalyzed music promoter (Mr. Allen) travels with his wife (Judy Davis) to Rome, where their daughter (Alison Pill) has lost her heart to a lawyer devoted to left-wing causes (Flavio Parenti). Meanwhile, in this shuffled anthology, a young newlywed loses her way to the Trevi Fountain and falls into the arms of a movie star while her befuddled husband tries to keep his relatives in the dark, substituting a prostitute (Penélope Cruz) for her at dinner. An ordinary Roman (Roberto Benigni) is plunged into a swirl of media celebrity. And a fledgling architect (Jesse Eisenberg) finds his relationship with his kind, if bland, girlfriend (Greta Gerwig) in shreds when her neurotic actress friend visits. Alec Baldwin plays the older architect — a ghost? a specter of the younger man’s self? — who witnesses the ordeal. “One of the most delightful things about ‘To Rome With Love’ is how casually it blends the plausible and the surreal, and how unabashedly it revels in pure silliness,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The movie’s limitations, “as frothy as the milk atop a cappuccino, are finally inseparable from its delights.” Complaining, he added, “would be as superfluous — though also, perhaps, as inevitable — as psychoanalysis.”

headline: After Muzaffarnagar Riots, a Standoff over Government Compensation
text: SHAMLI, Uttar Pradesh—On a sunny winter afternoon last week, 12-year-old Gulbaar drifted among the dusty pile of rocks that marked the graves of infants and children in a cemetery close to the camp called Malakpur. The camp houses more than 7,000 Muslims who have taken refuge here since violence broke out three months ago between Muslims and the Jat clan of the Hindus in the nearby districts of Shamli and Muzaffarnagar in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Familiar Ring to Retired Propaganda Chief’s Ode to an Ugly Bird
text: The Chinese Communist Party’s former propaganda chief has found a kind of post-retirement fame in a paean to an unsightly, scavenging stork and garish video to match.

headline: Former Banker at Morgan Stanley in Hong Kong to Pay Restitution to Investors
text: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong court on Thursday ordered a former Morgan Stanley banker who was jailed for insider dealing to pay civil compensation of about $3 million to nearly 300 investors.

headline: Tempers Flare as New Rules Strain Senate
text: WASHINGTON — If there is a rock bottom in the frayed relationship between Senate Republicans and Democrats, it seemed uncomfortably close as the final days of 2013 on Capitol Hill degenerated into something like an endurance contest to see who could be the most spiteful.

headline: Inside the Power of the N.R.A.
text: To get to Joe Manchin’s private office in the Hart Senate Office Building, you first pass through a lobby where you encounter a small bronze statue of an Old West lawman holding a firearm — an award given to Manchin several years ago by a chapter of the National Rifle Association for his unswerving defense of gun rights. Then you turn down a hallway, past several framed photographs of children who were victims of the massacre a year ago at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn. The combination of the bronze rifleman in the lobby and the young faces on the wall suggests a particular viewpoint — I stand with gun lovers; I stand with victims of gun violence  — that qualifies, in Washington anyway, as being nuanced, which is to say politically ill advised if not suicidal.

headline: Does Your School Hand Out Too Many A’s?
text: According to an article in its own school paper, The Crimson, the most common grade at Harvard is an A. On the Economix blog, the reporter Catherine Rampell points out that A’s have actually been the most common grade at Harvard not just recently, but also for the last 20 years — and that an A-range grade has also has been the most common grade awarded nationwide at colleges since 1997.

headline: Huishan Zhang: A Global Style Education
text: Suzy Menkes sits down with the designer Huishan Zhang and his mentor, Angelica Cheung, editor-in-chief of Vogue China, to discuss the influence of Chinese designers on the global market.

headline: TrueCar Raises $30 Million From Paul Allen’s Firm

text: Recent revelations about the huge amounts paid by families who violate China’s one-child policy have raised questions about just how the money is spent and spurred calls to ban the fines.

text: Stanley Fischer, who may join Janet L. Yellen atop the Fed, is now a respected elder among monetary economists, but he began his career as an insurgent.

headline: Suddenly, Illegal at Home
text: On the afternoon of Oct. 4, Maria Pierre stood up in front of a huge crowd of demonstrators at the Dominican Constitutional Court in Santo Domingo and confessed that she was in her native land illegally. “My only crime is that I was born here,” she began, and then her tears started flowing. The supportive crowd cheered her on with a loud chant: “We are Dominican, too! We belong here! We are not going anywhere!”

headline: Malone’s Liberty Global Bids for Rest of Dutch Cable Operator

text: Perella Weinberg Partners said on Thursday that it had sold its Chicago-based rail car leasing business to the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation of Japan in a deal valued at $1.1 billion.

headline: Study Suggests Online Sales Tax Bill Could Leave Billions Untaxed
text: Proponents of a federal law to force online retailers to collect sales tax should probably ratchet down their hopes and expectations. That, at least, is one conclusion to take from a new study sponsored by the Small Business Administration’s Office of Advocacy.

headline: Daily Report: Google Races to Map the World
text: The Internet land grab can be reduced to three key battles over three key conceptual territories. What came first, conquered by Google’s superior search algorithms. Who was next, and Facebook was the victor. But where, arguably the biggest prize of all, has yet to be completely won, Adam Fisher reports.

headline: A Long Goodbye for Mandela
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — From across South Africa and around the world, tens of thousands of people waited under a blazing summer sun on Thursday for a chance to bid farewell to Nelson Mandela on the second of three days his body was lying in state here.

headline: Interpreter at Mandela Service Says He Is Schizophrenic and Saw Angels Descend
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — A man accused of masquerading as a sign-language interpreter during Nelson Mandela’s memorial service, after he stood beside President Obama and other global dignitaries and gesticulated in gibberish, told interviewers on Thursday that he was a violence-prone schizophrenic and had seen angels descending in the stadium where the event was held.

headline: JPMorgan Nears Settlement in Madoff Case
text: JPMorgan Chase is nearing settlements with federal authorities over its ties to Bernard L. Madoff, reaching tentative deals that would involve roughly $2 billion in penalties and a rare criminal action, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The government plans to use a sizable portion of the money to compensate Mr. Madoff’s victims, according to DealBook.

headline: Indian Court Lifts Obstacle to Microsoft-Nokia Merger
text: MUMBAI, India — The Delhi High Court ruled on Thursday that Nokia would be allowed to transfer a phone factory to Microsoft, clearing a major obstacle to Nokia’s $7.4 billion sale of its mobile phone business to Microsoft after the court ordered Nokia to set aside $365 million for potential tax liabilities.

headline: Learning From the History of Vitamins
text: Our health depends on vitamins, and to understand that dependency, it helps to understand the history of vitamins. As I wrote in an article in Science Times this week, our ancestors have probably needed vitamins for billions of years. By studying how we and other species make vitamins, scientists hope to find new ways to keep us healthy — perhaps even by using vitamins as a weapon against our enemies.

headline: House Passes Budget Pact and Military Abuse Protections, but Not Farm Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday approved a bipartisan budget accord and a Pentagon policy bill that would strengthen protections for victims of sexual assault. But as it wrapped up its business for the year, it left unfinished a major piece of domestic policy — the farm bill — making it likely that Congress will not deal with it until January.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: Unprecedented Austerity
text: As many people have noted, a strange thing has happened on the fiscal policy front. Intellectually, the case for austerity has pretty much collapsed, having been reduced at this point to the Three Stooges Theory: we’re supposed to consider austerity a success because it feels good when you stop, or at least let up. At the same time, however, austerity policies continue to be imposed, on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Vatican Is Found to Make Progress in Policing Its Bank
text: VATICAN CITY — The Vatican has made significant efforts to comply with international controls to combat terrorism financing and money laundering, but needs to step up oversight of its financial institutions to ensure that new laws drafted to fight financial crimes are being properly carried out, according to a report issued Thursday.

headline: Foreigner Faces Deportation Over Scooter Incident
text: After ricocheting from subject of sympathy to target of vitriol by millions of Chinese Internet users who had seen photographs of him hitting a woman pedestrian with his scooter, a foreign resident of Beijing has been detained, fined and now faces deportation. It was just the latest case of the whirlwind rush to judgment and a tendency to stake out extremes frequently seen in Chinese cyberspace.

headline: For Gay Rights Advocates, Jubilation of Four Years Turns to Shock
text: NEW DELHI—On Wednesday morning, Abhina Aher, a transgender activist, woke up early and dressed in her best sari. She would have loved to be present at the Supreme Court to witness history in the making. But passes for the court hearing were limited, so Ms. Aher waited impatiently in front of the television.

headline: An Unbeliever in Disney World
text: “Saving Mr. Banks,” released by Disney, is a movie about the making of a Disney movie (“Mary Poppins”), in which Walt Disney himself (played by Tom Hanks) is a major character. It includes a visit to Disneyland and, if you look closely, a teaser for its companion theme park in Florida (as yet unbuilt, when the story takes place). A large Mickey Mouse plush toy appears from time to time to provide an extra touch of humor and warmth. But it would be unfair to dismiss this picture, directed by John Lee Hancock from a script by Kelly Marcel and Sue Smith, as an exercise in corporate self-promotion. It’s more of a mission statement.

headline: N3twork: A New Tool for Curating the Unruly Web
text: We live in an age of information overload. We are drowning in tweets, videos, blog posts, news articles, status updates, new products, emails and web pages. Pity the poor soul who wants to find the meaning amid the noise.

headline: An Antique Device Gives Musicians a Spin Through Yesteryear
text: Thus writes Greil Marcus in “The Old, Weird America,” citing “The Coo Coo Bird” as a seminal work in the Americana songbook, one that exemplifies a country self-invented and routinely reinvented by a loosely connected network of outsiders. The song itself is a mutant, starting as an Elizabethan English ballad before being twisted into something altogether stranger in the hollers of the American South.

headline: At Paris Brasseries, Cuisine to Match the Scene
text: Tucked away in the Gare St.-Lazare, in the Eighth Arrondissement of Paris, is the restaurant Lazare. This new spot from Eric Frechon, the chef who earned three Michelin stars at Epicure, is charming and satisfying. But it’s notable for another reason: It’s leading a revival of the Parisian brasserie. That’s good news for anyone who loves the fast-paced restaurants that once epitomized glamour while offering good simple Gallic grub and first-rate people-watching, but in recent years have gained a reputation for mediocrity after many became part of restaurant chains more interested in the bottom line than good cooking.

headline: Ron Howard on His Nerve-Racking Season
text: “I’m a little surprised,” the director Ron Howard admitted, after his racing drama “Rush” made an unexpectedly strong showing at the Golden Globes. It was nominated for best drama and best supporting actor, for Daniel Brühl, who beat out contenders like Jonah Hill in “The Wolf of Wall Street.”

headline: Drawing Yourself Into the Scene
text: On a sunny Saturday in early fall, a small group gathered for a Surrealist show at Cap de Creus, the craggy easternmost point of Spain where the artist Salvador Dalí had lived. The performers were wearing carnival-type costumes with black lace tutus and gold lamé gloves and were playing guitars and drums. They scrambled across the rocks and those of us in the audience followed — as much participants in the spectacle as viewers of it. When we arrived at a large and particularly oddly shaped outcropping, we were given paper and pens and asked to draw what we saw.

headline: The Radicalism of Lincoln’s 10 Percent Plan
text: Scores of students have been taught that Abraham Lincoln’s Proclamation of Amnesty and Reconstruction, appended to the presidential message to Congress of December 1863, offered rebels an easy way to get back into his good graces: as soon as they took an oath of loyalty to the Union and promised to support emancipation, he would pardon them and return their confiscated property (except for emancipated slaves, of course). Moreover, as soon as 10 percent of the 1860 electorate in any rebel state had taken the oath, he would permit that 10 percent to commence home rule and elect state officials.

headline: TPP

Please understand that this is a beta project and there may be issues that need to be addressed, but we aim to be very responsive to your feedback, whether they are problems you find or suggestions you may have.

headline: Colin Wilson, Author Acclaimed at 24 for ‘The Outsider,’ Dies at 82
text: Colin Wilson, a self-educated English writer who in 1956 shot to international acclaim with his first book, “The Outsider,” an erudite meditation on existentialism, alienation and creativity, but who incurred critical disdain for a string of later books about murder, sexual deviance and the occult, died on Dec. 5 in Cornwall, England. He was 82.

headline: Chiwetel Ejiofor’s Moment of Self-Doubt
text: To anyone who might think it odd that a British man played the role of a 19th-century free American black man forced, through kidnapping, into slavery, Chiwetel Ejiofor says this: slavery infected much of the world.

headline: Are Today’s New Surgeons Unprepared?
text: The surgeon had no prestigious named professorship, no N.I.H. grant and no plum administrative position in the hospital’s hierarchy. But to the other surgeons-in-training and me, he was exactly who we wanted to be.

headline: What is Really at Stake in the Thai Protests
text: In a trim garden outside her pink plaster house, 62-year-old Amnuay Warayot recounted her past life. Before moving here, she lived in a slum by the trains, where electricity and water were hard to come by and the wooden homes were no match for the northeast Thai rainy season. The man who gave her all this, she tells me, has won over her heart. His name is Thaksin Shinawatra, and he’s the former prime minister.

headline: Escapism at the Movies? Not Exactly
text: “Generalized anxiety.” That is by far the most common complaint voiced by the clients of a prominent New York psychiatrist whom I recently asked to identify the malaise of the moment. As much as that term evokes a sense of foreboding behind the glittering facade of Manhattan, it also describes the wary, embattled tone of world cinema in 2013.

headline: G.M. Sells Rest of Stake in Ally Financial
text: General Motors announced on Thursday that it had sold the last of its holdings in Ally Financial, its onetime financing arm, through a private placement of shares for $900 million.

headline: Some Marched Their Own Way
text: “Scenes of Provincial Life” would be an apt title for an account of the 2013 New York art world, a white-bread band going about its practiced rounds. Galleries pushed painting: schooled, skilled, dull. Marquee items that went on view in museums only mildly thrilled or chilled.

headline: Rays of Light and Menacing Shadows
text: It’s hard to say whether 2013 was a lucky or unlucky year for the art world, but it was definitely packed with exhibitions and events that inspired or dismayed, sometimes in related clusters.

headline: Why Mistakes Are Essential to Any Growth Strategy
text: Jessica Wade started a high-end clothing label in 2009. The business, which she named Jes Wade, is based in Manhattan and has two employees. While many owners of small companies have a low tolerance for mistakes, which I believe is one reason many of them never get bigger, Ms. Wade realizes that mistakes are learning opportunities.

headline: Charles Isherwood’s Top Shows of 2013

headline: From Brecht to Jukebox Musicals
text: Reflecting on the highlights of my year in theatergoing, I was often brought up short by a sense of renewed surprise. How odd, really, that a production of a play by Bertolt Brecht — a genius of 20th-century theater, yes, but often about as much fun as a doctor’s visit in production — provided more giddy fun than most Broadway musicals. The idea of listening in on eight hours of a phone conversation could hardly sound more tedious, but the show derived from that very source was among the most inspired and imaginative I saw this year. Herewith, in alphabetical order, are the shows that gave me the most pleasure, often by catching me off guard.

headline: Oscar Isaac Avoids an Embarrassing Fate
text: “It’s so weird, man,” Oscar Isaac said, of being booked on the “Today” show this morning, as the Golden Globes were announced. “They have me on and the idea is if I get nominated, they get my reaction. And if I don’t, I slink away in shame.”

headline: Park Avenue Armory Goes Immersive in New Season
text: Continuing to push the envelope on what constitutes an arts experience, the Park Avenue Armory will fill its sprawling, 55,000-square-foot Drill Hall with a water installation and present the indie British pop band, the XX, as part of its new season beginning March 19, the armory announced on Thursday. The season will also include a recital series in the armory’s recently renovated Board of Officers Room, so that audiences experience chamber music in a salon setting.

headline: Q. & A. With Carol S. Dweck
text: Carol S. Dweck, a psychologist at Stanford University, has done extensive research on why women tend to avoid careers in math and science. Her work has shown that women and girls who think that science and math ability are innate tend to perform worse and have less interest in those fields than females who believe that those skills can be acquired through hard work. As she describes the distinction, one is a “gift” mindset and the other a “growth” mindset.

headline: In Ukraine’s East, a Message for Protesters: Stop
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — As workers streamed into the Donetsk Metallurgical Plant, a sprawling, Soviet-era factory complex here, they had a message for protesters in Kiev’s Independence Square: Get back to work.

headline: Beatles American Albums to Be Released in a Boxed Set
text: As part of it celebration of the 50th anniversary of the outbreak of Beatlemania in America, Capitol Records is resurrecting a project it began in 2004, but quietly dropped before it was completed: the label announced on Thursday that it would release “The Beatles: The U.S. Albums,” a 13-CD set that includes the American versions of the albums the Beatles released in the 1960s, or at least, those with different track sequences (and, in some cases, different mixes) than the British versions that are now the standard discography. The boxed set is due on Jan. 21.

headline: Mexico’s Pride, Oil, May Be Opened to Outsiders
text: CIUDAD DEL CARMEN, Mexico — Every gas station in Mexico is stamped with the green-and-white logo of the state-owned oil monopoly, the economic lifeblood of the government. Oil Expropriation Day, commemorating the day Mexico seized control of the industry from foreign companies in 1938, is celebrated with speeches and even parades in some towns. An old song, “The Oil Worker Hymn,” credits oil with “saving our fatherland.”

headline: The Gun Report: December 12, 2013
text: BB guns are often thought of as a coming-of-age diversion, something young boys shoot in the woods. They are regulated in the same manner as air guns, which is to say, not much: They are not regulated federally, nor are they regulated by most state and local governments. But some states are beginning to recognize the destruction the weapons can cause.

headline: Pincay Sets the Record
text: Laffit Pincay Jr. breaks Bill Shoemaker’s record for career victories by a jockey at Hollywood Park, and later retires from riding.

headline: A Stay-at-Home Dad’s Dilemma, When the Marriage Ends
text: What happens to a marriage when a woman works and a husband stays home to raise children? On Sunday, The Times reported on how this plays out in the field of finance, where growing numbers of women say they are able to compete at new levels thanks to stay-at-home husbands. Readers from a variety of fields and economic backgrounds responded with an outpouring of experiences: the Connecticut stay-at-home father who tells white lies about his lack of employment (“which career is it this week?”); the wife who said the role reversal made her marriage “more egalitarian and respectful.”

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: organic milk, nuts and farm animal drugs. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Boehner Responds to Critics on the Right
text: The House speaker, John A. Boehner of Ohio, doubled down on criticism he gave on Wednesday and defended the budget deal negotiated by Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin.

headline: Alfonso Cuarón Gets a Nod But Could Use Another Perk
text: The filmmaker Alfonso Cuarón was boarding a plane in London to visit his family in Italy when he reflected on the nearly five-year effort to make and release “Gravity,” which received four Golden Globe nominations on Thursday, including best director, drama and actress (Sandra Bullock).

headline: President of Middlebury College Says He Will Leave
text: Ronald D. Liebowitz, who has greatly expanded the reach of Middlebury College, will step down in 2015, after 11 years as president, he said Thursday. Under Dr. Liebowitz, Middlebury, a selective small college in rural Vermont, took over the Monterey Institute of International Studies in California, opened new schools overseas and expanded its summer language schools. Dr. Liebowitz said a major remaining concern is enrollment of minority and low-income students, where Middlebury trails most other elite colleges. Middlebury also announced a governance overhaul, giving each trustee broader oversight duties.

headline: It’s Hard to Summon Sympathy for Big Banks
text: It’s no fun to be a banker these days.

headline: Koch’s Last Residence Is Named a Cultural Landmark
text: Edward I. Koch, some might argue, was a living landmark. Thursday, on what would have been his 89th birthday, his last residence, at 2 Fifth Avenue, was declared a New York cultural landmark.

headline: Wall Street Trade Group Names New Leader
text: A financial industry trade group, the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association, has named  Kenneth E. Bentsen, Jr., its president, as chief executive.

headline: A Senior Getty Curator Is Stepping Down
text: Scott Schaefer, who has been senior curator of paintings at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles since 1999 is retiring as of Jan. 21, the institution announced on Thursday.

headline: A Body of Work Gives the Mets Hope
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Sandy Alderson’s verb of choice, in past off-seasons, has been punt. It said a lot about perception and reality. The Mets almost ignored the free-agent market and traded star players. Quite clearly, they were punting on the next season, no matter how their general manager spun it.

headline: Ziggo Still Has Cards to Play in Liberty Global Talks
text: Ziggo has opened the door to Liberty Global, the media company controlled by John Malone. A few weeks after rebuffing an approach, the Dutch cable group has confirmed takeover talks with its larger rival. Any deal would be both big and logical, since Ziggo and a unit of Liberty, UPC, dominate the local market. And Liberty already owns a dominant stake in Ziggo. Now that Ziggo has conceded a willingness to sell to Liberty, the task is to get full value from a weak position.

headline: Reports on Central African Republic’s Humanitarian Needs
text: Journalists and international humanitarian workers who have been extensively covering the conflict in Central African Republic have highlighted the desperate need for aid for the more than half a million people who have been displaced by the fighting.

headline: One Way to Handle Smog: Lower the Standards
text: On seven of the first nine days of December, the air quality in Shanghai was so poor that the city warned children and the elderly to stay indoors. Flights and sporting events were canceled and stores sold out of face masks. Photographs of smog obscuring the Shanghai skyline circulated on the Internet. The pollution was even visible from space.

headline: Photographer's Journal: Bryan Denton
text: After covering the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan in Guiuan, Philippines, freelance photographer Bryon Denton reflects on his experience.

headline: Klinsmann Agrees to Four-Year Extension as U.S. Coach
text: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States men’s soccer team, agreed to a four-year contract extension Thursday, a strong show of support from U.S. Soccer only six months before the World Cup in Brazil.

headline: Reunion With Ex-Teammates Turns Sour for Rangers
text: Familiar players led the offense at Madison Square Garden. Unfortunately for the Rangers, they were skating for the Columbus Blue Jackets.

headline: Now Screening | A Shocking Short Film About Body Image, Starring Elle Fanning
text: The film above contains images that may be disturbing to some viewers.

headline: Reading Club | ‘Invisible Child’
text: Update: Jan. 14 We’ve now closed this post, but will put up a new post highlighting our favorite comments soon. When we do, we will add a link here.

headline: A.I.G. Said to Be in Talks With New Bidder for Its Aircraft Leasing Unit
text: The American International Group is hoping that a change in bidders for its big aircraft leasing unit, the International Lease Finance Corporation, will finally lead to a sale.

headline: Big Hair, Bad Scams, Motormouths
text: Irving Rosenfeld, the con man running the great scam in “American Hustle,” isn’t, his mistress admits, much to look at. He has a belly the size of a beer keg and a torturously complicated comb-over that he arranges with the fastidiousness of a Michelin-starred pastry chef. Appearances are not everything to Irving (Christian Bale), but rather just part of the swindle that is his life’s work, his passion and genius. The confidence game is his honey pot: It’s what lines his pockets, lights his fire and cigars, and has transformed the mistress, Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), into his equal in theft and dissimulation, making her the Rosalind Russell to his Cary Grant in a romp that’s pure Scorsese screwball.

headline: Plan for Art and Antiques Fair in China Falls Through
text: It looks as though Sotheby’s and the art dealers who show up at the European Fine Art Fair every March in Maastricht, the Netherlands, are not such great pals after all.

headline: Steve Coogan Gets a Comedy Award and a Drama Nod
text: It’s been a full day of celebrating for Steve Coogan, the British actor and writer known to American audiences mostly for his comedic turns in films like “Hamlet 2” and “Night at the Museum.” (In Britain, it’s his fictional broadcaster, the pompous Alan Partridge, that he’s best known for.)

headline: Dialysis Takes a Toll
text: Dialysis is difficult for people of any age, but especially for frail older adults with multiple chronic conditions such as diabetes, heart disease and dementia — the patients least likely to have their lives extended significantly by this treatment.

headline: Rangers Pick Seahawks Quarterback in Baseball Draft
text: If baseball does not work out for the Texas Rangers, they have a jump on fielding quite a football team.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus, in a Panic
text: Updated, 4:47 p.m. | Forget the actual awards ceremony. Merely listening to the Golden Globe nominations from the comfort of her couch was anxiety-inducing for Julia Louis-Dreyfus, who earned a nod for turn as Eva, a divorced mother in Los Angeles, in Nicole Holofcener’s “Enough Said.”

headline: Market Report
text: These chic, comfortable shoes are the stylish descendants of the clunky clogs and granola flip-flops of yore.

headline: China Spins Mandela to Fit Its Political Narrative
text: In 1964, Nelson Mandela, the anti-apartheid campaigner, was convicted of treason in a South African court and sentenced to life in prison. He spent 27 years behind bars.

headline: The Musket Room
text: Inside NoLIta’s New Zealand restaurant, where the food is ambitious and meticulously detailed.

headline: Health Care Reform, Through a Glass Darkly
text: Just to follow up on my comments yesterday about the health care law’s many possible futures, here’s an analysis of the latest enrollment numbers from National Review’s Patrick Brennan that flags a striking data point:

headline: Eating With the Apple Family
text: A meal at the family home of the Apples of Rhinebeck, N.Y., guarantees two things: food and conversation. Lots of it. In the four works in Richard Nelson’s play cycle, now at the Public Theater, the fictional members of the family gather around the dinner table at the home of Barbara Apple, a schoolteacher, on days that commemorate recent events in American history: election days of 2010 (“That Hopey Changey Thing”) and 2012 (“Sorry”); the 10th anniversary of 9/11 (“Sweet and Sad”) and the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy (“Regular Singing”).

headline: Investment From China May Be Near for Peugeot
text: GENEVA — PSA Peugeot Citroën, the ailing French automaker, moved closer to grabbing a financial lifeline on Thursday, saying that it was in negotiations with Dongfeng Motor, a state-owned Chinese company with which it already has a joint venture, that could lead to “a potential capital increase.”

headline: Hedge Fund Inflated Value of Coal Investment and Client Fees, S.E.C. Says
text: GLG Partners, a division of one of the world’s biggest hedge funds, has agreed to pay almost $9 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it overvalued its investment in Sibanthracite, a Siberian coal mining company, and in turn, inflated client fees.

headline: Size Is of the Essence
text: Twenty years ago, New Zealand cuisine was what the locals call “meat and three veg.” But that is a distant ancestor to what is on the plate tonight at the Musket Room on Elizabeth Street: an archipelago of venison in a licorice jus sea, buffeted by roasted fennel, juniper meringues and celery-root purée.

headline: Bank of America to Pay $131.8 Million Penalty in Mortgage Deals
text: The fallout from the bursting of the housing bubble continues to plague Wall Street.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Central African Republic, South Africa, India and Washington.

headline: Waiting for a Winter Breeze
text: From the Times photography archive, images of ice yachting, a sport that was popular when cold winters could be relied upon.

headline: Waiting for Ice, and a Winter Breeze
text: The mercury plummeted to below freezing on Thursday, and most people bundled up to avoid the cold. But for a certain branch of sailors, these temperatures are ideal. With the right conditions and a sustained cold snap, rivers and lakes freeze over, providing the perfect surface for ice yachting, a sport in which sailors navigate vessels across the ice.

headline: Steve McQueen Among 6 Hugo Boss Prize Finalists
text: Six finalists have been named for the 2014 Hugo Boss Prize, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation has announced. The $100,000 award, named for the German men’s wear company that sponsors it, is given every two years to an artist making significant contributions in contemporary art. Besides cash, the winner’s work receives an exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum in New York.

headline: Letters: ‘My Promised Land’
text: ‘My Promised Land’

headline: Researching Klinai, or Couches, in Ancient Tombs
text: FURNITURE CREATED

headline: The Art of Michael Skakel
text: Michael C. Skakel, who was convicted in 2002 of a 1975 murder in Greenwich, Conn., turned out many pieces of art during his time in prison.

headline: U.S. Agencies Dance Around Cellphone Use Aloft
text: WASHINGTON — The Transportation Department said on Thursday that it would consider banning the use of cellphones for voice calls aboard airplanes, a reaction to public outrage at a Federal Communications Commission proposal to lift a rule that has long forbidden the use of mobile phones during flight.

headline: In Prison, the Artist in Skakel Came Out
text: The drawing of the milk carton is rendered by a practiced hand in crisp red and white, with one of those advertisements for a missing person on the side.

headline: Jared Leto Heard the Good News on a Bus
text: Actor? Musician?

headline: Google Executives Got Discounts From Government on Fuel for Private Aircraft
text: Google executives received an unfair and inappropriate discount on jet fuel purchased from the government for personal flights on their nine private aircraft, according to a report released on Wednesday by NASA’s Office of the Inspector General.

headline: Comfort Food, Expanded
text: The Northend Bistro is a comfortable oasis that beckons from its tucked-in spot in, yes, the north end of Princeton. Bare wooden tables and paper napkins signal a casual experience; metal dining chairs reflect the light from an abundance of windows and from backlit glass panels.

headline: North Korea Says Leader’s Uncle Was Executed as a Traitor
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Friday that Jang Song-thaek, the uncle and presumed mentor of its leader, Kim Jong-un, was executed for plotting a military coup.

headline: Creative Ideas for the Holiday Gift List
text: Handblown glass bowls whose colors swirl like ribbon candy, whimsical felt fascinators and intricately adorned purses, ceramic cake stands as enticing as the desserts they were designed to hold — these are a few of the myriad offerings at seven gift-themed art exhibitions in galleries from Pelham to Cold Spring. The shows, though unrelated, share a common aim: to inspire visitors, as an announcement for one of them suggests, to “celebrate the season of giving with the gift of another’s creativity.”

headline: Mandela Memorial Interpreter Speaks in His Own Defense
text: As my colleagues Nicholas Kulish, John Eligon and Alan Cowell report, the sign-language interpreter accused of botching the translation of remarks by a host of world leaders at the memorial for Nelson Mandela this week in Johannesburg spoke in his own defense in a series of interviews on Thursday.

headline: For Some Players, Tax Ensures a Loss Even After a Win
text: When the Milwaukee Bucks traveled to Memphis for a preseason game against the Grizzlies, the Bucks lost by 3 points — and the backup point guard Nate Wolters lost about $1,000.

headline: Oklahoma Quakes
text: Oklahoma has been jolted by thousands of minor earthquakes in recent years, far more than the average of about 50 quakes a year.

headline: Hollywood Park, Then and Now
text: A crowd of 45,000, including Hollywood celebrities, gathered to watch the Gold Cup at Hollywood Park in 1939. These days, the crowds are much more sparse, and the track will run its last races on Dec. 22.

headline: A Life Vest for Borrowers
text: The subprime mortgage crisis gave rise to a raft of regulations intended to guard against another disastrous market bubble. But beyond that, some financial-services companies are betting that lingering fears among buyers will generate demand for products that would shield them from losses if home values took another dive.

headline: A Journey Toward Clarity After the Loss of a Partner
text: “Life changes fast.

headline: ‘Invisible Child': Behind the Scenes, Before and After
text: Andrea Elliott’s moving and exhaustively reported five-part series, “Invisible Child,” was 15 months in the making. At 28,738 words, and accompanied by affecting images by Ruth Fremson, a staff photographer, this story of a homeless girl in Brooklyn is the largest investigative project that The Times has run all at once.

headline: Mathematical Ratios, Papered, Folded and Cut
text: Spend an afternoon dipping in and out of galleries on the Lower East Side, and you are likely to encounter many examples of geometric abstraction — much of it offhand and whimsical. But if you want to see the work of an artist who cares deeply about geometry, pay a visit to Dorothea Rockburne’s austere, bracing exhibition of drawings at the Museum of Modern Art. The difference is instructive.

headline: Tiki Time
text: A look at tiki restaurants in the New York area.

headline: Brrrr! Let’s Drive to the South Seas
text: WHEN late autumn’s chill sets in, my husband and I escape to the South Seas. Not the actual South Seas, like Tahiti or Tonga, but to bars and restaurants in and around New York City with fake palm trees, lighted puffer fish, pu pu platters, waterfalls and sweet drinks with umbrellas in them. Not to mention giant tiki heads.

headline: Manhattan Day Trip to the Nation’s Start
text: “Forty Part Motet,” Janet Cardiff’s moving sound installation, might have been one of the most popular draws north of the Museum Mile this fall, but the Cloisters, where the show ended last weekend, is not the only stellar attraction in Upper Manhattan. There are three often-overlooked historic homes there where you can stretch your legs and your imagination for a high-flying ride through war, sex scandals and a shooting from over two centuries ago.

headline: Destruction Feeding Creation
text: WASHINGTON — Air raid drills were the norm for American grade school kids in the Cold War 1950s. If you were in class, and the alarm went off, you got under your desk with your hands on your head. How was that supposed to save you from bombs? You didn’t know. You just hoped it would.

headline: Art on Staten Island
text: Fairly or not, Staten Island doesn’t typically top the list of places you’d expect to encounter cutting-edge art in New York City. But as the island’s artists come together this weekend for another installment of “Second Saturday Staten Island,” an art walk, the Miser wonders whether that won’t change soon enough.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: In the Middle of Middle-earth
text: At the start of “The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug,” the second part of Peter Jackson’s extended-play adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkien’s children’s book, Bilbo Baggins has a sword called Sting and One Ring to Rule Them All — eventually. We have a ways to go. As everyone on Earth and in Middle-earth surely knows, Mr. Jackson, having turned Tolkien’s trilogy “The Lord of the Rings” into three hit films, has given its prequel a blockbuster do-over in three separate 3-D movies. The first, “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,” a soporific 170 minutes released in 2012, lived up to its subtitle principally by moving at a snail’s pace. At 161 minutes the new one by contrast feels like a sprint. (The third, “The Hobbit: There and Back Again,” is set for world domination in December 2014.)

text: Images from the Met’s new show of contemporary Chinese art.

headline: Disputed Statue to Be Returned to Cambodia
text: An ancient statue of a Hindu warrior, pulled from auction two years ago because of assertions that it had been looted from a temple deep in the jungles of Cambodia, will be returned to that country under an agreement signed on Thursday by Sotheby’s, its client and federal officials.

headline: A Magical Well That Never Runs Dry
text: When it comes to the history of Chinese art, there are few traditions as revered as bimo, or brush and ink. From this simple combination of tool and material, China’s greatest achievements — landscape painting and calligraphy — flowed for centuries.

headline: The Light (and Short) Fantastic Told
text: “Fantasy is my heart and love,” the poet and fiction writer Catherynne M. Valente once said in an interview. “And I just want to play in that garden for the rest of my life.”

headline: A Tension Between the Sacred and the Profane
text: What is it about African tribal art that so allures us denizens of the modern, industrialized world? I wonder this whenever I encounter tribal artifacts in museums and galleries, and I’m prompted to again by two exhibitions presented by Paul Kasmin Gallery in Chelsea. In Kasmin’s 10th Avenue gallery, there’s “Arman the Collector: The Artist’s Collection of African Art,” a stunning presentation of works collected by the artist known for accumulating many similar objects into absurdist sculptures. Then, around the corner, in Kasmin’s West 27th Street gallery, there’s “Brancusi in New York 1913 – 2013,” a glowing display of five polished bronze works celebrating the 100th anniversary of Constantin Brancusi’s participation in the New York Armory show of 1913.

headline: A Cellar for Any Situation, Any Price
text: You don’t need me to remind you the holidays are here (as if you could forget). While it’s easy to bemoan the crass commercialization and artifice, it’s also easy to overlook the opportunities for all sorts of gatherings and the real joys that come with them. Let’s just stipulate that in the hierarchy of pleasures, people come first. Now that we agree on that, good food and drink can help make any party better. Here are some suggestions for several possible types of gatherings. The suggestions are not rigid: if you see something you like better in another, go for it. Above all, these should be gifts to yourself.

headline: Loneliness of Secrets
text: Here’s my situation: Two sisters have been enemies for years. Neither one speaks to the other. Recently, their father, who lives far away, was found to have cancer and admitted to the hospital. One of the sisters knows about his condition, but the other doesn’t because the father made the one he told promise not to tell her sister or anyone else in the family. Should this promise be kept? Doesn’t the sister who knows have a duty to tell the other?

headline: He Wants Her Back. She’s Not Interested.
text: It’s difficult to discuss “Some Velvet Morning,” the latest movie from Neil LaBute, without giving away too much. This is by design. Set entirely inside a Brooklyn brownstone — with a brief trip to the backyard — this gendered gabfest has been constructed along familiar LaButian lines. A man and a woman pace like inmates, jawing and clawing and drawing metaphoric (or not) blood, and then Mr. LaBute, rather like a mean O. Henry, tosses in a detonating surprise that either changes what you’ve thought until that moment or ticks you off. This audience baiting is also very much by design, of course, and can be playful or sadistic or both, or neither.

headline: Legacy, Memory, Inspiration, AIDS
text: Bill T. Jones choreographed “D-Man in the Waters” in 1989, when the mortal danger of AIDS was at a high tide. The work celebrates the buoyant spirit of the dancer Demian Acquavella, who had AIDS and died the following year, but swimming in its waters are many others, including Mr. Jones’s partner, Arnie Zane, who had died the previous year. And at City Center on Wednesday, when Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed “D-Man” for the first time, there was inevitably one more spirit present: Alvin Ailey, whose AIDS-related death came the year the dance was made.

headline: Narco Corrido Concert
text: From Shaul Schwarz’s “Narco Cultura,” in which members of a “narco corrido” band play one of their songs glorifying the drug war culture.

headline: A Blade, Then Blood
text: Some opera productions are defined by what’s not there. Luc Bondy’s bleak “Tosca” has been part of the Metropolitan Opera’s repertory since 2009, when it opened the season to lusty booing. That was due in great part to the grim sets, which have none of the historical detail of the Franco Zeffirelli production. Only bare brick walls and what appear to be Ikea folding chairs offer respite for a viewer tired of puzzling over that Lucian Freud painting that has somehow found its way into the church, perhaps dumped there by Napoleonic troops after an art looting expedition into the future. Also missing in Mr. Bondy’s “Tosca” are the crucifix and candles she places on and around the body of the villainous Scarpia after she has stabbed him to death.
