text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Suffrage, Sought in Sharps and Flats
text: To watch public figures ferociously entrenched in their positions, talking past one another in a language that can seem perilously close to gibberish, you can either turn on CNN or take the No. 1 train to the Manhattan School of Music on Friday and Sunday.

headline: He’d Send You to Sleep With the Fishes, but the Water Is Still Frozen Solid
text: Before “Orange Is the New Black” or “Arrested Development” or “House of Cards” there was “Lilyhammer,” the original Netflix original series. Now that a second season of the show is arriving on Friday, it feels as if a landmark has been reached — one full cycle in the company’s new life as a content provider.

headline: Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner. No, Don’t.
text: The well-lubricated dinner party that goes haywire has been a standard platform for nasty domestic comedy ever since the days of Georges Feydeau. In “What’s In a Name?,” an uproarious French farce, the catalyst for the flinging of mud isn’t booze but a practical joke that is carried so far it rattles skeletons.

text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Now Screening | Putting a Human Face on the African AIDS Epidemic
text: The central figure in the director Maggie Betts’s affecting documentary, “The Carrier,” 28-year-old Mutinta Mweemba, is H.I.V.-positive and pregnant. A partner in a polygamous marriage in a small Zambian village, Mweemba is following a Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission (P.M.T.C.T.) program, receiving medication to keep the disease from being transmitted to her child. The film tracks Betts’s interactions with her family members (her husband and one of his two other wives are also infected) and her community, creating an unexpectedly intimate, nonjudgmental snapshot of the African AIDS epidemic. It shows how universal a mother’s fear of harming her child is, regardless of social or economic differences. “There’s no way an innocent baby who hasn’t even been born yet could have done anything to deserve this fate,” Betts says.

headline: Tiny Tim Cratchit, Older Now, Is a Bit of a Scrooge
text: The last we hear of Tiny Tim Cratchit in “A Christmas Carol” is heartening news. The boy, Charles Dickens wrote, is going to live, and Ebenezer Scrooge, miser-turned-philanthropist, will be like a second father to him.

headline: Spare Times for Dec. 13-19

Not the 47 artisans whose holiday creations are on view in this annual display, sponsored by the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation, at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park, at Fifth Avenue and 64th Street.

headline: Energy Department to Give $226 Million to Support Nuclear Reactor Design
text: WASHINGTON — The Energy Department will give a small company in Corvallis, Ore., up to $226 million to advance the design of tiny nuclear reactors that would be installed under water, making meltdown far less likely and opening the door to markets around the world where the reactors now on the market are too big for local power grids.

headline: H.I.V. and Ethnicity

headline: A Filmmaker’s Hold on His Muse
text: “Liv, you are my Stradivarius,” the great Swedish filmmaker Ingmar Bergman once told his most famous muse, Liv Ullmann, who knew him for more than 40 years and appeared in 12 of his films. Bergman died in 2007, but Ms. Ullmann, still radiant in her mid-70s, soldiers on.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Out of Prison, Back in the Life
text: The South Korean director Kwak Kyung-taek is from Busan, the setting for much of the action in “Friend 2: The Legacy,” a sequel to his breakout gangster hit from 2001. Unlike the hardscrabble characters in his new movie, Mr. Kwak is from a family of doctors. He abandoned medical school to study film at New York University, and both his style and themes seem indebted to New York-based films by his fellow alumnus Martin Scorsese and by Francis Ford Coppola.

headline: Young, Naïve and Selling Sex
text: At the beginning of “Tricked,” Jane Wells and John-Keith Wasson’s exposé of human trafficking in North America, the despicably smooth-talking Robert Money explains that all women are either prostitutes or whores. A preening pimp, he should know: His sordid taxonomy is the foundation of his entire business plan.

headline: Good Heavens, They’re Atheists
text: The ghost of Christopher Hitchens hovers disapprovingly over “The Unbelievers,” a self-professed rock ’n’ roll tour film about science and reason that plays like a publicity stunt for its secular stars.

headline: Doctor, Cellist, Clown, Humanitarian
text: The King of Cambodia seems really nice in “Beatocello’s Umbrella,” Georges Gachot’s heart-melting documentary. He has a wide, warm smile, and he pats the children’s heads when he visits them at the hospital. But the star here is Dr. Beat Richner, who is royal in his own rumpled, noble way.

headline: What Happens When the Kids Wander Off
text: Graphic sex and bloody violence are inextricably linked in “Here Comes the Devil,” a muddled supernatural thriller that fails to capitalize on either its horrific prologue or eerie location.

headline: Saving a Newborn One Breath at a Time
text: It might be hard to watch the signature “Fast and the Furious” movies of Paul Walker for a while because of his death last month in a car crash. But “Hours,” in which he stars and is rarely off screen, is a solid alternative. No speeding cars in this combination ticktock thriller and psychological study. Mr. Walker’s character, Nolan, spends almost the entire movie in a single building.

headline: Govern in Poetry
text: In advance of a long drive through the coulee country of eastern Washington, my friend Sam gave me an audio companion — a CD of the greatest presidential speeches of the 20th century. Um, thanks. I would sooner listen to Sarah Palin on Aristotle — you got that Greek philosophy thing going there — than hear the scratchy voices of long-dead politicians.

headline: Upper Riverside Drive: Audubon Slept Here
text: Amid the low thatch of five- and six-story apartment houses on Riverside Drive is a tall stand of buildings between West 155th and 158th Streets, eight- to 13-story apartment houses that stick out like a cottonwood grove on the prairie.

headline: The Fevered Jungle of Wall Street Receives Visitors From Colder Climes
text: Wall Street financiers have occasionally been referred to as sharks or snakes. But on Thursday, one prominent firm was associated with entirely different kinds of cute and lovable critters.

text: With one son thriving in a financial literacy class in high school, the other son showing a surprising gift for French, and a daughter about to try out for the school play, Dana Stripling was determined to do whatever it would take to keep her children in the Park Ridge school system.

headline: Bring Drunken Santas Under Control
text: ON Saturday, a festive, besotted mob of 20- and 30-somethings, decked out in various measures of Santa Claus dress and undress, will descend on the bars of lower New York City and rain down Christmas cheer like spoiled eggnog.

headline: N.Y.U. Graduate Assistants to Join Auto Workers’ Union
text: Graduate teaching and research assistants at New York University have voted overwhelmingly to unionize, the American Arbitration Association announced this week after conducting the vote.

headline: Kosovo Attains Status (on Facebook) It Has Sought for Years: Nation
text: PARIS — Ever since little Kosovo proclaimed itself an independent state five years ago, it has failed to win all the recognition it so craves. Neither the United Nations, which confers legitimacy, nor all the European Union, whose members are divided on the question, much less Serbia, from which Kosovo broke away, recognize the birth of a new European nation.

headline: Testing if ‘Loud’ Can Add Votes for Insurgents
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: Chemical Arms Used Repeatedly in Syria, U.N. Says
text: UNITED NATIONS — Chemical weapons were used repeatedly in the Syria conflict this year, not only in a well-documented Aug. 21 attack near Damascus but also in four other instances, including two subsequent attacks that targeted soldiers, the United Nations said in a report released Thursday.

headline: If the Sun Salutation Has to Fit Into a Cell
text: PALESTINE — Quiet is hard to find in prison. But in the Powledge Unit gym on Tuesday afternoon, the silence was interrupted only by the sounds of breathing, toes on sticky yoga mats and occasional moans from nine men in white uniforms as they sank deeper into pigeon pose.

headline: Belgian Senate Votes to Allow Euthanasia for Terminally Ill Children
text: BRUSSELS — Belgium took a big step on Thursday to becoming the first country to allow euthanasia for incurably ill children, after the upper house of Parliament voted by a large majority to extend to minors a 2002 law legalizing the practice for adults.

headline: A Message That Tries to Blend In
text: AS Madison Avenue continues debating the pros and cons of a hot trend in marketing known as native advertising — digital pitches styled to look like the editorial content of the publications in which they run — Vanity Fair magazine is voting “aye” by bringing out its first such effort, for Hennessy Cognac, that is to begin Friday on vanityfair.com.

headline: Somalia: From Canada, a Candidate
text: President Hassan Sheik Mohamud on Thursday nominated a Somali-Canadian as the country’s new prime minister after the previous prime minister, Abdi Farah Shirdon, was removed by Parliament in a no-confidence vote. The nominee, Abdiweli Sheikh Ahmed Mohamed, has a background in economics and development work around the world. He will have to be endorsed by Parliament before taking office.

headline: Spain: Catalonia Calls Vote on Split
text: Catalonia, Spain’s economic powerhouse, headed toward a standoff with Madrid on Thursday after separatist parties in the region announced a date next year for an independence referendum. The threat to hold a vote — and potentially break apart Spain — drew an immediate rebuke from Spanish officials who called it a violation of the Constitution. Catalan officials, however, say the vote would not be a constitutionally defined binding referendum, but rather “a popular consultation.”

headline: Schools Use Web Tools, and Data Is Seen at Risk
text: Public schools around the country are adopting web-based services that collect and analyze personal details about students without adequately safeguarding the information from potential misuse by service providers, according to new research.

headline: Drone Strike in Yemen Hits Wedding Convoy, Killing 11
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Drone-fired missiles struck a convoy of cars returning from a wedding on Thursday afternoon in a remote area of Yemen, witnesses said, killing at least 11 people in what appeared to be the second American drone strike in the past week.

headline: Treasury Urges More Federal Oversight of Insurance
text: The United States Treasury called on Thursday for a greater federal role in the regulation of insurance, particularly in areas like mortgage insurance, the collection and use of personal data to set prices, and the use of secretive entities known as captives to keep risks off the books of insurers.

headline: A Stream of Music, Not Revenue
text: When Spotify, the digital music company of the moment, announced this week an exclusive deal with Led Zeppelin and free access on mobile devices, it also reported impressive numbers. Its listeners have streamed 4.5 billion hours of music this year, and it has paid more than $1 billion in music royalties since its founding.

headline: Israel Shelves Plan to Move Bedouins Amid Outcry
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government on Thursday shelved a plan to resettle tens of thousands of Bedouin citizens in the Negev desert that had drawn international condemnation, spawned street demonstrations across Israel, and in recent days lost the support of lawmakers from the governing coalition as well.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: A Surprise From Hilton: Big Profit for Blackstone
text: In the topsy-turvy world of private equity math, what at first glance looks like a multibillion-dollar loss can in fact be a huge gain.

headline: Pakistan: Justice’s Crusade Closes
text: After a tumultuous eight-year term in which he defied and outplayed the military ruler Pervez Musharraf, terminated a prime minister and changed the Supreme Court’s role from political pawn to power player, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, 65, stepped down as Pakistan’s chief justice on Thursday. As his legacy, he leaves a court that has now proved able to call even the country’s powerful generals to account. But he also polarized public debate, drawing accusations that he had become a power-drunk crusader who brought an elected Pakistani government to the brink of collapse. His successor, Justice Tassaduq Hussain Jillani, is generally considered to be more mild-mannered, and he will have less than a year in the post before reaching the retirement age of 65.

headline: De Blasio Picks Bloomberg Official as Social Services Chief
text: Citing a deep concern about New York City’s approach to homelessness, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio on Thursday tapped a senior Bloomberg administration official to be his primary architect for all social service policies.

headline: Immigration Advocates Undeterred as House Departs Without Action
text: WASHINGTON — As the Republican-controlled House of Representatives wrapped up its work for the year on Thursday with no progress on immigration, leaders from both parties said they would return to the issue early in the new year.

headline: California: Guilty Plea Is Planned in Navy Case
text: A Navy criminal investigator, John B. Beliveau II, plans to plead guilty on Tuesday to accepting bribes from a Malaysian contractor, representing the first conviction in a major ship-supply scandal, his lawyer, Gretchen Von Helms, said Thursday. Federal prosecutors in San Diego have accused Mr. Beliveau of accepting trips and prostitutes in exchange for alerting the contractor, Leonard Glenn Francis, to inquiries into his billing practices. Mr. Beliveau, who is expected to cooperate with investigators, is one of six Navy officials connected to the scandal. Prosecutors contend that Mr. Francis overcharged the Navy by at least $20 million.

headline: Felton Expected to Miss 2 to 3 Weeks as Problems Mount for Knicks
text: Raymond Felton has posted career-low numbers as the Knicks’ point guard this season, and his situation went from bad to worse Thursday when the team announced that he would miss the next two to three weeks with a strained left hamstring.

headline: The Biggest Losers
text: The pundit consensus seems to be that Republicans lost in the just-concluded budget deal. Overall spending will be a bit higher than the level mandated by the sequester, the straitjacket imposed back in 2011. Meanwhile, Democrats avoided making any concessions on Social Security or Medicare. Call this one for Team D, I guess.

headline: U.S. Orders Sweeping Safety Review of Metro-North
text: Federal transportation officials said on Thursday that they would begin an extraordinarily rare review of the operations and “safety culture” of the Metro-North Railroad — the first such investigation ever conducted for a passenger railroad.

headline: As Sales Lag, VW Picks a New Leader for U.S.
text: Midway through an ambitious 10-year plan to become the world’s largest automaker, Volkswagen has hit a rough patch in the United States, with sales stagnating this year even as the rest of the industry has surged.

headline: Strengthen the Presidency
text: A couple of months ago, I visited the Congressional Budget Office, one of our most trust-inspiring government agencies. On the elevator ride, one of the economists confided that it can be challenging to be in government these days.

headline: Investigating Political Hack Work Near the George Washington Bridge
text: Apparently — by which I mean, definitely — a political hack shut lanes entering the George Washington Bridge for five days in September and ruined traffic.

headline: Educational Publisher’s Charity, Accused of Seeking Profits, Will Pay Millions
text: The Pearson Foundation, the charitable arm of one of the nation’s largest educational publishers, will pay $7.7 million to settle accusations that it repeatedly broke New York State law by assisting in for-profit ventures.

headline: Epiphany Turns a Coach Into ‘Riverboat Ron’
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The firing of Coach Ron Rivera was inevitable, or so the narrative went on Oct. 6 after the Carolina Panthers lost at Arizona, 22-6, to fall to 1-3.

headline: After Hurricane, Separation and Costly Home Repairs
text: Anne Corso and her husband, Nicholas, did not believe the storm would be as bad as the news reports said it would be.

headline: Finally, the Volcker Rule
text: The success of the Volcker Rule, unveiled this week, depends on federal regulators doing what they failed to do in the run-up to the financial crisis and have done only haltingly since then: Enforce the spirit as well as the letter of the law against the wishes of powerful banks.

headline: Opposition Leader’s Execution Spurs Protests in Bangladesh
text: NEW DELHI — The execution of a top opposition leader on Thursday night spurred violent protests across Bangladesh, with worse expected for Sunday when the opposition has called for a nationwide strike.

headline: Trade Talks Produce a Deal
text: After more than a decade of negotiations, the World Trade Organization’s 159 member countries reached an agreement last week that will provide a much-needed boost to the global economy by easing the flow of goods across borders.

Lift the Cuban Embargo
text: Some Republicans and Cuban-American lawmakers are criticizing President Obama for shaking President Raúl Castro’s hand at the memorial service for Nelson Mandela. Their reaction to a gesture of common courtesy should come as no surprise given Washington’s senseless commitment to a failed 50-year policy toward Cuba.

headline: Mean Streets to Hardcourts for Chicago Youth Tennis Program
text: CHICAGO — Inside an LA Fitness health club on the South Side of Chicago, dozens of young tennis players vied for space in the cramped five-court complex on a brisk fall afternoon.

headline: The Kremlin, the Press and the Protesters: A Case Study of Rule by Paranoia
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — The closing of the RIA Novosti news agency in the middle of the Ukrainian crisis reflects Vladimir Putin’s increasingly pronounced view of a zero-sum world, in which enemies at home and abroad plot against Russia. In depicting the Ukrainian protests as a “pogrom,” and in replacing a respected news agency with a propaganda machine, Mr. Putin followed the more openly aggressive stance of his return to the presidency in May 2012 — what Russians call Putin II, or Late Putin.

headline: Post-Katrina Police Prosecutions in New Orleans Face Setbacks

text: Is Kiev a key ally to the European Union, or just a potential trading partner and a buffer against Russia?

headline: Sentence Cut in Texas for School Official Jailed in Test Scandal
text: HOUSTON — The former superintendent of an El Paso school district who was sent to prison in one of the country’s worst education scandals has received an unexpected reward — a nearly one-year reduction in his prison term.

headline: A Fraud Trial Centers on Not-So-Fine Wine and Sky-High Prices
text: They were French winemakers of the highest caliber, from a narrow strip in Burgundy, France, from families who for generations have produced some of the world’s most sought-after wine.

headline: Nassau Police Leader Resigns After Inquiry Into an Arrest
text: The police commissioner of Nassau County resigned on Thursday after the county’s district attorney found that he had intervened to order an arrest in a politically charged case.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 13, 2013

headline: Among the Debris, Something Divine
text: Something bright and beautiful pulses in the shadows of “The Night Alive,” the extraordinary new play by Conor McPherson that opened on Thursday night in a Donmar Warehouse production imported from London by the Atlantic Theater Company.

headline: But Wait, There’s More
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Of all the things I learned today, the most surprising was that the techno-widget I wear in my ear when driving was named after a Danish king. Go figure. That BLUETOOTH device that makes it look like we are all talking to ourselves was named after King Harald “Bluetooth” Blatand, who ruled from A.D. 958-986.

headline: New Obama Adviser Brings Corporate Ties
text: WASHINGTON — The defense contractor Northrop Grumman gave money to the left-leaning Center for American Progress, founded by John D. Podesta, as the nonprofit group at times bemoaned what it called the harmful impact of major reductions in Pentagon spending.

headline: Shivering Timbers, And More
text: The formidable Irish actor Fiona Shaw is not encrusted with barnacles or dripping seaweed in portraying the crazed title character in the new stage presentation of “The Rime of the Ancient Mariner,” the celebrated verse ballad by Samuel Taylor Coleridge, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater. As she wanders up and down the aisles before the production begins, she is all but indistinguishable from audience members in her fleece sweatshirt, simple black pants and tennis shoes.

headline: Obama Panel Said to Urge N.S.A. Curbs
text: WASHINGTON — A presidential advisory committee charged with examining the operations of the National Security Agency has concluded that a program to collect data on every phone call made in the United States should continue, though under broad new restraints that would be intended to increase privacy protections, according to officials with knowledge of the report’s contents.

headline: On Left Side of Yankees’ Infield, Not Much to Stand On
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — For nine years they were next-door neighbors on the same stretch of real estate: five years on the left side of the infield at the old Yankee Stadium, four at the new.

headline: Ex-Brooklyn Judge Seeks Reversal of His Verdict in 1999 Murder Case
text: The judge’s conscience gnawed at him a little more every year after he retired from the bench. With every news article he read about a wrongful conviction, Frank J. Barbaro, the former Brooklyn judge and assemblyman, would return to a particular murder case in 1999, and question whether he had made the right decision to send a man to prison for 15 years to life.

headline: Judge Rules Against Cross on U.S. Land
text: LOS ANGELES — A federal judge ruled Thursday that a cross on federal land in San Diego violated the First Amendment ban on a government endorsement of religion and ordered it removed within 90 days.

headline: After Tributes to Mandela the Peacemaker, Recalling Mandela the Fighter
text: HOWICK, South Africa — To hear the tributes pouring forth across the globe, Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s first black president and a universal symbol of peace and reconciliation, may seem like a teddy bear of a man.

headline: Jobless Fear Looming Cutoff of Benefits
text: WASHINGTON — Mary Helen Gillespie of Londonderry, N.H., is about to lose her last government lifeline. Since being laid off from a large banking firm in April, Ms. Gillespie, 57, has been living on little more than her unemployment insurance payments of $384 a week. She has burned through her savings and moved back in with her parents.

headline: Chamberlain Is Said to Get Fresh Start With the Tigers
text: Six years after his electrifying debut as a Yankees reliever as unhittable as Mariano Rivera, Joba Chamberlain is a Tiger, having agreed to a one-year, $2.5 million deal with Detroit, a person close to Chamberlain said Thursday.

headline: 2,500 Applicants Get False News of Acceptance to Fordham
text: The financial aid notice that Zoe Rankin received from Fordham University on Wednesday afternoon was unequivocal.

headline: Bruised by Scandal, British Lawmakers Reject Raise
text: LONDON — Not many people turn down a raise; even fewer denounce the very idea. But leading British lawmakers, burdened by their reputation for money-grabbing, are fighting this week for the right to reject higher pay.

headline: Trial of an Ex-Premier Raises Tensions in Thailand Further
text: BANGKOK — Abhisit Vejjajiva, a former prime minister, was charged Thursday in a Bangkok criminal court with premeditated murder in a case connected to a military crackdown on protesters in 2010.

headline: With Program in Ruins, Coach Builds Trust at Hofstra
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — Joe Mihalich tells a story: When he was hired as the basketball coach at Hofstra in April, Jeff Hathaway, the athletic director, asked him if he would like to meet the team.

headline: $15 Hourly Minimum Wage in Northwest City Faces Court Challenge
text: SEATTLE — The highest municipal minimum wage in the nation, approved by voters last month in the small city of SeaTac, Wash., at $15 an hour, survived a narrow election and a recount. Now, just weeks before its scheduled Jan. 1 start date – raising the pay of thousands of SeaTac residents and workers at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, which is within the city limits — opponents are sending in the lawyers.

text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

headline: Nets Win Their Third in a Row Despite an Injury to Lopez
text: Deron Williams wove through the Los Angeles Clippers and dizzied them with his dribbles. His cuts and feints elicited whoops and delighted gasps from the Barclays Center crowd.

headline: Tobacco Firms’ Strategy Limits Poorer Nations’ Smoking Laws
text: Tobacco companies are pushing back against a worldwide rise in antismoking laws, using a little-noticed legal strategy to delay or block regulation. The industry is warning countries that their tobacco laws violate an expanding web of trade and investment treaties, raising the prospect of costly, prolonged legal battles, health advocates and officials said.

headline: After Acquiring Colon, Mets Discuss Trading Davis
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The Mets officials here seemed pleased with themselves as word spread of their agreement with Bartolo Colon.

headline: $3 Million Prizes Will Go to Mathematicians, Too
text: Yuri Milner, the Russian entrepreneur, philanthropist and self-described “failed physicist” who made a splash two years ago when he began handing out lavish cash awards to scientists, is expanding the universe of his largess again: He and Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook announced Thursday night that they would begin handing out $3 million awards to mathematicians.

headline: What’s on Friday
text: 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) WHALE WARS: A COMMANDER RISES For five seasons, the series “Whale Wars” has followed Capt. Paul Watson, the leader of the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society and a founder of Greenpeace, as he guided the Steve Irwin, the society’s flagship vessel, through Antarctic waters to save the lives of whales. Along the way, he has tangled with governments and made some enemies. In this two-hour special, Captain Watson must step down from his post just as his armada leaves for the Southern Ocean, causing those aboard to ask how their mission — and the organization — can succeed without his leadership.

headline: Love and Gender, According to the Hindu Epics
text: Now that the Supreme Court has restored the 19th-century ban on homosexuality, when all the arguments are done, when we Indians have heard everything about freedom over our bodies and homosexuality being a Western import and the right to privacy and more, maybe it’s time to remember our traditions. Perhaps there are lessons there about homosexuality too.

headline: Top Students at Community Colleges to Have Chance to Raise Ambitions
text: A disparate group of colleges from across the country — public and private, two-year and four-year — plans to announce a novel alliance on Friday aimed at producing high-achieving community college graduates and making it easier for them to transfer into bachelor’s programs.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/Siena College Poll of New York City consists of telephone interviews with 1,016 adult residents throughout the city conducted Dec. 7 to 11.

headline: New Yorkers on de Blasio and Bloomberg
text: The New York Times and Siena College asked New York City residents for their assessment of Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio and the outgoing mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Poll Finds Hope Is Running High for Next Mayor of New York City
text: With Bill de Blasio’s inauguration less than a month away, New Yorkers are highly optimistic about his mayoralty — but they remain skeptical that he can achieve major changes on some of the core issues that defined his candidacy, like the widening gap between the rich and poor and the scarcity of affordable housing, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll.

headline: Full Results of The New York Times/Siena College Poll
text: Most New Yorkers expressed optimism about the incoming administration of Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio.

headline: Huckabee, an Eye on 2016, Sees ‘a Real Opportunity’

headline: Thousands Gather in South Africa’s Capital to Get a Final Glimpse of Mandela
text: QUNU, South Africa — For a third and final day, thousands of South Africans filed past the body of Nelson Mandela on Friday before his glass-topped coffin was removed for the last time from the Union Buildings in the capital, Pretoria, where long lines of people waited in the gathering heat to catch a final glimpse of the man they credit with unifying the nation and presiding over the demise of apartheid rule.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Interpreter at Mandela Memorial Says He Saw Angels
text: In “Interpreter at Mandela Memorial Says He Saw ‘Angels’,” Nicholas Kulish, John Eligon and Alan Cowell report on a story that has “spread a pall of distraction and embarrassment” over South Africa’s commemoration of Nelson Mandela this week.

headline: What Is Your Relationship With Guns?
text: The anniversary of the elementary school shooting in Newtown, Conn., is this weekend, and the nation continues to wrestle with what role guns should play in American life. As The Times writes in “Gun Country,” a multimedia presentation: “They bring families together and tear them apart. They summon pride, and fear. They kill innocent people and protect them.”

headline: Grasping for Clues in North Korean Execution
text: SEOUL, South Korea — As he was confessing to crimes that would lead to his execution, the doomed uncle of North Korea’s leader suggested that he hoped the country’s many economic woes would drive the military to overthrow the Kim dynasty, the state-run news agency said.

headline: North Korean Execution Raises Unease in China
text: North Korea’s announcement that Jang Song-thaek, the uncle of the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, had been executed for treason triggered expressions of dismay in China, the North’s only major ally.

headline: The Volkswagen XL1: A Possible View of Tomorrow
text: If you’ve ever pined for the day when Volkswagen will return to its roots and build a car that’s stranger-looking and more efficient than most other cars, that time may have come. The XL1, VW’s superstreamlined plug-in diesel-electric hybrid, is like nothing out there. But it may be a glimpse into the future of personal mobility.

headline: A Poor Apology for a Word
text: LONDON — I am sitting in a cafe in a leafy part of South London. A teenager inadvertently bashes me in the face with his rucksack and I say “sorry,” as if on his behalf. Five minutes later, a young woman flattens my foot with her stroller and each of us blurts another “sorry.” Getting up to leave, I knock over my cup. A waitress descends on this little embarrassment with a cloth and an accusatory “sorry,” while I twice utter the same word.

headline: 25 Prisoners Flee Baghdad Jail
text: BAGHDAD — Twenty-five suspects held on terrorism charges, some facing the death penalty, escaped early Friday from a prison north of Baghdad, killing two guards and raising the question of whether they had received inside help, security officials said. The prison is where Saddam Hussein was hanged in 2006.

headline: The Great War’s Ominous Echoes
text: Oxford, England — Earlier this year, I was on holiday in Corsica and wandered into the church of a tiny hamlet in the hills where I found a memorial to the dead from World War I. Out of a population that can have been no more than 150, eight young men, bearing among them only three last names, had died in that conflict. Such lists can be found all over Europe, in great cities and in small villages. Similar memorials are spread around the globe, for the Great War, as it was known before 1940, also drew soldiers from Asia, Africa and North America.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Regulators Weigh Cellphone Use on Airplanes
text: The Transportation Department said on Thursday that it would consider banning the use of cellphones for voice calls aboard airplanes, a reaction to public outrage at a Federal Communications Commission proposal to lift a rule that has long forbidden the use of mobile phones during flight, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: 1913: News of Antarctic Expedition Reaches London
text: Captain Robert Falcon Scott’s expedition was one of the most dramatic journeys in the race for the South Pole. Having lost to Roald Amundsen, who reached the South Pole about a month before the British expedition, “Scott of the Antarctic” and his companions perished in the unforgiving conditions of the Antarctic regions in early 1912.

headline: Youth Trumps Experience and Wealth in Unlikely Aam Aadmi Party Win
text: NEW DELHI – Of all the David-and-Goliath battles the Aam Aadmi Party faced in the Delhi assembly elections last week, the one in Mangolpuri, a gritty district in the northern part of the capital, was among the least likely to result in a win for the upstart party.

headline: My Insurance Was Canceled — And That’s O.K.
text: My journey to get a new health insurance policy is just about complete.

headline: An Office Romance That Just Clicked
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: New Holiday Schedule Infuriates Many Chinese
text: Lunar New Year’s Eve, the most important day in the traditional Chinese calendar, has been excluded from the official holiday schedule for 2014, a change that has been met with outrage by many Chinese.

headline: European Union Warns on Bitcoin
text: LONDON – The European Union on Friday added to a string of recent warnings about the safety of using and investing in Bitcoin, the virtual currency that is not issued by any government.

headline: Los Besos en el Pan
text: This is the Spanish language version of the op-ed: When We Were Poor Before.

headline: In a World of Games, an N.B.A. Epic for the Ages
text: Games, games, so many games. From January to December. All over the planet. In so many sports.

headline: Mao’s Birth Commemorated in Gold and Gem-Encrusted Statue
text: Mao Zedong, the Communist revolutionary who rhapsodized the Chinese people as “poor and blank” has received the birthday present he probably never dreamed of. He has been commemorated in a manner befitting the excesses of modern-day capitalist China: a statue covered in gold and inlaid with gems that is said to be worth about 100 million renminbi, or $16.5 million.

headline: Going It Alone
text: France tries to stop the killing in the Central African Republic.

headline: How Blackstone Made Money on Hilton
text: The Blackstone Group, which took the Hilton hotel group public on Thursday, has increased the value of its investment by nearly $10 billion through a combination of lucky timing, smart financial engineering and disciplined management. In the topsy-turvy world of private equity math, however, that huge gain might at first glance look like a multibillion-dollar loss, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. After all, the initial market capitalization of Hilton Worldwide Holdings on Thursday was $20 billion, compared with the headline-grabbing price of $26 billion that Blackstone paid when it took Hilton private in 2007.

headline: Simon Property to Spin Off Strip Center Business
text: The Simon Property Group, the Indianapolis-based owner and operator of shopping malls, announced on Friday that it planned to spin off its strip centers and smaller enclosed malls into a real estate investment trust.

headline: The Francis Factor
text: BUENOS AIRES — Luck appeared to be on Argentina’s side last Friday, when the draw for next year’s World Cup placed it in “Group F” along with Bosnia and Herzegovina, Iran and Nigeria. No major challengers: phew.

headline: Trapped by a Subway Door
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Taking the Surreal to Its Very Limit
text: LONDON — Let’s start with the hats: an Op-art swirling circle of straw; disembodied Dali-esque lips; a fat, curling serpent of satin and mesh; or denuded feathers spiked into aggressive arrows — crazy concoctions that took headgear to its artistic limits.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Khadi and Co Blanket
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Questions and Answers About Cellphones on Planes
text: Airline passengers have been in an uproar since news broke that the Federal Communications Commission was planning to overturn a rule that banned the use of cellphones on planes while in flight. The following are some of the most popular questions I get from readers on this topic.

headline: Beyoncé Surprises Fans With New Album
text: A few days ahead of Santa Claus, another overnight visitor was delivering surprises to those awaiting holiday gifts. Fans of Beyoncé woke up on Friday morning to discover that she had released an entire new album, without any previous promotion or fanfare, and made it for sale directly on iTunes.

headline: 36 Hours in Colombo, Sri Lanka
text: Sri Lanka is so jam-packed with alluring outdoorsy activities that visitors often high-tail it out of the capital a day or two after arriving, choosing instead to spend their vacation days lounging on a southern beach, whale-watching off the coast or leopard-spotting in a national park. Yet Colombo is fast becoming a draw in itself. This city of 555,000 people has been on fast-forward since a 25-year civil war ended in 2009. Checkpoints have come down, trendy lounge bars have opened up, and the vibe is one of cautious optimism combined with an increasingly cosmopolitan outlook. Today, this colorful city on the Indian Ocean, with its laid-back island ambience, palm trees, decaying colonial buildings and smattering of modern office blocks, is the perfect place to get a sense of where Sri Lanka is going after so many tumultuous years.

headline: Rithy Panh on ‘The Missing Picture’ and Living With Tragedy
text: Of the 76 entries for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, Rithy Panh’s “Missing Picture,” representing Cambodia, is one of only two documentary films submitted in the category. But there’s never been a documentary quite like “The Missing Picture,” in which Mr. Panh uses clay figures, dioramas, period music and archival film footage recovered through detective work to tell the story of how his family — parents, siblings and nephews — and 1.8 million others perished in the Khmer Rouge genocide.

headline: Meeting Opposition Leaders, Ukraine’s President Calls for End to Protests
text: KIEV, Ukraine — In his first meeting with opposition leaders since the outbreak of a sustained civil uprising here, President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine had a succinct message on Friday for the tens of thousands of protesters calling for changes at the highest levels of government. He urged them to stop protesting.

headline: Mandela's Unfinished Revolution
text: For all his remarkable achievements, Nelson Mandela died with his dream for South Africa incomplete. Democracy and peace were attained, yet real racial harmony, social justice and equality seem, in some ways, further away than ever.

headline: How Young Iranians View America
text: ISFAHAN, Iran — It’s not hard for an American to draw a crowd in Iran. Just speak English.

headline: With Affordable Care Act, Canceled Policies for New York Professionals
text: Many in New York’s professional and cultural elite have long supported President Obama’s health care plan. But now, to their surprise, thousands of writers, opera singers, music teachers, photographers, doctors, lawyers and others are learning that their health insurance plans are being canceled and they may have to pay more to get comparable coverage, if they can find it.

headline: In Our Pages: December 14
text: 1888: Drunkenness in Great Britain

headline: Rudi Dornbusch and the Salvation of International Macroeconomics (Wonkish)
text: Over at the Economix blog, Binyamin Appelbaum has a post about Stan Fischer’s role in the early development of New Keynesian macroeconomics. I was a student at MIT at the time, and remember Stan assigning papers on long-term contracts, which he viewed as one possible way to think about the sources of nominal price and wage stickiness – which he obviously considered both a clear fact about the world and important.

headline: Engineering the Climate – Colbert’s ‘All-Chocolate Dinner’
text: The Colbert ReportGet More: Colbert Report Full Episodes,Video Archive

headline: In Florida, Plans for a Legoland Hotel
text: Legoland Florida, a 150-acre family theme park in Winter Haven, Fla., recently announced that is planning a new Lego-themed hotel.

headline: In Performance: Anne-Marie Duff
text: The actress performs a scene from Lincoln Center Theater’s production of Shakespeare’s “Macbeth,” on Broadway at the Vivian Beaumont.

headline: In Performance: Anne-Marie Duff
text: In Lincoln Center Theater’s new Broadway production of “Macbeth,” Anne-Marie Duff plays Lady Macbeth opposite Ethan Hawke at the Scottish king. In this scene she performs an excerpt from the character’s famous “unsex me here” scene in Act I. The show, directed by Jack O’Brien, is at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

headline: Feeble Hiring in Construction Is a Stubborn Drag on Growth
text: SIX years after the Great Recession began at the end of 2007, the United States still has fewer jobs than it did then.

headline: Off the Charts: Jobs Are Back, Except for Construction
text: Employment in the United States remains below the peak reached in January 2008, entirely because of a collapse in construction employment greater than any decline since World War II.

headline: A Health Care Mystery Explained
text: Ezra Klein is puzzled (or at least says he is; I suspect he understands it perfectly) by Republican hypocrisy on health care. For many years the GOP has advocated things that are supposed to bring the magic of the marketplace and individual incentives to health care: higher deductibles to give people “skin in the game”, competition among private insurers via exchanges — competition that would include reducing costs by limiting networks — and, of course, for cuts in Medicare. Now the GOP complains bitterly that some Obamacare policies have high deductibles, that it relies on the horror of exchanges, that some networks are limited, and that there are cuts in Medicare.

headline: Video: Christian Bale on What the Producer Doesn’t Need to Know
text: More than half of the potential Oscar best actor nominees became Golden Globes hopefuls on Thursday, helped by the Globes comedy and drama categories, which means Oscar Isaac (“Inside Llewyn Davis”) doesn’t have to compete against Chiwetel Ejiofor (“12 Years a Slave”). It’s still a crowded field, though, with many big-screen heroes in high-stakes roles. Oscar-caliber tales are often about survival, but rarely have so few been literally death-defying.

headline: Army Coach Faces Tough Call at Quarterback
text: Mired in a record 11-game losing streak against Navy, Army may resort to a late-season quarterback change when the storied series resumes Saturday in Philadelphia for a 114th meeting.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Coolest Small Businesses in America
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: On a Tragic Anniversary, Turning Off the News
text: Last year, at this time, we were listening to a lot of holiday music on the radio in the car.

headline: Rights Advocate Is Indicted in China Over Role in Campaign Against Corruption
text: BEIJING — Chinese prosecutors have formally indicted a prominent rights advocate for his role in an anticorruption campaign that prompted street rallies across the country and deeply alarmed Communist Party leaders, his lawyer said Friday.

headline: Strange Moors
text: “A True Novel” is a riveting tale of doomed lovers set against the backdrop of postwar Japan, with characters familiar to a Western audience: a rags-to-riches antihero, a tempestuous heroine who dies too young, a loyal housekeeper who tells their story. So how does the Gothic excess of “Wuthering Heights” translate to a culture better known for emotional restraint, even repression?

headline: Tough Guise
text: My all-boys high school A.P. English class was presided over by a glamorous, overqualified woman known to us as Dr. Lerner. I might have been in love with her. She smelled wonderful, like lemon trees on a hot day. Knowing she was a doctor of literature didn’t prevent me from imagining various medical situations in which she saved my life.

headline: Maestro
text: Whenever a generous collection of correspondence like “The Leonard Bernstein Letters” appears, one rejoices, but sadly. People still write one another, though usually through electronic and social media that discourage leisurely soul-searching or digressions. Lenny was lucky he didn’t live later, or we’d have “The Leonard Bern­stein Tweets.”

headline: Patronizing the Arts
text: Who’s afraid of Alain de Botton? At 43, he’s already an elder in the church of self-help, the master of spinning sugary “secular sermons” out of literature (“How Proust Can Change Your Life”), philosophy (“The Consolations of Philosophy”), architecture (“The Architecture of Happiness”). He has a remarkably guileless face and a friendly, populist vision of art. Why then do I keep checking my pockets? And why the grumbles that he condescends to his subjects and regards his readers, as the British writer Lynn Barber put it, as “ants”?

headline: Seduced by Naples
text: It doesn’t take long to understand Naples.

headline: Bon Appétit
text: In the creation myth of modern American food, Eden is played by pre- and postwar France. It was at its tables that a handful of people well attuned to pleasure had their worlds blasted open. Their ensuing desire to build lives around the joys of food and cooking caused a revolution in the United States — and it isn’t over yet.

headline: Tips for Smart Shopping in Marrakesh
text: The souks in Marrakesh have long charmed visitors with miles of closet-size shops selling Skittles-colored slippers; carpets intricately woven from camel wool and cactus silk; embroidered, buttery soft leather purses; and other wares that mark the city’s distinctive style.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘American Hustle,’ ‘Saving Mr. Banks’ and ‘The Hobbit’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics look at David O. Russell’s latest film “American Hustle,” Peter Jackson’s “Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug” and “Saving Mr. Banks,” featuring Tom Hanks as Walt Disney.

headline: Home Cooking
text: Not long ago, this big, messy country united. Culinarily, at least. We all sat down to our Thanksgiving tables and ate (mostly) the same thing at (mostly) the same time, before retreating to our big, messy corners to cook and eat the diverse, constantly evolving cuisine we call American. The latest batch of narrative food books (not to be confused with strictly recipe-driven cookbooks) explores some of those corners, reminding us how food defines who we are (Patriots? Capitalists? Shameless Worshipers of Celebrity?), where we’ve been and — ­perhaps most American of all — who we want to be.

headline: Reanimated
text: Comics can tell certain kinds of stories that prose, photographs and films can’t. They can also tell familiar stories in drastically different ways. The artists of some of this season’s graphic novels transform history into broad comedy or rollicking adventure. Others show us worlds frighteningly different from our own, or aestheticize the realities we know with something as simple as a set of squiggly lines or a canny splash of color.

headline: Call of the Weird
text: Dana Goodyear writes with wit, grace and a contagious sense of humor about some of the most disgusting food you may never see fit to put in your mouth. Dining with a forensic entomologist who is an advocate of insects as comestibles, she reports that “he had arrived at his latest culinary discovery, he said, while experimenting with mediums for preserving maggots collected from murder victims. . . . He soaked large sarcophagid maggots in baths of grapefruit, lemon, lime, and pomelo juice, and voilà! Maggot ceviche! ‘It’s a little chewy,’ he said, ‘but tasty.’ ”

headline: Dying for Attention
text: Patricia Cornwell’s imperious forensic scientist, Kay Scarpetta, shows uncharacteristic signs of vulnerability at the beginning of DUST (Putnam, $28.95), after she returns from a traumatic trip to Newtown, Conn., to help with autopsies of victims of the mass murders at Sandy Hook Elementary School. The experience has left her in an “amnesiac” state of mind. “I can’t recall or share what at last I could explain to devastated people after I’ve taken care of their dead.”

headline: Naughty or Nice? Not Everyone Is Jolly About SantaCon Coming to Town
text: New Yorkers have long endured other people’s celebrations.

headline: Southern Literature
text: THE MAID’S VERSIONBy Daniel WoodrellLittle, Brown, $25.

headline: What’s the Best Bet When Weighing Cornucopians and Catastrophists?
text: Bill Gates has posted a valuable review of “The Bet: Paul Ehrlich, Julian Simon, and Our Gamble Over Earth’s Future,” by Yale historian Paul Sabin. Gates nicely summarizes the book’s analysis of the famous wager over the limits of natural resources between the ecologist Ehrlich, author of the portentous bestseller “The Population Bomb,” and Simon, a champion of free markets and human ingenuity (called the “Doomslayer” by Wired).

headline: Paperback Row
text: I AM THE CHANGE: Barack Obama and the Future of Liberalism,  by Charles R. Kesler. (Broadside/HarperCollins, $14.99.) Kesler, a conservative scholar and the editor of The Claremont Review of Books, sees President Obama as the “latest embodiment of the visionary prophet-statesman” — the fourth phase of the Progressive experiment begun at the turn of the 20th century, following Woodrow Wilson, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Lyndon B. Johnson.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: WONDER OF WONDERS: A Cultural History of “Fiddler on the Roof,” by Alisa Solomon.  (Metropolitan/Holt, $32.) A smart social analysis of the making of the musical and its reflection of changing Jewish identity in America.

headline: Holiday Meat-and-Greet
text: We all know what to cook on Thanksgiving. But Christmas? New Year’s Day? Sam Sifton provides recipes and video guides for five protein-heavy main courses.

headline: Playing Both Sides
text: “The genius of you Americans,” the Egyptian president Gamal Abdel Nasser teasingly told a senior C.I.A. official, Miles A. Copeland Jr., in the late 1950s, “is that you never made clear-cut stupid moves, only complicated stupid moves.”

headline: Holiday Feast: Ham
text: Sam Sifton shows how to make a ham fit for any special occasion.

headline: Holiday Feast: Beef Rib Roast
text: Sam Sifton shows how to make a beef rib roast fit for any wintertime special occasion.

headline: Holiday Feast: Goose
text: Sam Sifton shows how to make a goose fit for any wintertime special occasion.

headline: Holiday Feast: Crown Roast of Pork
text: Sam Sifton shows how to make a crown roast of pork fit for any wintertime special occasion.

headline: Holiday Feast: Turkey
text: Sam Sifton shows how to make a turkey fit for any wintertime special occasion.

headline: Talk of the Town
text: Daniel Menaker loves words, and you can see it in every clause, in the rhythms of his language, even in the length of the sentences in his bracing memoir, “My Mistake.” A veteran editor at The New Yorker and Random House, an insider who has always felt like an outsider, he was jolted by lung cancer several years ago into re-­examining his past. He grabs the reader with urgency as he grapples with big questions: What shaped me? Where did I go right and wrong? What has my life meant? His clever, fast-paced prose makes you stop and think and wonder, meandering down your own byways, contemplating the ways his story ­reverberates.

headline: Waiting Out the Dark
text: Why did people join the Communist movement back in the day? Ivan Klima, the distinguished Czech writer, raises the question in the prologue to his memoir, “My Crazy Century,” and he raises the temperature, too, by defining Communism as “a criminal conspiracy against democracy.” People did join, though. Klima acknowledges a little sheepishly that he was among them, in his younger years. He offers a schematic preliminary explanation: Young people need to rebel, they yearn for simple theories of the world and so forth. And then, with his prologue behind him and his anger and mortification exposed, he devotes the next 400 pages to the real explanation, which turns out to be sadder and more complicated.

headline: Dickens Without the Darkness
text: Paper Mill Playhouse’s revival of “Oliver!” takes a lighthearted musical and whisks it up into an even cheerier one.

headline: Three-Ring Circuses
text: Staying informed about animal issues doesn’t mean reading exclusively about the fun stuff — a Border collie who knows 1,000 words, or the recent discovery that elephants recognize the gesture of pointing, much as we do. Animal lovers must also confront darker subjects, such as the link between terrorism and the slaughter of elephants for their ivory. Soul-bruising as it is, the awful truth can point the way toward remedies.

headline: Image of the Day: December 13
text: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh paying tribute to the victims of the 2001 attack on the Indian Parliament.

headline: A Fever You Can See in the Eyes
text: A 9-year-old boy has a high fever, a single swollen gland and no obvious source of infection.

headline: Welcome to Tchotchke Town
text: Scenes from a market in Yiwu, China.

headline: Confessions of a Daydreamer
text: I have, over the course of four decades, fought Rommel on the desert plains of North Africa. I have drummed for the Who at the Railway Hotel in Wealdstone and the Rochester Community War Memorial auditorium. I have clinked drinks with the wits at the Algonquin Round Table and won a Pulitzer for publishing an exposé on the slums of Mumbai, low-fiving the ghost of Henry Luce on my way to allowing Richard Avedon to shoot my portrait.

headline: The First Amendment Right to Nonpolitical Homework
text: For my daughter’s high-school biology class, the students are required to take a public action addressing climate change. They have a wide range of options of what they can do: write a letter to a public official, design a website, develop a public-service announcement or organize a flash mob. They are required to submit proof that they presented their work publicly — that is, that they mailed the letter, launched the website, etc. Is it ethical for the school to require students to speak publicly on a specific issue? Or even to give extra credit for doing so? Does the students’ right to free speech also give them the right not to speak publicly on this topic? KATHARINE LONDON, CAMBRIDGE, MASS.

headline: What Happened When Claire Danes Met the Real C.I.A.
text: Did you consider yourself a good secret-keeper before you got the role of Carrie Mathison on “Homeland”? I would not say that secret-keeping is one of my finer skills, actually.

headline: The 12.1.13 Issue
text: MAKING A SCENE

headline: Who Made Those Cop Shows?
text: When David Simon, the creator of “The Wire,” pitched his pilot to HBO, he promised to deliver “a cop show that seizes the highest qualitative ground through realism, good writing and a more brutal assessment of police, police work and the drug culture.” His show would reveal the gritty truth of law enforcement — with all its politics and sleaze — and give the lie to other cop dramas like “CSI” and “Law & Order,” where “every punch was pulled.”

headline: ‘How You Doing, Baby?’
text: One fall evening in 1995, I dialed the number of a woman who rented an apartment in the building I had just begun managing in Oak Park. Oak Park, home to Hemingway and Frank Lloyd Wright, is known for its progressive housing policies and integration efforts, especially around Austin Boulevard, which was three blocks away from my building and divides Oak Park from Chicago. The West Side of Chicago is famous, too — for gangs, for drugs, for crime. And before that, for discriminatory housing practices. But Oak Park created a series of programs based on the Fair Housing Act of 1968 as a way to right the wrongs of housing discrimination, including creating my job as a resident manager.

headline: Qualcomm Picks Insider as New Chief Executive
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Qualcomm, the wireless technology company that is one of the largest chip makers in the world, said on Friday that its chief operating officer, Steven M. Mollenkopf, would become its new chief executive.

headline: The Best Book Covers of 2013
text: The year’s best cover designs, chosen by Nicholas Blechman, the Book Review’s art director.

headline: Jumps, Taps and Slides in a Holiday Pastiche
text: “The Best Things Happen While You’re Dancing” is the title of one of the Irving Berlin songs in “White Christmas,” and it is also a fitting description for the production now at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport.

headline: Top of the 2013 Class
text: And then there were 10. This week, we reveal our 10 Best Books of the year, culled from last week’s 100 Notable Books. While many of the authors will be familiar to readers of the Book Review, all of them appear on the list for the first time.

headline: Drawing Boards
text: New books represent a range of drawing approaches — cartoons, comics, illustrations, logos, posters and more.

headline: Inside the List
text: Jack’s Back: When Tom Clancy died on Oct. 1, he and his recent collaborator Mark Greaney had just completed a new Jack Ryan thriller, “Command Authority” — and here it comes, crashing onto the hardcover fiction list at No. 1. That’s a familiar position for Clancy’s books, but it somehow eluded the novel that introduced him (and Ryan) to the world: “The Hunt for Red October” spent 28 weeks on the hardcover list in 1985, but never reached the top spot. (It did hit No. 1 in paper­back.) Not that Clancy needed to worry. By the time Ryan made his second appearance, in 1987’s “Patriot Games,” he debuted at No. 1.

headline: Together Again
text: The kitchen of the Thomas house in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, exudes an air of cozy domesticity.

headline: New York’s Hunger Problem
text: Across the nation, there are long lines at food pantries and millions of needy Americans are struggling to afford adequate food — a struggle made even harder last month with the expiration of a temporary boost to benefit levels enacted in 2009.

headline: Exclusive | 12 East 69th Street
text: The stark facade of this 19-room house, once home to a suite of medical offices, belies the interior.

headline: Upper East Side Mansion: Lavish on Every Level
text: An Upper East Side mansion whose stark limestone facade is a foil for six levels of elaborate interiors that take their cues from disparate locales like the Palace of Versailles, the historic castles and churches of Italy, and a red velvet movie theater that once thrived in Queens, is poised to enter the market at a genre-popping asking price of $114.077 million.

headline: Times Minute | Kim's Grip on Power
text: Also on the Minute, bitterness prevails as the Senate endures a second all-nighter. And is sugar to blame for unhealthy eating habits?

headline: Times Minute | Kim’s Grip on Power
Skills Practice | Distinguishing Between Fact and Opinion
text: An article published in The Times on Dec. 13 begins:

headline: Nuts About Greens
text: I was planning to devote this week’s Recipes for Health to walnuts, as the California walnut harvest took place just a few weeks ago and the walnuts I am buying in my farmers’ market couldn’t be fresher (well, they could be a little fresher – slightly moist, the way fresh, undried walnuts are sold in French produce markets. But the California growers dry their nuts before sending them to market, as the spoilage risk for moist fresh walnuts is high.) I began working on recipes, and once I had written out and begun testing I realized that each dish was a winter greens recipe that included walnuts. The two foods go wonderfully together.

headline: Yanks Offer Welcome to Ellsbury and Some Rebuttals to Cano
text: On Thursday at Safeco Field in Seattle, the Mariners introduced Robinson Cano, a former Yankee who claimed his old team had disrespected him during contract negotiations by not offering enough money. On Friday, the Yankees introduced Jacoby Ellsbury at a news conference at their stadium, and he had quite a different impression of the team that gave him $153 million over seven years to leave Boston.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Adventures in Eating
text: This week, Dana Goodyear discusses “Anything That Moves”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Daniel Menaker talks about “My Mistake: A Memoir”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Adventures in Eating
text: This week, Dana Goodyear and Daniel Menaker.

headline: El Museo del Barrio Names New Executive Director
text: Jorge Daniel Veneciano, who as the director of the Sheldon Museum of Art at the University of Nebraska, Lincoln, increased its operating budget by 50 percent and established an African-American Masters collection, will become the executive director of El Museo del Barrio on March 1, museum officials said on Friday.

headline: Regulator Leaves Loophole for Some Bankers to Avoid E.U. Bonus Caps
text: LONDON – Some European bankers making more than €500,000 a year may be able to avoid caps on their bonus compensation if their jobs do not cause potential financial risk to the bank, according to new draft rules introduced on Friday by a European regulator.

headline: A Modest Volcker Rule
text: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: A Disappearing Spy, and a Scandal at the C.I.A.
text: Robert A. Levinson was an overweight bear of a man who once worked as an F.B.I. agent and desperately wanted to recapture the life of international intrigue he relished as an expert on Russian organized crime. But as he sat in a hotel room in Geneva in early 2007, he was anxious about a secret mission he had planned to Iran.

headline: Chief at British Insurer Quits after 3rd Profit Warning
text: LONDON — The chief executive of the British insurer RSA Group stepped down on Friday after the company said for the second time in just over a month that it would have to significantly increase the reserves for its Irish business and for the third time in six weeks warned that its profit would be lower.

headline: Men Surpass Women in Publishing of Research
text: Despite years of progress for women in science, men continue to dominate scientific publishing in nearly every country, according to new research in the journal Nature.

headline: Giving Feedback That Works
text: So here’s the conundrum: Each of us requires critical feedback to get better at anything, but most criticism feels like condemnation, judgment, disapproval and disparagement. In short, it’s painful and destabilizing. So what is a leader or a manager to do?

headline: The Gun Report: December 13, 2013
text: Since the Newtown massacre on Dec. 14, 2012, there has been a school shooting once every two weeks in America. Here is today’s report.

headline: William Morris Likely Top Bidder for Sports Agency
text: Updated, 8:36 p.m. | As the auction for the global sports powerhouse IMG draws to a close, the Los Angeles-based talent agency William Morris Endeavor appears poised to submit the highest bid.

headline: Bipartisan Budget Deal Forged in House Faces Opposition in Senate
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan budget deal that sailed through the House on an overwhelming, bipartisan vote is running into difficulty in the Senate, where Republicans — some furious, some conservative and some running for office — are vowing to vote against the measure, which would roll back broad spending cuts.

headline: Trayvon Martin’s Parents Are Planning a Book
text: The parents of Trayvon Martin met with publishers this week to shop a book about their son, the unarmed black teenager who was shot and killed in Florida in 2012.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Adventures in Eating
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Thomas McNamee reviews Dana Goodyear’s “Anything That Moves: Renegade Chefs, Fearless Eaters, and the Making of a New American Food Culture.” Mr. McNamee writes:
