text: Holiday Shakedown

headline: Isabella Blow
text: An Exhibit at Somerset House in London is presented as a celebration of fashion as art.

headline: Allen Rosenberg, Olympic Rowing Coach Who Transformed the Sport, Dies at 82
text: Allen Rosenberg, a coxswain-turned-coach whose innovations in rowing technique helped produce Olympic and world champions, died on Dec. 7 at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 82.

headline: Charter Readies Offer to Acquire Time Warner Cable
text: Charter Communications is preparing to make an offer of less than $135 a share for Time Warner Cable, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Talking Talent | Alex Borstein, Star of HBO’s ‘Getting On’
text: Alex Borstein, an Emmy-nominated actress and writer — and the voice of Lois Griffin on the animated Fox series “Family Guy” — currently stars as Nurse Dawn Forchette on HBO’s black comedy “Getting On,” based on the BBC show about a women’s extended care facility in a Long Beach hospital. Alongside her co-stars Laurie Metcalf and Niecy Nash, Borstein brilliantly exercises her comedic chops and exquisite timing to create the most memorable nurse since Ratched. Having honed her gift for impressions, namely as Ms. Swan on “MADtv,” Borstein, a mother of two, will soon not just be recognized for her brilliant voice, but also for her tremendous talent.

headline: Violence in Central African Republic Killed Over 600 in a Week, U.N. Says
text: GENEVA — More than 600 people have been killed in the last week in the sectarian violence and lawlessness convulsing Central African Republic, and the crisis is getting worse, the United Nations refugee agency said on Friday.

headline: Shuffling Staff, Obama Strives for a Recharge After a Tough Fifth Year
text: WASHINGTON — As he finishes a fifth year in power that proved far more vexing than his fourth, President Obama is shuffling his staff to recapture lost momentum and confront the daunting challenges of the midterm election season.

headline: Where the Aromas are Welcoming
text: Aladin Indian Bistro, which opened in July, is hidden in plain sight on a busy hill on the east side of Norwalk, near an Orvis outlet store and one of Stew Leonard’s vast complexes. One lunchtime I zoomed past twice before I found it. It is easier to spot at night, with its big neon sign in front.

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald to Settle 9/11 Lawsuit Against American Airlines
text: The Wall Street firm Cantor Fitzgerald has agreed to settle a 2004 lawsuit against American Airlines and its insurers over Cantor’s business and property losses resulting from the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

headline: What I Love | Jim Brett
text: A look inside the Dumbo home of the president of West Elm.

headline: Jim Brett’s Three-Dimensional Diary
text: Jim Brett has figured out the elusive work/life balance. The president of West Elm — the international chain of 58 hip home-furnishings stores — he has seamlessly integrated the personal and professional by living across the street from the company’s headquarters in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn.

headline: At Syracuse, Mirror Images a Decade Apart
text: SYRACUSE — In the final few minutes of a practice this week, Trevor Cooney received a pass on the wing, dribbled once to create a sliver of space and let fly an effortless jump shot from beyond the 3-point arc. He was fading left, his body leaning toward the sideline, as the ball leapt from his fingertips, a perfect gooseneck follow-through guiding it toward the hoop.

headline: Songs That Transcend the Tricks
text: 1. Cécile McLorin Salvant “WomanChild” (Mack Avenue) A young jazz singer of radical talent, who teaches you in her own terms — with high clarity and zero pedantry — that singing old songs has nothing to do with transmitting an outdated sensibility, and that jazz is necessarily part of a bigger and greater story of American music, and that American music is necessarily part of a bigger and greater story of modern art.

headline: South Africa Looks Into Claims of Interpreter’s Criminal Past
text: QUNU, South Africa — The South African government said on Friday that it was looking into news media reports that the man hired to provide deaf interpretation at Nelson Mandela’s memorial service had once been accused of murder and other serious crimes. The reports added intrigue to the scandal surrounding the supposed interpreter, who used incomprehensible sign language and later said he was a violence-prone schizophrenic who hallucinated.

headline: Body and Mind, Rebounding
text: Hardship probably isn’t the first word that springs to mind when you think of the actress Gwyneth Paltrow and the trainer Tracy Anderson, who helped Ms. Paltrow firm up her jiggly bits with such success that they became business partners. Now the twosome is moving beyond the starry realm with “The Restart Project,” available for streaming starting Monday on AOL On, that celebrates mere mortals who have overcome adversity, whether career-ending injuries or debilitating obesity, through fitness and diet.

headline: A Straussian Tale of Thwarted Lust
text: Critics like to rib Leon Botstein for excessively square conducting that can drain some of the flair from the music. But his style has improved over the years, and he remains one of the most creative minds in American music, known for restless — some might say relentless — advocacy of the unexplored and underappreciated. He has long been a champion of Richard Strauss’s lesser-known operas, and on Sunday he leads his American Symphony Orchestra in “Feuersnot,” whose difficult-to-translate title the ensemble has rendered as “In Need of Fire.”

headline: Mistletoe, Vindicated
text: Museum of ruined dinners; the tipsy witness; how to ask smart questions.

headline: A Bausch Rarity Set to Stravinsky
text: In 1975, not much more than a year after Pina Bausch had become the director of the Tanztheater Wuppertal and well before she had become an international name, she choreographed a three-part Stravinsky evening for her company. The final section was “The Rite of Spring,” now one of the most famous dance versions of the piece, but the first two works were not to be seen again until a recent revival in Wuppertal brought together students from the local Folkwangschule and Juilliard to collaborate on a revival of “Wind von West” (“Wind from the West”), set to Stravinsky’s 1952 “Cantata.”

headline: Abrasive Tactics Lead to Notable Tunes
text: 1. Drake “Nothing Was the Same” (Young Money/Cash Money/Republic) Drake is all the emoji: the prayer hands, the dancing girls, the diamond ring, the blown kiss, the laughing through tears. This is his rowdiest album so far, but all that means is he’s matured enough to know how to punch hard while still hopelessly lost in his feelings.

headline: Unlikely Trio on the Lam
text: Jim Jarmusch’s “Down by Law” would have been attention-getting for its casting alone. The three misfits at the center of the story, who find themselves in a New Orleans jail, are played by John Lurie, Tom Waits and Roberto Benigni. But what makes this odd comedy really distinctive is the black-and-white cinematography by Robby Muller. “We are seeing a true filmmaker at work,” wrote Vincent Canby, reviewing the movie in The New York Times in 1986, “using film to create a narrative that couldn’t exist on the stage or the printed page of a novel.”

headline: Modern-Jazz Spin on the Sad Jester
text: Much of what you need to know about Geri Allen can be found in the second track of her most recent album, “Grand River Crossings” (Motéma), which bears the subtitle “Motown & Motor City Inspirations.” The track is a solo piano version of Smokey Robinson’s “Tears of a Clown,” refurbished with modern-jazz harmony but otherwise faithful to the structure of the tune. Ms. Allen’s fondness for the material shines through her erudition; she isn’t dabbling, showing off, or using the song merely as a springboard. Her elaborations feel grounded in earthly realities and respect.

headline: The Old West, Exalted in Bronze
text: The lyrics of the chestnut “The Wheel of the Wagon Is Broken” mourn an Old West irretrievably passed: “My days on the prairie are over. There’s weeds round the old ranch door.” The sculptor Frederic Remington, who probably more than any other artist enshrined the myth of the frontier in art, put it even more mournfully: “My West passed utterly out of existence so long ago as if to make it merely a dream. It put on its hat, took up its blankets and marched off the board.”

headline: A Mix of Sounds, Generations and Styles
text: 1. Craig Taborn Trio “Chants” (ECM) The deep, seductive intelligence at work in “Chants,” Craig Taborn’s first piano trio album in a dozen years, suggests an ocean of influences distilled into an original potion. Unpacking his terse compositions in communion with the bassist Thomas Morgan and the drummer Gerald Cleaver, Mr. Taborn gives each oblique maneuver a purpose, and often a flicker of intrepid grace.

headline: In Obama’s Praise of Mandela, a Nudge to Africa
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama delivered his eulogy of Nelson Mandela in Soweto, South Africa, on Tuesday, he intended it as both a celebration of Mr. Mandela and a chastisement, not just of himself for failing to live up to the Mandela legacy, but of the African leaders who listened to him in the pelting rain.

headline: Is ‘Entitlements’ the Best Word for Social Security and Medicare?
text: A New York City reader, Judith Abrams, wrote with a complaint about the use of the term “entitlements” in federal budget articles. In so doing, she raised other questions that are worth consideration.

headline: And a Teenager Shall Lead Them
text: 1. Lorde “Pure Heroine” (Universal) In hip-hop, keyboard-centered processionals often accompany self-congratulatory boasts. “Pure Heroine,” the debut album by Lorde — the songwriter and singer Ella Yelich-O’Connor, from New Zealand — commandeers those wide-open spaces with her lustrous voice and angel-choir harmonies carrying serious thoughts. Lorde writes about suburban provincialism, peer pressure, insecurity, determination and — in the irresistible “Royals” — about pop-culture fantasies and class-conscious realities. She’s 17.

headline: The Best Albums and Songs of 2013
text: Ben Ratliff, Jon Caramanica and Jon Pareles discuss their picks for the year’s best in pop and jazz.

headline: Movie Review: 'The Hobbit'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug."

headline: Italian Standards New to a Familiar Spot
text: Sapori (Italian for “flavors”) is the newest and the fanciest restaurant to arrive on the outskirts of White Plains near the County Center. At once cozy and elegant (save for some dated upholstery), the restaurant has an intriguing layout. Many rooms, alcoves and private nooks suddenly open and then close out of sight as you take the snaking path past a trim bar toward the back of the restaurant.

headline: So Much Operatic Life, and a Fatality
text: The year in classical music was rich with memorable orchestra concerts, chamber-music programs and recitals. Yet what stood out most for me were opera performances, not all of them in opera houses.

headline: Early Handel Operas Are Current Again
text: New York a hotbed of early music? No one would have said so 20 years ago (when some of us were saying the opposite) or even 10 years ago. But a remarkable shift has occurred over the last decade or so, thanks to a web of interlocking factors, including the formation of a curriculum in historical performance at the Juilliard School, the exponential growth of the music program at Trinity Wall Street, the enterprise of groups like Tenet and the Sebastians and the work of the service organization Gotham Early Music Scene.

headline: Golden Moments in Their 30s
text: You could call 2013 the Year of the 30-Something, as two of classical music’s most prestigious bastions opened their doors to children of the 1980s. The polymathic Nico Muhly, born in 1981, became the youngest composer to have a commissioned work performed at the Metropolitan Opera when his “Two Boys” had its American premiere in October. In April, Caroline Shaw (1982) was the youngest recipient of the Pulitzer Prize in Music for her rapturous “Partita for Eight Voices.”

headline: Giving Sound Itself a Starring Role
text: In 2013, I stopped taking the sound of music for granted. To be sure, I’ve always experienced music in a visceral way. Reviewing the Budapest Festival Orchestra’s performance in January, I marveled at how, under its conductor, Ivan Fischer, it created “volleys of sound so vividly three-dimensional that you sometimes had to resist the impulse to duck.”

headline: Delicate Touches Strongly Felt
text: Virtuosos often impress with their ability to produce unlikely sounds from their instruments. It’s such a pleasure when a pianist coaxes beautiful, singing lines from a percussive object and a singer produces trills and effects that seem impossible to have come from a human voice.

headline: Movie Review: 'Saving Mr. Banks'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Saving Mr. Banks.”

headline: Big Ticket | Gardens in the Backyard for $32 Million
text: Ripe for restoration, the mansion at 41 East 70th Street, a 28-foot-wide neighbor of the Frick museum that was built in 1929 for Walter N. Rothschild, a department store magnate, and his wife, Carola Warburg Rothschild, sold for $32 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The asking price for the mansion, whose backyard is part of the private gardens known as the Lehman Gardens, was $40 million.

headline: Robert Redford Had His Doubts About ‘All Is Lost’
text: When J.C. Chandor was putting the finishing touches on “All Is Lost,” he worried that having a nearly two-hour, nearly silent meditation about survival on the open sea might not quite connect with audiences.

headline: Duets, Trilogies and Revisiting Motown
text: The last 12 months have brought a fine harvest of new choreography. My Top 10 consists solely of works new either to me or altogether.

headline: In the Footsteps of Lara Croft
text: The men behind some of the most popular and celebrated video games in the medium’s not-as-short-as-you-think history concede that they haven’t spent an enormous amount of time pondering the portrayal of women in their work. “Seemingly not as much as I should have” was the sheepish acknowledgment Sam Houser, a founder of Rockstar Games, gave me during a long interview in Manhattan in September about Grand Theft Auto V, his newest game.

headline: Movie Review: 'American Hustle'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "American Hustle."

headline: Acura, Harley-Davidson and Suzuki to Issue Recalls
text: Acura will recall about 19,000 of its 2014 MDX utility vehicles in the United States because of a powertrain problem, the automaker said in a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website. The automaker said it was possible that one or two of the four bolts securing the propeller shaft could be loose. If the propeller shaft detached the all-wheel-drive system could be damaged and the vehicle would lose power.

headline: A Time for Farewells and Comebacks
text: This year in dance dawned with an ending. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music in January, the Trisha Brown Dance Company presented what were announced to be her final works. They weren’t her best, but the whole program, sampling from 45 years of choreographing, was of the quality that sets the high end of my critical scale.

headline: When Ballerinas Get Brassy
text: Dancers aren’t just the tools of choreographers and directors, but their lifeblood. It comes down to trust: Once a dancer steps onstage, the symbiotic studio relationship is transformed. Alone, the dancer balances that evanescent power of responsibility and freedom.

headline: Restraining the N.S.A.
text: After the Edward Snowden leaks started, President Obama said absolutely everything was being done to safeguard Americans’ privacy and rights. Then he called for a “vigorous public debate” about surveillance and eventually ordered reviews of National Security Agency programs — to make sure that all those promised safeguards were, in fact, in place.

headline: Review: 2014 Chevy Malibu
text: When the 2013 Malibu failed to excite critics (and more importantly, buyers), Chevy quickly refreshed it. The 2014 model gets more style, room, power and cornering fun.

headline: For Top Earners, a Bigger Tax Bite This Year
text: LESS than a year ago, people were worried about a variety of tax increases in 2013, from income and investment taxes going up to the exemption on estate and gift taxes going down. This year, without any last-minute negotiation around major tax policy, people are far less focused on taxes, and that has accountants and tax lawyers worried.

headline: Underdog Against Amazon, Best Buy Charges Ahead
text: It was a lonely holiday season last year for David Strasser, an analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott. Of the 25 analysts covering the electronics retailer Best Buy, he was the only one to make a buy recommendation. And the stock kept going down.

headline: Rare Victory in Hong Kong for Victims of Insider Trading
text: Nearly 300 Hong Kong investors are about to share an early $3 million Christmas present. That’s the amount that the former Morgan Stanley banker Du Jun has been told to pay the unwitting victims of his insider trading in 2007. White-collar criminals should beware, but investors shouldn’t expect a rush of future payments.

headline: Video: Chevrolet Breathes New Life Into the 2014 Malibu With a Turbo
text: When Chevrolet introduced the 2013 Malibu in the spring of 2012, the only model available for the first six months was the Eco. Critics were not impressed. Its eAssist mild hybrid power plant added cost and wasn’t overly fuel-efficient. The trunk-mounted battery cut into cargo capacity and flexibility. The back seat was tight on knee and legroom. Despite a quiet and stylish cabin, Malibu failed to make the all-important good first impression.

headline: Popcast: The Best Albums and Songs of 2013
text: This week: The New York Times pop and jazz critics discuss their top 10 albums of 2013.

headline: I Want It Steamy, and I Want It Now
text: This was the year that prose turned purple, binge viewing trumped appointment television, and “Scandal” took the place of “Breaking Bad” as the hot drama everyone wanted to talk about. Television is still in a golden age, but the best of 2013 looked a little brassy, more Aaron Spelling than Aaron Sorkin.

headline: A Golden Age With an Imported Shine
text: Here are my 12 favorite television shows of 2013 — the ones you won’t find piling up on my DVR, because I have to watch each new episode as soon as it appears. (Which means, of course, by the end of the next day.) Are they the 12 best shows of the year? Who knows. I didn’t come close to watching everything on TV, and neither did anyone else. All I know is that 10 wouldn’t have been enough.

headline: Grandfather Makes the Pastas
text: Trento in Farmingdale is a big, bold and beautiful new restaurant that is a far cry from the last enterprise on this site: the Crazy Donkey, a rock club. Emilio Branchinelli extensively renovated the property before opening it in June.

headline: Staring at the End, in Several Senses
text: It was a year dominated by the naked and the dead.

headline: Art Matters | Taking Back the Steel Drum From the Hippies
text: “The steel drum is the most misunderstood instrument in the world,” says the Trinidadian curator Everard Findlay. He admits that for many people, it evokes “guys on a cruise ship, with a smile and dreadlocks.” On Tuesday and Wednesday, Findlay hosted “7 Drums 7 Artists,” a cross-disciplinary tribute to the steel pan at NeueHouse, a co-working space in the Flatiron district that opened in April. Designed by Rockwell Group, NeueHouse, which bills itself as “a new way to work,” features art magazines hanging from wall-mounted racks and glass-globe chandeliers that lower from pulleys at night when the space becomes a venue. The co-founder, Joshua Abram, says that “learning happens at the edge of one’s network”; as part of that philosophy, NeueHouse offers evening cultural programming for its members that brings together artists, scientists, filmmakers and musicians.

headline: Video: David O. Russell on ‘American Hustle’
text: It’s been a good week for “American Hustle.” The film, which opened to very strong reviews today, picked up a nomination from the Screen Actors Guild for best ensemble (the guild’s equivalent to best picture) on Wednesday and the next day picked up seven Golden Globe nominations.

headline: Pairing Christmas Dinners With White Wines
text: Winemakers I know across Europe prepare different kinds of culturally rooted, traditional Christmas dinners. Some of the most festive are in Germany.

headline: Obama Nominates Hollywood Exec to Arts Council
text: LOS ANGELES – The National Council on the Arts, which helps manage the National Endowment for the Arts, will have a new high-profile member from Hollywood’s ranks if a nomination from President Obama goes through as expected. The White House announced on Thursday that Thomas E. Rothman, chairman of TriStar Productions, a division of Sony Pictures Entertainment, has been nominated to the 18-member council, which advises on the endowment’s policies and programs and makes recommendations on grant applications. He must be approved by the Senate before joining the Council.

headline: Garden Offers a Week’s Worth of Treats
text: Howie Garfinkel has been to thousands of college basketball games, but he has not seen a week filled with the kind of marquee matchups that begin Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: A Finish Worthy of Hollywood
text: It could have been a meet-cute scene in a movie.

headline: Billionaire Drops Plan for Casino in Spain
text: MADRID — Sheldon G. Adelson, the billionaire casino magnate, on Friday abandoned his plans to build a $30 billion gambling and leisure resort on the outskirts of Madrid after failing to win financial concessions and other favors from the Spanish government.

headline: So Your Duck Won’t Go South
text: Preparing a whole duck for dinner is something I don’t usually do. For the home cook, braising or roasting just the legs is definitely easier, and grilling large duck breasts is more or less like cooking a steak. For a festive occasion, though, a burnished whole bird makes quite an impression: fancier than chicken and more elegant than turkey.

headline: Mexico’s Oil May Be Opened to Outsiders
text: Ciudad del Carmen, a hub of the Mexican oil industry, has boomed since large reserves were discovered in the 1970s.

headline: Bacon of Moore Capital Buys Taos Ski Valley Resort
text: The ski areas of the American West are a familiar stomping ground for Wall Street titans, and a house in Aspen or Vail can be a prized asset.

headline: Individual Problems, Joint Solutions
text: Couples who are about to marry often share tales about how the things they have in common — whether cultural, religious or personality-wise — have brought them together and sustained their relationships. But there’s a special subset: those whose bonds were forged in part by mutual problems, some quite serious, that they’ve agreed to face together.

headline: ‘Twas the Night Before Christmas’ and Its Ties to Chelsea
text: Q. I know that Clement Clarke Moore is famous for the poem “ ’Twas the Night Before Christmas,” but is it true he was the major developer of Chelsea?

headline: Your Suggestions For 2014
text: Readers, thanks for your many insightful answers to the two questions I asked of you this week. To address your answers to my second question first, it’s great to hear many of you think I do a decent job engaging with you already, and I appreciate your suggestions for ways to try new forms of outreach and social media. That’s something I will try to do in 2014, so stay tuned!

headline: A Night Swim for Atlantic Herring
text: On a windless December evening, sunset faded to shimmering violet over Jamaica Bay. Icy Atlantic waters pushed past Canarsie Pier, filling the bay for the second time that day. Now, two hours from high tide and almost dark, overhead lamps cast shadows deep into Brooklyn’s watery depths. It takes a great leap of faith to believe anything survives in the frigid dark below, but thousands of Atlantic herring (Clupea harengus) are hidden there.

headline: Luxury Apartments for a Little Less
text: For some developers, moderation seems to be the latest byword, and that is helping Manhattan become ever so slightly more affordable.

headline: New York Philharmonic Musicians and Management Reach Labor Agreement
text: After negotiating for three months beyond the expiration of their last contract, the musicians and management of the New York Philharmonic reached a labor agreement on Thursday that guarantees the players what the orchestra described as “modest wage increases” in each of the contract’s four years.

headline: The Taxi of Tomorrow Is Here Today
text: That the New York State Supreme Court halted the Bloomberg administration’s plan to have a uniform fleet of Nissan NV200 taxis in New York City has undoubtedly been an unpleasant reality for Nissan. Particularly because production of the NV200 had already begun over the summer at the company’s assembly plant in Cuernavaca, Mexico.

headline: So Many Cookies, So Little Time
text: The Cookie Jar, owned by James and Maria Carrozza in the West Brighton neighborhood of Staten Island, offers more than 100 varieties of cookies to satisfy any sweet tooth.

headline: Sweetest Mayhem Inside the Cookie Jar
text: Every Saturday afternoon, Tangela Adenekan receives an important phone call.

headline: Listen Up, It’s Neutrino Time
text: HAVE you noticed how the Higgs boson has been hogging the limelight lately? For a measly little invisible item, whose significance cannot be explained without appealing to thorny concepts of quantum field theory, it has done pretty well for itself. The struggling starlets of Hollywood could learn a thing or two about the dark art of self-promotion from this boson.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: An East Village two-bedroom with a fireplace; a Prospect Heights four-bedroom in an Art Deco building; and Forest Hills Gardens six-bedroom colonial.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Israel, Gaza and South Africa.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Musicians to Play a 10-Concert Season
text: It is an idea that has been around for some time: The musicians of the Minnesota Orchestra, who have been locked out by management since Oct. 1, 2012, announced on Thursday that they will present a series of 10 concerts on their own, without management involvement. And in a sign of where the music world’s sympathies are, they have lined up a few big-name guests, most notably the violinists Itzhak Perlman and Joshua Bell.

headline: Cleaning the Place, and Clearing the Mind
text: On screen, Taryn Manning has played a string of troubled characters, from a prostitute in “Hustle and Flow” to Pennsatucky, a meth-user-turned-bible-thumper in the Netflix prison series “Orange Is the New Black.” In her real life as a recent arrival to Greenwich Village — she also has a house in Los Angeles — Ms. Manning, 35, juggles more salubrious identities: actress, musician, D.J. and owner of a dog named Penguin, a mix of Cavalier King Charles spaniel and Maltese. Sundays tend to be a combination of those interests, along with shopping and hanging out.

headline: Weekend Reading: The Twelve Days of Wall Street
text: Before you head off for your holiday office party, please groan along with this ode to holiday puns.

headline: A Washington Hotel’s History Tour
text: Hotels have employed sleep concierges, romance specialists and even “vibe managers” in charge of music. Now the Jefferson in Washington, D.C., has added a weightier position: in-house historian.

headline: Assailant Dead After Shooting at Colorado School
text: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — The student did not try to hide the shotgun he carried into Arapahoe High School at 12:30 p.m. Friday. He sought to confront a teacher, law enforcement officials said, and asked his classmates where he could find him.

headline: Opulent Meets Efficient: A New Wave of Luxury Hybrids
text: FOR nearly a decade, makers of luxury cars have insisted that their buyers would become conspicuous consumers of hybrid models — not merely for a mileage boost, but for the social boost of adopting green technology.

headline: Infiniti Learns a Bit of German
text: Since he was hired in mid-2012, Johan de Nysschen, the president of Infiniti, has been leading a comprehensive remaking of Nissan’s luxury brand.

headline: Hybrid Infiniti’s Allure: Fuel Savings and Power
text: For luxury carmakers, no technological parade is complete without a hybrid.

headline: Gadget Master
text: Infiniti’s tech-laden Q50 sport sedan serves up a taste of where the self-driving car seems to be heading.

headline: An Alternative to Giving Up the Car Keys
text: Robert Cullon, 80, has a neurological condition that makes his feet numb and forces him to rely on a walker. He thought he was driving just fine, but his six children were worried.

headline: Week in Pictures for Dec. 13
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include record snowfall, a chicken in Central Park and a change of address for the de Blasios.

headline: Looking for Charities That Make Children Want to Give
text: In the light of the season, and Ron Lieber’s recent blog posts about encouraging children to learn to give as well as get over the holidays, particularly to those who need help, we’re declaring a Motherlode “Week+ of Giving” Dec. 25-Jan. 1.

headline: ‘Affluenza’ Sets Off a Linguistic Contest
text: One of the more lighthearted reactions to a well-off Texas teenager’s being granted probation after killing four people while driving drunk has been a quest online to create terms equivalent to “affluenza” to explain the actions of poorer, nonwhite defendants.

headline: A Federal Proposal for Paid Family Leave
text: The last time we discussed the toll that caring for older relatives takes on working people, particularly women, readers shared some wrenching experiences:

headline: Charted: The Year of Kanye West
text: The provocateur Kanye West not only released an acclaimed album and went on tour this year, he seemed to show up in a headline nearly every day. Here the artist Andrew Kuo charts the rapper’s ups and downs, from his onstage rants to his engagement to Kim Kardashian at AT&T Park.

headline: Really? That’s Your Emergency?
text: On Saturday, the folks at TLC, although they are not known for their public-service programming, offer a solution to the vexing problem of drunken driving, which becomes particularly severe around the holidays. The way to get impaired drivers off the road is for the drivers to call 911 and report themselves.

headline: Robert Levinson’s Contract
text: The contract called for Mr. Levinson to write reports for an analysts’ group specializing in money-laundering and foreign corruption.

headline: Making a Building’s Water System Into a Hydroelectric Plant
text: HONG KONG — Daryl Ng was taking a long shower, as he does every morning. And his wife, as she does every morning, scolded him for needlessly using so much water.

headline: Twitter Reverses Privacy Change in Response to User Complaints
text: Twitter on Thursday adopted — and then quickly reversed — a change to the way people can block others from interacting with them on the service. The brief change set off an uproar among users who said it opened the door for abusive behavior.

headline: Week in Pictures for Dec. 13
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include record snowfall, a chicken in Central Park and a change of address for the de Blasios.

headline: Feeling a Bit Obsolete in the Driver’s Seat
text: Infiniti’s G37 has long been the star of Nissan’s luxury brand, largely because it’s been a hands-on car. Now, girding for an autonomous future, Infiniti is trying hands-off instead.

headline: Selections From Levinson’s Emails with Silverman
text: The path that took Robert A. Levinson to Iran began with his friend, Ira Silverman, a retired NBC investigative producer.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A three-bedroom contemporary on the Fire Island Inlet and a four-bedroom colonial with high-end finishes in Old Greenwich.

headline: A Style Diary of Miami Art Week
text: What does art fair style look like? Find out in the Miami Art Week photo diaries of Kristy Leibowitz and Rebecca Smeyne.

headline: Match Game: Finding the Perfect Plates for a Vintage Car
text: AVON, IND. — For some car collectors, completing a vehicle restoration with tires, wheels and paint that look period-correct is just not enough. Even such details as the license plates must be the correct vintage.

headline: Wichita Airport Technician Charged With Terrorist Plot
text: An avionics technician was charged Friday morning with plotting to detonate a car bomb at Mid-Continent Airport, in Wichita, Kan., federal authorities said.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Typical Men With Lives That Aren’t
text: ABC has a gimmick show called “What Would You Do?,” in which fake situations are staged in front of unsuspecting people to see how they react. This weekend, on CNN, three documentaries about extraordinary individuals ask, in effect, a variation on that question: Could you do this? Nothing staged here; the programs present compelling real-life stories about men who, each in his own way, have set examples others might find daunting to follow.

headline: Scenes From the Protests in Thailand
text: Antigovernment protests have been going on in Thailand since the beginning of November.

headline: Essential Accessory
text: Completing a vehicle restoration with wheels and paint that look period-correct is not enough for some collectors — not without the right license plate.

headline: The Agony of Instagram
text: Erin Wurzel, 26, thought she had plenty to feel thankful about this Thanksgiving weekend: she is engaged to a great guy (and was spending the holiday with his family), working on a her first novel and taking French with an eye to moving to Paris someday.

headline: Finding Poetry in Multiplicity
text: Tere O’Connor’s “Bleed” is an hourlong dance. It is not a story. It is not music made visible. It does not follow an established or predictable form. It is not random. It is not dull.

headline: Noble Molecules Found in Space
text: Atoms of noble gases like helium, neon and argon — odorless, colorless, single-atom gases with low chemical reactivity — have long been known to exist in outer space. But molecules involving them have escaped detection, despite years of searching.

headline: A Rockwell Holiday, at Last
text: Introductions at past holiday gatherings have been comically convoluted for Judy Bowman. “I used to explain, ‘This is Amy’s sister Vicky’s husband, Joel,’ ” said Ms. Bowman, a casting director in New York. “Now I can just say ‘my brother-in-law.’ ”

headline: Suggested Reading for de Blasio
text: If Harold Bloom, the Yale humanities professor, were to compile a New York version of his “Western canon,” he would face a shelf of books meeting his high standard: that they be authoritative, sublime, representative and distinguished by originality that “cannot be assimilated or that so assimilates us that we ceased to see it as strange.”

headline: Taking Fashion to a New Dimension
text: Will the 3-D printer replace the sewing machine as the favored tool of fashion designers?

headline: Four Times a Charm?
text: LOS ANGELES — Last Monday, two well-coiffed ladies of a certain age (50s, with work) sat down for a predinner drink at the Sunset Tower Hotel. I was at the next table, doing what any good reporter does when his companion is late: eavesdropping.

headline: Screening George Cukor
text: Images from select movies playing in the series “The Discreet Charm of George Cukor,” at the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: Pakistan’s Chief Justice Leaves a Mixed Legacy
text: LONDON — To some Pakistanis, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry will always be the “dictator slayer” — the judge who defied the military ruler Gen. Pervez Musharraf, helped evict him from office and went on to repurpose a once supine judiciary as a fiercely independent force.

headline: A Kaleidoscope of Nostalgia for an Unlived Past
text: What happens when entertainment becomes mixed up with experimentation? The choreographer and dancer Cori Olinghouse is haunted by the connection between vaudeville and the Dada and Surrealism movements — so much so that she created a couple of ghosts.

headline: The Romance of Falling Temperatures
text: If the warmth of summer and the natural fertility of spring are classic metaphors for romance, what about winter? The snow and the cold, despite their off-putting aspects, can indeed cause sparks, inspiring closeness and a necessary swapping of body heat. The following poems about the passionate effects of chilly weather were found in recent days in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

headline: Energy Secretary Calls Oil Export Ban Dated
text: Houston — Signaling a possible break with 40 years of energy policy, Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz has suggested that it may be time for the Obama administration to reconsider the nation’s ban on exporting domestically produced crude oil.

headline: The Hero and His Adversaries, Played Out With Fanfare
text: A music critic has something of a professional interest in resenting Richard Strauss’s “Ein Heldenleben” (“A Hero’s Life”). After all, this sprawling, semi-autobiographical tone poem takes aim squarely at the writers who doubted the young Strauss, who was in his mid-30s when he completed it in 1898. The work’s second section, known as “The Hero’s Adversaries,” paints his critics in strident, self-important lines in the woodwinds and tuba before vanquishing them with brass fanfares.

headline: Your Holiday Food Memories
text: A ’70s family is driving south on 95 from Brooklyn to Washington to have Christmas dinner at Grandmother’s house, five people crammed into a Dodge Dart, three of them boys under 10, noses running, seatbelt-less, itchy in dress clothes. I’m the oldest, dreaming of a model airplane, a new baseball glove, something not made by hippies, something normal. There’s probably a cat in a box, mewling, somewhere in the car.

headline: Special Matriarchal Lessons
text: What makes it a Madea Christmas? In the latest visit from Tyler Perry’s multimillion-dollar-grossing action-hero auntie, this modern-day Malaprop helps save a school, an interracial relationship, a bullied boy and a divided family, all while making fast friends with the white-trash royalty Larry the Cable Guy. She’d save a man from a burning wreck, but somebody else takes care of that.

headline: Invention and Whimsy, Inspired by a Toy
text: The spirits of John Cage and Charles M. Schulz’s Schroeder converged on the Lower East Side on Thursday night, when the UnCaged Toy Piano Festival got underway at Pianos, a cozy, noisy nightclub on Ludlow Street. Founded in 2007 by Phyllis Chen — a skillful pianist and composer, a budding impresario and a leading proponent of the toy piano as a vehicle for serious music — the festival opened with a performance by Margaret Leng Tan.

headline: A Ukrainian Uprising Fueled by Outrage (and Salted Pork Fat)
text: KIEV, Ukraine — As much as by outrage, the pro-European uprising here is being fueled by heaping bowls of buckwheat and pork fat, steaming helpings of borscht and other meaty and fatty fare.

headline: A Glory of Choral Music, Resplendent and Abundant
text: Two of the most venerable and reliable of the annual presentations of Handel’s “Messiah” in New York went head-to-head this week. John Scott conducted the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue on Tuesday evening and again on Thursday, the same night that Kent Tritle conducted Musica Sacra in the first of its two performances at Carnegie Hall.

headline: American Who Killed for Iran’s Revolution in 1980 Resurfaces in C.I.A. Spy Drama

In true L.A. fashion, the latest outpost of the cult Japanese brand is in an open-air shopping mall, on Hollywood Boulevard. Fans won’t be disappointed. With approximately 8,600 square feet of retail space, Muji Hollywood will be the brand’s largest North American location.

headline: Bill Cunningham | A Little Seasoning
text: The big fashion story is the emergence of a silhouette, total black and etched by snow. “Cutting silhouettes” was a favorite fashion expression from the 1820s to 1920. Last week, Fifth Avenue was reminiscent of this technique. The silhouette is brought to life by a long stretch of leg, multiple textured fabrics, fur and, of course, a black umbrella dusted with snow.

headline: British Wine Benefits as the Climate Changes
text: DORKING, England — For more than a decade, Matthieu Elzinga ran his own vineyard in the western Loire Valley of France. But this year, just as he was gaining an international reputation for his dry and crisp Muscadets, Mr. Elzinga sold the vineyard and moved to an emerging wine region: the south of England.

headline: Winemaking Across the Channel
text: According to scientific projections, Britain can expect wetter winters, drier summers, and less snow and frost, conditions that will encourage the country’s winemaking industry.

headline: Wine Gaining Ground in Britain
text: In recent decades, British wine production has been steadily rising, partly because warmer temperatures are moving northward. An average temperature greater than 50 degrees Fahrenheit (10 degrees Celsius) is considered the minimum for growing grapes. By 2080, according to some forecasts, such temperatures could reach as far north as Scotland.

headline: With Their Own Images, South Africans Remember Mandela
text: Since the 10-day period of mourning began after the death of Nelson Mandela last week, tens of thousands of people across South Africa took to the streets, waving flags and posters. They stood in the driving rain at a soccer stadium and attended a concert in Cape Town. For three days, thousands of people filed past his glass-topped coffin in Pretoria to pay their final respects to the country’s first black president, the man who brought an end to apartheid and unified the country.

headline: Obama to Keep Security Agency and Cyberwarfare Under a Single Commander

headline: In Vermont, a Town That Would Not Let Its Diner Go
text: WILMINGTON, Vt. — In the months after the Deerfield River overtook their diner, Patty and John Reagan began to imagine letting it go after more than 30 years of greeting people for breakfast, saying good night after the dinner shift and hearing their stories during the many hours in between.

headline: Three Photographers Reflect on Typhoon Haiyan
text: More than a month after Typhoon Hayian ended 6,000 lives and displaced four million more, the Philippine people are still struggling to begin their recovery. In the videos below, three New York Times photographers recount their coverage of a nation in the aftermath of disaster.

headline: Ohio: School Officials Plead Not Guilty After Rape
text: The superintendent and three current or former city school officials in Steubenville, Ohio, pleaded not guilty on Friday to charges filed following a grand jury investigation of the August 2012 rape of a 16-year-old girl. The superintendent, Michael McVey, 50, who is free on a personal recognizance bond, has been accused of evidence tampering, obstruction of justice and two other charges. After the hearing, his lawyer said he was confident the charges would prove unfounded, according to The Associated Press. The rape case drew national attention and led to the conviction in March of two Steubenville High School football players. Afterward, the Ohio attorney general, Mike DeWine, convened a special grand jury to examine whether officials covered up the crime, and the panel returned indictments against six people. But only some of those charges stem from the first rape case, while others relate to separate accusations investigated by the grand jury, including some stemming from allegations of the sexual assault of a 14-year-old student four months earlier, as well as other charges of theft and stolen property.

headline: Land Disputes Slow Recovery in Philippines
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — A mile offshore from this typhoon-wrecked city lies a postcard-perfect tropical islet fringed with golden sand beaches and topped with a mansion and swimming pool: the private island of one of this country’s most powerful families, the Romualdez clan of the former first lady, Imelda Marcos.

headline: A Judge’s Duty to Warn About Deportation
text: The combination of harsh immigration laws and stricter enforcement has made deportation the likely consequence when criminal defendants who are not American citizens plead guilty to a felony offense. Recognizing that “uniquely devastating deprivation of liberty,” New York’s highest court last month correctly held that due process requires state judges to warn noncitizen defendants that a guilty plea could lead to deportation.

headline: A Fight Over Cross-State Pollution
text: The Environmental Protection Agency is charged by the Clean Air Act with setting air-quality standards and issuing regulations to limit pollutants like life-threatening particulate matter and ozone. Because bad air often travels far from its source — 93 percent of the air pollution in New Haven, Conn., for example, comes from other states — the act’s “good neighbor” policy requires that every state work to assure that the pollution from its power plants does not “contribute significantly” to the pollution in other states. If a state has no plan or an inadequate one, the E.P.A. can impose its own.

headline: Faithful as a Mother Shark
text: The popular view of sharks as wandering predators, roaming the seas like outcast swordsmen in an old samurai movie, will have to be adjusted, what with this month’s big news about lemon sharks.

headline: Battling Homelessness in New York City
text: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio of New York has promised to address the city’s affordable housing crisis, a product of recession and years of bad choices by city, state and federal officials. The crisis has driven record numbers of families into often grim and inhospitable homeless shelters that can be hard, if not impossible, to escape.

headline: Fighting for the Legacy of Lincoln
text: Between Dec. 7 and 14, 1863, a new regiment was organized at St. Louis’s Benton Barracks: the 1st Missouri Colored Infantry, later renamed the 62nd Regiment, United States Colored Troops. Unheralded in their time and mostly forgotten in ours, soldiers of the 62nd were nevertheless responsible for changing the very essence of the Civil War and were instrumental in creating what may have been the first permanent memorial to Abraham Lincoln anywhere in the country.

headline: Make a Little Lower
