text: For N.H.L. fans, the temptation to compare Nathan MacKinnon and Sidney Crosby is almost irresistible.

headline: To Beat Rangers, Little Experience Is Necessary
text: The Rangers’ nine-game homestand is not going as well as hoped. It is not going well at all. They have lost the first four games, giving up four goals in each game. And after losing, 4-3, in overtime to the veteran Martin Brodeur and the Devils last Saturday, the Rangers have been befuddled by a series of inexperienced backup goalies.

headline: Unicef Urges Aid for Syria’s Shattered School System
text: GENEVA — The United Nations is trying to raise close to a billion dollars to try to pick up the pieces of Syria’s shattered education system and offset the “staggering decline” in what was once one of the region’s leading school systems after nearly three years of conflict.

headline: Infante Said to Join Royals
text: Omar Infante, a 31-year-old free agent, agreed to a four-year deal with the Kansas City Royals, according to a person familiar with the deal, which is pending a physical. The Yankees had offered Infante, who hit .318 with 10 homers for the Detroit Tigers last year, a three-year deal worth about $24 million to replace Robinson Cano at second base.

headline: Iran: Nuclear Talks Interrupted
text: Iranian diplomats involved in nuclear talks with six world powers in Vienna interrupted the discussions on Friday after the United States announced an expanded list of companies and individuals whose trading activities it would try to block for evading sanctions against Iran. The Iranians, suggesting that they needed to consult with officials in Tehran, responded angrily to what the Obama administration characterized as enforcement actions. They said the measures undermined the interim deal reached last month, when Iran was given sanctions relief in exchange for suspending some parts of its nuclear program for six months. “This two-sided game and confusion we are witnessing is not beneficial for the atmosphere of the talks,” Iran’s top negotiator and deputy foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, told the semiofficial Tasnim news agency on Friday. A spokesman for Catherine Ashton, the European Union’s foreign policy chief and the coordinator of the negotiations with Iran, said the discussions were expected to resume in the near future. But in Tehran on Friday, some politicians called for the acceleration of Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Google Adds to Its Menagerie of Robots
text: SAN FRANCISCO — BigDog, Cheetah, WildCat and Atlas have joined Google’s growing robot menagerie.

headline: Impersonating Karzai
text: Zabiullah, a former tea boy in Afghanistan’s presidential palace, has a following in Kabul because of his ability to impersonate the president, Hamid Karzai.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) JACK THE GIANT SLAYER (2013) In Bryan Singer’s retooling of the “Jack and the Beanstalk” tale, a chivalrous farmhand (Nicholas Hoult) fights for a kingdom and the love of an abducted princess (Eleanor Tomlinson), reigniting an ancient war between humans and a race of giants. Bill Nighy plays General Fallon, the leader of the cannibalistic brotherhood in an otherworld called Gantua; Ewan McGregor, above, in Errol Flynn mode, plays a knight who almost becomes finger food; and Stanley Tucci is the shifty fellow to whom the royal lass has been promised. “For its first 90 minutes, ‘Jack the Giant Slayer’ is painlessly diverting,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “The visual design for the giants and the beanstalks keeps your eyes busy, even when the story sets your mind to wandering.” Still, she added, “in the metaphorically rich original tale, a boy wakes to discover he’s produced a mighty stalk. Here, the boy is now a man, and while the stalk is still impressive, the movie just doesn’t have staying power.”

headline: Honey Waldman, 87, Dies; Created Theaters From Old Buildings
text: Honey Waldman, a stage producer who teamed up with her husband to convert a dilapidated movie house in the Hudson Valley and a bank in the East Village into distinguished theaters, died on Dec. 8 in Manhattan. She was 87.

headline: Jack Fishman Dies at 83; Saved Many From Overdose
text: Dr. Jack Fishman, who helped develop naloxone, a powerful medication that has saved countless people from fatal overdoses of heroin and other narcotics, died on Dec. 7 at his home in Remsenburg, N.Y. He was 83.

headline: Mandela’s Body Arrives in Home Province for Funeral Amid Cheers and Songs
text: MTHATHA, South Africa — Thousands of mourners lined the streets here to bid a raucous, heartfelt farewell to Nelson Mandela, whose body arrived in this city in his native Eastern Cape Province on Saturday ahead of a state funeral and burial on Sunday.

headline: After Typhoon Haiyan, a Dispatch From the South China Sea
text: Shortly after we published our article in the Oct. 27 issue about the Filipino marines stationed on a forsaken boat in the South China Sea, Typhoon Haiyan devastated the central Philippines. In the wake of the storm it became clear that thousands of Filipinos had died. The photographer Ashley Gilberston and I were naturally concerned about the guys we lived with on that boat, known as the Sierra Madre. Judging from the number of questions we got after the storm, so were a lot of the magazine’s readers.

headline: American and Chinese Navy Ships Nearly Collided in South China Sea
text: BEIJING — In a sign of the increased tensions between the United States and China on the open seas, navy vessels from the two countries almost collided in the South China Sea when a Chinese ship cut across the bow of an American cruiser, a senior United States defense official said on Saturday.

headline: Inequality As A Defining Challenge
text: It has taken an amazingly long time, but inequality is finally surfacing as a significant unifying issue for progressives — including the president. And there is, inevitably, a backlash, or actually a couple of backlashes.

headline: TPP and IP, A Brief Note
text: Dean Baker takes me to task over the Trans Pacific trade deal, arguing that it’s not really about trade — that the important (and harmful) stuff involves regulation and intellectual property rights.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Wall-Mounted Bottle Opener
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: As Rover Lands, China Joins Moon Club
text: HONG KONG — China on Saturday became the third country to steer a spacecraft onto the moon after its unmanned Chang’e-3 probe settled onto the Bay of Rainbows, state-run television reported.

headline: Down to the Wire at Hollywood Park
text: A look at Hollywood Park, which thrived in the golden eras of horse racing and Hollywood but is scheduled to close on Dec. 22.

headline: A Last Hurrah for Hollywood Park
text: INGLEWOOD, Calif. — “And now, ladies and gentlemen, Hollywood Park belongs to you,” the race caller, Joe Hernandez, said over the public-address system on June 10, 1938. Among the 40,000 people who came for opening day at Southern California’s newest racetrack were the era’s biggest film stars, including Al Jolson, Joan Crawford, Milton Berle, Claudette Colbert, Bob Hope and Barbara Stanwyck.

headline: Can We Respond to Problems like Global Warming Where There’s ‘No Simple Villain’?
text: The folks at Greenbiz.com have been posting a lot of fresh video from the San Francisco Verge conference on energy entrepreneurship and innovation where I spoke onstage with the pioneering energy analyst Amory Lovins and green business guru Joel Makower, sang “Liberated Carbon” and talked with Makower about networked intelligence and the role of storytelling in improving energy habits and policies:

headline: Inequality and Incomes, Continued
text: Some further numerical thoughts on the right of inequality to be considered a “defining challenge.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: South Korea’s Rise Through Ranks Raises a Sport’s Profile
text: TORONTO — The recent World Sledge Hockey Challenge featured the United States, Canada and Russia, the top three finishers in this year’s world championships, in one of the final international events before the Paralympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: The Neo-paleo-Keynesian Counter-counter-counterrevolution (Wonkish)
text: OK, I can’t resist this one — and I think it’s actually important.

headline: The Exile’s Lament
text: The author of “The Man Without a Country,” a novella published in the December 1863 issue of The Atlantic Monthly, did not get a byline. An eerie narrative of betrayal and punishment, the piece is ostensibly the memoir of a retired naval officer named Fred Ingham.

headline: Week 15 Matchup: Seahawks (11-2) at Giants (5-8)
text: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: Week 15 Matchup: Jets (6-7) at Panthers (9-4)
text: 4:05 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: On Election Day, Latin America Willingly Trades Machismo for Female Clout
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — When Chileans vote Sunday for their next leader, they will choose between a former president seeking to expand access to higher education broadly and a staunch conservative opposing tax increases aimed at reducing Chile’s high levels of inequality.

headline: Calls Mount to Free 2 Iranian Opposition Leaders
text: TEHRAN — A stone’s throw from President Hassan Rouhani’s office, in an alley blocked off by security forces, Iran’s main opposition leader has been living under house arrest together with his wife for the past thousand days or so.

headline: Runner Powers His Way Onto the Jets’ Radar
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Fifteen yards and five would-be tacklers stood in front of Chris Ivory against the Oakland Raiders last Sunday, but the Jets’ running backs coach, Anthony Lynn, watched the play unfold as if it had already happened.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Dec. 13, 2013
text: The House of Representatives just passed a budget deal that will likely avert another government shutdown, which could have come as early as next month. This week on Money Talking, regular contributors Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine discuss what the deal means for businesses and the economy. Plus, Google and other tech companies are calling on the N.S.A. to limit online surveillance of their users.

headline: Variety: A Humming Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Well, that was a quick and fun one. Maybe I just enjoyed the musical subject. Or maybe Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon heard me whining a few weeks ago about how one of their acrostics had been tough for me, and they eased up on the cluing. Either way, I tore through this one.

headline: Officials Say U.S. May Never Know Extent of Snowden’s Leaks
text: WASHINGTON — American intelligence and law enforcement investigators have concluded that they may never know the entirety of what the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden extracted from classified government computers before leaving the United States, according to senior government officials.

headline: A Utah Law Prohibiting Polygamy Is Weakened
text: A federal judge has struck down parts of Utah’s anti-polygamy law as unconstitutional in a case brought by a polygamous star of a reality television series. Months after the Supreme Court bolstered rights of same-sex couples, the Utah case could open a new frontier in the nation’s recognition of once-prohibited relationships.

headline: France Broadens Its Surveillance Power
text: PARIS — For all their indignation last summer, when the scope of the United States’ mass data collection began to be made public, the French are hardly innocents in the realm of electronic surveillance. Within days of the reports about the National Security Agency’s activities, it was revealed that French intelligence services operated a similar system, with similarly minimal oversight.

headline: Recalling the Other Heroes of the Anti-Apartheid Struggle
text: MUSWELL HILL, England — Far from the crowds pressing to offer a final farewell to Nelson Mandela, a lesser tribute yielded a reminder that he was not alone in the struggle for what he called the rainbow nation.

headline: How Pharmaceuticals Sell A.D.H.D.
text: What makes A.D.H.D. ads so effective? Dr. Aaron Kesselheim of Brigham and Women’s Hospital analyzes several ads and discusses how they play on parents’ common fears about their children.

headline: Michelin Recalls 1.2 Million Tires
text: Michelin North America is recalling 1.2 million tires in the United States — including some used as original equipment on full-size Ford vans — because the tread might come apart, according to a report from the tire maker posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Arrests Challenge Los Angeles County Sheriff’s 4-Term Tenure
text: LOS ANGELES — A man trying to visit his brother in 2011 in a downtown Los Angeles jail was arrested by a deputy sheriff, who took him, in handcuffs, to a windowless break room and shoved him against a refrigerator. One deputy stood guard while others kicked and punched the man, still in handcuffs, his face against the floor. They wrote a report accusing the man of assault and pressed charges, which the district attorney later dropped abruptly.

headline: Jeremy Zimmer of United Talent Agency, on Accepting Ideas
text: This interview with Jeremy Zimmer, chief executive and co-founder of the United Talent Agency, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: The Puzzle Master on the Crossword Centennial
text: SPECIAL POST — Dec. 21, 2013, is the 100th birthday of the American-style crossword puzzle, and Will Shortz can be seen talking about it in the following places:

headline: Nets Suddenly Find a Fragile Success
text: For five weeks, just about everything fell apart for the Nets, including their coaching staff’s dynamic and most players’ health. Now everything appears to be falling into place.

headline: A Perspective on Guns, Murder, Suicide from Attica
text: (This essay accompanies Nicholas Kristof’s Sunday column on guns in America; please comment below on either the Kristof column or this essay by Lennon.)

headline: Phenom in Red Sneakers, Not Spikes, Pitching Scoops, Not Sliders
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The whole baseball world seemed to be here for last week’s winter meetings, the convention hotel lobby packed like a nightclub, and baseball’s youngest proclaimed insider zipping around while he texted with sources. He was the one in creaseless khaki pants, crisp dress shirt and red sneakers, his head held high.

headline: The Selling of Attention Deficit Disorder
text: The Number of Diagnoses Soared Amid a 20-Year Drug Marketing Campaign

headline: Wake Up the Banking Police
text: The Volcker Rule has landed. Will the United States financial system be safer and sounder as a result?

headline: The Bitcoin Ideology
text: IF you’ve only recently tuned in to the seemingly endless conversation about bitcoin, you could be forgiven for thinking that the digital currency is little more than the latest Wall Street fetish or a juiced-up version of PayPal. After all, so many headlines in the last few weeks have focused on its market price and the cool stuff you can get with it: Bitcoin breaks $1,000! Bitcoin plunges by a half! Bitcoin has a banner Black Friday! Use bitcoin to buy a ride on Richard Branson’s starship!

headline: Leaked! Harvard’s Grading Rubric
text: A longtime government professor at Harvard lashed out Tuesday at what he deemed a system of rampant grade inflation after learning that students are receiving mainly A’s.

headline: Skip the Supplements
text: PHILADELPHIA — PARENTS whose children are admitted to our hospital occasionally bring along something extra to help with their care: dietary supplements, like St. John’s wort to ameliorate mild depression or probiotics for better health.

headline: Dear President of China
text: MEMO to: China’s President Xi Jinping.

headline: The Daughter Theory
text: FOR our age of wonks and white papers and warring experts, there ought to be a word — something just short of, though not shorter than, schadenfreude — for the gentle thrill inspired by a social-science finding that mildly unsettles one’s ideological opponents.

headline: Bigger Than Bambi
text: WASHINGTON — I STARTED speaking truth to power early.

headline: The Catholics Still in Exile
text: HONEYMOON isn’t a word usually associated with pontiffs, but Pope Francis is having an extraordinary one. Last week Time magazine named him its person of the year, saying that he had given fresh hope to many Catholics estranged by the church’s censorious ways. The magazine noted the absence of harsh condemnation in his mentions of divorced couples, of women seeking abortions and of gay people, including his statement that “if a homosexual person is of good will and is in search of God, I am no one to judge.” From all of this, Time concluded that he had lifted the church “above the doctrinal police work so important to his recent predecessors.”

headline: Steve Coogan
text: Steve Coogan is a British comedian, writer, producer and frequent tabloid subject. He is a writer, producer and star of the dramatic film “Philomena,” which won awards at both the Venice and Toronto Film Festivals and was released in the United States last month.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Two Parties, or More?
text: Would a European-style multiparty system work better?

headline: Jets’ Smith Situation May Mirror Carolina’s in Quarterback Reboot
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Every position on the Carolina Panthers demanded an upgrade after they went 2-14 in 2010, and as owners of the No. 1 pick in the draft, the Panthers could choose which one to address first. For the team’s new coach, Ron Rivera, it was not a difficult choice.

headline: The Code of Life
text: MONTREAL — AFTER almost 20 years as a working book critic, I’ve come to accept that my line of work is basically a relic of another age. Book buyers now prefer the collective “wisdom” of Amazon reviews; newspapers and magazines, struggling to survive, are devoting less and less space to book matters; and writers are being forced by the economics of the Internet to give their opinions away for little or nothing.

headline: First Encounter With the Enemy
text: IN the late 1950s self-esteem hadn’t yet been invented. High schools saw their sole mission as preparing students thoroughly for academic work. I was the best prepared student in the girls’ school in my New England town. On graduation I won the English prize and the Spanish prize. The university I chose was overjoyed to welcome me, or so its letter of acceptance implied. How prescient — my intellect would no doubt set it on its ivy-covered ear. Also, men would throw themselves in the river for love of me.

headline: A Formula for Happiness
text: HAPPINESS has traditionally been considered an elusive and evanescent thing. To some, even trying to achieve it is an exercise in futility. It has been said that “happiness is as a butterfly which, when pursued, is always beyond our grasp, but which if you will sit down quietly, may alight upon you.”

headline: The Killer Who Supports Gun Control
text: A YEAR ago, America was shocked by the murder of 26 children and adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School. But momentum to take action has faded, and we still lose that many lives to gun violence every eight hours on average.

headline: We Are Not All in This Together
text: Rising income inequality troubles Americans. Some of us worry that the fate of the many has become divorced from the fortunes of the few. Others are concerned that the government will attack inequality by taking their hard-earned money and giving it to the less virtuous.

headline: Kyrie Irving: Will He Stay or Will He Go?
text: CLEVELAND — Kyrie Irving, a budding superstar with the Cavaliers, cannot become an unrestricted free agent until 2016. That is the earliest he can choose to leave the team. That is not any time soon, and most fans here seem to understand the rules of his employment.

headline: Social Democrats Secure a Third Term for Merkel
text: BERLIN — Germany’s center-left Social Democrats, torn between a tradition of leftist protest and a pragmatic desire to be in government, have voted heavily in favor of a new coalition with Chancellor Angela Merkel, paving the way for her to be sworn in for a third term on Tuesday.

headline: A Fast-Follower Now Wants to Be a Tech Trendsetter
text: Samsung has perennially spotted trends, particularly in electronics, and then outpaced its competitors. Now, it’s trying to define the next big thing.

headline: Samsung: Uneasy in the Lead
text: Lee Kun-hee, the man who built the most successful, most admired and most feared business in Asia — a $288 billion behemoth that is among the most profitable in the world — had a message for his employees this year: You must do better.

headline: From Fish Trader to Smartphone Maker
text: Samsung has its origins as a trading company established in Korea in 1938. It is now one of the largest and most recognizable technology brands in the world.

headline: Struggling to Cope With the Memories of a Child’s Brief Life
text: The only thing Miriam Zarate was ever able to buy for her son Sebastian was a pair of socks.

headline: Cook Islands, a Paradise of Untouchable Assets
text: Picture a paradise where you can be lawsuit-proof. A place to hide your hard-earned assets far from the grasp of former or soon-to-be-former spouses, angry business partners or, if you happen to be a doctor, patients who might sue you.

headline: SantaCon Presses On Through Weather and Criticism
text: Freezing temperatures. Sheets of sopping snowflakes. Outcry from New Yorkers tired of a city turned into a playground for debauching Santas. None of it could prevent SantaCon, the costumed holiday season bar crawl that seems to have grown larger and naughtier as the years have passed.

headline: Solving the Shortage in Primary Care Doctors
text: Again and again, we hear that the country has too few doctors, particularly for primary care. And Obamacare is supposed to make the shortage much worse in the coming years as more Americans become insured and try to shoehorn themselves into already crowded medical offices.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Dec. 15
text: “This is truly the next chapter in G.M.’s recovery and turnaround history.”

headline: The Return of John Podesta
text: Many were delighted by John Podesta’s decision last week to join President Obama’s White House staff, none more so than the environmental community and the people in charge of the federal agencies that are most responsible for the environment. As counselor to the president, Mr. Podesta, who served as White House chief of staff during President Clinton’s last three years, will have a broad portfolio touching on the economy and congressional relations. But his biggest contribution will be to bring his passion on environmental and energy issues to a president who has to be constantly reminded of their importance.

headline: The Guantánamo Trials, in Pastel
text: When future historians search back in time to “Camp Justice” and the rigidly controlled, tightly censored terrorist trials in Guantánamo, Cuba, they will likely linger over the vivid courtroom sketches of Janet Hamlin. She is an artist who has doggedly drawn courtroom scenes for the past seven years as the lone sketch artist permitted for the news media, holding a kind of visual monopoly for one of the grimmest, most severely limited sources of pictorial information imaginable.

headline: Face to Anti-Face
text: How fashion can be used as camouflage from face-detection technology.

headline: The Road to Qunu
text: Thousands lined the streets in Mthatha, South Africa, to say goodbye to Nelson Mandela, whose body will be buried in Qunu, his hometown.

headline: Surprise in a Matchup of Presidential Stock Portfolios
text: On Oct. 11, 2012, with only a few weeks before the presidential election, Wall Street was rooting for Mitt Romney, the Republican challenger from Massachusetts.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 15
text: Things are looking up on Capitol Hill this week after the House approved a bipartisan budget deal to fund the government into 2015. The Senate is expected to pass it next week. But the compromise left some Tea Party groups grumbling.

headline: Surveillance: Cozy or Chilling?
text: LAST year, two literal-minded Supreme Court justices were considering whether police officers needed a warrant before placing a GPS tracking device on a suspect’s S.U.V. when they ended up having a rather fanciful argument: What would the founding fathers make of a GPS device, anyway?

headline: Speaking Their Language
Addressing an Awkward History
text: I have managed a small department in a large and growing company for 12 years. My predecessor was fired for poor performance, and my first job was to clean up her mess: compliance violations, abandoned assignments and so on. On the one-year anniversary of her firing, this person had a (desperately uncomfortable) intermediary make phone calls accusing me of “harassing” her — a complete fabrication, as I have never met or spoken to her. To this day, her online résumé contains false information about her tenure here.

headline: A Missing Revenue Stream From Mobile Apps
text: One of my favorite guilty pleasures is Susan Miller, a popular New York astrologer who has a cult following online. I read her horoscopes religiously and enjoy following her on Twitter for the fun mix of quirky updates and planetary advice she dispenses.

headline: Enrollment Errors Cut, Officials Say; Fixes Are Overstated, Insurers Report
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Saturday that it had reduced the error rate in enrollment data sent to insurance companies under the new health care law, even as insurers said that the government’s records were still riddled with mistakes.

headline: Japan’s Top Voice: High, Polite and on the Phone
text: SENDAI, Japan — The contestants roll their shoulders and lick their lips. The audience holds its breath. At the center of attention on stage at an expansive convention hall: a single telephone.

headline: Outperformed Abroad, Tepid Support at Home
text: Americans are outranked.

headline: Hello, Japan's Champion Speaking ...
text: At the All-Japan Phone-Answering Competition, thousands of office workers compete for recognition as a paragon of courtesy, pleasantry and efficiency.

headline: Here Comes SantaCon (Despite the Snow and Rain)
text: The annual costumed bar crawl, which has faced complaints from New York residents, went on despite the snow and cold temperatures.

headline: Signs of Momentum Shifting to Protesters in Ukraine
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Two large, swirling crowds faced off in Kiev on Saturday in public squares less than a quarter of a mile apart. One was the huge, antigovernment, pro-Europe demonstration that has electrified this capital since late last month. The other was composed of tens of thousands who poured into central Kiev for a counter rally in support of the embattled president, Viktor F. Yanukovich.

headline: In N.H.L., Code of Justice Can Break Down
text: The N.H.L.’s 15-game suspension of Boston’s Shawn Thornton for attacking Pittsburgh defenseman Brooks Orpik in a Dec. 7 game will hardly be the final word in hockey’s endless soul-searching over the role of the enforcer. The debate is sure to continue the next time a player is injured in a fight or some other form of the sport’s brand of frontier justice.

headline: A Cut Above the Rest
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Wow. Just … wow. Am I right?

headline: Gays Worry About Post-Mandela S. Africa
text: South Africa’s constitution guarantees equality. But some gays worry that with Nelson Mandela’s passing, some of those rights could come under threat.

headline: Video: Gay South Africans Worry Now That Mandela Is Gone
text: Few images better depict what was not so long ago called “the new South Africa” than the Kelly-Loulié family portrait.

headline: Even Gifted Students Can’t Keep Up
text: In a post-smokestack age, there is only one way for the United States to avoid a declining standard of living, and that is through innovation. Advancements in science and engineering have extended life, employed millions and accounted for more than half of American economic growth since World War II, but they are slowing. The nation has to enlarge its pool of the best and brightest science and math students and encourage them to pursue careers that will keep the country competitive.

headline: Tiny Bits of Plastic Pose Big Environmental Threats
text: Tiny plastic beads used in hundreds of toiletries from facial scrubs to toothpastes are slipping through water treatment plants.

headline: Scientists Turn Their Gaze Toward Tiny Threats to Great Lakes
text: NORTH EAST, Pa. — The newest environmental threat to the Great Lakes is very, very small.

headline: Teaching Science Teachers
text: The American Museum of Natural History is offering a master's degree in teaching, part of a broad national campaign to add 100,000 science, technology and math teachers by 2021.

headline: Egypt to Vote Next Month on New Constitution
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s interim government on Saturday set Jan. 14 as the start of a two-day referendum on a revised Constitution, which will be the first gauge of support for the military’s ouster of Egypt’s first fairly elected president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Russia Wins Team Title Despite Loss to the U.S.
text: Russia overcame a dreadful start, including a loss in Round 2 to the United States, to win the gold medal at the World Team Chess Championship, the second most prestigious team event behind the biennial Chess Olympiad.

headline: When Private Firms Run Schools, Financial Secrecy Is Allowed
text: On a recently approved Texas charter school application, blacked-out paragraphs appear on almost 100 of its 393 pages.

headline: A Vast River and the Legal Woes at Its Banks
text: LAREDO, Tex. —  Many Texans who live along the border with Mexico share the legend of La Llorona, who is said to have drowned her children in the Rio Grande. And they pass on another myth: Once you drink the river-fed tap water here, you are bound to the region.

headline: Losers in Race Get Head Start for Next Steps
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: The Literary Journal and the Small Press Live On in Austin
text: In choosing a name for their new literary press, A Strange Object, Callie Collins and Jill Meyers turned to a quotation from an early Donald Barthelme short story, “Florence Green Is 81.” In the story, a character describes the aim of literature as “the creation of a strange object covered in fur which breaks your heart.”

headline: Navy Storms to 12th Straight Win Over Army
text: PHILADELPHIA — From the first game in 1890, through decades and generations, the Army-Navy football series represented high-caliber competition between evenly matched teams. It does not stand for that anymore.

headline: A Violent Border City’s Revival
text: In Ciudad Juárez, a symbol of drug war devastation, the killing has subsided, replaced by new businesses, a nightlife and hope.

headline: Ciudad Juárez, a Border City Known for Killing, Gets Back to Living
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — When David Lujana closed his restaurant here and moved to El Paso in 2010, his wife had just survived a kidnapping attempt and this city produced eight homicides a day. It was Mexico’s murder capital and a place of mass exodus, with roughly a third of the city’s population fleeing in just a few bloody years.

headline: Bloomberg Focuses on Rest (as in Rest of the World)
text: Michael R. Bloomberg, determined to parlay his government experience and vast fortune into a kind of global mayoralty, is creating a high-powered consulting group to help him reshape cities around the world long after he leaves office.

headline: Winston Earns Heisman in a Runaway
text: Florida State quarterback Jameis Winston spent the past week on college football’s postseason awards circuit, cycling through banquets and red carpets and trophy presentations. That culminated Saturday in Manhattan, where Winston won the Heisman Trophy, his sport’s pre-eminent honor.

headline: Far Right in Eastern Europe Makes Gains as Syrians Arrive
text: SVILENGRAD, Bulgaria — After spreading turmoil and desperate refugees across the Middle East, Syria’s brutal civil war has now leaked misery into Europe’s eastern fringe — and put a spring in the step of Angel Bozhinov, a nationalist activist in this Bulgarian border town next to Turkey.

headline: Snowstorm Causes Delays at New York Airports
text: A winter storm that was expected to blanket New England and the Ohio Valley with a foot or more of snow over the weekend caused significant delays and cancellations at New York City airports on Saturday, officials said.

headline: Following the Murky Trail Left by Diamonds and Cash
text: ANTWERP, Belgium — The bond between banker and diamond dealer has long been a cozy one in an industry shaped by an insular culture of carats and cash, secrets and intrigues, weddings and bar mitzvahs. But lately those old bonds are dissolving in the packed square mile of gem traders here that forms the hub of the global diamond industry.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 14, 2013
Corrections: December 15, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 15, 2013
text: “The numbers make it look like an epidemic. Well, it’s not. It’s preposterous. This is a concoction to justify the giving out of medication at unprecedented and unjustifiable levels.”

headline: No Rest for Stoudemire; No Regrets for Knicks
text: A night earlier, Amar’e Stoudemire seemed to doubt he would play in Saturday’s game, the road-weary Knicks’ second game in two days, and their fourth in five. Yet he was on the court Saturday night against the Atlanta Hawks, wearing his familiar No. 1 jersey and black goggles, ambling up and down the court.

headline: A Rally for the Ukrainian Government
text: Tens of thousands of demonstrators came out to support Ukraine's President Yanukovich on Saturday.

headline: Thea Johnson, Geoffrey Bickford
text: Thea Burns Johnson and Geoffrey Keenan Bickford are to be married Sunday at the Parker Meridien New York hotel. Dr. Nathaniel Berman, a cousin of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

headline: Krista Brown and Maya Rosenthal-Larrea
text: Krista Nicole Brown and Maya Alexandra Rosenthal-Larrea were married Friday at their apartment in New York. Carl Rosenthal, Ms. Rosenthal-Larrea’s brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Brigitte Tomasulo, Richard Birrer
text: Brigitte Anne Tomasulo, the daughter of Denise Tomasulo and Richard P. Tomasulo of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married Saturday to Richard Bruce Birrer, a son of Christina D. Birrer and Dr. Richard B. Birrer of Locust Valley, N.Y. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in Manhattan at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, where he is the pastor.

headline: Anne Fenton and Jeffrey Sharpe
text: Anne Pierson Fenton and Jeffrey Alan Sharpe were married Friday evening at the Overlook Lodge in Bear Mountain State Park in Fort Montgomery, N.Y. Claire Karpen Pettry, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Matthew Williams and Paul Berg
text: Matthew Owen Ross Williams and Paul Jared Berg were married Saturday at Battery Gardens in New York. Justice Lester B. Adler, who sits on State Supreme Court in White Plains and who is an uncle of Mr. Berg, officiated.

headline: Eva Schildhause and Adam Weissmann
text: Eva Shafer Schildhause, a daughter of Stephanie A. Shieldhouse and Richard G. Shieldhouse of Jacksonville, Fla., was married Monday to Adam David Weissmann, a son of Jill and Jeffrey Weissmann of White Plains. Wilma Brier, the branch manager of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia Marriage Bureau, officiated.

headline: Kevin Williams, Brett Krutzsch
text: Kevin Wayne Williams and Brett Armin Krutzsch were married in Philadelphia on Saturday evening by Rabbi Rebecca T. Alpert at the Pennsylvania headquarters of the National Society of the Colonial Dames of America.

headline: Puja Parekh and Ashok Gowda
text: Puja Kirit Parekh and Dr. Ashok Laxman Gowda were married Saturday at the Frenchman’s Reef and Morning Star Marriott Beach Resort in St. Thomas, V.I. Pandit Sree M. Aswath, a Hindu priest, led the ceremony.

headline: Life Imitating the Stage
text: Christina Lea Rynearson and Daniel Lopez were married Saturday by Deacon Mike Keary at the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark.

headline: Samantha Golkin, David Nigliazzo
text: Samantha J. Golkin and David Mario Nigliazzo were married Saturday evening at Gotham Hall, an event space in New York. Rabbi Mendy Gutnick officiated.

headline: Rebecca Oyen and Joshua Benesh
text: Rebecca Sage Oyen, a daughter of Lois Sage and Christopher Oyen of Orlando, Fla., is to be married Sunday to Joshua Louis Benesh, the son of Kristine O. Benesh and Randy J. Benesh of Marion, Iowa. Mary Thompson Hunt, a friend of the bride’s family who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to perform the ceremony, incorporating Jewish traditions, at Disney’s Boardwalk Inn in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.

headline: Sandra Greer, Jane Post
text: Sandra Greer and Jane Post were married Monday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Alisa Fuentes, a deputy city clerk, officiated.

headline: Gail Tabak, Jason Paul
text: Gail Allison Tabak and Jason Scott Paul were married Saturday evening at the Pierre hotel in New York. Rabbi Robert N. Levine officiated, with Cantor Rebecca Garfein participating.

headline: Thousands Gather to Bury Mandela in His Home Village
text: QUNU, South Africa — They gathered in the rolling green hills of the Eastern Cape on Sunday to return a son to his native soil: princes and presidents, chiefs and priests, celebrities and grandmothers, comrades and cellmates, here to bury Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela.

headline: Video Notebook: Mandela Arrives Home
text: The Times’s John Eligon talked to South Africans in Qunu, Nelson Mandela’s boyhood village, as his remains arrived for burial.

headline: Vows: Celebrating Home
text: Amanda Lundy and Sean McGinley, both quirky collectors, live in their dream home in Sea Bright, N.J. Damage from Hurricane Sandy had them scrambling to renovate in time for their wedding.

headline: North Korean Leader’s Aunt Appears Unscathed
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Kyong-hui, an aunt of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, appears to have survived the purge and execution of her husband, Jang Song-thaek, as her name re-emerged on a leadership list in the North’s state-run news media over the weekend.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (FXX) MR. POPPER’S PENGUINS (2011) Jim Carrey — his limbs not quite as elastic in this comeback vehicle, directed by Mark Waters — manages not to be upstaged by a half-dozen flightless birds, above, as he plays Popper, a real estate wheeler-dealer and lousy father who ends up with a strange bequest from his own lousy dad. Carla Gugino is the ex-wife Popper is trying to woo back; Angela Lansbury is the reluctant seller he’s trying to persuade to part with Tavern on the Green; and David Krumholtz is the neighbor who objects to the goings-on in Popper’s snow-filled Manhattan duplex. “Mr. Carrey is the kind of performer whose shtick reliably trumps psychological sense, and the film’s blithe incoherence with respect to its main character is one of its virtues,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It turns sentimental now and then, but it knows — Mr. Carrey knows — that what the audience wants from him is silliness.”

headline: If Only It Were the 1930s
text: I’ve mentioned before that at this point Europe is actually doing worse in the aftermath of the 2007 crisis than it did in the Great Depression. Nick Crafts documents this at greater length, and adds a provocative analysis of debt dynamics.

headline: Teaching a Daughter She Can Do Anything, When A.L.S. Means Her Mother Can’t
text: Shortly before she turned 2, I overheard my daughter in her crib, talking to the water bottle she sleeps with. “I can’t carry you, Water,” she told the bottle. “You’re too heavy. You have to walk.” As with most things Scarlett said at the time, I could immediately identify the origin of the words. I had said them to her myself — probably that very morning — as we made our way up two flights of stairs to our San Francisco apartment.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Diptyque Solid Perfume
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Mandela Buried in Home Village
text: Nelson Mandela’s funeral Sunday was a final farewell after a series of celebrations and memorials since he died Dec. 5.

headline: In Our Pages: December 16
text: 1938: Secrets Of British Air Defense Revealed

headline: Disruptions: Internet’s Sad Legacy: No More Secrets
text: Anyone who can watch you will watch you.

headline: A West Side Obstacle Course Of Potholes and Cave-Ins
text: New York City is a rough ride, no doubt about it, with roads pocked with enough bumps and divots that driving one mile here feels as if it takes as much out of your car as driving 70 miles anywhere else.

headline: Scenes From Mandela’s Funeral Service
text: President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa spoke at Nelson Mandela’s funeral service, as did some of Mr. Mandela’s grandchildren.

headline: All in the Family
text: An old adage states, “You can pick your friends, but not your relatives.” The truth of this maxim was brought home to Abraham and Mary Lincoln when Mary’s half sister, Emilie Todd Helm, visited the White House in late 1863.

headline: European Union Suspends Trade Talks With Ukraine
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The European Union on Sunday broke off talks with Ukraine on the far-reaching trade deal that protesters here have been demanding for weeks, and a top official issued a stinging, angry statement all but accusing Ukraine’s president of dissembling during the negotiations.

headline: Parties Agree on Leader Ahead of Vote in Tunisia
text: CASABLANCA, Morocco — Tunisia’s political parties agreed on the selection of a new prime minister late Saturday, breaking months of political deadlock between the Islamist-led government and secular opposition parties.

headline: Peter O’Toole, Whose Acclaim Began With ‘Lawrence of Arabia,’ Dies at 81
text: Peter O’Toole, an Irish bookmaker’s son with a hell-raising streak whose performance in the 1962 epic film “Lawrence of Arabia” earned him overnight fame and established him as one of his generation’s most charismatic actors, died on Saturday in London. He was 81.

headline: New ‘Hobbit’ Film Opens at No. 1
text: Initial box-office results for “The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug” (Warner Brothers) came with a tinge of disappointment: Hollywood expects ticket sales for sequels to go up, and the initial total for “Desolation of Smaug” fell 13 percent below the opening amount collected last year by “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey.”

headline: Random House Acquires 1800s Prison Memoir
text: The recently discovered manuscript believed to be the first prison memoir by an African-American was swiftly acquired by Random House, the publisher said on Sunday. The 304-page manuscript, by Austin Reed, was recently authenticated by scholars at Yale University.

headline: China Focusing Graft Inquiry on Ex-Official
text: BEIJING — Sending tremors across China’s political landscape, President Xi Jinping and other party leaders have authorized a corruption inquiry against the powerful former head of the domestic security apparatus, Zhou Yongkang, according to sources with elite political ties.

headline: Smart Gifts, and Old Devices Made New Again
text: LONDON — From solar-powered Christmas lights and cellphone chargers to smart home thermostats, there are plenty of gifts available for technology lovers interested in saving energy.

headline: Developing Cures or Hyping Up Demand?
text: Can drug companies' influence over treatments for conditions like A.D.H.D. be reduced?

headline: St. John’s Finds Hope in a Loss to Syracuse
text: For 15 minutes of the second half against Syracuse on Sunday, St. John’s looked as if it might upset the No. 2 Orange at Madison Square Garden, scramble the national rankings and light up the New York college basketball scene once again.

headline: Mandela Laid to Rest
text: Thousands of relatives, friends and dignitaries gathered Sunday in Qunu, South Africa, for the state funeral of Nelson Mandela.

headline: Gunmen in Iraq Kill an Official and His Family
text: BAGHDAD — Unidentified gunmen stormed the house of a Health Ministry employee in a city north of the capital on Sunday and killed him, his wife and their three children, the police and medical officials said. Other attacks across the country left at least 14 more dead, officials said.

headline: Ancient Egypt as the Stuff of Fantasy, From the Grand to the Goofy
text: It takes a lot of devotion to Egyptiana to earn the nickname “Mr. Mummy,” as Bob Brier has. His books and documentaries cover subjects from pyramids, mummies and tombs to the murder of King Tut (film rights optioned by the director of “Godzilla”), and he is an avid collector of the paraphernalia he calls Egyptotrash. So “Egyptomania” promises to be the most accessible, entertaining and kitschiest of his books so far.

headline: Saudi Prince Criticizes Obama Administration, Citing Indecision in Mideast
text: MONACO — An influential Saudi prince blasted the Obama administration on Sunday for what he called indecision and a loss of credibility with allies in the Middle East, saying that American efforts to secure a peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians would founder without a clear commitment from President Obama.

headline: Drubbing by Seahawks Assures Giants of a Losing Record
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In the locker room Sunday, moments after the Seattle Seahawks thrashed his Giants, 23-0, Coach Tom Coughlin took the blame for the humiliating defeat.

headline: Two Personal Stories Become One Film
text: With his enthralling documentary “Two Lessons,” the Polish director and cinematographer Wojciech Staron fulfills a longtime plan to unite two separately filmed personal stories into a single work. The result is a captivating record of two journeys, two relationships and one family’s transformation.

headline: In Praise of Failure
text: If there was ever a time to think seriously about failure, it is now.

headline: Senate Prepares to Wrap Up Sluggish 2013
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate’s final week in session this year promises to be memorable not for legislative business like the pending budget and defense bills but for something far less inspired: the vast amount of time it spends doing nothing in particular.

headline: Life Master Pairs and Edgar Kaplan Blue Ribbon Winners
text: The winners of the two main pair events at the Fall Nationals in Phoenix this month had at least two things in common. First, the partners had not played together in a pair event before. Second, one player in each pair is an American, and the other was born and raised in one country but has represented another country internationally.

headline: A Well-Dressed Wolf Who Is Still Bad to the Bone
text: If the Devil has the rights to all the best tunes, nobody told Prokofiev. In his 1936 musical fable, “Peter & the Wolf,” the predatory Wolf doesn’t get much of a melody. His menace is usually rendered instead by creepy harmonies from a trio of horns. Peter, the Cat, the hapless Duck, even the grumpy Grandfather: Theirs are the famous tunes that have introduced generations of children to the instruments of the orchestra.

headline: Wide Repertory Invites Plenty of Meandering
text: A handful of hit singles gives a band some leeway, and MGMT used all it has at Barclays Center on Friday. MGMT — led by the singer Andrew VanWyngarden and Ben Goldwasser, who both play guitars and keyboards — strategically doled out the three hits from its 2008 debut album, “Oracular Spectacular”: “Time to Pretend” early in the set and “Electric Feel” and “Kids” near the end, each one drawing arena-wide squeals of recognition.

headline: Mining Tchaikovsky, and Finding More Amid the Snowflakes
text: Watching American Ballet Theater perform “The Nutcracker” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this month is entirely a pleasure, mixed with several elements of happy surprise. It’s just so unusual for American ballet to display character acting as vivid and widespread as it is here from a large number of performers. The servants, mice, parents and guests of the opening scenes seem to have stepped out of Gogol or Dickens. They’re played with varying degrees of caricature, very finely judged; the degrees of subtle, funny exaggeration are in proportion to their psychological distance from the child heroine. Everyone seems to be bubbling over with vitality.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Ambitions That Rise Long Before Curtains Do
text: Capturing the creative process in a documentary is next to impossible, and “Playwright: From Page to Stage,” on Monday on PBS’s “Independent Lens,” doesn’t succeed any better than previous efforts. But the film, which follows two young playwrights as they have new works produced in prominent regional theaters (culminating, for one, in a Broadway run), does have a few candid moments that go deeper than we’re used to seeing.

headline: Fire Investigation at Detroit Art Site
text: The Heidelberg Project, an interactive public art installation covering two blocks in Detroit, has been the site of eight suspicious fires since May, causing investigators to wonder why the project, which has existed in some form since 1986, has become a target, The Associated Press reported. The most recent fire took place on Dec. 8, destroying an abandoned house that had been repurposed as a canvas for paintings, recycled materials and found objects. Since October, five structures have been destroyed by fire. This is not the first time parts of the site have been destroyed. In 1991 and 1999, the city bulldozed large portions of the installation, viewing the collection of random items and hodgepodge paintings not as art, but as trash. Originally created by the artist Tyree Guyton to combat urban blight and decay, the Heidelberg Project has expanded its goals to provide art education and to promote community development. It is also something of a tourist destination, with over 275,000 visitors annually. There are no suspects in the fires. A private donor has offered a $25,000 reward in the case.

headline: Boyhood Longing (and Lobbying) for a BB Gun
text: Making a musical out of “A Christmas Story” must have hardly seemed like work to Joseph Robinette, the book writer, and Benj Pasek and Justin Paul, who provided the music and lyrics. How easy was it? When the second-act curtain went up on opening night of the production now running at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, a flagpole received a smattering of applause.

headline: Chilean Voters Return a Former President to Power
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Chilean voters handed a landslide victory to Michelle Bachelet on Sunday, returning her to the presidency amid continuing unease over high levels of inequality in Chile despite an enviable stretch of rapid economic growth.

headline: To Thine Own Algorithm Be True
text: Woe to the reporter who seeks to track Annie Dorsen’s speech patterns. The same combination of speed, breadth and complexity that makes her a thrilling conversationalist means any note taker faces a Sisyphean task.

headline: All Roads Lead to It
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — It seems a shame that Greg Johnson is saying GOODBYE to us just as he’s making his debut. We were just getting to know him.

headline: ‘The Life and Death of Marina Abramovic’
text: Scenes from the show at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: The End, if It’s Up to You
text: That familiar fantasy of spying on one’s own funeral has come spectacularly true for at least one of us mortals, the performance artist Marina Abramovic, whose work dates back to the 1970s and who has become a slavishly adored fixture on the art-celebrity circuit over the past decade. In “The Life and Death of Marina Abramovic,” a new music-theater piece being presented through Saturday in the Drill Hall of the Park Avenue Armory, Ms. Abramovic is lying plushly in state on a giant stage draped in black and lit by glowing white neon bars.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Dec. 16
text: EURO ZONE European Union finance officials begin convening in Brussels on Tuesday in an attempt to create a system to wind down failed banks, known as the Single Resolution Mechanism. Officials were unable to reach a deal last week amid disagreement on crucial issues of funding and resolution authority. Heads of state will be in town Thursday and Friday to sign off on any final agreement.

headline: Jingle Ball 2013
text: Scenes from the concert at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Bad Girl Meets Bad Santa
text: “THE INTENSITY FOR MILEY IS REAL,” read an audience member’s live tweet above the stage during the Z100 Jingle Ball on Friday night. Stone truth. Up to the moment of Miley Cyrus’s appearance, whenever her name was mentioned — by a live being like Elvis Duran, host of the Z100 “Morning Show,” or in a recorded announcement — the massed screaming had something extra, a sound of acrid immediacy, released into the air of Madison Square Garden like the smell of burning wires.

headline: ‘Indie Essentials’
text: A look at the Museum of the Moving Image’s new exhibition of “local multiplayer” games.

headline: Multiplayer Games With a Local Touch
text: Video games are the art form that computation has given us, and the shifting reputation of games and their players has roughly tracked that of computer users. Games were a lonely and isolating novelty until they were connected to the Internet, which turned them into a crowded and abusive novelty.

headline: ‘The Nutcracker’
text: Scenes from a new production from the Gelsey Kirkland Ballet.

headline: Toys Still Come to Life, but Candy Is Missing
text: As a pre-eminent dancer with American Ballet Theater in the 1970s and ’80s, Gelsey Kirkland was known for her storytelling. With her fabled vulnerability and big, sad eyes, she carried many a full-length ballet: “Giselle,” “Romeo and Juliet” and, perhaps most famously, “The Nutcracker.” In a 1978 review of Mikhail Baryshnikov’s version (the same one that lit up the nation’s living rooms via PBS), the critic Anna Kisselgoff wrote in The New York Times that Ms. Kirkland, as Clara, “has found one of her deepest roles.”

headline: Revelations That Ikea Spied on Its Employees Stir Outrage in France
text: PARIS — Virginie Paulin’s voice still trembles when she recounts how she was fired from what she considered her dream job at Ikea in France.

headline: Leftover Projects
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration has been pushing a number of last-minute real estate projects through the approval process in the mayor’s last few months in office. Here are some, with estimates of the cost to develop.

headline: A.I.G. Sells Aircraft Leasing Unit for $5.4 Billion
text: Updated, 6:30 a.m. | The American International Group has agreed to sell its big aircraft leasing unit, the International Lease Finance Corporation, to a competing business, AerCap Holdings of the Netherlands, for about $5.4 billion in stock and cash.

headline: Naturally, J.J. Cale
text: This animated Op-Doc explores why J.J. Cale, who wrote such classic songs as “After Midnight,” “Cocaine” and “Call Me the Breeze,” never achieved stardom.

headline: Ukrainians Gear Up for Holidays as Protests Continue
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Like hundreds of thousands of her fellow citizens, Olga Begun, 29, was in Independence Square on Sunday, fretting about the future of Ukraine, but not about the push-and-pull between Europe and Russia, or if the government will resign. Instead, she was thinking about outfits for the future Ukrainian that she is set to give birth to next month.

headline: One Brother Reaches Out to Another Across the Economic Divide
text: Sometimes, Mike Remboulis can almost forget. For an hour or so, in the crush of a crowded restaurant, he feels like any other guy with a beautiful girlfriend and a comfortable salary savoring the good life in Brooklyn.

headline: ‘Naturally, J.J. Cale’
text: This animated Op-Doc explores why J.J. Cale, who wrote classics like “After Midnight,” “Cocaine” and “Call Me the Breeze,” never achieved stardom.

headline: Charles M. Vest, 72, President of M.I.T. and a Leader in Online Education, Dies
text: Charles M. Vest, who as president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology oversaw an expansion in research and online education and increased the number of women and minority members in leadership positions, died on Thursday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 72.

headline: Jets’ Fourth-Quarter Mistakes, Unusual and Familiar, Hurt Playoff Hopes
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Rex Ryan approached the lectern at Bank of America Stadium late Sunday evening with the countenance of a man who needed a big hug, a generous pour or both. His voice was a bit hoarse, his eyes a bit droopy, as he recounted how the Jets’ 30-20 loss to the Carolina Panthers unfolded like a compressed version of their season.

headline: A Grand Weekend Out for Pennsylvanians
text: It was 1899 when the Pennsylvania Society first gathered for oysters and Delmonico steaks at the Waldorf-Astoria, a gilded era when, the story goes, the industrialists and bankers who owned Pennsylvania lived in New York City.

headline: A Microsoft Star Goes to Google
text: SEATTLE — Blaise Agüera y Arcas, a respected engineer and software designer at Microsoft, has left the company to join its rival Google.

headline: The Documented Life
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — LAST spring, I had the occasion to spend a day with the actor and comedian Aziz Ansari discussing our mutual interest in the psychology of texting. As we walked through Los Angeles, people approached him every few minutes not to ask for an autograph, but to demand a photograph. Mr. Ansari is gracious to his fans. He explained that instead of a photograph, he would offer a conversation. He inquired about their taste in music, what they liked about his performances, his stand-up, his sitcom “Parks and Recreation.” His fans were mollified but they were rarely happy. They had to walk away with nothing on their phones.

headline: Victims of Misclassification
text: WASHINGTON — LAST month, a Michigan construction worker named Matt Anderson testified in a Senate hearing about being a victim of employee misclassification. Mr. Anderson said that his employer forced him, after six years as an employee, to switch to “independent contractor” status. Though the move stripped Mr. Anderson of basic employee rights and protections, he went along with the change, he said, because “my fellow workers and I had families to support and we saw how bad the economy was.”

headline: NPR Gets $17 Million in Grants to Expand Coverage and Develop Digital Platform
text: NPR has amassed nearly $17 million in grants to increase substantially its coverage of education and global health and development, and finance creation of a new mobile and web platform that is expected to allow it to reach more listeners and better compete with outside aggregators of public radio content.

headline: Abraham Briloff, Accounting Professor, Dies at 96
text: Abraham J. Briloff, an accounting expert whose trenchant and sometimes scathing analyses of corporate financial records often sent investors scurrying to dump their stocks, died on Thursday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 96.

headline: Bankruptcy Court Hearing Examines Mystery at Wine Storage Business
text: Derek L. Limbocker, a onetime financial adviser, publisher of rare art prints and society figure in Newport, R.I., and New York, has been stiff-arming his clients for the past 13 months.

headline: Gaza, Vexed by Floods, Gets Fuel and Power
text: GAZA — Gaza’s lone power plant sputtered back to life on Sunday for the first time in seven weeks, bringing relief to the Palestinian coastal enclave where a lack of cheap fuel has contributed to the overflow of raw sewage, 21-hour blackouts and flooding after a ferocious winter storm.

headline: Fear of Dying Alone Drove a Panhandler to Seek Drug Rehabilitation
text: It had grown dark, and Rickey Henegan was seeking refuge for the night in a spot behind two Dumpsters. But the spot was occupied by the corpse of a fellow homeless man, who had been dead long enough for his body to start decomposing.

headline: Why Inequality Matters
text: Rising inequality isn’t a new concern. Oliver Stone’s movie “Wall Street,” with its portrayal of a rising plutocracy insisting that greed is good, was released in 1987. But politicians, intimidated by cries of “class warfare,” have shied away from making a major issue out of the ever-growing gap between the rich and the rest.

headline: Russia vs. Europe
text: The world needs Nelson Mandelas. Instead, it gets Vladimir Putins. As the South African hero was being sung to his grave last week, the Russian president was bullying neighboring Ukraine into a new customs union that is starting to look a bit like Soviet Union Lite, and consolidating his control of state-run media by creating a new Kremlin news agency under a nationalistic and homophobic hard-liner.

headline: Writing About Gangsters, as Far Back as He Can Remember
text: Jerry Capeci was trying to get his mitts around an international tale written in blood, a case that put together a Mafia boss in Montreal and murders in Brooklyn and Acapulco, Mexico.

headline: Scholars’ Group to Disclose Result of Vote on an Academic Boycott of Israel
text: A growing campaign among American professors to isolate Israel reaches a milestone on Monday when a large group of scholars is expected to reveal whether its members endorsed an academic boycott of Israel to protest Israeli treatment of Palestinians.

headline: Wilson Has Sights Set on Snow and Super Bowl
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Maybe next time. Maybe if Russell Wilson can make it back to MetLife Stadium in another month and a half for the annual orgy of excess known as the Super Bowl, the weather will cooperate more and be less of a tease.

headline: Airbnb Campaign Uses Birdhouses to Widen Its Reach
text: AIRBNB, which lets travelers rent accommodations in private residences worldwide, is introducing its first integrated, national advertising campaign on Monday, using birds and birdhouses as a metaphor for its customers and their accommodations.

headline: Going Out With Building Boom, Mayor Pushes Billions in Projects
text: The Bloomberg administration has been pushing through more than $12 billion worth of real estate projects in its waning days, trying to solidify the mayor’s claim to having transformed the face of New York City and lock in plans before Bill de Blasio takes over Jan. 1.

headline: Breadwinner Moms, Caregiving Dads
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mentally Ill, and Excluded at the Border
text: To the Editor:

headline: A ‘Prince’ for Today
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beyoncé Rejects Tradition for Social Media’s Power
text: The release of a blockbuster album has historically come with a few standard marketing moves. Flood the radio with an early single. Book as many TV appearances as possible. Line up partnerships with big retailers and consumer brands.

headline: Women’s Rights, Redux
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sheriffs Refuse to Enforce Laws on Gun Control
text: GREELEY, Colo. — When Sheriff John Cooke of Weld County explains in speeches why he is not enforcing the state’s new gun laws, he holds up two 30-round magazines. One, he says, he had before July 1, when the law banning the possession, sale or transfer of the large-capacity magazines went into effect. The other, he “maybe” obtained afterward.

headline: Getting to the Super Bowl
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Public Housing, Units Languish in Limbo
text: Two years ago, Chastity Ciprian said she asked about the two top-floor apartments, long vacant in her four-story building at Harlem River Houses, a public-housing project at the northern tip of Manhattan.

headline: As Merkel Embarks on Third Term, Critics Urge Her to Be Daring
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel, a decisive winner in September’s elections but muted ever since about where she plans to take Europe’s biggest economy, embarks this week on a third term that could put her stamp on German and European history — but only, critics say, if she abandons her cautious tactics for a more strategic embrace of the demands of the 21st century.

headline: Medicaid Outpaces Private Plans
text: After a botched start, the number of people signing up for health insurance plans under the Affordable Care Act has accelerated greatly, with the most substantial gains occurring in Medicaid programs for the poor.

headline: The Black Hole of Terrorism Watch Lists
text: In 2005, a Stanford doctoral student named Rahinah Ibrahim tried to check in at the San Francisco airport for a flight to a conference in Hawaii. She was traveling with her 14-year-old daughter. Authorities arrested Dr. Ibrahim, a Malaysian citizen, at the ticket counter and detained her in a holding cell for two hours. After she missed her flight, she was released and told that she had mistakenly been placed on the government’s no-fly list.

headline: Big Tobacco Bullies
text: With ever more Americans and Europeans giving up smoking, tobacco companies have increasingly focused on developing countries as markets for their addictive and deadly products. Now, as some of those nations try to regulate cigarettes by, for example, requiring warning labels, Big Tobacco is using trade and investment agreements to challenge and intimidate them.

headline: Safer Speeds on Commuter Rail

headline: Simon Singh Presents ‘The Simpsons and Their Mathematical Secrets’
text: America’s longest-running sitcom “The Simpsons” has a secret: It’s also one of the smartest shows on TV. Look past the antics of Homer and Bart and you’ll find the show filled with an abundance of mathematics references, thanks to its remarkably nerdy cast of writers. British science and math writer Simon Singh tells the whole story in his new book, “The Simpsons and Their Mathematical Secrets,” in which he introduces us to the writing team behind “The Simpsons” and uncovers many of the mathematical references in the shows. Dr. Singh will also be joining us this week as we take on three challenges from the book. (Click the book cover to download an excerpt from Chapter 4: The Puzzle of Mathematical Humor.)

headline: F.D.A. Questions Safety of Antibacterial Soaps
text: After years of mounting concerns that the antibacterial chemicals that go into everyday items like soap and toothpaste are doing more harm than good, the Food and Drug Administration said on Monday that it was requiring soap manufacturers to demonstrate that the substances were safe or to take them out of the products altogether.

headline: By Design | Zaha Hadid, Jewelry Designer
text: Zaha Hadid, the Iraq-born, London-based Pritzker prize-winning architect with more than 40 buildings around the globe, also makes jewelry. In 2010, she created a collection for Swarovski, and now she has followed it up with a set of rings and a cuff from lattices of gold filigree for Caspita, the Swiss jewelry brand. Inspired by naturally occurring cell structures, the pieces in the collection, which is called Skein, look like golden honeycomb, as if assembled by bees. Some are studded with diamonds. Polygons form a delicate mesh that envelops the finger, a shape that is reminiscent of Hadid’s Al Wakrah stadium in Qatar. In fact, she acknowledges, “There is a lot of fluidity now between jewelry design, architecture and art — a lot more cross-pollination in the disciplines.” The collection was introduced earlier this month at Colette’s pop-up at Art Basel in Miami Beach and at the Zaha Hadid Design Gallery in London last week. It goes on sale online today at Latest Revival.

headline: Can Peace Come to a Family a Brother ‘Destroyed’ Because His Sister Is Gay?
text: Q. Dear Civil Behavior: Almost 30 years ago, my older brother gave my parents an ultimatum — disown my little sister, who had just revealed she was gay, or he would cut himself and his family off from the rest of us. My parents refused to do such a thing and my brother made good on his threat and destroyed our family. I stood with my sister and have not seen or spoken to my big brother or any of his family since his declaration so long ago. Neither has my sister. Time has not healed the wounds of our family. On his deathbed, my dad asked me never to forget what my brother did to all of us and I promised him I would not — and I refuse to forgive him. My mother has forgiven my brother — and I’m glad for her. I also know my mom dearly wishes to have her family together before she dies. My question: Should I honor my father’s deathbed request or my mother’s final wish? — Straight Sister in the Middle

headline: Mushroom Ragoût
text: I like to use this as a gravy at Thanksgiving, instead of actual gravy, but that is far from its only use. I serve it on its own, as a side dish, as the base for a risotto and a filling for a pie, taco and quesadilla, as a sauce for pasta and an omelet filling. You can make it with all wild mushrooms for a splurge, with some wild mushrooms, or with a mix of cultivated oyster mushrooms (much less expensive than wild mushrooms like chanterelles) and button or creminis. Make this big batch and use it for lots of other dishes throughout the week.

headline: In Store | Retro Nike Sneakers Aimed at the Fashion Set
text: It goes without saying that New York’s fashion crowd is eagerly awaiting the opening of their very own Dover Street Market in New York City. But sneakerheads, too, have something to look forward to when the multibrand store opens in Kips Bay on Dec. 21. Nike, a longtime collaborator with Comme des Garçons and the original Dover Street Market, will introduce its newest take on one of its most popular styles, the Nike Air Python. First released in 1987, the now legendary basketball sneaker was the first of the brand’s shoes to hit stores sans the signature swoosh. The new Nike Air Python DSM NYC ($160) is part of an exclusive five-piece capsule collection that will also be available at the other two Dover Street Market locations in London and Tokyo. It includes a bomber jacket ($600) and fitted baseball cap ($40) in addition to the all-black sneakers, which feature python-printed leather and reflective tape detailing, an unconventional combination well suited for Dover Street Market’s avant-garde clientele. Two graphic T-shirts ($50 each) round out the collection, a nod to the Air Python’s roots in ’80s street culture. Nike Air Python DSM, $160, doverstreetmarket.com.
