text: BOISE, Idaho — A local illustrator’s chalk portraits of workers hang inside the store, where the same artist’s murals decorate the wall behind the cheese case.

headline: Juilliard Focus! Festival to Spotlight Postmodernists
text: The 2014 edition of the Juilliard School’s Focus! Festival will be devoted to the world of Alfred Schnittke, the iconoclastic Russian composer, who died in 1998. The festival, which runs from Jan. 24 to 31, and commemorates the 80th anniversary of Schnittke’s birth, includes six concerts and one panel discussion, and will explore not only Schnittke’s works, but also those of four of his postmodernist contemporaries, Arvo Pärt, Sofia Gubaidulina, Giya Kancheli and Valentin Silvestrov.

headline: Syria Activists Say Dozens Killed in Aleppo Air Assault
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian antigovernment activist groups on Monday reported what appeared to be a major escalation of the military’s prolonged siege of Aleppo, with video and witness accounts of a helicopter gunship attack in which crews dropped explosive barrels filled with TNT and shrapnel on more than 13 rebel-held neighborhoods.

headline: Interview With an Ayatollah
text: QOM, Iran – When it comes to Iranian clerics, Grand Ayatollah Youssef Saanei has long defied convention. Over the years, he has issued edicts that uphold women’s rights. He also preaches what in this society is a reformist political line and advocates rapprochement between Iran and the United States.

headline: Budget Deal Heads for Senate Approval as More Republicans Give Support
text: WASHINGTON — Support for a compromise two-year budget deal grew ahead of a Tuesday vote in the Senate as Republicans concluded they could not allow a measure that passed the House with overwhelming bipartisan support to die in Congress’s upper chamber.

headline: Clarity Grows for Front-Runners (at Least Among Critics’ Groups)
text: This season’s multitudinous race may finally be getting some shape, as the critical and industry love add up. The Broadcast Film Critics Association, which bills itself as the largest critics group in the United States and Canada, announced its picks Monday, and members were evenly split between “American Hustle” and “12 Years a Slave,” which both earned 13 nominations, including best picture, director, actor, screenplay (original and adapted, respectively) and ensemble.

headline: Inside Arapahoe High When Gunfire Erupted
text: Brett Stewart was sitting in psychology class at Arapahoe High School in Centennial, Colo., early Friday afternoon when he heard what sounded like a heavy book drop outside the classroom door.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Dec. 10-16, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: Interpreter at Mandela Service Is Tied to Deadly ’03 Attack
text: JOHANNESBURG — The man who provided incomprehensible sign language interpretation during Nelson Mandela’s memorial service last week was part of a mob that burned two men to death in 2003, according to news reports that quoted the interpreter, some of his friends and a relative.

headline: Deployment of Missiles Is Confirmed by Russia
text: MOSCOW — Russia has deployed short-range ballistic missiles in the country’s west, a move that it contends does not violate international treaties, the Defense Ministry said Monday, though it conceivably would allow Russia to carry out a precise strike against the Baltic nations and Poland.

headline: A Gap in the Affordable Care Act
text: The Affordable Care Act mandated that insurers cover dental care for children. Indeed, it was one of the 10 essential health benefits meant to set the bar for adequate health insurance.

headline: Private Equity’s Lucrative Second Bite of a Chip Company
text: The private equity firm Silver Lake Partners is taking a second juicy bite of Avago Technologies.

headline: An Homage to Douglas Engelbart and a Critique of the State of Tech
text: Theodor Holm Nelson, who coined the term hypertext, has been a thorn in the side of the computing establishment for more than a half century. Last week, in an encomium to his friend Douglas Engelbart, he took his critique to Shakespearean levels. It deserves a wider audience.

headline: Top Candidate for a Post at Europe’s Central Bank Is a Woman
text: FRANKFURT — The decision by Jörg Asmussen to leave the European Central Bank will deprive the policy-setting body of a financial expert who had helped sell its policies to a skeptical German public, despite his occasional disagreements with Mario Draghi, the bank’s president.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Fujifilm X-M1 Camera
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Judge Questions Legality of N.S.A. Phone Records
text: WASHINGTON — A federal district judge ruled on Monday that the National Security Agency program that is systematically keeping records of all Americans’ phone calls most likely violates the Constitution, describing its technology as “almost Orwellian” and suggesting that James Madison would be “aghast” to learn that the government was encroaching on liberty in such a way.

headline: Neanderthals and the Dead
text: Early in the 20th century, two brothers discovered a nearly complete Neanderthal skeleton in a pit inside a cave at La Chapelle-aux-Saints, in southwestern France. The discovery raised the possibility that these evolutionary relatives of ours intentionally buried their dead — at least 50,000 years ago, before the arrival of anatomically modern humans in Europe.

headline: StoryCorps Names Its First Chief Executive
text: StoryCorps, the 10-year-old Brooklyn public media organization that records and collects oral histories, has named its first-ever chief executive, Robin Sparkman, currently the editor in chief of The American Lawyer magazine.

headline: A Disability, and a Mother’s Embrace
text: Rachel Adams is an Upper West Side intellectual who gave birth to a boy with Down syndrome six years ago. In this era of advanced prenatal screening, the first question more than one friend asked her was: How could this have happened?

headline: Best Foot (and Hand and Eye) Forward
text: Q. Is there a correlation among the dominant hand, dominant foot and dominant eye?

headline: Science of Squeeze, the Terrible Twos, Dental Coverage Under the Affordable Care Act
text: Scientists are squeezing elements to extraordinarily high pressures using diamonds with surprising results; one researcher traces the roots of violence back to our infant years; if you’re buying health coverage on state exchanges, take notice — dental plans for children are often sold separately.

headline: The Truth Squad Takes On ‘Llewyn’ and ‘Wolf’
text: Veracity is always an issue with films based on true stories (and a point of entry for whisper campaigns). Over at Vulture, there’s a first-person account of how accurately the Coen brothers’ “Inside Llewyn Davis” represents the folk scene in the West Village in 1961, courtesy of two women who were there: Terri Thal, the wife of Dave Van Ronk (the musician whose memoir “The Mayor of Macdougal Street” inspired some of the film); and Sylvia Topp, wife of the writer and singer Tuli Kupferberg.

headline: Credit Card Peace Offerings Bring an Outcry Instead
text: I DIDN’T get an offer of an extra $500 in credits for various airline-charge reimbursements from American Express on my American Express Platinum Card. I wasn’t offered $200, either.

headline: Three Biological Parents and a Baby
text: Alana Saarinen sat at the piano, playing smoothly and with feeling. Behind her, plastic toys shared floor space with a book of plays she’d been writing. Her mother beamed.

headline: In Thailand, Standing Up for Less Democracy
text: BANGKOK — In a world now accustomed to democratic upheavals, including the Arab Spring and the Saffron and Orange Revolutions, the weeks of political upheaval in Thailand stand out for one main peculiarity. Protesters massing on the streets here are demanding less democracy, not more.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Bernd Schneider Caps an Improbable Season
text: Bernd Schneider, a longtime driver for the Mercedes-Benz factory team, closed out a successful, but unexpected 2013 season with a victory in the Gulf 12 Hours touring car endurance race on Saturday at the Yas Marina Circuit in Abu Dhabi.

headline: In N.F.L. Case, Help in Analyzing Deal
text: The judge overseeing the proposed $765 million settlement between the N.F.L. and more than 6,000 players who sued the league for negligence and fraud has appointed a special master to help analyze the final agreement, which could be filed in days.

headline: Breathe In, Breathe Out
text: Biologists have found that savannah monitor lizards extract oxygen from the air when inhaling and when exhaling — a characteristic, known as unidirectional breathing, that is most associated with birds. The discovery of this trait in lizards, reported in the journal Nature, raises questions about when and why it evolved. Either it developed in the 270-million-year-old common ancestor of lizards, birds and alligators (which were also recently found to practice unilateral breathing) — much longer ago than originally thought — or it developed independently in each evolutionary branch. As for why it evolved, the long-held theory that it aided flight in birds appears to need updating.

headline: A Study in Forensics, Through a Favorite Sleuth
text: What would Sherlock Holmes make of “How Sherlock Changed the World,” a Tuesday night special on PBS?

headline: Herbalife Shares Jump After Re-Audit of Books
text: Updated, 5:06 p.m. | Another day has brought more bad news for William A. Ackman’s bet against Herbalife.

headline: Sex and Intimacy After the Baby Arrives
text: Sex after childbirth? In the weeks after a newborn’s arrival, it may seem as far-fetched as nightclubbing.

headline: Animal Humanity
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Climate Change Denial
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: A Lifelong Fight Against Trans Fats
text: In 1957, a fledgling nutrition scientist at the University of Illinois persuaded a hospital to give him samples of arteries from patients who had died of heart attacks.

headline: A Simple Community Health Remedy in Mali
text: Deploying community health workers to treat sick children rapidly can make an enormous difference in how many live and how many die, according to a new study done in Mali.

headline: Federal Judge’s Ruling on N.S.A. Lawsuit
text: A program to systematically keep records of all Americans’ phone calls most likely violates the Constitution, a judge ruled.

headline: President Says a Coup Failed in South Sudan
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Soldiers loyal to the former vice president of South Sudan tried to overthrow the government, President Salva Kiir said Monday, continuing the political tension that has hung over the fledgling country for months.

headline: Poaching Memories from Google’s Wandering Eye
text: In this past weekend’s issue, Adam Fisher explained Google’s ambitious plan to populate its maps with Street View images from all over the world — even the walls of the Grand Canyon, as seen from the rapids of the Colorado River. It called to mind a favorite Tumblr of mine, 9 Eyes, by the Canadian artist Jon Rafman. The blog, named for the nine cameras initially used to capture Street View images (Google has added six cameras since the project began), features enigmatic scenes taken from Rafman’s travels throughout this growing virtual universe. What follows is an edited version of our conversation.

headline: Egyptians Mock Ads Promoting New Constitution With Typos and Stock Images
text: Last Updated, Tuesday, 12:37 p.m. | A campaign to win support for a draft of Egypt’s new constitution got off to a rocky start on Sunday, one month ahead of a referendum, when observers noticed that a banner promoting the document misspelled the word for “Egyptians” in Arabic and used stock images of foreigners to stand in for representative citizens.

headline: Acura Recalls 7,400 RLX Sedans; N.H.T.S.A. Concludes Viper Investigation
text: Nearly 7,400 Acura RLX sedans from the 2014 model year will be recalled because of a rear suspension problem that can make the vehicle difficult to steer, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: The Read Around: Elizabeth Gilbert
text: In her return to fiction writing with “The Signature of All Things,” the author Elizabeth Gilbert found that the process can be familiar yet liberating from the constraints of nonfiction.

headline: Conservative Wonks, Conservative Politicians, and Recessions
text: Josh Barro has a good but incomplete post about the conservative inability to deal in any meaningful way with the reality of recessions. As he says, GOP policy prescriptions — deregulate, cut spending (especially on the poor), and cut taxes (on the rich) — are the same when unemployment is above 9 percent as when it is below 5. “How,” he asks, “can a political ideology have nothing to say about how to address recessions?”

headline: How to React to Diminishing Returns
text: The first piece of pumpkin pie is a real treat. The second piece might be good. But we may almost have to force ourselves to eat the third. Instead of enjoying it, we’re miserable. Why doesn’t the last piece taste as good as the first?

headline: In Mexico, León Is on Top
text: The culmination of the Apertura (opening) season Sunday night did not quite rise to the suspense and drama of a Mexican telenovela, but it came pretty close.

headline: The Read Around: Video of Elizabeth Gilbert
text: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Below, the author Elizabeth Gilbert, who has returned to fiction writing with “The Signature of All Things,” talks about how the process can be familiar yet liberating from the constraints of nonfiction.

headline: Should We Toss Our Vitamin Pills?
text: One in two adults takes a daily vitamin pill, and Americans spend tens of billions of dollars each year on supplements. Now, a small coterie of physicians writing in a leading medical journal has offered this blunt advice: “Stop wasting money.”

headline: Man Dies in Carjacking at Short Hills Mall; 2 Suspects Are Sought
text: For anyone who has ever felt a twinge of nervousness walking through a parking garage at night, the seemingly random act of violence was chilling: a carjacking at the Mall at Short Hills, a retail mecca for affluent suburbanites in Millburn, N.J.

headline: Truths About Grades, and the Coldest Cold on Earth
text: Just in time for finals week, some sobering news about the nature of academic performance. Two new studies from Harvard University showed that early music education classes have no discernible effect on one’s cognitive abilities, the Harvard Gazette reported.

headline: Health Expenditure Is Really Really Big (A Clarifying Note)
text: OK, for some reason I didn’t see that coming. But when I pointed out that insurers are getting ready to lay out around $500 million to promote policies via the Affordable Care Act — which I see as very good news — a fair number of readers were outraged. Insurers are spending all that money on advertising, when they should be spending it on health care!

headline: After Hours | John Waters Has Lumps of Coal for All This Christmas
text: The cult filmmaker John Waters is like that lovably abrasive uncle you only see on holidays — the one who tells the same offensive jokes year after year, a few of which are still funny enough to earn a belly laugh, or perhaps a wan smile. That’s a bit what “A John Waters Christmas” felt like Friday night at the very-far-west Stage 48, where the crowd looked like the adult version of the misfit teens who go to “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” every Friday at midnight.

headline: In Performance: Kyle Riabko
text: Kyle Riabko plays his arrangement of “Anyone Who Had a Heart,” “This Guy’s In Love With You” and “Alfie” from “What’s It All About? Bacharach Reimagined,” at New York Theater Workshop.

headline: Connecticut School’s Production of ‘Rent’ Is Back On
text: After a petition drive and social media campaign by students at Trumbull High School in Trumbull, Conn., the principal said on Monday that he was reversing himself and allowing its production of the musical “Rent” to go forward in March as originally planned. The principal, Marc Guarino, said in an interview that he and the student Thespian Society had developed ideas that satisfied his concern that the production be accompanied by an educational component.

headline: Should Gifted Students Get More Resources?
text: In a country that has always been a little uncomfortable with the idea of an educational elite, it’s tough to argue for more services for gifted students in public schools, particularly when so many districts are already starved for resources and high-quality programs. But that’s what we did on Sunday in the third installment of our editorial series on fixing math and science education, and the touchy subject produced a particularly fervent response.

headline: Volcker Rule Quickly Hits Utah Bank
text: The Volcker Rule was approved just a week ago, but it’s already forcing some banks to come clean about owning the kind of risky securities that the new regulation is intended to prevent banks from investing in.

headline: Ignore the Snow. It’s the Motorcycle Show in New York.
text: New models were in abundance when the New York stop of the Progressive International Motorcycle Show circuit opened last week.

headline: A Stellar Farro Salad From Charlie Bird
text: Could farro salad be the new couscous salad? You certainly see it often enough on menus and at fancy takeout shops to make the case. But like with its cousin couscous, farro salad can be hit or miss. Sometimes it’s a deeply flavored, multi-textured delight. Sometimes it’s dull and bland.

headline: The Big Squeeze
text: WASHINGTON — In a recurring comic bit, David Letterman used to place household items — a plate of jelly doughnuts, a six-pack of beer — in an 80-ton hydraulic press, gleefully watching as the items squirted, exploded and disintegrated.

headline: No Plot, Just Poetry in a Gauzy Landscape
text: When the German choreographer Pina Bausch died in 2009, a wave of melancholy fell over the New York dance world: even though her company is based in Wuppertal, it was a fixture at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Yet her ties to the city ran even deeper, since she had also studied at the Juilliard School.

headline: Terrible Twos Who Stay Terrible
text: To understand the violent criminal, says Richard E. Tremblay, imagine a 2-year-old boy doing the things that make the terrible twos terrible — grabbing, kicking, pushing, punching, biting.

headline: Bacon’s Triptych to Be Shown at Portland Art Museum
text: The Portland Art Museum in Oregon announced on Monday afternoon that the world’s most expensive painting ever sold at auction — Francis Bacon’s triptych “Three Studies of Lucian Freud” — which brought $142.4 million at Christie’s in November, will be on view there from Dec. 21 through March 30th.

headline: Former Top Goldman Executive to Run Cushman & Wakefield
text: Edward C. Forst, a former co-head of Goldman Sachs’s investment management division who twice stepped down from top roles at the company, has agreed to join Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate giant, as its president and chief executive.

headline: Amid Tortures Of the Flesh, A Naïve Crush
text: Hallelujah! Who knew that the Austrian filmmaker Ulrich Seidl actually has a heart? You might not have guessed that if all you have seen of his work are his punishing examinations of bourgeois Austrian life, “Dog Days” (2001) and the first two parts of his “Paradise” trilogy, released this year.

headline: No Finger-Pointing on Metro-North Crash at M.T.A. Meeting
text: Two weeks after a fatal Metro-North Railroad derailment in the Bronx, board members from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Monday gathered for their first public meeting since the crash, discussing safety features that had been missing from the railroad but refraining from any direct criticism of its leadership.

headline: Pictures of the Day: North Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photos from North Korea, Ukraine, Brazil and the Central African Republic.

headline: Saving Kindle Notes Online, and Cleaning an LCD Screen
text: Saving Kindle Notes

headline: Shock but No Awe in ‘Homeland’ Season’s End
text: The hero of “Homeland” did not cheat death.

headline: Buddhists With Issues and Hopes of Nirvana
text: In his unsettling new novel, Bruce Wagner exchanges his usual stomping ground of Hollywood for Big Sur and India, and at first glance this world of Buddhists, gurus and spiritual pilgrims might seem light-years removed from the Los Angeles of depravity, delusion and greed he depicted in his last book, “Dead Stars” (2012).

headline: Times Minute | Watching North Korea
text: Also on the Minute, artifacts from closed churches find new life and discovering the color of pressure.

headline: Times Minute | Watching North Korea
Today’s Scuttlebot: Lego Stop-Motion of an Old Mac, and Twitter’s Male-Dominated Flub
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Two Saudi Prisoners Sent Home From Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON — Two Saudi men held by the United States without trial for nearly 12 years at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, have been repatriated, the Pentagon said Monday.

headline: Leaping In and Out of an Origami World
text: Some music is made for violin and unimaginable for trumpet. Other pieces are best on piano, worst on drums. Some video games are also like this, designed particularly for a particular instrument. An oddity called Tearaway, recently released by the British studio Media Molecule, is one such game. It enjoys the fortune and suffers the misfortune of being perfect for the unorthodox and not very popular hand-held PlayStation Vita.

headline: A Struggle to Balance Wind Energy With Wildlife
text: DENVER — As the Obama administration seeks to clear a path for more renewable energy projects, it has increasingly found itself caught between two staunch allies: the wind energy industry and environmental organizations.

headline: Artifacts | It’s Marina Abramovic’s World, Willem Dafoe’s Just Living In It
text: The theater director Robert Wilson is best known for his stunning stage pictures, gorgeous lighting and lengthy evenings. The latest of his productions to hit New York is “The Life and Death of Marina Abramovic,” a biography of the performance artist that takes its narrator, played to the hilt by Willem Dafoe, a mere two hours and forty minutes to unpack.

headline: After 45 Years, as Incendiary as Ever
text: Perhaps “White Light/White Heat” can’t be the surprise it was when it arrived in 1968. The second album by the Velvet Underground, “White Light/White Heat” has been canonized, analyzed, annotated, emulated and contextualized as a cornerstone of punk and experimental rock. Generations of listeners have been aware of the insistent, relentless drone of its extended songs, the outbursts of scrabbling dissonance and earsplitting distortion from Lou Reed’s lead guitar, the equally insistent presence of John Cale’s electric viola and keyboards, the deadpan tales of drugs and sex and death in Mr. Reed’s lyrics and the pithy drive, amid the cacophony, of Sterling Morrison’s rhythm guitar and Maureen Tucker’s steadfast drums.

headline: Flair, Intensity and Drama Circle Back a Quarter-Century Later
text: By her New York recital debut at Carnegie Hall in 1988, the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter, then 25, had evolved from teenage phenom to mature, adventurous artist. Earlier that year, she had demonstrated her burgeoning interest in contemporary music and her already formidable influence, requesting — and getting — from the eminent composer Witold Lutoslawski a version for violin and orchestra of his 1984 Partita for Violin and Piano.

headline: Striking Miners, and Children Who Paid the Price
text: This has been a year of notable 50th anniversaries, but time didn’t begin in 1963. A sorrowful PBS documentary on Tuesday night notes the 100th anniversary of an event forgotten by much of the country but not by the people of Michigan’s Upper Peninsula: a miners’ strike that led to a catastrophic stampede in which 73 people died, most of them children.

headline: Customers Out in the Cold Balk at Uber Surge Pricing
text: On New Year’s Eve 2011, Uber, a company that connects passengers and drivers of luxury vehicles, had a bit of a falling-out with its customers.

headline: A New Preamble Before the Big Show
text: WASHINGTON — Before we explore the problems with the permanent exhibition that opened this month at the National Archives here, it might help to recognize the challenges it faced. The exhibition, “Records of Rights,” is the first attraction you see after passing through the building’s new marble-clad entrance. It is meant to prepare a million visitors a year for what awaits them above, in the dimly lit Rotunda: original copies of the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and the Bill of Rights — founding documents with such a sacral stature, they are viewed in near silence. What kind of exhibition could possibly serve as preamble?

headline: New Era Passer and Old-School Coach
text: While some coaches who have recently moved up from the college ranks have excelled with athletic quarterbacks, Washington's Mike Shanahan has struggled with Robert Griffin III.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: New Era Passer and Old-School Coach
text: While some coaches who have recently moved up from the college ranks have excelled with athletic quarterbacks, Washington’s Mike Shanahan has struggled with Robert Griffin III.

headline: Glaxo Says It Will Stop Paying Doctors to Promote Drugs
text: The British drug maker GlaxoSmithKline will no longer pay doctors to promote its products and will stop tying compensation of sales representatives to the number of prescriptions doctors write, its chief executive said Monday, effectively ending two common industry practices that critics have long assailed as troublesome conflicts of interest.

headline: Study Links Autism and Somalis in Minneapolis
text: A long-awaited study has confirmed the fears of Somali residents in Minneapolis that their children suffer from higher rates of a disabling form of autism compared with other children there.

headline: Dinosaurs and Statistics
text: A new paper highlights possible statistical problems in a series of papers on dinosaur growth rates.

headline: A Hobbyist Challenges Papers on Growth of Dinosaurs
text: A dinosaur hobbyist who made his name as a Microsoft multimillionaire published a scientific paper on Monday alleging “serious errors and irregularities” in dinosaur research involving some of the world’s top paleontologists.

headline: Time Is Up for High-Security Wine Cellar Hit by Hurricane, Judge Rules
text: The wealthy clients of a troubled high-security wine storage cellar in West Chelsea will not be getting back their 27,000 cases of valuable wine in time for the holidays.

headline: Online Courses: High Hopes, Trimmed
Wellesley in China
K.K.R. to Buy Debt-Trading Affiliate for $2.6 Billion
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Monday that it planned to buy a publicly traded credit investment affiliate for about $2.6 billion as it seeks to simplify its corporate structure while expanding its balance sheet.

headline: A U.S. Truth Commission
India: Ex-Official Released on Bail
text: Lalu Prasad, a once-powerful political leader from northern India, emerged from jail on Monday after spending more than two months behind bars on corruption charges. Mr. Prasad, a former chief minister of Bihar, was convicted in October of participating in a scheme in which false receipts were used to siphon more than $6 million in public funds from a program meant for animal husbandry. He was sentenced to five years in jail. But the Supreme Court granted him bail on Friday after noting that most of those convicted with Mr. Prasad in the case had already been freed while their appeals were considered. Such appeals often take many years to be decided. When he emerged from jail on Monday, Mr. Prasad pronounced it a fine place for politicians. “Jail is the birthplace of Lord Krishna,” Mr. Prasad said. “I was never unhappy in jail.”

headline: Benefits Questioned in Tax Breaks for Nonprofit Hospitals
text: The billions of dollars in tax breaks granted to the nation’s nonprofit hospitals are being challenged by regulators and politicians as cities still reeling from the recession watch cash-rich medical centers expand.

headline: When ‘Sorry’ Means Never Having to Say ...
A Late Note, Improvised
text: To the Editor:

headline: What About Bisexual Men?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Redevelopment Plan Is Considered for Long Island College Hospital
text: Long Island College Hospital, which became a symbol of New York City’s struggling community hospitals during the mayoral race, is considering an offer to redevelop the property to include condominiums and an urgent care center.

headline: Bad Move on Immigration
Russia: 4 Die in North Caucasus Raid
text: Members of Russia’s security services killed four men suspected of being militants on Monday when they stormed an apartment building after a tense overnight standoff in the North Caucasus region, where Russia is trying to stamp out an insurgency. In a statement, the government’s National Antiterrorism Committee said that heavily armed troops supported by armored vehicles surrounded the building in the village of Bedyk in the republic of Kabardino-Balkaria on Sunday evening, acting on a tip that armed men were inside. A woman and a child left the house during the negotiations, but the men refused to surrender, officials said. Troops assaulted the building early Monday morning, killing all four men inside, including the group’s leader, Arsen Khandokhov. The Federal Security Service said that Mr. Khandokhov and his group were behind more than 20 terrorist attacks, including the murder of two tourists in the region in 2010.

headline: G.M. to Invest $1.3 Billion to Upgrade 5 Midwest Factories
text: DETROIT — After a year of big profits and surging sales in the United States, the American automakers are investing heavily in their domestic operations in anticipation of more good times to come.

headline: Ray Price, Groundbreaking, Hit-Making Country Singer, Dies at 87
text: Ray Price, who was at the forefront of two revolutions in country music as one of its finest ballad singers and biggest hit makers, died on Monday at his home in Mount Pleasant, Tex. He was 87.

headline: Apple Says ‘Beyoncé’ Set a Record on iTunes
text: Beyoncé’s surprise album release last week was celebrated by some commentators as a herald of things to come in the music industry, and dismissed by others as a mere stunt. But by sheer sales numbers, it was an unqualified success.

headline: S.E.C. Calls for Stiff Penalties Against Tourre
text: Four months after being found liable for defrauding investors in a soured mortgage deal, Fabrice Tourre now faces a stiff financial penalty for his actions.

headline: Travel to Far-Flung Places Spurs Private Jet Growth
text: The destinations read like the world map in the game Risk — Irkutsk, Mongolia, Madagascar.

headline: Tom Laughlin, 82, Star of ‘Billy Jack’ Movie Series, Dies
text: Tom Laughlin, the actor, writer, director and producer who created the “Billy Jack” movie series of the 1970s, a low-budget fusion of counterculture piety and martial-arts violence that struck a chord with audiences and became a prototype for independent filmmaking and distribution, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 82.

headline: A Transgender Volunteer for the Salvation Army
text: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — I GOT to the Waterville mall a few minutes early. My shift began at 11, and snow was falling from a pewter sky onto the parking lot. I’d been having a hard time. This was about four Christmases ago, a few years after I’d come out as transgender. In the aftermath of that unveiling, I’d lost a couple of important friendships. Getting into the spirit of the season had been a struggle.

headline: Getting Off to a Harmonious Start in Hong Kong
text: I GRADUATED from college on a Friday, started work that following Monday, and three weeks later my boss told me I was going to Europe on a business trip to sell tennis broadcast rights. I was 22 years old and I thought going on a business trip was great since I loved to travel. That was nearly 30 years ago.

headline: After a Posting Deal, Questions on a Pitcher
text: The new posting agreement between Major League Baseball and Nippon Professional Baseball was completed Monday when the executive committees of both leagues ratified the deal, perhaps paving the way for the right-handed pitcher Masahiro Tanaka, the most prized Japanese player since Yu Darvish two years ago, to finally be posted.

headline: Upon This Burger
text: LOS ANGELES — Just five years ago, Adam Fleischman was in a two-bedroom rental with his wife and their year-old son, fumbling around for a career that might stick. Screenwriting hadn’t worked out. Same for finance. He was 38 and, he told me, “It was do or die.”

headline: The Thought Leader
text: Little boys and girls in ancient Athens grew up wanting to be philosophers. In Renaissance Florence they dreamed of becoming Humanists. But now a new phrase and a new intellectual paragon has emerged to command our admiration: The Thought Leader.

headline: USEC, Enricher of Uranium for U.S., Seeks Bankruptcy
text: WASHINGTON — USEC, the sole American company in the uranium enrichment business, said Monday that it would file for bankruptcy early next year, although it hopes to keep operating.

headline: Muirhead and Britain Are Pushing for an Olympic Medal in Sochi
text: STIRLING, Scotland — It is a sight as arresting as any in winter sports: Eve Muirhead gliding metronomically across the curling sheet,  up to — and beyond — the moment when she releases the stone toward its target 150 feet away.

headline: Big Bonuses, but a Shift in Who Gets the Biggest
text: Wall Street’s senior executives have been holed up in conference rooms across Manhattan the last couple of weeks, locked in tense all-day sessions. The special project: dividing up this year’s spoils as bonus season approaches.

headline: Aid Challenge in Syria Mounts for U.N. Official
text: UNITED NATIONS — Valerie Amos, the top United Nations official responsible for easing the Syrian conflict’s humanitarian crisis, has made five visits to the country since early 2012 and has developed a cordial working relationship with Syrian relief officials.

headline: ‘What Is Good Teaching?’
text: In 2006, an idealistic New York public schoolteacher named Kevin Greer joined the faculty of an idealistic new high school, Brooklyn Community Arts and Media. Greer had previously taught English to 12th grade honors students at Dewitt Clinton, a huge high school in the Bronx. At B.C.A.M., which hoped to inspire students with an arts-driven curriculum, he would be teaching ninth graders. Most of the students had not chosen B.C.A.M., but had simply been assigned to the school. They weren’t nearly as self-motivated as Greer’s former students. Many if not most of them read below grade level.

headline: Secrets and Contradictions
text: I know a compelling character when I encounter her on the page. Her simplicity betrays an enigmatic complexity, and her known qualities suggest unknown ones. She possesses the one thing I want most from a character: the power to make me want to know more about her.

headline: Brooklyn’s Next Prosecutor Protests $286,000 Payment to Hynes Deputy
text: Brushing aside the objections of the man who made him an electoral lame duck, Charles J. Hynes, the departing Brooklyn district attorney, announced on Monday that he would pay his retiring top deputy almost $286,000 in unused vacation pay, or almost $100,000 more than what a typical city employee could be entitled to.

headline: One White House Shift Is Delayed for a Month
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will soon name a new overseer to complete repairs of the government’s health insurance website, but the current manager, Jeffrey D. Zients, is delaying his move to become chief White House economic adviser for about a month, administration officials said Monday.

headline: Seinfeld’s Deliberately Inept Web Campaign for Acura
text: IN “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee,” a web series introduced in 2012, Jerry Seinfeld borrows a vintage car like a Lamborghini or Jaguar and picks up fellow comics for a drive to a diner or coffee shop, with in-car and roving cameras capturing their conversations about stand-up comedy and show business. But for a new season that begins Jan. 2, it’s not just cars that Mr. Seinfeld is steering — he also wrote a series of commercials for the show’s sole sponsor, Acura.

headline: Many Detect End of Line for Stimulus by the Fed
text: WASHINGTON — The beginning of the end probably will not come on Wednesday, but it is coming soon. The Federal Reserve has made clear that its bond-buying campaign will not continue at the present pace for much longer.

headline: E.U. Pledges Aid for Mideast Peace
text: The European Union will provide “an unprecedented package of European political, economic and security support” to the Israelis and Palestinians if they reach a permanent peace deal, the union said in a statement on Monday after a foreign affairs council meeting in Brussels. The package will offer Israel and the future Palestinian state a special privileged partnership, including increased access to the European markets, closer cultural and scientific links, facilitation of trade and investments as well as promotion of business-to-business relations, the statement added. The European Union also condemned continued Israeli settlement construction and expressed concern over incitement and episodes of violence, actions it said undermined peace negotiations. Secretary of State John Kerry brokered a resumption of Israeli-Palestinian talks in July after years of stagnation.

headline: Playing With Abandon May Have Exacted Toll
text: A special Mass at a Roman Catholic church on Sunday in Jacksonville, Fla., was planned as a remembrance for Ryan Freel, a former major leaguer who committed suicide nearly one year ago at 36. It became more than that, however, after Freel’s family had learned four days earlier of a factor that might have precipitated his death on Dec. 22, 2012.

headline: A Powerful Rebuke of Mass Surveillance
text: For the first time since the revelation of the National Security Agency’s vast dragnet of all Americans’ telephone records, a federal court has ruled that such surveillance is “significantly likely” to be unconstitutional.

headline: The Next Chapter for Derivatives Regulation
text: Under the Dodd-Frank financial reform law, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, a five-member panel of three Democrats and two Republicans, has an all-important role in regulating the multitrillion-dollar market in derivatives.

headline: Insider Trading Trial of Former SAC Manager Goes to the Jury
text: The fate of a former top trader for the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors will soon hinge on whether or not jurors believe the government’s star witness, a technology analyst who has pleaded guilty to insider trading.

headline: Intersection: San Francisco’s Mission
text: In the Mission District, Jai Carrillo, a hairstylist, said his personal style was “kind of like if the ‘Golden Girls’ ran into Vivienne Westwood.”

headline: Discrimination in Sochi
text: While Vladimir Putin turns Russia into an increasingly dangerous place for gays and lesbians, the Winter Olympics in the Russian resort city of Sochi will soon begin drawing athletes and fans from around the world. There will certainly be gay athletes. And there will be thousands of spectators who come from countries where it is not a crime to love someone of the same sex.

headline: Cornered by Accusations, Christie Parries With Jokes and Stonewalls With Snarls
text: Gov. Chris Christie is a wonderfully primal New Jersey politician who embraces three truths: Transparency is for squares, bluster is your friend and fingerprints are a pain.

headline: Study Raises Questions About Antibleeding Drug
text: Horses treated with the race-day antibleeding medication furosemide bled at a greater rate than horses that did not receive the drug, a study released by the Breeders’ Cup on Monday found.

headline: Pope Replaces Conservative U.S. Cardinal on Influential Vatican Committee
text: ROME — Pope Francis moved on Monday against a conservative American cardinal who has been an outspoken critic of abortion and same-sex marriage, by replacing him on a powerful Vatican committee with another American who is less identified with the culture wars within the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Prison for Rhode Island Lawyer in Tale of Insurance and Death
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Joseph Caramadre contends he was a philanthropist and a clever lawyer, offering $2,000 payments to people who were dying. The United States attorney contends that he was a scam artist, preying on the very ill and getting rich by defrauding insurance companies.

headline: Bloomberg Focuses on His Legacy in Farewell Tour Across the City
text: With 15 days left in office, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is focused on his legacy.

headline: Finding Classroom Rigor in a Global Curriculum
text: Should more U.S. high schools offer International Baccalaureate programs?

headline: U.S.-Germany Intelligence Partnership Falters Over Spying
text: BERLIN — Nearly two months after President Obama assured Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany that the United States would never again target her cellphone, a broader effort to build a new intelligence relationship with Germany is floundering, with each side increasingly reluctant to make major changes in how it deals with the other.

headline: Knicks’ Smith and Shumpert Become Question Marks
text: The Knicks were undefeated when Coach Mike Woodson declared an open competition between Iman Shumpert and J. R. Smith for a spot in the starting lineup. Optimism was running high. Neither player had missed a shot.

headline: Federal Consumer Agency Sues Over Online Loans
text: It sounds like something from a movie: A $10,000 loan with an annual interest rate of nearly 90 percent, that costs more than $60,000 to repay.

headline: Bolivian Jail, an Actor’s Help and Now a Return to New York
text: A Brooklyn flooring contractor and father of five, who was jailed in Bolivia for 18 months until the intervention of the actor Sean Penn lessened his punishment to confinement under house arrest, has been spirited out of the country and is in the New York area, according to Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn.

headline: Judge Has Record of Wrestling With Thorny Issues, and the U.S. Government
text: WASHINGTON — Judge Richard J. Leon, who shook up Washington on Monday by declaring a National Security Agency data collection program “almost Orwellian,” is a conservative and a vivid writer who does not shrink from criticizing the federal government on matters as varied as pornography, death penalty drugs and terrorism suspects at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: New York Archdiocese Wins Ruling on Contraception
text: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was granted a federal injunction on Monday that blocks an Obama administration requirement to provide contraceptive care to employees at its nonprofit affiliates.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 17, 2013
text: “I cannot imagine a more ‘indiscriminate’ and ‘arbitrary’ invasion than this systematic and high-tech collection and retention of personal data on virtually every single citizen for purposes of querying and analyzing it without prior judicial approval.”

headline: Senate Confirms New Homeland Security Chief
text: The Senate on Monday evening confirmed Jeh C. Johnson as President Obama’s secretary of homeland security.

headline: Facing Suit, New York City Agrees to Remove Mold in Public Housing More Quickly
text: The New York City Housing Authority will deal more quickly and more thoroughly with mold in its apartments as part of an agreement by the Bloomberg administration to settle a federal lawsuit by people living in housing projects and coping with asthma.

headline: After Postgame Recriminations, the Giants Set a Conciliatory Tone
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — One day after emotions spilled over following the Giants’ 23-0 dismantling by the Seattle Seahawks, Coach Tom Coughlin brought his open hands closer together Monday in describing a time of “healing” for a team that appears to be in danger of fragmenting.

headline: Obama’s Library, Advisers’ Dream
text: WASHINGTON — This spring, a longtime staff member for President Obama, Alyssa Mastromonaco, let a friend in on a secret. Mr. Obama had assigned her to begin planning his post-presidential library and foundation.

headline: Ryan Thinks He’s the Man for the Job, but Does Idzik?
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Rex Ryan was asked a few questions Monday about some pivotal moments in the Jets’ 30-20 defeat a day earlier at Carolina, and so he addressed the screen pass that devolved into a long Panthers touchdown and the blocked punt that sent his team careening toward a third straight season without a playoff berth. He did not seem to mind, either, even though these questions were posed more out of obligation than curiosity.

headline: After Escaping Slaughter in Rwanda, a Deep Instinct to Survive
text: Epiphanie Musabiyemaria still does not know whether she is a Hutu or a Tutsi.

text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I will confess that I don’t know much about professional or even college basketball, and if you don’t either, do not fear; this will not interfere with your ability to solve Paula Gamache’s Tuesday puzzle.

headline: Secret Bids Guide Hopi Indians’ Spirits Home
text: The auction in Paris was set to move briskly, at about two items a minute; the room was hot and crowded, buzzing with reporters.

headline: Still Undecided on Fracking, Cuomo Won’t Press for Health Study’s Release
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made clear on Monday what has become increasingly obvious to both supporters and opponents of fracking: He is in no rush to make a decision.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 16, 2013
For Lindsay, a Rare Monument to a New York Mayor
text: A year ago Edward I. Koch got his bridge over the East River. On Monday, John V. Lindsay got the Lower Loop drive in Central Park. Maybe not as grand as a bridge, but still better than what has been accorded most of New York City’s other 20th-century mayors, who have gotten a helping hand into obscurity by being denied any physical monument to their legacy.

headline: Hugh Nissenson, Who Pushed the Novel’s Boundaries, Dies at 80
text: Hugh Nissenson, an author who was praised for creating convincing alternative worlds in books that pursued questions of faith and pressed the boundaries of the novelistic form, died on Dec. 13 at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: Unease as an Opposition Party Stands Out in Ukraine’s Protests
text: KIEV, Ukraine — As he strode onto the stage at Independence Square to the cheers of tens of thousands of protesters, Oleg Tyagnibok, the leader of the Ukrainian nationalist party Svoboda, punched a fist into the air and shouted “Glory to Ukraine!” and a roar came back: “Glory to its heroes!”

headline: Bruins’ Thornton Appeals 15-Game Suspension for On-Ice Attack
text: Boston Bruins forward Shawn Thornton is appealing the 15-game suspension given him by the N.H.L. Department of Player Safety on Saturday for attacking and injuring Pittsburgh Penguins defenseman Brooks Orpik.

headline: Rocky Start in Promoting New Charter for Egypt
text: A campaign to win support for Egypt’s draft Constitution got off to an awkward start in Cairo on Sunday when observers noted several errors on a large banner promoting what is intended to become the nation’s charter and a fundamental expression of Egypt’s identity.

headline: Johnson’s 10 3-Pointers Propel the Nets to a Rout of the 76ers
text: There were 28 seconds remaining in the third quarter Monday night when Joe Johnson found himself with the ball in front of the visitors’ bench at Barclays Center. James Anderson of the Philadelphia 76ers had smothered him into the corner, behind the 3-point line, but Johnson rose and flung up a shot anyway.

headline: A Political Deal in a Deeply Divided Tunisia as Islamists Agree to Yield Power
text: TUNIS — Compromise has been in short supply since Tunisia sparked the Arab Spring nearly three years ago. But this small North African nation has once again broken new ground with a political deal between longtime enemies among the Islamists and the secular old guard.

headline: At End, Knicks Fail to Stop Beal and to Stop the Clock
text: The final seven seconds at Madison Square Garden on Monday could be rewound over and over again — back from the point Carmelo Anthony threw his headband in disgust — and remain just as mystifying and incomprehensible.

headline: Growth Spurt Creates Alarm Over the House of (Many) Lords
text: LONDON — It seems unlikely that the members of the House of Lords would refer to their assembly as the world’s greatest deliberative body, as United States senators do, or used to anyway. The British are more given to self-deprecation. But there is a superlative that does apply, one that Britain’s politicians have been trying to shed: the world’s largest legislative body outside China, and growing.

headline: Paying Tribute to the Mad Genius of Buckminster Fuller
text: For most architecture aficionados, the name Buckminster Fuller conjures a single structure: the geodesic dome. The geometrically complex sphere, composed of a grid of triangles, may be Fuller’s most famous invention, but the late visionary dedicated himself to solving many of the world’s most vexing design problems, including affordable housing, efficient transportation and ecological preservation. While more than 300,000 geodesic domes have been built according to his plans, Fuller was far more prolific, producing 28 patents in total and publishing 28 books.

headline: Who Pays the Taxes and Gets the Benefits
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Nirvana to Join Rock Hall of Fame, Alongside Kiss, at Barclays Center

headline: The Beatles’ ‘I Want to Hold Your Hand,’ Then Al Green’s
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the  website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Rodman Headed to North Korea Again Despite Turmoil
text: Dennis Rodman’s trip to North Korea to help train the country’s basketball stars has not been disrupted by the political convulsions there, notably the execution of the leader’s uncle last week for treason and debauchery, the Irish online betting company sponsoring the visit said Tuesday.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 11:30 A.M. (MoreMax) ANNA KARENINA (2012) Keira Knightley (above) stars as Anna, the bored wife of a virtuous government official (Jude Law) in mid-19th-century Imperial Russia, who travels from St. Petersburg to Moscow to calm a marital storm in the household of her philandering brother (Matthew Macfadyen) in Joe Wright’s stagy adaptation of this Tolstoy novel. Aaron Taylor-Johnson plays the man who captures her heart: Count Vronsky, a young military officer with the eyes of a poet and a domineering mother (Olivia Williams). And Alicia Vikander is Kitty, a lovely young woman adored by Levin, the gloomy rural landowner (Domhnall Gleeson) widely understood to be Tolstoy’s alter ego, whose idea of love — an ennobling union of souls — is a rebuke to the amorality festering in cities. “I assume you know that it ends badly, but Mr. Wright’s real interest, like Tolstoy’s, is in everything that happens in between Anna’s first meeting with Vronsky and her final encounter with the wheels of a train,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. And while Mr. Wright’s screen versions of Jane Austen’s “Pride and Prejudice” and Ian McEwan’s “Atonement” “remain trapped in literariness,” he added, “Mr. Wright’s ‘Anna Karenina’ is different. It is risky and ambitious enough to count as an act of artistic hubris, and confident enough to triumph on its own slightly — wonderfully — crazy terms. Pious Tolstoyans may knit their brows about the stylistic liberties Mr. Wright and the screenwriter, Tom Stoppard, have taken, but surely Tolstoy can withstand (and may indeed benefit from) their playful, passionate rendering of his masterpiece.” Jacqueline Durran won an Oscar for costume design.

headline: Where Dance and Textiles Meet
text: This “Dance of the Weave” book project — documenting the interplay of dancers and the myriad hues, textures, drapes and moods of their costumes — began as a collaboration with Upasana, a design studio near Pondicherry that works with handloom weavers.

headline: Rural Women Stage Innovative Protest for Equality
text: The middle-aged farming women forming a human pyramid in front of the Zhejiang Provincial People’s Government headquarters in Hangzhou last week constituted a small protest that pointed to a big problem: persistent economic and political discrimination against women in rural China, they said.

headline: Amid China’s Bad Air, a Reminder That Smoking Still Kills
text: As the recognition of the danger of outdoor air pollution in China grows, health authorities are trying to use that knowledge to raise awareness of an even deadlier health threat: smoking. China has about 350 million smokers, and despite efforts to reduce consumption, tobacco is still widely consumed, and about half of adult males are regular smokers, according to surveys.

headline: Radio Station for Gay Indians Faces Uphill Battle to Draw Listeners
text: BANGALORE – Now that the Supreme Court has ruled that the Indian law against homosexuality cannot be overturned except by Parliament, gay sex is illegal once again, making it that much harder for young gay, lesbian and transgender Indians to identify themselves as such.

headline: Chinese Account Says U.S. Ship Was Warned Away From Aircraft Carrier
text: A Chinese ship warned an American guided missile cruiser to move away from China’s aircraft carrier in the South China Sea on Dec. 5, according to a Chinese account that confirms many of the elements of the incident as described by the United States Navy this week.

headline: No-Frills Car With Romanian Lineage Is Hottest in Europe
text: PARIS — The hottest car in Europe this year was not a BMW, a Benz or a Bentley. It was Renault’s low-cost brand, Dacia, out of Romania.

headline: Ants That Can Flow Like a Fluid, or Move Like a Solid
text: Fire ants, those stinging pests that are all too familiar to Southerners, have gotten plenty of attention from scientists — but not from physicists.

headline: Supersize My Wage
text: About 20 years ago, in the midst of a recession, New Jersey decided to boost its minimum wage to $5.05 an hour from $4.25. Its neighbor to the west, Pennsylvania, chose not to tinker with its wage floor. Two bright young economists at Princeton, David Card and Alan B. Krueger, recognized in that dull occurrence a promising natural experiment.

headline: Illuminating a Central African Crisis, Photo by Photo
text: When mostly Christian militias loyal to the ousted president launched an attack on the Central African Republic’s capital, Bangui, on the morning of Dec. 5, the Associated Press photographer Jerome Delay was in his hotel. Cut off from his driver because of the fighting, Mr. Delay walked and caught rides from pro-government forces instead.

text: A Federal District Court judge ruled on Monday that the National Security Agency program that is systematically keeping records of all Americans’ phone calls most likely violates the Constitution, and he ordered the government to stop collecting data on two plaintiffs’ personal calls and destroy the records of their calling history, Charlie Savage reports.

text: BERLIN — German lawmakers have elected Angela Merkel to lead a coalition government, marking her third term as chancellor at a time when Germany faces an array of economic and political challenges at home and abroad.

headline: Tactical Obfuscation
text: JERUSALEM — President Barack Obama, speaking earlier this month at the Brookings Institution’s Saban Center for Middle East Policy in Washington, described the two countries’ “different tactical perspectives.” Similarly, Secretary of State John Kerry has said: “While we may sometimes favor a different tactical choice — tactical — the United States and Israel have always shared the same fundamental strategic goal.” And that common goal, according to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, is “making sure that Iran doesn’t have nuclear weapons.”

headline: Britain Warns Syria After Report of Imprisoned Doctor’s Death
text: LONDON — Britain warned Syria on Tuesday that it would hold the government of President Bashar al-Assad responsible if a British surgeon incarcerated for more than a year for treating civilians in the Syrian civil war had died mysteriously in prison, as his family asserted.

headline: How I Found Love and Companionship Online
text: I am in my late 50s and should be a better shopper by now. But the word “sale” still seduces me and although men are not exactly on sale on Match.com they are, in effect, for sale. Match.com is ubiquitous with millions of registered singles and although it is easy to weed out the ones with certain politics, geographical areas, and the ones who have been on Match.com for years, I am easily seduced by a reasonable photo and a humorous profile.

headline: Instagram Direct and the Fracturing of Privacy
text: Last Thursday, Kevin Systrom invited members of the press to a fashionably shabby loft in Manhattan to introduce a new messaging service called Instagram Direct.

headline: In Performance: Kyle Riabko of ‘What’s It All About? Bacharach Reimagined’
text: “What’s It All About? Bacharach Reimagined” is a new revue devoted to the music of the composer Burt Bacharach and the lyricist Hal David. The production features musical arrangements by the 26-year-old singer Kyle Riabko, who also stars in the show. In this scene Mr. Riabko plays his arrangement of the songs “Anyone Who Had a Heart,” “This Guy’s In Love With You” and “Alfie.”

headline: The Stranger in the Story
text: Doing holiday duty on Thanksgiving — when breaking news can be hard to find — reminded me just how often our feature and enterprise stories rely on that old journalistic staple, the anecdotal lead. It seemed that practically every story discussed for the front page started out by introducing me, by name, to some stranger whose connection to the point of the article would emerge only with time and patience.

headline: Calls Grow Louder for Human Rights Chairman to Resign After Harassment Complaint
text: NEW DELHI — Lawmakers in the Rajya Sabha, the upper house of Parliament, joined women’s rights groups on Tuesday in calling for the resignation of the West Bengal Human Rights Commission chairman, who is accused of sexually harassing a law intern last year.
