headline: Amid Chinese Rivalry, Japan Seeks More Muscle
text: TOKYO — Taking Japan a step further from its postwar pacifism, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe approved a new five-year defense plan on Tuesday that calls for the acquisition of drones and amphibious assault vehicles to strengthen the nation’s military as it faces the prospect of a prolonged rivalry with China over islands in the East China Sea.

headline: How Medicare Subsidizes Doctor Training
text: My Economic View column on Sunday looked at medical residencies, the biggest bottleneck in the supply chain for doctors. Most of this “graduate medical education” training is subsidized by Medicare, for somewhat strange historical reasons sustained by both legislative inertia and the stakeholders who benefit from it. Here’s some detail about how the subsidies work.

headline: Contractors and Workers at Odds Over Scaffold Law
text: In 1885, as new engineering inventions were ushering in the era of the skyscraper, lawmakers in New York State enacted a law intended to safeguard construction workers who were finding themselves facing increasing dangers while working at ever-greater heights.

headline: U.S. Forging Closer Military Ties With Philippines
text: MANILA — Secretary of State John Kerry said here on Tuesday that the United States would give the Philippines $40 million in maritime security assistance and was negotiating with Manila to rotate more American military forces through the country, the latest signs of the Obama administration’s concerns about mounting pressure from China on its neighbors.

headline: ScienceTake: The Physics of Ants
text: They can flow like a liquid and bounce back like a solid. Masses of fire ants show a duality that intrigues physicists.

headline: Your Postcards From Our Places to Go in 2013
text: We gave you a list of spots to visit — and you hit many of them. Here are some of our favorite photos from those trips.

headline: Next Year’s Screenplay Nominees?
text: Among the tightest contests in this season’s highly competitive Oscar race are the screenplay categories. For original stories, will the Academy favor ones based on fact, like “American Hustle,” “Inside Llewyn Davis” and “Dallas Buyers Club,” or wholly invented cinema, like the romance “Her”? On the adapted side, will voters go with historical epics like “12 Years a Slave” or reward long character arcs, as in “Before Midnight”? The Bagger will investigate, ponder and pontificate.

headline: 1913: Toys For Christmas Are Marked by Grotesqueness
text: LONDON — “A Merry Christmas!” The year has passed so rapidly, a year so crowded with so many notable events, historical, political, social, tragical, that one can hardly realize that the season which is supposed to bring with it “peace on earth” is so near. But there it is; “A Merry Christmas!” in flaming electrically illuminated crystal device in front of Gamage’s, the greatest of London’s toy emporiums, and the delight of the children returning home from school for the Christmas holidays.

headline: Senate Ends Budget Debate, Clearing Way for Passage
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan tax-and-spending plan designed to bring some normalcy to Congress’s budgeting after three years of chaos cleared its final hurdle on Tuesday when 67 senators voted to end debate on the measure and bring it to a final vote before it goes to President Obama for his signature.

headline: Japan Star in Demand but Also in Limbo
text: In the battle for Japanese stars, Major League Baseball got its way this week when it persuaded Nippon Professional Baseball to accept a $20 million cap on compensation paid to Japanese teams whose players leave for the United States before they become free agents.

headline: Bob Dylan: Musician or Poet?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Dana Stevens and Francine Prose discuss whether Bob Dylan’s lyrics make him more poet than musician.

headline: Philip Glass and Tyondai Braxton Join a Benefit for the Philippines
text: The composers Philip Glass and Tyondai Braxton are headlining a benefit concert at Le Poisson Rouge on Thursday evening, to raise money for disaster relief in the Philippines, which was devastated by Typhoon Haiyan on Nov. 8. All proceeds from the concert will be donated to A Single Drop, an organization in the Philippines dedicated to creating water, sanitation, food and shelter projects.

headline: In Uzbekistan, the Practice of Forced Labor Lives On During the Cotton Harvest
text: SAMARKAND, Uzbekistan — For most of the year, Dr. Tamara Khidoyatova treats patients as a doctor at a hospital here in this picturesque, old Silk Road city. But for a few weeks every autumn, she is forced to pick cotton, for which she is paid little or nothing.

headline: Russia Offers Cash Infusion for Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — In a sharp rebuff to the West in the diplomatic wrangle over Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin said Tuesday that Russia would come to the rescue of its financially troubled neighbor, providing $15 billion in loans and a steep discount on natural gas prices.

headline: In Facebook News Feeds, Here Come Commercials
text: Facebook is betting the patience of some of its users against the hundreds of millions of dollars it could make on video advertisements.

headline: Snowden Offers Help to Brazil in Spy Case
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Edward J. Snowden, the former contractor for the National Security Agency now living temporarily in Russia, said in comments published on Tuesday that he was prepared to assist Brazilian investigations into American spying in Brazil. But he said he could not speak freely until a country granted him permanent political asylum, which he requested from Brazil months ago.

headline: Audrey Totter, Femme Fatale of ’40s Film Noir, Dies at 95
text: Audrey Totter, who as a femme-fatale star of Hollywood’s noir films of the 1940s could twist daggers with the subtlest arch of her perfectly plucked eyebrows, died on Thursday in West Hills, Calif. She was 95, and it had been decades since she last committed a crime — most were of the heart — on the silver screen.

headline: Walkabout: Ski Movies That Don’t Just Melt Away; Divorce Parties in Vegas
text: Once known as “ski porn” by powder enthusiasts, ski movies have evolved to include actual stories. (The New York Times)

headline: The National Guard Rebellion Is Over
text: It shouldn’t have taken so long. But it appears that the Great National Guard Rebellion, in which units in nine states refused to comply with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s order that same-sex spouses of military personnel be given full spousal benefits, is finally over.

headline: Pinot Noir and Duck: A Match Made in Heaven
text: Let’s not mince words: the conventional and excellent pairing for duck is pinot noir. It’s a beautiful combination that tends to work with many different accents and flavorings.

headline: McClendon’s New Venture Echoes Dealings at Chesapeake Energy
text: Aubrey McClendon’s new public offering plan is an echo of the bad old Chesapeake Energy. He lost his job as chief executive of the energy company over excessive spending and conflicts of interest. A new $2 billion venture would allow him to cherry-pick assets ahead of his investors and reward him generously. Despite Mr. McClendon’s knack for buying oil and gas properties, investor skepticism is in order.

headline: Former Trader Pleads Not Guilty in Rate-Rigging Case
text: LONDON — A former trader at UBS and Citigroup pleaded not guilty Tuesday to allegations that he manipulated a crucial benchmark interest rate.

headline: The Seahawks’ Pass Defense Thrives in a Tough Environment
text: As the passing revolution overtakes the N.F.L., football fans have become immune to the avalanche of falling records. Teams are averaging 239 passing yards per game and completing 61.3 percent of passes, metrics that would be single-season records. Peyton Manning is on a pace to break the single-season record for passing yards and passing touchdowns, and there was discussion last week that he was not even the most valuable player in the league. Josh Gordon set records for receiving yards in a two-, three- and four-game stretch this season, and the Cleveland Browns lost each of those games. You can forgive fans for not being impressed by gaudy passing numbers when Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Nick Foles started the season with 19 touchdowns and no interceptions.

headline: Talking Sex After Childbirth, and After Children
text: How soon after the birth of your children did you and your partner have sex — and what does sex mean, in that new context? Do you, or did you, start with cuddling, or with other intimate acts? Did oral sex come first, or penetration?

headline: A Way to Stay on the Job
text: Does your employer offer back-up elder care?

headline: Tech Leaders and Obama Find Shared Problem: Fading Public Trust
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama met with top technology industry executives on Tuesday to discuss two seemingly distinct controversies: a faulty health care website, and the digital surveillance practices of the National Security Agency.

headline: Ambrose Bierce’s Civil War
text: Unlike his fellow satirist, Mark Twain, who had only dabbled as a soldier for a few weeks in the summer of 1861 before deserting from his Confederate unit, Ambrose Bierce enlisted into the Union Army just days after President Lincoln issued a proclamation calling for volunteers; he went on to serve for nearly the duration of the war. He saw heavy combat in some of its bloodiest battles, including Shiloh, Chickamauga and Missionary Ridge. Although Walt Whitman and Herman Melville, among others, wrote movingly about the traumas of combat, Bierce was the only major author to have actually been a front-line soldier in the Civil War.

headline: The Designer Who Helped Give L.A. Its Look
text: Last Thursday, the neon sign outside the WUHO Gallery on Hollywood Boulevard was tinted magenta for the opening of Deborah Sussman’s exhibit “Deborah Sussman Loves Los Angeles,” which collects the 82-year-old designer’s work from 1953 to 1984. The shade was chosen to honor the thread of giddy pink that has run through her entire 60-year career. Inside, an intergenerational crowd swarmed the walls lined with vivid graphics: programs for the Hollywood Bowl, brochures for LACMA, toys for Hasbro, stage design for a Rolling Stones tour and, of course, her transformative environmental design for LA 84, the 1984 Summer Olympics — all of which were inspired by the culture and landscape of her adopted city.

headline: Ex-Microsoft Executive to Take Over Health Site Repairs
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has chosen a former Microsoft executive, Kurt DelBene, to replace Jeffrey D. Zients as head of the effort to finish repairs on the government’s health insurance website, administration officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Times Minute | After the N.S.A. Ruling
text: In the Video

headline: A Walkout, and a Furor, During Debate on Israel at 92nd Street Y
text: The announcement on Monday that the American Studies Association had voted to approve a boycott of Israeli universities has prompted significant concern among scholars in that country. Meanwhile, in Manhattan, it also contributed to an unusually contentious onstage debate about Israel at the 92nd Street Y, which took an unusually dramatic turn when one participant simply walked out.

headline: 6 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Crash of Helicopter in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Six American soldiers died Tuesday when their helicopter crashed in a remote area of southern Afghanistan, in the single largest loss of life for foreign troops in nearly six months, international coalition officials said.

headline: Times Minute | After the N.S.A. Ruling
text: Also on the Minute, political compromise in Tunisia and basketball diplomacy continues.

headline: From Brooklyn, Barrel-Strength Headphones
text: Grado Labs has built a strong reputation for its specialty headphones and phonograph cartridges since opening its doors in Brooklyn more than 60 years ago. Audiophiles laud the company’s headphones for their warm, pristine sound, spending $1,700 for the flagship set, the PS1000.

headline: Stonehenge to Open New Visitor Center
text: LONDON — Stonehenge is set to open a sleek new visitor center on Wednesday, designed to “restore the dignity” of the ancient burial site, according to the British government, and to better accommodate the more than one million tourists who visit each year.

headline: Wheelies: The Burgeoning Supply Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Bridging the Mideast Divide With Comedy
text: JERUSALEM — Usually, post-screening sessions with filmmakers are for audience questions. But after a showing of “Peace After Marriage,” Ghazi Albuliwi, the film’s writer-director-star, had a question of his own: Had any of the Israelis in the theater had sex with a Palestinian?

headline: Britain Opens Door to More Shale Gas Drilling
text: LONDON — The British government signaled on Tuesday that it was intensifying its efforts to encourage the development of shale gas production, with plans to award a new set of shale drilling licenses next year despite persistent opposition from environmental groups.

headline: Next Year’s (Potential) Contenders, This Year’s (Disputed) Stinkers
text: Still thinking about your 2015 Oscar pool? The Berlin International Film Festival, another source for potential candidates, announced some of its selections for next year, and they include heavies like George Clooney’s “Monuments Men” (once expected to be a spoiler in this year’s Oscar race) and Wes Anderson’s “Grand Budapest Hotel,” as well as the documentary “The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came to Eden,” about a group of erudite Europeans who settled a Pacific island in the 1930s; melodrama ensued.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Hottest Start-Ups of 2013
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Bebe Neuwirth to Play a Third Role in ‘Chicago’ on Broadway
text: Bebe Neuwirth will complete a tour of the principal female roles in “Chicago” in January, when she rejoins the cast as “the countess of the clink,” prison matron “Mama” Morton, for an eight-week Broadway run.

headline: Sysco Deal Leaves Money on the Food Table
text: The Sysco Corporation’s deal to acquire its chief rival, US Foods, would put food on the table at a wide swath of restaurants, schools and hospitals. But it may have left money on the table as well.

headline: New Mexico Teachers Resist a State Official’s Plan for Evaluating Them
text: ROSWELL, N.M. — On a recent night in this southeastern New Mexico town, Hanna Skandera, the state’s education secretary-designate, told a crowd gathered in a school auditorium about her encounter with a veteran teacher.

headline: House Opens Inquiry After Republican’s Cocaine Conviction
text: WASHINGTON — The House Ethics Committee has opened a formal investigation into Representative Trey Radel, Republican of Florida, who pleaded guilty last month to misdemeanor cocaine possession charges after being arrested in Washington for buying the drug.

headline: Wars on Christmas: A Top Ten List
text: In no particular order:

headline: The Obamacare Worm Continues to Turn
text: Dana Milbank has an interesting piece today, on two levels.

headline: Stephen King’s Popularity Is Still Scary
text: Faced with 3,000 fans taking his picture in Germany, Stephen King joked, “Do they realize I’m not Justin Beiber?”

headline: Fewer Gmail Users Are Opening Retailers’ Messages This Shopping Season
text: Some e-commerce marketers are having a challenging holiday season, and they blame Google for it.

headline: Seeking Infield and Bullpen Help, the Yankees Turn to Two Veterans
text: The Yankees added to their infield and bullpen depth on Tuesday, agreeing to contracts with second baseman Brian Roberts and the left-hander Matt Thornton. Roberts will get a $2 million guarantee for one year, and Thornton will make $7 million over two years.

headline: Cocktail Culture | A Gin That’s Designed to Be Drunk Like Whiskey
text: It has become de rigueur for the great spirit houses to put out ultrapremium expressions of their core products. A standout this season is Beefeater’s Burrough’s Reserve Barrel Aged Gin, a fairly radical reimagining of the historic brand’s classic liquid. The company’s Master Distiller Desmond Payne is adding to an already impressive legacy in the gin realm — he came to Beefeater 16 years ago, after a 25-year career at the helm of Plymouth Gin — with this new bottle. “I tried to think of ways to evolve the original recipe into a different space,” Payne says. He wanted to make a spirit that could be drunk alone, as a sophisticated nightcap, rather than in a gin and tonic. “I started to think of how to move it into the after-dinner experience,” he explains, “more alongside whiskeys and cognacs.”

headline: Mastering the Chinese Chop System
text: Imagine giving away your signature and allowing anyone to use it.

headline: Looking Back at 2013 | Ideas for Reflecting On and Teaching About the Year That Was
text: Updated | Jan. 1, 2014

headline: The Facebooking of Economics
text: David Brooks has a funny piece today about the new profession of Thought Leaders. I think I know who he’s talking about. But I started thinking about my own neck of the woods — and while the rules of the game in economics are definitely changing, it’s nothing like what David describes.

headline: Thirty Years Later, Ken Dryden Updates ‘The Game’
text: Since it was published in 1983, “The Game,” Ken Dryden’s memoir and extended meditation on goaltending, hockey, family and life with the dynastic Montreal Canadiens, has justly earned a reputation as the best book written about the sport, and perhaps any sport, in the English language. That high opinion has been expressed often over the years, by sources as diverse as Mordecai Richler, Sports Illustrated, Alan Thicke, the CBC and Bill Simmons.

headline: Microsoft Not Likely to Select New Chief Until 2014
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft’s search for a new chief executive is not likely to reach its conclusion until early next year, a board member said Tuesday in a blog post.

headline: BMW and Infiniti Issue Recalls
text: BMW will recall nearly 77,000 vehicles and Infiniti 23 of its new Q50 sedans, the automakers informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: A New Caviar Service, Fresh Oysters Delivered to Your Door, and More
text: To Indulge: Taking a Break With Caviar

headline: Outrage in India, and Retaliation, Over a Female Diplomat’s Arrest in New York
text: BANGALORE, India — The way an Indian diplomat was treated by law enforcement officials in New York last week has touched off a furor in India, where politicians from across the political spectrum expressed outrage and the New Delhi police retaliated by removing security barriers that were meant to protect the American Embassy.

headline: How to Eat Ramen
text: A step-by-step guide to slurping up noodles and all their accompaniments.

headline: Video: Celebrating Home
text: Amanda Lundy and Sean McGinley moved into their dream home in Sea Bright, N.J, in 2011. When Hurricane Sandy hit in October of last year, they knew they would have to gut the entire first floor. The couple, who did much of the renovating themselves, set a goal: It would be ready in time for their Dec. 4 wedding reception. It was.

headline: A Life of Noodles Comes Full Circle
text: At 50, Ivan Orkin appears to have pulled off a chain of unprecedented feats.

headline: More Flights for Football Fans
text: Delta Air Lines has a plan for college football fans. In early January, the airline will add extra nonstop service between cities hosting Bowl Championship Series games and the hometowns of some of the teams competing in them.

headline: The Dog Days of I.V.F. Doubt
text: Libby pooped on the floor.

headline: Despite Doldrums in Deal Activity, a Few Highlights This Year
text: The deal world remained muted this year in terms of big transactions and activity. According to Dealogic, the number of announced takeovers in the United States so far this year was down about 22 percent, while volume was $1.1 trillion, up about 15 percent from last year but still below the level in the years before the financial crisis. . Despite the relative doldrums, there were still some highlights and lowlights. Here are some of them:

headline: The Gun Report: December 17, 2013
text: The F.B.I. says it has prevented nearly 150 shootings and violent attacks this year, in part by steering potential gunmen toward mental health professionals, the Associated Press has reported.

headline: From France, a Dessert for the Easy-Bake Oven
text: Time after time, the students in my cooking classes in Paris or Provence tell me “I don’t bake.” These same students are often delighted when I assign them a dessert, for they know that they will at least learn to make one wonderful sweet. I think that they also secretly hope that by week’s end, they may actually get over their fear of baking.

headline: Europe Tries Again to Address Weak Banks
text: BRUSSELS — European Union finance officials began meeting here again on Tuesday, hoping finally to agree on a system for winding down failing euro zone banks, which would be a pillar of the bloc’s efforts to construct a full banking union.

headline: Video Game for Toddlers, With a Plush Controller
text: It has been said that it’s never too early to start children in a sport if you envision them growing up to go pro. Apparently that is true for big-league video gaming as well.

headline: It Clips on a Pocket, and Sets Headphones Free
text: It’s hard enough to find a great-sounding set of headphones; finding a set that sounds great and connects wirelessly is nearly impossible. But what if you could make the wired headphones you enjoy connect by Bluetooth?

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald Settles 9/11 Suit Against American Airlines for $135 Million
text: More than a dozen years after the Sept. 11 attacks, a last major piece of litigation against the airline industry and other defendants moved toward an end on Tuesday, as the Wall Street firm Cantor Fitzgerald revealed that it would settle its lawsuit for $135 million.

headline: Sex, Sociology and the Single Girl
text: Not surprisingly, my weekend musings on the gender-specific anxieties parents might have about their daughters, and how those anxieties might possibly translate into some sort of affinity for moral traditionalism, has prompted a lot of responses from socially-liberal and feminist commentators — some huffy, some bemused, some condescending, some all three. For the purposes of this post I’m just going to work off these remarks from the New Republic’s Marc Tracy, who interviewed Adelle Waldman, the novelist whose “The Love Affairs of Nathaniel P.” served as one of my column’s touchstones, and who used their conversation as grist for the following conclusion:

headline: European Agency Warns of Risk to Humans in Pesticides Tied to Bee Deaths
text: LONDON — European food regulators said on Tuesday that a class of pesticides linked to the deaths of large numbers of honey bees might also harm human health, and they recommended that the European Commission further restrict their use.

headline: A Digital Pen Combines Writing and Recording
text: In the Venn diagram showing People Who Prefer to Take Notes on Paper along with the People Who Want to Store Their Notes Digitally, the overlap is People Who Might Buy a Livescribe 3 pen.

headline: African Refugees Protest Detainment in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Some arrived here on Tuesday in sturdy walking boots donated by local aid organizations; others came less equipped for the leftover snow on the ground, wearing sandals and house slippers.

headline: Blind Man and His Dog Survive Fall Onto Harlem Subway Tracks
text: As Cecil Williams moved dangerously close to the edge of the platform at a Harlem subway station on Tuesday morning, his guide dog’s training and instincts seemed to kick in. The dog, a black Labrador named Orlando, tried to pull Mr. Williams, who is blind, back from the edge.

headline: As Pressure Builds, Egypt’s Police Experience a New Feeling: Fear
text: CAIRO — For six hours, heavily armed officers fired fusillades of buckshot and tear gas at students who were the latest front of anger toward Egypt’s military-backed rulers.

headline: Chancellor at University of California to Become Chief at Gates Foundation
text: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation has tapped Susan Desmond-Hellmann, chancellor of the University of California, San Francisco, as the next chief executive of the giant charitable organization.

headline: Brash Agent at William Morris Extends Reach in IMG Merger
text: Updated, 9:22 p.m. | Over the past two decades, Ari Emanuel has climbed — brashly, ruthlessly — into Hollywood’s power center with one position in mind: king.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Children and Poverty
text: To the Editor:

headline: Parsing an Academic Boycott of Israel
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Pursuit of Powder? Tips for Finding It
text: It’s every skier’s dream: to arrive at a resort just after a good storm, take one of the first lift rides up and ply delightfully fresh, powdery tracks. The reality, though, is that most of us can’t drop everything to chase storms. We have to plan a ski trip in advance. That means the odds of finding good snow, let alone a powder day (often defined as six or more inches of new snow), requires some strategizing.

headline: What’s New at Ski Areas?
text: From a new hotel beside the slopes at Jay Peak, in Vermont, to retooled lifts at Whistler-Blackcomb, British Columbia, North American mountain resorts spent the off-season bumping up the experience for skiers this winter. Curious about what’s new at your vacation spot this winter? Here’s a look.

headline: Trapped on a Plane: An Imaginary Investigation
text: After falling asleep on a flight earlier this month, passenger Tom Wagner missed his connection to Los Angeles because he woke up trapped inside the locked plane after everyone else — including the crew — had debarked for a layover. When questioned about accountability, the airline issued this explanation: “ExpressJet is investigating to determine how this occurred.”

headline: The Mayor Has a Request
text: Exactly 289 features are eligible to be Oscar nominees this year, the Academy announced on Monday, a slight increase from last year’s pool of 282 films.

headline: Thousands Flee From Fighting in South Sudan
text: Thousands of civilians have been seeking shelter at United Nations facilities in South Sudan to escape fighting that has flared in the capital, Juba, and the demand for a safe haven has grown so great that the crowds are spilling outside of the gates.

headline: River Café Opens Again After Hurricane Sandy
text: Headliner

headline: Juilliard's New Dances, 2013
text: Juilliard's New Dances series features the first U.S. staging of Pina Bausch's Wind von West and works by Takehiro Ueyama, Brian Brooks, and Darrell Grand Moultrie.

headline: Harold Camping, Dogged Forecaster of the End of the World, Dies at 92
text: Harold Camping, a Christian radio entrepreneur and biblical soothsayer who stirred consternation, ecstasy, complaints to the Federal Communications Commission and widespread ridicule by repeatedly prophesying the end of the world — twice in 2011 — died on Sunday at his home in Alameda, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Valisia LeKae Departing ‘Motown’ for Health Reasons
text: The actress Valisia LeKae, who earned a Tony Award nomination this year for her breakout performance as Diana Ross in “Motown: The Musical” on Broadway, has left the show to undergo surgery and chemotherapy to battle ovarian cancer, she and the producers announced on Tuesday.

headline: Clinging to a Monster in a Desperate Gambit
text: The “beast” that Óscar Martínez writes about in his often harrowing new book is not actually an animal. It’s the train on whose roof Central American immigrants ride across Mexico, making their way to what they hope will be a better life in the United States. The beast, though, truly is a monster: It can devour the lives or limbs of its stowaways, and hosts the human predators who target them.

headline: Marco’s
text: Inside the new trattoria that opened in the space of the original Franny’s in Prospect Heights.

headline: Franny’s Sophisticated Brother
text: Not long ago, the highest praise for a Brooklyn restaurant was “like Manhattan.” With Franny’s, which opened in Prospect Heights in 2004, the geographical reference point started to shift west.

headline: Senate Asks C.I.A. to Share Its Report on Interrogations
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Intelligence Committee has asked the C.I.A. for an internal study done by the agency that lawmakers believe is broadly critical of the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation program but was withheld from congressional oversight committees.

headline: Finding Jazz and Ballet Bouncing in the Night
text: The news, good and not-so-good, of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s current season at City Center has come in imports and premieres, but on Friday the company turned to a program exclusively of works by its founder. Apart from “Revelations,” the pieces were all to music by Duke Ellington (recorded, alas). Curiously, all that jazz came with a lot of ballet.

headline: Publishers to Bring Out Sequel to Stieg Larsson’s ‘Dragon Tattoo’ Books
text: Given the enduring popularity of the three installments of Stieg Larsson’s Millennium series — “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” “The Girl Who Played With Fire” and “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest”— and reports that Larsson was at work on the fourth of 10 planned volumes when he died in 2004, it’s hard to blame his publisher for wanting to continue the franchise.

headline: Deal Gives Philharmonic Musicians Modest Gains
text: The contract agreement that the New York Philharmonic reached with its musicians last week will keep the music playing at Avery Fisher Hall and spare the city from the kind of bitter labor unrest that has set off damaging strikes and lockouts at other orchestras.

headline: Ron Burgundy’s Boob Tube Goes 24 Hours a Day
text: “Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues” is in danger of being overshadowed by its own marketing campaign. The recent media appearances by Ron Burgundy — impersonated, if you need reminding, by Will Ferrell — have the quality of commercial performance art. He has been ubiquitous, hawking Dodge Durango trucks, accepting a tribute from a journalism school and matching wits with members of the profession he exists to lampoon. That television news has so eagerly embraced Ron Burgundy may be evidence that the “Anchorman” movies don’t go far enough, satirically speaking. The man may be a vain, ethically obtuse, generally clueless buffoon, but it would not occur to him to allow a fictional character on his air to sell a product. He’s no George Stephanopoulos.

headline: Despite Early Doubts, ‘Brandenburgs’ Endure
text: If ever a job application was seemingly a sure thing and came up empty, it was Bach’s “Brandenburg” Concertos, of which the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center gave a superb performance on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: Ornaments That Shine in Your Eyes
text: Our favorite Christmas tree ornaments are not always beautiful or expensive. Readers submit examples and explain their special charms.

headline: Placating Authorities Without Kowtowing
text: Russian composers like Shostakovich were censured by the Soviet regime, which also subjected musicians in Poland to its Socialist Realist aesthetic. The Polish composer Witold Lutoslawski had his music denounced as “formalist,” his first symphony banned for its modernist inclinations.

headline: A Complexity That Trumps Similarities
text: Sometimes I think the British artist-musician Martin Creed makes art for dummies, not excluding myself. At the same time, his accumulations and arrangements of everyday objects and materials initially seem so rudimentary and forthright that they can also make you feel smart.

headline: Sold! In China
text: The Shanghai financier Liu Yiqian went from taxi driver to multimillionaire. He is also one of China’s most prolific collectors of art.

headline: Pope Francis Encourages Breast-Feeding Mother in a Public Place
text: For his frequently expressed hope of returning the Roman Catholic religion to a focus on compassion rather than dogma (and his example of the same), Pope Francis has been lauded by media institutions from Time magazine to The Advocate. Now, David Gibson reports for the Religion News Service, he is encouraging public breast-feeding — or at least, encouraging one woman, waiting to see him pass with a hungry, crying baby in her arms, to nurse the infant who needs her no matter where she is. In an interview with Andrea Tornielli of La Stampa, the pope said:

headline: Beechhurst: Stepping Out of Whitestone’s Shadow
text: Residents of Whitestone, Queens, like to say that the only people who call the waterfront enclave at its northeastern corner “Beechhurst” are the people who live there — no one else differentiates between it and the rest of Whitestone.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Bulgaria, Russia and Ukraine.

headline: Like a Home Renovation, but With Vermeers
text: Until April of this year, the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam, a peer of the Louvre, the Prado and the Hermitage, was mostly closed for almost a decade, thanks to an extensive, expensive and frequently controversial renovation. That hiatus, during which some of the finest Rembrandts, Vermeers and other masterpieces of Dutch art vanished from public view, would most likely be forgotten if not for “The New Rijksmuseum,” Oeke Hoogendijk’s eye-opening, patience-testing new documentary. The film dwells on the logistical and bureaucratic details of the process, and if it does not exactly write a fresh chapter in the history of art, it stands as an exemplary study in the sociology of art administration.

headline: Lou Reed’s Complex Spirit Is Invoked at a Reunion of His Inner Circle
text: Righteous guitar noise began and ended the memorial for Lou Reed on Monday night at the Apollo Theater. It was a celebration, for an invited audience of family and friends, of what more than one speaker called his “complexity”: his kindness and his asperity, his spirituality and his earthiness, his groundbreaking music and his silent meditations.

headline: A Rollicking Treat Infused With Grace and Gravitas
text: On Monday night the acclaimed British conductor Jane Glover became only the third woman to conduct at the Metropolitan Opera. The occasion was the revival of Julie Taymor’s 2004 production of Mozart’s “The Magic Flute,” presented as a family-friendly offering for the holidays, trimmed to 100 minutes without intermission and performed in a snappy English translation by J. D. McClatchy. Mozart’s fairy-tale opera, Ms. Taymor’s fanciful production and a winning cast delighted the audience, judging by the frequent laughter of the many children in attendance.

headline: Disembodied, but, Oh, What a Voice
text: She sounds like the girl next door — young, friendly, eager. For Theodore Twombly (Joaquin Phoenix), the poetically melancholic hero in “Her,” Spike Jonze’s exquisite new movie, that voice (Scarlett Johansson) is a lifeline to the world, which he has loosened his hold on since separating from his wife. The voice brightly greets him in the morning and, with a sexy huskiness, bids him good night in the evening. The voice organizes his files, gets him out of the house and, unlike some multitasking females, doesn’t complain about juggling her many roles as his assistant, comfort, turn-on, helpmate and savior — which makes her an ideal companion even if she’s also just software.

headline: IQor to Buy Jabil’s Aftermarket Services Unit for $725 Million
text: IQor, a customer service outsourcing provider, agreed on Tuesday to buy Jabil Circuit’s aftermarket services business for $725 million to help round out its offerings.

headline: How Do You Say This in Hebrew?: ‘I Lost Your Grandma’s Body’
text: We went for Carol Lawrence. We stayed for people we had never heard of.

headline: Are Nuts a Weight-Loss Aid?
text: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind. — “Here are the nuts,” said Drew Sayer, a graduate student in nutrition science, before shoving me into the M.R.I. machine, flat on my back. “Chew them. Swallow them. And don’t move your head.”

headline: Q. & A. With Arthur Levine
text: Arthur Levine, the former president of Columbia University’s Teachers College, is a longtime critic of the quality of teacher preparation in the United States. In 2006, he wrote a report describing extremely low standards for admission and graduation from teaching programs. “Teacher education right now is the Dodge City of education, unruly and chaotic,” he said at the time. Now, as the president of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation, which supports scholarship and public service in a variety of fields, he remains focused on improving the achievement gap in education among races and incomes. The foundation has given stipends to nearly 1,000 teaching fellows who have gone on to teach in the STEM fields (science, technology, engineering and math) in high-needs public schools. He spoke recently to David Firestone of The New York Times Editorial Board about international competitions that show both students and teachers in many countries to be better prepared than those in the United States.

headline: A Flurry of New Activity at a Harlem Crossroads

headline: Test Your Budget-Travel Instincts
text: There’s a lot more to keeping travel costs down than eating ham-and-cheese sandwiches, crashing on friends’ couches and sticking to public transportation. This week, test your budgetary instincts with the first ever Frugal Travel Quiz. (Answers at the end.)

headline: Gunman at Reno Hospital Kills One and Wounds Two
text: A gunman opened fire at a hospital in Reno, Nev., on Tuesday, killing one person and wounding two others before killing himself, the police said.

headline: New York Court Finds That Sellers at Auction Can Remain Anonymous
text: New York’s highest court on Tuesday reversed a decision in a case that could have forced the state’s auction industry to change its practice of keeping sellers’ names anonymous.

headline: The F.D.A.’s Not-Really-Such-Good-News
text: That “good” news you may have read last week about the Food and Drug Administration’s curbing antibiotics in animal feed may not be so good after all. In fact, it appears that the F.D.A. has once again refused to do all it could to protect public health.

headline: New Landmarks in the West Village and the Bronx
text: The Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday granted landmark status to a historic district in Greenwich Village and to the interior of the main post office in the Bronx.

headline: The Wrong College Ratings
text: LYNCHBURG, Va. — BY the beginning of the 2015 school year, college students will have yet another tool for evaluating their higher-education options — only this one won’t come from U.S. News and World Report or Playboy, but the Department of Education. And rather than ranking academic quality or opportunities to party, this list will rate schools on “value.”

headline: Graft Inquiry Intensifies Turkish Political Rivalry
text: ISTANBUL — At dawn on Tuesday the police raided the offices of several businessmen with close ties to Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan as part of a wide-ranging corruption investigation, immediately raising the stakes of an unfolding political contest of wills here between two men who have long held sway over the country’s Muslim masses: an ailing and aging Turkish preacher who lives on a sprawling compound in the Poconos, and Mr. Erdogan.

headline: Robert C. Lieber
text: Mr. Lieber, 59, is an executive managing director of the Island Capital Group, a merchant real estate bank, and the new chairman of the Urban Land Institute of New York, a nonprofit urban-planning research group.

headline: AMC Prices Its I.P.O. at $18 a Share
text: AMC Entertainment Holdings priced its initial public offering at $18 a share on Tuesday as the movie theater chain prepared for its premiere on the stock market.

headline: India’s Upper House Approves Anticorruption Agency
text: NEW DELHI — India’s upper house of Parliament passed a measure on Tuesday to create an independent anticorruption agency, after more than four decades of debate and controversy over how to curb corruption. The vote all but ensured that the measure, called the Lokpal and Lokayuktas Bill, would become law.

headline: George L. Shinn, a Wall Street Chief Who Turned to Teaching, Dies at 90
text: George L. Shinn, who climbed from trainee to president of Merrill Lynch, the nation’s biggest securities firm, then led the First Boston Corporation, a major player on Wall Street during the 1980s, died on Monday in Scarborough, Me. He was 90.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Creator Is Suing AMC Over Payouts
text: Frank Darabont, the creator of one of television’s biggest hit shows, “The Walking Dead,” escalated his long feud with the AMC network on Tuesday, charging in a lawsuit that he had been cheated out of tens of millions of dollars because of “self-dealing” by the network.

headline: Ex-Child Welfare Caseworkers Plead Guilty in Death of a 4-Year-Old
text: Two former employees of New York City’s child welfare agency pleaded guilty on Tuesday, under an agreement with prosecutors, to misdemeanor charges relating to the death of a 4-year-old girl who was drugged, beaten and tied to a bed by her mother and grandmother, despite being under the supervision of the agency.

headline: Spider Drove a Taxi
text: This Op-Doc video celebrates New York City’s taxi drivers through the life of Johnnie Footman, known as Spider, who was the city’s oldest cabby.

headline: After Losing His Mother and His Health, a Man Takes Shaky Steps to Recovery
text: Mikhail Guryevskiy and his mother were virtually inseparable during the economic hardships they suffered in Ukraine, the ups-and-downs of his marriage, fatherhood and subsequent divorce, and their passage into the United States as immigrants from Odessa in 1996.

text: This Op-Doc video celebrates New York City’s taxi drivers through the life of Johnnie Footman, known as Spider, who was the city’s oldest cabby.

headline: Stubborn Poverty
text: Government programs have made a substantial dent in poverty. Still, the overall poverty rate is not much lower than it was 50 years ago.

headline: Applying Creativity to a Byproduct of Oil Drilling
text: WATFORD CITY, N.D. — Viewed from outer space, the 1,500 blazing oil well flares burning off excess natural gas illuminate the plains of western North Dakota more brilliantly than Minneapolis hundreds of miles away.

headline: A Historic Vessel, Stuck in Place
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — From the nearby Walnut Street Bridge, the Delta Queen does not appear to be in distress. The Tennessee River stirs gently, and the red paddle wheel of the venerable steamboat is still.

headline: Struggling Rangers Face Difficult Challenge in Penguins
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers should be fattening up ahead of Christmas, feasting on a steady diet of home games. Instead they are victory-starved and face Sidney Crosby and the Eastern Conference-leading Pittsburgh Penguins on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: BP Accuses Texas Lawyer of ‘Brazen Fraud’ in Workers’ Claims Over Gulf Oil Spill
text: BP on Tuesday accused a Texas lawyer of fraudulently driving up its settlement costs in the 2010 Gulf Coast oil spill by claiming to represent tens of thousands of clients who turned out to be “phantoms.”

headline: Outrage in Italy Over ‘Degrading’ Treatment of Migrants Caught on Video
text: A senior Italian official on Tuesday called for an end to the “degrading treatment” of migrants held in a detention center on the island of Lampedusa, one day after video obtained by the state broadcaster showed asylum seekers being forced to stand naked outdoors as guards hosed them down.

headline: Judge Orders Freedom or Retrial for Connecticut Man Jailed Since ’95
text: After spending nearly two decades in prison, a man convicted of a double homicide in New Haven in 1990 was ordered freed by a federal judge, who ruled this week that the prosecution had withheld evidence of his innocence.

text: Astronauts aboard the International Space Station will venture outside on three spacewalks to replace a malfunctioning pump that has shut down part of the station’s cooling system, NASA announced on Tuesday.

text: The first initial in the ABC television network stands for “American,” but it might well stand for “asterisk.”

headline: Conflicting Tales on How a Brooklyn Businessman Evaded Bolivian Custody
text: In an odd twist to a serpentine tale, two discrete stories emerged on Tuesday about how a Brooklyn businessman who was jailed in a squalid prison in Santa Cruz, Bolivia, for 18 months, then placed under house arrest, managed to escape and make his way to the United States.

headline: Secretary Kerry’s Derring-Do
text: I don’t know whether Secretary of State John Kerry will succeed in his two big chosen priorities: trying to forge an Israeli-Palestinian peace and a détente with Iran that deprives it of a nuclear weapon. But I admire his relentlessness. I admire the way he dares to fail — the only way to become a consequential secretary of state. And I admire his strategy: trying to construct a diplomacy that makes it impossible for Israel, the Palestinians and Iran to continue avoiding their big existential choices.

text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission has withdrawn his predecessor’s proposal to relax a longstanding ban on ownership of both a newspaper and a broadcaster in the same large metropolitan market.

headline: After Ruling Critical of N.S.A., Uncertain Terrain for Appeal
text: WASHINGTON — As Judge Richard J. Leon heard arguments last month in a challenge to a National Security Agency program, he said only one thing was certain.

headline: In a Brooklyn Park Design, Movable Parts at Play
text: Along one boundary of Betsy Head Park in Brownsville, Brooklyn, elevated trains grumbled past on Livonia Avenue. Monday’s wind knifed through layers of clothes. The handball courts were deserted. No one was shooting hoops from the pockmarked cement court. With baseball in hibernation, not a soul was to be seen on the bony, knuckled field. It was the week of the shortest days of the year.

text: Dacia is one of a group of car manufacturers from the former Soviet bloc that sold successfully during the Cold War.

headline: Why Other Countries Teach Better
text: Millions of laid-off American factory workers were the first to realize that they were competing against job seekers around the globe with comparable skills but far smaller paychecks. But a similar fate also awaits workers who aspire to high-skilled, high-paying jobs in engineering and technical fields unless this country learns to prepare them to compete for the challenging work that the new global economy requires.

headline: SUNY Withdraws Development Plan for Troubled Brooklyn Hospital
text: The State University of New York on Tuesday withdrew a plan to build condominiums on the property of the troubled Long Island College Hospital, after dozens of angry protesters complained that the community had not been consulted.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 17, 2013
Time Short, Bloomberg Touts Successes in Brooklyn
text: A light snow was falling on Prospect Park’s pristine new skating rink on Tuesday morning, and children clamored to don the skates that would carve the first marks into the ice. But Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared unmoved by the pretty scene before him, handing a pair of skates to each child in line with one brisk question: “What size?”

headline: The Travels of the Olympic Torch
text: The 40,389-mile Olympic torch relay to Sochi from Moscow is a meandering route designed to showcase the historical, cultural and geographic richness of Russia.

headline: Suspect in 9/11 Case Is Ejected From a Guantánamo Court After Outbursts
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — A military judge on Tuesday twice expelled Ramzi bin al-Shibh — one of five Guantánamo Bay detainees facing a death penalty trial — from a courtroom at the military base there in Cuba after he disrupted proceedings by shouting about his treatment.

headline: Scrambled Conferences Keeping Teams Up in the Air
text: The major collegiate athletic conferences have fractured and reconfigured in recent years as individual universities chased the additional millions in television revenue their football and basketball teams command.

headline: If Wall Safes Could Talk, the Tales of Graft Two Could Tell
text: In the rich and storied history of Jersey City’s political corruption, the gold medal still goes to Frank Hague, who ruled as mayor for 30 years from a desk with a special drawer that opened out to visitors, the better to collect his kickbacks. Hague, whose annual salary never exceeded $9,000, retired as a multimillionaire in 1947.

headline: Got a Light? Olympic Torch Relay Seems Cursed to the Ends of the Earth
text: It was bad enough when the Olympic flame went out and had to be relit with a disposable lighter rather than the official backup flame, and even worse when a torchbearer managed somehow to set himself on fire in the Siberian city of Abakan.

text: “Free cheese is only found in a mousetrap.”

headline: 3 House Retirements Complicate Outlook for Midterms
text: WASHINGTON — Three longtime members of the House, including two who represent swing districts, announced their retirements unexpectedly on Tuesday, joining a wave of lawmakers from both parties who have decided to leave Congress after the midterm elections next year.

headline: Janet Dailey, 69, Dies; Romance Author Who Sold in Hundreds of Millions
text: Janet Dailey, a former secretary who married her boss at 19, wrote her first novel on something of a dare and went on to become one of the most successful American romance writers of her time, selling as many as 300 million copies, died on Saturday in Branson, Mo. She was 69.

headline: Poor Decisions Add to Knicks’ Dysfunction
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Coach Mike Woodson watched the game film with his players Tuesday, reviewing their many blunders. The foul they opted not to give. The defense they refused to play. The timeout they decided not to take. It was ugly and demoralizing and necessary.

headline: Budget Deal Offers a Reprieve From Washington Paralysis
text: WASHINGTON — Something odd happened here on Tuesday. The Senate advanced a two-year bipartisan budget deal that will now surely be sent to the president for his signature later this week without waiting for a cliff, a chasm, a deadline or a shutdown to force its hand.

headline: George Hambrick, 91, Leader in Dermatology, Dies
text: Dr. George Hambrick, a dermatologist who in 1987 helped establish the American Skin Association, which has contributed to dermatologic research and helped educate the public about skin diseases, died on Dec. 10 at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 91.

headline: Obama Names Gay Athletes to U.S. Delegation
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama sent a clear protest of Russia’s crackdown on gay rights Tuesday by designating delegations to the Olympics in Sochi that include openly gay athletes but none of the nation’s top political figures.

headline: Three Days of Violence in South Sudan Leave Scores Dead
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Three days of violence that ignited in South Sudan after months of rising political tensions have left at least 75 people dead, the South Sudanese interior minister said Tuesday, although a wire service report put the death toll far higher.

headline: With Injuries, Step Forward Is Matched by Step Back for Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It seems impossible these days for Knicks Coach Mike Woodson to get a bit of good news without it being compromised by another injury to another player.

headline: Navy Investigator Pleads Guilty in Ship-Supply Case
text: SAN DIEGO — A Navy criminal investigator admitted Tuesday that he provided more than 100 pages of secret investigative files to a Malaysian contractor in exchange for prostitutes, cash and luxury travel, the first conviction in a ship-supply case involving high-ranking Navy officials.

headline: Is the Safety Net Just Masking Tape?
text: It’s easy for liberals to explain away setbacks to programs and policies that they favor — ranging from infrastructure investment to food stamps to increased education budgets — as a result of the intransigence of the Republican Party, with its die-hard commitment to slashing government spending on nearly every front.

headline: Colorado Shooter Had List of Schoolrooms to Attack
text: The gunman who shot a student at a high school in Colorado last week had letters and numbers written in permanent marker on his arm indicating that he planned to target several areas inside the school, the authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: Suspect in T.S.A. Agent’s Killing Is Indicted on 11 Charges
text: LOS ANGELES — Paul A. Ciancia, the man accused of killing an airport safety officer and shooting three others during a rampage at Los Angeles International Airport last month, has been indicted on 11 charges, including first-degree murder, the Department of Justice announced Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Seeks Pensions of 4 Convicted of Corruption
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan filed court papers on Tuesday as part of an effort to forfeit or be reimbursed for the pensions of three former members of the New York City Council and a former member of the Yonkers City Council, all of whom have been convicted on corruption charges.

headline: Glitches Along an Ambitious 14,000-Leg Relay
text: A look at some of the numerous mishaps along the 2014 Sochi Olympic torch relay.

headline: A Top Iraqi Official’s Advice to Karzai? Take America’s Deal
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — With one of the most important chapters of Afghanistan’s history open before him, President Hamid Karzai took time this month for a personal meeting with the longtime foreign minister of Iraq, Hoshyar Zebari.

headline: Murphy Adds Red Suit and Beard to Itinerant Mets Résumé
text: Citi Field was coated white, and snow continued to fall as schoolchildren gathered in a lounge beyond the outfield for the team’s annual holiday party. Daniel Murphy bounded around the room dressed as Santa Claus, ringing a bell, waving and shouting in a deep, booming voice: “Ho! Ho! Ho!” Zack Wheeler, his elf, grinned and followed.

headline: Former Energy Secretary Chu Joins Board of Canadian Start-Up
text: WASHINGTON — A Canadian company with a radically different approach to capturing carbon pollution from power plants has won an influential endorsement from Steven Chu, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist and a former secretary of energy, who is joining the company’s board.

headline: Uprooted in Central Africa, Too Terrified to Go Back
text: BANGUI, Central African Republic — The wounded man sat in an armchair in front of a shack on the edge of the airport runway, his arms and head heavily bandaged.

headline: Wanted: Schools Chief Who Has Never Crossed de Blasio on Education
text: With a populist pitch forged by his own experiences as a public school parent, Bill de Blasio surged to victory in New York’s mayoral race thanks, in part, to his vow to shift away from Michael R. Bloomberg’s education policies.

headline: North Korea: A Pageant of Power
text: Top party and military officials gathered at an indoor stadium in Pyongyang on Tuesday where they made speeches vowing to uphold Kim Jong-un as their unchallenged top leader. The gathering was held to commemorate the second anniversary of the death of Mr. Kim’s father, the longtime dictator Kim Jong-il, but analysts said Mr. Kim also used the event to show that he was firmly in control after the execution of his uncle last week. The meeting was the first major national event that Mr. Kim presided over since the execution of Jang Song-thaek, who had long been considered the No. 2 leader. Throughout the nationally televised one-hour ceremony, he was grim-faced and silent while senior officials made speeches paying homage to his father and vowing fealty to him.

headline: Florida Holds Off Memphis at Garden
text: In a tight, highly entertaining matchup in the Jimmy V Classic at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, No. 16 Florida held off No. 15 Memphis, 77-75, for its second consecutive win over a ranked opponent.

headline: In the Former Elaine’s Space, a New Restaurant Pays Tribute to Its Predecessor
text: Tonight, the restaurant the Writing Room opens on the Upper East Side in the space formerly known as Elaine’s. The old establishment was legendary for playing host to a wide range of New York literati, from Woody Allen to Nora Ephron, and other famous creative types, like Andy Warhol and Clint Eastwood. The new place, owned by Michael and Susy Glick, pays homage to the rich 48-year history of Elaine’s and its patrons.

headline: Increasing Marijuana Use in High School Is Reported
text: A new federal report shows that the percentage of American high school students who smoke marijuana is slowly rising, while the use of alcohol and almost every other drug is falling.

headline: Inequality and Good Intentions
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: What Happens in the Brain After a Concussion
text: A remarkable recent experiment allowed scientists to see inside the skull and brain of animals that had just experienced a concussion, providing sobering new evidence of how damaging even minor brain impacts can be. While the results, which were published in Nature, are worrisome, they also hint at the possibility of treating concussions and lessening their harm.

headline: Word of the Day | glower
text: glower •\ˈglau̇(-ə)r, ÷ˈglo(-ə)r\• verb and noun

headline: What’s on Wednesday

(ABC) BARBARA WALTERS PRESENTS THE 10 MOST FASCINATING PEOPLE OF 2013 For the last time Ms. Walters counts down some of the year’s biggest newsmakers, including Jennifer Lawrence; Robin Roberts, the “Good Morning America” anchor; the stars of “Duck Dynasty”; Miley Cyrus; Prince George; Kim Kardashian and Kanye West; and Edward J. Snowden.

headline: I Baked Them Myself
text: Christmas is very easy for me because I was brought up in a Jewish household and except for when my brothers and I were very young and hung up stockings, we did not do Christmas.

headline: 9 Injured in Gowanus Expressway Pileup
text: Nine people were injured in a messy series of crashes on the Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn on Tuesday night, fire officials said.

headline: Chinese Defense Ministry Issues Statement Playing Down Near Collision at Sea
text: Updated, 4:17 a.m. ET | The Chinese Ministry of National Defense on Wednesday issued its first official statement about what has been described as a near collision between Chinese and American warships in the South China Sea. The incident took place on Dec. 5 in waters off the southern Chinese province of Hainan Island during a training exercise of the Liaoning aircraft carrier group.

headline: China Unveils Memorial to Spies in Taiwan
text: China has completed a monument to Communist agents who were executed in Taiwan during the 1950s, a reminder of the longstanding conflict between the two sides. While tensions have eased in recent years, they have hardly disappeared. The monument was unveiled this week as a report emerged that Taiwan and China had discussed an exchange of imprisoned spies.

headline: A Conversation With: Robert van Zwieten, C.E.O. of Emerging Markets Private Equity Association
text: Uncertainty around the economic and regulatory climate in India this year has weighed heavily on foreign investors, who are exercising caution in committing fresh capital to India-focused private equity funds.

headline: In an Unexpected Move, the Indian Central Bank Leaves Rates Unchanged
text: MUMBAI, India — India’s central bank surprised economists on Wednesday when it held interest rates steady, citing an expected reduction in food prices and a struggling domestic economy.

headline: Now Imagine Mary Poppins Doing the Twist
text: The nanny Mary Poppins and the nasty Vincent Vega are now ensured a place where they can spend their golden years growing old together, using whatever they wish to help the medicine go down.

headline: Bitcoin Value Sinks After Chinese Exchange Move
text: HONG KONG — China’s biggest Bitcoin exchange was forced to stop accepting deposits in the Chinese currency on Wednesday, sending the price of the virtual money tumbling in one of its biggest markets globally.

headline: British Family Rebukes Government Over Surgeon’s Death in Syria
text: LONDON — The mutually hostile governments in London and Damascus were locked in a fresh dispute on Wednesday over the death of a British surgeon in a Syrian prison earlier this week whose family has accused the British authorities of failing to protect him.

headline: Indian Parliament Passes Bill Forming Anticorruption Agency
text: NEW DELHI — India’s Parliament gave final approval on Wednesday to a bill creating an independent anticorruption agency after more than four decades of debate and controversy over how to curb graft.

headline: Ronnie Biggs, Longtime Fugitive After the Great Train Robbery, Dies at 84
text: Ronnie Biggs, a carpenter and petty crook who became an international celebrity for his role in one of Britain’s most famous crimes, the Great Train Robbery of 1963, and for the decades he spent afterward eluding a worldwide manhunt by Scotland Yard, died on Wednesday in London. He was 84.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 18, 2013
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Zhang Ziyi Settles Libel Suit and U.S. Website Retracts Story
text: A website based in the United States has retracted a series of stories alleging that the Chinese film star Zhang Ziyi slept with powerful men in exchange for more than $100 million. Ms. Zhang had sued the website, Boxun News, which publishes mostly in Chinese, for libel in a California court. A court document said the two sides reached an undisclosed agreement in principle on Dec. 12.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Secret Bids Guide Hopi Indians’ Spirits Home
text: In “Secret Bids Guide Hopi Indians’ Spirits Home,” Tom Mashberg reports on a clandestine effort to return sacred Native American artifacts to their home tribe.

headline: A Chinese Coal Baron Tumbles into Debt
text: Thin and bespectacled, Xing Libin looks more like an intellectual or accountant than the coal baron he is — or, perhaps, was, with the company he founded, Liansheng Group, carrying 30 billion renminbi ($5 billion) in unpayable debt and set for a court-managed restructuring, according to widespread Chinese news reports.

headline: Kerry Calls Typhoon a Warning of Climate Change
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — After touring miles of roofless homes and shattered shantytowns destroyed by Typhoon Haiyan last month, Secretary of State John Kerry announced on Wednesday that additional American humanitarian aid would be sent to the Philippines. He called the giant storm a warning of extreme weather in a warming world.

headline: London’s Streetscapes, Stained by Homicide
text: A small article about a murder-suicide near his London home sent Antonio Zazueta Olmos in search of the crime scene. A man had stabbed his girlfriend to death, the local newspaper said, and he then took his own life by jumping in front of a train. But when Mr. Olmos got to the block he found nothing: no police tape, no flowers, no candles.

headline: How John McCain Turned His Clichés Into Meaning
text: When I walk into John McCain’s office a week before Thanksgiving, he is not at all happy — and seems to be enjoying it quite a bit.

headline: Do Rich People Get Off Easier When They Break the Law?
text: Last week a Texas judge decided not to send a teenager from a well-off family to prison after he killed four people while driving drunk. The judge made her ruling after hearing from a psychologist who claimed that the 16-year-old boy suffered from “affluenza,” a term used to describe psychological problems that can afflict children of privilege. While it is not clear if the psychologist’s testimony influenced the judge, the ruling has set off public outrage.

headline: Times Minute | Advice for Hamid Karzai
text: Also on the Minute, in Hollywood, a mega-talent agency is born and tragedy on the Olympic torch relay.

headline: European E-Payments Deal: Klarna Buys Sofort
text: LONDON — Sebastian Siemiatkowski has come a long way in almost a decade.

headline: New York Today: Goodbye, City Hall
text: Updated 11:09 a.m.

headline: Daily Report: Obama and Tech Leaders Confer on Public’s Lack of Trust
text: President Obama met with top technology industry executives on Tuesday to discuss two seemingly distinct controversies: a faulty health care website and the digital surveillance practices of the National Security Agency, Jackie Calmes and Nick Wingfield report.

headline: Stumbling Toward the Next Crash
text: LONDON — In early October 2008, three weeks after the Lehman Brothers collapse, I met in Paris with leaders of the countries in the euro zone. Oblivious to the global dimension of the financial crisis, they took the view that if there was fallout for Europe, America would be to blame — so it would be for America to fix. I was unable to convince them that half of the bundled subprime-mortgage securities that were about to blow up had landed in Europe and that euro-area banks were, in fact, more highly leveraged than America’s.

headline: Why Sales Reps Get Paid More Than Other Employees
text: A reader named Pablo recently sent me an interesting question that referred to a post I wrote back in 2010, “Do Salespeople Make Too Much Money?”

headline: Lusty Young Couples Instead of Mother Ginger
text: PARIS — It’s nice to know that not every ballet company in the world feels obliged to program “The Nutcracker” over the Christmas season. Instead of cute children, mice and sugar plums, the Paris Opera Ballet has sexual desire as its seasonal theme (and why not?) at the Palais Garnier, where the choreographer Angelin Preljocaj’s “Le Parc” is running through Tuesday.

headline: Lawlessness on Borders Taints Progress in Myanmar
text: TACHILEIK, Myanmar — The verdant fairways of the golf course outside this northeastern city in Myanmar might suggest a measure of normalcy and tranquillity — except for the handguns that some of the golfers wear.

headline: Government to Offer Free Fertility Treatments to Create Parsi Baby Boom
text: MUMBAI — Each day, gray-haired men and women shuffle into the offices of Bombay Parsi Council, the governing council for the Parsi-Zoroastrians of India. Each day, they huddle behind rickety desks, stacked with dusty ledgers and pictures of their prophet, and pray for Parsi children to boost their rapidly dwindling numbers.

headline: What to Look for Today at the Fed
text: Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve for a few more weeks, will hold his last official news conference on Wednesday afternoon, shortly after the Fed’s policy-making committee announces its plans for the global economy.

headline: Ukraine’s Premier Hails Russian Aid, Saying Crisis Has Passed
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukrainian officials on Wednesday praised a financial aid package from Russia as the country’s only hope to prevent economic collapse, although it was signed in defiance of a large and sustained protest in the capital.

headline: Raids and Graft Inquiry in Turkey Are Seen by Some as Muslim Cleric’s Plot
text: ISTANBUL — On Tuesday came dramatic dawn raids of the offices of businessmen close to the prime minister. On Wednesday came the scintillating details in leaks to the local media: $4.5 million in cash packed in shoe boxes found in the home of the chief executive of a state-run bank; a money-counting machine and piles of bank notes discovered in the bedroom of a government minister’s son.

headline: New York Film Society’s Executive Director Steps Down
text: In a shake-up of its top leadership, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said its executive director, Rose Kuo, was resigning after nearly three and a half years in the role and would be replaced, on an interim basis, by Lesli Klainberg, the society’s current managing director.

headline: Negotiating Conflicts, Part 2: Holiday Hostility
text: Sheila Heen, an expert in negotiation and difficult conversations, is answering reader questions about how to resolve disputes within families and in other parts of life.

headline: Ode to the Gotham Jazzmen
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Single-Parent Household Linked to Hypertension in Offspring
text: A new study of black men suggests that living with both parents in childhood reduces the risk for high blood pressure in adulthood.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Hermès Drawer Liners
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Talent Agency Deal to Reshape Hollywood Landscape
text: William Morris Endeavor was born of bold moves, the product of a merger between the old-line William Morris Agency and Ari Emanuel’s upstart Endeavor. Now the agency will make its biggest step yet: the takeover of another big name.

headline: Harland Clarke to Buy Marketing Company Valassis for $1.8 Billion
text: Harland Clarke Holdings, the company that probably provided you with your checkbook and various business forms, announced on Wednesday that it would buy Valassis Communications, a publicly traded integrated marketing company, for $1.84 billion in cash.

headline: Broad Skepticism on Health Care Law
text: With the approach of the new year, when health insurance policies under President Obama’s new health care law are set to begin, there is wide skepticism among both the insured and uninsured about how the law will affect them and the nation as a whole, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Image of the Day: December 18
text: India’s parliament approved a bill that empowers an independent ombudsman to investigate and prosecute cases of corruption.

headline: Christmas for Keeps
text: Are your children nestled all snug in their beds, while visions of Christmas books dance in their heads? Sweet as sugarplums, holiday books bring tradition, storytelling and history to the season, deepening and prolonging children’s pleasure in the days before the gifts are opened and after the wrapping’s been tossed away.

headline: Faster Rail Between Paris and Barcelona
text: After months of delays, a new high-speed rail service between Paris and Barcelona is underway. The first of the new route’s double-decker TGV trains took off from both the Gare de Lyon station in Paris and the Barcelona-Sants station on Sunday.

headline: A December Calculation by ‘August’
text: Updated, 10:20 a.m. | What a difference two days makes. At least, that seems to be the thinking at the Weinstein Company, which recently pushed back the release date of its “August: Osage County” to Dec. 27 from Christmas Day. There’s a lot of competition on the holiday: tentpole films (and potential awards competitors) like “Wolf of Wall Street” and “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty” also open then, on top of other high-profile, newish choices like “American Hustle,” “Saving Mr. Banks” and “Inside Llewyn Davis” already in theaters.

headline: Signs of Baby Steps on Stanching Wasteful Flaring of Natural Gas
text: I hope you’ll read “Applying Creativity to a Byproduct of Oil Drilling in North Dakota,” a valuable Clifford Krauss feature on baby steps taken by the oil and gas industry to stanch the wasteful, polluting flaring of natural gas from the country’s booming Bakken oil fields in North Dakota. (There’s no infrastructure for storing or transporting the gas and the oil is the quarry, given its much higher price.)

headline: ‘Iceman Cometh,’ With Nathan Lane, to Play Brooklyn Academy of Music
text: The Goodman Theater’s critically acclaimed production of “The Iceman Cometh,” which starred the Tony Award winners Nathan Lane and Brian Dennehy, will be remounted at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in early 2015 with the same cast and director from the Chicago run, according to a news release from the academy.

headline: Mrs. Porter Regrets, but Not Much
text: She knows why we’re there. It’s the whiff of gossip that lingers around her marriage to a composer who was both famous and famously gay.

headline: Paper or Plastic? Britain Joining Currency Trend
text: OTTAWA — It took only 900 years, but paper money is fading away.

headline: A Music Master and a Mensch
text: Cold weather, holiday-related exhaustion and a dearth of openings make for an ideal time to spend an evening on the couch, and with the PBS premiere of “Marvin Hamlisch: What He Did for Love,” you can still feed your cultural craving. The documentary, to be shown on Dec. 27, includes clips from interviews with Hamlisch, who died last year, as well as his wife, Terre Blair Hamlisch and several artists who worked with this multiple-award-winning composer.

headline: New Stars Named for McNally’s ‘Mothers and Sons’
text: The theater actors Frederick Weller (“Reasons to be Happy,” “Take Me Out”) and Bobby Steggert (“Big Fish”) will join Tony Award winner Tyne Daly on Broadway this winter in “Mothers and Sons,” a new play by Terrence McNally, the producers said on Wednesday.

headline: Hypertension Guidelines Can Be Eased, Panel Says
text: New guidelines suggest that people over 60 can have a higher blood pressure than previously recommended before starting treatment to lower it. The advice, criticized by some physicians, changes treatment goals that have been in place for more than 30 years.

headline: Budget Deal’s Impact Is Only a Blip
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: App Smart: Tracking Data Usage
text: A range of free and paid apps monitor data use and alert you when you have used too much.

headline: The Three Stooges Do Westminster
text: A couple of weeks ago I tried to get at what’s wrong with the latest tactic of the austerians in terms of a classic Three Stooges scene. Curly is seen banging his head against the wall; when Moe asks why, he replies, “Because it feels so good when I stop.”

headline: Data Cops Guard Against Excessive Charges
text: Data? Don’t talk to me about data. Mobile 4G data is the most expensive part of my smartphone habit. One recent morning, as I browsed Twitter in a coffee shop, everything stopped suddenly because I had already burned through the month’s data allowance. I had the option of waiting until January or paying about $4 for an extra 200 megabytes. Guess which I chose?

headline: Jones Group Nears Deal to Be Sold to Sycamore Partners
text: The private equity firm Sycamore Partners is closing in on a deal to buy the apparel company Jones Group for $15 a share, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Chemical Weapons Agency Unveils Plan for Destroying Syria’s Stockpile
text: GENEVA — Helped by a flurry of offers from Russia and China as well as the United States and European countries, the international watchdog agency overseeing the destruction of Syria’s chemical weapons unveiled details Wednesday of a multinational effort to get toxic agents out of the country but warned that the program faced delays.

headline: The Non-death Non-spiral
text: The glums of October, when the launch of healthcare.gov turned into a debacle, convinced many — in fact, just about all — conservatives that Obamacare was doomed, doomed, doomed. But the IT side is working much better — not as well as it should, but it’s getting there, and enrollment is rising fast.

headline: Shiite Pilgrimage Is Target of Attacks in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Shiite Muslims making one of their most important pilgrimages in Iraq were targeted again on Wednesday by gunmen and suicide bombers, medical and police officials said.

headline: After a Lengthy Battle, ‘Miles Davis Way’ Is Official
text: For about 25 years, until the mid-1980s, Miles Davis, the legendary jazz trumpeter who died in 1991, lived in an apartment building at 312 West 77th Street, where he enjoyed a well-established New York City tradition: loitering outside on the stoop, greeting passers-by and chatting with neighbors.

headline: Romania’s Overlooked New Wave
text: When it comes to the Oscar for best foreign-language film, Romania is a country that can’t get no respect. The Romanian “new wave” is one of the most significant developments in world cinema over the last decade, and Romanian films regularly walk away with top prizes at festivals like Cannes and Berlin. But no Romanian film has ever been nominated for an Oscar, and only one, Cristian Mungiu’s “Beyond the Hills,” released last year, has even been shortlisted.

headline: From Scientists, Gift Ideas for the Elderly
text: We tried, my sister and I. Every fall and winter, we discussed what extremely practical gift we should get our father for his September birthday and for Hanukkah. A flannel shirt, because his current two were fraying. A warm new sweater, because he disliked paying utility bills and always kept his apartment cool. A leather wallet, because his old one, stuffed with years of photos and credit cards and no-longer-relevant ID’s, was held together with rubber bands.

headline: Excerpt: 'Community'
text: The NBC sitcom returns in January with Dan Harmon, the series creator, back at the helm.

headline: Worry in Tunisia Over Youths Who Turn to Jihad
text: ZAGHOUAN, Tunisia — Hayet Saadi says the trouble with her son Aymen began more than a year ago, when he was just 16. He started attending the mosque five times a day, she said. Then he began talking of jihad, and of going to Syria to join the rebels fighting the government of President Bashar al-Assad. In March, he skipped his high school exams and left home.
