headline: Drug Maker’s Donations to Co-Pay Charity Face Scrutiny
text: As drug prices have soared in recent years and insurers have increased co-payments, a new type of charity has blossomed to fill a vital niche — helping patients pay the steep out-of-pocket costs for their medicines.

headline: Signs of Cracks in the Law of Jante
text: STOCKHOLM – For Sweden’s technology industry, championing individual success has never come easy.

headline: As Plaza Is Named for Champion of Downtown, Talk of a New Park
text: Elizabeth H. Berger, the president of the Downtown Alliance, was an unstoppable champion of Lower Manhattan, where she lived and worked for 30 years.

headline: Angst Rebooted for a New Season
text: LOS ANGELES — Dan Harmon entered an editing suite on the Paramount lot here, planning to cut a minute from an overlong episode of “Community.” Before he finished tinkering with its opening sequence, it was nearly another minute longer.

headline: New 49ers Stadium Will Be Built With Intel Guts
text: The San Francisco 49ers just advanced a little deeper into Silicon Valley.

headline: New Clef Plug-In Lets You Forget About Your Password
text: The future will be passwordless.

headline: How Dan Harmon Did, Or Did Not, Get His Groove Back at ‘Community’
text: LOS ANGELES — Just as Vince Gilligan will be forever associated with “Breaking Bad” and Shonda Rhimes embodies “Scandal,” Dan Harmon pretty much was and is “Community,” the intensely loved if not widely watched NBC comedy about quirky students at a community college — a show that seemingly could not exist without his intense passion and offbeat vision.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Mandela’
text: For Diana Cilliers, the recent death of Nelson Mandela was certainly very sad, but strangely enough, also inspiring.

headline: Baucus, Conflicted Architect of Health Overhaul, Is Obama’s Pick for China
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Max Baucus of Montana, soon to be nominated as President Obama’s next ambassador to China, is the powerful — and, to many fellow Democrats, infuriating — chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. He is also the conflicted architect of Mr. Obama’s health care law.

text: Common sense is catching up with the Bitcoin craze. In the process, it is bringing its backers financial losses and intellectual embarrassment.

headline: For Mothers-to-Be, Finding Health Care in a Group
text: Recently in a nondescript conference room near Union Square in Manhattan, eight very pregnant women, husbands, boyfriends and a sister sat in a circle around a small patchwork quilt for two hours and talked about managing the discomforts of pregnancy.

headline: Snowboarders Wait Out Storm
text: While Jeremy Jones and Bryan Iguchi readied for a descent of the Grand Teton, a spring storm hit Wyoming. As they waited for the storm to clear, the snowboarders embraced the snow.

headline: Video: Snowboarders Wait Out Storm Before Grand Descent
text: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: Doctor, Teacher, Soldier, Spy
text: In December 1863, a Union cavalry company escorted the disinterred remains of Dr. Rufus Gillpatrick through the streets of Lawrence, Kan., to Oread Cemetery, where they were reburied. Still marked with desolation from William Quantrill’s violent raid in August, the city remained an abolitionist stronghold and was a fitting final resting place for Dr. Gillpatrick. Although he had been, at times, a surgeon, politician, teacher, military adviser, reporter, farmer, soldier and spy, Gillpatrick was perhaps best known to contemporaries for the ardent opposition to slavery that ultimately cost him his life. His curious career and violent death illustrates the porous line between civilian and soldier on the frontier.

headline: Unleashing a Dogwalk Empire
text: Becky O'Neill of Alexandria, Va., started off walking one dog at a time. Today, her business posts $2.3 million in annual revenue.

headline: Outcry in Eastern Long Island Over a Plan to Cull Deer
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — It will happen after dark, with night sensors. The shooters will have noise suppressors on their rifles, so as not to disturb residents or alert the targets. They will operate mainly from elevated stands and wait for apples and corn to do their work. Nets might be deployed to capture the animals before they are shot, or as government officials prefer to say, “harvested.”

headline: Clip: 'The Desolation of Smaug'
text: A spider attack scene from the second installment in Peter Jackson's "Hobbit" trilogy.

headline: In Store | Acne Comes to Downtown L.A., Adds to the Neighborhood’s Growing Sex Appeal
text: For most Angelenos, Downtown L.A. is no longer up-and-coming: it came, it’s up. In addition to the Walt Disney Concert Hall and the Museum of Contemporary Art, it offers purveyors of omakase and organic cold-pressed green juice. There’s a Standard Hotel, and early next year there will be an Ace too. Yet no recent development in the once-dowdy district has felt quite as game-changing as the opening today of an Acne Studios flagship store there.

headline: 3 Things to Know About the New Blood Pressure Guidelines
text: The long-awaited new hypertension guidelines will change how we approach patients with high blood pressure. Here are three things you should know about them.

headline: Along Came a Computer-Generated ...
text: The latest installment in “The Hobbit” trilogy is likely to make arachnophobes squirm. That’s the hope of the director Peter Jackson, whose own fear of spiders helped infuse some important scenes in “The Desolation of Smaug” with creepy, crawly discomfort.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 16 Matchup Breakdown
text: Something we tell people all the time is not to overthink the matchups in fantasy football. Analyzing the matchups can help you make tough decisions between players of similar skill sets, but there are elite players who should be in lineups every week, players we like to call matchup proof.

headline: The Top 75 New York Times Best-Selling Education Books of 2013
text: Prof. Randy Pausch’s “last lecture,” a talk he gave at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh in 2007, was made into a book. Though it was published in 2008, that book still sells strongly enough that it is No. 5 on our 2013 Education Best-Sellers list, below .

headline: Classical Playlist: Leonard Bernstein, Keller Quartet, Cassandra Miller and More
text: BRAHMS: Symphony No. 4New York Philharmonic; Leonard Bernstein, conductor(Sony Classical)As I worked recently on a review of the new compilation of Leonard Bernstein’s letters, I went through a lot of his recordings. During that time I was listening to a version of Brahms’s Fourth Symphony that Sergiu Celibidache made with the Munich Philharmonic. Finding it excessively polite, I put on Bernstein’s savagely great take with his New York forces. It’s things like this that will ensure his legacy. (Zachary Woolfe)

headline: Here’s What My Company Will Pay for Health Insurance
text: On Friday of last week, I collected insurance sign-up forms from my employees. After all of the work I have done — including figuring out how to compare insurance-plan prices, and finding a plan that offers my employees a wide range of options, and explaining the changes to my employees — the decisions are in.

headline: House Hunting in Costa Rica
text: Prices in this Pacific resort area have begun rising again, particularly for properties under $450,000 and over $1 million.

headline: Toe Fossil Provides Complete Neanderthal Genome
text: Scientists have extracted the entire genome of a 130,000-year-old Neanderthal from a single toe bone in a Siberian cave, an accomplishment that far outstrips any previous work on Neanderthal genes.

headline: Below the Line: Designing ‘Her’
text: Some films shout their production design. Others keep it to a dull roar. “Her,” the new Spike Jonze romance about a man falling for his operating system, has a design scheme that is distinct but subtle. That’s the work of K. K. Barrett, who has helped create the many imaginative settings in Mr. Jonze’s movies, from the interiors of John Malkovich’s subconscious (“Being John Malkovich”) to the vast exteriors of a child’s imagination (“Where the Wild Things Are”). With “Her,” Mr. Barrett wanted to build a futuristic world with wide spaces inhabited by a lonely man.

headline: Obama Is Urged to Sharply Curb N.S.A. Data Mining
text: WASHINGTON — A panel of outside advisers urged President Obama on Wednesday to impose major oversight and some restrictions on the National Security Agency, arguing that in the past dozen years its powers had been enhanced at the expense of personal privacy.

headline: Amnesty Bill in Russia Could Free Activists
text: MOSCOW — An amnesty bill that seemed to promise freedom for defendants in some of Russia’s most politically charged criminal cases passed the lower house of Parliament on Wednesday. The two jailed  members of the punk protest group Pussy Riot and the 30 Greenpeace demonstrators  arrested at an Arctic offshore oil rig appeared to be among those likely to receive amnesty.

headline: Local Turf-Sharing Accord With the Taliban Raises Alarm in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Afghan Army commander stationed in the deadliest corner of Helmand Province brokered a cease-fire and turf-sharing deal with local Taliban insurgents there, according to government and police officials, in an example of the sort of ground-level bargaining that some see as increasingly likely once international troops withdraw next year.

headline: Updates on Bernanke and the Fed
text: The Federal Reserve’s policy making committee has concluded its last meeting of the year. In addition to its decision to taper its bond-buying program modestly, the Fed released its latest economic forecast, and Ben S. Bernanke, nearing the end of his term as Fed chairman, held a news conference. Here are the key points as the events unfolded.

text: Updated, 4:32 p.m. |

headline: Bitcoin, Nationless Currency, Still Feels Governments’ Pinch
text: If Bitcoin is a bubble, as its critics contend, it is showing signs of deflating.

headline: Cuomo Hires New York City’s Chief Digital Officer
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration has been credited for its eager embrace of technology. Now, as the mayor prepares to leave office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is hiring New York City’s chief digital officer to work for the state.

headline: My Half-Jewish Child Wants Christmas. I Don’t, Anymore.
text: I’m Jewish. My entire childhood, every year, my life fell apart in late November.

headline: Food Stamp Fraud, Rare but Troubling
text: IRWINTON, Ga. — In the back of Shinholster’s Grocery and Meat Market, they simmer pig skin and lard in an old black kettle. Hams from animals raised in the yard hang near an aging cash register.

headline: Why Big Airlines Fight With Small Airports
text: Proponents of mergers among the nation’s airlines love to spin tales about how consolidation will result in more stable and profitable companies in an industry known for bankruptcies. They say travelers will be able to fly to more destinations, and that workers at the airlines will enjoy better job security and compensation.

headline: Judge Rules Detroit Suburban Homeowner Should Stand Trial in Shooting Death of Renisha McBride
text: Updated 11:36 a.m., Thursday, Dec. 19 A Michigan judge ruled on Thursday morning that a white suburban Detroit homeowner should stand trial on charges of second-degree murder in the shooting death of a young black woman who banged on his door in the early-morning hours of Nov. 2 after she had been involved in a car accident.

headline: Fed to Start Unwinding Its Stimulus Next Month
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it would gradually end its bond-buying program during 2014, a modest first step toward unwinding the central bank’s broader stimulus campaign as its officials gain confidence that the economy is growing steadily.

headline: Republican Concedes in Virginia, Ending Recount in Attorney General Race
text: Mark D. Obenshain, the Republican candidate for attorney general of Virginia, conceded the race on Wednesday, halting a recount and handing Democrats possession of the top three statewide offices for the first time since 1993.

headline: Djokovic and Becker Form Star Tandem
text: In tennis these days, old stars do not fade away. They go on to coach new stars.

headline: Jury Convicts Wine Dealer in Fraud Case
text: A renowned wine dealer was convicted on Wednesday of defrauding some of the country’s wealthiest by selling bottles of purportedly rare and sought-after vintages that were counterfeit products of his own kitchen alchemy: mixing old bottles of wine and creating bogus labels.

headline: Talking Talent | Jeff Goldblum, Star of the Off-Broadway Play ‘Domesticated’
text: Best known for embodying diverse roles in films like “The Fly” and “The Big Chill,” Jeff Goldblum is currently making his Lincoln Center Theater debut in “Domesticated,” the Pulitzer- and Tony-winning writer Bruce Norris’s riveting exploration of gender, sexuality and love now playing at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. He plays Bill Pulver, a gynecologist turned politician whose private cheating scandal becomes a media circus. With Laurie Metcalf, who plays Bill’s wife, Judy, he masterfully take the audience through the family’s public humiliation and ensuing unraveling. When “Domesticated” closes next month, Goldblum will head back to his hometown of Los Angeles to resume his weekly jazz show at the bar Rockwell, and in March he will appear in Wes Anderson’s new ensemble film, “The Grand Budapest Hotel.”

headline: Wanted: Wiggle Room
text: Dr. Michael Warren had a complicated relationship with his condominium in the meatpacking district.

headline: Knicks Get a Much-Needed Victory, Albeit a Frustrating One
text: MILWAUKEE — In a season that has been abysmal for the Knicks, Wednesday began with a bit of good news and a much-needed break when they arrived at BMO Harris Bradley Center. Tyson Chandler, the 7-footer who provides a steady presence in the lane and in the locker room, returned to the lineup after missing 20 games with a broken right fibula. The Bucks’ leading scorer, O. J. Mayo, missed the game to attend the funeral of his grandmother.

headline: Immigration Remakes and Sustains New York, Report Finds
text: He arrived in the United States in 1988, an uneducated 21-year-old from rural Fujian Province, China. With the help of smugglers he made his way to Chinatown in Lower Manhattan, found work in a variety of restaurants and, in time, managed to get a green card.

headline: Final Appraisal of Detroit Institute Art to Be Released Thursday
text: A detailed appraisal of the market value of many of the masterpieces hanging in the Detroit Institute of Arts has been completed by Christie’s auction house, which was hired by Detroit’s emergency manager to put price tags on the works for a possible sale to help the city, now in federal bankruptcy, pay back billions in debt.

headline: Ex-BP Worker Is Found Guilty of Obstruction in Gulf Spill
text: HOUSTON — Nearly four years after the Gulf of Mexico oil rig explosion that left 11 dead, a former low-level engineer at BP was found guilty on Wednesday of obstruction of justice for deleting messages during a federal investigation into how much oil leaked.

headline: Vodafone Says Its British Tax Bill Shrank Last Year
text: LONDON — The British telecommunications operator Vodafone, which has had disputes with the British authorities over its tax payments, said Wednesday that it had paid 19 percent less in the 12 months to March 31 than it had in the previous year.

headline: Decoding the Fed’s Statement
text: The statement Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions.

headline: Europe’s Start-Up Superstar
text: While Berlin and London have grabbed headlines for their technology scenes, Stockholm has recently emerged as one of Europe’s hottest start-up capitals.

headline: Elance and oDesk Merge Their Employment Clouds
text: Online employment remains something of a work in progress.

headline: Employers Shouldn’t Care About Credit Histories
text: People who end up with damaged credit — often through no fault of their own — can be shut out of jobs by employers who hold their credit histories against them.

headline: The Gun Report: December 18, 2013
text: * Damien Fields, 39, who was shot six times in the chest and killed on a Jersey City, N.J., street Friday evening, was remembered by his sister-in-law as the family’s peacemaker. Which was quite a feat, as he was one of 18 children.

headline: European Officials Agree on Plan for Failed Banks
text: BRUSSELS — European Union finance officials agreed late Wednesday on a system for winding down failed banks, an important step toward introducing a banking union.

headline: Rare Close Win for Knicks, but Not a Work of Art
text: Nothing shapes the perceptions of N.B.A. players and coaches more than how they perform at the end of close games, a time commonly referred to as the clutch. These heightened moments of drama are replayed ad nauseam on TV and in the minds of fans. The big shots may be worth the same number of points as those taken in the first quarter, but the narrative of the game lends them an oversize importance.

headline: It’s ‘Beyoncé’ at No. 1
text: Beyoncé’s surprise album hit a couple of milestones on Wednesday: it was certified a No. 1 hit by Billboard, and its sales crossed the one million mark.

headline: Former SAC Trader Is Convicted of Insider Trading
text: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | Prosecutors lacked the incriminating wiretaps that underpinned past insider trading cases. The emails pointed to no smoking gun. And the government’s star witness, a felon who testified to avoid prison time, fumbled his way through five days of cross-examination.

headline: Cynthia Eagle Russett, Chronicler of Women’s History, Dies at 76
text: Cynthia Eagle Russett, a historian whose best-known book explored attempts by Victorian thinkers to scientifically “prove” women’s inferiority, died on Dec. 5 in New Haven. She was 76.

headline: Presidential Advisory Committee’s Recommendations for N.S.A.
text: On Wednesday, a review board issued more than 40 suggested changes at the National Security Agency.

headline: Social Conservatives and Social Science
text: In a foray with some relevance to my last post on the social science surrounding premarital sex, Bryan Caplan wonders about what he calls “the curious absence of socially conservative economics.” Noting that “academic economists range from liberal to libertarian,” he asks: “What can we learn from conservative economics’ failure to launch?” One possibility, he allows, is that social conservatism simply doesn’t have any solid economic arguments behind it, but that “has an obvious problem: Rationalizing social conservatism using Econ 101 is child’s play.  Just close your eyes, tap your heels three times, and say ‘Negative externalities.'” (From risky sex, drug and alcohol use, family breakdown, etc.) And yet, Caplan says, “almost no social conservative bothers to make [economic] arguments. Why don’t they?”

headline: Germany Defends Surcharge Exemptions
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany vowed Wednesday to fight a European Union investigation into her government’s policy of exempting hundreds of companies from a surcharge on electricity that is used to promote renewable resources.

headline: U.S. Prosecutor Defends Arrest of Indian Diplomat
text: The federal prosecutor whose decision to charge an Indian diplomat in New York City last week touched off a furor in India made an unusual and robust public defense of that decision on Wednesday night, saying “there can be no plausible claim that this case was somehow unexpected or an injustice.”

headline: Report Detail Could Further Implicate Syria in Chemical Attack, Analysts Say
text: UNITED NATIONS — Buried in the annex of a United Nations inquiry into chemical weapons use in Syria is information that some outside analysts say could further implicate the government of Syria in the deadliest of the five confirmed attacks.

headline: For 2015, the All-New Mercedes-Benz C-Class Grows
text: Mercedes-Benz announced this week that it would introduce an all-new version of the compact C-Class for 2015. Since 2007, when the previous C-Class was released, the automaker says it has sold more than 2.4 million units, making it Mercedes’s best-selling model.

headline: The Newest New Yorkers 2013 Edition
text: A new report by the City Planning Department provides a detailed statistical analysis of New York City’s ever-shifting immigrant population.

headline: Q. & A. With Liping Ma
text: Liping Ma, a former teacher and principal in China, has written extensively about the differences between how the United States and China teach math to elementary school students. After earning a doctorate in curriculum and teacher education from Stanford University, she worked as a senior scholar at the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. In 1999, she published “Knowing and Teaching Elementary Mathematics,” an influential book that argues elementary school teachers need a better grounding in arithmetic and math in order to teach them effectively to their students. She currently works as an independent researcher. Dr. Ma spoke recently with Vikas Bajaj of The New York Times editorial board about her research and why Chinese and other Asian students score well above their American counterparts on international math tests.

headline: Ask Well: Sterilizing Baby Bottles?
text: Your mother and grandmother may have sterilized baby bottles, but the American Academy of Pediatrics says that is no longer necessary.

headline: Was the Dasani Series Unfair to Bloomberg, as His Deputies Charge?
text: I wrote last week about an unusual five-part series on a homeless girl, Dasani, in Brooklyn — the largest investigation The Times has published all at once in its history — praising it as moving and important.

headline: 36 Hours in Jackson Hole, Wyo.
text: Ever since the first French fur trappers crossed into Jackson Hole from the area that is now Yellowstone National Park in the early 19th century, visitors have been flabbergasted by the majestic beauty of this flat plain fenced in by snow-clad peaks soaring a mile up from the valley floor, including the now iconic 13,770-foot Grand Teton. Jackson Hole and its slopes are more accessible than ever, with direct flights from Newark, Denver, Houston, Dallas/Fort Worth, Minneapolis, Chicago, Atlanta, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Salt Lake City, and a recent overhaul of Jackson Hole Mountain Resort’s lift system. But there is also plenty on the valley floor to grab your attention, including vast wilderness reserves where deer and the buffalo roam. Add to that Jackson, an old-school cowboy town with lots of new panache, the bohemian log cabin village of Wilson and the luxurious modern facilities of Teton Village, and you’ve got a weekend where true-West sensibilities and wilderness adventures are balanced by comfort and style.

headline: Scenes From Jackson Hole, Wyo.
text: Hit the slopes, go for a bite and take in the views.

headline: Age Is Just a Number When You’re Solving Crime
text: My timing’s not ideal, jumping into Christopher Fowler’s Peculiar Crimes Unit series with its 10th installment, “The Invisible Code.” But better late than never. Perhaps it’s sufficient explanation of the series’s allure to say that when Mr. Fowler first conceived it, he planned to write about “a pair of intelligent Golden Age detectives who are forced to deal with the modern world.” He was advised to make them younger and to add more sex and violence, but his strengths are humor and Holmesian cogitation, and he stuck with them. He was right. One book in the series won an award for the funniest mystery novel of 2008.

headline: The Year In Pictures
text: A look back at 2013.

headline: Budget Vote Passes the Details to Two Panels
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate’s final passage Wednesday of a two-year, bipartisan budget plan handed the nuts-and-bolts task of funding the government to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees, a mixed blessing for Republican appropriators who relish the chance to direct billions of dollars in federal money but must contend with a political right flank that is critical of government spending and eager to attack.

headline: A Taste of German Christmas Markets
text: As a boy, the chef and restaurateur Hans Röckenwagner looked forward to late November, when the Weihnachtsmarkt (Christmas market) would open in his home village of Schliengen, in southern Germany.

headline: More Employees Depart SAC Capital as Firm Shifts Focus
text: The slow exodus of traders and analysts continues from SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund founded by Steven A. Cohen.

headline: Guggenheim Rotunda Is Garlanded With Sound
text: It’s been a tough season for George Steel, the general manager and artistic director of the beleaguered New York City Opera, which shut down recently after 70 years because of financial problems. But the Vox Vocal Ensemble — which Mr. Steel founded and which often performed at the Miller Theater during his successful tenure as executive director there — is flourishing.

headline: Wireless Speakers Let Music Roam Free
text: You may have noticed the spate of new wireless audio speakers on the market, many of them marketed to be sold in multiples and placed throughout the house. For the speaker companies, it isn’t all about function and audio science: their priority is to sell you five or six speakers at a time. Your priority should be to figure out what you want from music.

headline: The Fragile Courtship of Unicorns
text: The current Broadway revival of “The Glass Menagerie” has won rave reviews for John Tiffany’s dreamy, minimalist staging and the performances of Cherry Jones and Zachary Quinto as the onetime Southern belle Amanda Wingfield and her rebellious son, Tom. But there have been also exceptional notices for the two lesser-known young actors who round out the cast: Celia Keenan-Bolger, who plays Tom’s disabled, beyond-painfully shy sister, Laura, and Brian J. Smith as Jim, who arrives in the second act as her first, and presumably last, gentleman caller.

headline: Ask Well: How to Clean Baby Bottles
text: Question:

headline: A Tribute Evening, but With No Goodbye at the End
text: “Sometimes we like to celebrate people while they are still agile,” said Robert Battle, the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, at City Center on Tuesday. He was explaining that although the evening’s program celebrating the dancer Matthew Rushing was the kind of event usually given to a retiring artist, Mr. Rushing is not retiring yet.

headline: Soft Ballads Wrapped in a Seasonal Fervor
text: As I listened to Michael Feinstein’s beautiful, overarching renditions of two ballads whose titles begin with the word “if” on Tuesday evening at Birdland, I reflected on how much tougher and more complicated pop music has become in the decades since they were written.

headline: Harvard Student Accused of Bomb Hoax to Avoid Final Exam Appears Before Judge
text: A federal magistrate agreed to release a 20-year-old Harvard student from Washington State on a $100,000 bond Wednesday during a hearing on charges that he made bomb threats to avoid a final exam, according to a statement from the United States attorney’s office in Boston.

headline: A Rare View of Strauss in a Very Devilish Mood
text: The musicologist and conductor Leon Botstein has made a career out of championing works that have been overlooked or neglected. On Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, he conducted a rarely performed one-act comic opera by Richard Strauss, “Feuersnot” (“In Need of Fire”), written 1900-01 as an indictment of Munich and what he saw as the provincialism of its inhabitants — a narrow-mindedness, he felt, that stood in the way of their appreciating both Wagner’s and his own genius.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, South Sudan, Greece and Ukraine.

headline: Excerpt From Ben Bernanke’s Statement
text: Mr. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, announced that the Fed would scale back the stimulus, saying the economy had made progress but still had “much farther to travel.”

headline: Martin Fleisher Is Bridge League’s Player of the Year
text: The American Contract Bridge League’s Player of the Year title goes to the winner of the most platinum master points at the three North American championships. These points are awarded only in the major national events.

headline: Obama Said to Pick Montana Democrat as China Envoy
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to nominate Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, as his next ambassador to China, according to three officials familiar with the pending announcement.

headline: Adapting Big Questions for the Screen
text: John Ridley, the screenwriter of “12 Years a Slave,” wrote the script on spec. In 2008, Mr. Ridley, who had had a decent career ranging from novelist and sitcom writer (“Martin,” “The Wanda Sykes Show”) to feature gun for hire, sat down with Steve McQueen, the British artist then making a transition to filmmaking. Mr. McQueen introduced him to the 1853 book by Solomon Northup, the memoir of his abduction into slavery. Its voice and detail took Mr. Ridley by surprise.

headline: A Diversity of ‘Nutcrackers’
text: Institutions have been known to award a best “Nutcracker” prize. I wonder how on earth they make their choice. You have only to watch the “Nutcracker Suite” section of the 1940 Disney animated movie “Fantasia” to see how choreographic imagery in response to Tchaikovsky’s music can flourish while utterly unconnected to the story he was envisioning.

headline: Barneys: Coming Around Again
text: Twenty years after it decamped to its shiny bauble of a store on Madison Avenue, and 17 years after leaving its landmark Chelsea location in the hands of a discount retailer and later a museum specializing in the art of the Himalayas, Barneys New York is heading back home.

headline: Italian Art Center to Open in Manhattan in February
text: A new foundation to promote Italian modern and contemporary art plans to open its doors to the public in SoHo in February. For its inaugural exhibition, the foundation, called the Center for Italian Modern Art and located at 421 Broome Street, will feature work of the Futurist artist and designer Fortunato Depero, who once lived in New York. The show will coincide with a scheduled exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum, “Italian Futurism 1909 – 1944: Reconstructing the Universe.”

headline: Art-Scene Glimpses, Lost Then Found
text: The black-and-white images from the 1960s immediately evoke an era of experimentation and ebullience on the art scene: Andy Warhol clutching a bouquet at a gallery opening; Yayoi Kusama lying on a sculptural love seat at the height of her first American fame; naked women covered in blue paint rolling on paper to create an image for Yves Klein, while musicians play in the background.

text: “Americans do not support an egalitarian society.”

headline: A Final Swerve From Ronaldinho?
text: It may have been his last game of signficance on the world stage.

headline: Video: In San Francisco, Wearable Recyclables
text: The San Francisco Mission District is known for its music scene, dive bars and colorful street art. Jai Carrillo, a hairstylist who lives in the area, sometimes draws inspiration from the color in the area’s many murals.  Fashion can be like performance art, he said, while sporting a white crochet shirt, black shorts, lace-up boots and a studded fanny pack that he made from an old purse.

headline: Scrooge Has a Sense of Humor
text: Last week, Jackie Hoffman stood in the bitter cold at Rockefeller Center and soaked in the scene. It was noon on a weekday. As excited tourists took selfies, ice skaters glided and fell on the rink below and a pack of transfixed schoolchildren looked up at the brilliantly lit towering Christmas tree, Ms. Hoffman gave voice to millions of already holiday-weary New Yorkers: “This is like the Bataan Death March.”

headline: Scene City: Club Kids Spread Holiday Cheer
text: Susanne Bartsch and David Barton host their 11th annual holiday toy drive.

headline: Uninsured Struggling Before and After the Health Law
text: Many Americans without health insurance struggle to pay for basic medical care, but they disapprove of the president’s health law at about the same rate as the insured.

headline: Uninsured Skeptical of Health Care Law in Poll
text: WASHINGTON — Americans who lack medical coverage disapprove of President Obama’s health care law at roughly the same rate as the insured, even though most say they struggle to pay for basic care, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on 1,606 telephone interviews conducted Dec. 4 through Dec. 15 with adults throughout the United States.

headline: Times Minute | New Poll on Health Care
text: Also on the Minute, Americans opting for the health care tax penalty and upcoming dates to watch.

text: In the Video

headline: The Latest New York Times/CBS News Polling Results
text: Uninsured Americans disapprove of President Obama’s health care law at nearly the same rate as those with health insurance, the new poll shows.

headline: Target Investigates Breach Involving Credit Card Data
text: UPDATED | Target confirmed Thursday morning that data was stolen from 40 million shoppers.

headline: Giving New Meaning to ‘Gin and Juice’
text: Cold-pressed juices are not just for cleanses anymore.

headline: The Best of Two Seasons
text: In a swirl of extravagant costumes, tiara-crested drag queens and disco records, Susanne Bartsch and David Barton hosted their annual holiday toy drive at the Soho Grand Hotel on Tuesday night.

headline: The New Skinny on Brooklyn
text: YOU’RE FRENCH. Well, probably not, but you would like to be, right? There’s plenty to recommend it: the high metabolism, the contentious press, the sauces.

headline: Hibernate? Look Good in the Cave
text: In the lane, snow is glistening — but the wind, it’s freezing. The holidays may be the time to gussy up and go out, but many of us may be more tempted by a marathon viewing of Season 3 of “Homeland” or “Game of Thrones.” So why not gussy up for that? Giving a cold shoulder to winter’s chill is all the more glamorous and guilt-free when you look good doing it. Start with these laid-back options. And if you open the door to find a pack of carolers instead of your Chinese food delivery, you’re good.

headline: The Shunk-Kender Archive
text: An art foundation is giving away 200,000 images from one of the great archives of photography documenting 20th-century artists.

headline: A Hunk of Metal, a Chunk of Clout
text: Like other 20-somethings with big dreams but little cash, Billy McFarland, a college dropout turned entrepreneur from New Jersey, wanted a shortcut to the good life.

headline: A Woman’s Fantasy in a Modern Reality
text: In 1973, Erica Jong exploded onto the literary scene with “Fear of Flying,” her chronicle of the soul-searching, sensuality-seeking adventures of an intellectual young poet named Isadora Wing during a business trip with her second husband to a psychoanalysts’ conference in Vienna.

headline: Kings of Leon and ‘August: Osage County’
text: The Kings of Leon contributed a song, “Last Mile Home,” for the film that is eligible for an Oscar.

headline: Inmates Helping Inmates
text: MILWAUKEE — IT’S the singular guest at a prison who receives a standing ovation from inmates. I’ve heard of only two: Johnny Cash and Percy Pitzer, a retired warden who in 2012 started a nonprofit corporation to award college scholarships to children of inmates.

headline: The President of the Cool
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — WHEN I lived in New York during the early 1960s, John F. Kennedy was a hero among the downtown art crowd — not because of any legislative or foreign policy achievement, but because he pardoned the jazz pianist Hampton Hawes.

headline: Migrants Don’t Need More Rights
text: OXFORD, England — CAN you have too many rights? It sounds like a bizarre notion. But in the case of migrants, there may be something to it.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: How Alleged Harvard Hoaxer Didn’t Cover Digital Tracks, and Hackers on Front Lines
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: How Do I Make Wood Floors Appeal to Buyers?
text: Q. My wood floors are in desperate need of refinishing. What colors and finishes will appeal most to buyers?

headline: Defining Moments and Crystal Stairs
text: In June of 1998 in Jasper, Tex., just about three hours southeast of where I was raised, where the Lone Star State pushes itself into the back of the boot shape of Louisiana, a black man named James Byrd Jr. was subjected to what folks called a “lynching-by-dragging.”

headline: It’s Sure to Make You Reflective
text: Makeup mirrors reflect one another across a gallery at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in “Metropolitan Vanities: The History of the Dressing Table.” The exhibition, which opened this week, proves that no civilization is above a little primping.

headline: Growth in U.S. Health Care Spending Slows
text: It is a sweeping trend that should mean bigger paychecks for middle-class households and hundreds of billions of dollars in savings for the government. Yet only one in 20 Americans is aware of it.

headline: An ‘Arab Idol’ Wows His Fans in America
text: CHICAGO — A year ago, Mohammed Assaf was a 23-year-old wedding singer in a Gaza refugee camp. But since he won the “Arab Idol” singing competition in June, in front of more than 100 million viewers, he has become something of a pop superstar in the Arab world.

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Visual Album’ Fashions
text: When Beyoncé dropped her surprise album, fans were not only treated to 14 new songs and 17 new videos, but also dozens of new looks — some by the stylist B. Akerlund.

headline: Trimmed, Themed Trees Galore
text: Delores Nunn, who lives in Yorktown, Va., recently finished decorating 15 artificial trees, each according to a theme, for her home.

headline: Santa May Need a Map
text: This week it was reported that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York and his girlfriend, Sandra Lee, are displaying eight Christmas trees in their home. They’ve got nothing on Delores Nunn, who is 59 and lives in Yorktown, Va. Ms. Nunn recently finished decorating 15 artificial trees for the house she shares with her husband, James, a retired Army colonel. Each tree is trimmed according to a theme, including nuns, travel, sock monkeys, the beach, wine and nature. A small dog-themed tree sits near the food bowl of Mazie, the couple’s springer spaniel-poodle mix. “I’m sure there are people who do 20 trees, but they can’t get more enjoyment out of it than I do,” she told a reporter who visited last month.

headline: First on the List, a Blank
text: All of a sudden, Ugg boots were everywhere. Knee-high Hunter rain boots also seemed to sprout from the ground directly onto millions of American feet. And last year, denim in the colors of Skittles candies, like green and red, were inescapable.

headline: Gifts Enable Blind Man Who Survived Subway Fall to Keep Aging Guide Dog
text: For over seven years, Cecil Williams and his guide dog, Orlando, have been inseparable companions, the dog leading his master onto buses and subway cars and through the everyday flood of pedestrians along the streets of New York.

headline: Following the Vapor Trail
text: At a recent party in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, as a joint was passed around casually, talk turned to the relative subtlety of vaporizers as a delivery mechanism for marijuana.

headline: A Stylist for Beyoncé
text: B. Akerlund was responsible for Beyoncé’s looks in 4 of the 17 new videos in the performer’s self-titled “visual album.”

headline: Caribbean Travelers Warned About Mosquito-Borne Illness
text: Travelers to the Caribbean island of St. Martin are being warned that, for the first time, a mosquito-borne illness called chikungunya has been detected there. Chikungunya causes fever, headache and severe joint pains that last about a week, and sometimes longer. There is no vaccine, so the only prevention is to avoid mosquito bites, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Wednesday. So far, 10 cases have been confirmed in St. Martin, and health officials believe the virus is present in the island’s mosquito populations — the first time that it appears to have established itself anywhere in the Western Hemisphere. Previous outbreaks have occurred in Africa, Asia and parts of Europe.

headline: Samsung’s Video Campaign Pits Earth’s Soccer Stars vs. Aliens
text: TO promote its Galaxy mobile devices, Samsung Electronics is taking, fittingly, a galactic approach, with an international marketing campaign that blends science fiction with soccer fandom.

headline: Recommended Changes to the N.S.A.
text: After months of disclosures on the data-gathering practices of the National Security Agency, a presidential</br>advisory committee submitted 46 recommendations for the agency’s operations to President Obama.

headline: Brazil Snubs Boeing in Fighter Jet Deal
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — In a disappointment for Boeing, Brazilian defense officials said on Wednesday that they had picked the aircraft maker Saab for a $4.5 billion contract to build 36 fighter jets over the next 10 years.

headline: What Would Beyoncé Wear? She Knows
text: “Yesterday I woke up and it was Beyoncé, all day,” said the stylist B. Akerlund by phone on Monday from her native Sweden, where she had returned for the holidays just as the star was releasing her new self-titled album on the Internet, produced with a perhaps unprecedented canny stealth and selling a record 828,773 units worldwide in less than three days. “People actually went kind of crazy about it.”

headline: New York City Students Show Slight Gains on Test Scores
text: New York City public school students posted tiny gains this year on the bulk of federal academic tests that were last administered in 2011, though the city’s fourth graders showed no growth at all in reading scores over the last two years.

headline: F.C.C. Seeks to Do Away With Sports Blackout Rule
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday proposed repealing its blackout rule, which for decades has been the bane of sports fans whose ability to watch their favorite team’s home games on television has depended on whether enough of their fellow fans bought tickets to see it in person.

headline: The Fantasy, Then the Fashion
text: TIM WALKER IS a listener, taking in conversational cues and stray bits of wisdom with a mind that whirs incessantly, much like the camera he carries wherever he goes.

headline: Leafy Charm in a Home for Fish
text: Despite its name, the Tree Vase was meant to be a home for fish. Its designer, Vanessa Mitrani, who is based near Paris, set out to create an unusual aquarium and thought of putting a tree into the scenery. Her early vision was of “a tree growing in a sort of cave on the side,” she said, “and something else going on below, with either fish or flowers.”

headline: A No-Sweat Work Shirt? No Sweat
text: Kevin Lavelle, then 19, was working as an intern in Washington when he saw a congressional staff member rush into a meeting wearing a shirt that was soaked with sweat. “He looked terrible,” Mr. Lavelle, now 27, recently recalled.

headline: Rangel Is Expected to Seek 23rd Term in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — Charles B. Rangel, the venerable but embattled congressman from Harlem, will announce on Thursday that he is running for a 23rd term, according to a colleague in the New York House delegation.

headline: Parlor Game
text: When Pilar Proffitt and Robert Bristow, of the design firm Poesis, renovated No. 9, a hotel in Millerton, N.Y., they built a full-scale prototype of the new parlor in their Connecticut studio. Pulling together tables and artwork that Mr. Bristow had made, along with a sofa and a dusty-rose palette, they charmed Taryn and Tim Cocheo, the inn’s new owners. “We love it, and let’s just move it all in,” Ms. Proffitt recalled them saying.

headline: Health Insurers Extend Deadline for First Premiums
text: Insurance companies, worried about potential chaos next month as people begin seeking coverage under the federal health care law without completing the necessary paperwork, have agreed to give consumers an extra 10 days to pay their first-month premiums, according to a statement from the companies’ trade group on Wednesday.

headline: Rope That Yaks Can Be Proud of
text: When you’re a textile artist praised for lush floor coverings, there is only one way to go, and that is up. Earlier this month, at Ralph Pucci’s Miami showroom, the felt maestro Dana Barnes showed her evolving collection of sculptural columns called Cling.

headline: Egypt Accuses Morsi of Vast Terrorist Plot
text: CAIRO — The military-backed government filed new criminal charges on Wednesday against Mohamed Morsi, the deposed president, accusing him of participating in an epic terrorist plot that involved killing protesters and leaking state secrets to the Iranian Revolutionary Guards.

headline: When Novelty Is the Lure
text: Annie Jimenez, 26, who works at the T-Mobile store on West 34th Street, was the first of about 70 women waiting to buy Rihanna’s RiRi Hearts collection for MAC cosmetics at Macy’s Herald Square one morning his fall.

headline: Fashion Designers’ Limited-Edition Beauty Products
text: Some of the most notable limited editions in cosmetics this season are collaborations with fashion designers. Even if the products are not ones you use every day, the packaging is decidedly better than average.

headline: King Cole Bar and Salon at the St. Regis Hotel
text: Since its inception in 1948, the King Cole bar at the St. Regis hotel has been the redoubt of a certain Upper East Side set who like their drinks stiff, jackets quilted and daughters educated at Brearley. But earlier this year, the bar underwent a multimillion dollar renovation, and John Delucie, who specializes in resurrecting institutions like Ye Waverly Inn and Bill’s Gay Nineties, took over. In November, it reopened as the King Cole Bar and Salon. Mr. Delucie brought his night life cachet, a war chest of regulars and a younger crowd that buzzes later than before. Even old King Cole, who is depicted in the giant mural behind the bar, seems like a new man, now that years of dust and grit have been removed.

headline: Shopping Events in New York City Starting Dec. 18
text: Openings

headline: Sales at Ann Gish, Fishs Eddy and Others
text: Alice Goldsmith ceramics are up to 75 percent off, through Saturday (a four-piece bowl set, regularly $150, is $65; vases, regularly $75, are $30); 603 Bergen Street (Vanderbilt Avenue), No. 104, Brooklyn; 718-636-2248, alicegoldsmithceramics.com.

headline: Whole Foods Won’t Sell Chobani Greek Yogurt as of Early Next Year
text: Together, Whole Foods and Chobani have become two of the biggest success stories in the food business in the last decade, but now they are parting ways.

headline: Bloomberg and de Blasio Offer Clashing Views on Fiscal Future
text: Talk about a tale of two cities.

headline: Candy Crush and Mr. Christie
text: For the past couple of months I have been in the thrall of a game called Candy Crush Saga.

headline: The Laptop: Cheaper but Still a Workhorse
text: When people think about mobile computing these days, chances are they’re thinking about smartphones and tablets.

headline: Plan Would Ban Fighting in Top U.S. Amateur Hockey Leagues
text: USA Hockey’s board of directors will consider a proposal next month to ban fighting from all levels of amateur hockey in the United States.

headline: Wall Street Sees Hollywood as a Gateway to Sports and Entertainment
text: Two years ago, Egon Durban, a senior private equity executive, floated an idea with the co-chief executives of the William Morris Endeavor talent agency: Had they considered making a run at IMG, a 53-year-old peer with complementary businesses?

headline: Life Expectancy of New Yorkers Rises With Influx of Immigrants, Study Finds
text: A stunning increase in the life expectancy of New Yorkers over the past 20 years, compared with the rest of the country, has been driven by sharp declines in deaths from AIDS, homicide, smoking-related illnesses and, in a surprising twist, an increase in the numbers of immigrants, a new study has found.

headline: Minnesota Becomes Fourth State to Lose Chief of Exchange
text: The director of Minnesota’s health insurance exchange, April Todd-Malmlov, abruptly resigned this week, making the exchange the fourth state program to see a leadership change in the midst of mounting criticism over the rollout of President Obama’s new health care law.

headline: A Classicist at Rest
text: How does a classical architect decorate at home? Modern all the way.

headline: The Closet Modernist
text: If you study the residential work of Allan Greenberg — all those colonnaded front porches, Palladian windows and formally landscaped lots with stables and grand driveways — a theme emerges. You’d expect to find the architect himself living in equally classical surroundings, perhaps in Virginia horse country or among the hedge-fund set in Connecticut.

headline: Pennsylvania Governor Supports Anti-Bias Bill
text: PHILADELPHIA — Gov. Tom Corbett of Pennsylvania has thrown his support behind a state bill that would ban discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation, adding unexpected support from a Republican who once said gay marriage was the equivalent of a brother marrying a sister.

headline: Questions Linger After Death of Yale Teacher in Police Custody
text: When Samuel See was found dead in a New Haven jail cell last month, nine hours after being put there after a domestic dispute with his husband, the question was how did he die, a disquieting mystery that remains unsolved.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 18, 2013
George Rodrigue, Painter of Blue Dog, Dies at 69
text: George Rodrigue’s career as an artist started with dark and lush landscapes of his native Louisiana bayou. But it shifted abruptly, and profitably, when he began a series of portraits of a single subject: a melancholy mutt that came to be known as Blue Dog.

headline: An Epidemic of Attention Deficit Disorder
text: The hard-sell campaign by drug companies to drive up diagnoses of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., and sales of drugs to treat it is disturbing. The campaign focused initially on children but is now turning toward adults, who provide a potentially larger market.

headline: A Cat Woman’s Lair
text: If there is a stylish product made for cats, chances are Kate Benjamin owns it or has written about it. Or both.

headline: Cool for Cats
text: PHOENIX — If there is a stylish product made for cats, chances are Kate Benjamin owns it or has written about it. Or both.

headline: Olympics Invite Trouble When Politics Drive Choices
text: Less than two months before the opening ceremony of the Sochi Olympics, the 2014 Winter Games are making headlines again, but — as usual — the big news is not about the athletes or the competitions. It’s about politics.

headline: Tunisia’s Reawakening
text: Three years ago, a 26-year-old fruit vendor named Mohamed Bouazizi set himself ablaze in the central Tunisian town of Sidi Bouzid after being shaken down and humiliated by corrupt local officials, setting off an outpouring of anger across the Arab world against tyrannical regimes. But what was hailed as the Arab Spring soon disintegrated into dismal and violent sequels, most notably in Libya, Egypt and Syria.

headline: For Army Football, a Duty to Win Again
text: No one wanted Army to beat Navy more than Rich Ellerson did. Coaching at Army was his dream job. His father was a West Point graduate and a career military officer, as were two of his brothers. One of them, John, was a captain of the 1962 team. Ellerson’s son Andrew is a cadet and the Black Knights’ long snapper.

headline: Eyad El-Sarraj, Psychiatrist Who Fought for Palestinians’ Rights, Dies at 70
text: Eyad El-Sarraj, a Palestinian psychiatrist who pioneered mental health care in Gaza and became an internationally recognized human rights advocate, criticizing both the Israeli and Palestinian authorities, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Israel. He was 70.

headline: Metro-North Railroad Time Sheets Were Falsified, Inquiry Says
text: Metro-North Railroad foremen and repair crews have repeatedly falsified time sheets, spent large stretches of work days running personal errands and misused agency-issued vehicles, according to an investigation by the inspector general for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

headline: Turn Off the Data Vacuum
text: In the days after one of the biggest national security leaks in United States history revealed the existence of vast, largely unchecked government surveillance programs, President Obama said he would “welcome” a robust national debate over the appropriate balance between protecting national security and respecting individual privacy and civil liberties.

headline: The Ambassador of Spanish Ham
text: Florencio Sanchidrián is said to be one of the world’s great cortadors de jamon, or Iberian ham cutters. Cutting ham is not just a profession, but an art, and Mr. Sanchidrián shows how it is done.

headline: Günther Förg, German Artist Who Made Modernism His Theme, Dies at 61
text: Günther Förg, a German painter, sculptor and photographer whose work exemplified, toyed with, tweaked and commented on — sometimes all at once — the broad artistic movement known as modernism, died at his home in Freiburg, Germany, on Dec. 5, his 61st birthday.

headline: Spreading Spain’s Glory in Thin, Slow Slices
text: MADRID — On a recent morning, Florencio Sanchidrián was showing a class of 20 hostelry students just why he believes that 50 percent of the value of a leg of Spanish cured ham depends on how well it gets sliced.

headline: In Their Trailer, a Man Takes Care of His Father
text: The Beers property is the one with the muddy and uneven grounds, and the small nondescript house with the Sandpiper trailer parked beside it.

headline: I Found Myself in a Dark Wood
text: “In the middle of our life’s journey, I found myself in a dark wood.”

headline: Turkey Jailing the Most Journalists
text: For the second consecutive year, Turkey is imprisoning more journalists than any other country, according to a report from the Committee to Protect Journalists released Wednesday. Turkey was followed by Iran and China; the three countries account for more than half of the 211 journalists jailed worldwide as of Dec. 1. The number of journalists killed and imprisoned fell in 2013, but the year was the second worst for the number of imprisoned since record keeping began in 1990; the worst was last year, when 232 were held. The report said 52 journalists were killed so far this year. The largest number, 21, were killed in Syria’s civil war. The second largest number of fatalities was in Egypt, with six dead.

headline: Man Is Granted $2.4 Million for False Arrest and Beating by Police
text: A federal jury awarded $2.4 million on Wednesday to a man who they found had been beaten and arrested under false pretenses in Upper Manhattan by the New York police.

headline: New Issue of Corruption for Witness in Yonkers
text: In 2008, two Westchester County businessmen quietly began assisting in a federal corruption investigation that led to the convictions of two Yonkers political figures, including a former councilwoman, Sandy Annabi.

headline: Survivors of Bangladesh Disaster Receive Little Aid
text: Though the Rana Plaza collapse eight months ago stirred an international outcry, the people most directly affected by it are still living with uncertainty.

headline: Super Bowl Monday? N.F.L. Is Making Contingency Plans
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — As ballets go, this one was rather mechanical. A cast of front-loaders twirled and turned and performed parking-lot pas de deux with a machine that can melt 600 tons of snow in an hour.

headline: After Bangladesh Factory Collapse, Bleak Struggle for Survivors
text: SAVAR, Bangladesh — Inside the single room he shares with his wife and young child, Hasan Mahmud Forkan does not sleep easily. Some nights he hears the screams of the garment workers he tried to rescue from the wreckage of the Rana Plaza factory building. Or he dreams the bed itself is collapsing, sucking him down into a bottomless void.

headline: Kitchen Islands and Carts
text: “Did I tell you about my parents’ kitchen island?” John DeLucie said as he inspected the ones on display at the Williams-Sonoma store at Columbus Circle in Manhattan. “They combined three rooms on the main floor of our house and created a huge kitchen with an island so big we can all work on it at one time.”

headline: Figuratively Speaking
text: Administrivial Thursday, December 19, 2013 Puzzle Alert! Although this puzzle can be solved in Across Lite and the New York Times game play, there are elements in the print version that cannot be duplicated electronically. We recommend using the PDF for the best solving experience.

headline: Jets Carry On as Time Winds Down on Season
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — David Nelson arrived at the Jets’ complex at 6:30 a.m., same as any other Wednesday. He attended the special-teams meeting, as usual, then gathered with his teammates for Coach Rex Ryan’s morning address. No one moped around, Nelson said, but “it didn’t feel the same this week as it did last week.”

headline: Deal for IMG Shows Sports’ Draw and Potential
text: In a world filled with 99-cent songs, low-budget reality television shows and high-budget films that flop, sports is as bankable as any entertainment on earth.

headline: State Dept. Warns of New Terrorist Group Posing Threat to U.S. Interests in Africa
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department warned Wednesday that a new terrorist group linked to an Algerian militant has emerged as “the greatest near-term threat to U.S. and Western interests” in the Sahel region of Africa. The State Department’s move underscored the resilience of the militant factions and their ability to forge new terrorist alliances, even in the face of Western pressure.

headline: De Blasio Prods Council to Elect Ally as Speaker
text: Eight years after losing a race for speaker of the City Council, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio is determined to win one.

headline: Phil Robertson Suspended From ‘Duck Dynasty’

text: LA PAZ, Bolivia — A top Bolivian government minister on Wednesday accused the United States of being behind the escape from house arrest of an American businessman facing money-laundering charges — potentially creating a new strain between the two countries.

headline: 100 Acres of Poison Ivy Transformed
text: It took 23 years, but Wayne and Beth Gibbens eventually turned the cornfield they bought in Virginia horse country into a naturalistic landscape.

headline: Graham Mackay, Who Built Beer Empire, Dies at 64
text: Graham Mackay, who anticipated the global consolidation of the beer industry and helped transform his South African brewing company into SABMiller, the world’s second-largest behind Anheuser-Busch InBev, died on Wednesday in Hampshire, England. He was 64.

text: The international agency overseeing the destruction of Syria’s chemical weapons adopted a plan Tuesday night for handling the job and made some of the details public on Wednesday.

headline: With Their Stars (but Not Their Act) Together, the Nets Come Up Short
text: On the side of Barclays Center is a giant decal of the Nets’ projected starting lineup for this season. In a seemingly rare occurrence, all five players depicted were in action Wednesday night, but the Nets still lost, 113-107, to the Washington Wizards.

headline: New York Is Ahead of Some Cities, but Lags Nationally
text: Percent of public school students who are at or above proficiency in math and reading, based on National Assessment of Educational Progress test results, in selected city school districts and nationwide.

headline: Obama’s Choice for China Envoy a Longtime Free Trade Advocate
text: Senator Max Baucus, who has been chosen by President Obama as the new ambassador to China, is a free trade proponent whose chief China concerns have been lifting restrictions on the sale of American beef from his home state, Montana, to the Chinese market.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 19, 2013
text: “They always say I will get compensation, but they don’t say when.”

headline: Week 16 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Playoff Percentages
text: As the playoff field narrows with two games remaining, we can use what’s known as a Monte Carlo simulation to play out the remainder of the season several thousand times, weighting the game outcomes according to the game probabilities produced by the Advanced NFL Stats efficiency model.

headline: Moving the ‘Sphere’
text: A crew moved Fritz Koenig’s “Sphere,” New York City’s interim Sept. 11 memorial, to another part of Battery Park.

headline: Japanese Pitcher Tanaka Won’t Be Let Go, Reports Say
text: Less than two days after the highly sought Japanese pitcher Masahiro Tanaka said he wanted to pitch in Major League Baseball next season, there was still no definitive word from his team, the Rakuten Golden Eagles, whether it would let him leave.

headline: Barred From College Entrance Exams, in a Blow for China’s Blind
text: Li Jinsheng wanted to study law. But because he is blind, virtually the only profession he could train for in China was massage. So he did that and set up a massage business in Queshan County, Henan Province.

headline: A House Tour of the Designer Paul Fortune’s Laurel Canyon Masterpiece
text: The London-born, L.A.-based interior designer Paul Fortune has worked on numerous iconic projects over the years, from Marc Jacobs’s Paris apartment to the Sunset Tower Hotel in Hollywood. This fall, he put his home in Laurel Canyon, known for its warmth and elegance, which he has described as a long-running experiment in design, on the market after 25 years there. Before turning the page, Fortune welcomed the designer and writer David Netto for one final sentimental tour before handing over the keys to the new owner.

headline: Nautical Style for Landlocked Ladies Who Lunch
text: Sailing stripes are going full steam ahead. Coco Chanel famously employed the motif in her day, and her enduring luxury label is at it again with a new take on its iconic quilted handbag. The traditional stripe also surfaced on a canvas slip-on from Mother of Pearl and a maritime tote from Valentino. For the ultraluxe swashbuckler, a bold streak of white on a rabbit fur stole from Marc Jacobs, wool sweater from Chloé and tailored trousers from Vince would look just as chic at high tea as it would on the high seas. And a Verdura bracelet of pearls and sea-colored sapphires anchors any seafaring look.

headline: Big Banks and the Failure of Bankruptcy
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Tougher Tests Mean Fewer 2014 Vehicles Get Top I.I.H.S. Safety Ratings
text: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has again made it more difficult to earn its Top Safety Pick Plus and Top Safety Pick awards by tightening its criteria for the third time since the 2006 model year. The move is likely to dismay automakers because they will suddenly have far fewer vehicles they can promote as worthy of the institute’s plaudits.

headline: In Death Penalty’s Steady Decline, Some Experts See a Societal Shift
text: The death penalty in the United States continued its pattern of broad decline in 2013, with experts attributing the low numbers to a critical shortage of drugs used for lethal injection, increasing public concern over judicial mistakes and the expense of capital cases, and a growing preference for life without parole.

headline: A Decline in Executions
text: Executions reached a peak of 98 in 1999. But since then, their numbers have fallen more or less steadily.

headline: Rangers Find Room for Hope After Narrow Loss

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (ABC) THE YEAR Robin Roberts, above, anchors this collaboration by ABC News and People magazine featuring what they see as the biggest stories of 2013 — from the Boston Marathon bombing, Cleveland kidnappings, and the George Zimmerman and Jodi Arias trials to Pope Francis and the young Pakistani activist Malala Yousafzai, with nods to twerking and binge watching. Ms. Roberts’s colleagues George Stephanopoulos, Josh Elliott, Lara Spencer, Ginger Zee, Cynthia McFadden, Dan Abrams, Dan Harris and David Muir report.

headline: The Ties that Bind Transgendered Communities
text: MUMBAI — The Supreme Court ruling that restored Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code, making homosexuality illegal again, dismayed gay rights activists across the country. But for the transgendered people known as hijras, the ruling changed little.

headline: Chinese Bitcoin Investors Fret as Value of Virtual Currency Plunges
text: The virtual currency Bitcoin has taken a sharp tumble in value since Chinese regulators moved to restrict its usage. That has created no small amount of grumbling among Chinese Bitcoin buyers, who have been some of the most enthusiastic investors in the digital money.

headline: U.N. Ambassador, in Central Africa, Vows Aid and Hears of a Unity Shattered
text: BANGUI, Central African Republic — Samantha Power, the American ambassador to the United Nations, came to this tinderbox of a city on Thursday to pledge American support to end the sectarian strife that has engulfed the country, saying that the international efforts to stem the violence have been essential but not sufficient to restore calm.

headline: Fatal Assault and Fears of War as Turmoil Builds in South Sudan
text: A political crisis in South Sudan, the world’s youngest country, worsened significantly on Thursday, as a deadly assault hit a United Nations peacekeeping base, the number of civilians seeking refuge in the organization’s other facilities there exceeded 30,000 and diplomats expressed fears about the potential for a civil war.

headline: South Korean Officials Accused of Political Meddling
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The Defense Ministry in South Korea said Thursday that at least 11 officials at its cyberwarfare unit, created four years ago to fight North Korean propaganda, had spread 2,100 online political messages praising President Park Geun-hye and her party or attacking their domestic opponents ahead of her election a year ago.

text: A blue BMW crossed the cracked parking lot and rolled to a stop outside a tired-looking Macy’s.

headline: What Musician, Actor or Author Should Be a Superstar, but Hasn’t Quite Made It Yet?
text: Sometimes we “discover” a great song on iTunes or an old album on our parents’ shelf by chance. Or we hear a fantastic local band that hasn’t quite made it yet. Maybe we read a book that everyone should be reading, but isn’t. Some artists become superstars, but many other talented people don’t ever make it really big.

headline: Target Struck in the Cat-and-Mouse Game of Credit Theft
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Target may have been an easy bull’s-eye for criminal hackers intent on stealing credit card information, but the theft of records for 40 million store customers was hardly the worst security breach among big retailers in recent years. And the incident revealed on Thursday is unlikely to be the last.

headline: The People I Know Who Want to Burn Me Alive
text: MOSCOW — The only thing more creepy than hearing someone suggest the likes of you should be burned alive is hearing someone suggest the likes of you should be burned alive and thinking, “I know that guy.” With various Russian public persons competing for the role of the country’s most virulent homophobe, I have had that experience a few times.

headline: Prosecutor Says Kate Middleton’s Phone Was Hacked
text: LONDON — A prosecutor in a high-profile trial on Thursday accused Rupert Murdoch’s News of the World tabloid of hacking into the voice mail of the Duchess of Cambridge when she was known as Kate Middleton, before her marriage to Prince William, second in line to the throne.

headline: Putin, Secure in Power, Says He May Free Jailed Rival
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin said on Thursday that Russia could soon free its most famous prisoner, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former chief executive of Yukos Oil, whose arrest and jailing 10 years ago signaled an authoritarian turn in the nation’s modern history.

text: SHANGHAI — China’s money market rates rose sharply on Thursday, increasing short-term borrowing costs and threatening to recreate the liquidity squeeze that rattled markets in June.

headline: The Domestic Help’s Views in Debate over Diplomat’s Arrest
text: NEW DELHI — Indian opinion has been divided since hearing about the arrest of Devyani Khobragade, the Indian deputy consul general in New York, on charges of visa fraud and paying her housekeeper far less than the current New York state minimum wage of $7.25 an hour.

headline: From Singapore, a First-Time Filmmaker and an Unlikely Reunion
text: You’ll have to pardon the Singaporean director Anthony Chen if he’s feeling a bit dazed these days. In May, his film, “Ilo Ilo,” won the Camera d’Or prize for best first feature film at the Cannes Film Festival. Then Singapore submitted it for the Oscar competition for best foreign-language film. In November, “Ilo Ilo” won four Golden Horse awards, including best picture and best original screenplay, at the Chinese-speaking world’s equivalent of the Oscars. And finally, Variety placed him on its list of 10 directors to watch.

text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

text: One of the top seven entries sent in for our 15-Second Vocabulary Video contest, this one is by Nina T. and defines the word serendipity.

text: No wiretaps. No smoking-gun emails. And a star witness who was testifying to avoid prison.

headline: Pakistani Army Kills 23 Suspected of Being Militants
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 23 people suspected of being militants were killed and 12 were wounded on Thursday when Pakistani Army troops carried out shelling and ground raids in Mir Ali, the second largest town of the restive northwestern tribal district of North Waziristan, according to government officials.

headline: Sex and Drugs and I.P.O.’s
text: If you want to know the truth, the Wolf of Wall Street — the person, that is, not the Martin Scorsese-Leonardo DiCaprio movie that opens on Christmas Day — spent only a fleeting few months on the actual Wall Street. In 1987, Jordan Belfort — a.k.a. the wolf himself — took a job at L. F. Rothschild, an old white-shoe firm. It was his first job in the business, and he was given the assignment of cold-calling “prospects” that he would then turn over to a broker. In his memoir — upon which the movie is based — Mr. Belfort claims, among other things, that a successful Rothschild broker (played by Matthew McConaughey on screen) took him to lunch on his first day and told him to masturbate often if he hoped to be a good broker himself. Given Rothschild’s stodgy reputation, I tend to think this story is an exaggeration, an act of salesmanship intended to lure in Hollywood. No matter. Not long after Mr. Belfort began working for L. F. Rothschild, the crash of 1987 wiped out the firm and took his job with it.

headline: Neil deGrasse Tyson: By the Book
text: The Hayden Planetarium director and author, most recently, of “Space Chronicles,” would love to have met Oscar Wilde: “Anyone who could pen the phrase ‘We are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars’ gets a seat at my dinner table.”

headline: Dwight Garner’s 10 Favorite Books of 2013
text: THE FLAMETHROWERS by Rachel Kushner (Scribner). Ms. Kushner’s second novel — it’s about speed, art and politics — unfurls as if on an Imax screen. It has the kind of poise, wariness and moral graininess that puts you in mind of weary-souled visionaries like Robert Stone or Joan Didion.

headline: Janet Maslin’s 10 Favorite Books of 2013
text: LAWRENCE IN ARABIA: WAR, DECEIT, IMPERIAL FOLLY AND THE MAKING OF THE MODERN MIDDLE EAST by Scott Anderson (Doubleday). This superbly fine-tuned account of the Middle East during World War I is no hagiographic T. E. Lawrence biography. Lawrence’s strategic talents, not least his “peculiar skill at polite belligerence,” are seen within the full context of wartime espionage by other players. Mr. Anderson does a fine job of piecing together the many conflicting Middle East interests that are ordinary eclipsed by the alluring Lawrence story. An original, illuminating history that requires and rewards close attention.

headline: Michiko Kakutani’s 10 Favorite Books of 2013
text: THE GOLDFINCH by Donna Tartt (Little, Brown & Company). In this astonishing Dickensian novel, Ms. Tartt uses her myriad talents — her tactile prose, her knowledge of her characters’ inner lives, her instinct for suspense — to immerse us in a fully imagined fictional world that reminds us of the wonderful stay-up-all-night pleasures of reading. The novel is at once a thriller involving the theft of a famous Dutch painting; a panoramic portrait of New York (and America) in the post-9/11 era; and an old-fashioned coming-of-age story about an orphan named Theo who, with his best friend Boris, one of the great recent fictional creations, will enter the pantheon of classic buddy acts alongside Laurel and Hardy, Vladimir and Estragon, and Pynchon’s Mason and Dixon.

headline: No Literary Horse Race, Just Books We Like
text: Let us be the first to tell you: These are quirky lists. They’re supposed to be. These are our favorite books of the year, so please don’t confuse them with 10 Bests, because we can’t make lists like those. For one thing, all of us — Michiko Kakutani, Dwight Garner and I — read so many books on assignment that we don’t have the leeway to be comprehensive. For another, we’ve listed books that we liked as much as we admired. That’s where the quirks come in.

headline: Apply a Little Pressure
text: Not long ago, I found a piece of what I assumed was beef in the freezer. My choices were to cook it or throw it out, and because time was short — defrosting was not an option — the pressure cooker seemed the right option.

text: Cookbook author and pressure-cooking expert Lorna Sass shows Mark Bittman how to make lamb meatballs with a Greek-inspired tomato sauce in under five minutes.
