text: Mark Bittman makes Porcini Risotto with Lorna Sass, a cookbook author and pressure-cooking expert.

headline: New York Job Recovery Isn’t Quite as Strong as Bloomberg Proclaims
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is riding out of office on a wave of positive reports about the creation of jobs in New York.

headline: Suicide Bombers Attack Shiite Pilgrims in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Suicide bombers attacked Shiite pilgrims in tents and as they marched to shrines during one of their most important religious commemorations, part of a wave of violence on Thursday that the police said had killed 41 people.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Christmas Tree Lots’
text: This Poetry Pairing features “Christmas Tree Lots” by Chris Green and the article “If a Tree Falls in the Den …” by Bob Tedeschi.

headline: U.S. Gains Confidence With Insider Trading Victory
text: The United States attorney’s office in Manhattan extended its winning streak on insider trading cases on Wednesday when a jury convicted Michael S. Steinberg on conspiracy and four counts of securities fraud. Mr. Steinberg, a portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, is a close associate of the firm’s founder and owner, Steven A. Cohen.

headline: Florida’s Cattle Wars
text: The fall of Vicksburg in July 1863, which gave the Union control of the Mississippi River, not only cut the Confederacy in half, but it cut off the supply of Texas cattle from reaching hungry troops to the east (and federal blockaders patrolling the Gulf of Mexico prevented delivery by ship). Consequently, the Confederacy increasingly looked to a seemingly unlikely source, Florida, as a source of beef for its armies.

headline: Talking to Children About Cheating: Dishonesty Is Worse Than a Bad Grade
text: I’ve had cheating on the brain this week because I’ve been researching an article about creating cheating-free classrooms. A few friends asked me to write about how parents can best address the topic of academic dishonesty with children.

headline: Aging and the Art of Losing
text: This is often how the story emerges: the cold, metal scale in the geriatrics clinic betraying a tightly held secret. “You’ve lost another four pounds,” I say to my patient, an 85-year-old woman who layers multiple shirts against the season’s chill and peels them off to reveal skin that hangs on her stooped frame. She wears an oxygen cannula and is mildly short of breath after this exertion. With some taps of the keyboard, I note a 22-pound weight loss in the past two years.

headline: In Our Pages: December 20
text: 1938: Change of Plans for Al Capone

headline: A Bruegel, a Rembrandt, a van Gogh: Appraisal Puts Prices on the Priceless in Detroit
text: The price tags are now on the paintings.

headline: Bankruptcy Manager in Detroit to Divide Duties With Mayor
text: DETROIT — The city’s emergency manager on Thursday turned over major governmental responsibilities to its mayor-elect, marking a restoration of political power to the mayor as Detroit reorganizes under federal bankruptcy laws.

headline: Daft Punk and Kendrick Lamar Among Grammy Awards Performers
text: Some unusual pairings distinguish the first round of artists who have been announced to perform at the Grammy Awards next month. The Recording Academy said Thursday that the rapper Kendrick Lamar, who has seven Grammy nominations, including best new artist and album of the year, will perform with the rock band Imagine Dragons, nominated for record of the year and best rock performance. Pink, the pop-punk singer, will take the stage with Nate Ruess of the rock trio Fun.; both are nominated for song of the year and best pop duo/group performance for “Just Give Me a Reason.” And the helmet-headed electronic rock duo Daft Punk, an unusual pair in their own right and an infrequent television presence, will also perform on the show.

headline: Video: Kings of Leon and Mixed Family Feelings
text: Along with stars like Taylor Swift, Coldplay and U2, Grammy winners Kings of Leon could become Oscar nominees soon. Their song “Last Mile Home,” featured over the credits of “August: Osage County,” is on the Academy’s list of eligible titles. At the film’s New York premiere last week, the group, brothers from Nashville, was preparing to see the final cut for the first time. They had screened an earlier version in Nashville to inspire them to write. But they didn’t include characters from Tracy Letts’s Pulitzer-prize winning dysfunctional clan in their song.

headline: Times Will Study Potential Changes to Its Sunday Magazine
text: The New York Times Magazine will be reassessed by the newspaper’s managing editor, Dean Baquet, and Deborah Needleman, the editor of T Magazine, for the next three months before a new editor is appointed, according to a memo sent Thursday to employees.

headline: Gergiev, With Eye on Munich Job, Responds to Antigay Accusations
text: BERLIN — Valery Gergiev, the Russian conductor whose recent performances have been overshadowed by a debate over Russia’s law limiting the discussion of homosexuality, has assured officials in Munich that he “fully supports” the city’s stance against discrimination. Mr. Gergiev is to take over as director of the Munich Philharmonic in 2015.

headline: Muddy Waters Offers to Pay to Double-Check Board Review of Chinese Firm
text: At first, Carson C. Block accused NQ Mobile, a Chinese mobile security firm, of perpetrating a “massive fraud.” Now he’s offering to backstop an inquiry into the company.

headline: Some of Hottest Seats in Sports Belong to Premier League Coaches
text: LONDON — After André Villas-Boas became the fifth soccer manager to lose his job in the 20-team Premier League this season, The Daily Mail offered a salutation to Tim Sherwood, who was named this week to replace him at Tottenham Hotspur on an interim basis as the club hunts for a big-name successor.

headline: It’s Not the Powerball, but a Prize Picasso
text: As ways to start an art collection go, there’s nothing quite like getting a Picasso. Accomplishing that takes a little luck, of course, but Jeffrey Gonano, a 25-year-old project manager for a fire sprinkler company in Wexford, Pa., had luck in his corner on Wednesday, when his ticket was drawn at a charity raffle run by Sotheby’s in Paris. The ticket cost 100 euros (about $137). The prize, Picasso’s “Man With Opera Hat,” a small gouache that dates to 1914, was estimated by Sotheby’s to be worth $1 million.

headline: Times Publisher Sets Out Plan for ‘Native’ Ads
text: Seeking to allay potential newsroom concerns about the introduction of a new digital product called native advertising, the publisher of The New York Times on Thursday said that features like a color bar and the words “Paid Post” would enable readers to identify material as advertising content.

headline: A Storyteller Who Thrives in the Shadows
text: On the first page of the recent Batman No. 24, the Caped Crusader doesn’t swoop high above Gotham City, and the Joker doesn’t stalk dark alleys, straight razor in hand. But it’s one of the best moments ever in a Batman comic. In this tender scene, Bruce Wayne’s butler and mentor, Alfred, is giving him a pre-battle buzz cut.

headline: Netrebko to Perform at Le Poisson Rouge
text: The Metropolitan Opera, intent on reaching a younger crowd, is presenting one of its reigning stars, the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko, in a concert at the Greenwich Village indie hotspot Le Poisson Rouge on Jan. 15.

headline: Awkward Family Moments at the ‘Wolf’ Premiere
text: The real-life Jordan Belfort, the antihero of “The Wolf of Wall Street,” played in the film by Leonardo diCaprio, made an appearance at the Ziegfeld Theater premiere on Tuesday, along with his family. Rob Reiner, who plays his father, Max Belfort, met the real man for the first time. The resemblance is not uncanny: Mr. Reiner is large, Mr. Belfort is not. But “it was a kick for me,” said Mr. Reiner, tasked with characterizing the company overseer once known as Mad Max. “He said he used to scream just like that.”

headline: Subprime Mortgage Loan Servicer Ocwen Agrees to $2.2 Billion Settlement
text: Updated, 8:53 p.m. | A $2.2 billion agreement is settling accusations against a large but little known player in the mortgage industry that escaped last year’s sweeping mortgage settlement.

headline: A Pornographer’s Farewell
text: Of all the surreal communications I received from Al Goldstein — whose trials, criminal and otherwise, I covered early in the millennium — one is preserved in its entirety.

headline: A Farm-to-Resorts Movement
text: Whether to reduce food imports, feed guests the freshest produce possible or provide a rustic experience, a number of new and expanding resorts in the Caribbean are emphasizing farm-to-table ties.

headline: Obama Commutes Sentences for 8 in Crack Cocaine Cases
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, expanding his push to curtail severe penalties in drug cases, on Thursday commuted the sentences of eight federal inmates who were convicted of crack cocaine offenses. Each inmate has been imprisoned for at least 15 years, and six were sentenced to life in prison.

headline: Has Snowden Been Vindicated?
text: Do criticisms of N.S.A. programs by a presidential panel and a federal judge show that Edward Snowden is a principled whistleblower?

headline: The Year in Moments, Quirky and Magical
text: From broken guitars to a play in the back of a truck, surprises abounded on stage this year.

headline: The Magical Worlds of Mitty and Mary
text: Oscar season increasingly begets movies about movies, or movies that remind us of other movies, and this year’s batch is no exception. The release of “Saving Mr. Banks,” telling the story of the writer P. L. Travers’s tangles with Walt Disney, has led Disney (the company, not Uncle Walt himself) to rerelease “Mary Poppins” in a joint DVD/Blu-ray edition, ahead of the film’s 50th anniversary next year. And Ben Stiller’s forthcoming remake of “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty” has inspired a handsome new DVD from Warner Home Video of the “Mitty” from 1947 starring Danny Kaye.

headline: Credit Suisse Gains a Top Energy Banker
text: Credit Suisse has poached a top oil and gas banker from Morgan Stanley.

headline: 2 Found Guilty in Grisly Killing of British Soldier
text: LONDON — Two British-born converts to Islam were found guilty on Thursday of the murder of a British soldier who was run over with a car on a London street and then hacked with knives and a meat cleaver as closed-circuit cameras recorded parts of the grisly scene.

headline: Rutlemania Is Back, and It’s Unreal
text: There’s long been debate over who can truly claim the title “the Fifth Beatle.” The disc jockey Murray Kaufman pursued it. Later, arguments were made for the keyboardist Billy Preston or Yoko Ono. A new graphic novel bestows the honorific on the band’s manager Brian Epstein. However, the Beatles’ most essential partners may be their fictional counterparts: the Rutles, stars of the mockumentary “All You Need Is Cash.”

headline: Court Decision on Same-Sex Marriage in New Mexico
text: The New Mexico Supreme Court ruled that it is illegal to deny a marriage license to a gay or lesbian couple.

headline: The Gun Report: December 19, 2013
text: We get a lot of comments here at the Gun Report like, “Criminals will always find a way get guns.” In other words, gun laws won’t stop a criminal determined to get a gun from doing so. Which begs the question: How exactly do criminals get guns?

headline: On Iran and Syria, Tests of Diplomacy Intertwine

headline: Defrocking of Minister Widens Split Over Gays
text: The Rev. Frank Schaefer, a Methodist minister, was stripped of his clerical credentials on Thursday for violating church law by presiding at his son’s same-sex wedding. The punishment, imposed by the United Methodist Church in Pennsylvania, was requested by the church prosecutor to deter other ministers from blessing same-sex marriages.

headline: Hershey Goes to China for Its Biggest-Ever Deal
text: The Hershey Company isn’t known for its deal-making appetite. But the American chocolate giant is willing to open up for a big deal in China.

headline: Painter of Works Sold as Masterpieces Says He Too Was Duped
text: Pei-Shen Qian, the Queens artist who federal prosecutors say created dozens of fake paintings that were later sold as Modernist masterpieces, said that he had no idea his works were being marketed as the real thing, according to a report in Bloomberg Businessweek on Thursday.

headline: New Ski Gear, From Head to Toe, and Below
text: Remember how, in nearly every Bond film, Q unveils some fantastic tool meant to help 007 weather his latest adventure? The companies that make ski and snowboard gear seem to be taking that approach these days. Want to record your runs? Try a motion-sensitive, GPS-enabled video camera. Want a lighter snowboard? Try one with aerospace-grade triaxial carbon fiber. You get the idea. Below you’ll find these items and other innovative new gear hitting shelves this winter.

headline: In British Columbia, Little Big Resort
text: When I first moved to the Pacific Northwest 18 years ago, a veteran outdoors writer and mentor told me, “When it has snow, Red Mountain is my favorite place to ski.” Coming from a guy who had dragged his planks all over the globe in search of good turns, such praise about a British Columbia ski area I’d never even heard of — even with that baked-in caveat — made a lasting impression.

headline: Tracking the Snowy Owl Migration in Real Time
text: Spotted in states like Maryland, Pennsylvania, Michigan, North Carolina and New York, snowy owls are heading south in what ornithologists say is the largest migration in two decades.

headline: By the Numbers: How Few Votes It Takes to Secure a Nomination

Over at the Wrap, there’s a useful accounting  of just how many – or in most cases, how few – votes it actually takes to get nominated.

headline: Turning Points: Margaret MacMillan Talks About ‘The War That Ended Peace’
text: Publishers this year got the jump on commemorating the centenary of World War I, offering many books about the period by leading historians. “The War That Ended Peace” by Margaret MacMillan examines the relations among European countries in the relatively calmer years leading up to 1914. In The New York Times Book Review, Richard Aldous wrote that Ms. MacMillan “neatly recounts the events that led to battle” and that her “portraits of the men who took Europe to war are superb.”

headline: Protecting Citizens, and Their Privacy
text: THE United States and its allies face major national security threats, particularly from international terrorism, the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and cyberwarfare and espionage. Effective surveillance by the National Security Agency and other agencies within the intelligence community has helped to keep Americans safe from such threats. The nation will continue to need such protection in the future.

headline: What’s So Sad About Christmas?
text: Some Christmas songs are meant to be cheerful but depress you because they’re so awful. These tend to play on an endless loop and brutally de-jollify public spaces this time of year.

headline: Baby Makes 3 or 4, but Not 5
text: My husband and I had our first baby this year. We’re thrilled. And even though my parents got divorced last year, I want both of them to celebrate Christmas with us. So far, they’ve refused to be in the same room together. (It was a messy split.) I told them how important it is for me and my son to celebrate his first Christmas as a family. But they still said no. How can I get them to see how important this is to us?

headline: Garlic Fails to Curb Yeast Infections

headline: Starting Over in a Familiar Spot
text: Of all the kinds of restaurants in suburban New Jersey that a chef might hitch his dreams to, a traditional French bistro must rank among the most tempting and the most treacherous. Tempting because the pleasures are many, especially for those who have encountered the real thing; treacherous because that special Gallic alchemy of bustle and warmth, of forthright and deeply satisfying cooking, is confoundingly hard to pull off.

headline: Your First Dance Songs
text: For many couples, a first-dance song has the power to evoke memories of their steadfast relationship. As part of our occasional series, Wedding Album, we invited New York Times readers to share the name of the song they selected for their first dance and why it is meaningful to them. We received dozens of stories that represented the tribulations of long distance relationships, the enduring love of high school sweethearts, and the satisfaction of finding love at an older age.

text: CLASSICAL music is finally embracing the download. Classical music devotees have traditionally been more, well, traditional in their attachment to actual physical recordings.

headline: Congress Is Warned Anew Not to Breach Debt Ceiling
text: WASHINGTON — With its new budget deal, Congress has avoided one threat of another government shutdown. But unless Congress acts, the threat of a breach of the debt ceiling looms early next year, the Treasury Department warned in a letter to congressional leaders on Thursday.

headline: Bryant and Lakers’ Plans Break Down
text: LOS ANGELES — When the Lakers awarded Kobe Bryant an eye-popping two-year, $48.5 million contract extension last month, it seemed like an inordinate amount of faith — and cap space — to place on their aging star, who at 35 had not yet come back from a torn left Achilles’ tendon.

headline: Young Souls Portray the Wit of ‘Hamlet,’ With Brevity
text: Let it not be said that Shakespeare means nothing to young people.

headline: Couric Talk Show to End in June After Two Seasons
text: “Katie,” the syndicated talk show starring Katie Couric, which began with enormous fanfare in September 2012, will cease production at the end of the current season.

headline: Perelman Pledges $50 Million to a New York Hospital
text: When Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire financier, visited his father-in-law at the emergency room of a hospital in Manhattan after Hurricane Sandy last year, he was horrified by what he saw.

headline: Verizon to Release First Transparency Report
text: Following in the footsteps of companies like Google and Facebook, Verizon Communications is going to reveal more about what customer information it shares with the government.

headline: Hazelnuts Complement Oregon Pinot Noirs
text: Oregon pinot noirs have started to express terroir. At this point in their history they have yet to exhibit the velvet lushness of fine red Burgundies, but they are on their way. And when it comes to terroir, a few iconic ingredients that suggest Oregon beg for these wines. I’m thinking mushrooms, black truffles and hazelnuts.

headline: New Look for Verdi’s Corpulent Clown
text: A bully and a tease, buffoonish and brilliant: Falstaff is many things. But above all, the hero of Verdi’s comic opera is defined by his girth. “Se Falstaff s’assottiglia, non è più lui,” Sir John sings early on in the first scene: If Falstaff grows thin, he is no longer himself.

headline: ‘Man’s Best Friend’ Takes on a New Meaning
text: She has floppy ears, eyes of exquisite sadness and an operatic tendency toward ecstasy, anguish and other big emotions. Leave her alone in a thunderstorm, and she may fall into despair.

text: Also on the Minute, a possible Russian pardon and "Hamlet" in 15 seconds.

headline: In a Variety of Music, Seeing Is Hearing
text: Images of strange and startling beauty percolate through Squonk Opera’s “Mayhem and Majesty,” a small spectacle of a show occupying that hard-to-classify intersection where live music meets visual art.

headline: Study Documents 2012 Downturn in Chinese Art Market
text: SHANGHAI — China’s art auction market suffered a sharp downturn in 2012, amid a global slump in demand for Chinese art, fueled in part by concern about the many fakes that are offered for sale.

headline: Economists: Less Scrooge-Like Than You Thought
text: A few years ago Joel Waldfogel wrote “Scroogeonomics: Why You Shouldn’t Buy Presents for the Holidays,” an economic manifesto about the wastefulness of gift-giving. The Initiative on Global Markets at the University of Chicago’s Booth School of Business recently queried its panel of 46 economic experts on the subject, and the responses were surprisingly less Grinch-like.

headline: Making Music Outdoors
text: Perhaps it’s somewhat perverse, given the season, for the Miser to recommend joining a series of outdoor musical parades across the city this weekend. But looking over the lineup for this year’s “Make Music Winter” festival on Saturday, you might conclude that coat weather never sounded so good.

headline: Does the A.A.P. Logo Belong on Formula Gift Bags?
text: If you walked out of a hospital with a new baby and an Enfamil-sponsored gift bag of formula during the past year, you might be wondering why it sported the American Academy of Pediatrics’ logo on its tag, just a little over a year after the same group released a lengthy policy statement reaffirming its recommendation that babies be exclusively breast-fed for the first six months, and up to one year with complementary foods. The logo appears on a safety tag attached to a bag containing gifts of formula as well as a booklet published by the American Academy of Pediatrics, “New Mother’s Breastfeeding Essentials,” with, according to Crystal Lewis of Women’s eNews, “Mead Johnson’s name prominently displayed on the inside of the cover page.”

headline: The Animation of the Imagination
text: One way to look at An Animated World, a retrospective of films distributed by the New York-based company Gkids, is in terms of dollars. Of the 18 films in this festival, which begins Friday at the IFC Center in Manhattan, those that have already been released commercially in American theaters have made a total of about $2.8 million. That’s 1 ½ percent of what Disney’s “Frozen” has earned in less than a month.

headline: ‘Ambassador for the New’
text: A look at a new exhibition at MoMA that highlights the career of the gallery owner and art collector Ileana Sonnabend.

headline: ‘The American West in Bronze, 1850-1925’
text: A look at works in a new show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Why Oregon Will Fondly Remember 2011
text: How important is vintage in discussing fine wines? I’d say we overrate it, or at least over-generalize about it. Focusing on vintage characteristics may be a helpful shorthand approach for wine writers, but usually it is too simplistic, leading to reflex decisions rather than more-considered ones.

headline: Backward to Somewhere
text: The modest, run-down home at the center of “The Past” is filled with rooms that — much like the characters who are busily, sometimes leisurely passing through them — somehow feel cut off from one another. Set in a characterless Paris suburb that’s as physically and psychically distant from the City of Light as the moon, the movie is both a family melodrama and a relationship story, which perhaps inevitably means it’s about love and loyalty, secrets and lies, and how the past, never being dead, just hovers around waiting to smack us upside the head. All this also makes it something of a haunted house movie, except that its characters are plagued by ghosts of their own design.

headline: After Hours | A Goofy Display of Acrobatics, Juggling and Hula Hooping
text: Céline Dion, Cirque du Soleil, poutine. Let’s face it: We expect a highly virtuosic level of cheesiness from the Quebecois, and we revel in it. So it goes at N.Y.U.’s Skirball Center, where “Cirkopolis,” the latest body-twisting delight from the Montreal neo-circus troupe Cirque Eloize, is in residency through Jan. 5. The show begins with a single man, a beaten-down bureaucrat in business drab, stamping papers at a desk before giant projections of rotating industrial cogs, à la “Metropolis.” It sounds like the scene is being set for some Weimar-tinged exploration of the alienation of the human worker. Not quite. Those Bauhaus facades are a mere backdrop for a dazzling display of human bodily levitation, contortion and gyration. The acrobats defy gravity in jaw-dropping performances on giant wheel-like contraptions, atop one another’s bodies, suspended from trapezes and ropes, and, astoundingly, up and down a 100-foot pole at frenetic speeds. It’s hard not to deliver an ovation when a pretty young woman in a fluttery red dress whirls inside a massive hula hoop, like a human dreidel.

headline: Ceiling at Theater in London Collapses on Audience
text: Updated, 6:32 p.m. Dozens of people were injured, including at least seven of them seriously, when part of the ceiling of the Apollo Theater in London’s West End collapsed onto the audience during a performance Thursday night, police and fire officials said.

headline: Manifest Destiny, at the Point of a Gun
text: Around 1905, the city fathers of Denver decided that a monument to honor their pioneering predecessors was in order. The commission went to Frederick William MacMonnies, an American sculptor trained in the Beaux-Arts who lived in France. MacMonnies proposed a multitiered fountain topped by the figure of an Indian chief, but local citizens objected to celebrating a recently feared and despised enemy. So MacMonnies offered instead a sculpture of the all-around frontiersman Kit Carson (1809-68), who, to this day, appears in bronze riding a rearing horse at the summit of the Pioneer Monument in downtown Denver.

headline: A Legendary Dealer’s Eagle Eye
text: If you think that all art exhibitions result from the natural meeting of laudable subjects and curatorial passion, consider “Ileana Sonnabend: Ambassador for the New,” which opens on Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art. Although the subject is a worthy one — Sonnabend was among the most foresighted art dealers of the late 20th century — the show is a byproduct of legal hassles and diplomatic campaigns surrounding her billion-dollar estate, which may be one reason it feels, as a tribute, cool and impersonal, a portrait-in-art that is only a sketch.

headline: Theater Listings for Dec. 20-26
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: The Obsessions of a Straight American Guy
text: PHILADELPHIA — When Jason Rhoades died unexpectedly in 2006, at the age of 41, he left behind a vast and bewildering body of work: rambling, porous, performative installations that were as deliriously grandiose as anything by Dieter Roth, Paul McCarthy, Matthew Barney or Thomas Hirschhorn. Curators are still sorting it all out, to judge from “Jason Rhoades: Four Roads,” at the Institute of Contemporary Art here.

headline: Comedy Listings for Dec. 20-26
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Desperate Years: To Be Young, British and Lacking
text: For today’s socially conscious British filmmakers, northern England is more or less what southern Italy was to the postwar neorealists: a landscape of social misery, both picturesque and harsh. Instead of a disenfranchised peasantry clinging to tradition in the face of modernity, contemporary British cinema finds a demoralized postindustrial underclass fighting for dignity at the margins of the global economy.

headline: Art as Currency in a Tragic Time
text: A personal art collection can be displayed as a trophy room or as a diary. The Ileana Sonnabend exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art is cast in greatest-hits mode; MoMA’s the right place for it. “Macho Man, Tell It to My Heart: Collected by Julie Ault” at the nonprofit gallery Artists Space is an intimate document, scrappy, annotated, apartment size. The whole thing, 200 pieces stretched over two locations, could probably fit in a decent-size studio, if you stored some behind furniture and under the bed.

headline: Movie Listings for Dec. 20-26
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage in the New Year
text: New Mexico’s Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that excluding same-sex couples from the freedom to marry violates the state’s constitution. That makes New Mexico the first marriage equality state in the Southwest.

headline: Pop and Rock Music Listings for Dec. 20-26
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Jazz Listings for Dec. 20-26
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Not So Fast on Volcker Rule, Regulators Tell Smaller Banks
text: It didn’t take long for the financial industry to get bank regulators to make an exception to the Volcker Rule when it comes to limiting risk-taking by smaller banks.

headline: An Aging Actress Faces the Mirror
text: The cosmic and the microscopic are casually — and delicately — juxtaposed in “All the Light in the Sky,” an evocative, slightly melancholic movie directed and photographed by the prolific mumblecore auteur Joe Swanberg. This portrait of a middle-aged actress in Los Angeles who makes a decent living as a Hollywood bit player but worries about the future, is bolstered by the astoundingly natural performance of Jane Adams (“Happiness,” “Hung”). Her chipper, articulate character, Marie, is 45 and acutely aware of her professional shelf life. She lives in a comfortable Malibu home on stilts that hugs the Pacific Coast.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Dec. 20-26
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dance Listings for Dec. 20-26
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Russian Court Convicts Gay-Rights Advocate
text: MOSCOW — A regional court in Kazan, Russia, convicted a gay-rights advocate on Thursday for violating the country’s much-criticized law against “gay propaganda.”

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Dec. 20-26
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Other Countries, Other Shores
text: We love poets for the things their poems lead us to imagine; but equally, we love them for how we imagine their lives to be. Confusing poets’ lives with their work is an illusion as old as the tradition of confusing words with objects. But in fact it is for the sake of this illusion that we feel such a strong need for poetry, for novels, for literature. There are some poets whose work we read with their lives in mind, and what we know of those lives ensures that their poetry leaves a more enduring impression. C. P. Cavafy is, for me, just such a poet. Like Edgar Allan Poe, like Franz Kafka, Cavafy makes no explicit reference to himself in his best and most stirring work; and yet, with every poem we read, we cannot help thinking of him.

headline: A Cockeyed Optimist
text: Economic nostalgia can have a strong appeal, especially following more than five years of a financial crisis and its aftermath. In the United States, people talk longingly of the mid-20th century, when the middle class was growing and upward mobility was the norm. In Europe and Japan, many hark back to the 1980s, before the euro was born and the Japanese bubble burst. Even in China and India, two of the world’s more dynamic economies, some like to celebrate a time when life did not revolve around breakneck growth.

headline: Norman Rockwell, the Storyteller
text: Dear fragile Norman Rockwell. He grew up in a series of cramped apartments and shabby boardinghouses in Upper Manhattan, skinny, weak-chinned, squinty, an abysmal student, inept at math, probably dyslexic, neglected by his parents, overshadowed by a handsome, athletic older brother, and for the rest of his life was uncertain of himself and modest to a fault. He enrolled in art school to become an illustrator in the footsteps of Howard Pyle and N. C. Wyeth, just as the Armory Show of 1913 was about to usher in the avant-garde and relegate illustration — art as storytelling — to the back pages. He was a loner, did not feel close to his parents or brother, was not a devoted father to his three sons. He was married to his work; his three wives, Irene O’Connor, Mary Barstow and Molly Punderson, learned to accommodate. His biographer reports that his love life was stark: “Nothing that can be described as a love letter survives among his papers. It seems unlikely that he ever wrote one.”

headline: Like Simba, Only He’s a Plucky Pachyrhinosaurus
text: “The Lion King” goes prehistoric in “Walking With Dinosaurs,” a good-looking extension of the franchise that began as a BBC television series.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Dec. 20-26
text: ‘A Christmas Carol’

headline: A Dream Factory for a Benighted China
text: “What you don’t dare imagine, we dare to do” is the motto of the dream team known as “Personal Tailor,” a fantasy fabrication service (led by Ge You and Bai Baihe) that provides wealthy clients with a taste of the lives they have always wanted. No request is too outlandish (the “Custom Martyrdom Package” will furnish you with a simulated Nazi interrogation, hunger strike optional) or too elaborate, even if the outcomes are not always as planned.

headline: Spare Times for Dec. 20-26
text: Christmas at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Jan. 6) The museum’s annual Nativity display, featuring a crèche within a Christmas tree, made its debut in 1957. It was the idea of Loretta Hines Howard, an artist and collector who donated over 200 18th-century Neapolitan crèche figures to the museum. After her death in 1982, her family continued the tradition. Visitors circling the tree and this year’s display can see more than 20 cherubs and 50 angels positioned among the branches.

headline: Enter Playwright, Trailed by Filmmakers
text: Tracy Letts knows his play “August: Osage County” is a winner. A scathingly funny tale of a broken Oklahoma family, “August” won the Tony Award, the Pulitzer and almost every other accolade for best play after it opened on Broadway in 2007.

headline: From Simple Chords, Trance-Inducing Effects
text: It’s not hard to concoct a list of likely inspirations for Stars of the Lid, the persuasive ambient-music duo formed in 1993 by Brian McBride and Adam Wiltzie. Seminal tape-loop meditations by Robert Fripp and Brian Eno, the haunting tidal wash of Gavin Bryars’s most influential handful of works, the infinite sadness of Gorecki’s Third Symphony, the unsettling disquiet of Angelo Badalamenti’s “Twin Peaks” music: All this and more resonates in the duo’s work.

headline: A Whirl of Bodies Spinning Illusions
text: “reMIX,” the Momix program that opened Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater for a three-week run, is a greatest-hits show. There are 13 pieces, one going back to 1982, one new to New York, but most familiar from previous “reMIX” samplers. However shuffled, the product formula remains the same: fit performers doing gymnastic exercises that are fitfully impressive, theatrical illusions that intermittently please or fool the eye, lots of props.

headline: It Ain’t Over When the ‘Hallelujah’ Is Sung
text: May I just ask: Were you one of the two dozen or so audience members who stampeded out of Tuesday night’s New York Philharmonic performance of Handel’s “Messiah” right after the “Hallelujah”? Because if so, I feel it incumbent upon me to tell you: You missed the best bits.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Price of a Stolen Credit Card, and #NSAMovieTitles
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Hiking in a Winter Wonderland
text: JUST because temperatures have dropped doesn’t mean outdoor efforts to elevate your heart rate should take a nose dive, too. New York City offers many walking trails and paths through scenic, wooded parks and along breathtaking waterways.

headline: Jones Group to Be Bought Out by Private Equity Firm
text: The Jones Group said on Thursday that it had accepted a buyout offer of $15 per share from private equity firm Sycamore Partners, bringing the long rumored deal to fruition.

headline: Fred Benjamin, Exacting and Inventive Teacher of Jazz Dance, Dies at 69
text: Fred Benjamin, an internationally known teacher of jazz dance who was also part of the creative wave of young black modern-dance choreographers who came to prominence in the 1970s, died on Dec. 14 in Manhattan. He was 69.

headline: Where the Ghosts Smoke Cigars
text: One of the newest landmarks to be designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission is the 1929 Tammany Hall, on the east side of Union Square at 17th Street. Although it was built during a high point of Tammany fortunes, when Al Smith, Robert F. Wagner and Gentleman Jimmy Walker were regulars, it’s really not much to look at: a mild, inoffensive essay in the Georgian style.

headline: In the Shadow of Rising Towers, Laments of Lost Sunlight in New York
text: Having to live in someone else’s shadow is one of the risks of being a New Yorker. Yet for untold thousands, this vexing state of affairs is literally true. In a city forever sprouting new buildings, the quest to reach higher often comes at the cost of stealing somebody else’s light.

headline: The Top 10 Photo Books of 2013
text: Stacks of books lined the countertops of the photo department in precarious, even Seuss-ian formations. They made for a daunting task, possibly a workplace hazard. There were formidable publications from the likes of Philip Lorca DiCorcia, Gregory Crewdson and Joel Meyerowitz. Books by artists like Taryn Simon and Edward Burtynsky, whose works had appeared in the magazine. We even had entries with titles like “Quotations from Chairman Mao Tsetong” and “Holy Bible.” “There are too many good books this year,” lamented one exhausted photo editor when the judging was finished.

headline: For Both Sides in Texas Primaries, a Key Is to Get Names Known
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: GTT ★
text: LUBBOCK

headline: This Week’s Movies: Dec. 20, 2013
text: The New York Times movie critics on “Her,” “The Past,” and “Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues.”

headline: The Night Witch
text: This animated Op-Doc explores the life of Nadezhda Popova, known as Nadia, who became a World War II hero as part of a Soviet all-female bombing regiment.

headline: ‘The Night Witch’
text: This is one of five films commissioned in conjunction with The Times Magazine’s The Lives They Lived issue, which commemorates people who died this year.

headline: What I Love | Jean Hanff Korelitz and Paul Muldoon
text: A sudden — or not so sudden — move is an instant hit with everybody concerned.

headline: The Poetry of Downsizing
text: Last spring, when the novelist Jean Hanff Korelitz and her husband, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Irish poet Paul Muldoon, decided to move to New York City from Princeton, N.J., they figured the hard part would be finding an apartment they liked. Really, that was the easy part. They found lots of apartments they liked.

headline: Chinese, Without the Fusion
text: The Orient in Bethpage is the real deal: a Chinese restaurant with no sushi bar, no fusion dishes and no apologies. Twenty years ago, there were many restaurants like this, though most were not nearly as good. Today there are far fewer, and the Orient gets my vote as the best Chinese restaurant on Long Island.

headline: Hunter Chic With Some Tongue in Cheek
text: Nick Di Bona, who worked for almost a decade at Peter Pratt’s Inn, in Yorktown, has opened his own place, Madison Kitchen, on the west side of the tracks in Larchmont, near a sports club and auto body shops. Mr. Di Bona, who is not yet 30, has turned a former red-sauce Italian joint into a glittering ode to the midcentury cocktail lounge. It’s not a big space, but after a long renovation, it looks like a million bucks.

headline: Judge’s Party Switch Gives Democrats Something to Build On
text: When Lawrence E. Meyers won a seat on the statewide Court of Criminal Appeals in 1992, he was the first Republican elected to the state’s highest criminal court.

headline: Hagel Criticizes Chinese Navy, Citing Near Miss
text: WASHINGTON — The Chinese Navy has been “irresponsible,” and its actions risk escalating tensions with the United States, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said Thursday in the highest-level rebuke of Beijing since a Chinese warship came dangerously close to an American guided missile cruiser this month.

headline: A White-Glove State of Mind
text: As New York City’s luxury buildings wage battle over who can deliver the most outsize amenities to residents, some are expanding their focus to include the doormen who quietly usher in residents, handle the packages and hail the cabs.

headline: Sinking Land Brings Calls for Pumping Alternative
text: Amid a persistent drought, a growing population and a dwindling supply of surface water, much of Texas is  searching  for underground water resources.

headline: For Target’s Shoppers, a New Holiday To-Do List
text: Target confirmed on Thursday that hackers gained access to credit card and debit card information for 40 million of its customers during the crush of the holiday shopping season. The company encouraged everyone who shopped in its United States stores from Nov. 27 through Dec. 15 to be vigilant about monitoring their accounts and their credit. Here are some tips on how to do so.

headline: Group Seeks Special Label for Food: ‘Natural’
text: The trade organization representing the nation’s largest food and beverage companies wants permission to label as “natural” products that contain genetically engineered ingredients like corn, soy, canola and sugar, according to a letter sent to the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Is It Really a Bistro? Who Cares?
text: It is a welcoming sight on a cold winter’s eve — a country house, brightly lit, on a country corner. This is 2hopewell Bistro and Bar. Inside you find a cozy basement tavern, and above it dining rooms with ax-hewn posts, flickering candlelight, white walls and wide pine floorboards. Potted palms and Rothko-like prints by the artist Anne Hebebrand, illuminated on the walls, add an apt touch of color. The restaurant is intimate and quiet, with expert service timed perfectly to deliver a luxurious evening. There’s no hurry here.

headline: Same View, Less Money
text: As new luxury high-rises like One57 garner stratospheric prices for their unobstructed Central Park views, some developers are focusing on the potential of the park’s northern frontier. At a development on West 110th Street, developers hope to draw buyers farther north with the promise of Central Park views at a more modest price.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,284 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: I.M.F. Criticizes Ukraine Plan for Economy
text: MOSCOW — The International Monetary Fund issued on Thursday a scathing report on Ukraine’s financial situation, saying that the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovich had largely abandoned much-needed economic reforms that it had agreed to undertake as part of a deal in 2010 that provided more than $15 billion in loans.

headline: A Quicker Trip to the Doctor, for Minor Ailments
text: Christine O’Rourke, who often travels for her job as a regional sales manager for a laboratory company, says she doesn’t have time to wait to see a doctor when she is ill. So instead, she visits a local urgent care clinic near her home in Morris Plains, N.J.

headline: Good Poor, Bad Poor
text: On Sundays, this time of year, my parents would pack a gaggle of us kids into the station wagon for a tour of two Christmas worlds. First, we’d go to the wealthy neighborhoods on a hill — grand Tudor houses glowing with the seasonal incandescence of good fortune. Faces pressed against the car windows, we wondered why their Santa was a better toy-maker than ours.

headline: John Boehner’s Betrayal
text: WOODSTOCK, Ga. — THERE’S a political axiom that says if nobody is upset with what you’re doing, you’re not doing your job. We’ve seen this proved time and again in the liberal attacks on conservatives like Sarah Palin and Dr. Benjamin Carson, who provide principled examples to women and minorities and are savaged by the left for doing that job so well.

headline: Part of Ceiling Collapses During Sold-Out Show at London Theater
text: LONDON — At least seven people were seriously hurt and 81 were lightly injured, according to fire and medical officials, when part of the ceiling of a tall Edwardian theater collapsed Thursday night during a sold-out performance.

headline: Goodbyes Pour In for Popover Café
text: Carol Baer opened the Popover Café on Amsterdam Avenue in July 1981, using hot plates and household convection ovens. Over the course of 32 years it has become one of those places where locals line up for weekend cholesterol, for reasons that might elude an outsider. “Everyone always got treated the same,” Ms. Baer, 68, said last week in the restaurant’s yellow and red dining room, which she acknowledged was in need of an update. “Streisand waited in line. Warren Beatty waited in line.”

headline: Hypertension Guide May Affect 7.4 Million
text: With two-thirds of Americans over 60 experiencing high blood pressure, new treatment guidelines released on Wednesday might mean fewer medications, lower doses or even none at all for millions of people.

headline: Loophole Slowly Tightens on a Bank
text: “Oh what a tangled web we weave, when first we practice to deceive.”

headline: Predictions for the New Year
text: The coming year is expected to be a little kinder to home buyers. While affordability will continue to be a problem in hot markets like New York and San Francisco, buyers in general may find they have more homes to choose from and more lenders vying for their business.

headline: Under Seattle, a Big Object Blocks Bertha. What Is It?
text: SEATTLE — A secret subterranean heart, tinged with mystery and myth, beats beneath the streets in many of the world’s great cities. Tourists seek out the catacombs of Rome, the sewers of Paris and the subway tunnels of New York. Some people believe a den of interstellar aliens lurks beneath Denver International Airport.

headline: Authorities Move Against Rights Group in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Heavily armed state security agents stormed the offices of a prominent human rights organization late Wednesday, detaining and beating staff members during a nine-hour ordeal, according to lawyers for the organization.

headline: Defying Winter’s Dreariness With an Arctic Embrace
text: LONDON — Liz Barraclough likened it to falling naked into a bank of nettles. Guy Wickett said it felt like making snowballs without gloves. Timothy Sutton was more direct: “It bloody hurts,” he said. “But the good thing is if you scream under water no one can hear you.”

headline: Senate Passes Pentagon Bill After Compromise on Obama Nominees
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate reached a last-minute agreement late Thursday night to vote on a small batch of President Obama’s nominees before the weekend, allowing senators to head home in time for the holiday break without approving some crucial appointments, like Janet L. Yellen as chairwoman of the Federal Reserve.

headline: $2.4 Billion Deal for Hong Kong Wireless Business
text: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong billionaire Richard Li is raising his bet on telecommunications, agreeing on Friday to pay $2.4 billion to acquire one of Hong Kong’s biggest mobile phone networks.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Judge Assails Military in Rejecting Count Against Ex-Marine
text: A federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday dismissed the most serious charge against a man accused of the accidental shooting of a fellow serviceman while they were on active duty in Iraq in 2008, ruling that it would be unfair to charge him in civilian court after officials failed for years to charge him in a military court.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Osborne and the Stooges
text: There was, I’m pretty sure, an episode of “The Three Stooges” in which Curly kept banging his head against a wall. When Moe asked him why, he replied, “Because it feels so good when I stop.”

headline: Taxi Industry Bids the Bloomberg Era a Not-So-Fond Farewell
text: When the moment arrived on Thursday to bid farewell to an administration it loathed, New York City’s taxi industry dispensed with any pretense of mixed emotions.

headline: An Easing of Rules on Charges by Amex
text: After a decade of legal battles, the three major credit card companies are backing away from longstanding policies that prevented merchants from charging customers extra for paying with plastic.

headline: Post-Hearing Decision on Wilfredo Santiago
text: Read the entire ruling by Judge Colleen McMahon of Federal District Court.

headline: Washington: Seattle Mayor Forms Panel to Look at Incomes
text: Mayor-elect Ed Murray of Seattle, who ran on a pledge backing a $15 minimum wage, said that he would create an Income Inequality Advisory Committee, led by a union leader and a business executive, and that he planned to propose legislation to the City Council by spring. Washington has the nation’s highest state minimum wage, $9.19, and the small city of SeaTac, Wash., passed a $15 minimum wage on Election Day. It is the nation’s highest municipal rate and twice the federal minimum of $7.25. Mr. Murray, a Democrat, said he would not prejudge the panel’s recommendations, and wanted to avoid an expensive referendum.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Share Your Photos of Light in New York City
text: In New York City, pockets of natural light can be hard to find, even in sunnier seasons. And as new buildings gleam higher in the skyline, those living closer to street level are living in deepening shadows. With the winter solstice occurring this Saturday, Cara Buckley of The Times wrote an article looking at the short- and long-term impact of scarce natural light on the lives of New Yorkers.

headline: Fans Criticize Move to Suspend ‘Duck Dynasty’ Star
text: The A&E network was assailed on Thursday by thousands of fans of its most popular show over its decision to suspend the patriarch of the “Duck Dynasty” family, Phil Robertson, because of comments made in an interview in GQ magazine that the network deemed homophobic.

headline: The Tragic Situation
text: Sometimes life presents clear choices, but often it presents tragic situations. A tragic situation is one in which you are caught in a vise between two competing goods, so it is necessary to compromise one or the other, or maybe a bit of both. Or it’s one in which you are pursuing something good, but you must fight brutal enemies along the way, so it is impossible to be virtuous while being innocent.

headline: Hackers Hit Servers at The Washington Post for a 3rd Time
text: Hackers breached The Washington Post’s computer servers for the third time in three years, the newspaper reported late Wednesday.

headline: Nomination of Baucus Buoys Midterm Hopes For Senate Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — When the veteran Senator Max Baucus announced his retirement in April, a feeling of dread went through the Democratic ranks, not so much over the potential loss of his Montana seat, but over the game of musical committee chairs that would elevate an iconoclast to lead the coveted Finance Committee and a pro-oil moderate to head the energy committee.

headline: Toss Out Records When Rangers and Islanders Meet? They’re Likely to Approve
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — When the Islanders visit the Rangers at Madison Square Garden, decibel levels rise and records have minimal meaning.

headline: Growing Corruption Inquiry Hits Close to Turkish Leader
text: ISTANBUL — In building his political career, Turkey’s powerful and charismatic prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, relied heavily on the support of a Sufi mystic preacher whose base of operations is now in Pennsylvania.

headline: Release the Torture Reports
text: A dozen years after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, it is appalling that official reports about the extent and nature of the rendition, detention and torture that came in their aftermath are still being kept from the American public and even members of Congress charged with overseeing intelligence activities.

headline: Canadian Review Panel Approves Plans for an Oil Pipeline
text: OTTAWA — An environmental and economic review panel approved plans for a pipeline and port project that, if built, will move oil from Alberta’s oil sands to tankers on Canada’s Pacific Coast.

headline: Russian Amnesties
text: The announcement in Russia that Mikhail Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon; the two Pussy Riot demonstrators; and Greenpeace activists may all be freed soon, along with thousands of other Russians, is certainly good news. But decreeing clemency, a move initiated by President Vladimir Putin, is not the same as acknowledging that these prisoners were improperly incarcerated to begin with.

headline: Jihadist Leader Envisions an Islamic State in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In his first television interview, the leader of the Nusra Front, one of the most powerful jihadist groups in the Syrian insurgency, told Al Jazeera that he believed victory was near; that his battle was a fight to defend Sunni Muslims from a global plan to keep them weak; and that his organization sought to establish, but not rule, an Islamic state.

headline: Insider Jury-Room Demonstration Persuaded Holdouts in Ex-Trader’s Trial
text: After more than nine hours of deliberating in a cramped room so warm that they had to ask for ice, the nine women and three men on a federal jury had reached an impasse.

headline: India’s Misplaced Outrage
text: India’s overwrought reaction to the arrest of one of its diplomats in the United States is unworthy of a democratic government. Officials in New Delhi have inflamed anti-American outrage instead of calling for justice, especially for the domestic worker who is at the heart of the case.

headline: Investors’ Story Left Out of Wall St. ‘Wolf’ Movie
text: The Wolf of Wall Street is about to have his day.

headline: In Navy Billing Scandal, a Third Company Puts an Executive on Leave
text: Amid a scandal that has already ensnared two ship supply companies in allegations of overbilling the Navy, a third firm that provides services to the Navy’s fleet has placed one of its senior executives on leave over questions about how he handled Navy contracts at another company.

headline: Lessons From the Sandusky Case
text: As the scandal unfolded that sent Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach, to prison last year for raping and molesting 10 boys, it became clear that Pennsylvania’s child abuse laws were among the weakest in the nation. The main law was too narrowly defined, requiring “severe pain,” disfigurement or “serious” impairment of a major bodily function for an act to be deemed child abuse. The loopholes this allowed were reflected in the state’s low ranking in substantiated cases of child abuse of all kinds — a rate of 1.2 per 1,000 children versus the national average of 9.1 in 2011, according to Protect Our Children Committee, a state advocacy group.

headline: ‘Pajama Boy’ and Nathaniel P.
text: I give real credit to Noreen Malone at The New Republic for tying my mini-war with liberal magazine writers over sex, female happiness, and the Brooklyn-set novel “The Love Affairs of Nathaniel P.” to the larger cultural battle over masculinity touched off by the onesie-clad “Pajama Boy” featured in an Obamacare awareness-raising pitch. But this, I’m afraid, is not what I meant at all:

headline: New York Council Votes to Ban Foam Food Containers and to Curb E-Cigarette Smoking
text: In its last scheduled legislative session of the year, the New York City Council passed major health and environmental regulations on Thursday, establishing a ban on plastic-foam food service containers, extending the city’s ban on public smoking to cover e-cigarettes and requiring composting at large restaurants.

headline: For More Democracy, Not Ethnic Hatred, in Ukraine
Should the Charitable Deduction Be Modified?
Effective Teachers in the Inner-City Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama Weighing Security and Privacy in Deciding on Spy Program Limits
text: WASHINGTON — If President Obama adopts the most far-reaching recommendations of the advisory group he set up to rein in the National Security Agency, much would change underneath the giant antennas that sprout over Fort Meade, Md., where America’s electronic spies and cyberwarriors have operated with an unprecedented amount of freedom since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

headline: A Legacy in the Balance on Surveillance Policies
text: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, the proposed overhaul of the American surveillance state confronts him with a fundamental choice: Will he become the commander in chief many expected in 2008 or remain the one he became in 2009? Or is there a balance in between?

headline: Senate Bill to Impose New Sanctions on Iran Spurs Veto Threat From White House
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators, defying the White House, introduced a bill on Thursday to impose new sanctions on Iran if it failed to conclude a nuclear agreement, or stick to the terms of its interim deal, with the United States and other major powers.

headline: U.S. Deportations Decline; Felons Made Up Big Share
text: The Obama administration deported 368,644 foreigners during the 2013 fiscal year, immigration enforcement officials reported on Thursday, 10 percent fewer than in 2012 but nonetheless bringing the total number deported under President Obama to more than 1.9 million, by far the most for an American president.

headline: Smith Puts On Air Show With 17 3-Point Shots
text: To embrace J. R. Smith is to take the bad with the good. When Smith helped lead the Knicks to the playoffs last season, few were complaining. But on Wednesday night the team and its fans saw what it is like when Smith is determined to keep shooting even when things have gone somewhat awry.

headline: Trail of Fractured Political Friendships on Way to Advancement in City Council
text: They seemed destined to be friends: two women who became next-door neighbors on 111th Street in East Harlem, different generations of Puerto Ricans who were active in community organizing and politics.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 20, 2013
text: “Hefner did it with taste. Goldstein’s contribution is to be utterly tasteless.”

headline: Another Rule in Health Law Is Scaled Back
text: WASHINGTON — Millions of people facing the cancellation of health insurance policies will be allowed to buy catastrophic coverage and will be exempt from penalties if they go without insurance next year, the White House said Thursday night.

headline: Where It Never Gets Above Zero Degrees

headline: S.E.C. Tension as It Examined Mortgage Cases

headline: A Shakespearean Tale of Far-Flung Adventures
text: The major Shakespearean revivals in New York this year have mostly favored the best-known works: “Romeo and Juliet,” “Macbeth,” “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” and “Twelfth Night.” After revisiting those long-familiar plays, I found it a treat to encounter the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey’s engaging production of the rarely staged “Pericles” in Madison.

headline: A City Councilwoman Not Afraid to Take On Inequality
text: In fall 2011, when tents and tarps covered Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, the same heated debates about inequality and economic fairness that animated the Occupy Wall Street protests were playing out in the New York City Council.

headline: A Night When Ghosts Fly and Scrooge Reforms
text: Jacob Marley’s Ghost is the best flier, leaping atop Ebenezer Scrooge’s canopy bed at one point and later wailing as he soars to the rafters. But then all of Marley’s big scene is quite dramatic; he makes his entrance through a trap door that appears to lead to the fires of hell.

headline: Fury in India Over Diplomat’s Arrest in New York
text: Public flag burnings. The removal of security barriers around the United States Embassy in New Delhi. Diplomatic overtures amid talks of sanctions.

headline: Cruz Has Surgery, Ending His Season
text: Victor Cruz, the Giants’ leading wide receiver with 73 catches for 998 yards and 4 touchdowns, had an arthroscopic debridement of his left knee Thursday that will end his season.

headline: At 14, Top Prospects Decide if Path to N.H.L. Runs Through College
text: SARNIA, Ontario — In the hockey-rich swath of North America that encompasses Michigan and Ontario, the Ontario Hockey League and the newly formed Big Ten hockey conference do not compete just for talent at youth tournaments and junior showcases. They also lobby parents about which system is the better final exam for an N.H.L. career.

headline: Additional Four Charged in Florida Prison Escape Scheme
text: MIAMI — Anxious to defuse a scandal involving two prison inmates who obtained their freedom by forging release orders, Florida officials said Thursday that they had traced the scheme to an inmate who taught others how to carry out the deceptions.

headline: Christie’s Appraises Detroit Institute Artworks
text: The auction house appraised about 2,800 works — less than 5 percent of the institute’s entire collection — arriving at a total valuation of between $454 million and $867 million.

headline: Poetry and Trains, Operating at Strolling Speed
text: The New York Botanical Garden is bringing the magic of its annual holiday train show outdoors to its bare but still beautiful Bronx grounds this winter, with a special poetry walk featuring the works of Billy Collins, former poet laureate of the United States and of the State of New York.

headline: Formal Beginning to de Blasio’s Plan to Expand, and Pay for, Prekindergarten
text: Trying to harness the widespread electoral and celebrity support that delivered him to City Hall, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio on Thursday unveiled his newest campaign, to win a tax on high-earning New Yorkers to vastly improve the city’s prekindergarten and after-school programs.

headline: Report Finds Human Error in 911 Delay in Fatal Crash
text: A 4-year-old girl, struck by a sport utility vehicle fleeing the police, lay motionless on a sidewalk on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Immediately, radio calls from officers at the scene cascaded with increasing urgency to 911 dispatchers.

headline: When One Artist Singles Out Another
text: “We’re such old pals,” the artist Keith Sonnier was saying one afternoon last month while visiting the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill. He was talking about his fellow artists Ned Smyth and Judith Hudson, who were also at the museum, but he could also have been referring to the whole community of well-established artists, many of them internationally known, who live and work on Long Island’s East End.

headline: Court Filing Shows Troubled Past for Suspect in Etan Patz Case
text: The man accused of killing Etan Patz has a history of sexually abusing a family member, drug abuse and acts of domestic violence against his former and current wife, according to a court document filed last week by prosecutors in the case.

headline: Scourged by Fire, and Aiding a Sister Burned Even Worse
text: The little girl wanted to demonstrate her fine penmanship, to show how splendidly she could write. Proudly, she clenched the pencil between her two fingerless fists. She carefully wrote her name: Gabriella. It was perfect. She looked pleased.

headline: Sparkling Wines to Please a Range of Palates
text: Long Islanders stocking up on dry sparkling wines for Christmas and New Year’s festivities can find what they are looking for locally. I recently tasted some that were released in 2013.

headline: No One Else Like Her
text: Calamity hit the Rogers family twice through fire, in 1992 and 2007. Gabriella, then 4, was burned on 95 percent of her body the second time.

headline: China Everbright Bank Shares Fall on Trading Debut
text: Updated, 3:11 a.m. | HONG KONG–Despite what has been a buoyant market for Chinese companies’ share offerings in Hong Kong in recent weeks, shares in China Everbright Bank sank on their trading debut on Friday.

headline: Carp ‘Saved,’ Then Caught, as Religious Act Goes Awry in China
text: Supposed to help with rebirth, or at least a long life, what looked remarkably like a Buddhist act of faith called “releasing lives to freedom” went horribly wrong on the banks of the Yellow River this week when fishermen waited downstream with nets to “wildly” snap up a large amount of the released carp, Chinese media reported.

headline: An Exhibit of Beards and Mustaches, the Uncut Version
text: “Beards: The Long and Short of It,” a new exhibition at the Morris Museum in Morristown, doesn’t look the way Angela Sergonis-Melchionne envisioned it when she started planning the show last year.

headline: Long Goodbye for Quinn, the Departing Council Speaker
text: One of Christine C. Quinn’s longtime nemeses on the New York City Council, Letitia James, had nothing but praise for her on Thursday, saluting her ability to overcome personal obstacles and become “the backbone of our institution.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 19, 2013
In Duke’s Win at the Garden, a ‘Natural’ Draws Comparisons to Anthony
text: Rodney Hood was 10 in 2003 when Syracuse, led by a freshman named Carmelo Anthony, beat Kansas for the national title.

headline: John W. Cornforth, 96, Nobel-Winning Chemist, Dies
text: John W. Cornforth, an Australian-born scientist who shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1975 and could trace that achievement to his discovery as a child that he was growing deaf, died on Dec. 8 in Sussex, England. He was 96.

headline: Richard D. Heffner, Host of ‘The Open Mind,’ Dies at 88
text: Richard D. Heffner, a historian, educator and broadcaster who was the longtime host of “The Open Mind,” the venerable current-affairs program on public television, and who also spent two decades as chairman of the motion picture industry’s film-ratings board, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Bernard Shaw, Husband and Bodyguard of Patty Hearst, Dies at 68
text: Bernard L. Shaw, a former San Francisco police officer who became the bodyguard and husband of Patricia Hearst, the heiress who was abducted in 1974 by a leftist guerrilla organization and then imprisoned for crimes she was accused of committing on its behalf, died on Dec. 17 at his home in Garrison, N.Y. He was 68.

headline: Report on Emergency Response in Ariel Russo Accident
text: A 42-page document, released on Thursday by the city Department of Investigation, offers a nearly second-by-second reconstruction of the timeline of the fatal crash that killed the 4-year-old.

headline: Scott Brown Plans New Hampshire Move
text: So Scott Brown is moving to New Hampshire, he confirmed Thursday. The former senator from Massachusetts said his reasons for moving were “strictly personal,” and that they had more to do with empty-nesting than with his political future.

headline: Who Says Laughter’s the Best Medicine?
text: Just in time to protect patients from the dangers of holiday cheer, a new scholarly review from a British medical journal describes many harmful effects wrought by laughter.

headline: The Economics of Being Kinder and Gentler in Health Care

headline: 6 Injured in 2 Fires in the Bronx

headline: Japan Stays Aggressive on Stimulus
text: TOKYO — Japan’s central bank decided on Friday to hold steady on its aggressive monetary stimulus program and said the nation’s economy continued to recover moderately. Economists expect the bank to expand its asset-buying program next year to counter any ill effects of a scheduled sales tax increase.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 8 P.M. (TNT) CHRISTMAS IN WASHINGTON 2013 Hugh Jackman hosts this 32nd annual holiday concert benefiting the Children’s National Health System, taped on Sunday at the National Building Museum in Washington and attended by President Obama and his family, above. The Backstreet Boys, Sheryl Crow, Anna Kendrick, Janelle Monáe and Pat Monahan perform; the N.B.A. Hall of Famer Charles Barkley talks about Children’s National programs. “A Christmas Carol” (1999), David Jones’s adaptation of the Charles Dickens classic, starring Patrick Stewart as Ebenezer Scrooge, Richard E. Grant as Bob Cratchit, Saskia Reeves as Mrs. Cratchit and Joel Grey as the First Sprit, follows at 9. Writing in The New York Times, Caryn James called the production glorious: “Its greatest triumph is Mr. Stewart’s performance. (He has played all the parts in his one-man stage version.)” She said, “This impenetrable man will not be easily touched, even by ghosts.” This “Christmas Carol” is a lasting addition to a list of towering renditions, she added. “Evoking the pure joy of the Christmas season and its spirit of giving, it reveals why Dickens’s story has such inexhaustible appeal.”

headline: A Stark Gap in Breast Cancer Deaths
text: The difference in mortality rates between black women and white women with breast cancer has widened since 1975, in part because black women have not benefited as much from improvements in screening and treatment. Among the states with available data, Tennessee has the largest gap. Massachusetts, where the rates have converged, has the smallest.

headline: The Cancer Divide: Mary
text: Mary Singleton, 57, learned in July that she had Stage 4 breast cancer. After the diagnosis her son, George, moved home to Memphis to help take care of her and to help run her printing business.

headline: Tackling a Racial Gap in Breast Cancer Survival
text: MEMPHIS — After her doctor told her two months ago that she had breast cancer, Debrah Reid, a 58-year-old dance teacher, drove straight to a funeral home. She began planning a burial with the funeral director and his wife, even requesting a pink coffin.

headline: Head of Japanese Restaurant Chain Is Shot Dead
text: TOKYO — In a brazen gun attack that shocked a country tough on firearms, the head of a nationwide dumpling restaurant chain was shot dead in front of his company’s headquarters on Thursday.

headline: In Letter, North Korea Warns South Over Rallies
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has sent a letter to the office of President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, threatening “retaliatory strikes without warning” if anti-Pyongyang rallies by conservative activists in Seoul are not stopped, officials here said on Friday.

headline: A Conversation With: Political Scientist Ashutosh Varshney
text: NEW DELHI — In less than six months from now, more than 700 million voters in India will exercise their voting franchise to elect the country’s next government. The 2014 elections will be a major test for the governing Congress Party, which has battled a series of corruption allegations and heavy defeats in recent state assembly elections.

headline: Fear of Credit Crisis Resurfaces in China as Interest Rates Rise
text: HONG KONG — Money market rates in China surged again on Friday, shrugging off the central bank’s efforts a day earlier to provide more liquidity to the market and raising fears that the Chinese financial system could be hit by a credit crisis similar to the one that occurred in June.

headline: After Death, Indonesian Ad Industry Scrutinized
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The death of an Indonesian copywriter has generated a surge of anger in Indonesia, turning the young woman into an inadvertent symbol of the grueling, workaholic culture of the advertising world.

headline: Introducing the Huracán, Lamborghini’s Gallardo Successor
text: Lamborghini today released images and specifications for its successor to the V10-powered Gallardo, since 2004 the junior model to the automaker’s flagship nameplates – first the Murciélago, then the Aventador. Following the Lamborghini tradition of christening cars with names associated with Spanish bullfighting, the new model will be called the Huracán 610-4, after a bull that fought valiantly in Alicante in the late 19th century. The Huracán will make its public debut at the GenevaMotor Show inMarch.

headline: Chinese Respondents Top Materialism Poll
text: A global poll of attitudes toward wealth has found what many domestic critics allege already: Chinese today are just too materialistic.

headline: Christie’s First Auction in India Breaks Records for Local Artists
text: Demonstrating the robust demand for Indian art, Christie’s first auction in India almost doubled its high estimate of $8 million to bring in $15.4 million, or 965.9 million rupees, selling nearly all the works on offer and breaking a number of records for Indian artists.

headline: South Sudan Steps Closer to Unraveling
text: The United Nations provided sobering details on Friday of an assault on a peacekeeping base in South Sudan that underscored the organization’s fragile ability to protect civilians in the country, where sectarian mayhem has escalated in recent days.

headline: Freed Abruptly by Putin, Khodorkovsky Arrives in Germany
text: MOSCOW — After 10 years in prison, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former chairman of Yukos Oil and once Russia’s richest man, walked free from a penal colony in northern Russia on Friday and flew to Berlin on a private jet. It was an abrupt and stunning end to an episode that had marked a darkly authoritarian turn for Russia under President Vladimir V. Putin, while sending a fearsome warning to the rest of the elite, oligarch class.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Bleak Struggle for Survivors Eight Months After Bangladesh Factory Collapse
text: In “After Bangladesh Factory Collapse, Bleak Struggle for Survivors,” Jim Yardley reports on the aftermath of the Bangladesh factory collapse that occurred eight months ago.

headline: From the Bowery, Comfort and Joy
text: Susan Meiselas was walking near her apartment on Mott Street in the winter of 1976 when she spotted a figure in a crimson suit, a stocking cap with fur trim and a long white beard making his way down the sidewalk before disappearing into the subway. Curious, Ms. Meiselas followed him.

headline: What Are Your Predictions for 2014?
text: This is our final Student Opinion question until Jan. 2, 2014, so it seems only fitting to ask: What are your predictions for the new year? What do you think, or hope, might happen in the world next year? In your own personal life? Why?

headline: Chinese Navy to Aid U.S. Ship Destroying Syrian Chemical Weapons
text: The same day that Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel of the United States blasted the actions of a Chinese ship in the South China Sea as “irresponsible,” China announced that it would deploy a military ship to work with an American vessel involved in the destruction of Syria’s chemical weapons.
