headline: The Pies That Bind
text: My winning streak as our family’s champion pie king ended six years ago — and that’s when all the trouble started. Since going to college down South, I had sat on the holiday pie throne without fear of challenge, learning early what my Tar Heel neighbor Frances Mayes wrote in “Under the Tuscan Sun”: “[P]ecan pie [is] a necessary ingredient of Christmas.” Remaining the king was a result of the time I’d invested refining my pecan pie recipe — which, if I may — had two outstanding attributes: a generous helping of Kentucky bourbon to cut the treacly sweetness of the Karo syrup and a top secret mixing technique that prevented the pie from becoming gelatinous.

headline: Virtual Reality, Real Spies
text: Aha! It seems that national security personnel have been infiltrating the online game World of Warcraft, disguised as loathsome Orcs or brew-swilling Pandarens or pointy-eared, deep-cleavaged Blood Elves. What are these costumed undercover agents doing in the hi-def scenery, apart from having fun? The cover story is that they hope to expose hordes of terrorists laundering money in pretend banks or trading toxic info on drawbridges; or else to unearth — concealed in a surreal mushroom or luminous flower or ominous grotto — a keyhole leading to the Dark Web.

headline: S.&P. Cuts European Union’s Credit Rating
text: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders gathering here for a summit meeting on Friday barely had time to congratulate themselves on their new banking deal before getting a slap in the face from the ratings agency Standard & Poor’s.

headline: The New Face of Chinese Propaganda
text: BEIJING — An old schoolmate of mine is now a midlevel government official. This friend, Mr. Lin, is also a member of the Chinese Communist Party. He worships Mao Zedong and often quotes Mao’s saying, “Man must have some spirit.” He once told me that when he visited New York, he most liked the Statue of Liberty, because it had “spirit,” and least liked Times Square, because it was “all about business.”

headline: After Hurricane Sandy, Reclaiming Christmas
text: On the first day of December, from the time the children were little, I hung the Advent calendar on the door to the laundry room. I never liked that calendar much. It was ordinary, made of cloth, maybe three feet long with 25 pockets. Each day, as we counted the time left until Christmas, our four children, starting with the youngest, took turns filling another pocket with a small toy or candy cane or reindeer, and then finally, on Christmas morning, Santa’s head.

headline: Establishing a Process to Evaluate Ideas
text: Innovation is one of the keys to business success. If you don’t innovate, your business will suffer. If it isn’t made obsolete by competition, it will likely end up as a commodity business with little to distinguish it from competitors. And yet, not every new idea that a business comes up with is going to be a good one.

headline: China Targets Lavish Funerals in Crackdown on Official Corruption
text: After taking on lavish banquets and expensive gifts, the crackdown on official extravagance led by President Xi Jinping has a new target in its sights: opulent funerals. According to an announcement, posted online on Thursday, Communist Party members have been instructed to “set an example in holding simple and civilized funerals.”

headline: Jazz Pharmaceuticals to Buy Gentium for $1 Billion
text: LONDON – The Irish drug maker Jazz Pharmaceuticals agreed to acquire Gentium in a deal valued at about $1 billion, diversifying its portfolio of treatments for rare diseases.

headline: Daily Report: Data Theft at Target the Latest Salvo in a Long War
text: Target may have been an easy bull’s-eye for criminal hackers intent on stealing credit card information, but the theft of records for 40 million store customers was hardly the worst security breach among big retailers in recent years. And the incident revealed on Thursday is unlikely to be the last, Nicole Perlroth reports.

headline: BlackBerry Staggers to a Deeper, $4.4 Billion Loss
text: OTTAWA — BlackBerry, the hobbled smartphone maker, reported more dire financial news on Friday, posting a $4.4 billion loss and a 56 percent drop in revenue in its latest quarter. The company also outlined a sharp retreat from its once-core handset business by entering a partnership with the Asian contract manufacturer Foxconn.

headline: Ugandan Lawmakers Pass Measure Imposing Harsh Penalties on Gays
text: LONDON — The Ugandan Parliament announced Friday that it had approved legislation imposing harsh penalties on gay people, including life imprisonment for what it called “aggravated homosexuality,” effectively brushing aside previous objections to antigay legislation from outside powers, including President Obama.

headline: Revision Shows U.S. Growing at Fastest Rate Since 2011
text: WASHINGTON — The United States economy grew at a surprisingly robust 4.1 percent annual pace in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said on Friday. It was the strongest advance in nearly two years and only the third time the economy had expanded that quickly from one quarter to the next since 2006.

headline: Report Card Ranks Lower House of Parliament as Least Productive Ever
text: NEW DELHI — Now that the 15th Lok Sabha, or lower house of Parliament, has closed its winter session, the verdict by one research institute is in: This group of lawmakers is shaping up to be the least productive in the history of Parliament.

OVER MORTGAGE CASES After months of investigating the role of Goldman Sachs, Wells Fargo and others in troubled mortgage securities — and even warning that enforcement actions were possible — the Securities and Exchange Commission shelved those cases and at least two others.

text: LONDON – European antitrust regulators said Friday that they had opened an in-depth investigation into an agreement by the Spanish telecommunications company Telefónica to buy Germany’s smallest mobile operator, E-Plus, from its Dutch rival KPN.

headline: N.S.A. Spied on Allies, Aid Groups and Businesses
text: Secret documents reveal more than 1,000 targets of American and British surveillance in recent years, including the office of an Israeli prime minister, heads of international aid organizations, foreign energy companies and a European Union official involved in antitrust battles with American technology businesses.

headline: Weary Obama at Break, Hoping for a Breakthrough
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s news conference on Friday was full of banter and holiday wishes, in keeping with the year-end White House ritual. But Mr. Obama’s demeanor and words were often downbeat, leaving no doubt that the gathering was not, as he said at the beginning, “the most wonderful news conference of the year.”

headline: Deutsche Bank to Pay $1.9 Billion Over Troubled Mortgage Securities
text: Deutsche Bank agreed on Friday to pay about $1.9 billion to settle claims that it misled Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac over the quality of home loans bundled into mortgage-backed securities, becoming the latest big bank to reach a settlement with federal housing regulators.

headline: Chicago’s Opportunity Artist
text: Six blocks from where I grew up, on Chicago’s South Side, the artist Theaster Gates showed me a neo-Classical ruin, a Prohibition-era bank shuttered for 33 years that I only ever registered vaguely as a part of the area’s enduring blight. “That’s my bank,” he announced with a flourish, pointing proudly to its glazed terra cotta and its ornamental eaves. Maybe it requires an artist to picture the possibilities in such a wreck, or a real estate developer to envision its promise. Gates, 40, is both at the same time, an enormous dreamer canny enough to make his outlandish ideas for the neighborhood a reality. When the bank was days from demolition, Gates spoke with Mayor Rahm Emanuel, whose brother, Ari, owns several Gates pieces; the city agreed to sell the abandoned building to Gates for $1, with the stipulation that he come up with the $3.7 million necessary for its renovation. A portion of that money, Gates devised, would be made from the bank’s original marble, which he cut into individual “bond certificates” engraved with an image of the building, his signature and the words “In ART We Trust.” He created 100 tablet-size bonds, selling them for $5,000 apiece; larger slabs, as weighty as tombstones, went for $50,000. Because they’re works of art, Gates told me, the marble will actually increase in value, functioning like real bonds. “So, yeah, it’s a bank! The bank should continue to make currency. I want it to have a banking function.”

headline: B.J. Novak’s Thanksgiving Congregation
text: Take a hike, Donder; Dante de Blasio or Dante Alighieri?

headline: (Sub)Mission Creep
text: I work at a midsize publishing company. I randomly met a writer outside of work and offered to read over his unpublished manuscript. I had him send it to my work address, but it was unclear whether I was reading as a new friend or a potential publisher. I read the manuscript during work hours. It was wonderful. I’m certain he would be able to get picked up by a competing company — one with better publicity and marketing resources than my own, more willing to give him higher compensation and greater attention. This could be a chance for our company to publish something special, and I would receive credit for acquiring a new author. But as a friend, I would never recommend us. To whom am I ethically obligated here, this writer or my company? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

headline: The Bots Are Taking Over
text: Snapshots of a band of brothers.

headline: Life With Bella
text: The banquet hall of the Midtown hotel was filling up with a stressed after-work crowd. It was a meeting of the A.C.P.A. — the Association of Celebrity Personal Assistants. After the cocktail hour, everyone signed a confidentiality agreement and placed their folding chairs in a circle. We went around: name, celebrity, horror story.

headline: Finding Inner Peace With the Angriest Punk of ’70s New York
text: “We’ve suffered enough as human beings and as women,” Lydia Lunch said one bright morning in Ojai, Calif., as she gazed beneficently around her. Sixteen women, most of them middle-aged, had gathered at Ananda Verandah (“Ananda” is Sanskrit for “bliss”) to take Lunch’s Post-Catastrophe Collaborative workshop.

headline: Mireille Guiliano On Aging With French Dignity
text: In 2005, you published “French Women Don’t Get Fat.” What do you think makes our cultures so different? I think half a century ago, things changed drastically. Before those days, women were at home and they were cooking. With feminism, you had to go to work, and if you had to go work — well, you know, forget the cooking. For many French women a job is not the top priority in life — family is. In the U.S. you’re sort of defined by what you do. That’s why so many women are lost when they finish their career.

headline: The 12.8.13 Issue
One! Last! Time!
text: On Christmas Day, Robert De Niro and Sylvester Stallone will open in “Grudge Match,” a movie about a couple of old, rival boxers spoiling for one last fight. This may seem like an unpromising premise, but perhaps the movie will please the same audience that went for the recent comedy “Last Vegas,” which is about three AARP-appropriate Brooklyn guys from the old neighborhood — one married, one divorced and one widowed — who get together for one last ring-a-ding-ding Vegas weekend to toast the impending wedding of their fourth pal, a holdout bachelor who has spontaneously decided to tie the knot. (Gentle life lessons ensue.) The fact that the preternaturally tan and swinging groom to be is played by Michael Douglas (age 69) adds a dribble of amusement to the premise. So does the paycheck-collecting participation of aging movie stars like De Niro (him again), Morgan Freeman and Kevin Kline.

headline: Who Made That Smoke Alarm?
text: In the early 1960s, Duane Pearsall tinkered in his engineering lab with a machine he called a “static neutralizer” — an ion generator designed to control static electricity in factories and photo labs. But when one of his technicians lit up a cigarette, a meter measuring the ions went haywire. Pearsall realized he’d just hit on a low-cost, low-power method for sniffing smoke. During the next decade, he and his team developed the SmokeGard, which hung from the ceiling and made a noxious noise whenever it sensed a fire. Soon, smoke detectors were in most homes in America and had saved hundreds of lives. Yet they could also be irritating. “You have no way of knowing whether it’s operational unless you set fire to your house,” wrote one newspaper humorist in 1977 of a cheap smoke detector he bought in a local store. “Merely holding the smoke detector in your lap while you watch Farrah Fawcett-Majors is not a true test.”

headline: Weak Recovery, but Comparatively Good
text: INDUSTRIAL production in the United States has returned to its prerecession level, nearly six years after the downturn began and more than four years after the recession officially ended.

headline: Off the Charts: In the United States, Production Is Back
text: Industrial production in the United States returned in November to the level it was at before the recession began.

headline: A Historian in Camelot
text: Most intellectuals are attracted to power, but none with less ambivalence than Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the brilliant historian of the New Deal who became the quasi-official chronicler of the Kennedys. Schlesinger was born into an American aristocracy in its prime — the Eastern liberal intelligentsia. He was the son of an eminent Harvard historian and grew up apparently knowing everyone. He met his first Kennedy (sister Rosemary, before her lobotomy) when he was 14, at a Christmas party in 1931. It was natural, maybe even inevitable, that Schlesinger, while serving as an intelligence officer in Germany at the end of the war, would be invited to dinner “at the palatial mansion shared by George Ball and Ken Galbraith.” In Washington after the war, the young author of “The Age of Jackson” had a place at the table of Georgetown dinner parties thrown by the columnist Joseph Alsop, where he met Democratic Party royalty — Averell Harriman (“quite favorably impressed by him”), Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. (“looks astonishingly like his father and has adopted many of his mannerisms”) and John F. Kennedy (“seemed very sincere and not unintelligent, but kind of on the conservative side”).

headline: A Book Brings Champions Together
text: Next year, two previous “Jeopardy!” champions, Tom Nissley and India Cooper, will compete in the show’s Battle of the Decades, a tournament featuring winners from the 1980s through the 2000s. The publishing world recently gave the pair reason to meet ahead of the game.

headline: Pop Music

headline: Tractor-Trailer Kills 8-Year-Old Boy Walking to School in Queens
text: An 8-year-old boy who was walking with his sister to school was struck and killed by a tractor-trailer on Friday in an intersection in Queens just two blocks from his home, the authorities said.

headline: Inside the List
text: The Limited: Hardcovers, paperbacks, ­e-books — the combined lists include them all. But what about collectible limited editions, wherein a specialty publisher produces a small run of books to an exacting standard, often by hand? (Think of the old leather-bound Franklin Library titles, for example.) The Times doesn’t track those, since by their nature they sell in numbers too small to register. That doesn’t mean they never intersect with the best-seller lists, though. One such publisher is Joe Stefko, the owner of Charnel House books in Catskill, N.Y., who for more than 20 years has printed limited editions of Dean Koontz’s novels. Stefko, 58, a former drummer for Meat Loaf, got interested in fine books when he played with the Turtles. “Other bands had drug dealers coming to their dressing rooms,” he told a music fan site some years ago, “and we had book dealers coming to ours.” As you’d guess from its name — and its address, P.O. Box 666 — Charnel House specializes in horror, and Stefko has designed covers with protruding fangs (for Christopher Moore), real bullets (for Stephen King) and deep fingernail gouges (for Tim Powers). “These are commercial books,” he told me in a phone interview, “but I turn them into fine art.”

headline: Fragile Lull Is Shattered by Clashes in Africa
text: BANGUI, Central African Republic — Clashes broke out in several quarters on Friday here in the capital, leaving 19 people dead, shattering the tentative lull that had held for a week and revealing the dangerous numbers of armed militiamen still in the city.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Behind the Music
text: This week, Alan Light discusses four new memoirs by music stars; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; David Leonhardt talks about Angus Deaton’s “Great Escape”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Today in Small Business: Surcharge!
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

text: After getting the Initial Operational Clearance, the aircraft moved a step closer to be inducted into the squadrons of the Indian Air Force.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: AMERICA’S GREAT GAME: The CIA’s Secret Arabists and the Shaping of the Modern Middle East,  by Hugh Wilford. (Basic Books, $29.99.) How the C.I.A., pushed by John Foster Dulles, lost the respect of the Arab world in the 1950s.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SHOOTING VICTORIA: Madness, Mayhem, and the Rebirth of the British Monarchy,  by Paul Thomas Murphy. (Pegasus, $18.95.) Between 1840 and 1882, while thrones across Europe toppled, there were eight unsuccessful attempts on Queen Victoria’s life. Murphy’s book — a learned ramble through history, literature, penology, constitutional theory and even ballistics — argues that the would-be assassins cemented Victoria’s popularity and helped preserve the British monarchy.

headline: Survival Skills
text: In many classic children’s novels, parents are a problem best dispensed with early on. Life only gets interesting — if, typically, more unpleasant — once they are out of the way. Hence the popularity of the orphan plot, from Dickens to Rowling, and, lately, its contemporary cousin, the single-parent plot (see “The Hunger Games” and “Twilight”).

headline: Lights, Camera, Dysfunction
text: In a 2009 episode of the television show “Wife Swap,” a pudgy 7-year-old named Curtis was paired for a while with a mom from another family who emphasized good eating habits, waking up early and other affronts to 7-year-olds everywhere. Curtis’s on-air retorts, including “Bacon is good for me” and “Chicken nuggets is like my family,” made him a meme online, where he is still known as King Curtis.

headline: More Precious Than Rubies
text: Like a fairy tale, “The Kingdom of Little Wounds” starts with a pin’s prick and a drop of blood. Ava Bingen, a seamstress and the book’s main character, must quickly mend Queen Isabel’s gown, which has ripped in the midst of a ball. Her needle slips and she pricks royal flesh. It’s 1572 in the Scandinavian city of Skyggehavn, and Ava, for her incompetence, is thrown into the dungeon.

headline: Winter Wonders
text: My 3-year old daughter knows nothing of snow. She’d only just turned 2 when we moved to Rome — a spellbinding city in many ways but one where snow rarely falls. (In 2012, a blizzard ground the city to a halt, and Romans are still talking about it with wide-eyed amazement.) My daughter can’t possibly remember the winters of her New York babyhood, but suddenly, about six months ago, she began to ask me when the snow would come. When would we play in the snow? Where was the snow hiding? I could only guess she was exhibiting a child’s sixth sense for wonder: Snow is a portal out of the ordinary churn of life, forcing even grown-ups to go out and play. Coincidentally, and luckily for my daughter, three new picture books herald the majesty of snow, bringing its almost magically transformative power to any child who yearns for it.

headline: Reigning Heavyweight
text: Vice president Joe Biden was wrong when he said, at last year’s Democratic Convention, “It’s never been a good bet to bet against the American people.” In fact, claiming that America is going to hell in a handbasket has been among the more reliable routes to both the Oval Office and the best-seller lists. Josef Joffe, the publisher-editor of the German weekly Die Zeit, points out in his new book, “The Myth of America’s Decline,” that the United States has been dogged for much of its history as a superpower by warnings of doom.

headline: In Other Words
text: If you’ve ever doubted that individual words can be a window into a whole culture, “The Book of Jezebel,” “The Horologicon” and “Wordbirds” will change your mind.

headline: Correspondence to Self
text: Writing multiple novels is generally considered a triumph, writing multiple memoirs a somewhat shameful habit. Still, I’ve never heard anyone sniff about Paul Auster’s autobiographical recidivism; perhaps his 16 acclaimed novels compensate for it. In any case, on the basis of his five memoirs alone, Auster should be recognized as one of the great American prose stylists of our time.

headline: Continental Drifters
text: “The strain of holding the I together adheres to the I in all stages; and the temptation to lose it has always been there with the blind determination to maintain it.” This quotation, from Theodor Adorno and Max Horkheimer’s “Dialectic of Enlightenment,” is the first of the three epigraphs of “Nothing,” Anne Marie Wirth Cauchon’s bluntly apocalyptic and psychologically attentive first novel. Her two I’s, Ruth and James, who take turns narrating the book’s brisk chapters (until later, when Ruth takes over most narrating duties), are young drifters who seem to be in their early 20s and have separately left Minneapolis for the valley town of Missoula, Mont.

headline: A Law Unto Himself
text: The lobby of the Idanha Hotel in Boise, Idaho, was the scene of great excitement in the spring and summer of 1907. There, most mornings, sat a large man with a luxurious, curled mustache, smoking cigars and loudly holding forth, surrounded by newspaper reporters and gawping onlookers. Behind him, guarding against the threat of assassination, stood a former cowboy, armed with a Colt .45 and a 20-inch blade hidden inside a walking stick. “Most pass by with awed looks,” a witness wrote, “while some few are proud to be seen sitting alongside and basking in the great man’s halo.” One of those who stopped to stare was the actress Ethel Barrymore, in town with a touring company. The object of curiosity introduced himself: “I’m a Pinkerton man.”

headline: Transcendent States
text: Certain writers are driven by a distilled, coherent rage. This rage may have started as a red-hot boil, but the best of these writers don’t approach the page until the original insult has cooled and the words crackle like ice. Personally, I find these folks terrifying. I like to read them, but I’m not so sure I want to know them. Their humor is barbed, their policy, scorched earth. So let’s just say that if I were to catch a glimpse of Bruce Wagner — the grumpy, gimlet-eyed, savagely funny chronicler of all things West Coast — across a crowded room, I’d likely slink out the door.

headline: Looking for Home
text: What is the distance between here and there, between now and then, between right and wrong? In Greg Baxter’s pellucid first novel, “The Apartment,” it may be simply the length of a day — but a day in which one travels surprisingly far, literally and figuratively. Baxter, whose only previous book is a work of nonfiction, “A Preparation for Death,” which details his implosion and rebirth as a writer and a person, has written a novel of subtle beauty and quiet grace; I found myself hanging on every simple word, as tense about the consequences of a man finding an apartment as if I were reading about a man defusing a bomb. And, possibly, that is what “The Apartment” is as well: the analysis of an explosion deferred, or narrowly avoided, a hairbreadth escape. It is one of the best novels I have read in a long time.

headline: Bookshelf: Play On!
text: New books include Gus Gordon’s “Herman and Rosie,” featuring a crocodile who plays oboe and a doe who sings jazz.

headline: Google Back in Europe’s Antitrust Sights
text: LONDON — Google’s latest proposal to settle an antitrust investigation in Europe does not go far enough, the European Union’s competition commissioner said on Friday, dealing a blow to the company as it tries to resolve the case.

text: 1888: Eiffel Tower Builders Strike

text: In this week’s video, Times critics look at Spike Jonze’s latest film, “Her,” Will Ferrell in “Anchorman 2″ and “The Past,” directed by Asghar Farhadi.

headline: In Store | Exotic Jewelry and Rare Company in Orange County
text: Last month A’maree’s, the family-owned fashion and design shop in the surprising location of Newport Beach, Calif., hosted an exhibition of jewels by Mika Damascou, the mother of the artist (and T Magazine contributor) Konstantin Kakanias, who organized the show with the L.A. stylist Danielle King. The occasion was right in line with the spirit of the store, which marches to its own drummer in terms of what it stocks — fashion, furniture, jewelry, bicycles — and who it supports. The current iteration of A’maree’s is run by the sisters Dawn Klohs and Denise and Apryl Schaefer, whose mother founded it in the 1970s. For the past three years it has existed in a sublime 1960 building on the water by Ladd & Kelsey, the architects of Pasadena’s Norton Simon Museum, a dreamlike Modernist pavilion with arched windows and a scalloped roofline.

headline: A Test Run at Russia’s Olympic Hopeful
text: Before I could board the gondola at Rosa Khutor, a ski area that is part of Sochi, the site of next year’s Winter Olympics, I first had to trundle through a metal detector manned by Russian soldiers with machine guns and furry hats. This is not something I’m used to. At chairlifts in the American West, where I typically ski, you find cheerful young attendants who are stoked to be on their feet all day because that’s what it takes to live the dream.

headline: A Family Connection to Skiing History
text: In this weekend’s ski issue, I write about Rosa Khutor, a new ski resort above the city of Sochi, Russia, that is the site of the alpine events for the coming Winter Games. Built with the Olympics in mind, Rosa Khutor has ambitions to become a world-class ski area that attracts Russian skiers, who might otherwise flee to the Alps, and international visitors, who might otherwise never think of Russia when planning a ski vacation. It’s a great mountain, with great potential.

headline: Skiing in September? Head South
text: It felt like a scene from a surrealist film.

headline: No Widespread Misconduct Is Found in the Secret Service
text: WASHINGTON — The Secret Service does not have widespread misconduct, and the agency’s leadership has not “fostered an environment that tolerates inappropriate behavior,” according to a review of the agency’s culture by the inspector general’s office for the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: South Africa’s Biggest Trade Union Pulls Its Support for A.N.C.
text: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa’s largest trade union withdrew its support for the African National Congress on Friday, a move that is likely to erode the party’s dominance ahead of national elections next year and reorder the politics of a country the party has governed with huge majorities since the end of white rule two decades ago.

headline: Spike Jonze, Video Game Character
text: Updated, 12:25 p.m. | In some ways, the Spike Jonze romance “Her” is a different beast for the inventive director-writer-prankster – it’s the first feature he wrote on his own – and in some ways it’s a lot like his other films (“Where the Wild Things Are,” “Being John Malkovich,” “Adaptation”). All take a long time in the editing room, up to a year. They’re naturalistic in performance, but not heavily improvised – though the story can sometimes change after they finish filming.

headline: Cleveland Museum Acquires a Collection of Indian Islamic Art
text: The Cleveland Museum of Art on Friday announced that it had acquired of one of the most important collections still in private hands of Deccan and Mughal painting from India’s major Islamic courts of the 16th century through the late 18th century.

headline: Beating Back Pain
text: Two months ago, I stepped into a shower in a hotel room in Baton Rouge, La., and felt a slight twinge in my back. I didn’t pay it much mind. I’ve experienced twinges from time to time, but for more than 25 years, I have been essentially free of back pain.

headline: Air Force Removed General Over Drunken Acts in Russia
text: WASHINGTON — An Air Force general who oversaw some of the nation’s nuclear weapons was dismissed for drunken antics during an official trip to Moscow last summer, according to a new investigative report.

headline: A Plea to Deny Gunmen Their Quest for Infamy
text: DENVER — Call him the gunman. Call him the killer or the perpetrator, the defendant or the assailant. Only, the survivors urge, do not say his name.

headline: After Brief Halt, F.D.A. Allows Sales of Drug for Cancer to Resume
text: After a clamor from some patients and doctors, the Food and Drug Administration announced on Friday that it would allow sales to resume of a leukemia drug that was temporarily withdrawn from the market for causing potentially deadly side effects.

headline: Ready? O.K.!
text: Cheerleaders have been a part of scholastic and collegiate sports for decades.

headline: The Mighty, Mighty Cheerleaders
text: Ready? O.K.! You’ve heard it a thousand times. At your son’s high school basketball game, your daughter’s homecoming football game at college and, of course, ubiquitously throughout the classic cheerleading movie, “Bring It On.”

headline: City Opera Ticket Holders Have to Get in Line With Other Creditors
text: When the New York City Opera filed for bankruptcy on Oct. 3 it asked the court if it could refund $323,000 worth of ticket income to subscribers who had faith in the increasingly shaky company. At the same time, it mailed a letter to those ticket buyers, expressing confidence that the court would grant that request but suggesting that patrons could also waive their right to a refund and donate the money to the failed company instead. Enough ticket buyers agreed to reduce the debt by about $30,000.

headline: Dream Leads Hindu Priest to Flushing Store With Temple
text: Kumar Natarajanaidu flipped the cassette in his old tape player and resumed his trance, kneeling on a folded New York Jets blanket and rapidly chanting prayers in Tamil, leaping up each time a customer entered seeking DVDs or flowers.

headline: Wells Fargo Poised for Wall Street Run
text: Wells Fargo will start knocking more loudly on the bulge bracket’s door. The California lender is already one of the top 10 global investment banks by fees, according to data from Thomson Reuters. Much of that comes courtesy of middle-market clients. But if the bank run by John Stumpf starts going after bigger fish, it could put Wall Street’s bigwigs on the defensive.

headline: Land Leases Are Deferred to de Blasio
text: The Bloomberg administration will not make any decision about a plan to lease some open spaces on public housing land to private developers and will instead leave it to the new mayor — who has objected to the initiative.

headline: Beyoncé‘s Surprise Attack
text: Jon Caramanica, Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss what Beyoncé‘s self-titled new record represents in her career, and in pop right now.

headline: How Lucrative Thy Branches
text: Chris Botek, a tree grower in Lehighton, Pa., is used to people being shocked by how much his Christmas trees cost.

headline: For a Hedge Fund Pioneer, a Tiger Fund Burning Bright
text: Julian Robertson, the billionaire investor and an early pioneer of the hedge fund industry, is  again proving to be a top picker of new talent.

headline: If You Need a New Addiction, Try QuizUp
text: Two years ago, Alec Baldwin was removed from a plane when he refused to turn off his phone because he was engaged in a game of Words With Friends. Some may have judged Mr. Baldwin for what seemed like a bad decision. But to Words With Friends devotees, his anger would have felt entirely familiar: The best smartphone games are downright addictive.

headline: Fashion at a Very High Price
text: From cheerful red handbags to festive green belts, colored accessories are often mandatory for the style-conscious during the holiday season. But what many fashionistas don’t know is that many of these products may be tainted with high levels of lead — and the brighter and shinier they are, the greater the risk.

headline: Popcast: Beyoncé’s Surprise Attack
text: Last week Beyoncé announced, minutes before Friday morning, the release of her new self-titled album; it all appeared on iTunes, as well as a separate video for each song. The album sold, according to iTunes, a million copies in five days. No HealthCare.gov-like problems were reported.

headline: Highlights From Obama’s News Conference
text: President Obama held a news conference on Friday before departing with his family for a two-week vacation in Hawaii, and Times reporters provided updates and analysis during the event.

headline: Playing With Your Christmas Gift? Scheduled for Thursday
text: I’m putting “fun” on the calendar.

headline: Have You Been Through a School Lockdown? Tell Us About Your Experience
text: This month, when an 18-year-old student walked into Arapahoe High School in Colorado with a pump-action shotgun and began shooting, teachers and students and administrators knew almost immediately how to respond. Classroom doors slammed shut. Students huddled in the corners and stayed quiet. A resource officer inside the school sprang to action. Nearby, other schools locked down until they knew whether they, too, faced any threat.

headline: U.S. Soccer Releases All-Time Best National Teams
text: To end its centennial year, U.S. Soccer this week released its all-time Best XI for the men’s and women’s national teams.

headline: News Corp. Buys a Media Start-Up for $25 Million
text: In a move highlighting the increasing role that user-generated content plays in the news business, News Corporation, owner of The Wall Street Journal, announced on Friday that it had bought Storyful, a company that calls itself a “social news” agency.

headline: A Day of Music, and Movement Therapy, for a Conductor
text: Was it really just two years ago that Trinity Wall Street church scaled back its music program in what an article in this newspaper later called a “seeming brush with death”? The church’s music and arts director, Julian Wachner, 44, is now rushing to erase such memories. Austerity is out. In its place: a four-month festival of Benjamin Britten’s music, Bach cantatas every Monday and a series celebrating the 12 nights of Christmas, which runs from Dec. 26 to Jan. 6. That’s between Mr. Wachner’s side gigs conducting at the Brooklyn Academy of Music or the Juilliard Opera Theater and as music director of the Washington Chorus, all while he recovers from a summer shoulder injury that temporarily stilled his baton. Mr. Wachner lives in TriBeCa with his wife, the Rev. Emily Wachner, the church’s priest for welcome, liturgy, hospitality and pilgrimage, and the couple’s American bulldog, Sophie, and cat, Rowan.

headline: What Stronger Health Spending Growth Means for Obama
text: Gross domestic product growth was much faster than previously estimated in the third quarter, partly because health care spending was revised sharply upward. Consumer spending on health care services grew at an annual pace of 2.7 percent last quarter, instead of 0.9 percent, as the Commerce Department had previously reported.

headline: Pajama Boy Vs. Duck Dynasty
text: Senator John Cornyn’s longshot challenger in the 2014 Texas Republican primary, Rep. Steve Stockman, is milking the Phil Robertson controversy for all it’s worth.

headline: South Bend, Ind., to Recall Studebaker’s 1963 Departure
text: Fireworks shows are usually for celebrating a notable anniversary or achievement. But on Friday night in South Bend, Ind., the fireworks will recall a low point: fifty years since Studebaker left its factory there and moved to Canada to fade into oblivion.

headline: Statement From Khodorkovsky in Berlin Answers Some Questions, but Not All
text: Last Updated, 7:20 p.m. | Hours after his sudden release from prison on Friday, the Russian dissident Mikhail Khodorkovsky released a statement from Berlin, along with an image of himself being greeted at the airport by Hans-Dietrich Genscher, a former German foreign minister who helped arrange his travel, as my colleagues Steven Lee Myers and David Herszenhorn report.

headline: Czars Rule: Romanovs Prove Popular in Today’s Russia
text: A replica of Russia’s grand imperial crown, made of nearly 11,500 diamonds, will be on display in Moscow until early January at the State Historical Museum near Red Square, the latest of dozens of exhibitions across Russia devoted to the 400th anniversary of the founding of the Romanov dynasty.

headline: Review: 2014 Mazda CX-9
text: Introduced in 2007, the Mazda CX-9 has been around the block. After all these years (and two face-lifts), corners remain this nimble three-row crossover’s natural habit.

headline: A Valedictory Radio Chat for Bloomberg and for His Host
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg leaves office at the end of the month. It so happens that his regular on-air interlocutor, the radio dynast John R. Gambling, is retiring, too.

headline: Contracting Overhaul Is Promised for Navy
text: WASHINGTON — Navy Secretary Ray Mabus on Friday acknowledged gaps in the Navy’s oversight of the companies that provide supplies for the nation’s warships across the world and announced wide-ranging plans to revamp contracting practices that experts say have made it far too easy for businesses to defraud the service out of tens of millions of dollars.

headline: Living With a Business Below
text: Every New York apartment has a catch, and so when Ashley Falcon, a gregarious fashion stylist, considered the built-in closets, roomy kitchen and plentiful windows in a particular Greenwich Village rental while apartment-hunting two years ago, she decided that she could stomach the downside: living above a funeral home.

headline: Spanish Tortilla With Tomato Salad
text: Spanish tortillas are an adaptable dish that can be served at brunch or a cocktail party.

headline: With Friends Like These
text: After shepherding West Virginia into legal existence with its own government and representatives in Washington, Francis H. Pierpont made a surprising decision. Instead of remaining with his friends, family and new duties in the state capital, Wheeling, in late 1863 he headed east toward Alexandria, Va., to take up a much more challenging task: governor of the Restored State of Virginia – in effect, the government in exile.

headline: Bingeing on Beyoncé: The Ripple Effect
text: Early in the morning of Dec. 13, Beyoncé turned the Internet upside down with the surprise release of a new music and video album, announced with a simple Instagram post.

headline: Harry Potter Headed Onstage in London
text: LONDON — There have been seven books, selling over 450 million copies, and eight films. Now Harry Potter will apparate into the West End in 2015, in a new play about the early years of J. K. Rowling’s boy wizard, before his years at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. Ms. Rowling will collaborate on the play with an as-yet unnamed playwright; she will also be a co-producer, she told The Daily Mail on Thursday.

headline: Conspicuous Combustion
text: The Lamborghini Aventador LP 700-4 Roadster, an exotic sports car with a $488,175 sticker, brings out one’s inner exhibitionist.

headline: A Potato’s Postcard From Spain
text: Before I had ever tasted a tortilla Española, the traditional Spanish potato omelet, I couldn’t imagine what the fuss was about. What could be so special about a dish made from only eggs, potatoes and onion?

headline: Carriage Driver Is Charged With Animal Cruelty
text: A carriage horse driver with a checkered history was charged on Friday with animal cruelty after a police officer observed him working a horse that was visibly injured, according to court documents.

headline: Engaging Shenanigans, Big Surprises
text: The question was written in the sand. It was asked under the big top and with bells on. There was a bended knee followed by a “Will you marry me?” on an elevator ride, and a proposal made on a hotel rooftop to a soundtrack of whirling propellers. There are many other memorable and creative ways to ask that age-old question. So, since that query is often posed during the holiday season, now may be a good time to review some of the most interesting proposals submitted this year to the Vows pages of The Times.

headline: Art and Entertainment That Makes Us Feel Old Before Our Time
text: For much of the 20th century, scientists believed that the slower one’s metabolism, the longer one’s life. This is called the rate of living theory, and although it is not actually true for humans, it feels increasingly accurate of our machines. The faster our computers get, the faster they seem to break, burn out or become obsolete. The average life span of an American cellphone is 18 months. No wonder the members of my superconnected demographic — young, urban, educated, “creative,” often described as “millennials” — are all afraid we’re shooting to obscurity.

headline: How to Make Noise about Antibiotics
text: Some of you have asked me how best to make your opinions heard about routine use of antibiotics in animals, the subject of my column this week. You could:

headline: London Theaters Checked After Ceiling Collapse
text: LONDON — The authorities were carrying out inspections of London’s West End theaters on Friday, intent on avoiding any further collapses like the one at the Apollo Theater, where a falling ceiling injured more than 80 people watching a play in the packed house.

headline: Ally in $98 Million Settlement on Bias in Auto Loans
text: Ally Financial agreed on Friday to pay $98 million to settle accusations that it discriminated against minority borrowers who were charged more than white customers for auto loans by car dealers.

headline: Nigella Lawson Assistants Found Not Guilty of Fraud
text: LONDON — Two Italians sisters who spent more than a million dollars on the celebrity chef Nigella Lawson’s credit cards were acquitted of fraud charges Friday by a London jury.

headline: Dancing Our Way to a Holiday Break
text: The Academy has started the promotional reel for its March 2 telecast in a major way, with the host Ellen DeGeneres dancing down the street, trailed by a crowd of men and women clad in tuxedos. The trailer, released on Thursday and scheduled to play in theaters next month, was conceived and directed by Paul Feig, the “Bridesmaids” and “Heat” filmmaker, and set to new music by Fitz and the Tantrums. The dancer and choreographer Stephen (tWitch) Boss, a judge on the TV show “So You Think You Can Dance,” was responsible for the moves in the video.

headline: Studios Unfazed by Colossal Wrecks
text: For Hollywood film studios, 2013 is shaping up as “the year of the flop,” as the public radio host Brian Lehrer described it on the air in August.

headline: Robots Strut (Or Trot) Their Stuff In Florida Competition
text: HOMESTEAD, Fla. — My hotel clerk asked me if I was part of the “robot thing.”

headline: Tardy Taper Thoughts
text: Not dead yet, in case you’re wondering — just busy with preparations for family travel, and then with travel itself; this post was written during a layover.

headline: Special News Quiz | Farewell, 2013
text: The Year in Rap, from Flocabulary.

headline: Jazz Deal for Gentium Shows Benefits of Inversions
text: In 2011, Jazz Pharmaceuticals, a California-based drug maker, acquired Azur Pharma, a small rival based in Ireland.

headline: Their Chart-Toppers Are Each Other
text: In August 2011, Meghan Milewski was sitting in a bar in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, when she got a text from Sameer Naseem, one of her best friends. “He said, ‘We have to meet up — I have a present for you,’ ” she said.

headline: 3 More Indicted in Silk Road Online Black Market Case
text: Updated, 6:38 p.m. | New reporting about the Silk Road defendants has been added.

headline: It’s Early to Bed as Knicks Battle a Matinee Curse
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Noon games on weekends are a rarity for the Knicks. This season, they have also been a disaster. When the Knicks played the San Antonio Spurs on Nov. 10 at that early starting time, they lost by 31 points. When they tried again a month later against the Boston Celtics, they lost by 41.

headline: Daughter Seeks Freedom for Jailed Ukraine Leader
text: KIEV, Ukraine — As Russia’s best-known political prisoner, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, arrived in Germany on Friday at the end of a whirlwind 24-hour passage to freedom, the daughter of Ukraine’s most prominent political prisoner urged the president here to follow in the footsteps of the Russian president and set her mother free.

headline: The Gun Report: December 20, 2013
text: Two decades ago, Kenzo Dix, 15, a high school freshman in Northern California, was at the house of a friend, who was showing off his father’s semi-automatic Beretta pistol. The child, who had been shooting with his father, unloaded the full magazine, inserted an empty magazine and pulled the trigger, not knowing there was still a bullet in the chamber. The bullet went through Kenzo’s shoulder and into his heart. The young basketball player and graffiti artist was killed.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Spain; British Columbia; Utah
text: Canary Islands International Music Festival, Spain

headline: Microfoundations and the Parting of the Waters
text: The blogospheric debate about microfoundations, saltwater/freshwater and all that has, I think, been illuminating. Among other things it’s serving almost as an oral history of What Really Happened – minus the oral part, but not mediated by the usual slowness and overthinking of formal publication.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Behind the Music
text: This week, Alan Light and David Leonhardt.

headline: Man With a Thorn in His Side
text: Readers predisposed to dislike Morrissey could respond to his “Autobiography” with the same barb Vladimir slings at Estragon in “Waiting for Godot”: “No one ever suffers but you.”

headline: Book Review Podcast: Behind the Music
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Alan Light reviews four new memoirs by famous musicians, including “Simple Dreams,” by Linda Ronstadt. Mr. Light writes:

headline: Missing From Podiums: Women
text: “Dinosaur, go back to your cave!” the British conductor Sian Edwards said over the phone with a laugh, her eyes audibly rolling.

headline: Friday Night Music: London Grammar
text: Yes, I know it’s only afternoon — but this layover is my only chance to post today. Also, I’m behind the curve on this group — they’re already pretty big. And while I’m apologizing, maybe I should feature one of their fine original songs instead of a cover. But I fall in love with groups via an entry performance, and this was the one for this band.

headline: A Sugar Plum Fairy Tale
text: This time of year, a Sugar Plum Fairy needs to take care of her toes. “Do you mind if I sew my point shoes?”

headline: Obama Discusses N.S.A. Surveillance
text: At a news conference at the White House, the president talked about changes to the National Security Agency’s surveillance capabilities.

headline: Something About It Says ‘Party!’
text: TESTED 2014 Ford Fiesta ST

headline: What I Discovered on My Flash Drive
text: The first thing I did with my 2013 Lamborghini Aventador LP 700-4 Roadster, the half-million-dollar beast of a sports car I was recently allowed to possess for five days, was drive it to pick up my daughter from detention. She’d been busted for talking in Biology.

headline: Target Customer Information Shows Up on the Black Market
text: The nightmare before Christmas continues for Target.

headline: Enduring Virtues Onstage in London
text: Between 1949 and 1976, the Royal Ballet of London was the most frequent foreign ballet company to visit the United States. Beloved for both theatricality and purity of style, it made annual or biennial visits to New York and other American cities. Two of its coast-to-coast tours lasted five months each. New York became its second home; one of its seasons at the Metropolitan Opera House was eight weeks long. Its stars included Margot Fonteyn, Moira Shearer, Beryl Grey, Svetlana Beriosova, Nadia Nerina, Antoinette Sibley, Lynn Seymour, Merle Park and Anthony Dowell, with Rudolf Nureyev its most celebrated guest artist. For many Americans, it was the yardstick by which to judge all other kinds of ballet classicism.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Stumbling, Strategic Steps to Manhood
text: Of all the videos Justin Bieber has been featured in this year, none is likely to leave as deep an impact as the one that surfaced last month of him sleeping comfortably — vulnerably — on a couch in Brazil. That video was filmed by a woman, described in news reports variously as a porn star, a prostitute or a mere party guest, who blows him a kiss at the end of the clip and who went on to tell the press that she and Mr. Bieber had shared a night of sex.

headline: A Virtual Alternative to the Hot Pursuit
text: If StarChase, a maker of GPS-tagging systems for police departments, has its way, cable TV stations will soon be looking for new material to fill slow news days. That’s because the Virginia Beach company has developed a device meant to eliminate the high-risk car chases that draw viewers and seem, inevitably, to end in tears.

headline: Video: The Mazda CX-9 Has Aged Well
text: Introduced in 2007, the Mazda CX-9 crossover has been refreshed twice, and I’ve now reviewed it three times. Some vehicles seem dated after just a few years on the market, but with its most recent Kodo design face-lift, the CX-9 retains a youthful appearance. We should all be so lucky.

headline: Afterlife for an X Prize Contender
text: With a background in chemical engineering and his job as an air quality regulator for the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, Kevin Smith might seem an unlikely sort to be spending his free time building a car in a backyard garage. But Mr. Smith’s education and experience no doubt contributed to his home-built car’s being refined far beyond a typical shade tree effort.

headline: A Car Monitor That Also Talks to Facebook
text: Even cars that have reached their teenage years can now enjoy the benefits of social networking. Their ability to stay connected comes with the introduction of Zubie, a plug-in device and service that not only monitors a vehicle’s condition and location but also lets owners share that information with family and friends.

headline: Amid Skepticism, Support for Parts of Health Law
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll found that while many Americans expressed concern or outright disapproval with how the health care law might affect their family, specific components of the law had strong support.

headline: Tricky Business: Defining Authenticity
text: When the Guggenheim Museum sold pieces by Kandinsky, Chagall and Modigliani in the early 1990s to help it buy one of the world’s most important collections of Minimalist and Conceptual art, it knew it was paying not only for hundreds of seminal works but also for a mare’s nest of problems.

headline: Weekend Reading: Skipping the Wall St. ‘Wolf’
text: Martin Scorsese’s film about Jordan Belfort is set join a long list of Wall Street movies that are focused more on frat-boy antics than financial wizardry.

headline: Big Ticket | A Place for Everything for $10.16 Million
text: A serene Classic 7 condominium at the Mayfair at 610 Park Avenue that brims with light, thanks to generous northern, southern and eastern exposures, sold for $10.165 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Even When This Music Rocks, It Stays Mindful of Its Roots
text: Viento de Agua OPUS IV

headline: Music and Success
text: DOES music make you smarter?

headline: Levine and Mahler, Laredo and Mozart
text: During Christmas week, Carnegie Hall is surprisingly active, starting on Sunday afternoon at 3, when the Met Orchestra performs an all-Mahler program conducted by James Levine. The compelling baritone Peter Mattei will be the soloist in “Song of a Wayfarer.” Then Mr. Levine will lead the teeming, episodic yet inexorable Seventh Symphony, an 80-minute workout for a maestro and orchestra. Then the conductor Jaime Laredo presents two programs with the New York String Orchestra, a group of select young musicians in training. On Tuesday, Christmas Eve, at 7 p.m., he leads Mozart’s Overture to “Le Nozze di Figaro” and “Paris” Symphony, as well as Mendelssohn’s Violin Concerto with Bella Hristova as soloist. On Saturday at 8 p.m., the esteemed pianist Leon Fleisher will be heard in Prokofiev’s Concerto No. 4 for left hand and orchestra, on a program that opens with Elgar’s “Introduction and Allegro” and ends with Tchaikovsky’s “Pathétique” Symphony. (212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: An Indie Rapper, Loud and Proud
text: The indie rapper Le1f (born Khalif Diouf) is an oddball and an empire builder: an openly gay (or as one of his songs puts it, “gayngsta”) rapper with a degree in dance who also runs a label, Camp & Street. He produced the Das Racist track “Combination Pizza Bell and Taco Hut” before starting his own busy, prolific career, including two generous free mixtapes. He has a low voice, a startling wardrobe and an ear for sparse but insistent tracks.

headline: The Land of Sweets Sheds Its Tutus
text: A dancegoer’s options are fairly limited this week: There’s “The Nutcracker,” and then there’s “The Nutcracker.” But two of the season’s most popular renditions couldn’t be more different. At Lincoln Center, New York City Ballet soldiers on in its six-week run of George Balanchine’s classic version, with its pristine dancing and reverence for childhood fantasy. A darker sort of fantasy is playing out at the Minetta Lane Theater, home to Company XIV’s burlesque twist on this E. T. A. Hoffmann tale.

headline: Cash for Cab Drivers
text: New York’s incoming mayor, Bill de Blasio has enjoyed strong support from taxicab fleet owners, while the current Taxi Commissioner, David Yassky, has been a strong advocate for taxicab drivers. Perhaps not surprisingly, Mr. de Blasio has made it clear that Mr. Yassky, will be one of the first people out the door come January 1.

headline: A Cappella Contest Makes a Comeback
text: “The Voice” has paid a lot of bills for NBC, but another good singing competition, “The Sing-Off,” never became a ratings juggernaut and was apparently dead at the end of its third season in 2011. Then the network had a change of heart. It decided to bring “The Sing-Off” back this month for a two-week, seven-episode Season 4 and gave its premiere “The Voice” as a lead-in.

headline: Star of the Show? The Art Dealer
text: Trace the history of the finest pieces of postwar art, and many of them lead back to Ileana Sonnabend, the gallery owner and collector, who died in 2007. Andy Warhol’s “Liz #1 (Early Colored Liz),” which sold at Sotheby’s for $18 million last month? Sonnabend. Robert Rauschenberg’s 20th-century mixed-media collage “Canyon,” which the Museum of Modern Art won over the Metropolitan Museum last year? Sonnabend.

headline: Loverly Memories of a Director
text: Spend Christmas Day at the Walter Reade Theater revisiting three of the most memorable films directed by George Cukor, whose work is being surveyed through Jan. 7 by the Film Society of Lincoln Center in its series called The Discreet Charm of George Cukor.

headline: Obama’s Year-End News Conference
text: Before taking questions from reporters, the president delivered an opening statement, saying he firmly believed 2014 could be a breakthrough year for America.

headline: Best Marriage Proposals of the Year
text: A look back at the most interesting marriage proposals submitted to the Weddings/Celebrations section of The New York Times in 2013.

headline: Obama on Health Care
text: The Times’s Jackie Calmes asked the president about his statement that “if you like your plan, you can keep it” being called the “Lie of the Year” by PolitiFact.

headline: Analyzing the American Express Surcharge Settlement
text: In August 2012, lawyers for merchants won a settlement from MasterCard and Visa, an agreement that on close inspection struck many merchant advocates as not much of a victory.

headline: Calculating the Number of Windows in Buildings in Manhattan
text: Q. Like many first-year M.B.A. students, I am preparing to interview for summer internship positions. A typical interviewer may ask a question such as “How many windows are there in all the buildings in Manhattan?” to test your critical reasoning skills. There are ways to estimate, but I’d love to know for sure: Just how many buildings are there on the island of Manhattan, and how many windows do they contain?

headline: Trudging Somberly to Their Deaths, as a Lone Soul Mourns
text: At the heart of Megan Kendzior’s dance “Witness” is a question: How can we observe atrocities and look away? The production, an exploration of indifference and trauma, was inspired by her research into the Holocaust and her visit to the Auschwitz death camp. Her tools are bodies — 15 dancers, to be exact — the plaintive sound of the accordion and many pairs of shoes, which refer to the horrifying room of victims’ shoes at Auschwitz.

headline: Ballads Punctuated by Frenzy
text: The guitarist Mike Stern reached peak combustion at an unlikely point in his first set at the Iridium on Thursday night, while cutting a path from one guileless ballad to the next. He enlisted only his tough-minded drummer, Dennis Chambers, for this excursion, issuing no directive beyond a tempo. In no time they achieved a blues-rock bliss state, goading each other toward notions of strenuous metaphysical abandon.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Nepal.

headline: Boasting a Power That Pepé Le Pew Would Admire
text: “Mr. Stink” is a charming holiday fable with an added draw for “Downton Abbey” fans: the sight of Hugh Bonneville, the distinguished Earl of Grantham in that series, reduced to an almost unrecognizable state of vagrancy in playing the title character.

headline: No Space Too Small, No Lease Too Short
text: When Kanye West brought his Yeezus tour to New York last month, he needed somewhere to sell his merchandise. Instead of a concert booth, he opened a pop-up shop at 355 Bowery and sold $35 snapback hats and $20 tote bags.

headline: Maria Bello: Partnerships, Love and Conversations, to Be Continued
text: “Why now?”

headline: The World at Her Fingertips
text: When Natalie Massenet ascended the stairs of the Carnegie Hall stage a month ago to accept a Woman of the Year trophy from Glamour magazine, she outdid Jennifer Lawrence at the 2013 Oscars ceremony, nearly tripping on her Alessandra Rich white lace gown (soon available for upward of $3,000 at Net-a-Porter, the online luxury retailer she founded) before impaling the hem with her high-heeled sandals.

headline: The High Priest of Horology
text: Jay Z asked him to pick out a watch for his two Carnegie Hall concerts last year (he wore a Jaeger-LeCoultre Reverso).

headline: Climate Scientists, Then and Now, Espousing ‘Responsible Advocacy’
text: I’ve long appreciated Gavin A. Schmidt‘s approach to doing and communicating climate science. Schmidt, deputy director of NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies, has endured many slings and arrows, not to mention hacks and legal tangles, in building RealClimate.org into what I’ve called a vital online touchstone for anyone trying to understand research on the human influence on the planet’s thermostat.

headline: Ho, Ho, Ho? Oh, No, No, No!
text: We skitter, we dodge. My boyfriend and I will be flying to India on Christmas Day. Jetting off on Santa’s Judgment Day is not unusual for me; I’m among that tiny percentage of the population who hears “Santa’s helpers” and thinks “skycaps.” Part of my seasonal wanderlust lies in the belief that a Christmas celebrated by two adults and no children can be eerily quiet, a Beckett play performed in a canyon on the moon. But the larger part lies in my conviction that the most beautiful and tinselly bauble to be found on Dec. 25 is reduced airfare.

headline: Federal Judge Rules That Same-Sex Marriage Is Legal in Utah
text: Salt Lake County began issuing marriage licenses to jubilant same-sex couples on Friday, hours after a federal judge ruled that Utah’s amendment barring same-sex marriage violated the United States Constitution.

headline: Who Will Keep Financial Reform Going?
text: In late November, nine Democratic senators sent President Obama a letter about a vacancy on the five-member Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the agency charged under the Dodd-Frank law with regulating most of the multi-trillion dollar market in derivatives.

headline: For Millennials, a Generational Divide
text: You know them when you see them. They are tapping on their smartphones, strolling into work late and amassing Instagram followers faster than a twerking cat. They complain. They “disrupt” stuff. They simultaneously (and somewhat improbably) like both Kanye West and Kenny Chesney.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Disappointing Response
text: By the time President Obama gave his news conference on Friday, there was really only one course to take on surveillance policy from an ethical, moral, constitutional and even political point of view. And that was to embrace the recommendations of his handpicked panel on government spying — and bills pending in Congress — to end the obvious excesses. He could have started by suspending the constitutionally questionable (and evidently pointless) collection of data on every phone call and email that Americans make.

headline: Uh-Oh: George Clooney Is Drooling Again
text: When Heather Allard, an entrepreneur from Pawtucket, R.I., saw the dog with the red bow tie on the Internet, she had to have him. It was partly the mixed boxer’s commanding jaw and the steadiness of his eyes, but it was mostly his name: James Earl Jones.

headline: One Mushroom Ragoût, Five Meals
text: I have never been a gravy fan, but I am a fan of what I call “Mushroom Ragoût Gravy,” which is not a gravy at all but a mushroom ragoût, or stew. I always make too much. I double the recipe if we are going to be a dozen people, which we usually are during holiday gatherings, even though I know that nobody will have enough room on their plates for more than a spoonful.

headline: Many Arms and Many Splendors
text: The pace at Octopus Garden, a Brooklyn store, turns frenzied before Christmas Eve when Italian-Americans celebrating the Feast of Seven Fishes crave octopus, cuttlefish and calamari.

headline: A Treasure House of Shifting Aspirations
text: SAN MARINO, Calif. — What does a 15th-century illuminated manuscript of “The Canterbury Tales” have in common with an “Old Mission Brand” label from a crate of oranges? What is the connection between the novelist Thackeray’s 1853 drawing of a black girl in South Carolina and plantings meant to echo the famed Chinese gardens of Suzhou? What could possibly connect 19th-century light bulbs and Gainsborough’s much-loved painting “Blue Boy”?

headline: Red Carpet Watch: Judi Dench’s Style
text: Ms. Dench favors caftan style looks on the red carpet.

headline: Weighing Health Plans: The Devilish Details
text: On the way home from a bar in the wee hours of the morning, Branden Eastwood, 29, managed to break his ankle stepping into a cab. He wasn’t insured, so it became an expensive night out: He received $42,000 in medical bills from a Georgetown hospital.

headline: Octopus Garden Prepares for Feast of Seven Fishes
text: Most times of the year, no one can be seen in Octopus Garden save the workers in the back trimming squid beaks or keeping an eye on the octopus-washing machines. Vincent Cutrone, the owner of the store (hidden off Avenue U in Gravesend, Brooklyn, and marked with a sign made of stick-on letters from the hardware store), often is not at the counter. When the rare walk-in customer appears, his staff just hollers to him in the office.

headline: Agustin Madala Wins the Goren Trophy
text: The Goren Trophy is awarded to the player who wins the most masterpoints during the Fall North American Championships. This year’s winner was Agustin Madala, who hails from Argentina but represents Italy. He amassed 402.22 points, 83.32 more than Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y.

headline: Survival Goes to Extremes
text: A former Navy SEAL, Jake Zweig got his start on reality TV as a small-minded loudmouth on the third season of “Top Shot,” the underappreciated marksmanship competition show on the History Channel. He was a talented shooter, but also petty and sulky and disruptive; his elimination came as a relief.

headline: Telecom Italia Shareholders Reject Bid to Remove Board
text: Shareholders in Telecom Italia on Friday voted against a proposal to remove its board in a battle over the company’s future. But a sizable percentage of votes supported the dissidents’ plan.

headline: Google Bus Vandalized During Protest
text: Activists blocked three buses carrying Bay Area tech workers to their Silicon Valley jobs on Friday, breaking a window of one of the vehicles. It was the second demonstration this month targeting the buses, which are rapidly becoming a symbol of the surging animosity between the tech world and everyone else in the Bay Area.

headline: Putting on the Blintz
text: The fabulously feline chanteuse Eartha Kitt inspired these blintzes. In an otherwise insipid song called “Mink, Schmink,” recorded in the 1950s, she sings about how wealth and riches don’t mean a thing if you haven’t got love, rhyming “princes, schminces” with “caviar and chicken blintzes.”

headline: Yemen Deaths Test Claims of New Drone Policy
text: WASHINGTON — In some respects, the drone strike in Yemen last week resembled so many others from recent years: A hail of missiles slammed into a convoy of trucks on a remote desert road, killing at least 12 people.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 20
text: Subjects include a memorial in Newtown, Conn.; the SantaCon celebration in the East Village; and new citizens at a naturalization ceremony in Manhattan.

headline: Times Minute | 2014 a 'Year of Action'
text: Also on the Minute, a singer turned activist in Ukraine and surfboard entrepreneurs.

text: In the Video

headline: Seven Days of Style | The New Owners of Fashion Week and New Homes for Rihanna, Burberry and Acne Studios
text: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREDec. 14 – 20

headline: New Center, but Woes at Historic Site
text: The Weeksville Heritage Center in Crown Heights in Brooklyn started out operating from a cluster of small wood-frame houses, the remnants of a free black community established in 1838. The organization has preserved those three houses, along with documents and artifacts. Now, a new 23,000-square-foot, $34 million building just yards from the houses presents a chance for Weeksville to create a national showcase for black history and culture.

headline: NASA Solves Helmet Leak With Makeshift Snorkels
text: NASA, in preparation for a spacewalk on Saturday, has devised makeshift snorkels that would allow an astronaut in a spacesuit to continue breathing even if a sudden water leak should fill the helmet, as happened to an Italian astronaut who almost drowned in July.

headline: Judi Dench of ‘Philomena’: In Real Life, Dressing the Part
text: WHO Judi Dench.

headline: Ethiopian Funkster, Back After Long Break
text: There’s a back story behind the African funk that had the whole room dancing on Thursday night at Baby’s All Right, the new club in Williamsburg. Hailu Mergia, the keyboardist leading the band, was playing his first American show since 1991. For the last two decades, he has been driving an airport taxicab in Washington.

headline: Week in Pictures for Dec. 20
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a memorial in Newtown, Conn.; the SantaCon celebration in the East Village; and new citizens at a naturalization ceremony in Manhattan.

headline: An Egg for Every Occasion
text: In 1980, at a reunion of participants in Dr. Dean Ornish’s first landmark study on lifestyle and heart disease, for which I had been the chef, I was bold (or naïve) enough to tell the group that I often had an egg or two when I felt a need for a shot of protein.

headline: During Religious Season, Nonbelievers Assert Right to Celebrate
text: In the darkness of an Upper West Side concert hall last weekend, 150 audience members holding twinkling plastic candles sang and swayed to celebrate reason and the season. Snow fell with abandon outside.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Red and White All Over
text: Decorations and whimsical expressions transformed the city into smiles and joy for the annual SantaCon celebrants.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Red and White All Over
text: Decorations and whimsical expressions transformed the city into smiles and joy for the annual SantaCon celebrants, and even a large police presence this year couldn’t dampen their spirits. Private homes and spectacular store windows at stalwarts like Lord & Taylor, Bergdorf Goodman, Tiffany’s and Bloomingdale’s turned often-harsh streets into a winter wonderland.

headline: Americans Need to Eat at Home More Often
text: Apparently these are cropping up all over the place. This one is near Washington, D.C.’s Union Station. Email your own to bittmanstuff@gmail.com.

headline: Bumps in the Road for the Olympic Torch
text: The Olympic torch has begun its journey from Moscow to Sochi, and it’s been anything but a smooth one. Along the record-breaking 40,389-mile route, the torch has had its fair share of mishaps.

headline: Fed to Crack Down on Risk-Shifting Deals
text: A major banking regulator moved on Friday to curb a type of financial maneuver that banks can exploit to make themselves look stronger than they actually are.

headline: A Favor Economy in Which Kind Acts Come With Expected Reciprocity
text: Some years ago, I had a friend who moved to New York with various aspirations, and until they were fulfilled he supported himself working at a restaurant. The place was cultish and bohemian — artists had started it — and interesting people worked there. Eventually my friend got to know the daughter of a famous actor there. On various occasions, he ate out with this woman and her father, noticing that when they did, the bill rarely arrived. This led my friend to one of his most astute and enduring observations about New York: “Only rich people eat for free.”

headline: Changes and Delays to the Health Law
text: Over the past year, the Obama administration has made a series of major changes to the health care law, many in response to the troubled rollout of Healthcare.gov.

headline: How Turkey’s Troubles Could Spread in Emerging Markets
text: As Turkey struggles to contain its latest political crisis, fears of a run on its currency — dormant since the summer — have quickly re-emerged.

headline: Student Protest Over Gay Vice Principal’s Forced Resignation Spreads
text: A student protest at Eastside Catholic High School in Sammamish, Wash., over the forced resignation of a vice principal because of his marriage to another man spread Friday as students from other Roman Catholic and public schools joined in.

headline: Don’t Smoke Crack Here. Please?
text: A 34-year-old artist who had lived in the same apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for 12 years came home one day in April and found something strange on the floor of his building’s lobby. It was broken and burned-looking, a little piece of garbage, but it was also like a postcard from the 1980s that had gotten lost.

text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.
