text: To the Editor:

headline: Federal Case Is Brought Over Fruit
text: A few mushy bananas may not be worth making a federal case of, but 110,000 cartons of overripe fruit that arrived this week in South Jersey has made for both a federal case and an international incident.

headline: How Y’all, Youse and You Guys Talk
text: What does the way you speak say about where you’re from? Answer the questions to see your personal dialect map.

headline: A Change After a Difficult 2013
text: President Obama’s end-of-year news conference had a different tone from his inauguration speech in January.

headline: Leading the Charge Against Spain’s Mortgage Crisis
text: BARCELONA, Spain — ADA COLAU was sitting in a cafe here on a recent evening when another customer, heading for the door, recognized her and veered toward her table.

headline: For a Mayor on His Way Out, a Subway Station on Its Way In
text: For years, Michael R. Bloomberg has been a subway rider of singular distinction: a mayor who often took the train to work, as common New Yorkers do, albeit after a chauffeured drive from his townhouse to an express stop a mile away.

headline: Israel: Palestinian Killed Near Border
text: Israeli forces on Friday fatally shot a Palestinian man who approached the border fence separating Gaza from Israel and wounded five others at several points along the fence, Palestinian medical officials said. The Israeli military said that Palestinians had thrown rocks at soldiers near the fence and fired a mortar shell into Israel. Ouda Hamad, 22, was the third Palestinian to be killed in clashes with Israeli soldiers this week. On Wednesday and Thursday, Israeli forces in the West Bank killed two Palestinians, one during arrest raids in the Jenin refugee camp and one in Qalqilya. The military said the man killed in Qalqilya had fired on the soldiers. A spokesman for the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, condemned the West Bank killings as a “dangerous Israeli escalation” meant to undermine peace negotiations.

headline: China: Tibetan Sets Himself on Fire
text: A monk in a Tibetan region of western China died after setting fire to himself on Thursday afternoon, according to two Tibet advocacy groups based outside China. The monk, Tsultrim Gyatso, was the 125th person inside a Tibetan area of China to commit self-immolation as an act of protest since 2009, according to Kate Saunders, a spokeswoman for the International Campaign for Tibet. Another group, Free Tibet, put the total at 123, with 27 this year. The latest protest took place in a town that Tibetans call Amchok, in the Chinese province of Gansu.

headline: Murray Hill Church’s Neighbors Would Prefer to Look at the Clock
text: The Christmas season, with its silver bells, silent nights and packed pews, might not be the most opportune time to take issue with your local Catholic church. But a group of neighbors of the Church of Our Saviour in Midtown Manhattan are doing just that, complaining that — of all things — the incessant ringing of church bells has produced a heavy helping of bad cheer.

headline: Youkilis Joins Star Pitcher’s Team in Japan
text: Whether the Japanese star Masahiro Tanaka stays with the Rakuten Golden Eagles for the 2014 season or pitches in the United States remains unclear. But one established major leaguer has decided to leave the majors and join Rakuten, no matter where Tanaka ends up.

headline: Radio Stations Find Ratings ‘Rocket Fuel’ in Switch to Christmas Format
text: Thanksgiving is over — the in-laws are gone — and Christmas is not yet here. It’s a cold weekend day, not much happening, and you head to the strip mall. Flat-screens beckon, Chromebooks too, and assorted pads, pods and tablets. You turn on the radio, find your trusty Lite-FM station, and settle in for some Elton, Celine, Shania and Mariah.

headline: A Twitter Message About AIDS, Followed by a Firing and an Apology
text: Updated, 12 p.m. A message about race and AIDS in Africa posted on the Twitter account of a Manhattan public relations executive at an Internet media giant on Friday caused a global outcry on Twitter and around the web. The executive apologized on Sunday after she was fired on Saturday.

headline: Chocolate Prices Soar as Appetites Get Bigger
text: GENEVA — Chocolaterie Pascoët, a small “laboratoire,” or factory, in the Carouge district here, was a hive of activity on a recent morning. The team was scrambling to fill the last orders for Christmas.

headline: Senate Wraps Up Briskly After a Tumultuous Year
text: WASHINGTON — The final day of the Senate’s 2013 session ended on an anticlimactic note on Friday as senators pressed the pause button on the bickering that had kept the chamber nearly paralyzed this year.

headline: In Apology, and a Sale, Target Tries to Appease
text: Scrambling to tamp down consumer outrage over the theft of credit and debit card data from more than 40 million of its customers, Target announced on Friday that it would offer a 10 percent discount on purchases inside its stores on Saturday and Sunday — the final shopping weekend of the holiday season.

headline: Having a Servant Is Not a Right
text: AT the heart of the fracas surrounding the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York who promised to pay her housekeeper $9.75 per hour, in compliance with United States labor rules, but instead paid her $3.31 per hour, is India’s dirty secret: One segment of the Indian population routinely exploits another, and the country’s labor laws allow gross mistreatment of domestic workers.

headline: Nets Look to Get Both Feet in Brooklyn
text: The beige buildings collectively known as Industry City form narrow cobblestone canyons perpendicular to the Sunset Park waterfront. The loud roar of vehicles speeding down the nearby Gowanus Expressway gives way toward the west to the slow rumble of trucks creeping across the uneven streets.

headline: Libya Militias Fleeing Cities, Leaving Chaos
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — For the first time since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in 2011, the independent militias that dominated Libya’s biggest cities and sometimes cowed the central government have fled from the streets, chased away by a combination of civilian protesters and armed groups.

headline: New Health Law Frustrates Many in Middle Class
text: Ginger Chapman and her husband, Doug, are sitting on the health care cliff.

headline: Revitalizing Our Forests
text: THIS Christmas season, I am roasting chestnuts by the fire. American chestnuts, to be exact. These nuts, once widespread, were almost wiped out by a fungal blight. For a century, most of the chestnuts we eat, like the sweet Castanea sativa variety, have been imported from Europe and Asia.

headline: 3 Aides Say Assemblyman Sexually Harassed Them
text: Three former aides to an upstate New York assemblyman have accused him of sexual harassment, saying he repeatedly made sexually explicit comments in their presence and offered invitations to share a hotel room with him.

headline: Canadian Court Strikes Down Laws on Sex Trade
text: OTTAWA — Citing a constitutional right of prostitutes to security, the Supreme Court of Canada voted unanimously on Friday to strike down the country’s laws governing the sex trade.

headline: Civic Break for the Holidays
text: So, how do you like living in a country that has a budget?

headline: China Revives Mao-Era Self-Criticism, but This Kind Bruises Few Egos
text: BEIJING — The 10 middle-aged officials who gathered in a nondescript government office in southwestern China last month were assigned a highly fraught mission: Highlight one another’s faults and confess any transgressions that might undermine the Communist Party’s credibility among the masses.

headline: De Blasio’s Tale of 2 New Yorks Inspires Liberals Beyond City
text: Lovely A. Warren won election as mayor of Rochester last month with a campaign lamenting what she called the “two Rochesters,” challenged by crime and poverty, but also boasting prosperous neighborhoods.

headline: Navigating the Road to Becoming a Single Mother
text: Four at-home pregnancy tests displayed the identical results; the stakes had been too high for Haley Carter to let just one decide her future.

headline: A Steep Financial Cliff for Older Consumers
text: Some older consumers with incomes just over four times the poverty line will not qualify for subsidies and will pay high premiums under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Setting the Table for a Regal Butterfly Comeback, With Milkweed
text: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa — Bounding out of a silver Ford pickup into the single-digit wind-flogged flatness that is Iowa in December, Laura Jackson strode to a thicket of desiccated sticks and plucked a paisley-shaped prize.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 20, 2013
‘Duck Dynasty’ and Quackery
text: I must admit that I’m not a watcher of “Duck Dynasty,” but I’m very much aware of it. I, too, am from Louisiana, and the family on the show lives outside the town of Monroe, which is a little over 50 miles from my hometown. We’re all from the sticks.

headline: Senate Bill Threatens Nuclear Deal, Analysts Say
text: Proponents of Senate legislation that threatens Iran with tough new sanctions if nuclear negotiators fail to reach a comprehensive agreement contend it will pressure the Iranians to honor the pledges they made in an interim deal reached in Geneva a month ago.

headline: Regulate E-Cigarettes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brooklyn Fire Kills Girl, 16, and Critically Injures Two
text: A 16-year-old girl was killed and two women were critically injured in a fire that engulfed the two upper floors of their three-story home in Brooklyn early Friday morning, officials said.

headline: John Bell Hood’s Leg
text: It happened so fast. As Maj. Gen. John Bell Hood of the Confederacy led his soldiers into action at the battle of Chickamauga on Sept. 20, 1863, a Minié ball struck his right leg; later that day his leg was amputated four inches below the hip. Although such operations resulted in an 80 percent casualty rate throughout the Civil War, Hood survived, and traveled with his damaged appendage to the residence of the Little family, 15 miles away from the battlefield.

headline: Tom Cruise Settles Defamation Lawsuit Against Publisher
text: LOS ANGELES — Tom Cruise has settled his prominent lawsuit against the publisher of In Touch and Life & Style magazines, his lawyer said.

headline: Despite Baucus Nomination, Critics Cite Void in China Lineup
text: WASHINGTON — With his appointment of a seasoned Senate free-trader as his new ambassador to Beijing, President Obama has chosen an emissary who faithfully reflects his priorities with China, which have tended to emphasize jobs and other economic issues.

headline: By Sci-Fi Standards, Newest Robots May Disappoint
text: HOMESTEAD, Fla. — The robot gently grabbed the door handle and pulled it open. But before it could shuffle through the frame, it lost its grip and the spring-loaded door slammed shut.

headline: The Soul of the Square
text: At Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine, the pop singer Ruslana Lyzhychko keeps demonstrators upbeat and energized in freezing temperatures every night.

headline: Return to Regular G.O.P. Programming
text: The budget deal that Congress approved and sent to President Obama on Wednesday may bring some relief to agencies burdened by sequester cuts all year, but it does nothing to bring the two political parties closer together. Republicans immediately reverted to their obstructionist agenda, making it clear that the budget compromise with Democrats was a brief aberration.

headline: One-Handed Basketball Player Gets a Shot With Florida
text: MILTON, Ga. — A referee’s whistle halted play during a recent game at Milton High, a school situated among horse farms in an affluent area north of Atlanta. A foul had been called, leaving the culprit’s coach mystified.

headline: Ned Vizzini, 32, Dies; Wrote Teenage Novels
text: Ned Vizzini, a precocious and highly praised writer of popular young-adult novels that often dealt with themes of teenage anxiety and depression — and still made readers laugh — died on Thursday in Brooklyn. He was 32.

headline: Bangladeshi Workers’ Long Wait
text: It has been nearly eight months since the collapse of a building in Bangladesh killed more than 1,100 garment factory workers and left many others with grave injuries. But most of those victims and their families have yet to receive adequate financial help or medical care.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Stops Joking About Casting Problems
text: After coming under intense criticism for its lack of onstage diversity, “Saturday Night Live” is poised to hire its first black female cast member since Maya Rudolph left the show in 2007. Lorne Michaels, the executive producer, told The New York Times that “S.N.L.” recently held special auditions and that one or two black women would most likely join the cast in January — a good thing for notions of balance, of course, but also for the show’s relevance.

headline: Britain: Judge Rejects Libyan’s Rendition Case
text: A Libyan dissident, Abdel Hakim Belhaj, cannot pursue in a British court his “well founded” claim that he was unlawfully abducted in 2004 in a joint MI6-C.I.A. operation, and later tortured, because the case involved other countries and could damage Britain’s relations with the United States, a British high court judge ruled Friday. The judge, Peregrine Simon, ruled, “with hesitation,” that Mr. Belhaj could not sue MI6, the foreign intelligence service, and a former foreign secretary, Jack Straw, even though parliamentary oversight and police investigations were “not adequate substitutes” for a decision by a court. He dismissed the case, he said, because American, as well as British, officials were involved in the rendition of Mr. Belhaj and his pregnant wife to Libya in 2004 and agreed with the British government that a case in open court would harm its relations with Washington. Mr. Belhaj will appeal.

headline: Law Will Tighten Oversight of Special Education Providers
text: Responding to reports of fraud and abuse, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo this week signed into law a bill to strengthen oversight of New York State’s preschool programs for disabled children.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 21, 2013
text: “They’re frustrated. Everybody was thinking that Obamacare was going to come in with more affordable rates. Well, they’re not more affordable.”

headline: Plan Sought to Protect Food Supply From Terrorism
text: The Food and Drug Administration proposed a rule on Friday to require major food producers to develop a plan to prevent intentional attempts to contaminate the food supply. The agency said it favored the rule, not because such a criminal act is likely, but as an extra precaution. Under the rule, open to public comment until the end of March, companies would need plans to address vulnerabilities in production processes, particularly to acts of terrorism. They would have one to three years to comply.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: The beginning of the end for the Federal Reserve’s stimulus program, a big investment by General Motors and the theft of credit card data by hackers.

headline: Beltran Is Back in New York, With Nothing to Prove
text: “A second chance for what?” Carlos Beltran said on Friday, and on paper he sounds irritated. But in person, with a small group of writers in a club at Yankee Stadium, he did not seem that way. Beltran was in a fine mood, actually, having just formalized his three-year, $45 million contract with the Yankees.

headline: Janet D. Rowley, Who Discovered Cancer Can Be Genetic, Dies at 88
text: Dr. Janet D. Rowley, a physician who four decades ago became the first person to show a conclusive link between certain genetic abnormalities and certain cancers, died on Tuesday at her home in Chicago. She was 88.

headline: Corrections: December 21, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quite a Milestone, as Milestones Go
text: Administrivial Sunday, December 22, 2013 puzzle Alert! In the main Sunday, December 22 puzzle, there will be a Notepad in the Across Lite version that says “When this puzzle is done, draw a line connecting the 21 circled letters from A to U in alphabetical order. The resulting shape will provide a clue to 6-, 8-, 14-, 53- and 70-Down.”

headline: U.S.C. Coach May Have Brought Some Baggage With Him
text: LOS ANGELES — The University of Southern California football team has spent its recent days being greeted by Elvis, entertained by acrobatic dancers and preparing for Saturday’s Las Vegas Bowl against Fresno State. But Steve Sarkisian, the team’s newly hired coach, has a more pressing concern: hoping that what happens in Seattle stays in Seattle.

headline: In Newark, a Final Meeting, Perhaps, for Two Ageless Stars
text: NEWARK — The Finnish Flash rolled through New Jersey one last time on Friday, and as with all the stops on Teemu Selanne’s N.H.L. farewell tour, it was a special occasion. The game between the Anaheim Ducks and the Devils was the last regular-season appearance for Selanne, 43, in the metropolitan area and, almost certainly, the last time he would play in the N.H.L. against Jaromir Jagr, 41, the league’s other ageless wonder.

headline: Sudden Stop in Momentum as Rangers’ Woes Continue
text: The Rangers, eagerly seeking a burst of home ice energy after encouraging efforts in their previous two games, lost a befuddling contest to the Islanders, 5-3, on Friday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: More Stones Crop Up on Nets’ Rocky Road
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Nets entered the season talking up their collective size as one of their greatest strengths. But as the season continues, the team keeps shrinking in the face of even the smallest challenges.

headline: Early Bowl Games to Watch
text: Who says all the good bowl games are in January? Bowl season has already started, and while the AdvoCare V100 Bowl on Dec. 31 may not have the cachet of the Rose Bowl, it will feature two of the best running backs in the nation. And that is just one of the intriguing matchups to watch before the end of 2013. This may be your last chance to see quarterbacks Teddy Bridgewater, Johnny Manziel and Jordan Lynch before they start playing on Sundays.

headline: EuroVision Star Becomes Voice of Protest
text: When Ukrainian security forces stormed Kiev’s central square on Dec. 11, the pop singer Ruslana was on stage and attempting to defuse the situation. “I kept a quiet confidence in myself, and I believe that my voice kept them calm,” she said recently. Ruslana, the 2004 winner of the EuroVision Song Contest, has been a constant presence at Independence Square, also known as Maidan, since demonstrators gathered there in late November to protest the government’s decision to postpone an economic agreement with the European Union. She is on stage every night from midnight until sunrise, keeping thousands of demonstrators upbeat and energized in freezing temperatures. Many protesters consider her to be one of the leaders of the movement, but she vehemently disagrees. “We said that one cannot lead Maidan, one can only join Maidan,” she said.

headline: Kelly Clark, Lawyer Who Won Boy Scouts Abuse Case, Dies at 56
text: Kelly Clark, a lawyer whose successful child molestation lawsuit against the Boy Scouts of America in Oregon led to the release of a trove of documents containing thousands of accusations of sexual abuse, died on Tuesday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 56.

headline: The Bots Are Taking Over
text: Snapshots of a band of brothers.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER’S OPEN MIND In an episode taped before his death on Tuesday, Mr. Heffner, above, interviews David Blumenthal, a professor emeritus at Harvard Medical School who is an adviser to President Obama and the president of the Commonwealth Fund, a foundation seeking a high-performance health care system, about his book “The Heart of Power: Health and Politics in the Oval Office.” It puts the president’s quest for universal health insurance in historical context. Mr. Heffner helped create what became Thirteen WNET, New York City’s public station, and was its first general manager.

headline: Indian Envoy Is Transferred to U.N. Post
text: Indian officials said Saturday that they had transferred a diplomat who is facing charges in the United States to a job with India’s United Nations delegation, a position that could protect her from allegations that she was underpaying a housekeeper.

headline: Chinese Security Official Is Focus of Corruption Inquiry
text: BEIJING — One of China’s top security officials is being investigated by the Communist Party for “suspected serious law and discipline violations,” according to Xinhua, the state news agency.

headline: Turkish Premier Blames Foreign Envoys for Turmoil
text: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Saturday continued his embrace of what has traditionally been the strategy of Turkish politicians facing a crisis: Blame foreign powers, in this case the United States.

headline: Joy Johnson, a Marathoner to the End
text: Joy Johnson

headline: Photograph: Bert Stern’s Rolleiflex
text: Bert Stern

headline: Red Burns’s Plan to Serve Humanity Through Technology
text: Hiroko Masuike for The New York TimesRed Burns, in 2007, at the loft that houses the Interactive Telecommunications Program.

headline: Video: For Seamus
text: Seamus Heaney

headline: Shakuntala Devi’s Feats of Mathematical Greatness
text: AP Photo/Dallas Morning NewsDevi at Southern Methodist University calculating the 23rd root of a 201-digit number.

headline: Obamas Arrive in Hawaii for Vacation
text: HONOLULU — After an end-of-the-year news conference whose first question — “Has this been the worst year of your presidency?” — offered a trenchant reminder of President Obama’s troubled 2013, the president seemed especially ready for a break from the nation’s capital.

headline: NASA’s Tweets and Video of Emergency Spacewalk
text: Updated, 12:50 p.m. As my colleague, Kenneth Chang reported two astronauts, Col. Michael S. Hopkins of the Air Force and Richard A. Mastracchio, stepped out of an air lock on the International Space Station to work Saturday on replacing a malfunctioning pump module. It is part of the space station’s cooling system.

headline: Surfboard Design, Catching a Wave From Old Hawaii
text: In 2008, Dan Malloy, a professional surfer, received a package in the mail from Australia. In it was a thin, rectangular slab of wood with one rounded edge. It was a board like none he had ever seen, remarkable for being so slender and for lacking contours or fins.

headline: Astronauts Begin Repairs on a Space Station Module
text: Two NASA astronauts, working more quickly than expected, completed a spacewalk on Saturday in which they took the first steps to repair a malfunctioning pump module that is part of the cooling system for the International Space Station.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Oscar de la Renta Cocktail Plates
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Photograph: Jeff Hanneman’s First Guitar
text: Jeff Hanneman

headline: The Moment That Captured Nixon
text: Associated PressDavid Frost and Richard Nixon in California, 1977.

headline: Suárez Pays Immediate Dividend
text: One of the more tried and true soccer clichés — “he opened his account” — normally refers to a player scoring his first goal of the season or his first goal with a new club.

headline: 4 Suspects Held in Fatal Carjacking at Mall
text: After five tense days and an all-out manhunt, New Jersey authorities announced Saturday that four men had been arrested in the carjacking and fatal shooting of a New Jersey lawyer last weekend.

headline: Easy Holiday Entertaining
text: For holiday entertaining this close to Christmas, it is wise to keep things easy in order to remain festive and in good cheer. Greeting guests at the front door with a glass of wine in hand both sets the tone for a casual event and is more enjoyable than running yourself ragged in the kitchen. This year, my husband and I are entertaining a dozen friends and family on Christmas Eve in our small Welsh hillside cottage, where there is no electricity. It’s not quite as heathen as it sounds, and what could be more Christmassy than a dwelling lit by candles and warmed by open fires?

headline: Irish Try to Eradicate Ghosts of a Housing Crash
text: ATHLONE, Ireland — The demolition getting underway here recently was in a housing complex where a 2-year-old, probably chasing a dog, had climbed through a fence last year and drowned in a pool of water behind a dozen partly constructed homes.

headline: For Syrian Refugees, Obstacles to School Are Many
text: Of the more than two million Syrian refugees in the region, about 865,000 are children, and 70 percent of them are not enrolled in school, Unicef says.

headline: The Slow Disappearance of Queen Fawzia
text: Queen Fawzia

headline: For Most Young Refugees From Syria, School Is as Distant as Home
text: BAALBEK, Lebanon — Standing in the front of a classroom, Khalid Naji, a 13-year-old Syrian refugee, clutched a red felt pen and began copying the English sentence he had composed in his notebook. “Rana doesnt blay football,” he wrote on a whiteboard, looking down at his notebook before slowly composing each letter, “but he riding story.”

headline: Thai Opposition Party Will Boycott February Elections as Large Protests Continue
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s main opposition party said on Saturday that it would boycott national elections scheduled for February, strengthening its alliance with the tens of thousands of antigovernment protesters who have rallied on the streets of Bangkok for the past month.

headline: Canada’s Women’s Hockey Team Loses Its Edge Before Sochi
text: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — Late in his second practice with Canada’s women’s hockey team Thursday, Coach Kevin Dineen gathered his players inside the blue line and introduced a contest. The forward lines, the defensemen and the goalies nominated someone from each group to shoot at the opposite goal. First group to miss had to skate a lap. Hard.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Dec. 22
text: “The current storage by the government of bulk metadata creates potential risks to public trust, personal privacy and civil liberty.”

headline: Video: Spider Drove a Taxi
text: Johnnie (Spider) Footman

headline: Variety: 3-D Word Hunt
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — It’s that time of year: Will Shortz’s 3-D Word Hunt is here!

headline: Letters: Doctors and Residencies
text: Doctors and Residencies

headline: Seeking the Why of Giving
text: Beyond the tax deduction, what motivates people to give money to charity? With Americans donating hundreds of billions of dollars to causes every year, it’s a question that directly affects nonprofits, and new academic research is trying to offer a clearer answer.

headline: The Not-a-Scientist’s Assistant
text: I was 20 years old, going to college in New York and in need of a job. My roommate waitressed at a restaurant where she made huge tips, but I didn’t have the bone structure or hair texture to be hired somewhere like that. Instead, I waited outside the Village Voice offices. It was the late ’90s, and every Wednesday when the paper came out, a line of people stretched down the sidewalk to get a first look at the classified ads. That’s how different things were before the Internet. Back then, people would unbend their legs and assume a vertical position, known as standing.

headline: How Y’all, Youse and You Guys Talk
text: What does the way you speak say about where you’re from? Answer all the questions below to see your personal dialect map.

headline: A Complaint Registered, Then Expunged
text: In this episode we look at Angie’s List, and, up front, the Haggler should probably confess that he is very jealous of Angie. Why? Because she has her own list! It’s a website of crowd-sourced reviews of local businesses. Essentially, Angie’s List is an online compendium of thumbs ups and thumbs down, or put more succinctly, a list of who’s naughty and nice.

headline: Penny Pritzker, on Hearing the Whole Story
text: This interview with  Penny Pritzker, the secretary of commerce, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Attack on U.S. Aircraft Foils Evacuation in South Sudan
text: WASHINGTON — Three United States aircraft flying into a heavily contested region of South Sudan to evacuate American citizens were attacked on Saturday morning and forced to turn back without completing the mission, American officials said. Four service members were wounded, one seriously.

headline: Nets’ Lopez Breaks Bone in Foot and Could Miss Rest of Season
text: Health has been everything for the Nets this season: the ominous variable that threatened to derail their season even before it began, the fickle state they lacked during their disastrous start, the factor they enthusiastically linked to their brief moments of success. As a vague and mutable concept, it still offered hope that the Nets could turn around their season. Now that seems far less likely.

headline: A Great Ride, but Reality Is Returning
text: It’s been the kind of year that makes an average investor feel like a genius: You could just put your money in a stock index fund and watch the market speed ahead. Why not take a few moments to savor it?

headline: Don’t Mistake This for Gridlock
text: Economic policy in the United States is ruled by gridlock. That’s the common belief, and it’s easy to see the evidence for it in the daily headlines. Immigration reform didn’t even come up for a vote in Congress this year, and the budget deal approved by the Senate last week managed to amend the sequestration but was far from a “grand fiscal bargain.” It was the best that could be accomplished, given gridlock.

headline: Off Limits, but Blessed by the Fed
text: The good news arrived in a confidential letter from the Federal Reserve Board in Washington. The nation’s biggest bank, JPMorgan Chase, had won the right to expand its reach in a lucrative business that has nothing to do with banking: electricity.

headline: Favelas in Rio Are New Lodging Hot Spots
text: As Brazil prepares to host the 2014 World Cup, residents of Rio's favelas are turning once dilapidated and dangerous hillside dwellings into valuable hotel rooms.

headline: Now Taking World Cup Bookings, Rio’s Slums
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Gun battles still boom through the streets. Drug dealers still ply their trade in the labyrinth of alleyways. Residents of the Rocinha neighborhood still fume over the brutal tactics of the police, who were recently charged with torturing and killing an impoverished bricklayer.

headline: Bulls’ Noah Provokes With Words
text: For once, it seems, Joakim Noah was not the one looking for a fight.

headline: Mining for Bitcoins in Iceland
text: At a secure facility that was once a NATO base, computer servers run around the clock mining bitcoins. The company behind the operation relies on cheap energy to turn processing power into cash.

headline: Manning Is Still Working to Find Answers in a Lost Season
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eli Manning has been the face of the Giants for a decade, his powerful throwing arm and rich football pedigree offering vast promise, despite his enormous struggles as a rookie in 2004. His slight smile and understated demeanor spoke of his selflessness when he helped the franchise win Super Bowls to close the 2007 and 2011 seasons, twice emerging as the game’s Most Valuable Player.

headline: 18 Soldiers in Iraq Are Killed During Raid on Rebel Group’s Training Camp
text: BAGHDAD — A high-ranking Iraqi Army commander was among 18 soldiers killed on Saturday by suicide bombers and roadside explosions as they raided the training camp of a Qaeda affiliate in western Anbar Province near the Syrian border, Iraqi security officials said.

headline: Player Development Is Where Penguins Remain Healthy
text: Year after year, the Pittsburgh Penguins are hit hard by injuries to star players, and even more so in the past two seasons. But they continue to win, in large part because of General Manager Ray Shero’s foresight and industriousness.

headline: NASA Video of Saturday’s Spacewalk
text: Two NASA astronauts at the International Space Station began the first of at least two spacewalks on Dec. 21. Their goal is to replace a malfunctioning pump module that is part of the cooling system.

headline: Haunted by Doris Lessing
text: Doris Lessing

headline: Teammates Expect the Usual Chemistry, This Time in Red, White and Blue
text: ST. PAUL — No one needed introductions in July when the five players who make up the leadership group for the United States Olympic men’s hockey team met with its coaches and executives at a hotel near Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, and later for dinner at an Italian restaurant. All five — David Backes, Dustin Brown, Ryan Callahan, Zach Parise and Ryan Suter — played on the silver-medal-winning American team at the Vancouver Games in 2010, and in various combinations at other international tournaments.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Nike+ FuelBand
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Finishes Beyond All Control in the N.F.L.
text: In the N.F.L., teams play once a week and everyone essentially has too much time to think. It has led to a culture of excessive preparation that leaves nothing to chance.

headline: Political Strife in South Sudan Sets Off Ethnic Violence
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — He sat among tens of thousands of terrified people crammed into the United Nations compound, most of them women and children, taking notes about their desperate rush to safety. Like them, he had come seeking protection.

headline: Photograph: Esther Williams’s Famous Bathing Suit
text: Esther Williams

headline: Morsi to Stand Trial on Role in ’11 Uprising
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian judge on Saturday ordered ousted President Mohamed Morsi to stand trial on charges that he colluded with foreign militants in an elaborate plot to free prisoners and “spread chaos” during the 2011 uprising against Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Master of His Virtual Domain
text: Last spring, a few months before his eighth birthday, my son announced that he wanted to join a clan.

headline: Into the Bitcoin Mines
text: On the flat lava plain of Reykjanesbaer, Iceland, near the Arctic Circle, you can find the mines of Bitcoin.

headline: Mixed Messages Add Anxiety as Deadline Nears in Health Act
text: WASHINGTON — For most Americans, Monday is the deadline to sign up for health insurance that takes effect on Jan. 1. It was supposed to be a turning point in the troubled history of the new health care law, the moment when the spotlight would shift from the federal government’s online marketplace to the insurance companies providing coverage to hundreds of thousands and eventually millions of people.

headline: Uber and the Macro Wars
text: Yesterday I offered a brief history of the civil war in macroeconomics, in which I explained that it really began over the question of apparent wage and price stickiness. It was an obvious empirical fact that wages generally don’t fall in recessions, and that as a result changes in nominal spending are reflected in real output. (Just as a reminder — this does NOT mean that wage flexibility would improve our current situation — on the contrary, thanks to the overhang of household debt, it would make things worse).

headline: Santacare Is Coming to Town
text: To my American constituents, of both the naughty and nice parties, I’m pleased to announce the rollout of the Affordable Gift Act, referred to by the name of its sponsor — yours truly — as Santacare.

headline: Triumph of the English Major
text: I REMEMBER the moment when I finally decided that I was pulling my weight, or at least some of it, in the great collective effort that is, or used to be, the American economy.

headline: Debbie Sterling
text: Debbie Sterling is the founder and chief executive of GoldieBlox, a toy company dedicated to encouraging girls’ interest in engineering and construction.

headline: A Wordnado of Words in 2013
text: PRIVACY. Selfie. Geek. Science. Four dictionary publishers each selected one of those words as its word of the year for 2013. But it’s tough to catalog the preoccupations of the year in a single word. There were many flying around that seemed to capture a moment, an emotion, a thought, a new way of doing or describing things, or the larger zeitgeist. Some were new, some not so new, but they all seemed to say something about the times. Here are a few:

headline: Ideas From a Manger
text: PAUSE for a moment, in the last leg of your holiday shopping, to glance at one of the manger scenes you pass along the way. Cast your eyes across the shepherds and animals, the infant and the kings. Then try to see the scene this way: not just as a pious set-piece, but as a complete world picture — intimate, miniature and comprehensive.

headline: A Missing Spy and the Right to Know
text: NEW YORK TIMES readers expect, reasonably enough, that their newspaper will publish what it digs up in the way of news, especially news about the clandestine activities of the federal government.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Lifting Kids Out of Poverty
text: Readers discuss how to mirror our success with helping seniors.

headline: Health Care’s Road to Ruin
text: HAVING spent the last year reporting for a series of articles on the high cost of American medicine, I’ve heard it all. There was Fred Abrahams, 77, a skier who had surgery on both ankles for arthritis — one in New York for more than $200,000 and one in New Hampshire for less than $40,000. There was Matthew Landman, 41, billed more than $100,000 for antivenin administered in an E.R. after a small rattlesnake bite. There was Robin Miller, a Florida businessman, who needed to buy an implantable defibrillator for his ill brother, who was uninsured; the machine costs tens of thousands of dollars, but he couldn’t get a price for a make or a model.

headline: Thank You for Hacking Me
text: I got hacked.

headline: Waiting for Wonder Woman
text: HOLLYWOOD — MAYBE because I have seven nieces whose dreams matter to me, maybe because I have so many female friends whose talents dazzle me, or maybe just because I think it’s madness not to encourage and recognize the full potential of half of the human race, I keep looking to the movies for something better. For something more equitable. For women saving the world or saving the president or at the very least saving themselves.

headline: How to Monetize Your Closet
text: I INTERVIEWED Brian Chesky, the co-founder of Airbnb, in July about the “sharing economy.” While I was researching Chesky’s company, I got a call from an entrepreneur, Tracy DiNunzio. She had heard that I was writing about Chesky and wanted to tell me about her start-up because it was related to Airbnb, the site on which anyone can rent a spare bedroom to anyone else around the world and pick up a little cash.

headline: Santa on the Brain
text: ASHLAND, Va. — I’LL never forget that December day 12 years ago, and the family holiday crisis I so narrowly averted. I had spent the morning at my office writing a neuroscience textbook, and was looking forward to returning home to spend some time with my 3- and 7-year-old daughters, Skylar and Lara. But the news I received from my husband as I walked through the door was devastating. The girls had been exploring in the attic — a space I’d thought was the perfect hiding place for Santa’s gifts. It was more than a week before Christmas and they had just seen their presents!

headline: A Reading List for Feuding Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — AS mainstream and Tea Party Republicans wrestle for control of their party, it might be wise over the holidays for each faction to crack open a pair of recent books that recount previous episodes of internecine political combat.

headline: In No One We Trust
text: In America today, we are sometimes made to feel that it is naïve to be preoccupied with trust. Our songs advise against it, our TV shows tell stories showing its futility, and incessant reports of financial scandal remind us we’d be fools to give it to our bankers.

headline: Chaos and Creation in N.F.L.’s Final Minutes
text: N.F.L. coaches try to plan the final minutes of a game, but desperation is the mother of invention, and the making of great moments.

headline: The Peril of Antibiotic Use on Farms
text: After years of inaction, the Food and Drug Administration has finally taken an important step to reduce the use of medically important antibiotics in animal feed. The goal is to curb the rise of bacteria that become resistant to antibiotics used in both human and veterinary medicine.

headline: Europe’s Flawed Banking Deal
text: European finance ministers have agreed on a plan to rescue failing banks. It is not a good one. Policy makers at key institutions like the European Parliament and the European Central Bank should push for a better deal.

headline: Bad Times for Big Brother
text: It has been a long week for the National Security Agency. Last Monday, a federal judge ruled for the first time that the agency’s continuing sweep of Americans’ phone data — a once-secret program legally sanctioned for seven years and illegally conducted for five years before that — was very likely unconstitutional. Judge Richard Leon denounced the agency’s activities in collecting data on all Americans’ phone calls as “almost Orwellian.”

headline: What Iranians Say Now About ‘the Great Satan’
text: TEHRAN — The old American Embassy building in the heart of this capital city was recently opened to tours for Westerners. It is now a museum run by the Revolutionary Guard and its Basiji paramilitary allies, where they keep alive a paranoid narrative of American malice and deceit by showcasing dust-encrusted spy equipment and a modern mural of alleged American perfidies.

headline: Video: Caleb Moore, Daredevil on a Snowmobile
text: Caleb Moore

headline: Late Run Can’t Offset Knicks’ Early Stumbles
text: With each dispiriting loss in which the Knicks’ defense deteriorates and their offense comes and goes, the pressure mounts. The boos grow louder, as do the calls for Coach Mike Woodson’s job.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 22
text: This week, a White House-appointed panel recommended that President Obama rein in the National Security Agency and impose more oversight. Also, a United States District Court judge ruled Monday that an N.S.A. program that systematically collects records of American phone calls is probably unconstitutional, but he stayed his order while the case is appealed.

headline: In More Than Spirit, Cheryl Denelli Righter Lives On
text: Cheryl Denelli Righter

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Somali Parliament Approves New Prime Minister
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The Somali Parliament on Saturday approved the appointment of the new prime minister, Abdiweli Sheikh Ahmed Mohamed, who is expected to lead the government for the next three years.

headline: Overcrowding in Classrooms
text: Across the country, public schools employ about 250,000 fewer people than before the recession.

headline: George Mitchell, Father of Fracking
text: How to Frack Shale: Drill down to a layer of shale. Detonate charges to create fissures in the rock. Pump a water, chemical and sand mixture into the crevices, creating better pathways for natural gas to escape. Capture the gas that escapes.

headline: White House Tries to Prevent Judge From Ruling on Surveillance Efforts
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration moved late Friday to prevent a federal judge in California from ruling on the constitutionality of warrantless surveillance programs authorized during the Bush administration, telling a court that recent disclosures about National Security Agency spying were not enough to undermine its claim that litigating the case would jeopardize state secrets.

headline: Rangers Add Choo to Outfield
text: The free-agent outfielder Shin-Soo Choo and the Texas Rangers have agreed to a seven-year contract worth about $130 million, according to a person who was briefed on the deal. The contract is contingent on Choo passing a physical. Choo will probably bat leadoff and play left field for Texas.

headline: Week 16 Matchup: Browns (4-10) at Jets (6-8)
text: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: Week 16 Matchup: Giants (5-9) at Lions (7-7)
text: 4:05 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: Animation: The Creator of the Etch A Sketch Gets His Own Treatment
text: André Cassagnes

headline: Peter Kaplan, Cracking Wise
text: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times

headline: Good One!
text: Administrivial Sunday, Dec. 22 Puzzle Alert! In this puzzle, there is a Notepad in the Across Lite version that says, “When this puzzle is done, draw a line connecting the 21 circled letters from A to U in alphabetical order. The resulting shape will provide a clue to 6-, 8-, 14-, 53- and 70-Down.”

headline: For Peace in Syria, Will Assad Have to Stay?
text: Is it time to acknowledge Assad will not be removed soon and plan for Syria's future with him?

headline: With Punishments or Pardons, Putin Shows He Is in Control
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin’s freeing of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia’s best-known prisoner, by swift, personal fiat capped a remarkable string of single-handed decisions of late.

headline: Pardoned Russian Tycoon Is Free to Start Planning His Future
text: BERLIN — Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky spent his first full day as a free man in the German capital reconnecting with his eldest son and his parents, whom he had not seen during the 10 years he spent in prison in Russia. But even as he recovered in a luxury hotel on Saturday, Mr. Khodorkovsky began planning how to use his newfound freedom, holding meetings with German officials and organizing his first public appearance.

headline: A Sentence for a Family
text: Jesse Webster has been incarcerated 18 years for dealing cocaine; his family hopes President Obama will commute his sentence.

headline: A Dealer Serving Life Without Having Taken One
text: GREENVILLE, Ill. — A lifer with a pen sat in the 65-square-foot cell he shares. A calendar taunted from a bulletin board. He began to write.

headline: Spike in Harm to Liver Is Tied to Dietary Aids
text: When Christopher Herrera, 17, walked into the emergency room at Texas Children’s Hospital one morning last year, his chest, face and eyes were bright yellow — “almost highlighter yellow,” recalled Dr. Shreena S. Patel, the pediatric resident who treated him.

headline: When the Right to Bear Arms Includes the Mentally Ill
text: Last April, workers at Middlesex Hospital in Connecticut called the police to report that a psychiatric patient named Mark Russo had threatened to shoot his mother if officers tried to take the 18 rifles and shotguns he kept at her house. Mr. Russo, who was off his medication for paranoid schizophrenia, also talked about the recent elementary school massacre in Newtown and told a nurse that he “could take a chair and kill you or bash your head in between the eyes,” court records show.

headline: Is Arkansas Still Friendly to Bill? Clinton Tests It
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — When it came time to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the opening of a dam on the Little Red River this fall, former President Bill Clinton came running. But once he arrived in the state, he had more on his mind than just public works.

headline: The Clinton Connection
text: No one in the Clinton family is running for office in 2014, but the influence of the former president can be seen in several coming elections in his home state of Arkansas.

headline: Video: The Night Witch
text: Nadezhda Popova

headline: Elmore Leonard on the Open Range
text: Elmore Leonard

headline: Subtract Teachers, Add Pupils: Math of Today’s Jammed Schools
text: COATESVILLE, Pa. — The recession may have ended, but many of the nation’s school districts that laid off teachers and other employees to cut payrolls in leaner times have not yet replenished their ranks. Now, despite the recovery, many schools face unwieldy class sizes and a lack of specialists to help those students who struggle academically, are learning English as a second language or need extra emotional support.

headline: Fort Worth Sues Driller, Citing Millions in Lost Royalties
text: Chesapeake Energy’s mark on Fort Worth is hard to miss.

headline: When Maria Tallchief Took Paris by Storm
text: Maria Tallchief

headline: Kenneth A. Schechter, 83, Dies; With Help, He Flew Blind
text: “On the ninth of my planned 15 bomb runs, at 1,200 feet, an enemy antiaircraft shell exploded in the cockpit. Instinctively, I pulled back on the stick to gain altitude. Then I passed out. When I came to a short time later, I couldn’t see a thing. There was stinging agony in my face and throbbing in my head. I felt for my upper lip. It was almost severed from the rest of my face. I called out over the radio through my lip mike (which miraculously still worked), ‘I’m blind! For God’s sake, help me! I’m blind!’ ”

headline: Gay Couples in Utah, Surprised but Glad, Rush to Marry After Ruling Permits It
text: SALT LAKE CITY — They arrived with children in strollers and with bouquets of flowers, with co-workers and with friends — dozens of gay couples pouring into a government building just a few miles from the headquarters of the Mormon Church to do what many said they thought would never be possible: get a Utah marriage license.

headline: Beyond Fiji and Perrier, With a Water Sommelier
text: When a doctor told Michael Mascha, a wine connoisseur, that he could either live or continue to drink, it wasn’t an easy choice.

headline: Michiaki Takahashi, 85, Who Tamed Chickenpox, Dies
text: Dr. Michiaki Takahashi, whose experience caring for his 3-year-old son after the boy contracted chickenpox led him to develop a vaccine for the virus that is now used all over the world, died on Monday in Osaka, Japan. He was 85.

headline: Big Rocks, Torn-Up Roads, Fragile Glass
text: Like many others, Eddie Posselt was drawn to South Texas last year by job opportunities in the oil fields. Initially he found work in Carrizo Springs as a well tester. But six months later, a different opportunity presented itself.

headline: The Horse Race for 2013 Funds Enters Last Lap
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: Escalating Crisis of Faith for Knicks’ True Believers
text: Mike Woodson slouched into his postgame, post-disaster news conference with the dour look of an undertaker with entirely too much business on his hands.

headline: Victim in Colorado School Shooting Dies
text: A Colorado high school student who was shot in the head on Dec. 13 by a schoolmate died on Saturday afternoon, her family and hospital officials said.

headline: Video: Naturally, J.J. Cale
text: J.J. Cale

headline: Turning Away From a Path to Suicide
text: Everything was on the rise: her blood pressure, her glucose levels, her body weight. The odds of Wana Joseph succumbing to a premature death were multiplying.

headline: Striving for Security, a Man Seeks Steady Work
text: Every day, Carlos Castro makes a series of phone calls. His wallet depends on it.

headline: Care Comes Full Time for a Citizen
text: Andrew Branch once went an entire year without leaving his apartment.

headline: Who Was Dear Abby?
text: Frank Johnston/The Washington Post, via Getty ImagesAbigail Van Buren (left) and Ann Landers at an awards dinner in Washington in 1997.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 21, 2013
A Period With Fewer Teachers
text: Unlike in previous recoveries, the number of local public education jobs remains below where it was four years ago.

headline: America’s No. 1 Player Wins London Chess Classic
text: Hikaru Nakamura, America’s top player, won the London Chess Classic last week, fueled by victories over rivals who have often given him trouble.

headline: Motorcyclist and Pedestrian Are Killed in a Crash in Queens
text: A 78-year-old woman and a man driving a motorcycle were both killed when the motorcyclist struck her on Saturday afternoon in Queens, the police said.

headline: Ball-Swiping Buckeyes Rally to Defeat the Irish
text: Shannon Scott said he and his fellow Ohio State guard Aaron Craft share something of a sixth sense, what he calls a “turnover sense.” When one of them harasses an opponent, the other can sense the turnover coming and even take off to jump-start a transition basket.

headline: Norah Turnham, Michael Roderick
text: Norah Elizabeth Turnham, the daughter of Phyllis L. Turnham and the Rev. Dr. Timothy J. Turnham of Washington, is to be married Sunday to Michael Paul Roderick, the son of Diane M. Roderick and Richard F. Roderick of Smithfield, R.I. The bride’s father, a Southern Baptist minister, will officiate at the New York City Fire Museum.

headline: Brian Allen and Steven Horsch
text: Brian Thomas Allen and Steven Dale Horsch were married Saturday in the Cochran Chapel at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass. The Rev. Michael J. Ebner, a Methodist minister and a former Protestant chaplain at Andover, officiated.

headline: Shooting the Breeze About Wind Power
text: Melissa Hope Matlins and Daniel Adam Riegel were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Barry A. Marks at the Green Building in Brooklyn.

headline: Alexandra Zipf and Jordan Stuart
text: Alexandra Behan Zipf and Jordan Scott Stuart were married Saturday at St. John Vianney Roman Catholic Church in Gladwyne, Pa. Msgr. Donald E. Leighton performed the ceremony.

headline: John Cocchiarella, Robin Tomas
text: John Charles Cocchiarella and Robert Martin Hermosa Tomas were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, a staff member in the City Clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Lara Fox, Paul Moskowitz
text: Lara Danielle Fox and Paul Gilbert Moskowitz were married Saturday evening at the Pierre hotel in New York. Rabbi Jeffrey A. Wohlberg officiated.

headline: Julie Samuels and Joshua Mendelsohn
text: Julie Phyllis Samuels and Joshua Marc Mendelsohn were married Friday at the Dirksen Federal Building in Chicago. A cousin of the bride, Judge James B. Zagel of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, officiated.

headline: Katherine Sexton and Eric Gurian
text: Katherine Lodgen Sexton, the daughter of John E. Sexton of New York and the late Lisa E. Goldberg, was married Saturday evening to Eric Andrew Gurian, a son of Marcia J. Gurian and David I. Gurian of West Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Andy Bachman officiated at Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

headline: Lindsay DeHartchuck and Rishi Kumar
text: Lindsay Jill DeHartchuck and Rishi Kumar were married Saturday evening at the Umstead Hotel and Spa in Cary, N.C. Justin R. Savesky, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Christina McGrath and Justin Spring
text: Christina Marie McGrath and Maj. Justin Benjamin Spring were married Tuesday under Colorado’s self-uniting marriage statute at Centennial Hall, a county building in Colorado Springs. On Dec. 28 they will have a religious ceremony at the United States Air Force Academy Cadet Chapel in Colorado Springs, where Msgr. Robert E. Jaeger, a Roman Catholic priest, will officiate.

headline: Robyn Kotek, Jason Turetsky
text: Robyn Heather Kotek and Jason Richard Turetsky were married Saturday evening at Pier 60 at Chelsea Piers in New York. Rabbi Noam Marans officiated.

headline: That New York Spirit
text: Gail Debra Steiner and Roger Saul Levine were married Saturday evening at the Stone Mill, an event space at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Amy Katz officiated.

headline: Edgar M. Bronfman, Who Built a Bigger, More Elegant Seagram, Dies at 84
text: Edgar M. Bronfman, the billionaire businessman and philanthropist who as chairman of the Seagram Company expanded his family’s liquor-based empire and who as president of the World Jewish Congress championed the rights of Jews everywhere, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: No Arrests in Brooklyn Hit-and-Run
text: The police are looking for a driver who ran over a 51-year-old man on Saturday evening in Brooklyn and kept going.

headline: In Late ‘S.N.L.’ Debut, Bloomberg Quips About His Post-Mayoral Plans
text: Even after three terms, Michael R. Bloomberg is still managing a mayoral first.

headline: Antigovernment Protesters Vow to Block Elections in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — In one of the more provocative moves of Thailand’s monthlong political crisis, antigovernment protesters marching through Bangkok on Sunday vowed to disrupt the coming elections in their campaign to rid the country of its most influential political family.

headline: Corrections: December 22, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Negotiating Pettiness and Heartache in the Modern, Blended, Non-Brady Family
text: “The Brady Bunch.” Remember them? At 42, I find myself the matriarch of a big, blended family (that is what we call it now), a Carol Brady for the 21st century. But here is my question: where exactly was Carol Brady’s ex-husband?Our theme song goes like this:

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: IfOnly Caramel Collection
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Free to Speak About Russia, but Now From a Safe Distance
text: BERLIN — After a decade of incarceration that transformed him from Russia’s wealthiest man into its most famous political prisoner, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky faced journalists in Berlin on Sunday following a head-spinning 36-hour journey to freedom.

headline: Disruptions: Betting on a Coin With No Realm
text: This is the story of a $6 million pizza.

headline: John Eisenhower, Military Historian and Son of the President, Dies at 91
text: John S. D. Eisenhower, the son of President Dwight D. Eisenhower who forged a reputation in his own right as a military historian, died on Saturday at his home in Trappe, Md., on the Eastern Shore. He was 91.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: ‘The Fairy Tales of Hans Christian Andersen’
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Japanese Team Dominates Competition to Create Generation of Rescue Robots
text: HOMESTEAD, Fla. — An international competition to pave the way for a new generation of rescue robots was dominated by a team of Japanese roboticists who were students in the laboratory of a pioneer in the design of intelligent humanoid machines.

headline: Reflections on the Killing of Chico Mendes 25 Years Ago
text: It’s hard for me to believe that it’s been 25 years since a cattle rancher ordered his son to shoot Chico Mendes, a rubber tapper and unionist who had become an effective international campaigner for sustainable use of the Amazon rain forest. I spent the year following Mendes’s assassination piecing together “The Burning Season,” my book on his life, death and influence. But I haven’t been back to that corner of the Amazon since the trial of his murderers in 1990. The Guardian has published an excellent article assessing his legacy. Linda Rabben, an anthropologist and activist focused on human rights and the environment, is the lead organizer of a conference on Mendes and grassroots environmentalism next spring. She sent this short “Your Dot” contribution on Mendes:

headline: In Blow to Leadership of ’11 Revolt, Egypt Activists Are Given 3 Years in Prison
text: CAIRO — Three activists who played central roles in the uprising against former President Hosni Mubarak were convicted on Sunday of participating in recent protests and sentenced to three years in prison, raising fears that the new government was seeking revenge against opponents of Egypt’s old order.

headline: Vienna Philharmonic Revokes Nazi Honors
text: The Vienna Philharmonic has revoked honors it bestowed on six notable Nazi officials during Hitler’s reign in Austria and Germany. The action was taken at the annual meeting of members of the orchestra, which is self-governing, on Oct. 23.

headline: For Liverpool Fans, There Is Plenty to Cheer
text: LONDON — England upholds some mighty odd soccer traditions around Christmas.

headline: ‘Hobbit’ Edges Out ‘Anchorman 2’ at Box Office
text: A scorched-earth ad campaign delivered solid ticket sales for “Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues” over the weekend, while two Oscar hopefuls had mixed results in wider release, computer-generated dinosaurs flopped and a Bollywood import arrived in Imax and broke records. But no newcomer was strong enough to overtake “The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug” (Warner Brothers), which repeated as the No. 1 movie in North America by selling about $31.5 million in tickets at 3,928 locations, for a two-week domestic total of $127.5 million.

headline: State Official Appointed by de Blasio as Leader of Child Welfare Agency
text: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio on Sunday named a top state social services official to serve as his child welfare commissioner, installing an experienced leader atop an agency with a history of failing the children it serves and bedeviling mayors who try to reform it.

headline: A Woodstock for Robots
text: At the Robotics Challenge 2013 Trials in Homestead, Fla., teams that built rescue robots competed for a chance at a $2 million prize.

headline: A Gift That Keeps on Giving – to Strumming Musicians
text: Here’s an unsolicited, last-minute, pre-Christmas plug for the Pick Punch, a device my 15-year-old son gave me for my last birthday that turns old credit cards or other plastic sheet — in this case a stray hotel key — into stringed instrument picks.

headline: Man Threw Son, 3, From High-Rise Before Jumping to His Death, Police Say
text: A Brooklyn man who had recently separated from his wife and was sharing custody of their 3-year-old son threw the boy from the roof of a 52-story Manhattan high-rise on Sunday afternoon before jumping to his death moments later, the police said.

headline: Combating Criminals With Flash
text: The hero of “Dhoom 3” isn’t India’s top cop, Jai Dixit, who’s summoned to Chicago from Mumbai to catch a thief. Jai (Abhishek Bachchan) may be the series’s franchise player, but in each “Dhoom” film, a heroic guest villain has eclipsed him.

headline: Bangladeshi Factory Owners Charged in Fire That Killed 112
text: NEW DELHI — The police in Bangladesh charged the owners of a garment factory and 11 of their employees with culpable homicide in the deaths of 112 workers in a fire last year that came to symbolize the appalling working conditions in the country’s dominant textile industry.

headline: Debating the N.S.A.’s Data Collection, and a Panel’s Findings
text: Washington — A member of President Obama’s advisory committee on signals intelligence, the panel that recommended major restrictions on the National Security Agency’s data collection, on Sunday countered the notion that the panel had found no value in the agency’s activities.

headline: In Our Pages: December 23
text: 1938: Firemen Battle To Save Invalides Monument Roof

headline: A Nureyev Ballet, With a Hint of Ambivalence, Takes Its Time
text: PARIS — Rudolf Nureyev’s “The Sleeping Beauty,” currently being performed by the Paris Opera Ballet, is ornate, ceremonious and very, very long. It also hints at Nureyev’s ambivalence toward the Russia he left behind when he defected to the West in 1961 at 23 while on tour with the Kirov Ballet.

headline: After the Deluge, the Restoration
text: More than most Renaissance artists, Giorgio Vasari knew the perilous existence of human creations. In “The Lives of the Artists,” the chronicle of the great quattrocento painters and sculptors for which he is best known, he describes how a stone bench, hurled off a parapet by an anti-Medici mob in Florence in 1527, “chanced, as Fortune would have it,” to land on Michelangelo’s “David,” breaking one of its arms into three pieces.

headline: Haunted by Holiday Shows Past
text: The spurious “war on Christmas” bemoaned on Fox News notwithstanding, a war really has been going on in recent years at the holidays: a war between traditional television Christmas specials and that aggressive musical interloper, the singing-competition finale. It’s a mismatch. With December now dominated by singing competitions — “The X Factor” and “The Voice” wrapped up last week; “The Sing-Off” ends Monday night — the old-fashioned variety-show-style Christmas special feels as if it could go extinct any year now.

headline: You Can’t Save Them All
text: You don’t play video games, but you’re curious about them. How should you get started? That’s a question that Steve Gaynor, the writer and director of the independent game Gone Home, has taken to asking guests on his podcast (Tone Control: Conversations with Video Game Developers): What would they recommend to someone who is entirely new to the medium?

headline: Strategy Remains Elusive for Ukraine Opposition
text: KIEV, Ukraine — One of the most effective, and affecting, sights on Maidan, the independence square that antigovernment protesters have made theirs for the past month, is a simple wall of wooden blocks. There are hundreds, in jagged formation, each with the name of a village, town or city etched in black.

headline: Jets Ride Ryan’s Power of Persuasion to Victory Over Browns
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Rex Ryan stamped. He shouted. He cursed and snarled and appealed, releasing a reservoir of fury on a man who was in position to make a very important decision. When he had finished pleading, Ryan had what he wanted.

headline: Book Theft in Italy, With a Hint of Politics
text: MILAN — For years, the books kept coming. A precious edition by Thomas More. Leather-bound volumes from the Italian Renaissance. Some stolen from the Baroque-era Girolamini Library in Naples, given as gifts to an influential longtime consigliere to former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.

headline: Make Music Winter
text: The celebration in Prospect Park was marked by a participatory performance and unseasonably warm weather.

headline: A Romp, Meant to Ring in the Cold, Feels Like Spring
text: Last year, Make Music Winter, the annual solstice celebration of participatory performance, took place with an emphasis on its final word. I joined in “Winterize,” the baritone Christopher Dylan Herbert’s peripatetic outdoor version of Schubert’s “Winterreise,” at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on a raw, gray afternoon as chilly as the melancholy score.

headline: Reaching for Soul’s High Ground
text: Classic soul singing is, among countless other things, the art of the interjection. “Whoo!” “Mmmmm.” “Ohhhhhh.” “HahahaHA!” “Owww.” “Yeah, yeah!” “Am I lying?” Can I take my time?” “Listen to me!” “Do you feel it?” Used right, those interjections can be percussion, comedy, respiration, tension, release and more. Bobby Womack, 69, used them all at City Winery on Friday night, wearing a red leather suit, a red hat and red sunglasses as he started a three-night stand.

headline: Q. and A.: U.S. Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker on China Trade Talks
text: Since a key Communist Party conference issued a plan in November to advance market reforms, a series of foreign envoys have rolled through China seeking to capitalize on some of its more business-friendly initiatives. Top American trade officials took the same tack during talks in Beijing last week, but made clear afterward that it would take time for United States businesses to reap dividends from the conference, known as the Third Plenum.

headline: China Deal Gives Apple Big Market to Court
text: Just about any way you slice it, 763 million customers is a huge potential pie.

headline: An Affection for Books, Dogs, One Tough Nun and, Yes, a Husband
text: The best advertisement for Ann Patchett’s new collection of nonfiction is anything else Ms. Patchett has written. Her novels (“Bel Canto” remains the most exquisite), memoir about a friend (“Truth & Beauty”) and assorted speeches and essays all share unusual frankness and drawing power. Ms. Patchett’s style is not overly confessional, but it is beguiling in ways that make her sound like someone you’d want to know. Her new book, “This Is the Story of a Happy Marriage,” reinforces the impression of an uncommonly kind person who is not above self-interest but loves books, her grandmother, the toughest nun who taught her in grade school, her husband and her darling dog.

headline: Enough Anxiety to Fill Two Books
text: WASHINGTON — There are countless American families braving the usual anxieties of the holiday season: frantic shopping, exasperating travel and tedious relatives.

headline: Monaco Triumphs at Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams
text: The Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, the premier event at the Fall North American Championships last month in Phoenix, was won by the defending champions, Team Monaco: Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness. They finished just over two boards ahead of Norberto Bocchi and Agustin Madala from Italy, Krzysztof Buras and Grzegorz Narkiewicz from Poland, and Aleksander Dubinin and Andrei Gromov from Russia. Third were Martin Fleisher, Chris Willenken and Zia Mahmood of New York City; Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.; Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif.; and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.

headline: Passengers on Bus Near Tel Aviv Flee Just Before a Bomb Explodes
text: JERUSALEM — A bomb exploded on a bus in Bat Yam near Tel Aviv on Sunday minutes after the passengers were asked to get off, preventing casualties. The police said that initial evidence pointed to an attempted terrorist attack, presumably by Palestinian militants, the first of this kind in just over a year.

headline: Don't Get in Bed With Assad
text: Beirut — One might think that America’s policy toward Syria couldn’t get any worse, but the rise of extremists there is generating dangerous thinking in Western capitals. High-level advisers and former officials have recently started to talk about Bashar al-Assad as a lesser evil than whatever comes next; some even see him as a potential partner in fighting jihadi terrorists.

headline: The Weight of the Past
text: This column is about Edward Snowden. And the National Football League. And, I suspect, most of the rest of us.

headline: Japan’s ‘Proactive Pacifism’
text: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has approved a plan to strengthen the nation’s military.

headline: Nets, Built to Win Now, May Need to Cut Losses
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It may be futile when one is chased by a shark in deep water to question the decision to have gone swimming in the first place. But regret is a common human experience, and so it is fair to wonder if Billy King is feeling any as his master plan for winning an N.B.A. championship appears to have fractured like the fifth metatarsal in Brook Lopez’s right foot.

headline: Obama Says ‘Further Action’ Possible in South Sudan
text: HONOLULU — After an attack on three United States aircraft attempting to evacuate American citizens from South Sudan, President Obama sent a letter Sunday to top congressional leaders in which he said he might take “further action” to support United States citizens and interests in the contested region.

headline: Believe You Me
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — There is nothing better for my solving ego than a Monday Andrea Carla Michaels puzzle, and it’s not just because it’s Monday. It’s because she, along with her collaborator, Michael Blake, fills her puzzles with wonderful things that they and Will Shortz clue in such a way that my pencil never stops moving until the entire grid is filled. And when it’s done, I might not remember filling in all of the entries because it was just that smooth, but I know that I’ve had a good time. You really can’t ask for more than that on a Monday.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Dec. 23
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Monday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Dec. 23
text: INCOME AND SPENDING On Monday, the Commerce Department will announce the data on personal income and spending in November. Economists on Wall Street are looking for an increase of 0.5 percent for both figures, according to Bloomberg, but a stronger reading would allay fears of weak overall economic growth in the fourth quarter of 2013. Growth is expected to slow substantially from the robust 4.1 percent annual pace recorded in the third quarter, but recent data has been a bit more positive so experts will be watching to see if that continued in November with personal income and spending.

headline: Our Teaching Methods, and Theirs

text: CINCINNATI — It has been a long time since a streetcar was just a streetcar here.
