text: If ever there was an uncrowned king who commanded more respect and reverence than any ruler, hereditary or democratic, it was Sri Uthradom Thirunal Marthanda Varma of Travancore, a princely state in British India, now part of the state of Kerala. Adulation and admiration for him were evident for many years, but the outpouring of grief in Kerala over his demise at the age of 91 on Dec. 16 was exceptional in terms of the number of mourners and the sense of loss expressed.

headline: NASA Astronauts Make Christmas Eve Spacewalk to Repair International Space Station
text: Updated, 2:16 p.m. On a Christmas Eve spacewalk, two astronauts successfully made the necessary repairs to a malfunctioning pump module outside the International Space Station after starting the job over the weekend.

headline: A Lot Changes in Tech Over Four Years and 1,000 Blog Posts
text: This is my 1,000th blog post on Bits. I know this because our publishing system keeps track of these things.

headline: Behind the Headline Numbers of a Mortgage Settlement
text: Corporate America has long known the public relations power of putting a big dollar number on a deal.

headline: In Performance: ‘It’s a Wonderful Life’
text: This week’s video features Howard McGillin and Haley Bond in a scene from the Irish Repertory Theater’s production of “It’s a Wonderful Life: The 1946 Live Radio Play,” a stage adaptation of Frank Capra’s classic holiday film. Six actors play 25 characters in the show, which takes place in a 1940s radio station and features live sound effects, some of which are recreated in the video. The production, directed by Charlotte Moore, continues through Dec. 29.

headline: Getting Guns Right
text: Our recent multimedia presentation offered some in-depth and nuanced stories about people’s relationships with guns. Unfortunately, a small error in the front-page print summary led to the following correction:

headline: Game Theory: Surprises and Challenges for Video Games in 2013
text: As 2013 winds down, we’re starting another edition of Game Theory, a look at the year in video games with the regular gaming critics for The New York Times and other contributors. This was an odd year, one that feels like a prelude to some grand changes.

headline: Arctic Blast in Manhattan
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Futuristic Mac Pro Has Power to Spare
text: For the moment, I am living the life of a tech one-percenter.

headline: Deployed Before Christmas
text: As my husband and I have prepared for Christmas this year — picking up last-minute gifts, trying our hand at eggnog recipes, sharing wine late into the night — memories of last year’s season have been returning to me, clear and stark.

headline: NASA’s Christmas Eve ‘Earthrise,’ Revisited and Revisualized
text: Andrew Chaikin, a historian of the Apollo space program, alerted me yesterday to a new NASA visualization of the moment, 45 years ago today, when the Apollo 8 astronauts, amid pre-planned operations, suddenly noticed the Earth “rising” over the lunar horizon. [On this Christmas Eve, two astronauts on the International Space Station are in the midst of a “spacewalk” (there has to be a better term) to repair cooling equipment. Live video is here.]

headline: Political Fight in South Sudan Targets Civilians
text: JUBA, South Sudan — The security forces went house to house, rounding up civilians by the dozens and binding the wrists of some with wire, survivors said. Some were summarily shot in the street, they said, while others were hauled off to crowded cells. Bodies of the executed were tossed into shallow graves, one recalled. Another jail where civilians had been taken reeked of death, a witness said.

headline: A Season for Resolution: Approaching an I.V.F. Deadline
text: I usually adore the holiday season.

headline: A Hot Duet for Those Cold Nights
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Report Faults Increase in China’s Local Government Debt
text: SHANGHAI — China’s local government debt has reached an “alarming level” and poses a significant risk to the country’s fast-growing economy, according to a Chinese government think tank.

headline: 1963: Brittany Cows Get Hush Hay
text: PARIS — Christmas gives cattle in Brittany a unique opportunity to assert authority over their masters.

headline: Stories Add Up as Bully Image Trails Christie
text: In 2010, John F. McKeon, a New Jersey assemblyman, made what he thought was a mild comment on a radio program: Some of the public employees that Gov. Chris Christie was then vilifying had been some of the governor’s biggest supporters.

headline: Edwin A. Shuman III, Former Prisoner of War Who Defied Hanoi Hilton Guards, Dies at 82
text: As Christmas 1970 approached, 43 American prisoners of war in a large holding cell at the North Vietnamese camp known as the Hanoi Hilton sought to hold a brief church service. Their guards stopped them, and so the seeds of rebellion were planted.

headline: Image of the Day: December 24
text: Indian army officials at the Wagah border post after returning from Pakistan.

headline: The Plight of the Employed
text: Mike Konczal writes about how Washington has lost interest in the unemployed, and what a scandal that is. He also, however, makes an important point that I suspect plays a significant role in the political economy of this scandal: these are lousy times for the employed, too.

headline: Killing and Retaliation at Gaza-Israel Border Continue Violent Cycle
text: JERUSALEM — An Israeli laborer who was repairing the security fence along the border with Gaza was fatally shot on Tuesday by a Palestinian sniper, according to the Israeli military, and Israel immediately responded with airstrikes and tank and infantry fire against targets it associated with militant groups in the Palestinian coastal territory.

headline: Walkabout: Shrinking Plane Seats Pinch a Nerve; Fleeting Landscapes for the Thrill-Seeker
text: Airlines are shrinking the size of their seats, raising revenue, butalso tensions among frustrated passengers. (The New York Times)

headline: What Are We Meant to Get Out of Movies Based on Short Stories and Novels?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Zoë Heller discuss the year’s literary film adaptations and what we’re meant to get out of movies based on books.

headline: A Holiday Scene on the Subway
text: Christmas shoppers in New York find a way to navigate the subway system with their arms full of packages.

headline: Yorkshire Pudding, Once for Nine, Now for Four
text: This Christmas the Yorkshire pudding will be smaller than usual. For the last 20 years, Christmas Eve has meant a holiday feast at our dear friends Linda and Dick’s home across the street. Their two boys and our three children grew up as close as siblings, sharing backyard and basement adventures from preschool through high school. Linda and Dick’s family celebrates both Christmas and Hanukkah; our family celebrates Hanukkah. But on Christmas Eve, all the action was across the street.

headline: An Annual Test for Those Bearing Gifts: Dashing Through the Subway
text: There is no Christmas hymn for the man who heaves a hulking toaster oven over the subway turnstile, no ode to the traveler who dares to wedge a 40-inch television onto the Lexington Avenue line.

headline: Eating Nuts in Pregnancy Tied to Lower Allergy Risk in Offspring
text: A new study suggests that mothers who eat nuts during pregnancy can eat them without fear of causing nut allergies in their babies.

headline: Coaching Carousel May Leave Heads Spinning
text: Last season, seven N.F.L. coaches were fired on the day after the regular season ended, also known as Black Monday, with Jacksonville dismissing Mike Mularkey a couple of weeks later. This season, Houston has already dismissed Gary Kubiak, and as many as 10 more coaches could be fired Monday.

headline: Old Resentments Come Up Swinging
text: Old jocks never die; they just team up. One veteran action hero may not be able to open a movie nowadays, but put two or more shoulder to shoulder in the same film, as in the “Expendables” series, and there’s gold to be mined and a senior male fan base to be activated. That’s the shrewd marketing philosophy behind “Grudge Match,” the overlong, drab, not-so-funny sports comedy that teams Sylvester Stallone and Robert De Niro as onetime boxing champions in an unlikely rematch 30 years after their last bout. Rocky versus the Raging Bull; how about that for a tagline?

headline: New York Man Holds Largest Collection of Video Games, Guinness Says
text: Video game fanatics who find a copy of the new “Guinness World Records 2014 Gamer’s Edition” under their trees will discover that Richard Lecce, the king of collectors, first listed in the 2010 edition, has been deposed. The new Guinness-certified owner of the world’s largest video game collection is Michael Thomasson, a game designer and professor at Canisius College, in Buffalo. (Mr. Thomasson’s subjects are video game history, graphics and game design.)

headline: Amnesty by Russians Includes Greenpeace Case
text: MOSCOW — A sweeping amnesty that is underway in Russia was extended on Tuesday to a member of the crew of the Arctic Sunrise, the Greenpeace International ship seized on the open seas three months ago.

headline: BEST OF 2013
text: These 15 stories showcased boldness, simplicity and independence in women’s dressing.

headline: Filling in the Outlines of a Dickens Character, This One Real
text: A brooding, enigmatic beauty strides across a beach in Margate, England, during the opening moments of “The Invisible Woman.” The year is 1885. In a nearby school, a group of boys, rehearsing a play by Wilkie Collins (Tom Hollander) and his friend Charles Dickens (Ralph Fiennes), awaits her return. We soon learn that the distraught woman, Nelly (Felicity Jones), is married to the school’s headmaster, George Wharton Robinson (Tom Burke). As the film’s production notes put it, “For Nelly, the rehearsals are igniting memories of a lost life, one that is still haunting her.”

headline: Exploring Anti-Semitism in Hungary
text: The Times will be taking a deep look at anti-Semitism in Hungary this coming year. As we report on this issue, we hope to hear from Hungarian Jews on their experiences.

headline: Times Minute | Health Care Deadline
text: Also on the Minute, an examination of Valley Girl Speak and a performance of a scene from "It's a Wonderful Life: The 1946 Live Radio Play."

headline: Best of 2013 | The Year in Women’s Fashion
text: These 15 stories showcased boldness, simplicity and independence in women’s dressing. Read…

headline: Times Minute | Health Care Deadline
text: In the Video

headline: De Blasio’s Daughter Reveals Substance Abuse
text: Days before her father’s inauguration, the 19-year-old daughter of Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio disclosed a history of drug and alcohol abuse that his campaign had taken pains to shield throughout a candidacy that relied heavily on the image of a happy and tight-knit family from Brooklyn.

headline: Housing Recovery May Be Running Out of Steam
text: The housing recovery in the United States could run out of steam in 2014. Banks are likely to tighten lending standards once new rules come into place. Rising interest rates may drive down home loan volume, too. Cash purchases by investors could set a floor for house prices, but they may not be enough to prevent a major slowdown.

headline: Seals of Approval for Home Health Care Providers
text: FINDING someone to care for an ill or aged relative at home can be challenging. Sorting through the options can be time-consuming, and the need to find help may arise during a crisis, when decisions must be made quickly.

headline: Wheelies: The Lightweight Heavy Duty Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: American Express to Pay $75 Million Over Credit-Card Practices
text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has ordered American Express to pay more than $75 million to settle claims that it charged improper fees and misled its credit card customers over so-called add-on products like identity fraud protection.

headline: Change Comes Slowly for Bulgaria, Even With E.U. Membership
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — As Ukrainian protesters camp out in their capital to demand closer ties to Europe, Boris Rangelov, a student protest leader in Bulgaria, has a sobering message from the cold capital of his country, another former Communist nation but one that, unlike Ukraine, joined the European Union years ago: Change takes a long time.

headline: In South Sudan, Reports of Massacres and Mass Graves
text: In a video report from Bentiu, in South Sudan, published on Tuesday, a United Nations official described how civilians have been fleeing the violence and taking refuge at the body’s mission there. It showed civilians gathering belongings, forming long queues to receive assistance and being treated for wounds.

headline: Time Warner Cable, Bruised After Its Battle With CBS, Extends Viacom Deal
text: SpongeBob SquarePants will continue to bubble into homes on Time Warner Cable uninterrupted into the new year.

headline: Sphinx Awards Highlight Promise Among Young Musicians
text: The Sphinx Organization, a national training program devoted to getting black and Hispanic students involved in classical music performance, announced the winners of its 2014 artist scholarships on Tuesday. The awards, for musicians in the early stages of their careers who demonstrate, as Sphinx puts it, “artistic excellence, outstanding work ethic, a spirit of determination and great potential for leadership,” include a $50,000 career-development scholarship and the organization’s Medal of Excellence.

headline: Streisand Sees ‘I’ll Eat You Last’ at Last
text: It was the question that loomed over Broadway last spring: Would Barbra Streisand attend a performance of “I’ll Eat You Last,” the one-woman play starring Bette Midler as the real-life Hollywood agent Sue Mengers, whose falling-out with Ms. Streisand is the juicy meat of the show? Ms. Streisand never went, but her publicist confirmed this week that the actress and director did see “I’ll Eat You Last” during its run this month at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles.

headline: He Can Balance a Checkbook, but Not His Imagination
text: As imagined by Ben Stiller, Walter Mitty is a man out of step with his time. An archetypal daydreamer introduced to the public by James Thurber as a henpecked suburban husband and later impersonated on screen by Danny Kaye as a misunderstood, starry-eyed sweetheart with a lovely singing voice, Walter has evolved into a modern office drone with an unusually active fantasy life. He is also, in some respects, the opposite of just about every other comic hero in American movies today, including many played by Mr. Stiller. And “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty,” directed by Mr. Stiller (who takes the title role), has a dreamy, melancholy tone quite different from what you might expect to find in a big-budget holiday comedy.

headline: 13 Solutions for Fighting Crazy Ants
text: Almost as lively as Jon Mooallem’s recent story about crazy ants — who are so relentless they even swarm inside electronics, killing appliances and themselves — were the comments that followed that article. Readers offered their own creative methods for stemming the insect invasion:

headline: Is the Internet a Mob Without Consequence?
text: The immediacy and fast pace of the Internet can be magical. But when someone makes a comment that the masses disagree with, a mob with 140-character pitchforks can develop in seconds and the Internet can become terrifyingly bellicose.

headline: In Lyon, Artists and Designers Light Up the City
text: Lyon, France’s third-largest city, was made for Christmas.

headline: Ice Storms Leave Hundreds of Thousands in the Dark
text: Hundreds of thousands of people from Michigan to Maine were expected to be in the dark on Christmas even as electrical crews raced Tuesday to restore power to homes after a weekend ice storm caused widespread blackouts.

headline: Chimes Stop at Manhattan Church, but Neighbors Are Wary
text: A Manhattan Roman Catholic church whose bells have riled its neighbors this holiday season now seems to be ringing in Christmas with silence.

headline: Maoists to Join Nepal Assembly After Ensuring Election Inquiry
text: NEW DELHI — Nepal’s main Maoist party agreed on Tuesday to join the Constituent Assembly and participate in writing the final chapters of the country’s constitution, ending more than a month of uncertainty.

headline: An Old Flame Shows Up, but Who Invited the Witch and Monsters?
text: Between the prospect of Hollywood’s sexing up a legendary Japanese story with rampaging C.G.I. monsters and the eager reports of a protracted production, there has been ample opportunity to hobble “47 Ronin” long before its warriors finally emerge in theaters. But say what you will about this fantasy adventure, set in “a land shrouded in mystery” (per the opening voice-over), it’s still a studio movie adaptation of a story that ends — centuries-old spoiler! — with mass ritual suicide. Credit due for that bit of faithfulness, I suppose — and Merry Christmas, by the way.

headline: An Animated Tribute to Andre Cassagnes
text: The creator of the Etch A Sketch gets his own treatment.

headline: Bettman Upholds Thornton’s Long Suspension
text: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman rejected an N.H.L. Players’ Association appeal of Bruins forward Shawn Thornton’s 15-game suspension Tuesday, calling Thornton’s Dec. 7 attack on Penguins defenseman Brooks Orpik both intentional and dangerous.

headline: Musharraf’s Treason Trial Is Postponed
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The scheduled opening on Tuesday of treason proceedings against the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf was put off until the new year after bomb materials and handguns were found along his route to the trial, officials said.

headline: One Media Player to Rule Them All
text: Real estate is an expensive commodity in New York City.

headline: A Video Chat App Called Spin Invites a Party
text: Not everyone can be home for the holidays, and although technology offers a solution, video conferencing seems a little sterile between family and friends. But a free iOS app, Spin, offers a kind of video conferencing that is less formal, simple and more fun. It’s like a souped-up version of Apple’s FaceTime.

headline: Yusef Lateef, Innovative Jazz Saxophonist and Flutist, Dies at 93
text: Yusef Lateef, a jazz saxophonist and flutist who spent his career crossing musical boundaries, died on Monday at his home in Shutesbury, Mass., near Amherst. He was 93.

headline: When Greed Was Good (and Fun)
text: Future archaeologists, digging through the digital and physical rubble of our long-gone civilization in search of reasons for its collapse, will be greatly helped if they unearth a file containing “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Martin Scorsese’s three-hour bacchanal of sex, drugs and conspicuous consumption. Then as now, the movie is likely to be the subject of intense scholarly debate: Does it offer a sustained and compelling diagnosis of the terminal pathology that afflicts us, or is it an especially florid symptom of the disease?

headline: Genius or Insanity?
text: “Here’s to the crazy ones — the misfits, the rebels, the troublemakers, the round pegs in the square holes. The ones who see things differently — they’re not fond of rules, and they have no respect for the status quo. …” — Steve Jobs

headline: Planning a Trip: Guidebook Versus the Web
text: I recently asked my friend Doug if he still uses guidebooks to plan his trips abroad. He’s a smart guy and a veteran traveler, so I figured he would have a thoughtful reason one way or the other. He did not.

headline: Cracker Barrel’s Top Investor Considers Bid for Company
text: Cracker Barrel’s largest shareholder urged its board on Tuesday to consider selling the company — to him.

headline: Big Data Becomes a Mirror
text: Why do English speakers say “drove” rather than “drived”?

headline: Q. and A.: Detective Novelist Qiu Xiaolong on Chinese Corruption
text: Qiu Xiaolong, the detective novelist and poet, was in the middle of a talk in Beijing about his latest Inspector Chen novel, when a member of the audience jumped in with a question: Did Mr. Qiu think there were many undiscovered corpses in China these days as a result of crime and official corruption?

headline: Sign-Up Period Extended Again for Health Plan
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Tuesday that it would provide more time for people to complete their applications for health insurance if they could show that they missed the deadline because of problems with the federal health care website.

headline: Ahem, Ummm, Well ...
text: Public speaking can give you the willies. Even the most seasoned speakers worry that they will be exposed as frauds, or purvey all the narrative excitement of televised fishing. They worry that they will have to refer by name to Turkmenistan’s president, Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedow.

headline: Poised to Marry a Prince? She Will Not Be Spared
text: Any potential royal bride running the feverish gantlet of the British tabloids must prepare to have her name mangled. Diana, soon to be the princess of Wales, became “Shy Di,” and Kate Middleton, now duchess of Cambridge, was transformed into “Waity Katie” because of the long time she dated Prince William before they were engaged.

headline: Rethinking How to Split the Costs of Carbon
text: It is probably a safe bet that very few Americans unwrapping a brand-new iPhone left under their Christmas tree are thinking about its impact on the global climate.

headline: Ever True to You, Dear BlackBerry
text: Just last year, Beyoncé Knowles was photographed holding the BlackBerry Bold P’9981, a model designed by Porsche that sold for more than $2,000.

headline: From ‘Wolf’ to Sheepish Clothing
text: In Martin Scorsese’s new film, “The Wolf of Wall Street,” it is not hard to tell when Jordan Belfort, the high-finance hustler of the 1990s, played by Leonardo DiCaprio, has officially made it on Wall Street: His suits go from billowy, double-breasted, off-the-rack numbers to lordly pinstripes, complete with a chunky gold Rolex watch, Gucci loafers and a giant red silk tie.

headline: Long Forgotten: A Last-Place Finish, and Razors
text: By the time the Boston Red Sox had defeated the St. Louis Cardinals in the 2013 World Series to win their third title in 10 years, most of the team resembled the cast of “Duck Dynasty” — had the reality TV stars decided to really let themselves go.

headline: 3 Surprises: Daring Play, Thrilling Win and Wedding
text: About 10 minutes remained in the N.C.A.A. women’s regional semifinal between Louisville and Baylor in March. Baylor was the defending national champion. Brittney Griner, its 6-foot-8 center, had blocked more shots in her career than any male or female player in college basketball history.

headline: Detroit Wins $55 Million in Concessions From 2 Banks
text: The struggling city of Detroit said on Tuesday that it had won rare concessions, worth $55 million, from two large banks that sold it a type of financial contract that normally cannot be reduced, even in bankruptcy.

headline: Rare Arias on a Lean Budget
text: The idea might sound familiar: An opera company leaves its home for an itinerant life performing a handful of new or rare operas each year at venues across New York.

headline: A U.S. Comeback Lifts a Yacht Club
text: Norbert Bajurin, owner of a San Francisco radiator shop and commodore of the Golden Gate Yacht Club, was exhausted. It was July. The club was empty. Out the windows, a pair of catamarans, their sails stretching 13 stories tall and their hulls lifted above the water by engineering audacity, slid across San Francisco Bay, practicing for the America’s Cup.

headline: House Hunting on Sardinia
text: The Italian market has been flat since the start of 2012, but Sardinia presents a contrast, with wealthy buyers competing for seafront properties.

headline: House Hunting on ... Sardinia
text: €3 MILLION ($4.1 MILLION)

headline: Toad, Mole and Badger Leap to a Bigger Stage
text: LONDON — “Let my creatures live again,” says the narrator at the start of Will Tuckett’s stage adaptation of “The Wind in the Willows,” the children’s book by Kenneth Grahame that has been beloved here almost since it was first published in 1908. The characters do live in Mr. Tuckett’s version, the first Royal Opera House production to transfer into a commercial theater in the West End of London, opening last week and running through Feb. 1.

headline: Soldiers Fighting, but Coping Most of All
text: You can tell from the title that “Lone Survivor” is not messing around. Spoiler sensitivity is for sissies and dilettantes: Real men face the inevitable with stoical resolve. So when the movie sends four guys on a dangerous mission, you can be reasonably certain that only one of them is coming back, and you already know (as soon as the credits are over) that it will be the one played by Mark Wahlberg.

headline: The Year in Questions
text: Oh, the news out there is frightful. But a quiz is so delightful.

headline: Giving Voice to Early Mahler
text: Setting a benchmark for “beauty” in a voice, as in anything, is naturally a highly subjective endeavor. A sound one listener may consider distinctive may prove grating to another. Even some of the most beloved singers, like Maria Callas, had their detractors.

headline: Daredevil on a Snowmobile
text: This Op-Doc celebrates the achievements of Caleb Moore, a competitive snowmobiler who was the first to fatally crash at the X Games.

headline: Fit for a First Lady
text: “I LOVE MY DESIGNS,” Anni Kuan said the other day, her exuberance as unforced as her curve-grazing dresses, cocoon coats and boot-cut pants that lend a touch of raciness to her otherwise low-key designs.

headline: ‘Daredevil on a Snowmobile’
text: This Op-Doc celebrates the achievements of Caleb Moore, a competitive snowmobiler who was the first athlete to fatally crash at the X Games.

headline: Does Anchovy Gelato Go With White Wine?
text: Artichoke gelato, tomato-basil sorbet, carrot granita. The list may seem more suited to a creative restaurant menu than a gelateria. But Rome’s top artisanal producers have turned to savory flavors to gain an edge in a city where thousands of gelato shops compete for customers. And with the country in the economic doldrums, their unconventional flavors are reaching more gelato fans than ever, as plummeting commercial rents have allowed even more gelaterias to open or to expand existing brands.

headline: At Dover Street Market, Differences of Opinion
text: At the newly opened Dover Street Market New York on 30th Street and Lexington Avenue, walls are covered with polka dots and shoes are sprinkled in glitter. There are seven small floors, stacked on top of one another like a treehouse, reached by a clear glass elevator that slowly moves through the center of the store.

headline: Is a Home Bar in My Living Room an Asset or Liability?
text: Q. I have a home bar at one end of my living room. Is this an asset or liability for selling?

headline: Sales at Room & Board, John Robshaw and Others
text: Room & Board is discounting some sofas, tables, storage pieces, rugs and decorative accessories up to 50 percent (the Soren lounge chair in maple with ebony stain, originally $649, is about $500); 105 Wooster Street (Prince Street), 212-334-4343, roomandboard.com.

headline: In Spacewalk, Astronauts Complete Repairs to Station
text: NASA astronauts on Tuesday completed urgent repairs to the cooling system of the International Space Station that should return it to normal operation within a few days.

headline: Say ‘Cheese’
text: A restaurateur has taught himself to raise livestock and make dairy products on an island near Seattle.

headline: A Table-to-Farm Pioneer
text: In the 22 years since Kurt Timmermeister bought four acres of rocky, suspect farmland here for $100,000, he has had his ribs broken by an amorous female cow, lost a lamb to a crow that pecked its eyes out, and recoiled from the cannibalism of his chickens (when they weren’t eating one another, they were picked off by raccoons), among other blood- and mud-flecked dramas.

headline: ‘Interactive’ Gets a New Meaning
text: It may be the most memorable sex scene of the season.

headline: Rodolfo Hernandez, 82, Dies; Awarded Medal of Honor
text: Rodolfo Hernandez, who received the Medal of Honor for rushing into heavy fire while wounded and armed with only an inoperable rifle and bayonet and then killing six enemy soldiers during the Korean War, died on Saturday in Fayetteville, N.C. He was 82.

headline: A Table That Changes Gears
text: It took 10 years, but the London designer Christopher Duffy thinks he finally got his MK1 Transforming Table right.

headline: A Mystery Menagerie
text: Kerman rugs, which originated in 15th-century Persia, feature dense floral patterns and sometimes intricate reproductions of painted masterworks. Modernists consider them old-fashioned. But Martí Guixé, the unconventional Spaniard best known for designing inventive eating accessories and environments, has bent the genre for Nanimarquina. His Ghost carpet of hand-knotted wool features birds, flowers, horses and deer that fade in and out of the tapestry. Mr. Guixé said that he worked slowly over three months, translating his mood changes into graphic irregularities that give the pattern a touch of mystery.

headline: Remembering a Voice for the Region
text: One day during Edward I. Koch’s third term, when allegations of corruption were swirling around mayoral allies like Donald R. Manes, the Queens borough president, the radio reporter Stan Brooks stopped Mr. Koch at City Hall. Mr. Brooks, as always, had his microphone in his hand and his tape recorder running.

headline: Skin Deep: 1970s Party Hair
text: Follow these easy steps to recreate a 1970s look for festive occasions.

headline: Nails That Dazzle for New Year’s
text: In keeping with the disco spirit for New Year’s, bedazzling your nails is cheaper and probably more flattering than a Lurex pantsuit.

headline: Health Plans and the Middle Class
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Sheriffs Ignore Gun Laws They Don’t Like
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Christmas Eve
text: A saxophone player’s carols and a pageant at Grace Church.

headline: A Better Way to Teach
text: To the Editor:

headline: For an Elegant Thank-You Note, Paper to Match
text: Just in time to furnish the materials for holiday thank-you notes, Thornwillow Press has opened an in-store boutique among the purveyors of luxury crafts at Atelier Courbet in Little Italy.

headline: The Duck March
text: In a daily Memphis tradition, ducks march through the lobby of the Peabody Hotel.

headline: Clemency on Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cellphones in Flight?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Buy 200: They’re Small
text: A couple’s Los Angeles bungalow is packed with curiosities, but it has nothing on their bunker.

headline: Always Room for One More
text: LOS ANGELES — Twenty-seven years ago, Bob Breen and Clare Graham began living together in an Arts and Crafts bungalow in the Los Feliz neighborhood here, furnishing it by zealously shopping the flea markets and swap meets of Southern California for vintage décor. That same year, 1986, they also bought an old supermarket in a sketchy part of the city cut off by freeways.

headline: His Refuge from the Digital Din
text: Brian Faherty is the founder of Schoolhouse Electric and Supply, a home décor company with stores in New York and Portland, Ore., and a robust e-commerce site, but he hasn’t adapted easily to the digital world. Nor has he figured out how to resist his smartphone.

headline: Skin Deep: 1970s Party Makeup
text: Follow these easy steps to recreate a glamorous 1970s look at home.

headline: For One Night, a Trip Back in Time
text: For New Year’s Eve inspiration this year, one might look to Amy Adams’s glamorous ’70s makeover on “American Hustle” (the beauty equivalent of the plunging sequined minidress). Herein, the film’s hair and makeup experts, along with Gina Brooke, Madonna’s makeup artist, and Michael Angelo, a favorite hairstylist of New York social swans, tell how to get the look you want to know better.

headline: For Punch or Porridge
text: Although this is the season of festive drinks, Josh Vogel did not have anything like champagne punch in mind when he designed a ladle. He imagined it dispensing more pedestrian nourishment, like oatmeal. “But if the spirit moves,” he said, “why not eggnog, too?”

headline: The Syrian Electronic Army Is at It Again
text: It’s a happy hacker holiday once again.

headline: It’s the Most Unknowable Time of the Year
text: ONE of my first childhood memories: New Year’s Eve, Leningrad, 1976. The doorbell rings, my mother opens it, and a bear walks in on his hind legs. Four-year-old me starts trembling. Bear! Bear! Soon I will be eaten. No, my mother tells me: “It’s Grandfather Frost,” the secular, socialist-friendly Russian equivalent of Santa Claus, with New Year’s standing in for Christmas. And it’s true. On top of his shabby gray-white fur that makes him so uniquely ursine, the bear sports a red hat and a flowing white beard made of cotton balls.

headline: Ruggedly Handsome Lamps
text: An advocate of a laid-back California style, the interior designer Trip Haenisch, 51, works hard to create rooms that don’t appear precious. He wants people “to feel like they can just jump on a sofa and put their feet up, or move furniture around,” he said, even if those people are celebrities. (Courteney Cox and Hank Azaria are among his clients.)

headline: Fit for a Queen of Historic Preservation
text: Neither leukemia nor a daunting number of new constructions kept the author of “A Field Guide to American Houses” from extending her life’s work.

headline: Virginia Savage McAlester: Leading the Ultimate House Tour
text: Dallas — If Virginia Savage McAlester were going to die of leukemia, the right time would have been before she ordered a new Texas historical marker for her house. Space on the plaque was at a premium: The 6,000-square-foot home has been in the family since 1921, and her patrician forebears have played an influential role in the city for most of those years.

headline: Free Facebook, Common Globally, Finally Comes to American Mobile Phones
text: For years, Facebook has been cutting deals with telecom carriers in developing countries like India and the Philippines to offer free Facebook access to cellphone customers using simple phones with no data plans.

headline: When a Politician’s Child Goes Astray
text: Politicians strive to control the message. Teenagers and young adults are not known for their ability to stay on script.

headline: Wyoming May Act to Plug Abandoned Wells as Natural Gas Boom Ends
text: DENVER — Hundreds of abandoned drilling wells dot eastern Wyoming like sagebrush, vestiges of a natural gas boom that has been drying up in recent years as prices have plummeted.

headline: In Germany’s Rust Belt, a Polished but Ailing City
text: OBERHAUSEN, Germany — What is it like to be “Germany’s Detroit,” as the news media here has crowned Oberhausen, which for the second year running has received the dubious distinction of being the German city with the highest per capita debt?

headline: Alabama Prosecutor Asking Again for Tougher Rape Sentence
text: ATLANTA — An Alabama prosecutor is, for a second time, trying to persuade a judge to impose a tougher sentence on a rapist to whom he gave no prison time.

headline: Shadow Carbon Footprints
text: In addition to the carbon dioxide produced inside their borders, countries also add to their emissions tally by consuming goods made elsewhere.

headline: Postal Service Raises Price Again but Says It’s Not Forever
text: The cost of first-class postage stamps is going up by 3 cents — but only until the Postal Service makes up losses that it has estimated it accumulated during the recession. The increase — to 49 cents from 46 cents — will go into effect on Jan. 26.

headline: Brazil: Floods and Landslides Kill 30
text: Heavy rains in Espírito Santo and Minas Gerais, two states in southeastern Brazil, have left at least 30 people dead and forced about 50,000 people from their homes, civil defense authorities said Tuesday. Dozens of cities in both states declared states of emergency after some victims died in landslides and flash floods. President Dilma Rousseff flew to Vitória, the capital of Espírito Santo, where she announced that more than $260 million in public funds would be channeled to disaster relief efforts. Brazil’s army was also being mobilized to repair bridges in affected areas, officials said. Meteorologists in Espírito Santo said that parts of the state were struggling with the heaviest rains in 90 years.

headline: Who Is Selling Target’s Data?
text: We may be one step closer to knowing who was behind the security breach at Target that compromised 40 million customer records.

headline: Father and Son Share a Passion for Sailing
text: NEWPORT, R.I. — Listen to Rome Kirby, and it was clear by age 10 that he wanted to follow in the wide wake of his father, Jerry, and sail in the America’s Cup and the Volvo Ocean Race. Listen to his parents, and it was clear quite a bit earlier than that.

headline: Banks’ Suit Tests Limits of Resisting Volcker Rule
text: The banks have fired their first salvo in what could soon turn into a war of litigation over the Volcker Rule.

headline: When I’m Sixty-Four
text: LONDON — It does not seem that long ago that the Beatles could plausibly portray geriatric redundancy as beginning at an age sometimes referred to as young these days. “Will you still need me,” they asked, “Will you still feed me, when I’m sixty-four?”

headline: This Day of Good Cheer
text: This is not the shortest or the darkest or the quietest or even the holiest day of the year. But it is the most joyous and the most richly seasonal. Around Christmas Day orbit the lesser holidays that help account for the texture of this season: days of shopping and decorating, the days of Advent and Christmas Eve, the liturgical 12 days that end in Twelfth Night, better known to most of us as Jan. 5.

headline: Marv Wolfenson, 87, Dies; Led an N.B.A. Rebirth in Minnesota
text: Marv Wolfenson, who with his longtime business partner, Harvey Ratner, brought N.B.A. basketball back to Minnesota in the form of the Timberwolves, died on Saturday in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 87.

headline: The Global Cancer Burden
text: Cancer is on the rise around the world and poses a particular threat in many low- and middle-income countries. Death tolls globally far exceed those from such devastating infectious diseases like AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. According to recent reports from international health agencies, global mortality from those three diseases has, in fact, been cut substantially — by nearly half in the case of malaria — over the past decade.

headline: Companies, Shifting Production, Expand to Accommodate Robots
text: Even a robot needs a home.

headline: France’s Operation Butterfly
text: Operation Sangaris, the French intervention in the Central African Republic that began in early December, was pitched to the public and to the United Nations by President François Hollande’s government as a humanitarian intervention necessary to prevent genocide.

headline: Handling Life’s Surprises With His Father’s Spirit
text: Wesley Booker exudes an air of tranquil confidence. But his laid-back manner reflects a staunch assuredness, not nonchalance.

headline: BlackBerry Co-Founder Cuts Stake
text: OTTAWA — Mike Lazaridis, a founder and former executive at BlackBerry, took advantage of a rare rise in its share price to cut his stake in the company.

headline: Another City by the Bay Comes Into Its Own
text: Long considered San Francisco’s little brother — or maybe its punk cousin — Oakland has struggled with negative perceptions wrought by crime, protests and a mediocre football team.

headline: Hotel Ducks Gone Wild May End Up in Hunters’ Sights
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — The flooded prairies and backwaters along the Arkansas River are a dangerous place during hunting season for even the toughest of ducks.

headline: Start-Up Uses Plant Seeds for a Biofuel
text: SAN DIEGO — In an unmarked greenhouse, leafy bushes carpet an acre of land here tucked into the suburban sprawl of Southern California. The seeds of the inedible, drought-resistant plants, called jatropha, produce a prize: high-quality oil that can be refined into low-carbon jet fuel or diesel fuel.

headline: Queensboro Bridge Lane to Be Closed Every Night
text: Cars have slammed into a beauty salon and shattered the windows of a Caribbean restaurant over the years, each after failing to navigate a turn at the base of the Queensboro Bridge where it unspools into Long Island City, Queens.

headline: More Hunger for the Poorest Americans
text: This is a harsh season for Americans struggling to afford food. Last month, the long lines at food pantries across the country grew longer with the expiration of the boost to food stamp benefit levels included in the 2009 economic stimulus plan. Those lines are apt to grow even longer thanks to the refusal of House Republicans to renew extended unemployment benefits as part of the recent budget deal.

headline: Indiana Finds It’s Not So Easy to Buck Gay Marriage Trend
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Dominated by Republicans and steeped in traditional values, Indiana seemed among the least likely places to become a battleground in the nation’s debate over same-sex marriage when the legislature overwhelmingly chose in 2011 to push forward a state constitutional amendment barring gay couples from marrying.

headline: Spitzer and His Wife Say Their Marriage Is Over
text: Eliot Spitzer, the former governor of New York, and his wife, Silda Wall Spitzer, are set to divorce after 26 years of marriage, the couple said Tuesday night.

headline: Knicks’ Vicious Run of Injuries Is Exacting a Toll on Anthony
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Carmelo Anthony was the last player to leave the locker room after Monday’s game here against the Magic, and he was dressed for the trip back to New York: slim-fitting slacks, blue sweater, pageboy cap. As far as these things go, he looked composed.

headline: Michael R. Stoler
text: Mr. Stoler, 66, is a managing director of Madison Realty Capital, a private equity fund specializing in commercial debt. He is also the president of New York Real Estate TV, where he has produced and hosted several shows, among them “The Stoler Report-New York’s Business Report.”

headline: As New Services Track Habits, the E-Books Are Reading You
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Before the Internet, books were written — and published — blindly, hopefully. Sometimes they sold, usually they did not, but no one had a clue what readers did when they opened them up. Did they skip or skim? Slow down or speed up when the end was in sight? Linger over the sex scenes?

headline: Appeals Court Refuses to Halt Same-Sex Marriages in Utah
text: DENVER — A federal appeals court cleared the way on Tuesday for same-sex marriages to continue across Utah, denying an emergency request from state officials to halt a flood of unions that began after a lower-court judge declared the state’s ban on same-sex marriage to be unconstitutional.

headline: A New Jolt to Filipino Siblings Orphaned by a Typhoon
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Identified as orphans by local officials after Typhoon Haiyan, five siblings ages 8 to 18 were suddenly taken from an evacuation center here, prompting an immediate search by municipal officials and Unicef representatives who feared that human traffickers had abducted them.

headline: Op-Art
text: An illustrator’s pragmatic take on holiday cheer.

headline: Freed Russian Applies for Swiss Visa Allowing Travel in 26 Nations
text: GENEVA — Four days after his release from a Russian prison and arrival in Germany, the former oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky has applied for a Swiss visa that would allow him travel to most of Europe, a spokesman for Switzerland’s Department of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 24, 2013
In Familiar Refrain, Prices Rose Again
text: A fanciful splurge over the holidays will cost more than ever this year, at least for those who take their gift cues from the popular holiday classic “The Twelve Days of Christmas.”

headline: For Female Ski Jumpers, Agony of Exclusion Finally Ends
text: Jessica Jerome was in second grade when she asked her parents if she could try ski jumping. Her father’s first thought? No way!

headline: Corrections: December 25, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: One Set of Gifts
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Merry Christmas to all those who celebrate! Will Shortz has a nice puzzle gift for you to unravel today.

headline: As Rematch Looms, Nets Are No Closer to Finding Themselves
text: The last time the Chicago Bulls were in Brooklyn, they sent the Nets tumbling out of the playoffs and into a period of soul-searching. The Nets were deemed too soft. There was no core, no spine. They would need to be retooled and rebranded.

headline: Bloomberg Becomes a Grandfather
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg became a grandfather on Christmas Eve when his daughter Georgina Bloomberg gave birth to his first grandchild.

headline: Returning to the Stage, at 55
text: A former Alvin Ailey superstar and a current artificial-hip owner, Elizabeth Roxas-Dobrish, returns to the stage to perform "Revelations," the company's best-known work.

headline: With Willing Spirit, a Reprise for Ailey Dancers
text: The voice on the phone belonged to Masazumi Chaya, the associate artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and he had a startling proposition. Would she — Elizabeth Roxas-Dobrish, 55 years old, former Ailey superstar and current artificial-hip owner — come out of retirement to dance at a special performance on New Year’s Eve?

headline: Westchester County Leader Weighs a Run for Governor
text: Although an early poll suggests his bid may be quixotic, Rob Astorino, fresh from an impressive re-election victory for county executive of Westchester, is mulling whether to seek the Republican nomination to challenge Andrew M. Cuomo for governor next year.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 25, 2013
text: “When you’re younger, you have everything — you have the flexibility, you have no fear. But you don’t savor every step, every movement of every fingertip, every beat of the music. I feel like I’m tasting food for the first time.”

headline: For Fitness, Intensity Matters
text: This year, exercise science expanded and fine-tuned our understanding of how physical activity affects our brains, joints, hearts, and even genes, beginning before birth and continuing throughout our lifespans, which can be lengthened, it seems, by exercise, especially if we pick up the pace.

headline: Welfare Benefits for Big Business
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Tanaka Mystery Now Has an Ending: In U.S.
text: Masahiro Tanaka, the pitching ace who went 24-0 in 2013 as he led the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles to a Japan Series title, will be allowed to sign with a major league team for the 2014 season, becoming the latest Japanese star to be allowed to leave for the United States before he became a free agent.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (BBC America) DOCTOR WHO Matt Smith, left, takes his final bow as the Doctor in this Christmas special, and it’s a doozy. He will face Cybermen, Daleks, Weeping Angels and the Silence, but his greatest challenge might be playing the part of “the boyfriend” for Clara (Jenna Coleman) at her family’s Christmas dinner. Peter Capaldi is also set to appear as the 12th incarnation of the Doctor.

headline: Rockets Fired by Taliban Hit U.S. Embassy in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A pair of rockets fired by the Taliban struck the United States Embassy in Kabul shortly before dawn on Wednesday, sending hundreds of American diplomats and aid workers based at the mission scrambling into fortified bunkers to start their Christmas Day, the embassy said.

headline: Answers to the Year in Questions
text: Compare your answers to the questions.

headline: Image of the Day: December 25
text: Christmas is a national holiday in India and celebrated throughout much of the country.

headline: Corruption Scandal Is Edging Near Turkish Premier
text: ISTANBUL — A corruption investigation that has encircled the Turkish government moved an ominous step closer to Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Wednesday, as three top ministers whose sons have been implicated abruptly resigned — and one of them, on his way out the door, said Mr. Erdogan should step down as well.

headline: Celebrating Christmas in China
text: When I was a little girl, I raised money for missionaries who were taking Bibles into China. As the daughter of a preacher, it was one of many similar projects I undertook, like going door to door to collect money for starving children in Africa and gathering wheelchairs and crutches to send to missionary doctors in South America.

headline: In Our Pages: December 26
text: 1888: Travels of a Post Card

headline: Personal Tragedy, Tricorders and the Idea of Mapping One’s Body
text: When Walter De Brouwer puts his head to something, he can produce single-handedly what usually takes several hospital machines and labs. His single hand, it should be said, holds a small and promising device with which Mr. De Brouwer, the co-founder and chief executive of Scanadu, hopes to remake medicine.

headline: Game Theory: The Year of the Indie
text: Increasingly this year, I’ve enjoyed games made by passionate coteries of video game artisans, so much so that for me this is the Year of the Indie. Not that independent games are new. The other day, cold and shivering, I arrived early at the Museum of the Moving Image’s “Indie Essentials” exhibition to take in 25 games quietly, meditatively. I was warmed, then moved, by this recent history of indies, spartanly staged in low light, each a gem of shining creativity.

headline: An Armenian Christmas Surprise
text: Dear Diary,

headline: Worshipers Are Targeted at a Christmas Service in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — At least 26 people were killed and 38 others were wounded on Wednesday when a car bomb exploded in a parking lot near St. John’s Roman Catholic Church in a southern neighborhood of Baghdad, according to police and medical officials.

headline: China Investigates Vaccine Maker After Deaths of Infants
text: SHANGHAI — Health authorities in China are investigating one of the nation’s biggest vaccine makers after eight infants died in the past two months following injections that were meant to immunize them against hepatitis B.

headline: BEST OF 2013
text: These 15 stories demonstrated why (and how) guys are dressing better than ever.

headline: Daily Report: E-Book Services Track Readers’ Habits
text: Before the Internet, David Streitfeld reports, books were written — and published — blindly, hopefully. Sometimes they sold, usually they did not, but no one had a clue what readers did when they opened them up. Did they skip or skim? Slow down or speed up when the end was in sight? Linger over the sex scenes?

headline: Journalist Is Beaten in Latest Attack on Ukrainian Opposition
text: MOSCOW — A crusading antigovernment journalist and activist in Ukraine who became famous last year after documenting the opulence of the heavily guarded residential compound of President Viktor F. Yanukovich was savagely beaten early Wednesday.

headline: App Smart: Equipping New Devices
text: A selection of great apps to get you going with a new smartphone or tablet.

headline: Basic Apps for Your New Smartphone or Tablet
text: So you’ve got a brand-new smartphone or tablet. Its gleaming screen is hypnotic. It feels like the future as it nestles, or perhaps just perches, in your hand. But until you download some apps, all its amazing 21st-century potential is unrealized. Yet there are millions of apps to choose from. Where to start?

headline: The Rat Takes the Cheese
text: Eek! Mice and rats are constantly scampering around children’s literature (Aesop’s fables; E.T.A. Hoffmann’s “Nutcracker and Mouse-King”; Beatrix Potter’s “The Tale of Two Bad Mice”), but there’s usually a difference between the two. Though mice are often portrayed as naughty, they are rarely as utterly repellent as rats. The sweet “Mouse House Tales,” by Susan Pearson with illustrations by Amanda Shepherd, and the hilarious and down-and-dirty “Cheese Belongs to You!,” by Alexis Deacon with illustrations by Viviane Schwarz, perpetuate this traditional polarity. But whatever your feelings about rodents, these two books shouldn’t be missed, even if you have to perch on a chair to read them.

headline: Home iMovies on Your iPhone
text: Home movies are increasingly being filmed on the smart phone. Here is how to do it using iMovie, from Apple.

headline: 1895: Christmas in Herald Square
text: From The New York Herald, European Edition, Christmas special.

headline: Unlocking Your Inner Movie Director (and Editor)
text: Making and showing home movies used to require clunky cameras and film projectors, or at least a VCR. Wrangling friends and family to sit down on the couch and watch them was often the easy part.

headline: Best of 2013 | The Year in Men’s Fashion
text: These 15 stories demonstrated why (and how) guys are dressing better than ever.

headline: TV Message by Snowden Says Privacy Still Matters
text: LONDON — In a message broadcast Wednesday on British television, Edward J. Snowden, the former American security contractor, urged an end to mass surveillance, arguing that the electronic monitoring he has exposed surpasses anything imagined by George Orwell in “1984,” a dystopian vision of an all-knowing state.

headline: Why Corporations Might Not Mind Moderate Depression
text: Yes, it’s Christmas — but the family events won’t begin for hours yet, and I want to follow up on a train of thought I started yesterday.

headline: South Sudan’s President Condemns Ethnic Killings
text: JUBA, South Sudan — As heavy fighting between government forces and rebels continued in South Sudan on Wednesday, President Salva Kiir spoke out against ethnically motivated killings in a Christmas address.

headline: Classical Playlist: Thomas Adès, Benjamin Hochman, Angela Hewitt and More
text: ‘LIEUX RETROUVÉS’Steven Isserlis, cellist; Thomas Adès, pianist; works by Liszt, Janacek, Fauré, Gyorgy Kurtag, Mr. Adès.(Hyperion)The British composer Thomas Adès wrote “Lieux retrouvés” (“Revisited Places”), a moody, ingenious and fiendishly difficult 18-minute cello and piano duo, specifically for his colleague and countryman Steven Isserlis, the brilliant cellist. Mr. Adès, a formidable pianist, plays the pieces with Mr. Isserlis on an exciting recording along with works by Liszt, Janacek, Fauré and Gyorgy Kurtag — an inspired grouping of diverse composers that highlights surprising musical connections between their styles. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Kanye West Faces Lawsuit Over Song Sample
text: The Kanye West track “Bound 2” has already become one of the most recognizable songs from his album “Yeezus,” helped along by a video in which he and his fiancée, Kim Kardashian, recreate an amorous moment, and by widespread online parodies of said video. But the song proved especially familiar to Ricky Spicer, a soul singer who is suing Mr. West for what he says is the unauthorized use of his voice on the track, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: The Pixies Join Festival Lineup in Israel
text: More than three years after canceling a planned performance in Israel, the Pixies are once again scheduled to play there as part of a new music festival in June. The Israeli newspaper Haaretz reported that the band would perform on a bill that also includes Soundgarden at a two-day festival scheduled for June 17 and 18 at Bloomfield Stadium in Tel Aviv.

headline: Italian Posters for ‘12 Years a Slave’ Prompt Race Debate
text: In America and throughout the world, the Steve McQueen film “12 Years a Slave” is known for its searing depiction of a black man’s life in bondage during the 1800s and a widely praised performance by its leading man, Chiwetel Ejiofor. But, in the eyes of a company distributing the movie in Italy, the film was apparently more notable for its white co-stars Brad Pitt and Michael Fassbender.

headline: 36 Hours in South Beach, Miami Beach
text: A weekend in South Beach ought not to begin with “What to pack?” but rather, “What to pursue?” Do you long for the South Beach of painted-on dresses, frozen margaritas and electric neon? The South Beach of stylish new (or renovated) hotels (Gale, Lord Balfour, SLS South Beach) and restaurants (Yardbird Southern Table & Bar, Khong River House, Tongue & Cheek)? Or the South Beach of yesteryear, of pastel Art Deco buildings, museums and monuments? Perhaps you simply crave ...the beach. Miami can be whatever you want it to be — laid back, decked out, gay, straight, a family recess, a single’s playground — which is precisely what makes it such an effortless getaway. In this dreamland at the southern tip of Miami Beach, you can choose your own adventure.

headline: Pope, Off Script, Nods to Atheists in Holiday Call for World Peace
text: ROME — Pope Francis used the first Christmas address of his papacy on Wednesday to make a broad call for global peace and an end to violence in Syria and parts of Africa, urging atheists and followers of other religions to join together in this common cause.

headline: A Savvy Investor’s Spiritual Exploration
text: A biographical film about a brand-name investor might not seem like holiday fare, but in two respects “Contrarian,” a documentary about John M. Templeton, seems just right for the day after Christmas.

headline: Christmas Around the World
text: From a NATO camp in Afghanistan to a picturesque beach in Australia, here’s a look at how people across the globe celebrated the holiday.

headline: A Teasing Online Return for ‘Sherlock’
text: There was never a doubt that Benedict Cumberbatch would return to the role of Sherlock Holmes, the modernized incarnation of Arthur Conan Doyle’s consulting detective he plays on the hit BBC series “Sherlock.” Despite a second-season finale in 2012 that seemed to show Holmes falling to his death, Mr. Cumberbatch’s star has risen considerably since then (in films like “Star Trek Into Darkness” and “The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug”), and besides, the BBC had already committed to a third season of “Sherlock.” (The series is shown in the United States on PBS’s “Masterpiece.”)

headline: Bypassing Fear and Embracing Networking
text: We just published a conversation with Hanny Lerner, the founder and president of MOD Restoration, a furniture reupholstering company in Brooklyn. In the interview, Ms. Lerner, 29, who grew up in a Hasidic community with limited information about the outside world, discussed how she managed to get up to speed and grow her business, which had 2013 sales of just under $2 million and employs about 10.

headline: Mapping a Darker Side of New York
text: New York City has long been associated with crime, in drama and in reality. From early bootlegging and street hustles to stock market frauds that have caused the global financial market to shudder, it’s fair to say that the city has had its share of bad actors.

headline: A Brooklyn Church Uncovers a Long-Hidden Celestial Scene
text: At Christmas, thoughts at many churches turn to a certain star.

headline: Egypt, Dealing a Blow to the Muslim Brotherhood, Deems It a Terrorist Group
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-backed leaders on Wednesday designated the Muslim Brotherhood a terrorist organization, outlawing the country’s most successful political movement and vowing to treat anyone who belongs to it, or even takes part in its activities, as a terrorist.

headline: Nets’ Effort Questioned, by Fans and by Coach
text: The chorus of boos and jeers started with about half a minute left in the game, when Tornike Shengelia tried to dribble the ball behind his back but instead felt it stripped away. Shengelia, an infrequently used reserve, was far from the object of the fans’ ire, but he was the Nets player unfortunate enough to be standing there when it all finally boiled over.

headline: Handel Well Populated, Onstage and Off
text: The Oratorio Society, under the direction of Kent Tritle, performed Handel’s “Messiah” in front of a capacity crowd on Monday at Carnegie Hall. The stage was also filled to capacity. The society’s choir has close to 200 singers. The alto section alone, with 59 members, is more than twice as big as, say, the entire Choir of Trinity Wall Street, whose “Messiah” I also reviewed this month.

headline: Feeling For | Ugo Rondinone’s Miniature, Wearable Art
text: Art is my job and my passion. I look at it, think about it, talk about it and write about it. Now, thanks to the artist Ugo Rondinone, I dream of wearing it. Rondinone made a splash earlier this year when an installation of his nine colossal stone sculptures, often likened to Stonehenge, inhabited Rockefeller Center. A few months later, in collaboration with the creative couple Sebastien and Stephanie Jannssen, Rondinone created mythical little masks that fit into the palm of your hand. The seven 23-karat-gold sculptures, created in a limited edition of six (plus three artist’s proofs), represent each day of the week and can be worn as a pendant. This enigmatic piece is sure to cure any case of the Mondays by making even the most cynical among us smile. Like most great works, it’s an investment piece. But as any art lover will tell you, it’s impossible to own all the art you want. That’s what dreams are for. Price upon request; sorrywereclosed.com.

headline: Dempsey to Help Fulham, and Himself
text: Clint Dempsey has heeded the call of Jurgen Klinsmann, coach of the United States national team, to get some playing time in Europe during Major League Soccer’s off-season and has heeded the desperate call of Fulham, one of his former teams, to help rescue the London club from relegation.

headline: How a Bridge Deal Can Resemble a Boxing Match
text: In Britain and other countries in the Commonwealth, Dec. 26 is known as Boxing Day. It has nothing to do with pugilism. Instead, in the Middle Ages, the landed gentry would deliver gifts in boxes to their serfs on this day.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: This month, a novel that conjures an imaginary city, an elegant book of poems complemented by haunting paintings, two dark collections of short stories where nothing is as it seems, and two rugged graphic novels with enjoyably ragged edges.

headline: Liu Ping’s Christmas in Jail
text: Liu Ping, a democracy advocate, doesn’t talk much about her Christian faith, preferring to talk about politics. But Christmas means something to her.

headline: From One Garage in Queens, a World of Fakes
text: Court papers in one of more than a half dozen lawsuits filed against a defunct Manhattan gallery, Knoedler & Co., reveal just how far the fakes it sold had spread before the fraud was discovered.

headline: A Honcho in Winter With More Tales to Tell
text: In 1998, Robert Evans, the least bashful producer in Hollywood, suffered three strokes in rapid succession. Their combined effects were so debilitating that it was not clear whether Mr. Evans would ever walk, talk or chase women again. But as his new memoir, “The Fat Lady Sang,” makes clear, at least Mr. Evans’s capacity for bragging and self-promotion remained mercifully unimpaired. He is still able to say “Wham, bam, there I am” in as many ways as this stubbornly upbeat book will allow.

headline: Apples for a Seasoned Acting Teacher
text: As other acting students watched in a darkened rehearsal studio, Alan Safier, a 64-year-old theater veteran, stepped toward a spotlight to begin a monologue from Shaw’s “Caesar and Cleopatra.” His eyes wide, Mr. Safier delivered his first line in a low, awe-struck tone.

headline: The Confidence, and the Art, Looked Real
text: To many people, the art dealer Jose Carlos Bergantiños Diaz seemed like an enviable man.

headline: Using an iPad With Linux
text: Using an iPad

headline: Finding the Drama in the Boss and Dylan
text: Nobody knows better than the British chanteuse Barb Jungr that even the most seemingly banal pop song lyrics have hidden wellsprings of intense feeling. It is the performer’s job to dig into the ground and bring up a gusher.

headline: Trove of Information From the 1930s, Animated by the Internet
text: In 1932, when Charles O. Paullin published his monumental Atlas of the Historical Geography of the United States, reviewers were overwhelmed by its nearly 700 maps covering seemingly every facet of the country’s social, economic and political life, including maps, then novel, showing county-by-county results for presidential elections going back to the beginning of the Republic.

headline: Evolving Young Satirist Stands Up to Convention
text: If any comedian could have a midlife crisis at 23, it would be Bo Burnham.

headline: Japanese Start-Ups Channel Samurai Spirit
text: The Samurai Startup Island, in a low-rent office district built on a landfill on Tokyo Bay, is at the vanguard of what many hope is a new generation of innovators.

headline: Start-Up Spirit Emerges in Japan
text: TOKYO — The 20-somethings in jeans sipping espresso and tapping on laptops at this Tokyo business incubator would look more at home in Silicon Valley than in Japan, where for years the surest signs of success were the gray suits of its corporate salarymen. But for those hoping the nation’s latest economic plan will drag Japan from its long malaise, the young men and women here at Samurai Startup Island represent a crucial component: a revival of entrepreneurship.

headline: Owner of Forgotten Clock Finds a Name (and Hands) to Put With the Face
text: For the last 20 years, the priciest curio from what was called the biggest yard sale of the 20th century lay undiscovered, but not unappreciated, in Barry Lubetkin’s apartment on the Upper East Side.

headline: Anthony Is Out, and Knicks Are Helpless Against Thunder
text: The Knicks’ problems may have begun when Carmelo Anthony arrived for pregame warm-ups Wednesday wearing a brown blazer and grabbed a seat on the bench.

headline: Gun Laws and the Mentally Ill
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Cancer’s Racial Gap
text: To the Editor:

headline: Triage and Food Stamps
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Round-the-Clock Giddiness in a 24-Hour Music Video
text: One afternoon this fall Tyler, the Creator, and his buddies Earl Sweatshirt and Jasper Dolphin, of the rap collective Odd Future, turned up on a street corner in downtown Los Angeles. Their agenda: to shoot a cameo for the music video “Happy,” by Pharrell Williams.

headline: Choosing to Be Naughty
text: ADS for fitness clubs and weight loss programs typically sell the notion that getting in shape will give consumers a confidence boost to get that promotion or date. But a new campaign from Equinox fitness takes the unusual approach of saying that getting in shape may get you in trouble.

headline: Swiss Group Tries to Bring Grangemouth Plant to Profitability
text: Grangemouth is only one outpost in the global empire of James A. Ratcliffe, but he has said that profitable units in the United States and elsewhere should not subsidize those losing money in Britain.

headline: The Cradle of Scotland's Refining Prowess
text: Grangemouth’s place in the chemical and oil industries goes back more than a century.

headline: A Refinery That Looms Over Scotland
text: The Grangemouth refinery complex has roots to the 1920s glory days of British industry and is a linchpin to the nation’s economy.

headline: Scotland Fights to Keep Energy Lifeline
text: GRANGEMOUTH, Scotland — The vast petrochemical complex at Grangemouth is a constellation of lights and glowing plumes of steam west of Edinburgh that has become a shimmering symbol of Scotland at an economic and political crossroads.

headline: Snowden's Christmas Message
text: Edward J. Snowden delivered an alternative Christmas message on British television. The former American security contractor warned of the dangers posed by the loss of privacy.

headline: Barbara Branden, Biographer of Ayn Rand, Dies at 84
text: Barbara Branden, who helped popularize Ayn Rand’s philosophy of self-interest in the 1960s but caused a schism among Ms. Rand’s followers with an unauthorized biography she wrote after the theorist’s death, died on Dec. 11 in West Hollywood, Calif. She was 84.

headline: A Work Still in Progress
text: When the country observed the Constitution’s 200th anniversary back in 1987, two narratives vied for public acceptance. There was the triumphalist narrative celebrated in Philadelphia, where a quarter-million people took part in a 15-hour-long gala, lining the route for a parade with floats that included a 40-foot replica of a parchment scroll.

headline: An Ode to Spam
text: I would like to take time now to thank everyone who sent me holiday messages via the Internet: The wishes of good cheer, the reports of family achievements in the year past, and the multiple requests for my email or bank password.

headline: Common Knee Surgery Does Very Little for Some, Study Suggests
text: A popular surgical procedure worked no better than fake operations in helping people with one type of common knee problem, suggesting that thousands of people may be undergoing unnecessary surgery, a new study in The New England Journal of Medicine reports.

headline: Islamic Banks, Stuffed With Cash, Explore Partnerships in West
text: A noted Muslim law scholar, Yusuf DeLorenzo, recently pored through the books of Continental Rail, a business that runs freight trains up and down the East Coast.

headline: Rescuing a Predator
text: The largest crocodile in South America is on the verge of extinction, and government and private efforts to rescue the species are having limited success.

headline: Venezuela’s Fitful Effort to Save a Scaly Predator
text: MANTECAL, Venezuela — Stealing the eggs from an enraged, 10-foot crocodile is a delicate operation.

headline: Highlights from Pope's Christmas Message
text: Pope Francis delivered his first Christmas message from the Vatican.

headline: Week 17 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Romo’s Bad Rap
text: The final game of the regular season will decide the winner of the N.F.C. East. The Eagles visit a wounded Cowboys team that will very likely be without its starting quarterback, Tony Romo. The conventional wisdom about Romo is that he’s a very skilled quarterback who can put up solid numbers each year, but that he somehow lacks the nerves to succeed in the clutch.

headline: An Entrepreneur Who Wouldn’t Be Stopped by Anything
text: Hanny Lerner estimates that 80 percent of her customers find her company, MOD Restoration, at the website she designed. Ms. Lerner, 29, does not code, but she has experience in user-interface design and created the screen blueprints for her site.

headline: Michael Bloomberg: Big Brother or Pioneer?
text: Was the departing mayor of New York City a public health innovator or a “nanny state” scold?

headline: Wind Power Developers Race Clock to Secure Subsidy
text: As the rest of the world prepares to toast the new year, the wind industry is hard at work on its own year-end tradition, rushing to make sure projects qualify for an important subsidy before it is set to vanish at the stroke of midnight on Tuesday.

headline: The Night Pittsburgh Became a Baseball Town Once Again
text: For many years, the Pittsburgh Pirates played their home games at Three Rivers Stadium, a home they shared with the Steelers at the confluence of the Allegheny, Ohio and Monongahela Rivers. It was a picturesque setting, except that the upper bowl encircled the ballpark and blotted out any sense of place.

headline: Pettersen Stars in a Supporting Role
text: Suzann Pettersen of Norway won four tournaments, including her second major at the Evian Championship. She recorded two third-place finishes and a tie for fourth in three of the year’s other majors, faltering only at the United States Women’s Open, where she missed the cut. She had 10 top-three finishes on the L.P.G.A. Tour and was on the victorious Solheim Cup team, which in any other year would have won her mountains of attention and possibly the Player of the Year award.

headline: In California, a Mayor’s Rise Is a Sign of the Times
text: SEBASTOPOL, Calif. — When Robert Jacob ran for the City Council here last year, he had already made the list of “Forty Under 40 of 2012” in a local business magazine. So it was to be expected that his business gave him face recognition among voters on the campaign trail, many of whom greeted him by exclaiming, “You’re the pot guy!”

headline: Gifts Sent by U.P.S. Miss a Big Deadline
text: Santa delivered sacks stuffed with i.o.u.’s this Christmas.

headline: In a Car-Culture Clash, It’s the Los Angeles Police vs. Pedestrians
text: LOS ANGELES — In a city of seemingly endless highways — with its daily parade of car accidents, frustrating traffic jams and aggressive drivers — the Los Angeles Police Department these days is training its sights on a different road menace: jaywalkers.

headline: In Final Weeks, a Push to Put Bloomberg’s Stamp on Major Legal Cases
text: In the Bloomberg administration’s final weeks, New York City’s Law Department has been actively trying to settle some of its longest-running court battles and, where that has failed, to at least put its stamp on significant legal cases before Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio takes office.

headline: Small Theaters in Adirondacks Face Choice in Switch to Digital: Pay or Perish
text: LAKE PLACID, N.Y. — Some nights, it is so cold that not even those who live here venture outside, so the Palace Theater closes early rather than show movies to an empty house.

headline: Despite New Evidence, Review of Conviction in 1989 Brooklyn Killing Stalls
text: Jonathan Fleming had been in prison for 23 years — for a murder he insisted he did not commit — before things began to look up this spring: After reinterviewing witnesses who had implicated him in his 1990 trial, his lawyer turned up evidence that he said could lead to Mr. Fleming’s release.

headline: In Need of Help, but Not the Emergency Room
text: A program in Wake County, N.C., trains paramedics to perform mental health exams on patients in the field.

headline: E.R. Costs for Mentally Ill Soar, and Hospitals Seek Better Way
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — As darkness fell on a Friday evening over downtown Raleigh, N.C., Michael Lyons, a paramedic supervisor for Wake County Emergency Medical Services, slowly approached the tall, lanky man who was swaying back and forth in a gentle rhythm.

headline: Eczema and Holy Water
text: My 9-month-old son’s first time on a plane — a 10-hour journey from J.F.K. to Istanbul — was a disaster. The dry air of the cabin, the confinement and possibly some allergen on the in-flight menu all contributed to an unprecedented eruption of his eczema. It was demoralizing. His skin had been cracking and inflamed for months, but we had taken such pains with it — daily applications of heavy cream and austere dietary restrictions — in anticipation of introducing him to his relatives in Turkey.

headline: Through Art, Coping With Depression and a Death
text: Disorder has come to characterize Robinette Christian’s life of late.

headline: Poison Gas Kills Eight Left in Dark After Storm
text: With downed power lines forcing hundreds of thousands to spend Christmas without electricity, ice storms that raged through the Northeast and the Midwest continued to have a deadly effect as carbon monoxide given off by gasoline-powered generators killed three Americans and five Canadians, officials said.

headline: Homeland Security’s New Chief
text: The Senate has confirmed Jeh Johnson, once the Pentagon’s top lawyer, to lead the Department of Homeland Security. Mr. Johnson brings a sharp legal mind and reputation for probity to the job. He will need both to manage the department, a daunting agglomeration of agencies and missions and chronic management problems.

headline: Getting Out of Discount Game, Small Colleges Lower the Price
text: SPARTANBURG, S.C. — A higher education riddle: When can a college slash tuition by almost half, without losing revenues? Answer: When nobody much pays full tuition anyway.

headline: A Rivalry Goes Unfulfilled as the Lakers Fall to the Heat
text: LOS ANGELES — Kobe Bryant, a creature of habit and one of symbolism, too, acknowledged it was a strange feeling to wake up on Christmas morning for the first time in 15 seasons without a basketball game to play.

headline: A Step Toward Affordable Housing
text: Representative Melvin Watt, a Democrat of North Carolina, who was confirmed earlier this month as the director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, will need to use all of his agency’s powers to cope with a worsening affordable housing crisis that is placing poor and elderly Americans at risk of homelessness and forcing many of the nation’s 43 million renters to skimp on food and medical care to meet the rent.

headline: Mistaken Ruling on Contraception
text: The contraception mandate in the new health care reform law accommodates religious beliefs. It exempts houses of worship from having to provide contraceptive coverage without a co-pay. Church-affiliated organizations like schools and hospitals need only send a short form to their insurance administrator, which takes care of the coverage.

headline: Farewell
text: The first Rural Life appeared on the editorial page nearly 16 years ago. This is the last. This seems a good season to leave, with a long winter ahead, the wood stove burning, and plenty of hopes and plans for the coming year. When The Rural Life began, I didn’t imagine that it would last so long or chart so many changes in my life. Nor did I imagine that it would find so many good readers. But it has, and I’m grateful for that.

headline: Bloomberg Checking In on Fallen Workers’ Families
text: The phone call came as a surprise.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 25, 2013
Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 26, 2013
text: “What it does is it inhibits the vitality of Los Angeles. When you go to New York, when you go to Chicago, when it’s safe to cross the street, you just cross the street. You just do it.”

headline: Yankees Know Risks of Splurging on Japanese Aces
text: Friday is the seventh anniversary of one of Brian Cashman’s more disastrous moments in his long run as general manager of the Yankees.
