On Dec. 27, 2006, Cashman signed off on a five-year, $20 million contract for the Japanese left-hander Kei Igawa, a pitcher who, in the seasons that followed, went on to win two games for the Yankees while spending most of his time out of sight and out of mind in the minor leagues.

headline: New Tests for Brain Trauma Create Hope, and Skepticism
text: Revelations in recent years that thousands of former football players might have severe brain trauma from injuries sustained on the field have set off a rush in the medical community to seize the potentially lucrative market for assessing brain damage. But experts say claims regarding the validity of these assessments are premature and perhaps unfounded.

headline: In Announcing Unfavorable News, Timing Is Everything
text: In the celebrated tradition of dumping unfavorable news on holidays, weekends or days when the media is otherwise preoccupied, New York City’s political folk spun a little frenzy before ducking out on Christmas Eve.

headline: Corrections: December 26, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: It’s Chaos, I Tell You
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Raise your hand if you finished this puzzle and you still weren’t sure what the theme was. Yup, me too.

headline: U.S. Sends Arms to Aid Iraq Fight With Extremists
text: WASHINGTON — The United States is quietly rushing dozens of Hellfire missiles and low-tech surveillance drones to Iraq to help government forces combat an explosion of violence by a Qaeda-backed insurgency that is gaining territory in both western Iraq and neighboring Syria.

headline: Thrust Into Role, Knicks’ Udrih Is Thrown Off His Game
text: Beno Udrih’s first pass on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden was intercepted by Russell Westbrook.

headline: Identical Twins? Yes. Identical Wins? No Way.
text: New York’s hapless N.B.A. teams — the Knicks and the Nets — have the same record (9-19) through Wednesday’s wipeouts. They have lost on the same day seven times this season. Not once have they won in tandem.

headline: Japanese Premier Visits Contentious War Shrine
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan visited a contentious Tokyo war shrine early on Thursday, provoking swift condemnation from China and South Korea, both victims of Japan’s wartime aggression.

headline: Obamas Celebrate Christmas in Hawaii
text: HONOLULU — President Obama took a break from opening gifts and singing carols with his family on Christmas Day, and spoke to about 580 military troops in Hawaii, where he and his family are spending their winter break, thanking them for their service.

headline: Tropical Prints that Transport
text: Despite the winter wonderland outside, it’s decidedly tropical in stores thanks to the bright colors and warm-weather prints in this season’s resort collections. The chic grandchildren of the Hawaiian shirt, statement separates like a colorful, palm-printed skirt from Fausto Puglisi beg to be paired with basic palettes and clean lines. And from the bright stones on an Annelise Michelson necklace, an upscale version of Panamanian street market finds, to the sandy-colored backdrop on a Prada bag emblazoned with a vintage hula girl, the often-kitschy theme is being reinvented into a motif that the modern woman can get behind without having to travel to a hot and humid destination.

headline: Preventing Civil War in South Sudan
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: A Nurse Gains Fame in the Days of Polio
text: In the years after World War II, polls perennially showed that Eleanor Roosevelt was the woman whom Americans admired most in the world. But in a 1951 Gallup poll, that distinction went to an Australian nurse, Elizabeth Kenny, popularly known as Sister Kenny.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 10:35 A.M. (Cinemax) SHAUN OF THE DEAD (2004) In this horror comedy directed by Edgar Wright, Simon Pegg plays Shaun, a worthless layabout who seems content to go nowhere fast just as long as he can hang out at his favorite pub with his best friend, Ed (Nick Frost), and his girlfriend, Liz (Kate Ashfield). But when Liz dumps Shaun, he decides to get his life together to win her back. Of course there’s also the small matter of a zombie apocalypse going on outside his door. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that the film skillfully satirized the zombie genre by “implying that Britain may already be populated with the living dead, metaphorically speaking.” He added, “The motley Londoners who face down the creatures are so inept and unthinking in their response to the catastrophe that the uncharitable part of you may decide that they deserve their probable (but not guaranteed) fates during what panicked television commentators label Z-Day.”

headline: With Shrine Visit, Leader Asserts Japan’s Track From Pacifism
text: TOKYO — Shinzo Abe’s past year as prime minister has concentrated chiefly on reviving Japan’s long-ailing economy. Yet in Mr. Abe’s mind, the country’s newfound economic prowess is a means to an end: to build a more powerful, assertive Japan, complete with a full-fledged military, as well as pride in its World War II-era past.

headline: Thai Election Body Urges Vote Delay as Unrest Flares
text: BANGKOK — After chaotic clashes between the police and antigovernment protesters in Bangkok on Thursday left one police officer dead and dozens of people injured, the Election Commission of Thailand urged that national elections scheduled for Feb. 2 be postponed, further clouding the country’s future after a month of debilitating street protests.

headline: Documenting the World for 125 Years
text: So, you want to see the Great Sphinx, but don’t have the big bucks for an Egyptian jaunt. Easy — go to your computer, type a few words into a search engine and within seconds thousands of images pop up for your viewing pleasure. Prefer to see the timeless creature at sunset, drenched in warm orange hues? Sure. Curious to see different angles? No problem.

headline: Times Minute | Post-Christmas Shopping
text: Also on the Minute, looking back at the top stories of 2013 including Detroit's bankruptcy and Lance Armstrong coming clean.

headline: Times Minute | Post-Christmas Shopping
text: In the Video

headline: New York Today: Political Lowlights
text: Updated 9:30 a.m.

headline: Don’t Trash Colombia’s Democracy
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — On Dec. 9, I was giving a talk at City Hall on the need to fight corruption when, suddenly, my cellphone alerted me to this message: Colombia’s inspector general had decided to remove me from my job as mayor of the nation’s capital and to bar me from holding office for 15 years.

headline: African Leaders Press for Peace in South Sudan
text: JUBA, South Sudan — As clashes between government troops and rebels continued in South Sudan on Thursday, diplomats moved swiftly to drag the warring sides to the negotiating table but announced none of the breakthroughs they had hoped for.

headline: Bad Scripts and Politics Make for a Bad Year in Tollywood
text: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh — Bollywood, the movie-making machine based in Mumbai, may be the best-known Indian film industry globally, but farther south in Andhra Pradesh, there is another that churns out more films each year and has a more intensely devoted following, so much that entertainment is inextricably linked with the state’s turbulent politics.

headline: Egypt Broadens New Crackdown on Brotherhood
text: CAIRO — Just a day after Egypt’s military-backed government declared the Muslim Brotherhood a terrorist group, a more aggressive crackdown was already emerging Thursday, as the authorities announced dozens of arrests across the country, and the seizure of land, stocks and vehicles belonging to the Islamist movement’s members.

headline: Software for Sorting Out Child Support
text: Getting divorced, particularly when children are involved, can be a hard and messy business, rife with mediators, lawyers and courts. It’s little remarked how hard the realities of the situation can be afterward, when people are on their own.

headline: Prosecutor Overseeing Turkish Graft Inquiry Is Removed From Case
text: ISTANBUL — An Istanbul prosecutor who had been overseeing a sprawling corruption investigation of the prime minister’s inner circle was removed from the case on Thursday, in a new sign of a profound power struggle over Turkey’s judiciary and police forces.

headline: Game Theory: BioShock Infinite and Video Game Reviews
text: After years of debate about the artistic merit of video games, the question of the medium’s artistic worth looks to have finally been decided. I say this in reference to the critical reaction surrounding BioShock Infinite, the first-person shooter from Irrational Games and one of this year’s most popular titles.

headline: In Our Pages: December 27
text: 1888: Duke, Duchess Escape Bomb

headline: Game Theory: A Golden Era for Criticism
text: Bemoaning the state of games criticism has been fashionable since at least 2006, when Chuck Klosterman wondered in Esquire why there was no Lester Bangs of video games. I suspect if you flipped — or, more likely, pointed and clicked — through my archive you could find me mourning something similar.

headline: One-Stop One-Man Charity
text: Dear Diary:

headline: BEST OF 2013
text: These 15 stories showed why visual culture is more vibrant than ever.

headline: Home Fires, Acridly Burning
text: Sam Shepard kicks off the screen adaptation of “August: Osage County” with a foggy reference to T. S. Eliot and a succinct account of some of the family pathology that will occupy his kin (and the audience) for the next couple of hours. “My wife takes pills,” he says, “and I drink.” Mr. Shepard is Beverly Weston, a poet living in a big, faded farmhouse in northeastern Oklahoma. Beverly’s wife, Violet, soon makes her wobbly, cackling entrance in the person of Meryl Streep. She takes pills. He drinks. And then Mr. Shepard quits the scene. You will miss him. You might also envy him.

headline: Alternatives to Shopping ‘Til You’re Dropping
text: With the holiday daze upon us, I thought it worth posting a Dot Earth reader on alternatives to shopping until you’re dropping.

headline: The Salt Wars
text: On Christmas Eve 1863, the Union steamers Daylight and Howquah set out from Beaufort, N.C., with volunteers from the 158th New York State and Ninth Vermont onboard. Their destination was Bear Inlet, where they were to join the warship the Iron Age to destroy local salt works, as well as a cargo of salt offloaded by a Southern blockade runner that had been captured the previous day. Arriving at low tide, the steamers were unable to land their troops until Christmas morning. Once onshore, the federal forces set about destroying three Confederate salt works, as many as 400 sacks of salt and dozens of empty turpentine barrels. By 5:30 that afternoon, the expedition had returned unscathed to Beaufort.

headline: Image of the Day: December 26
text: Women in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, commemorating the ninth anniversary of a tsunami that killed more than 200,000 people in Asia.

headline: A Chicago Cocktail Crawl
text: Chicago bars have a way with a resonant cultural reference.

headline: Homes for $800,000
text: A look at a waterfront condo in Baltimore, a Craftsman-style house in Dallas and a cabin in South Dakota.

headline: What You Get for... $800,000
text: BALTIMORE

headline: Daily Report: Japanese Start-Ups Channel Samurai Spirit
text: The 20-somethings in jeans sipping espresso and tapping on laptops at a Tokyo business incubator would look more at home in Silicon Valley than in Japan, where for years the surest signs of success were the gray suits of its corporate salarymen. But for those hoping the nation’s latest economic plan will drag Japan from its long malaise, Martin Fackler reports from Tokyo, the young men and women at Samurai Startup Island represent a crucial component: a revival of entrepreneurship.

headline: New Cruises for Rollin’ on the River
text: A lazy cruise down the Mississippi River, sipping cocktails while watching the paddlewheel turn: it’s not just a vision of bygone days. Europe’s boom in river cruising has reached the United States, in the form of luxury paddlewheelers.

headline: 5 Are Killed in Outbreak of Violence in New Jersey
text: Five people were shot and killed in two separate shootings in and around Newark on Wednesday, an outbreak of violence that led to renewed questions about public safety in New Jersey’s largest city.

headline: The Birth Parents Move In
text: “This will either end really well, or really badly,” I thought as I loaded the rabbit cage into the car. My normally fearless, fierce 2½-year-old daughter, Grace, was terrified of this small nervous bunny, the first she had ever seen outside of a book. Grace’s birth parents, Bridgett and Bill, grabbed two guitars, a suitcase and a few small bags from their rain-soaked tent. And then we all went home together to the small apartment Grace and I share.

headline: Best of 2013 | The Year in Art
text: These 15 stories showed why visual culture is more vibrant than ever. Read…

headline: In the Human Brain, Size Really Isn’t Everything
text: There are many things that make humans a unique species, but a couple stand out. One is our mind, the other our brain.

headline: U.S. Captive of Al Qaeda Makes a Plea to Obama
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An American development consultant abducted by Al Qaeda in Pakistan more than two years ago has urged the Obama administration to help secure his freedom in an impassioned video message released by the group.

headline: Letters: The Art of Taxidermy and More
text: The Art of Taxidermy

headline: Revisiting a Long-Forgotten Chat With Candidate Bloomberg
text: Michael R. Bloomberg asked to be interviewed.

headline: Chamber Opera and Rachmaninoff
text: Gotham Chamber Opera has earned a strong reputation in recent seasons, presenting unusual repertory, innovative productions and excellent young singers. Here it partners with the equally estimable music forces of Trinity Church for a staging in St. Paul’s Chapel by Andrew Eggert of “La Descente d’Orphée aux Enfers” (“The Descent of Orpheus to the Underworld”). This chamber opera by Marc-Antoine Charpentier will be conducted by Neal Goren, Gotham’s artistic director. The cast includes Daniel Curran as Orphée. (7 p.m., Wednesday and Friday, Broadway and Fulton Street, Lower Manhattan; 212-868-4460, gothamchamberopera.org.)

headline: Legendary Ways to Ring in the Year
text: Where and how to ring in the New Year is a perennial question. If you’re feeling festive and want to make a full night of it, there are several theater-related offerings to choose from.

headline: Armchair Travels, to Amsterdam
text: Imagine if the Metropolitan Museum of Art suspended operations for almost a decade to undergo a major makeover. That gives you an idea of the scale in “The New Rijksmuseum,” Oeke Hoogendijk’s almost-four-hour documentary, playing as a Film Forum double feature through Wednesday. Ms. Hoogendijk’s beautifully shot film presents the countless concerns — among them unending revisions demanded of architects; a transition between general directors; and contentious meetings with politicians, contractors and the very vocal Dutch Cyclists Union — that went into a $500 million transformation of Amsterdam’s signature museum.

headline: Holiday Soul and Illusion
text: It’s that end-of-December feeling: The last thing you want to do is step into a shop. Mercifully, there are mood-altering alternatives. New York City Ballet presents final performances of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker,” while Momix continues its illusionary, body-conscious spectacle at the Joyce Theater with Moses Pendleton’s “Momix reMIX.” And for some holiday soul, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater continues its season with three programs. On New Year’s Eve, “Revelations” will feature Ailey veterans of the past and present, including Linda Denise Fisher-Harrell, Renee Robinson, Guillermo Asca, Elizabeth Roxas-Dobrish, Dudley Williams and Donna Wood Sanders. Next Sunday, there’s the season finale, showcasing excerpts from Ailey’s dances and the season’s new works along with “Revelations” in its entirety. It would have been Ailey’s 83rd birthday. Bring your party hat.

headline: Pro Skier Hacks Into Challenging Run
text: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind The Line,” the skier Sage Cattabriga-Alosa has to tunnel through a snow mass to get to a ski run in Alaska.

headline: Grooving to Egyptrixx
text: The new Egyptrixx album, “A/B Til Infinity,” is a lustrous and resonant thing. Released on the Night Slugs label, home to some of the most challenging but danceable music of the last couple of years, it relies heavily on texture, scrape and atmosphere for its effect, and only sometimes slips into outright groove. Compared to its predecessor, 2011’s “Bible Eyes,” as well as several EPs, this album by Egyptrixx (the recording alias of David Psutka) shows him drilling down to one coherent idea about dance music: The thing that moves the body need not be rhythm, but rather a primal response to sound. With Sinden and Judge Wise. (11:30 p.m., Friday, the Glasslands, 289 Kent Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; theglasslands.com.)

headline: A Parade Wedding and a Dream Home
text: The New Year is once again coming up roses for HGTV, that champion of the fantasy lifestyle, which heralds 2014 from its traditional perch at the 125th Rose Parade. Starting at 11 a.m., Vin Scully, the Hall of Fame sports broadcaster and grand marshal, will lead nearly 50 floats, centered on the theme “Dreams Come True” and adorned with more botanical elements — black lichen, Spanish mosses, safflower blossoms, cordon puffs, coconut flakes and even chive and onion seed — than the average florist might go through in five years, down Colorado Avenue in Pasadena, Calif. The “Property Brothers,” Drew and Jonathan Scott and Nancy O’Dell will provide a play-by-play of the nuptials of Danny Leclair and Aubrey Loots on the AIDS Healthcare Foundation’s wedding-cake float with the tagline “Love Is the Best Protection.” And eight former Women Airforce Service Pilots from World War II expected to ride atop a float titled “Our Eyes Are on the Stars.”

headline: Art Films at MoMA and Times Square
text: Before New Year’s revelers overtake Times Square, art lovers can have their own countdown to midnight. At 11:57 each night through Monday, an abbreviated version of Isaac Julien’s film “Playtime” is being shown on electronic billboards and kiosks as part of the “Midnight Moment” art program presented by the Times Square Alliance and the Times Square Advertising Coalition. The full-length version of “Playtime” explores the international art market from the perspectives of five characters with varying levels of access and privilege. One is an auctioneer in London, another a worker in Dubai.

headline: Video: Pro Skier Hacks Into Challenging Run
text: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Love Is Hunger: Watch Your Appetite
text: The creepy thriller “The Truth About Emanuel” deals with “loss and heartbreak and madness and mortality,” the writer and director Francesca Gregorini said recently. “Every artist is haunted by specific themes, and those, for better or for worse, seem to be mine.”

headline: Heartthrobs Rule the Korean Stage
text: SEOUL, South Korea — His acting was all smiles and scowls, and his dancing fell short of Broadway caliber, but Yang Yoseop, at 23, was an old pro at exuding heartache. Which was all that really mattered.

headline: Finra Fines Barclays $3.75 Million Over Record Retention
text: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said on Thursday that it fined Barclays Capital $3.75 million over its failure to properly retain records.

headline: Acupuncture, Real or Not, Eases Side Effects of Cancer Drugs
text: Both acupuncture and sham acupuncture were effective in reducing menopausal symptoms in women being treated with aromatase inhibitors for breast cancer, a small randomized trial found. Joint and muscle pain, hot flashes and night sweats are common side effects of those estrogen-lowering drugs.

headline: On Point in Message, and Technique
text: Whether it rises to the surface or not, the notion of labor usually lurks somewhere in a Heather Kravas dance, in which repeated steps and patterns are knitted together with such exactitude that the results blend vulnerability with steely tenacity. It’s an idea that she extends to herself, especially now as she prepares to unveil “a quartet,” her latest, at the Kitchen in Chelsea beginning Jan. 8.

headline: Bring Your Film Here, Then Run
text: “We’re not a big country” the director Drasko Djurovic said from his home in Montenegro. “We’re like the Bronx.” So he was very grateful to be part of the Academy Awards. “It means great opportunities for future projects.”

headline: Elegant Provocateur in a Puritanical Era
Zombies Amok Amid Fine Design
text: Should auld acquaintance be filleted? That’s the message of a batch of splattery movies released on Blu-ray just in time for New Year’s Eve.

headline: Times Minute | Controversial War Shrine
text: Also on the Minute, a crackdown on jaywalking and a look back at Rana Plaza.

headline: Times Minute | Controversial War Shrine
text: In the Video

headline: Mirth Amid Strauss Waltzes
text: One of the baritones was asked to work on his pitch: “Enter as a tenor!” A soprano was coached on her volume: “Make that the top of your crescendo!” And the ensembles were urged to work on their diction, and the rhythm of their back and forth: “Like table tennis!”

headline: Sebastian Faulks: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “A Possible Life” and “Jeeves and the Wedding Bells” says literary novels tend to make bad movies: “One form is all inward; the other is two-dimensional.”

headline: K-Pop Meets Broadway
text: Theater producers in Seoul have been increasingly hiring K-pop stars, as well as Korean soap opera actors and other celebrities, to perform in homegrown versions of American and European shows.

headline: New Program to Support Operas by Women
text: Have you ever wondered whether female characters in opera would be less likely to go mad, struggle with horrible diseases (consumption, usually) or be murdered by their former lovers if the works were composed by women?

headline: Warrant Issued in Russia for the Owner of Hédiard
text: MOSCOW — A court in Moscow has issued an arrest warrant for Sergei Pugachev, a Russian banker who bought the French confectionery and luxury food chain Hédiard six years ago with hopes of expanding its global reach only to run it into bankruptcy instead, the Kommersant newspaper reported on Thursday.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: bad laughter, cancer rates and nuts during pregnancy. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: In Blue-Collar Toledo, Ohio, a Windfall of Chinese Investments
text: TOLEDO, Ohio — The realization was as surprising as it was momentous. Toledo, long known as Glass City, needed glass, and it could no longer be manufactured here quickly enough.

headline: Yanks and Dodgers Know Tanaka’s Agent Well
text: Masahiro Tanaka, the 25-year-old pitching ace from Japan, is officially up for grabs to Major League Baseball teams. To get him, they will have to go through Casey Close, the prominent baseball agent at Excel Sports Management who also represents Derek Jeter and Mark Teixeira of the Yankees and pitchers Clayton Kershaw and Zack Greinke of the Dodgers.

headline: Museum of the City of New York’s Gelato Giveaway
text: At no other time of year is the Miser’s mom repaid more kindly than over the Christmas holiday, while watching, with a level of glee only an act of cosmic justice could occasion, her eldest child attempt to manage the perfectly unmanageable hopes, desires and vestigial energies of his own little angels.

headline: A Night’s Meal at the Opera
text: WHEN I was growing up, most girls I knew went to Lincoln Center for “The Nutcracker.” I went to the opera. Specifically, to Metropolitan Opera rehearsals with my father, who didn’t think twice about pulling me out of school. The first one, when I was in fifth grade, was “Madama Butterfly,” with Teresa Stratas. Let other children tarry with visions of the Sugar Plum Fairy. We cut straight to heartbreak and suicide. I loved it.

headline: Discoveries in the Past Year’s Auctions
text: When some of the year’s most intriguing auction lots emerged on the market — lots that hardly anyone had known existed — museum staffs hurriedly persuaded patrons to finance purchases. Here are eight success stories about objects that are already going on view and yielding more secrets.

headline: ‘Degenerate Art’ Opens at Neue Galerie in the Spring
text: The Neue Galerie’s big spring show, “Degenerate Art: The Attack on Modern Art in Nazi Germany, 1937,” has been nearly three years in the making, yet it seems particularly prescient after the discovery last month of what may well be the biggest trove of missing 20th-century European art — about 1,400 works suspected of being traded or looted during the Nazis’ reign, including paintings by Matisse, Chagall, Renoir, Toulouse-Lautrec, Picasso and a host of other masters. Some disappeared in the late 1930s, around the time the Nazis raided German museums and public collections, confiscating works they called degenerate because Hitler deemed them un-German or Jewish in nature.

headline: Google Penalizes Rap Genius for Gaming Search Rank
text: Google has apparently punished a provocative music-lyrics website after learning it had unscrupulously tried to improve its search rankings.

headline: Philadelphia Monsignor’s Conviction Overturned in Cover-Up of Sexual Abuse
text: A Pennsylvania appeals court on Thursday overturned the criminal conviction of a Roman Catholic official who was accused of covering up sexual abuses by priests he supervised. The court rejected the legal basis for a prosecution that was viewed as a milestone in holding senior church officials accountable for keeping abuse reports secret in past decades and transferring predatory priests to unwary new parishes.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Is a Hit With TV Pirates, Too
text: More than a few fans of “Game of Thrones” are so eager for the murder, villainy, depravity and wedding banquets gone horribly wrong depicted on that series that they don’t mind engaging in a little piracy to see the show. The hit HBO fantasy series enjoyed the dubious distinction of placing first on a list of the year’s most pirated television shows, compiled by TorrentFreak.com.

headline: A Film Festival’s Greatest Quick Hits
text: A diverse sampler, “2013 Sundance Film Festival Short Films” bundles together prizewinners and other notables from the most recent edition of the festival in Park City, Utah. As with many collections of shorts, there’s a slight danger of whiplash (to borrow the title of one selection) when each filmmaker introduces a look, sets a mood, sketches a story. Over the course of the eight-film selection, you might see a foulmouthed teacher berating a nervous drummer, photographs of working-class villagers by the sea in 1980s northern England, a dead man rising and pieces of furniture roaming the countryside in Ireland.

headline: Victory, and Setback, for Indian Opposition Leader
text: NEW DELHI — The fiery head of India’s leading opposition party, who remains under pressure for his handling of an ethnic riot 11 years ago, won a victory on Thursday in one of the many disputes dogging him as he seeks to become India’s next prime minister, but faced a setback in another.

headline: A Wider Family Circle
text: We have been estranged from our son for a couple of years (thanks mostly to his difficult and dominant longtime girlfriend). Still, we followed your advice and wrote him a loving letter for Hanukkah, which he returned in kind. We’ve spoken on the phone a few times since then and even set a date for New Year’s brunch. Now he’s told us that he wants to bring the girlfriend to our reunion. Is there a nice way to let him know that we want to keep it just family for now?

headline: ‘I Have Been Totally Abandoned and Forgotten,’ Captive Says
text: An American kidnapped in Pakistan more than two years ago has sent an impassioned video message to President Obama, imploring the administration to negotiate with his captors for his release and saying he felt “abandoned and forgotten.”

headline: In Red Hook, a Home a Bit Away From It All
text: About 10 years ago, after he finished his master’s degree in architecture at Columbia University, Ben Krone rented a three-bedroom loft in a big brick factory building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Living in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn
text: A stable, relatively affordable enclave in a borough that has grown almost too popular for its own good.

headline: Dyker Heights, Brooklyn: A Neighborhood for All Seasons
text: Dyker Heights, a middle-class, largely Italian-American neighborhood in southwestern Brooklyn, bears signs throughout the year of a place that people deeply care for.

headline: In ‘Natasha, Pierre,’ House Managers Are Part of the Action
text: They may be friendly, or they may be brusque, but the ushers who point the way to your theater seat have only so much to do with your experience once the curtain goes up. In the new world of immersive theater, where lines between the audience and the performers are blurred, it’s a little more complicated. “Here Lies Love” at the Public Theater featured a squadron of helpers in neon pink jumpsuits, moving the standing audience around a dance floor as the show’s set whirled and reconfigured.

headline: Claire Chase Invites Young Musicians to Create New Paths
text: Of all the empowering statements the flutist Claire Chase made in her convocation address to the graduating students of Northwestern University’s Bienen School of Music in June, one must have really surprised them: “I’d love for every single one of you to put me out of business. Then I will know that I have done my job.”

headline: Jenji Kohan, Creator of ‘Orange Is the New Black’
text: When Jenji Kohan set out to find a network home for “Orange Is the New Black” two years ago, empowering a revolution in the way we watch television was not on her agenda.

headline: The Meanings of the Selfie
text: Selfies are something new to me, but as I have become increasingly addicted to Instagram, I have been accused of posting too many of them. I was called out on the “Today” show, and have even been called the selfie king.

headline: Mustaches in Vogue on Film Screens
text: It might be going too far to proclaim 2013 the Year of the Mustache, but viewers have been privy to a glorious bounty of mustachioed upper lips at the movies this year. Phil Olsen, the captain of Beard Team USA, knows a thing or two about hirsute looks. He and his colleagues will battle for global facial hair supremacy at the World Beard and Mustache Championships in Portland, Ore., in September. He agreed to share his thoughts on a selection of actors with striking ’staches.

headline: Michael B. Jordan on His Role in ‘Fruitvale Station’
text: The “B.” in Michael B. Jordan stands for “Bakari,” which in Swahili means “of noble promise.” For Mr. Jordan, the 26-year-old star of “Fruitvale Station,” 2013 has been the year in which potential — “I’ve been walking in it since I was born” he said of the pressure embodied in his middle name — fully blossomed into reality.

headline: Miley Cyrus on Her Jump to Sexy Twerker
text: In 2013, Miley Cyrus wagged her tongue and set tongues wagging. Thanks to a handful of steamy videos, some outrageous wardrobe choices and an erotic comedic performance at the MTV Video Music Awards, Ms. Cyrus took the warp-speed path from directionless ex-child star (as the Disney Channel’s Hannah Montana) to the most directional of pop stars, sliding easily into the role of pop’s enfant terrible. Her album “Bangerz” (RCA) — for which she’ll begin touring in February — was notable for its risk-taking attitude in a year when her competition played it frustratingly smooth.

headline: Portrait of an Aunt With Dark Secrets
text: The mythical status of Nicholas Shakespeare’s aunt Priscilla, the subject of this biographical memoir, took shape in his family on her return to London after the liberation of Paris. A glamorous survivor of four years as a British enemy alien in France during World War II, married to a French viscount, astonishingly and adulterously dating the British movie star Robert Donat. The family’s image couldn’t have been how she saw herself, as the once-adored daughter of a father she barely glimpsed after she was swept off to Paris by a mother she described (seemingly accurately) as “a selfish, vain, stupid woman,” next as an aspiring ballet dancer crippled by illness, then a shy 20-year-old whose parents wouldn’t support her, and — on her way to have a French abortion — a pickup by the viscount.

headline: A Cinderella Is Back to Waiting for a Happy Ending
text: In Cornell’s last men’s basketball game, at Stony Brook, Coach Bill Courtney often threw his arms up in frustration after turnovers and frequently flashed an exhausted smile when his team committed imprudent fouls.

headline: Lorde’s ‘Royals’ Is Class-Conscious
text: A flourishing teen-pop industry thinks it knows what teenagers care about: crushes, breakups, clothes, parties, perhaps an occasional glimmer of rebellion or idealism. It dispenses songs that are calculated to suit that market. But in 2013, a songwriter who is an actual teenager emerged from the far side of the planet with something smarter and deeper: a class-conscious critique of pop-culture materialism that’s so irresistible it became a No. 1 pop single.

headline: Damian Woetzel at the Vail International Dance Festival
text: When Damian Woetzel retired in 2008 as a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, popular opinion had him aiming at a ballet company directorship. But he has taken a more surprising direction, becoming an all-around arts advocate. He is involved in Musicorps, which helps war veterans; he’s on the President’s Committee on the Arts and the Humanities; and he directs the Aspen Institute Arts Program.

headline: Sheikha al-Mayassa Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani of Qatar Museums
text: In October, when Sheikha al-Mayassa Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, the 30-year-old chairwoman of the Qatar Museums Authority, unveiled 14 monumental new bronze sculptures by the British artist Damien Hirst in front of a women’s and children’s health center on the outskirts of Doha, her intention was neither to shock nor offend residents of this conservative Middle Eastern city.

headline: ‘Key & Peele,’ With Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele
text: There are two complementary forms of radical humor taking place on “Key & Peele,” the sketch show that just finished its third season on Comedy Central. On the one hand is the race humor, savvy in tweaking fraught white encounters with blackness and sometimes equally fraught black encounters with blackness. On the other hand are sketches that are completely race neutral in content, which are given frisson merely by the race of the comedians: Both Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele are the children of black fathers and white mothers.

headline: Wheelies: The Fresh Air Volvos Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Is This a Video I See in Front of Me?
text: Pity the English teacher of today, faced with a roomful of adolescents busy updating their Facebook status, communicating on Snapchat or gossiping via text message about the latest perfidy committed by a frenemy. Trying to instill in students a passionate interest in Shakespeare (or even a passing one) has never been a teacher’s easiest task. With all those digital distractions, the challenge of awakening teenagers’ interest in his plays has surely become harder.

headline: Big Spanish Labor Union Facing an Investigation on Misuse of Funding
text: MADRID — Spain’s shrinking labor unions have struggled during the economic crisis to put a brake on the government’s austerity measures and help reduce record unemployment.

headline: 2013: A Look Back, and Beyond
text: Reporters and editors for The New York Times are recalling the people, teams and moments that made 2013 memorable, and in some cases looking ahead to next year.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Writers and Drinking
text: This week, Olivia Laing talks about “The Trip to Echo Spring”; and John Williams discusses Morrissey’s “Autobiography.”

headline: With Health Law Cemented, G.O.P. Debates Next Move
text: WASHINGTON — With the first enrollment deadline now passed, Republicans who have made the repeal of President Obama’s health care law their central aim are confronting a new reality: More than two million Americans are expected to be getting their health insurance through the Affordable Care Act come Jan. 1.

headline: Amazon Reveals a New Hint About Prime Membership Rolls
text: SEATTLE — The world’s biggest online retailer has mastered the art of talking a lot about its holiday sales, while saying very little.

headline: Epiphanies at ‘Home’
text: Watching prepubescent girls undergoing stirrings of sexual awakening is not generally regarded as a comfortable or suitable cultural experience. (Yes, there’s always Balthus, but then again ....) Still, you’d have no reason to feel guilty about enjoying the downright wholesome spectacle of the 8-year-old girl who recounts in song her realization that she just might be attracted to member of her own sex in “Fun Home,” the wonderful musical that ends its run at the Public Theater on Jan. 12 (publictheater.org).

headline: No Aid Seen in Syrian Town Despite a Deal to Lift Barriers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The rebel-held Syrian town of Moadhamiya hoisted the government’s flag from its tallest building on Thursday as part of a tentative truce deal, a symbolic victory for the government, which has blockaded the town for nearly a year, preventing food and medical supplies from entering.

headline: Learning to Measure Time in Love and Loss
text: For about 10 years, I worked full time in prisons as a teacher, logging more than 40 hours a week behind those fences, including a long winter at one facility that had been a cereal factory and stood near the highway in downtown Indianapolis. It was a rock of a building with finger-thick grilles on the windows.

headline: The Creative Alchemy Behind Potent Soundtracks
text: Marvin Hamlisch died more than a year ago, but he can still teach a fine master class.

headline: Bringing Parisian Flair to Police Procedural
text: Put the blame on Danes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Thailand, Peru, Central Africa Republic and China.

headline: Where Weather’s Always Fine for a Run
text: IF the words “wintry mix” are enough to make your inner runner want to head to the nearest treadmill, or even forgo a workout altogether, there’s another option: Visit an indoor track. New York City has a strong indoor-running scene, with an array of gyms, universities and Y.M.C.A.s offering tracks insulated from the elements.

headline: Injuries, More Injuries, Stunning Upsets and Other Wimbledon Weirdness
text: The tennis year was full of riveting story lines: the dominance of Serena Williams; the triumphant comeback of Rafael Nadal; the long-awaited Wimbledon title for Andy Murray and Britain; a record-setting year for the Bryan brothers; the steep decline of Roger Federer.

headline: LightSquared Proposes New Financing as Way to Emerge From Bankruptcy
text: The wireless communications company LightSquared may have a path out of bankruptcy that lets its biggest shareholder, the billionaire hedge fund manager Philip Falcone, retain some of the control he has sought.

headline: The Queen’s Reign
text: The Focus Dance season at the Joyce Theater brings just two performances of “Scott, Queen of Marys” (1994) by Doug Elkins: Jan. 7 and 12 (joyce.org). When I first saw this in December 2012, I at once arranged to see it a second time that week, and now I’m impatient for this chance to renew the acquaintance.

headline: The Lady Barbara
text: One of the main qualities we look for in a diva is a variety that somehow stays the same; we want from our great artists both adventure and safety. But Barbara Stanwyck pushed her range further than most. She was sometimes a femme fatale and sometimes a screwball comedian; she was a noble missionary’s wife in “The Bitter Tea of General Yen” (1933) and a scheming con artist in “The Lady Eve” (1941).

headline: Women Ruling Falstaff’s Roost
text: Two memorable new productions book-ended the year at the Metropolitan Opera: François Girard’s painfully human “Parsifal,” set in a post-apocalyptic no-man’s land, and Robert Carsen’s zippy “Falstaff,” set in a 1950s England of Technicolor opulence. For a director approaching “Parsifal,” the challenge is to come up with ideas to populate the dramaturgical moonscape that are Wagner’s interminable monologues in this five-hour-plus opera. Verdi’s comedy “Falstaff,” by contrast, is teeming with action, and the task of the director — no less difficult — is one of traffic control.

headline: Officer Kills Armed Suspect in the Bronx
text: A police officer shot and killed a suspect in an armed robbery in the Bronx early Thursday as the suspect struggled over his loaded gun with another officer, the police said.

headline: Subterranean Acts of Sudden Intimacy
text: IN its heyday, Billy Rose’s Diamond Horseshoe was quite the thing — “the most zestful, gorgeous and lovable pleasure palace in town,” a critic for The New York Times wrote shortly after it opened in December 1938. Buried deep in the basement of what is now the Paramount Hotel on West 46th Street in Manhattan, the theater transported audiences back to New York in the Gay Nineties, the era of Diamond Jim Brady and Lillian Russell, in a revue stacked with old vaudeville troupers and glamorous showgirls.

headline: Memories, Stitched Together, for Gallery Walls
text: After a year of shows that combined folk and self-taught artists (a.k.a. “outsiders”) with M.F.A.-groomed “insiders,” we’re finally starting to recognize quilts as powerfully contemporary artworks. Last summer’s excellent Americana-theme group show “Roving Signs,” for instance, organized by the artist Terry Winters for the Matthew Marks gallery, featured the dazzling abstract quilts of Rosie Lee Tompkins alongside works by Donald Judd, Rachel Harrison and Richard Aldrich.

headline: A Chilling Crime in an Everyday Setting
text: Maybe it was how normal Aaron Hernandez’s neighborhood appeared. Perhaps that’s what made the accusations so chilling.

headline: Reactions to World War II Shrine Visit
text: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan visited a contentious shrine and honored Japan’s war dead, triggering protests from China and South Korea.

headline: Unusual Play by Unfamiliar Yankees
text: The 2013 Yankees may be best remembered for their inability to remain healthy in a season that, despite the efforts of a lineup of down-to-their-last-hurrah veterans and castoffs from around the league, ended short of the playoffs.

headline: Pageant of a Bucolic Ukraine
text: Korchma Taras Bulba opened its first New York restaurant in SoHo, featuring Ukrainian food and servers in traditional dress.

headline: A Day in SoHo, a Night in Ukraine
text: It starts and ends with vodka.

headline: That’s Vintage Verdi, That ’61 ‘Otello’
text: SOME days are left in 2013, so it is still officially the bicentennial of Verdi’s birth, which means it is not too late for the classical music critics of The New York Times to share their choices of favorite Verdi recordings. This August we came up with our favorite recordings of Wagner, who also had a big bicentennial year. As with Wagner, Verdi has been as central to the history of recordings as he is to the history of music.

headline: Representational Work in Years When Abstract Was Hot
text: However often it is bent, the rule still holds: People who govern public art museums must set aside self-interest in carrying out their institutional duties. Maintaining higher standards is especially urgent when a museum runs into trouble, as the National Academy did five years ago,  when it sold two Hudson River School paintings to cover budgetary shortfalls and briefly considered selling its Fifth Avenue building to resolve its debts.

headline: All That Glitters (and a Lot That Shines)
text: Anyone who visits museums has spent time looking at costly luxury goods and status symbols cherished by the upper echelons and ruling classes of bygone eras. The list of objects elevated to unprecedented heights of artistry includes Japanese lacquer boxes, Fabergé eggs, French porcelain, Roentgen furniture, bejeweled objects from the treasuries of this cathedral or that court. Almost without exception, they dazzle the eye with astounding craftsmanship, superb design and carefully orchestrated material extravagance.

headline: In the Holiday Movie Crush, a Few Twists
text: The Fourth of July it’s fireworks. Thanksgiving Day it’s turkey. Christmas week, it’s movies, and lots of them. Schools release their students, studios release their awards contenders and the box office totals swell.

headline: Wintry Wanderings Among Chelsea’s Ghosts
text: I’ve lived in some historic places over the years — Paris, Greenwich Village, Washington — but it wasn’t until I spent a winter in Chelsea a year ago that I felt as if I were inside a diorama. The ur-Chelsea, I mean: London, not the quarter of Manhattan that provided Joni Mitchell with inspiration for a song and, in the process, Bill and Hillary Clinton with a name for their newborn daughter. For historical voyeurism, London’s Chelsea is hard to beat, especially if you incline to artist-writer types, or as my late friend Christopher Hitchens would put it, “people of that kidney.”

headline: The Year in Pop
text: Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the dominant ideas and themes in pop in 2013.

headline: Lawmakers Cite Progress on Budget Near Deadline
text: WASHINGTON — With the next budget deadline just weeks away, top lawmakers said this week that they had made significant progress negotiating a huge government-wide spending bill that gives the once mighty congressional Appropriations Committees an opportunity to reassert control over the flow of federal dollars.

headline: Islamic World Through Women’s Eyes
text: BOSTON — Middle Eastern women, supposedly powerless and oppressed behind walls and veils, are in fact a force in both society and the arts. They played a major role in the Arab Spring and continue to do so in the flourishing regional art scene — specifically in photography — which is alive and very well indeed. Some Middle Eastern photographers have taken their cameras to the barricades, physical ones and those less obvious, like the barriers erected by stereotypes, which they remain determined to defy. The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, takes note in “She Who Tells a Story: Women Photographers From Iran and the Arab World,” an ambitious and revealing exhibition of work by 12 women, some internationally known.

headline: ‘She Who Tells a Story: Women Photographers From Iran and the Arab World’
text: The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, presents an ambitious and revealing exhibition.

headline: Captive U.S. Citizen Makes Plea to Obama
text: Kidnapped by Al Qaeda in Pakistan more than two years ago, Warren Weinstein, 72, appealed to the president in a video message to negotiate his release.

headline: Intoxicating Prose
text: “Modern life,” Hemingway once wrote, “is often a mechanical oppression and liquor is the only mechanical relief.” It’s a pertinent observation if we remember that it was written in an age before other drugs had become widely available, but it’s also one of the premises of Olivia Laing’s charming and gusto-driven look at the alcoholic insanity of six famous writers, namely John Cheever, Tennessee Williams, John Berryman, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver. Rather than simply weld their stories together into a kind of collective biography, Laing weaves portraits of each man into an overland journey she made between New York and Port Angeles, Wash., last abode of Raymond Carver. The idea is to bind together cities and landscapes in which these men were immersed.

headline: Times Minute | Violence in Thailand
text: Also on the Minute, K-Pop meets Broadway and is 2014 going to be the year television dies?

headline: A Barrier to Emigration Falls for Bulgarians
text: On the first day of 2014, labor restrictions will end for Bulgarians and Romanians in nine European Union member states.

headline: The City at the Center of the World
text: The Dutch in the 17th century, Russell Shorto informs us at a characteristic moment in “Amsterdam: A History of the World’s Most Liberal City,” were on their way to becoming “the greatest shipping nation the world had ever seen.” Amsterdam’s canal ring was “the greatest urban feat of the age.” In fact, Shorto says, Amsterdam more or less gave us the American Revolution, the French Revolution, the Enlightenment and the stock exchange (though Antwerp’s stock exchange building is 80 years older). The United East India Company, put together in Amsterdam, was “unique in world history,” Shorto writes. It “remade the world.” It “pioneered globalization and invented what might be the first modern bureaucracy.” It inaugurated “the beginning of consumerism, which, for better or worse, is surely a component of liberalism.”

headline: As European Barriers Fall, Bulgarians Feel West’s Tug
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Ervin Ivanov, a fourth-year medical student, is sure he’ll leave Bulgaria, and he is sure that most of his classmates will too.

headline: Times Minute | Violence in Thailand
text: In the Video

headline: Homeowner’s ‘Cannons’ Warn Demolition Teams: No Closer
text: With hundreds of homes around him demolished, and fearing for his own, Zhou Jianbang, a man in Xingyang city, Henan Province, has built a half-dozen black “cannons” and stationed them around his house as warning to demolition teams to stay away, a state-run news agency reported.

headline: An Interview With Liz Eswein, Instagram User-Turned-Entrepreneur
text: We often read about how the founders of start-ups become rich and famous, but sometimes, users of new web services also find a way to benefit financially. Take Liz Eswein. Just a couple of years ago, she signed up to Instagram while a senior at New York University. Then she managed to turn that account into an Instagram-based business called The Mobile Media Lab, which has generated more than $1 million in revenue by helping brands use the service. The following is an edited interview with Ms. Eswein.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Lost Year of Tech, and Inside Apple
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Music Picks for Revelers
text: Critics and writers for The New York Times recommend New Year’s Eve pop music events in the city.

headline: Music for Final Hours, Set to Primal Beats
text: It’s over. It’s a wrap. Nothing more to see here. The damage is done. Finis. These are the lies we tell ourselves on New Year’s Eve, a holiday that ostensibly celebrates renewal but really places an arbitrary cap on a year’s worth of love and hurt and strife and joy and seals it, freeing up space to try again, once the ball drops. Going out on New Year’s Eve, then — that’s really for the people who want that jar sealed tight. They want to rage, to get lost in shamanistic fever, to laugh until the body doesn’t know how else to move. Here, writers for The New York Times weigh in on events that, for some, may fill a need for a sense of finality but that are also a reminder that even after the worst, life goes on. JON CARAMANICA

headline: Life on the Edge
text: IN environmental parlance, the ecotone is the zone where two habitats merge, that threshold where water meets the shore, where the forest comes to meadow, or where woodland ends at a cultivated lawn. It is the edge habitat where everything — soil content, vegetation, moisture, humidity, light, pollination — changes. It’s also where species from both sides converge, rendering it a place of complex interaction and diversity.

headline: A Big Push From Small Lenders
text: Big banks like Wells Fargo and Bank of America still rule the mortgage market, but their collective dominance has waned considerably over the last three years. Smaller lenders, some of them quite new, have stepped in to grab market share, often by emphasizing customer service and local expertise.

headline: Dietary Supplements and Safety
text: To the Editor:

headline: Should New Limits Be Put on N.S.A. Surveillance?
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘The Rural Life’ Had a Message for Each of Us
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toddlers and Tablets
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gifted in Math, and Poor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Unwanted Water and Smoke
text: The Great Smoke-Out

headline: Los Angeles Airport Shooting Suspect Pleads Not Guilty
text: RANCHO CUCAMONGA, Calif. — The man accused of killing one person and injuring three others during a shooting rampage last month at Los Angeles International Airport pleaded not guilty on Thursday to 11 federal charges, including the murder of a Transportation Security Administration officer, which could carry the death penalty.

headline: A Landmark Lost and Found
text: People who weren’t even born when Pennsylvania Station was demolished in 1963 burn with indignation. It’s a wound that won’t heal.

headline: Israeli Jets Strike Gaza Strip in Response to Rocket Attacks
text: JERUSALEM — For the second time in three days, the Israeli Air Force struck the Gaza Strip on Thursday night in response to rockets fired earlier from Gaza into Israel, continuing a new wave of violence that has complicated peace talks.

headline: Infection Resulting in Amputation Raises Questions About Asian Immigrants’ IV Use
text: Whenever the endless shifts at the day spa in Flushing, Queens, where Myung Hwa Jang worked got to be too draining, Ms. Jang’s colleagues would head down the street for some refreshment. And so on a brisk day in February, feeling run down, Ms. Jang found herself in a storefront clinic, a needle in her arm and a bag of solution she knows as “ringer” sliding into her veins.

headline: Restoring Ranch Land for a Profit, and a ‘Trout Dividend’
text: From the road skirting its property line, Freestone River Ranch looks like a flat, cattle-trodden pasture flanked by rolling hills. But Jay Ellis, founder of the private equity firm Sporting Ranch Capital Management, sees something sparkling in the distance. He slams on the brakes and jumps out of his rented sport utility vehicle to get a closer look at one of the dozens of natural springs spilling out from small aqueducts. “You could fill up your water bottle and drink it,” he says excitedly. “It’s that pure.”

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,285 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: As Food Programs Are Cut, Deer Hunters Share the Bounty
text: For hunters like Rick Prekup, deer season is the happiest time of the year.

headline: Overstock to Embrace Bitcoin, Giving the Currency a Lift
text: One of the biggest questions looming over Bitcoin, the digital currency generating attention in the tech business, is when big mainstream merchants will begin accepting it.

headline: I Promise to Do Things I Have No Power Over
text: The state’s top lawyer really is not a crime fighter, but you would not know that during election season.

headline: King of PCs, Lenovo Sets Smartphone Ambitions
text: In the United States, Lenovo is still best known as the Chinese company that bought IBM’s PC business in 2005.

headline: Ukraine: Third Suspect Detained in Beating of Activist
text: Ukrainian authorities on Thursday said they had detained a third man in connection with the brutal beating of an antigovernment activist and had increased the severity of potential charges in the case after initially deeming it a matter of “hooliganism.” The authorities also said that they were questioning three members of Parliament, though their connection to the case was unclear. The activist, Tetyana Chornovol, 34, was severely beaten Wednesday by men who forced her car off the road. Partly as a result of her description of the attack, the authorities said, the suspects now face possible charges of inflicting serious bodily harm. Ms. Chornovol, who is also a journalist, remained hospitalized on Thursday as hundreds of people marched on the Ministry of Interior Affairs and demanded the resignation of the minister, Vitaly Zakharchenko.

headline: Playing on America’s Love for Its 2-Ton Darlings
text: ABOUT a third of Americans have nicknames for their vehicles, according to the Auto Alliance, an automaker trade group, and now some marketers are highlighting the practice to strike a chord with consumers.

headline: Mike Hegan, 71, Player Who Made Long Journey Home
text: Mike Hegan, the scion of a Cleveland baseball family who played a dozen seasons elsewhere in the big leagues but returned to his hometown as a longtime broadcaster for the Indians, died on Wednesday in Hilton Head, S.C. He was 71.

headline: The Fear Economy
text: More than a million unemployed Americans are about to get the cruelest of Christmas “gifts.” They’re about to have their unemployment benefits cut off. You see, Republicans in Congress insist that if you haven’t found a job after months of searching, it must be because you aren’t trying hard enough. So you need an extra incentive in the form of sheer desperation.

headline: New Victories for Marriage Equality
text: With every new court ruling or legislative enactment or popular vote affirming Americans’ fundamental right to marry, the arguments against same-sex marriage sound increasingly desperate and hollow.

headline: Considering War’s Toll in Debate on Death Row
text: The car would not stop. Flares did not stop it. Shots fired into the engine had no effect. As far as the four Marines stationed at a roadside checkpoint in Iraq knew, the sedan hurtling toward them was a bomb on wheels.

headline: South Africans Band Together, Finding a New Enemy in Highway Tolls
text: JOHANNESBURG — The sleek, white structures began sprouting up over highways here about three years ago, leaving people to wonder what they were.

headline: South Sudan’s Imperiled Future
text: Two years after South Sudan declared independence from Sudan, political tensions between President Salva Kiir and Riek Machar, the former vice president, have erupted into violence, raising the possibility of civil war and ethnic cleansing.

headline: More Diversity in New York City’s Police Dept., but Blacks Lag
text: It is among Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly’s prouder legacies: A majority of the police officers in New York City are now members of minorities, and have been since roughly 2006.

headline: After Carriers Falter, Questions for Web Shopping
text: After years of preaching the convenience and reliability of online shopping — shop in your pajamas, with fast, free delivery — retailers may have been too successful at spreading the message this year, contributing to the volume of holiday orders that overwhelmed delivery services like U.P.S. and FedEx.

headline: Frederick Fox, Milliner to Royals, Dies at 82
text: Frederick Fox, who was 9 when he began designing hats for his mother and sisters to wear to church in their tiny Australian cattle town and grew up to become milliner to Diana, Princess of Wales, and Queen Elizabeth II of England, died on Dec. 11 in London. He was 82.

headline: Utah Ruling Means No Respite for the Supreme Court on Same-Sex Marriage
text: WASHINGTON — In June, when the Supreme Court stopped short of deciding whether the Constitution guaranteed a right to same-sex marriage, many thought the court had bought itself several years before it had to confront the question again.

headline: Bears’ Cutler to Finish Season in a Rival’s Shadow
text: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — At Halas Hall, the Chicago Bears’ practice complex, the news trickled in on Thursday afternoon — tweet by tweet, unconfirmed report after unconfirmed report — until it was finally official: The Green Bay Packers had named Aaron Rodgers their starting quarterback for their visit to Soldier Field on Sunday.

headline: New York Soon to Trail Florida in Population
text: ALBANY — New York, whose status as the most populous state has long been ceded, will soon fall behind Florida into fourth place, a long-anticipated drop that is rife with symbolism and that could carry potentially serious economic consequences in coming years.

headline: When Beauty Is Not (Exactly) Truth
text: Should we be more forthcoming about what we do to enhance our looks?

headline: Policing the Projects of New York City, at a Hefty Price
text: After riding the elevator to the top floor of a building in the Louis H. Pink Houses in Brooklyn and scanning the rooftop, the police officers made their way back down, floor by floor, searching the stairwells and hallways. On the sixth floor, slumped against the stairs, was a man who said he was waiting for his ex-girlfriend. The officers ran a warrant check on the 49-year-old man and arrested him after learning he was wanted for a parole violation.

headline: Risky Nationalism in Japan
text: On Thursday, one year after coming to power, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe visited Yasukuni, the controversial Shinto shrine that honors Japan’s war dead, including war criminals from World War II. China and South Korea swiftly criticized the move, as did the United States. Mr. Abe’s visit will worsen Japan’s already tense relations with China and South Korea, which see the shrine as a symbol of imperial Japan’s wars of aggression and colonialism. The United States Embassy said America was “disappointed that Japan’s leadership has taken an action that will exacerbate tensions with Japan’s neighbors.”

headline: Prominent Scholars, Citing Importance of Academic Freedom, Denounce Israeli Boycott
text: The American Studies Association’s endorsement this month of a boycott of Israeli academic institutions continues to stir passions, with four colleges and universities announcing their withdrawal from the association, a second leading higher-education association denouncing the boycott and a rising tide of college presidents speaking out against it.

headline: Monmouth Coach Leads by Example, Both Bad and Good
text: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J. — Josh James is a 6-foot-2 freshman point guard for Monmouth, lithe and agile, with an edge and a little tenacity, which can delight his coach but can also terrify him.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 17 Matchup Breakdown
text: With some N.F.L. teams out of contention and other (and better) teams potentially resting star players for the postseason, Week 17 is always difficult to navigate from a fantasy perspective. It is not easy to predict which players will give your fantasy squad a full performance, which is why most fantasy football leagues play their championship games in Week 16.

headline: Vista Workers Told Their U.S. Health Plan Fails Test
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has told Vista volunteers and other AmeriCorps workers that their government-provided health coverage does not measure up to the standards of the new health care law, and that they may be subject to financial penalties unless they obtain insurance elsewhere.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Dec. 26, 2013
The Sidney Awards, Part 1
text: The highly prestigious Sidney Awards go out to some of the best magazine essays of the year. This year, many of these essays probed the intersection between science and the humanities. Links to all can be found on the online edition of this column.

headline: 2 States May Seek Refunds From Health Site Creator
text: Two states that hired the same lead contractor to build their online marketplaces for health insurance under President Obama’s Affordable Care Act have experienced so many problems and delays that they are threatening to withhold millions of dollars in payments to the company and even seek refunds.

headline: For ESPN, Millions to Remain in Connecticut
text: BRISTOL, Conn. — The governor of Connecticut arrived at ESPN’s expansive campus here to celebrate the groundbreaking of the sports media giant’s 19th building, a digital center that would be the new home of “SportsCenter.” It was August 2011, and this was the third visit in a year by Gov. Dannel P. Malloy, whose first was about three weeks before his election.

headline: Homicidal Psycho Jungle Cat
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — If you’re just joining us, the J.A.S.A. Crossword Class is a wonderful resource in New York City for those who want to learn how to construct a puzzle. Caleb Madison used to teach it, and when he went off to college (no, that’s not a typo), Ian Livengood took over the teaching duties. There’s a link at the bottom of this post if you’d like to learn more about the class.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 27, 2013
text: “When you think about the U.S., you can’t just think about New York and L.A. Don’t get me wrong, L.A. is fabulous. New York is great. But if you want to connect with American life, it’s Toledo.”

headline: His Green Card Returned, Doors Reopen
text: On July 22, 2011, José Arias and José del Carmen Arias, then 19, were just another father and son in a long security line at the San Juan Airport in Puerto Rico. Both had green cards showing they were lawful residents of the United States. They had made this journey — from the Dominican Republic, where both were born, back to Puerto Rico, where they lived — many times before.

headline: A Boxing Day Bounty for Premier League Fans
text: LONDON — Only in England is the day after Christmas such an inclusive day of sports. It might be cold out there, but racehorses pull in bumper crowds. Followers of cricket sit through the night, knowing that England faces a humiliating whitewash in Australia. And anywhere there is a soccer club, most seats in the house are sold because it is a time-honored tradition in Britain to fill Boxing Day with sports, like filling children’s stockings with gifts.

headline: Spitzer’s Company Buys Coveted Parcel on the West Side
text: Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer is getting into the development business on the West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Owner’s Drug Arrest Puts Future of Acclaimed Restaurant in Doubt
text: Once there were veal sweetbreads and ocean trout, rave reviews and $120 tasting menus for Gwynnett St., a fine-dining restaurant whose ambition seemed out of place in East Williamsburg.

headline: John Miller, CBS Correspondent, to Join New York Police Dept. Again
text: John Miller, a prominent CBS News correspondent who drew both praise and scrutiny for his ability to leverage his law-enforcement and national security contacts for big news stories, is leaving the network to work in counterterrorism for the New York Police Department, CBS announced on Thursday.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 1:45 P.M. (IFC) THE ASSASSINATION OF JESSE JAMES BY THE COWARD ROBERT FORD (2007) Andrew Dominik directed this contemplative portrait of the final days of the outlaw Jesse James (Brad Pitt, above) and his gang (Sam Rockwell, Paul Schneider, Jeremy Renner and others). One member of the posse is Robert Ford (Casey Affleck), who is more obsessed fan than loyal sidekick. And when Jesse James, the man, does not live up to the myth, Ford decides to grab a piece of fame for himself. “Dressed in near-all black, the question mark known as Jesse James stands away from the camera, knee-deep in a golden, grassy field stirred by the wind or perhaps just an off-screen mechanical fan,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “The cinematography may speak to Mr. Dominik’s yearning for meaning and importance more than it does of his outlaw, but the visuals often dazzle and enthrall.” Roger Deakins received an Oscar nomination for best cinematography for his work on the film, and Mr. Affleck was nominated for best supporting actor.

headline: Bomb in Beirut Kills Politician, a Critic of Syria and Hezbollah
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The bomb that tore through downtown Beirut on Friday killed a former Lebanese finance minister who was a prominent critic of the Syrian government — an attack that unleashed a storm of political recriminations that threaten the fragile entente keeping the Syrian war from spilling outright into Lebanon.

headline: New Tensions Cloud Deal for Okinawa Base
text: TOKYO — Even as officials on both sides of the Pacific hailed an agreement to resolve a tangled dispute over a Marine base on Okinawa, strong opposition to the deal in Okinawa and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s recent visit to a war shrine cast a shadow over the diplomatic celebration.

headline: A New Year’s Prediction
text: Prospects for an end to the war in Syria in 2014 look dim.

headline: Mexican Cowboys in a YouTube World
text: The trail that led Werner Segarra to being a cowboy snaked from Puerto Rico, Germany, Saudi Arabia and Arizona before he found himself at a ranch in Huásabas, Mexico. Mind you, when he first got there — part of a 10-day high school travel experience — he (and his teacher) thought he was going to work in a gas station. He imagined himself popping out tires and checking the oil.

headline: With Flowers, Ai Weiwei Protests His Loss of Freedom
text: Every morning the artist and dissident Ai Weiwei places fresh flowers in the basket of a bicycle outside his Beijing studio in a pretty protest at something serious: a government ban on his freedom to travel.

headline: Times Minute | Egypt's Decision
text: Florida will soon pass New York as the third most populous state. Also on the Minute, the crackdown on the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt and looking back at the Iran nuclear accord.

headline: If You’re ’Appy and You Know It
text: PARIS — Recently my daughter’s teacher asked if I would talk about America to her second-grade class, in a French public school. The teacher does an hour of English each week, and I’d be the guest speaker.

headline: Prosecutor Overseeing Turkish Graft Inquiry Is Removed From Case
text: ISTANBUL — An Istanbul prosecutor who had been overseeing a sprawling corruption investigation of the prime minister’s inner circle was removed from the case on Thursday, in a new sign of a profound power struggle over Turkey’s judiciary and police forces.

headline: Daily Report: Lenovo Seeks to Expand Success Beyond Laptops
text: In the United States, Lenovo is still best known as the Chinese company that bought IBM’s PC business in 2005. But in China, it is better known as the world’s new No. 1 PC maker, a force to be reckoned with in smartphones and a bellwether for the nation’s economic and technological might, Eric Pfanner reports.

headline: Indian Deaths Underscore Risks in U.N. Peacekeeping Missions
text: The family of Dharmesh Sangwan would have phoned the United Nations soldier in South Sudan on his 34th birthday on Sunday, and then welcomed him home 10 days later for a big celebration in their village in Haryana.

headline: Convoy Attack in Kabul Kills 3 Coalition Soldiers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A car bomb struck a military convoy on a major road in Kabul on Friday, killing three coalition soldiers and underscoring the continuing threat to foreign troops even as they assume a diminishing role in combat operations.

headline: Game Theory: Exploring Meaningful Violence
text: “Boring” isn’t usually the first word that comes to mind when one thinks about violence. And yet that’s exactly how I felt about so much of the shooting, maiming and torturing in the video games of 2013. As I nodded off amid my 40th gunfight in the first-person shooter BioShock Infinite, I had to ask: Am I desensitized to video game violence, or is there something more going on here?

headline: A Fellow Lover of Smoked-Fish Ends
text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Conversation With: Aam Aadmi Party Leader Arvind Kejriwal
text: Braving the cold wind and rain on Friday morning, a motley crowd gathered in the lobby of an apartment building in the industrial city of Ghaziabad on the outskirts of Delhi. Each time the cranky elevator machinery whirred, heads turned and the group held its collective breath in anticipation of Arvind Kejriwal, leader of the Aam Aadmi Party.

headline: Image of the Day: December 27
text: Laborers keeping themselves warm on a cold day in New Delhi.

headline: BEST OF 2013
text: These 15 stories delved into culinary innovation, food world trends and, of course, delicious dishes.

headline: No Gifts, Please. Just Praise My Good Intentions
text: For her 11th birthday, Madison Helm of Marlton, N.J., had a few requests. She wanted to hold a slumber party for six of her closest friends. She wanted them to bring an item on the Animal Welfare Association’s wish list instead of a gift. She also, at an age her parents deem too young to have her own Facebook account, wanted her mother to publish a status update on the social networking site immediately to give her family and friends the chance to applaud her charitable affair.

headline: Prisoners of Pardon
text: MOSCOW — For a long time now many Russians have shared a single dream: to see Mikhail Khodorkovsky free. During the 10 years that the former oil tycoon spent in prison, the image of a liberated Khodorkovsky came to symbolize a number of outcomes: a victory for the opposition, the appearance of a bona fide political alternative to President Vladimir Putin, and perhaps even the end of the Putin era.
