text: This week: ideas in pop, 2013.

headline: Sherlock Holmes Is in the Public Domain, American Judge Rules
text: In the more than 125 years since he first appeared, Sherlock Holmes has popped up everywhere from fan fiction set in outer space to screen adaptations like CBS’s “Elementary,” set in contemporary Manhattan. But now, following a legal ruling, the deerstalker-wearing detective is headed to another destination: the public domain.

headline: This Week's Movies: Dec. 27, 2013
text: The New York Times movie critics on three new releases.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Writers and Drinking
text: This week, Olivia Laing and John Williams.

headline: Poetry
text: HELLO, THE ROSES  By Mei-mei Berssenbrugge  New Directions, paper, $16.95.

headline: The All-Inclusive List of Lists
text: If you feel you’ve seen lists that slice and dice the books of 2013 in every way imaginable, then you haven’t visited the music and literature blog Largehearted Boy. David Gutowski, the man behind the site, aggregates year-end books coverage. With a full two weeks left in the year, his list of lists had 834 entries.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BETWEEN MAN AND BEAST: An Unlikely Explorer and the African Adventure That Took the Victorian World by Storm,  by Monte Reel. (Anchor, $15.95.) In 1859, Paul Du Chaillu emerged from a four-year hunting expedition in Gabon with a major zoological discovery: 20 preserved skins of a massive ape, which soon took its familiar name — gorilla. Reel’s robust intellectual history recounts Du Chaillu’s exploits and places his “objects of wonder” at the center of the nascent debate over Charles Darwin’s theories about the origin and nature of mankind.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: AMERICAN MIRROR: The Life and Art of Norman Rockwell,  by Deborah Solomon. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) Solomon pays honest respect to Rockwell for his dedication through periods of self-doubt, depression and marital tumult.

headline: Bullet Diplomacy
text: In “Small Wars, Faraway Places,” Michael Burleigh recounts the violent end of the British and French empires in Africa and Asia, and their partial replacement by the United States in its often ill-informed and costly efforts to combat Communism during the early stages of the Cold War. Burleigh surveys many of the major international wars and anticolonial insurgencies between 1945 and 1965, but opts to focus most on those involving America, Britain and France, and how they related to the rivalry with the Soviet Union. The result is a well-researched and readable account of two tumultuous decades. Burleigh judges most of these wars, both small and large, to have been futile and destructive. But while he clearly has no interest in defending or rehabilitating such conflicts, he nonetheless offers a fair, thoughtful assessment of the motives and interests behind them. He also takes care to understand and explain the grievances of the insurgents.

headline: Man Against Nature
text: “The superficial reader will get the love story & the adventure,” Jack London wrote, in 1903, of the story that would become “The Sea-Wolf,” “while the deeper reader will get all of this, plus the bigger thing lying underneath.” These are the typically blunt words of a writer who seemed to think of his work in terms of purchase value. Here, he might have been describing his own life: much adventure, a sort of love story, a weird bang of a finish. In a new biography by the London scholar Earle Labor, the “bigger thing” has a harder time coming out: Perhaps it doesn’t exist.

headline: Stealth Maneuvers
text: Imagine the writer as a wager of war. Some stun with shock-and-awe prose, surprise plot twists, barrages of literary ordnance. Others deploy steady blasts of sentiment, turning heartstrings into so many tripwires. But some conduct a subtler campaign, built on stealth maneuvers: escalating schemes, deft and imperceptible, that quietly, thrillingly, devastate. ­Frederick Busch, the author of more than two dozen books, who died in 2006 at the age of 64, was a master of this approach.

headline: Close Quarters
text: It is tempting to call “Communion Town” a novel about a city. But neither “novel” nor “city” quite captures the eerie multi­dimensionality of Sam Thompson’s dazzling debut; everything about “Communion Town” — from its genre to its subject to its shifting perspectives — proves to be more complicated than it seems. At the end of the book, the city remains as hazy to readers as shadows on the walls of a cave. What “Communion Town” renders with stunning and often heartbreaking lucidity is the complexity of consciousness itself.

headline: Guests of the Ayatollah
text: To write about one’s country while living in another is to invite questions about loyalty. Why are you writing this? And for whom? The questions can take an ominous tone: What is your agenda? The journalist Hooman Majd faced such suspicions on one of his trips to Tehran, when an employee from the Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance told him bluntly: “Just because you have an Iranian passport doesn’t mean you can come here and write whatever you want when you leave.”

headline: Little Angels
text: Is morality innate? In his new book, “Just Babies,” the psychologist Paul Bloom draws from his research at the Yale Infant Cognition Center to argue that “certain moral foundations are not acquired through learning. . . . They are instead the products of biological evolution.” Infants may be notoriously difficult to study (rats and pigeons “can at least run mazes or peck at levers”), but according to Bloom, they are, in fact, “moral creatures.”

headline: Storm Clouds in the Aura of a Sunny Teenage Pop Star
text: The key moment in “Justin Bieber’s Believe,” the new hagiographical film, comes in the second half, in a segment that touches ever so lightly upon Mr. Bieber’s tumultuous public image over the last year. The scene is London, last March: A small cluster of paparazzi is egging Mr. Bieber on, and he takes the bait, jumping at the photographers and being held back by a bodyguard. At least half of the conversation (on both sides) is bleeped.

headline: Best of 2013 | The Year in Food
text: These 15 stories delved into culinary innovation, food world trends and, of course, delicious dishes. Read…

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Wolf of Wall Street,’ ‘August: Osage County’ and ‘The Secret Life of Walter Mitty’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics review Ben Stiller’s “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty,” John Wells’s “August: Osage County” and Martin Scorsese’s “The Wolf of Wall Street.” All of this week’s reviews are here.

headline: Argentina Tries to Give Malbec More Status
text: In Argentina, where the malbec grape is king, winemakers have put an intriguing spin on what is usually known as a Bordeaux blend. Instead of the typical mix of cabernet sauvignon, cabernet franc and merlot, they are relying primarily on cabernet sauvignon and malbec.

headline: Inside the List
text: Best of the Best: The Book Review has had its say; a few weeks ago, we named our 10 Best Books of 2013. But in the interests of inclusiveness — and, O.K., advance planning before the holidays — I wondered what our 10 best authors would pick as their favorites. So I asked them. The rules were simple: Tell us the best book you read this year (whether it was published in 2013 or not) and, briefly, describe it. Not everybody responded — I wasn’t the only one beleaguered by sugarplums — but enough did to devote the column this week, and next, to their replies: the best books as chosen by the authors of the best books, a sort of chain letter of terrific reading ideas. Here they are.

headline: Deadly Bomb Attack Rocks a Restaurant in Somalia’s Capital
text: PARIS — At least 10 people were killed in Mogadishu, the Somali capital, on Friday when a remote-controlled bomb exploded in a restaurant in the northwestern part of the city, government officials said.

headline: ‘Wolf’ Leads the Pack of Newcomers at Christmas Box Office
text: Box-office analysts are typically able to predict with eerie precision whether a movie will be a hit or a miss just by examining opening-day ticket sales. There is one exception: Christmastime. Because studios release so many pictures in such short order and so many moviegoers are on vacation, initial grosses can be deceptive; films that look soft can find their footing or fall off sharply.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

text: The first in an occasional series about vintage comics.

headline: China’s Banks Are on the Rise
text: China’s banks are racking up foreign assets, driven by trade flows, and the country’s corporate diaspora. Even at the current slow pace, what today looks like “following the client” could soon become “following everyone’s clients.” (See chart.)

headline: You Too Can Play the Hotel Game
text: Forget matching colorful candy pieces or farming zombies. How about a mobile game that tests your juggling skills by managing a virtual hotel?

headline: A New York Minute
text: OK, I’m a New Yorker. So says the dialect questionnaire from the Times, which I’ve just gotten around to; try it, it’s fun. Actually, what it said is that I’m from New York, Yonkers, or Newark — but close enough.

headline: In Battle Against Fraud in Free Phone Service, the Poor Might Pay the Price
text: AUSTELL, Ga. — From her trailer with a rusting roof on Lot 54, Donna James uses the free Samsung cellphone provided by a federal program to speak with friends who give her rides, clerks at medical offices, a caseworker, emergency dispatchers and, of course, bill collectors.

headline: In 2013: Rebounds, Traders and Rights
text: What a difference a year has made for Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix.

headline: Music Collective’s Concert to Benefit New York Youth Center
text: Late Bloomers, a collective of music and arts professionals interested in community causes, announced on Friday that it will present a series of benefit performances featuring young New York performers to raise money for local organizations that do charitable work. The group’s first event is a concert to benefit the Ali Forney Center, a shelter and support center for homeless gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender youth that has outposts in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan.

headline: The Big Screwup
text: You know how it went. They made big promises: just go to the website, provide the information, and all will be well. What actually happened was nothing like that. It’s true that many, perhaps most people did in the end manage to get what they sought; but millions found themselves frustrated and angry. Was it a disaster? That depends on which anecdotes you choose to emphasize. Will it have long-run consequences? Too soon to tell.

text: Also on the Minute, tax incentives for ESPN and revisiting the government shutdown.

text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday ruled that a National Security Agency program that collects enormous troves of phone records is legal, making the latest contribution to an extraordinary debate among courts and a presidential review group about how to balance security and privacy in the era of big data.

headline: Revisiting Inventions and Cellphone Contracts
text: MY final column of the year gives me a chance to revisit some topics from 2013 to see what has changed or what, as astute readers have pointed out, I didn’t include in the first go-round.

headline: On the Asymmetry of Booms and Slumps (Wonkish)
text: Something I’m thinking about: Recently Antonio Fatas listed four ingredients that he considered missing in macroeconomic models, with the first element being the asymmetry of the business cycle. Basically, the standard models say that output fluctuates around a normal level, with the ups and downs equal in size, and that all policy can do is reduce the variance. Fatas believes, however, that the business cycle is better seen as occasional drops below potential output, then returns to trend — a view that makes good policy much more important. I agree. But why?

headline: Winch Cats Take to the Steepest Slopes
text: When the going gets steep, the smart use winch cats.

headline: Illegal Video Downloads Continue Upward Trajectory
text: There are some lists where you don’t want to be crowned as the winner: most likely not to succeed, for example, or most boring person of the year. And if you own a company that makes and sells TV shows, having one of your creations at the top of the Most Pirated Show on Television list probably isn’t something you’d stick on your fridge.

headline: Taking Stock of 2 Thefts With Little in Common Except Their Status: Unsolved
text: In a perfect world, or at least a perfect newspaper story, the two objects, each of extreme value in its own way, would not only turn up, but would be discovered in the same place — a breathtaking trove. In this scenario, a master thief has stashed them away in his underground lair, where he gazes upon them from time to time, chuckling over a Cognac.

headline: Let’s Hope the Hangover Is Virtual
text: On Tuesday evening, when Times Square is mobbed, Dr. Maria Evans, a 53-year-old surgical and clinical pathologist, will be having a party in Kirksville, Mo.

headline: Linda Ronstadt’s Borderland
text: We are driving outside Naco, Ariz., near the Mexico border, on a two-lane blacktop under a half-moon and stars. The distant mountains are lost in shadow, and there’s not much to look at beyond the headlight beams and the rolling highway stripes.

headline: Aftermath of an Explosion in Beirut
text: An explosion downtown killed at least six people and injured dozens. Mohamad B. Chatah, a former ambassador to the U.S. is among the dead.

headline: A Road Trip Through Ronstadt Country
text: Scenes from a journey with the singer between Arizona and Mexico.

headline: Freed Pussy Riot Activists Stand Firm and Shift Focus
text: Four days after their release from a Russian prison, two members of the punk band Pussy Riot gave their first news conference to emphasize that they were starting a human rights organization, while sticking by the message that put them in jail: ending the presidency of Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Dodging a Holiday in a Remote Mexican Town
text: The night before Thanksgiving, while most of my acquaintances were setting tables or stuffing turkeys, I was in a lonesome town in Mexico, watching a salamander eat mosquitoes on a greasy kitchen wall. It was a hungry thing and went about devouring its prey with whip-quick lashes of an energetic tongue. Though I had chosen to avoid the feast day in the north, I didn’t mind the little lizard’s gluttony. Its meal, after all, was untroubled by the usual distractions: by football on TV or, moreover, the familiar family dramas. Despite — or perhaps because of — its enforced veneer of bliss, the month between the Macy’s parade and the Times Square ball drop can often inspire an unseasonable longing to escape.

headline: Events in Westchester for Dec. 29-Jan. 4
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: 15th-Century Italian Panels to Tour United States
text: Three marble panels depicting children singing and playing music, which the Italian sculptor Luca della Robbia created for the Florence Cathedral’s organ loft, will go on tour in the United States, traveling first to the High Museum of Art in Atlanta from Oct. 25 until Jan. 11, 2015.

headline: In 2013, the High End Ruled
text: Rising demand and a record shortage of apartment listings set the stage for a seller’s market in 2013. But new development stole the spotlight.

headline: Review: 2014 Kia Soul
text: To humans and hamsters, the Kia Soul has been a design touchstone. It’s often the Korean brand’s best-selling model, so designing an all-new version was no small task.

headline: Syrian Security Forces Kill Dozens of Rebels in Ambush
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces ambushed and killed dozens of insurgents on Friday near the ancient Christian town of Maaloula, north of Damascus, during fighting close to the Lebanese border, Syrian rebels and government television said. Syrian state television said that government forces killed more than 60 fighters from the Nusra Front, an insurgent group with links to Al Qaeda. A Syrian rebel commander in the area, Abou al-Majd, said the attack killed more than 20 fighters, including Syrian members of Nusra and other local rebels. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, an organization based in Britain that tracks the conflict through a network of contacts in Syria, reported that dozens of fighters had been killed, and that 20 had been wounded. A government offensive has been taking place in the mountainous Qalamoun region for several weeks, driving a new wave of refugees into Lebanon.

headline: Big Ticket | A Park Avenue Gem for $18 Million
text: A full-floor apartment at the Rosario Candela-designed 778 Park Avenue at East 73rd Street, held by the estate of the New York City philanthropist Celeste Bartos, sold for $18 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. Listed for the first time since 1943, the 10-room full-floor unit, No. FL17, had a $22.5 million asking price and has $18,658.32 in monthly carrying costs.

headline: Maserati Recalls Cars; Mercedes-Benz Investigation Is Upgraded
text: Maserati will recall 63 of its 2014 Quattroporte GTS V8 models because of a possible loss of electrical power and a potential fire risk, according to a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: In Sign of Strength, Audi Steps Up Investments
text: FRANKFURT — Audi, the luxury car unit of Volkswagen, said on Friday that it would spend more than it ever has on expansion and new models over the next four years, a demonstration of how Germany’s high-end carmakers have retained their financial strength during a crisis that has devastated their European rivals.

headline: Video: The Next-Generation Kia Soul Keeps Its Soul
text: When Kia introduced the first-generation Soul for the 2010 model year, many dismissed it as a blatant rip-off of the Scion xB. Perhaps, but Soul went on to outsell the xB six to one. Who knew hamsters had that kind of disposable income (or could reach the pedals)?

headline: Vote on Monte dei Paschi’s Future Is Postponed
text: SIENA, Italy — The latest chapter in the saga of Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the world’s oldest bank, ended inconclusively Friday after a decision on a rescue plan was postponed amid a quarrel between top management and the bank’s largest shareholder.

headline: The Stars Inside the Building
text: The real estate industry in New York City continues to produce pricey new condominiums, seemingly at the rate of tennis balls spit out of a ball launcher. This market revival has pushed the role of the boldface architect back into the spotlight, although that position may have to be shared this time around with interior designers.

headline: Events on Long Island for Dec. 29-Jan. 4
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Mission Schools Opened World to Africans, but Left an Ambiguous Legacy
text: Of the hundreds of pages in Nelson Mandela’s autobiography, “Long Walk to Freedom,” barely a dozen recount his college education at the University of Fort Hare, established by white Christian missionaries. He spent less than two of his 95 years there. Most obituaries made only a brief mention of that period.Mandela left Fort Hare partway through his studies during a conflict with its leader, a Scottish evangelist named Alexander Kerr, about a student boycott of college elections. “At that moment, I saw Dr. Kerr less as a benefactor than as a not-altogether-benign dictator,” Mandela wrote in his memoirs. As for himself, a 22-year-old at that point in late 1940, “I was in an unpleasant state of limbo.”

headline: Adding Citrus to Salads and Desserts
text: I always stuff an orange or a tangerine into the toe of my son’s Christmas stocking. He is more interested in the chocolate in his stocking and I usually end up eating his orange, but I’ll never forego this European tradition that dates from a time when citrus was a rare treat. We in the United States take our oranges and grapefruit for granted year round, but citrus really does have a season — winter — and it is welcome at this time of year, when we need all the vitamin C we can get.

headline: Target’s Nightmare Goes On: Encrypted PIN Data Stolen
text: After hackers stole credit and debit card records for 40 million Target store customers, the retailer said customers’ personal identification numbers, or PINs, had not been breached.

headline: Where Celebrity Assistants Go When They’re Losing Their Minds
text: In this past weekend’s Lives column, Jessica Berger Gross, who worked as Bella Abzug’s personal assistant in the late ’90s, wrote about finding emotional support in a confidential gathering held by the Association of Celebrity Personal Assistants. Intrigued, we got in touch with one of the association’s founders, Rita Tateel, to find out more about the group.

headline: Charities That Inspire Kids: The Ronald McDonald House
text: Earlier this month, I asked readers to share stories of charities that had touched and inspired their families and sparked an urge to give in their children. As we head through what’s often a week of charitable giving for many and into 2014, we’ll post some of those stories here.The Ronald McDonald House

headline: At Long Island Restaurants, Fondue Is Melted Comfort
text: On a recent Saturday afternoon, several groups of diners who had come in from the cold could be seen huddling around bubbling pots of cheese fondue at the Village Cheese Shop in Mattituck. “Nostalgic and interactive and warming” is how the owner of the 13-year-old-shop, Rosemary Dougherty Batcheller, 54, described the appeal of fondue. “You linger over it, and it has a festive feeling.”

headline: Children Need To Take Risks, and Parents Need to Let Them
text: I’m haunted by a 3-year-old French girl in a buttercup-yellow dress. She’s a vague remnant from an article I read sometime in the last two to three years about the supreme competence of French children. While her mother chatted with a reporter in the living room, the girl very ably made cupcakes in the kitchen. In the years since I read the article, she periodically appears in my life as a rebuke against too much caution.

headline: Tinkering by Beijing
text: The People’s Bank of China has allowed extremely sharp movements in interbank lending rates, discouraging banks from relying too heavily on short-term borrowing.

headline: Markets on Edge as China Moves to Curb Risky Lending
text: HONG KONG — China’s financial system is in danger of becoming too big to bail out.

headline: A Reluctant Bride Conquers Her Fears
text: When Marvin Coote kissed Rachel Skiffer not long after they met at a dance at Harvard, it was just her fourth real kiss — and one of the previous three had come during a game of “Truth or Dare.”

headline: Art Matters | Korakrit Arunanondchai, the Rapping, Body-Painting Free Spirit of the Art World
text: “This summer while I was in Thailand, I made a fake road movie with my twin,” Korakrit Arunanondchai says. “He plays me and I play him; I play a Manchester United fan and he plays, like, a denim painter. We go on a soul-searching journey together.”

headline: Last Words From a Beirut Bombing Victim
text: Video and social media images of a bomb blast in downtown Beirut were widely shared online, highlighting the first such attack in several years to hit the capital’s business district as well as some of the final public remarks and writings of a prominent Lebanese politician who was among the six people killed.

headline: Week 17 N.F.L. Matchups: Big Games in Underwhelming Divisions
text: Eagles (9-6) at Cowboys (8-7)

headline: The Farm-to-Centerpiece Movement
text: Not long ago, Jessica Gigot might have had a hard time designing a seasonal bouquet for her February wedding, even in the coastal Pacific Northwest with a relatively mild climate and long growing season.

headline: Serving Comfort Food and Beyond
text: Twofiftytwo Restaurant in Bedminster occupies an Arts and Crafts-style bungalow painted a beautiful deep red and featuring a wide and welcoming front porch. Such innocence hardly prepares you for the elegance of its interior, a room of pale grays and creams with wood veneer tables and foam-green leather banquettes. Only expensive spas project this kind of serenity.

headline: What I Love | Jonathan and Faye Kellerman
text: When in New York, the writers Jonathan Kellerman and Faye Kellerman retreat to a pied-à-terre near the park.

headline: Change Would Be Criminal
text: It used to be that when the Los Angeles-based novelist Jonathan Kellerman came to the city that never sleeps, he never slept either. “I was here all the time for book tours, for business with my publisher,” said Mr. Kellerman, 64, who is married to a fellow best-selling crime writer, Faye Kellerman. “I stayed at the best hotels, but they were always noisy and I never got a night’s rest.”

headline: Customizing Trips With a Computer Assist
text: Guidebooks and crowdsourced travel websites compete with advice on where to go. But the new site Trekkel attempts to automate a trip designer’s job by asking users to rate their interests and itemizing a custom list of recommendations in return.

headline: Through the Winter on a Locally Sourced Menu
text: Although chefs at farm-to-table restaurants in Connecticut build their menus around locally sourced ingredients, few match the commitment of Kim Dziubinski, the owner of Seagrass Grill in the Indian Neck neighborhood of Branford. She is making her way through its first winter — it opened in April — with the goal of using only fruits, vegetables, dairy products, meats and poultry that are locally produced and, whenever possible, organic.

headline: On Twitter, Documenting an Antarctic Journey and a Countdown to a Rescue
text: A Chinese vessel is battling severe weather and ice jams as it tries to make its way toward a research ship wedged in Antarctic ice, and the ordeal has been documented in social media postings by a professor on the ship, Chris Turney.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Writers and the Bottle
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Lawrence Osborne reviews Olivia Laing’s “The Trip to Echo Spring,” which chronicles the alcoholism of six American writers: John Cheever, Tennessee Williams, John Berryman, Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver. Mr. Osborne writes:

headline: Beyoncé Stays on Top
text: Beyoncé’s new album, released by surprise on iTunes, has held at No. 1 for a second week and has now sold almost a million copies in the United States, even as some retailers refuse to stock it.

headline: Lawrence Ulrich’s Top 12 of 2013
text: In 2013, the best new models included many stellar sports cars, perhaps signaling that good times are about to roll.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: James G. Cobb’s Top 12 of 2013
text: It was a good year for car buyers, as postrecession investments paid off, bringing interesting models to showrooms.

headline: When Love Grows Steamy, Don’t Use the Ironing Board
text: The phrase “saved the worst for last” comes to mind.

headline: A Condo for Art Collectors
text: Supporters of the High Line, the wildly popular elevated park, are quick to point out that it has catalyzed the redevelopment of West Chelsea. What may get lost in the enthusiasm is the fact that art galleries, too, have provided a major spark, going back to the 1990s, when they first began appearing amid factories in this longtime industrial area.

headline: Critics’ Picks: Recovery Is Paying Off
text: It was the year when Fisker fizzled and Coda collapsed, along with the dreams of several other would-be automakers. Tesla provided endless drama as its chief executive, Elon Musk, swatted at naysayers, state dealer associations and federal regulators, even as the Model S became a trophy car for the affluent and tech-savvy.

headline: Tune In, and Turn On the Reading Light
text: Mark Lewisohn never intended to become a Beatles biographer. His interest was mainly in pure research, and his first books were compilations of facts: an annotated listing of all the Beatles’ concerts (“The Beatles Live,” 1986); a descriptive catalog of the music, released and unreleased, in EMI archives (“The Beatles Recording Sessions: The Official Abbey Road Studio Sessions Notes, 1962-1970,” 1988); and a record of the group’s radio and television appearances (“The Complete Beatles Chronicle,” 1992). Around the time his recording sessions book was published, he described the market for Beatles biographies as oversaturated.

headline: Ale’s Not Just for Drinking
text: Gastro pubs have been popping up across Westchester for several years, bringing hundreds of craft beers to diners’ attention, from light lagers to imperial stouts. Along with interesting food, these gastro pubs will offer 10, sometimes 20 different drafts at a time and dozens of bottled choices, including those from Captain Lawrence, the eight-year-old Elmsford brewery that makes about 15 different brews, and Yonkers Brewing Co., founded in 2010. Peekskill Brewery, an ambitious restaurant in that Hudson River town, even makes its own beer.

headline: Distributor Apologizes for Movie Posters Ignoring Chiwetel Ejiofor
text: BIM Distribuzione, the film distribution company that is marketing “12 Years a Slave” in Italy, has formally apologized for distributing posters and publicity materials that played down Chiwetel Ejiofor, the black actor who is the film’s protagonist, while prominently featuring two white supporting actors: Michael Fassbender, who plays a sadistic slave owner, and Brad Pitt, who has a small role as a laborer.

headline: Dream Boats
text: The most noteworthy design studies of 2013.

headline: India Finds New Methods to Punish U.S. Diplomats
text: NEW DELHI — India’s diplomatic corps, still seething over the arrest of an Indian diplomat in New York, continued its tit-for-tat campaign against American diplomats this week, revoking privileges, beginning tax investigations and issuing new consular identity cards that say the card holder can be arrested for serious offenses.

headline: Movie Review: 'The Wolf of Wall Street'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Wolf of Wall Street."

headline: Movie Review: 'August: Osage County'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "August: Osage County."

headline: 'The Secret Life of Walter Mitty'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty."

headline: Final Report on Sandy Hook Killings Sheds New Light on Gunman’s Isolation
text: Authorities in Connecticut released a final report on Friday outlining the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown on Dec. 14, 2012, providing the most complete account to date for one of the nation’s most wrenching massacres.

headline: At Lloyds, a Bank and Its Boss on the Rebound
text: António Horta-Osório was eight months into his new job as chief executive of the Lloyds Banking Group in 2011, wrestling with a plan to refocus the British lender, when he stopped sleeping.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A Westchester five-bedroom home on six acres, a sprawling Fort Lee waterfront condo; and a Nassau contemporary with an artsy two-sided fireplace.

headline: Arrest Warrant for Hédiard Owner Is Revoked
text: MOSCOW — A court in Moscow on Friday withdrew an arrest warrant for the Russian banker Sergei Pugachev, the owner of the French luxury food chain Hédiard, a day after the warrant’s issuance had been prominently reported in the Russian business newspaper Kommersant.

headline: A Refusal Stands Strong, 32 Years Later
text: It has been 32 years since Jennifer Holliday unleashed on the world her version of “And I Am Telling You I’m Not Going,” in the original Broadway production of “Dreamgirls,” and pop-gospel belting hasn’t been the same since. Like the sound of thunder rolling off a mountain, its echoes cascading for miles, Ms. Holliday’s voice resounded with a power that combined the range of Sarah Vaughan with the fervor of Aretha Franklin. And at Thursday’s sensational opening-night show of her debut at 54 Below, Ms. Holliday infused that howl of refusal with the same defiant, fearsome intensity she displayed onstage three decades earlier.

headline: Aiming to Reinvent Itself, Panasonic Moves Beyond the Living Room
text: FUJISAWA, Japan — Panasonic used to make televisions, refrigerators and computer monitors in this suburb of Tokyo. Now, six years after closing its factories in Fujisawa, the company is building homes on the site, which is sandwiched between Mount Fuji and the Pacific.

headline: A Year of Teasing at Shapes to Come (and Sometimes Just Teasing)
text: As in most years, the international auto salons of 2013 showcased scores of futuristic design studies and fanciful concept cars among their attractions. Some of the vehicles were merely exercises in styling fantasy; others hinted at exciting, mold-breaking production cars to come.

headline: Plug In, Turn On, Pass Gas Station
text: When the final figures for 2013 are tabulated, sales of battery-electric and plug-in vehicles in the United States are expected to nearly double 2012’s totals, according to the Electric Drive Transportation Association, a trade group based in Washington. Even so, that is fewer than 100,000 vehicles, in a year when the industry is on track to comfortably top 15 million sales.

headline: Of Hovercraft, Heroes and Hens
text: We writers enjoy bemoaning that there are no more surprises in the automotive world, but the last 12 months was full of them, from an exhaust note that caused constant double-takes to a Rolls with unexpected avian appeal. And then, of course, there was the hovercraft.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: An Upper West Side Co-op with two-bedrooms and a working fireplace; and a Park Slope three-bedroom with an open living and dining room.

headline: Sharing a Jazzy Working Holiday
text: The close of the year is a time for many things: cozy reunions, warm nostalgia, extravagant splurges. If you’re Wynton Marsalis, artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, it’s also a time to set up shop in a smallish room and get back to work, as if you had ever stopped.

headline: Spain Orders Smaller Price Increase for Electricity
text: MADRID — The Spanish government decreed on Friday that the country’s utilities could charge consumers only 2.3 percent more for their electricity next month after accusing utilities of manipulating a recent auction to win a price increase of 11 percent.

headline: Out of the Comfort Zone
text: A disturbing image or a discordant style, or both, might have qualified a work to be included in “Rabble-Rousers: Art, Dissent, and Social Commentary” at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington.

headline: The Independent Journal Esopus, Still Going Strong After a Decade of Publishing
text: It takes chutzpah to start a print publication these days, and a loose grip on reality to imagine that it could last a decade. But the biannual journal Esopus defied the odds last month when it published its 20th issue, “Special Collections,” which features work by Matthew Weiner, the creator of “Mad Men.” Tod Lippy, the magazine’s affable founder and editor, is a one-man masthead, conceiving and executing every issue with assistance only from interns who get paid in lifetime subscriptions.

headline: Spiritual and Prolific, in an Era of Upheaval
text: You can generally depend on Italian Renaissance art for tasteful, traditional Christmas imagery, and “Francesco Vanni: Art in Late Renaissance Siena” at Yale University Art Gallery delivers plenty of Madonnas, angels and adorable infants. But it also offers a view of European art at a moment of upheaval and of an artist working in the centers of religious power and responding to these changes.

headline: A Move Done, Barnes Leader Makes Another
text: PHILADELPHIA — The conflict was often ugly, the lawsuits vicious, the risks fairly pronounced.

headline: What the Tipsy Peasant Knew
text: For those who imbibe with abandon on New Year’s Eve and need soothing relief the day after, soup may be the answer. Some swear by a big bowlful of menudo: spicy Mexican tripe soup topped with chopped raw onion, chiles and a squeeze of lime. There’s Korean hae jang gook, a heady concoction of ox blood, meaty bones, bean sprouts and dried cabbage. The list of possibilities is long. Every nation seems to have a surefire hangover cure to recommend.

headline: When Your Life Needs a Do-Over
text: “Mastering the Art of Quitting: Why It Matters in Life, Love, and Work,” by Peg Streep and Alan Bernstein. Da Capo Lifelong Books, $24.99, 272 pp.

headline: Exploring the Science in Football
text: Joshua Padilla dropped back to pass and let the football fly.

headline: Robert W. Wilson, Frugal Philanthropist, Dies at 87
text: Robert W. Wilson, a retired hedge-fund founder who became a major philanthropist, donating about $600 million to causes that included environmental conservation, the American Civil Liberties Union and Roman Catholic education (though he was an openly gay atheist), died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: A Spot to Start, or End, the Day
text: Hector’s Cafe & Diner has remained relatively unchanged since it opened in 1949.

headline: The Year in Fashion
text: No one really talks about fabulous, must-have clothes anymore. Have you noticed? Instead, in 2013, the conversation focused on business deals (which luxury brand would go public next, the further designs of Amazon) and how celebrities faced their baby fat. Still, the year had its ironic moments and left-field surprises, plus a few artists who refused to be complacent.

headline: The Year in Fashion
text: Names that stood out: John, Raf, Baz and Marc.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Lebanon, Egypt, Central African Republic and Afghanistan.

headline: Melancholy Danes
text: I’m going to be visiting Scandinavia next month, so I’m doing preliminary homework — and for someone who hasn’t been following the region closely, there are surprising developments. Here’s real GDP, with the US to give some sense of comparison:

headline: Friday Night Music: London Grammar, Hey Now
text: Some readers last week asked for a performance of one of their originals; KEXP delivers a stunner:

headline: Flaming Baba au Rhum
text: A baba is traditionally baked with raisins, but Melissa Clark makes hers with chocolate.

headline: Flaming Baba au Rhum Earns the Oohs and Aahs
text: Of all the desserts that you could set on fire, you may never have considered the baba au rhum.

headline: A Diner Where Worlds Collide
text: Beginning most days at 3 a.m. on a tiny stretch of Washington Street, men in bloodstained aprons muscle open the gates of their meatpacking storefronts and unload dripping carcasses onto waiting trucks. The routine is much the same as it has been for generations, although the meatpackers are now surrounded by designer boutiques and chic lounges.

headline: Bridge Deals Online to Learn From and Discuss
text: The Internet has had a profound effect on our lives, primarily for the better.

headline: Forecasting the Year Ahead, and Preparing to Be Wrong
text: THIS is the time of year when investment analysts predict what they believe will happen over the next 12 months. That they are invariably wrong about something is a given. Or, to be more charitable, it is a given that events that no one could have foreseen will have caused their deeply researched predictions to be incorrect.

headline: A Winter Bouquet, Locally Grown
text: The florist Jennie Love digs through the snow at her urban flower farm in Philadelphia to create a seasonal, organically grown bridal bouquet out of unusual materials.

headline: Leaders Say South Sudan May Be Closer to Peace Pact
text: JUBA, South Sudan — Regional leaders in East Africa announced Friday that they had made progress on a peace deal to help end the crisis in South Sudan, but there was no indication that either side in the conflict was abiding by a cease-fire.

headline: Documentaries: Where Sundance Goes, Oscars Follow
text: LOS ANGELES — The winner of this year’s Oscar for best documentary, “Searching for Sugar Man,” was first seen at the Sundance Film Festival. Ten of the 15 documentaries on the 2014 Oscar shortlist made their debut in the Sundance snow.

headline: Indian Family Sees Its History in a Shirt
text: Ten years ago, lost to drugs and alcohol, Karen Little Thunder moved back to the Rosebud Indian Reservation in South Dakota, where, she said, she saved her own life by reconnecting to her Lakota heritage, particularly the legacy of her great-great grandfather. He was Little Thunder, a Lakota leader and a contemporary of Crazy Horse, whose life spanned several decades central to the history of the tribe — from the battles it fought across the Great Plains to its resettlement on reservations.

headline: Regulators Reviewing Volcker Rule Provision
text: Federal regulators on Friday once again tried to quiet the controversy about the potential impact of a provision of the Volcker Rule on hundreds of community banks.

headline: Times Minute | Legal Victory for N.S.A.
text: Also on the Minute, Justin Bieber's new movie and looking back at drones in 2013.

headline: Times Minute | Legal Victory for N.S.A.
text: In the Video

headline: Monk Parrots Find Freedom
text: Staring at a parrot flying through the biting cold of Queens, it is easy to imagine its escape from the warmth of someone’s home, and just as easy to picture its brief future. But looks can be deceiving.

headline: Her Term Is Up as Well
text: Greeting a visitor to her office at Wolfensohn Fund Management earlier this month, Diana Taylor betrayed a touch of jitters. “Would you like something to drink,” she asked twice in quick succession, before catching herself, and murmuring distractedly, “Oh, I asked you that.”

headline: Trendsetter of 2013? Goodwill
text: It was an unexpected goofball hit that caught music industry pundits dozing in their rocking chairs. It was an exuberant success celebrating the sartorial joys of pajama bottoms worn as daywear, Grandpa’s plaid cardigans and moth-bitten leopard-print mink.

headline: The Year in Style
text: Names that stood out: Miley, Macklemore, Marc and Tommy.

headline: Muslim Brotherhood Supporters Defy Egyptian Crackdown
text: CAIRO — Defying the widening crackdown against them, supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood marched in cities across Egypt on Friday, protesting the government’s decision to declare the group a terrorist organization and clashing with security forces in several places.

headline: A Tow-Truck Driver Who Races to the Wreckage
text: “New cars, full coverage,” is what Joey Cali said he was looking for as he cruised the streets of East New York.

headline: Medicare to Cover More Mental Health Costs
text: For decades, older adults with depression, anxiety and other psychological conditions have received unequal treatment under Medicare. The program paid a smaller share of the bill for therapy from psychiatrists, psychologists or clinical social workers than it did for medical services. And Medicare imposed strict lifetime limits on stays in psychiatric hospitals, although no such limits applied to medical care received in inpatient facilities.

headline: Urban Melodrama
text: The saga of Gov. William Sulzer’s impeachment a century ago cannot be told often enough, both as an object lesson and as urban melodrama. Jack O’Donnell’s “Bitten by the Tiger” (Chapel Hill Press) is a welcome addition to the growing genre.

headline: Turkish Game Show Pulled After Hinting at Corruption Scandal
text: Last Updated, 7:43 p.m. | A popular Turkish game show disappeared from the airwaves this week after its host appeared to make a veiled reference to a widening corruption scandal by asking a contestant to name a slang term for a person who takes bribes.

headline: He Makes Madame’s Toast
text: The pastry chef François Payard, 47, honed his craft first in France and later at Le Bernardin and Daniel; with the entrepreneur Marlon Abela he now has a dozen patisseries and bakeries in New York, Las Vegas, Japan and South Korea. On Sundays he tries to dial it back, so he can unwind with his wife, Fernanda Capobianco, 32, owner of the bakery Vegan Divas; prepare and share good food with friends in the couple’s Turtle Bay apartment; and take his mind off business for a day.

headline: Protesters Clash With Police in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — Thousands of protesters calling for the resignation of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey over a corruption scandal clashed with the police on Friday night as they tried to reach Taksim Square in central Istanbul, suggesting that the growing political crisis could converge with street unrest.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. While I (as a good Samaritan) was helping two groups of tourists at my local No. 1 subway station, the employee at the “token” booth refused to give me more than one subway map. How many maps does each booth get? Who is responsible for keeping each booth supplied? And, most important, what is M.T.A. policy about giving out subway maps to tourists?

headline: Bill Cunningham | Start the Countdown
text: New Year’s Eve is a time for extravagant dresses, decorative headdresses and oversize necklaces. Shown here: designs worn at some of the best parties over the last 12 months — a preview of sorts for the Metropolitan Museum of Art exhibition of Charles James’s spectacular ball gowns, opening in May. Museum parties included the one at the Frick Collection, with Champagne and caviar, and the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, with Champagne and doughnuts. (The Gardner opened, by the way, on New Year’s Day 1903.) In Times Square, it will be just Champagne (and lots of it).

headline: Bill Cunningham | Start the Countdown
text: The night before the new year is a time for extravagant dresses, decorative headdresses and oversize necklaces.

headline: Turkey Legs Conquer Land of Mouse Ears
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — It made its humble debut at a single stand in the late 1980s next to Big Al’s Coonskin Caps in Frontierland. Slowly it spread — dripping, always dripping — beyond Walt Disney World here to Disneyland in California.

headline: Ready, Set, Hike! A Trial Trek to MetLife Stadium
text: RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The officials planning Super Bowl XLVIII want it to be the Super Bowl of public transportation. They are not just discouraging fans from walking to MetLife Stadium on game day in February — they are forbidding it. The only way in will be through a security perimeter, and there will be nowhere to enter the security perimeter on foot.

headline: New Energy Struggles on Its Way to Markets
text: WASHINGTON — To stave off climate change, sources of electricity that do not emit carbon will have to replace the ones that do. But at the moment, two of those largest sources, nuclear and wind power, are trying to kill each other off.

headline: Spirits of New York: Local Distilleries
text: An easing of laws regulating the production and sale of liquor in New York state has helped spur the establishment of micro-distilleries across the five boroughs.

headline: A Taste of the Social Web’s Turkey Legs
text: The web is studded with a perhaps surprising number of examples of Disney customers indulging in the massive drumsticks known as the jumbo turkey leg — from otherwise mild-mannered seemingly nuclear families to all-female groups of carnivores to whole collections of Instagrams that depict man versus meat.

headline: Recipes With Local Liquor
text: King County Manhattan

headline: Projects Under Scrutiny Displace Istanbul’s Poor
text: ISTANBUL — On the narrow streets that slope from one of Istanbul’s hills toward the shoreline of the Golden Horn waterway, old wooden houses where military officers of the Ottoman Empire lived are being painstakingly refurbished to their original design. Before the officers arrived, the area, which includes the city’s biggest mosque, was for centuries a center of Islamic scholarship.

headline: 90 Proof New York
text: Steven DeAngelo was bored on Wall Street. Colin Spoelman never found a job he wanted to do. Brad Estabrooke was laid off from one he would never miss. Dave Kyrejko was a former art school student working with fish tanks and aquariums.

headline: Holocaust History, as Told by a Survivor
text: EMSDETTEN, Germany — LASZLO SCHWARTZ never had a proper adolescence. The Nazis made sure of that.

headline: A New Year’s Wish List for New York City
text: The year we are putting behind us was dominated in New York by some of the liveliest politics in memory — or rather, some of the liveliest mayoral politics outside Toronto. We elected Bill de Blasio as the 109th mayor of the city and embraced his “tale of two cities,” but not until we milked the “tale of two Anthony Weiners,” one of them the story of a volatile and ineffectual former congressman, and the other the story of a prolific composer of lurid texts generated under the ingeniously conceived alias Carlos Danger.

headline: Loyal Subscribers Keep Hobby Magazines Afloat
text: Lance Prucnal’s family, like others in the digital age, has canceled most of its newspaper and magazine subscriptions.

headline: Bowing to Pressure, A&E Revokes Suspension of ‘Duck Dynasty’ Star
text: The indefinite suspension of Phil Robertson, the patriarch of the family at the center of the A&E Network’s huge ratings hit “Duck Dynasty,” became definite Friday — at zero episodes. The network announced he would not be suspended after all.

headline: Bloomberg and Kelly Share Valedictory Moment
text: For Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, it has become something of an annual tradition: proclaiming yet another year of reduced crime and fewer murders.

headline: First Attempts Fail to Free Ship Stranded by Heavy Ice
text: Icebreakers sent to free a stranded Russian research ship, the Akademik Shokalskiy, off Antarctica were stopped by heavy ice within sight of the ship, officials said early Saturday. A Chinese icebreaker in the area, the Xue Long, or Snow Dragon, was asked to divert toward the Shokalskiy, which is carrying members of the Australasian Antarctic Expedition and became stuck in the ice on Tuesday about 1,700 miles south of Tasmania. A spokeswoman for the Australian Maritime Safety Authority said the Xue Long was about seven miles from the Shokalskiy when the ice became too thick to cut through. A French icebreaker also could not clear a path to the ship, said an expedition spokesman. The ships will await the arrival of an Australian icebreaker, which has a greater icebreaking capacity, he said.

headline: The Faces Behind the Counter
text: When we eat at a McDonald’s or a Burger King, we rarely pay attention to the people behind the counter. Our eyes are often focused upward on the brightly lighted menus, or perhaps downward on our smartphones or watches. But according to employment statistics, more than 55,000 people work in fast-food restaurants in New York City, and the number is rapidly increasing. Many of them earn the minimum wage: $7.25 an hour, increasing on Jan. 1 to $8. Forty percent are 25 or older. More than a quarter are parents raising children.

headline: New Home Offers Hope After Years of Devastation
text: Kenneth Silver had little to lose by 2012. His way of life was already severely diminished, and when Hurricane Sandy swept through Coney Island, its waves washed away what little he had left.

headline: Sweatshops and Our Tax Dollars
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Quest to Slow or Stop the Aging Process
text: To the Editor:

headline: Benefits Ending for One Million Unemployed
text: WASHINGTON — An emergency federal program that acts as a lifeline for 1.3 million jobless workers will end on Saturday, drastically curtailing government support for the long-term unemployed and setting the stage for a major political fight in the new year.

headline: Antibiotics for Livestock
text: To the Editor:

headline: Women and Mandatory Drug Sentences
text: To the Editor:

headline: Releasing a Killer’s Name
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Freedmen of Wisconsin
text: In the summer of 1862, a 31-year-old slave named Samuel Mathews and his family freed themselves by escaping from their plantation in Franklin County, Ala. With the army of Union Gen. William Rosecrans nearby, local Confederates had been talking of impressing Mathews into service as a cook. Unwilling to serve the rebel army, Samuel, his 25-year-old wife, Sarah, their 8-year-old son, Richard, and their 7-year-old daughter, Ellen, snuck away to a Union Army camp in nearby Tuscumbia, in the northwest corner of the state. But it was only the first step in their journey to freedom, which would last eight months and finish 700 miles north in the unlikely locale of rural Dodge County, Wis.

headline: Chief Will Step Down After Five Years at Hyundai’s U.S. Unit
text: The chief executive of Hyundai’s American unit, who for five years navigated the company through the recession to huge growth, will step down next week, the company said in an abrupt announcement.

headline: Different Paths, and Endings, for Two Derby Hopefuls
text: Horse racing is a game of chance. Seasoned horsemen and horseplayers know that if a Kentucky Derby favorite makes it to the starting gate, he is still anything but a sure bet.

headline: Libya Holds Four American Military Personnel for Hours
text: WASHINGTON — Four American military personnel assigned to the United States Embassy in Tripoli, Libya, were detained Friday and then released after being held for hours by the country’s Interior Ministry, American officials said.

headline: Academics Who Defend Wall St. Reap Reward
text: Signs of the energy business are inescapable in and around Houston — the pipelines, refineries and tankers that crowd the harbor, and the gleaming office towers where oil companies and energy traders have transformed the skyline.

headline: Louis Scarcella’s Ex-Partner Is Coming Under Scrutiny in Brooklyn Cases
text: Behind his back, Stephen W. Chmil was called Robin — the quiet sidekick to his more handsome, daring and celebrated partner.

headline: Follow Me, Follow My Mom
text: “I JUST don’t like you sharing personal information with strangers,” my mother said.

headline: Hey, Stars, Be Nice to the Stagehands. You Might Need a Loan.
text: They create the technical razzle-dazzle when the Rockettes take the stage for the “Radio City Christmas Spectacular.” They raise the 45-foot-high Christmas tree for “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker.” And on New Year’s Eve, they will make the opulent ballroom set spin for the Metropolitan Opera’s new “Die Fledermaus.”

headline: Asada, After a Struggle, Is Soaring Over the Ice Again
text: DETROIT — Figure skating’s kiss-and-cry area is designed for sequined emotion. But when Mao Asada of Japan received her composite score at the 2010 Vancouver Olympics, her expression remained as flat and neutral as the ice.

headline: Greeting the New Year
text: This is the season of lists: roundups and recaps, forecasts and resolutions.

headline: Finessing Typewriters for Nearly 40 Years, and Now Turning Over the Keys
text: Bino Gan has never seen any of Woody Allen’s movies, but in his own way he has helped in the writing of them. Mr. Gan has made sure that the famous Olympia typewriter Mr. Allen uses to write his screenplays is always in good pecking order.

headline: In Miracle Season, Auburn Breaks a Machine
text: The Auburn football program has a thing for slogans. “All In” was the rallying cry a couple of years ago. “Together” showed up on shirts this season, a “Season of Miracles” in which “Destiny” was big, alongside the perennial catchphrase “Family” — the kind of stuff you hear on corporate retreats or in Hallmark specials.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 27, 2013
Police Salaries and Pensions Push California City to Brink
text: DESERT HOT SPRINGS, Calif. — Emerging from Los Angeles’s vast eastern sprawl, the freeway glides over a narrow pass and slips gently into the scrubby, palm-flecked Coachella Valley.

headline: Despair at Guantánamo
text: In April, when a hunger strike by detainees at the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, was in its third month, Pentagon officials agreed with defense lawyers that the underlying cause was a growing despair among prisoners who have been in detention for a decade with no hope of getting out. The protest, which at its height involved 106 of the 166 prisoners there this summer, served to put the Guantánamo issue back on the radar in Washington.

headline: Singapore’s Angry Migrant Workers
text: Frustration among Singapore’s unappreciated and underpaid migrant workers has been building in recent years as their numbers have grown faster than the country can accommodate them. Tensions boiled over earlier this month, after a 33-year-old Indian migrant worker was killed by a bus in the Little India neighborhood. A crowd of fellow workers from South Asia gathered at the scene. Their anger quickly escalated, with some 400 people pelting stones, attacking emergency responders and setting fire to vehicles. It was the worst riot to hit Singapore, one of the world’s most orderly countries, since 1969.

headline: This Week, Mass Surveillance Wins
text: Has the National Security Agency’s mass collection of Americans’ phone records actually helped to prevent terrorist attacks?

headline: Summer Camp That Makes a Difference
text: Yancy Rivera’s son Brian, 11, is autistic and painfully shy. Summers used to be the worst time, with Brian out of school and spending his days watching TV. So Ms. Rivera, a single mother who works in a Lower East Side pharmacy to support him and his older brother, began searching three years ago for a summer day camp.

headline: Paul Blair, Center Fielder for Champions, Dies at 69
text: Paul Blair, the fleet and elegant ball hawk who roamed center field for four World Series champions, the Baltimore Orioles twice and the Yankees twice, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 69.

headline: Rocket’s Day at Line Costs Grizzly Who Cries Foul
text: Over the course of a long N.B.A. season, it is not uncommon to see a player, or more often a coach, punished by the N.B.A. for publicly criticizing the refereeing in a game.

headline: Snooker Star Who Walked Away Races to Title
text: Imagine Rafael Nadal walking away from tennis for a year and then returning to win Wimbledon. Or imagine Tiger Woods winning the Masters and then threatening to quit golf for good. That is akin to what happened in 2013 with the Englishman Ronnie O’Sullivan, perhaps the finest snooker player in history.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 28, 2013
text: “I would not venture to say they are overpaid. What I would say is that we can’t pay them.”

headline: 2,500 Pigs Join Debate Over Farms vs. Scenery
text: MOUNT JUDEA, Ark. — Anita Hudson’s moment of realization came early this year when she saw cement trucks whizzing past her home in this blip of an Ozark town. For Sam Dye, it was when an employee at the school where he once was principal pointed out bulldozers clearing a wooded area in the distance.

headline: Corrections: December 28, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: Alternative to a Head Slap
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Are you feeling snacky?

headline: For an Excited Nude Statue, Finally a Little Bit of Privacy
text: There is only one statue shrouded by a wood fence in Socrates Sculpture Park, a waterfront exhibition space in Long Island City, Queens. It is also the only one with its own warning sign.

headline: Cutting Back Unemployment Benefits
text: How the expiration of a federal unemployment benefit program impacts the amount of time jobless workers can receive benefits and the share of the jobless who receive them.

headline: Team Is a Memory, but the Whalers Live On Behind N.H.L. Benches
text: The Hartford Whalers of the N.H.L. departed in 1997, packing their bags, pads and sticks and moving to North Carolina, where the franchise was reborn as the Carolina Hurricanes.

headline: Reassured or Not, Knicks Still Look Overburdened
text: A day after James L. Dolan’s impromptu meeting with his embattled team, not much changed for the Knicks at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Nets Get Off the Mat, but Heavyweights Loom on the Schedule
text: In a week when their tumultuous season may have reached its lowest point — a week marred by back-to-back 17-point losses, a season-ending injury to the All-Star center Brook Lopez and reports of locker-room turmoil — the Nets finished a three-game home stand by showing a glimpse of the play that many had envisioned when they talked of a title contender budding in Brooklyn.

headline: In War of Attrition, a Giants Rookie Remains Unscathed
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Justin Pugh, the Giants’ rookie right tackle, refers to the N.F.L. as the “Not for Long” league. After the wrenching changes he has observed in the team’s offensive line and elsewhere, no one can blame him for developing such cynicism at an early age.

headline: Cruz Wants Tighter Connection to Manning
text: Victor Cruz said Friday that there was an obvious disconnect between Eli Manning and the Giants’ wide receivers this season, which may have contributed to Manning’s career high in interceptions.

headline: Fletcher Lasted Where Most Don’t
text: In the 1998 N.F.L. draft, more than 30 linebackers were selected. But the only linebacker to enter the league that season who is still playing today is London Fletcher, who was not drafted and provides one of the more remarkable stories in league history.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 27
text: Subjects include: Santa’s bag of presents in Herald Square, a Christmas pageant at a church in Manhattan and a foggy view of the Hudson River from Harlem.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) WARM BODIES (2013) “The zombie romance ‘Warm Bodies’ is cute and amusing enough to catch on cable one day, where its star-crossed, blood-drenched lovers will eventually present sweet relief from the apocalyptic freakout that is the AMC series ‘The Walking Dead,’ ” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this twist on the zombie genre, written and directed by Jonathan Levine and based on the novel by Isaac Marion. Nicholas Hoult plays a zombie; Teresa Palmer, above with Mr. Hoult, is Julie, the living girl he strangely does not want to eat; and John Malkovich plays Julie’s father, who threatens to keep the star-crossed lovers apart.

headline: Fire on Indian Express Train Kills Dozens
text: NEW DELHI — More than two dozen passengers, many of them headed home for the holidays, were killed early Saturday when an express train traveling through the center of India caught fire.

headline: Delhi’s New Leader Vows to Halt Corruption
text: NEW DELHI — Standing before a crowd estimated in the tens of thousands, Delhi’s unlikely new leader, swept into office on an anticorruption campaign, was sworn in Saturday, and he vowed to arrest anyone in his government, from police officer to bureaucrat, who demanded a bribe.

headline: BEST OF 2013
text: TK

headline: Vaccine Aide Gunned Down in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A health worker supervising a polio vaccination campaign was fatally shot and two others were wounded on Saturday when gunmen opened fire at a hospital in northwestern Pakistan, officials said.

headline: The Merchant of Just Be Happy
text: On a cool mid-September afternoon at the California horse ranch of the life coach Martha Beck, two blindfolded, crouching men came to an impasse. The men had been told to think of themselves as animals and to use only their sense of hearing to try to locate and tag each other — all in an effort to awaken the senses and instincts presumably deadened by desk jobs and smartphones.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Dec. 29
text: “I feel like Christmas is incomplete.”

headline: The Leaders and the Left Out
text: My employer has something it calls the Leadership Council, a group that meets monthly to discuss organizational issues. Currently we have around 80 employees. Some 35 of them — or 44 percent — are on this council.

headline: Animal Welfare, as Mission
text: Austin Gates, 50, of Harrison, Mich., recently changed departments at the A.S.P.C.A., which she joined in 2010.

headline: A Second Wind From an Injured Knee
text: When Kim Gustafson moved to Vail Valley in Colorado more than a decade ago, he was 54 and had recently retired as an executive in the office-equipment business. But he wasn’t ready to stop working. “I’m not the type of person who wanted to play checkers,” he says.

headline: Carey Smith, on Becoming the Team’s ‘Hyperlink’
text: This interview with  Carey Smith, C.E.O. of Big Ass Fans, a ceiling fan company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Reading Your Palm for Security’s Sake
text: They aren’t taking any chances at Barclays Bank in Britain. Stating an account number and other bona fides isn’t enough to get to your money at the bank’s wealth and investment management service. As an additional safeguard, a program analyzes customers’ voices when they call in, to make sure they match a voice print on file.

headline: Tony Hsieh’s Office: Welcome to the Rain Forest
text: 1. “Hey, hey, we’re the ... ”

headline: Clawbacks? They’re Still a Rare Breed
text: Financial executives who are actually held to account for misdeeds remain as rare as hen’s teeth, alas. That’s why a recent enforcement action by the Securities and Exchange Commission caught my eye.

headline: Best of 2013 | The Year in Design
text: These 15 stories took us to places full of elegance and eccentricity. Read…

headline: Monte dei Paschi Foundation Votes to Delay Sale
text: SIENA, Italy — Shareholders in Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the world’s oldest bank, derailed a plan by management to raise urgently needed new cash, leaving the bank’s future in limbo and illustrating the conflict in crisis-ridden Italy between change and tradition.

headline: Alive, and Living in the Moment
text: If you have heard Jeff Bauman’s name, you have probably seen the photograph, of him clutching what was left of his left leg, being wheeled off by a man in a cowboy hat near the finish line of the Boston Marathon. Because of the photograph, Bauman became a face of the bombings that day in April.

headline: Signs of a Russian Thaw (Toward Business)
text: It was just after 9 on a mid-May morning in 2011 when Ruslan Telkov got into his car and headed toward one of his upholstery company’s warehouses near Moscow. His parents had warned him not to start his own business, that only frustration and heartache awaited, if not worse. But it was not the 1990s anymore, he told them; the days of bandit capitalism in Russia were over. “I decided it’s what I wanted, and that was that,” he said.

headline: When Giants’ Season Ends, Effort to Avoid a Similar One Begins
text: It was late on a mid-October night when Eli Manning’s voice cracked, a trembling quiver that said what everyone around him already knew: The 2013 Giants season, after six weeks, was irretrievably broken and ruined.

headline: Big Decisions for Jets, and Not Just on the Coach
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The sentiment expressed most often by Rex Ryan over the last week — aside from his pledging that, no, he has not thought about his uncertain future — is that the Jets are an ascending team. It is his steadfast belief that they have an enviable foundation, especially on defense, and a young core that will expand through free agency and the draft.

headline: Train Fire Kills Dozens in India
text: A train traveling between Nanded and Bangalore caught fire at 3:30 a.m. on Saturday. An electrical short-circuit was suspected as the cause, according to local media reports.

headline: In Textbook Fight, Japan Leaders Seek to Recast History
text: TAKETOMI, Japan — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s conservative government has begun to pursue a more openly nationalist agenda on an issue that critics fear will push the country farther from its postwar pacifism: adding a more patriotic tone to Japan’s school textbooks.

headline: A Shifting View of Japanese History
text: Japan’s conservative government is considering a requirement that school history textbooks nurture patriotism and include nationalist views of World War II, a departure from the current mainstream texts.

headline: Variety: An Iron Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — This was a tough one for me.

headline: In the N.H.L., a Stricter Standard for Safety’s Sake
text: Whether it is happening fast enough is a matter for debate, but there is no question that the N.H.L. is evolving when it comes to player safety.

headline: Members of Jewish Student Group Test Permissible Discussion on Israel
text: At Harvard, the Jewish student group Hillel was barred from co-sponsoring a discussion with a Palestinian student group. At Binghamton University, a Hillel student leader was forced to resign his position after showing a film about Palestinians and inviting the filmmaker’s brother to speak. And on many other campuses, Hillel chapters have been instructed to reject collaboration with left-leaning Jewish groups.

headline: Civilians Trying to Flee South Sudan Violence Are Caught Between Two Sides
text: MALAKAL, South Sudan — When the shooting started last week, Othom Bol quickly fled with his wife and their three young children to what he thought would be the safety of the United Nations peacekeeping base on the outskirts of town.

headline: Unexpectedly, an Aging Jagr Has Become the Jagr of Old
text: NEWARK — As the milestones mount, the quips keep coming.

headline: Warriors Duo Leads a Flood of 3-Pointers
text: Klay Thompson and Stephen Curry, who make up the starting backcourt for the Golden State Warriors, are shooting 3-pointers more often than any other teammates have before. They are 1-2 in the N.B.A. in 3-pointers and 3-point attempts. And in a league that has gone crazy for the 3-point shot, it could be argued that they are a rare case of players who should be shooting from long range even more.

headline: An Epidemic of Carjackings Afflicts Newark
text: The grocery shop in Newark was crowded on Monday, as customers picked up last-minute supplies for Christmas.
