headline: The Top 10 Top 10 Lists of 2013
text: It’s that joyous time of year again: end-of-year list season! Two years ago I sang the praises of listmaking in the magazine, discussing the fun of “creating, in 10 increments, the person you want to be.” As 2013 comes to a close, it’s a wonderful chance to look back on a year of listmaking. Which critics are working at the peak of the Top 10 form? Who is reinvigorating the tropes of the best list, finding new ways to tell old stories? Let’s take a look at the Top 10 Top 10 Lists of 2013.

headline: Daily Report: Considering the Future of Internet Governance
text: With Edward J. Snowden’s theft and redistribution of reams of classified data starkly highlighting the Internet’s ubiquity and its potential for widespread surveillance, the new year is likely to see renewed calls to change the way the Internet is governed.

headline: Rock Hall of Famers’ Hits, One More Time
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: U.S. Frees Last of the Chinese Uighur Detainees From Guantánamo Bay
text: WASHINGTON — In what the Pentagon called a “significant milestone” in the effort to close the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the military announced Tuesday that the United States had transferred three Chinese detainees to Slovakia.

headline: In Performance: Ciarán Hinds in ‘The Night Alive’
text: This week’s scene features Ciarán Hinds in a scene from Conor McPherson’s new play “The Night Alive,” a dark comedy about a group of Dubliners whose live intersect in mysterious ways in the rundown home of Tommy, played by Mr. Hinds. In this excerpt he talks about an encounter with a well-dressed boxer. The show, directed by Mr. McPherson, continues through Feb. 2 at the Atlantic Theater Company’s Linda Gross Theater.

headline: Dancing Across the Generations
text: On a September night this year in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, my wife and I, visiting New York from Alabama, head to a bar and restaurant where our daughter is celebrating her 26th birthday. As the evening unfolds and Meredith’s friends pack the place, the music gets louder, with a D.J. favoring Afro-Cuban music laying down a catchy beat.

headline: ScienceTake: How to Control Starfish
text: During a meal, the stomach of a starfish comes out of its mouth and grabs hold of what it is eating. Figuring out what controls this process could mean good news for the coral that starfish feed on.

headline: Bright Passages
text: In the spirit of the season, we’ll take a brief break from carping to offer a small sampling of sparkling prose from recent weeks.

headline: Game Theory: The Best of 2013
text: The Game Theory panelists have feverishly replayed, reconsidered and revisited many video games of 2013. Here are their selections for the year’s top releases.

headline: The Real Man Behind the Fancy Frames
text: Dear Diary,

headline: Rand Slaps Down Rand
text: Update: A bit out of it this morning. Here’s Rand Ghayad’s piece.

headline: BEST OF 2013
text: These 15 stories took us to destinations around the world where magic and modernity collide.

headline: A Belgian’s American-Seeming Film
text: Nearly everything about “The Broken Circle Breakdown,” Belgium’s shortlisted submission for the foreign-language Oscar, is improbable, starting with what first inspired it. When George W. Bush placed limits on stem-cell research in his first term, the Belgian playwright and actor Johan Heldenbergh was so angry that he decided to write a theater piece as a way of venting.

headline: Columbia Rare Book Library Gets the Kitchen Sink
text: The cartoonists R. Crumb, Art Spiegelman and Al Capp have one thing in common. All were published, at one time or another, by Kitchen Sink Press, whose archives were recently donated to the Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Columbia University by Denis Kitchen, the press’s founder.

headline: Cynical Fantasies
text: One thing that happens when you try to have a rational discussion of Bitcoin, gold, and/or other libertarian causes is that you get a lot of cynical remarks about government (which is one of the clues that this is, to an important extent, about politics.) You say that there’s nothing putting a floor under Bitcoin’s value? Well, how do you know that the government won’t debase the dollar to nothing? Huh? Huh?

headline: Schumacher’s Condition Improves Slightly, Doctors Say
text: LONDON — Doctors treating Michael Schumacher for the brain injuries he sustained in a skiing accident in the French Alps said Tuesday that there was “a slight improvement” in his condition after an overnight operation.

text: Headliner

headline: Winch Cats Are the Ultimate Off-Road Vehicles
text: All-wheel-drive cars, such as 4-wheel-drive S.U.V.'s, are capable snow machines — to an extent. Then there are snowcats, with tracked wheels and plow blades that enable them to go pretty much anywhere.

headline: A Statistic Behind Every Super Bowl Contender
text: Each of the 12 teams in the N.F.L. playoffs has a big strength or a big weakness, and each has a statistic to tell the tale.

headline: 1963: In Paris, a Year Captured by Youth
text: PARIS, Dec. 30—For France, 1963 was a great year for youth. It was the first time that young fashions and fashion designers came fully into their own.

headline: Monitoring Elections Could Kill You. Well, Sort Of.
text: Maybe it’s true, after all. There really was a lot of deadwood at the city’s much-maligned Board of Elections. Or perhaps all that pressure massaging the balky new electronic machines was too much. Or the thousands of openings for $200-a-day election inspectors on Election Days just happen to attract a high number of older retirees.

headline: The Many Lessons ‘Wolf’ Teaches Us
text: Depending on whom you ask, “The Wolf of Wall Street” is either a cautionary tale or a gleeful fable. (The screenwriter, Terence Winter, thought it was neither, preferring to present the facts without judgment.)

headline: QuizUp, a Social Trivia App, Tests Mobile Gamers
text: Every year, a new game craze captures the attention of mobile phone users around the nation and globe.

headline: Sustainable Resolutions for Your Diet
text: New Year’s resolutions tend to be big, impressive promises that we adhere to for short periods of time — that blissful stretch of January when we are starving ourselves, exercising daily and reading Proust. But, and you know this, rather than making extreme changes that last for days or weeks, we are better off with tiny ones lasting more or less forever.

headline: Global Optimism for 2014, With an Eye on Dormant Risks
text: If Shinzo Abe and Mario Draghi were being compensated by investment banks rather than taxpayers, they would both be looking forward to some pretty hefty year-end bonuses.

headline: Monetary Policy in Japan: Finally on Track
text: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Best of 2013 | The Year in Travel
text: These 15 stories took us to destinations around the world where magic and modernity collide. Read…

headline: John Dominis, a Star Photographer for Life Magazine, Dies at 92
text: John Dominis, a Life magazine photographer who was known for capturing celebrities, wild animals and presidents at their unguarded best, and who was caught off guard himself while taking his most famous picture — of two American medal winners raising black-gloved fists at the 1968 Olympics — died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Simon Rattle Among the Artists on Queen Elizabeth’s Honors List
text: The arts figure prominently among those included Queen Elizabeth II’s New Year’s Honors List, with two marquee names from the classical music world who have already been knighted gaining additional recognition.

headline: A New Year’s Tradition’s Last Ear-Splitting Blast
text: A longstanding Brooklyn tradition might end tonight with a blast – literally.

headline: Acting Tips From Mrs. Wolf of Wall Street (Hint: Get a Flask)
text: Debate is still raging about the moral implications of Martin Scorsese’s “Wolf of Wall Street,” but no one is saying that Mr. Scorsese and his willing producer and star, Leonardo DiCaprio, playing the corrupt stock trader Jordan Belfort, didn’t go all out in their nearly three-hour orgy of sex, drugs and greed.

headline: Video: A Look With Mom’s Monogram
text: Allison Yatto was home for the holidays when she was spotted walking along Sixth Avenue draped in a dramatic floor-length fur coat.

headline: How Do E-Books Change the Reading Experience?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Mohsin Hamid and Anna Holmes discuss how technology affects the way we read.

headline: Jean-Baptiste Say, Cockroach
text: Regular readers know that I talk quite a lot about zombies, but also occasionally talk about cockroaches. Reading Menzie Chinn today, it occurred to me that it might be helpful to review the distinction between these two technical terms.

headline: An Auspicious New Year’s Day Buffet
text: This year, as I always do on New Year’s Day, I will host an open house and serve my beloved black-eyed peas salad. But I had also found half-bags of various grains and beans in my pantry and wanted to use them up, so I decided to work them into a few other dishes for my buffet, mostly salads that will hold for a few hours. Most of these staples are foods that are considered symbolic of good luck and expanding fortunes in the New Year by different cultures. For example Italians eat lentils at the New Year because they resemble coins and expand when cooked. I will double my money by combining lentils with coinlike carrot slices in a delicious Middle Eastern salad. I use lots of greens and herbs in my salads as well; green leaves also symbolize money and growth.

headline: 64-Year Wait for a Bowl Win
text: For Northwestern’s football team, the highlight of the year came both early and late. Very late.

headline: House Hunting Near the Jura Mountains
text: A restored 1928 house on the market in the village of Gex in eastern France for $4.05 million, or €2.95 million.

headline: House Hunting Near ... The Jura Mountains
text: A SIX-BEDROOM HOUSE WITH MONT BLANC VIEWS

headline: Judge Orders Release of Dying Lawyer Convicted of Aiding Terrorism
text: A federal judge in Manhattan ordered a “compassionate release” on Tuesday for Lynne F. Stewart, the former defense lawyer convicted of assisting terrorism who is dying from cancer in a federal prison in Texas.

headline: The Risks of Investing in Animal Medicine
text: Animal medicine, whether for livestock or pets, is a booming business. Pfizer’s recent spinoff, Zoetis, trades at a large valuation premium to traditional drug makers, for example.

headline: Jets Praise Leadership, but Make No Promises
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Among the revelations from General Manager John Idzik and his newly retained coach, Rex Ryan, at the Jets’ season-ending news conference was that Geno Smith was a quarterback on their roster. They were also excited that Smith was on their roster. Also, they were not so excited about Smith that they would pledge that he would — or even should — be the favorite to start next season.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Lingering Concussion Problem
text: When the N.F.L. agreed in August to pay $765 million to settle hundreds of cases accusing it of hiding information about the dangers of concussions, the league no doubt hoped that fans would instead focus on the players and the games that make the sport a national obsession.

headline: Bloomberg Legacy: Democracy
text: Michael Barbaro, a Times political reporter, analyzes how Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's wealth, and his success in securing a third term, affected the democratic process in New York City.

headline: Bloomberg Legacy: Education
text: Javier C. Hernández, a Times education reporter, assesses Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's record on education.

headline: Bloomberg Legacy: Health
text: Anemona Hartocollis, a Times health reporter, talks about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's record on health issues in New York City.

headline: Bloomberg Legacy: Wealth
text: Sam Roberts, urban affairs correspondent for The Times, discusses Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s wealth, and its effect on the city’s politics.

headline: Chinese Businessman Seeking Stake in Times Co.
text: SHANGHAI — A wealthy Chinese businessman and philanthropist known for his zany public stunts said on Tuesday that he was leading a group of investors seeking to acquire a large or controlling stake in The New York Times Company.

headline: Bloomberg Legacy: Crime
text: Jim Dwyer analyzes Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's performance on crime and public safety.

text: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Rescuing a Stranded Ship
text: Also on the Minute, more Guantánamo detainees are freed and a look at Mayor Michael Bloomberg's legacy.

headline: Does Philanthropic Peer Pressure or Morality Matter More?
text: Do you know the philosopher Peter Singer’s thought exercise about charitable giving? It’s this: Imagine you’re on your way to work, but you see a child who has fallen into a pond and appears to be drowning. The idea of ruining your shoes or suit — or even, say, your brand-new Christmas iPhone — would not keep you from rescuing that child. You would, in fact, do it again the next day. So, why don’t we? What is keeping us from giving more to ill and malnourished children around the world, whose lives could be saved by the cost of a pair of shoes?

headline: 266 And All That
text: Ah, some of the comments on my post about cynical lack of realism happen to illustrate a favorite observation of mine: the extent to which people who demand that we learn the lessons of history tend to rely on historical episodes in which we have very little idea of what really happened.

headline: The Bloomberg Legacy
text: Times reporters and columnists look back at the Bloomberg legacy in some of the key areas that most affect New Yorkers.

headline: The Birth of the Greenback
text: On Dec. 30, 1861, Elbridge Gerry Spaulding, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Banking and Currency, gave a speech on the House floor declaring that the nation was “never in greater peril than at this moment.” The Civil War was eight months old, but Spaulding’s concern wasn’t martial, but fiscal.

headline: DeBlasio’s First Move: Carriage Horses
text: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio, for all of his good qualities, has a problem prioritizing. While we wait for him to appoint his team (oh so slowly) and we wonder what his policies are going to be, exactly, on things like schools, Mr. de Blasio announced yesterday that one of his first acts will be … to ban carriage horses from Central Park.

headline: Lacking a Villain, Super Bowl Power Failure Proves the Hero
text: A few weeks before flying to New Orleans to cover Super Bowl XLVII, I had finally crossed “The Dark Knight Rises” off my list of movies to watch.

headline: As the Clock Ticks Down, Mayor Bloomberg Experiences 12 Years of Gratitude
text: On the last day of his last term as mayor of New York, Michael R. Bloomberg put on a pinstripe gray-and-blue suit, tied a red-and-white tie, and soaked up something that is rarely proffered: the unabashed gratitude of a brusque city.

headline: Notable Opinion Art of 2013
text: A selection of illustrations that reflects on the issues of the past year.

headline: The Purrpose Driven Life
text: As 2013 comes to a close and people and publications take stock of the year just passed in various ways (see, for example, last weekend’s magazine) now’s the time — if ever — to note the passing of some cats who made their mark on the world, with contributions from various members of The Times’s staff.

headline: Feeling For | Nicholas Kirkwood’s Timeless, Sparkling Shoes
text: Black, gold and a hint of sparkle — the usual makings of a New Year’s Eve outfit — beautifully converge on these towering, architectural shoes from the “It” Brit designer Nicholas Kirkwood. The glittering ball mounted under the arch of black satin is fun and festive for ringing in 2014, a tiny ode to the Times Square ball drop. And with the sculptural swaths of gold-trimmed black satin that hug the feet, this pair of high-heeled sandals from Kirkwood’s resort collection is also classy enough to complete party looks all year long.

headline: Video: Jonah Hill on ‘The Wolf of Wall Street’
text: Jonah Hill donned fake teeth and colorful shirts to play Donnie Azoff, the protégé of the stock trader Jordan Belfort (Leonardo DiCaprio) in “The Wolf of Wall Street.”  In this video from a luncheon with some of the film’s cast and crew, he discusses his excitement about getting the opportunity to work with Martin Scorsese.

headline: Accuracy, Secrecy and Equality: What Mattered to Times Readers in 2013
text: One of the strange things about the role of public editor – and, believe me, there are quite a few – is never knowing how readers will react to an article, a headline, a photograph or an opinion piece.

headline: Charities That Inspire Kids: Cora Dance
text: Earlier this month, I asked readers to share stories of charities that had touched and inspired their families and created an urge to give in their children. As we head through what’s often a week of charitable giving for many and into 2014, we’ll post some of those stories here.

headline: Rescue Efforts for Trapped Antarctic Voyage Disrupt Serious Science
text: Early this morning, I received an e-mail message from one of many polar scientists whose important and costly field research in Antarctica has been seriously disrupted by the diversion of icebreakers to try to evacuate the journalists, tourists, crew and scientists on an unessential “expedition” aboard a chartered Russian ship.

headline: Mixed Results for WNET Membership Drive
text: WNET, the New York City public television station, this week ended its 18-month campaign to encourage new donors and the mixed results are in. The drive added 52,800 new members, above the target of 50,000. The catch, however, is that the total ended up right back where it started, at about 180,000 members over all, since the new donors replaced those who let their membership lapse.

headline: In India, Complications for Education
text: India’s Right to Education Act guarantees a free education for children ages 6 to 14. But as the law is carried out, many fear the standards will be too tough for many existing schools to stay open.

headline: The Grand Old Primate Party?
text: A Pew survey released yesterday on the public’s view of evolution shows Republicans growing more skeptical of Darwin’s findings, with only 43 percent now endorsing the theory — a drop of 11 points since 2009. Most Democrats are steady believers, with 67 percent in favor, a rise of three points. What all this means for social issue politicking in the new year remains to be seen. But the net effect is a remarkable 24-point evolution credibility gap between the two parties, more than double the 10-point gap of four years earlier.

headline: Out of the Shower, Onto the Runway
text: Yes, 2013 was the year that Adidas shower slides became an acceptable form of fashion footwear. The onetime locker-room essential was taken up by cool kids on the street, was adopted by the singer Grimes, and even invaded Fashion Week, on Alexander Wang’s niece, who proved a most stylish street-style star when she wore a Nike version to her uncle’s show. Designers quickly took note, offering a slew of interpretations for 2014. These rubber Chloés from the resort collection, now on pre-order at a whopping $840, are said to be selling out fast. For styling, take a cue from the Joseph spring show (above), where slides were shown with sporty-sleek trousers, relaxed blazers and anoraks.

headline: Lost in the Storm
text: An 11-year-old girl reflects on all that she lost when her home in Tacloban, the Philippines, was devastated by a typhoon in November.

headline: When Stranded in the Antarctic, Get Ready and Wait
text: Icebreakers have so far failed to reach the Australian research expedition ship that has been stuck in Antarctic ice for a week. So passengers and crew have no other choice but to prepare for rescue. And then wait.

headline: Tattoo Ideas? Ink Lovers Get a Buzz in Their Ear
text: There’s a joke among tattoo artists that whenever Rihanna gets a new tattoo, droves of 20-something women will soon come asking for the same.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘The Great Gatsby’
text: For Catherine Martin, fighting with her husband, the director Baz Luhrmann, is just part of their professional (and personal) process.

headline: 2013: Sports Year in Print
text: Editors for The New York Times selected 10 of their favorite front pages of the sports section from 2013.

headline: In Latvia, a New Year Also Rings In the Euro
text: FRANKFURT — The euro not only survived 2013, it thrived. And, at the stroke of midnight in Eastern Europe on Tuesday, the currency even added a new member.

headline: Chicago Killings Fall, as Officials Praise Progress
text: CHICAGO — A year after this city, the third largest in the United States, drew national notice for its staggering number of homicides, killings have slowed here.

headline: Help for a Common Seasonal Complaint
text: A parched and flaky complexion is among the most common winter complaints. Herein, three new face creams that promise to protect from the elements with extra richness.

headline: No Time to Lose for Michelle Bridges
text: The Beverly Hills offices of the Narrative Group, the public relations firm tasked with making the Australian fitness personality Michelle Bridges into a household name in the United States, are pristine white with hot-pink accents on signage, laptops and smartphones.

headline: Pop-Ups and Sales to Start 2014
text: Pop-ups

headline: A Heady Brew of Organic Moonshine Roots
text: Valerie June was a bundle of endearing eccentricities when she performed at the Highline Ballroom on Friday night. Between songs, with a mixture of candor and caginess, she offered glimpses of her past and present as leisurely shaggy dog stories, told in her rural Tennessee drawl. They were true-life tales of a country gal making her career in the wider world, savoring both the greens and corn bread her “mama” cooks and the baguettes and charcuterie of her current home, Brooklyn. She’s no bumpkin.

headline: Dressing Gatsby
text: Catherine Martin, the costume and production designer for ‘The Great Gatsby,’ says a key to keeping the costumes exciting was not to rely only on old standbys like the beaded flapper dress.

headline: Exercise Game Tracks Your Fitness All Day
text: I live a sedentary life. Or so my video game console tells me.

headline: The Law That Saved the Bald Eagle
text: In this season of birthdays and holidays, on Saturday the environmental community rightly celebrated the 40th anniversary of the passage of one of the most ambitious of the Nixon era’s landmark environmental statutes: the Endangered Species Act. The act is at once the noblest of those statutes — aimed, in President Nixon’s words, at protecting “an irreplaceable part of our natural heritage — threatened wildlife”; and also the most controversial, detested by loggers, developers and other interests for elevating the needs of nature over the needs of commerce. Approved by huge margins in both chambers (the vote on the House was an astounding 355-4), the act would stand zero chance of passage in today’s poisoned political climate.

headline: De Blasio Picks Two Koch Veterans to Help Negotiate City Union Contracts
text: Eyeing the arduous task of negotiating new contracts with each of the city’s 152 bargaining units, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio on Tuesday named two veterans of the Koch administration’s labor battles to strengthen his hand in talks with the unions, which are demanding more than $7 billion in retroactive pay to make up for years without regular raises.

headline: The Marriage of Wireless Speaker and Streaming Service
text: Two of the biggest tech trends this year were the growth of wireless speakers and streaming music services. Pure, a British electronics manufacturer, took the next logical step and combined the two.

headline: Smooth Out the Rough Edges of Your Action Video
text: If you wonder why demonstration videos from action-camera makers like the GoPro look so smooth and flawless, there’s a trick to it. Professionals have software that reduces jolts and vibration in the video after it has been shot, as well as software that enhances the look and color.

headline: Ski Helmet Use Isn’t Reducing Brain Injuries
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — The fact that Michael Schumacher was wearing a helmet when he sustained a life-threatening head injury while skiing in France on Sunday probably did not come as a surprise to experts who have charted the increasing presence of helmets on slopes and halfpipes in recent years. The fact that the helmet did not prevent Schumacher’s injury probably did not surprise them, either.

headline: A Monkey to Hold Your Phone? Go On, Grin
text: Tech designers are an imaginative bunch, but when it comes to commodity items like chargers and cable organizers, they tend toward the mundane.

headline: U.S. Judge Upholds Most New York Gun Limits
text: A federal judge ruled on Tuesday that New York’s strict new gun laws, including an expanded ban on assault weapons, were constitutional, but struck down a provision forbidding gun owners to load more than seven rounds into a magazine.

headline: Iris Apfel on the Meaning of Style
text: Earlier this year, the 92-year style maven sat down with T editor-in-chief Deborah Needleman for a candid conversation about a life that has always been in fashion.

headline: American Icon Iris Apfel on Individualism, Freedom of Expression and Great Style
text: Style is “attitude, attitude, attitude,” Iris Apfel says. “It ain’t what you do, it’s what you do with it.” The 92-year-old style icon, fashion designer, interior designer and TV entrepreneur sat down with T magazine editor-in-chief Deborah Needleman at the Museum of Arts and Design to discuss her surprise rise to fame in 2005 with “Rara Avis,” an exhibition of her clothing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the line of affordable accessories she hawks on the Home Shopping Network. In between, she shared musings on life, style and the pursuit of happiness.

headline: Video: Left Without Mother, Girl Reflects on Typhoon
text: More than 6,000 people died during Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines, many of them small children, vulnerable in the rising floodwater.

headline: Diplomat Back in Iran After Exile in the U.S.
text: TEHRAN — One of Iran’s most prominent former diplomats, an ally of President Hassan Rouhani, has returned to the country, ending his unofficial exile in the United States, state news media reported on Tuesday.

headline: Is This a Solution to Uncomfortable Airplane Seating?
text: Air travelers in first and business class are accustomed to a certain amount of choice when it comes to seating, but that kind of control may be available to economy passengers in the future.

headline: The World Welcomes 2014
text: From New York to Taipei, a look at New Year’s Eve celebrations.

headline: Spanish Explorers Land in Chelsea
text: I can’t remember what we were eating at Toro, the new tapas restaurant in far western Chelsea, when one of the people at my table looked up in wonder.

headline: Toro
text: Inside this new tapas restaurant in western Chelsea.

headline: Apple Says It Is ‘Unaware’ of N.S.A. iPhone Hack Program
text: Apple said Tuesday that it was unaware of the National Security Agency’s efforts to hack into the iPhone and has never facilitated agency efforts to install backdoors into its products.

headline: Afghans’ Plan to Release Prisoners Angers U.S.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Just months after American officials ceded control over all detention operations in Afghanistan, President Hamid Karzai’s government has quietly planned dozens of prisoner releases that American and Afghan officials said on Tuesday would include committed insurgents who had attacked Americans.

headline: Frederick Douglass Boulevard: Newly Revived
text: New York has had its share of neighborhood turnarounds in the last 20 years, but few have been as rapid and transformative as that of Frederick Douglass Boulevard, a formerly blighted corridor of often-abandoned tenements interspersed with rubble-filled lots and tire-repair shops. Sometimes called Eighth Avenue, Frederick Douglass originates at 110th Street, the longtime psychic barrier between the Upper West Side and Central Harlem, and runs to the Harlem River Drive above 155th Street, near a public housing development on the site that New York Giants baseball once called home.

headline: Gaining Red-Carpet Swagger
text: Taylor Schilling was no more than 11 when she performed in a middle-school production of “Fiddler on the Roof.”

headline: Seeking Stardom of Their Own
text: It’s hard to walk through the streets of SoHo these days without seeing an image created by Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin.

headline: An Ever-Ripening Bouquet
text: All long runs of “The Nutcracker” bring multiple castings. New York balletomanes revisit the productions at American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet to discover new facets of both experienced and novice dancers. The roles themselves change: this Sugar Plum Fairy is majesty itself, that one all twinkle; this Clara as Princess is fervent, but that one gleeful. Meanwhile, dancers change and grow as they tackle multiple roles.

headline: Shelling of Bus in Northern Syria Caps a Merciless Year
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Half obscured by smoke and dust, a man in a video brandished a milk crate loaded with what he said were fragments of human flesh: the remains of people torn apart when a shell hit a city bus in Aleppo in northern Syria on Tuesday, the latest in a series of attacks on civilian targets by the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Vitamin E Slows Decline of Some Alzheimer’s Patients in Study
text: Updated, 6:17 p.m. |

headline: Q. & A.: Ai Weiwei on Creating Art in a Cage
text: Last week we described how Ai Weiwei, the artist and dissident, places flowers in the basket of a bicycle outside his Beijing studio in protest against the Chinese government’s confiscation of his passport. Now Mr. Ai discusses in an interview what it’s like to be trapped in a country he loves, but may not leave.

headline: What You Get for... $650,000
text: MIAMI BEACH

headline: Homes for $650,000
text: This week’s properties include a condo in Miami Beach, a four-square in Idaho and a midcentury modern near Chicago.

headline: Florida Law on Drug Tests for Welfare Is Struck Down
text: KEY WEST, Fla. — A federal judge on Tuesday struck down as unconstitutional a Florida law that required welfare applicants to undergo mandatory drug testing, setting the stage for a legal battle that could affect similar efforts nationwide.

headline: Watch Live: New Year’s Eve in Times Square
text: [Video: Watch on Livestream]Ten! Nine! Eight! Seven! Six! Five! Four! Three! Two! One!

headline: Colorado Counts Down to Legalized Marijuana Use
text: Colorado residents have more to count down to on Tuesday than just the approach of a new year: on Wednesday, their state will become the first in the nation to permit the sale and use of marijuana for recreational purposes, after landmark votes in November significantly eased marijuana laws there and in Washington State.

headline: Ruling From the United States District Court for the Western District of New York
text: Read the complete ruling from the United States District Court for the Western District of New York.

headline: Where 600 College Students Live Above the Store
text: Manhattan may be a bit large to be considered a college town. But the rapid expansion of dozens of postsecondary schools across the borough in recent years has added a hard-to-ignore collegiate flavor.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photos from India, Syria, Nepal and Kashmir.

headline: Clubs Ban Photos, Putting Off Some Instagram and Selfie Fans
text: When the dance club Output opened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, earlier this year, its website proclaimed that the club was “open to anyone, but not for everyone.” Among those who quickly realized they were not wanted: shutterbugs put off by the club’s stringent no-photo policy. Enacted at Output to refocus attention, however compromised, on the music rather than selfie shots, the ban earned praise and condemnation in equal, if not simultaneous, measure.

headline: Bliss Must Be Just Around the Corner
text: Lara Vapnyar emigrated to the United States from Russia in 1994, when she was 23. She spoke little English, and has said that she turned to writing only after failing to find other work. All failures should write so well. Since 2003, she has turned out two collections of stories, “There Are Jews in My House” and “Broccoli and Other Tales of Food and Love,” and now, with “The Scent of Pine,” two novels. (Her first, “Memoirs of a Muse,” came out in 2006.)

headline: Utah Asks Highest Court to Suspend Gay Marriage
text: DENVER — Less than two weeks after a federal judge cleared the way for gay couples to wed in Utah, leaders from the socially conservative state on Tuesday asked the United States Supreme Court to halt the tide of same-sex marriages.

headline: The Rose Bowl’s Storied History
text: A look back at the pageantry in Pasadena and the grandeur of the granddaddy of them all.

headline: 100 Glorious Years of the Rose Bowl
text: When Stanford and Michigan State meet on the field on New Year’s Day, they will become a part of the Rose Bowl’s storied history, playing in the 100th Tournament of Roses game. A look back at the pageantry in Pasadena and the grandeur of the granddaddy of them all.

headline: India Comes Together to Say Farewell
text: Millions of pairs of eyes — thousands at Wankhede Stadium, many more across India and the world — homed in on the piece of bat extending from the hands of Sachin Tendulkar.

headline: For Santini Family, a Memorable Year of Hockey
text: At some point, Steve Santini’s hockey calendar will clear long enough to reflect on a year bursting with achievements.

headline: Maestro at Work: Hold That Cough
text: I have a New Year’s resolution. Will you join me? This year I’m going to perfect the art of self-asphyxiation. It’s not pretty. But neither is the act of cough-bombing a performance during its most sublime pianissimo. And as I’m convulsing in my seat, eyes watering, my sleeve pressed to my purple face, I will focus on this consoling thought: At least I won’t be singled out and reprimanded by the performer onstage.

headline: Big-Spending Knicks and Nets Excel at Impoverishing the Draft
text: I am an eternal optimist when it comes to the Knicks, but even I have to admit that the 102-101 loss to the Washington Wizards on Dec. 16 killed any optimism I had left for this season. (That it took that long shows you just how delusional I am.)

headline: A New Year’s Checklist for Travelers
text: It’s a new year, time to start a gratitude journal and hit the gym, yes, but also time to ensure you get lounge access, free miles and the best possible outcome should your flight be canceled. In 2013 travelers bemoaned being barred from planes, stranded in faraway cities and confused about what’s allowed on board. Resolve to not make the same mistakes in 2014 and prepare — not just for delays but also spur-of-the-moment getaways — with this five-step travel checklist.

headline: Korean Cash Takes Broadway Bows
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Only one Korean theater producer has a Tony Award for best musical, a Broadway honor that is coveted the world over. Yet the 2013 trophy for “Kinky Boots” sits inconspicuously here on Kim Byeong-seok’s cluttered bookcase, amid cheap memorabilia from “Cats,” “Grease” and “42nd Street.”

headline: Coming Out
text: A glance at news anchors who have recently revealed their sexual orientation.

headline: Celebrating Survival in Each Year’s Final Clock Tick
text: David Ropeik, the communications consultant and author of “How Risky is it, Really?”, posted an interesting piece at Big Think exploring common aspects of many rituals around the world celebrating the end of one year and arrival of the next.

headline: ‘In Other News’: TV Personalities’ Low-Key Coming Out
text: When Robin Roberts, an anchor of “Good Morning America,” disclosed this week that she was gay and in a long-term relationship with another woman, she did so not in a news release or on the cover of a magazine, but during a seemingly casual aside in a year-end Facebook post.

headline: A Cold, Appraising Eye, Spying Treasure
text: It doesn’t take an expert’s eye to see that Virgil Oldman, the supercilious auctioneer played by Geoffrey Rush in Giuseppe Tornatore’s creaky art thriller “The Best Offer” (“La Migliore Offerta”), is riding for a fall. And fall he does, for the unknown woman — to borrow the title of another Tornatore film — who wants to sell paintings and other treasures from the villa she inherited. That the mysterious seller insists on communicating by phone or through closed doors probably increases her appeal to a man who makes much of his living looking at things.

headline: Philadelphia Forges Plan to Rebuild From Decay
text: PHILADELPHIA — On a desolate North Philadelphia street, an isolated block of five Victorian rowhouses is surrounded by vacant lots and a commuter rail line.

headline: Richard Ravitch
text: Mr. Ravitch, 80, is a lawyer who for several years worked in his family’s business, HRH Construction, developing Waterside Plaza and Manhattan Plaza. He was the lieutenant governor of New York, under Gov. David A. Paterson, and served in numerous government-appointed positions, including the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, both of which he led as chairman.

headline: 2013 Year-End Report on the Federal Judiciary
text: In a 15-page report, Chief Justice John G. Roberts called for more funding for the judicial branch.

headline: Budget Cuts Imperil Federal Court System, Roberts Says
text: Budget cuts have imperiled the ability of the federal court system to deliver prompt justice and to protect the public, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote on Tuesday in his annual report on the state of the federal judiciary. He said the mandatory budget cuts known as sequestration had taken a disproportionate toll on the federal court system and were poised to “pose a genuine threat to public safety.”

headline: Cohen Cuts Price on N.Y. Apartment, to $98 Million
text: The hedge fund billionaire and trader Steven A. Cohen has bought and sold many things: stocks and bonds, modern art and sprawling real estate. But lately, the founder of SAC Capital Advisors appears to be doing more selling than buying.

headline: Great Expectations for 2014
text: From the theater to visual arts, opera to pop, critics for The New York Times anticipate the highlights of their fields in the coming year. Among the events that whet their appetites: the cinematic provocation of Lars von Trier, the Big Ears music festival, Hindu and Buddhist sculpture at the Met, Italian Futurism at the Guggenheim, the history of Polish Jews, a new Caryl Churchill play and a John Updike biography. GRAHAM BOWLEY

headline: ‘Intent to Deceive’
text: Forgeries and fakes have their own mystique and now their own show.

headline: So Valuable, It Could Almost Be Real
text: A personal escort — flying first class to be well rested and alert — will accompany the painting “The Head of Christ” from the moment it leaves the Boijmans Van Beuningen museum in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, until it is safely locked in the vault at Springfield Museums in Massachusetts this month, when it will be exhibited in the United States for the first time.

headline: Returns for the S.&P. 500 Are Best in 16 Years
text: This year, the S.&P. 500 had its highest total return since 1997.

headline: Stagehands, Earning Their Keep
text: To the Editor:

headline: Headbanging in Bolivia to the Flutes of Yore
text: SUCRE, Bolivia — The band members wore black. The lead singer screamed into his microphone and whipped his long, black hair around. The guitarists clawed at their instruments. The drummer pounded with fury. And then the panpipe player took his solo, and the fans packed into the mosh pit went into a frenzy.

headline: Daunting Calculus for Maine Shrimpers as Entire Season Is Lost
text: PORT CLYDE, Me. — Shrimping in the Gulf of Maine was so bad last season that Randy Cushman, a longtime fisherman, wondered if there was any point in going out at all.

headline: French Comic’s ‘Anti-System’ Salute Is Frequently Used to Mock Jewish Suffering
text: Updated, Wednesday, 12:52 p.m. | Until three days ago, when a French soccer star celebrated a goal for his club in England with a form of stiff-armed salute devised by a stand-up comic who stands accused of inciting hatred of Jews, the English-speaking world was largely unaware that the meaning of the gesture, called a quenelle, is a source of heated debate in France.

headline: District Judge Upholds Government’s Right to Search Electronics at Border
text: The government’s right to search travelers’ electronic devices at the border was upheld in a ruling released by a federal judge on Tuesday, which dismissed a lawsuit challenging this policy.

headline: The Unlobbyists
text: The changing nature of politics has reshaped lobbying, not necessarily for the worse. Top dogs in Washington’s influence industry are losing ground to a new breed.
